# 太平经合校

**The Collated *Classic of Great Peace*: Excerpts from Scroll A of the *Digest of the Classic of Great Peace* – The Primordial Origins of the Determinative Methods for the Lineage of Worthy and Sage Beings, Established by the August Thearch of the Golden Watchtower, the Posterior Sage Thearch, the Master and Preceptor, According to the Cyclical Revolutions of the Era and the Ebb and Flow of Balanced Qi**

**Question:** "The Three Sequences turn like a wheel, with departures and arrivals. The people must have a sovereign. May their surname and given name be known?"

**Answer:** "Excellent! Why do you ask this again?"

**Questioner:** "Illustrious masters are rarely encountered, and propitious moments pass swiftly. Overcome with longing, I venture to inquire. Though dull and presumptuous, my reverence runs deep."

**Answer:** "Ah! This is no presumption. Heaven impels your question to enlighten later generations. Those who awaken now discern the true and cast off the false. Were I to remain silent, I would fear Heaven’s sorrow, lest chaos go unchecked in its time. Sit at ease, and I shall expound it for you. You will then understand clearly, without doubt.

Of old, Heaven and Earth and today’s Heaven and Earth share the same beginning and end, no different. First good, then evil; in between, rise and decline, success and failure. The *yang* nine and hundred-six complete their cycle, and when six nines make a full revolution, great dissolution follows. Heaven and Earth merge in chaos, and all beings dissolve into ruin. Only those who accumulate goodness escape, becoming the *zhongmin* (Seed People) for all time.

The wisdom and understanding of the *zhongmin* still vary in degree, not yet perfectly unified. Thus, they still require a *jun* (sovereign) and *shi* (master). When the sovereign is sagely and the master enlightened, their teachings confer immortality. Through cultivation, they attain sagehood—hence the name *zhongmin*. The *zhongmin* are the kindred of sages and worthies who attain long life.

The Great Sovereign of Long Life is titled the *True and Upright Supreme Unity Wondrous Qi of Great Peace*, the *August Thearch of the Upper Clarity Golden Watchtower*, the *Posterior Sage Ninefold Mystery Thearch*. His surname is Li. He is the descendant of the *Highest Supreme*, the scion of the *Jade Thearch’s* Void and Nothingness. During the era of the *Mysterious Origin Thearch*, in the fifteenth year of the *Great August* reign, the year *bingzi* (3rd Celestial Stem, 1st Earthly Branch) saw the first stirrings of his *qi*. In the first year of the *August Peace* reign, *jiashen* (21st Celestial Stem, 9th Earthly Branch), he took form. In the seventh year of the *Upper Harmony* reign, *gengyin* (27th Celestial Stem, 3rd Earthly Branch), on the third day of the ninth month, the day *jiazi* (1st Celestial Stem, 1st Earthly Branch) at the hour *mao* (5th Earthly Branch, 5–7 a.m.), when *xing* (punishment) and *de* (virtue) mutually restrained one another, at the precise moment of conjunction, he was born in the *Northern Mystery Jade Kingdom*, the *Heavenly Ridge Spirit Realm*, within the *Human-Bird Pavilion* on *Mount Penglai*, amidst the *Li Valley*. His mother was the *Mysterious Void Mother of the Upper Mystery*, a chamber of the *Nine Mysteries*, dwelling in the valley’s shade.

At the onset of the *Mysterious Void Mother’s* conception, she dreamed of dark clouds and sun and moon entwining her form, while the lightning of the Six *Qi* stirred her spirit. In profound resonance with the *Yang* Dao, she conceived the Perfected One. On the dawn of his birth, three suns rose in the east. After his nurturing, nine dragons spat forth divine water. Thus, his clan took its name from the *Spirit Valley*, and his given name from the radiance of the luminaries.

At the age of three, his body embodied the Dao and congealed the true, his words blossoming like golden flowers. At five, he often gazed at the sun, rejoicing in its dawn, and faced the moon, sighing at its end. Above, he observed the brilliance of *yang* *qi*; below, he beheld the waning and decay of the *yin* path. Thereupon, he gathered his *hun* and harmonized his *po*, guarded the precious spirit of the womb, recorded his essence, replenished his blood, and fortified his fluids to solidify his sinews.

At seven, he learned to swallow light and ingest rosy clouds, chewing the roots of the sun. At fourteen (two sevens), he possessed a golden countenance and jade visage, abandoning worldly attachments and severing mundane passions. He embraced transformation to save the world, his essence resonating with the *Great Simplicity*. He received the teachings of the *Three Origins*, studied the *Three Caverns*, and mastered the *Nine Methods*.

At twenty-one (three sevens), he dwelled in solitude, tempering his sharpness. At twenty-eight (four sevens), he harmonized with the world, blending his light. At thirty-five (five sevens), he disseminated the *Mysterious Ford*, his merit and virtue spreading far and wide. At forty-two (six sevens), he received the scriptures and was named *Posterior Sage Thearch*. This was no different from those who had attained the Dao and become Thearchs in former heavens. His investiture was recorded for the present age—hence the title *Posterior Sage*. The Dao of the Former Sage and the Posterior Sage is one and the same.

He ascended to the halls of *Upper Clarity*, wandered the palaces of the *Great Ultimate*, and governed the ten directions of Heaven. He was enfeoffed to oversee the billions upon billions of beings, inspecting all the celestial rivers and seas, the earth’s sources and mountain forests. None failed to look up in obedience. He presided over the nine layers and ten tiers—hence the title *Ninefold Mystery*.

At seventy, he determined the boundless span of his life, adapting to the fitting times of concealment and manifestation. He edited the arts of deathlessness and composed the methods of long life. Treasuring the scriptures, talismans, and diagrams, the wondrous methods of the Three Antiquities, he sealed them in jade caskets, attended by divine officials. Their transmission followed strict protocols, their practice and concealment governed by signs. He established canons and bestowed them upon the *zhongmin*. Those who cannot practice them are not *zhongmin*.

Now, as Heaven and Earth unfold, the pure wind recedes into the distance. The *August Peace* *qi* withdraws, and calamities surge unchecked. Since the era of the *Upper August*, through the Three and Five Dynasties, warfare, epidemics, floods, and fires have arisen in relentless succession. All stem from the billions of beings whose hearts are perverse and forms deceitful, who rupture the Five Virtues and contend with the Six Passions, indulging in violence and aggression, mutually encroaching upon one another. Noble and base, elder and younger, exalted and humble—all are thrown into chaos and separation.

Thus, the Two Modes lose their order, the Seven Luminaries deviate from their courses, the Three Powers undergo strange transformations, and omens and portents proliferate. Spirits and ghosts inflict harm, beings and creatures wither and perish. Disasters and misfortunes follow one upon another. Yet, none awaken or repent. Myriad poisons rage unchecked, beyond counting.

There are Four Great Evils: war, disease, flood, and fire. When the *yang* nine completes a cycle, and solitary *yin* flourishes, waters overflow. When the hundred-six completes a revolution, and *yang* prevails, fires erupt. Before the time of Yao, there is no need to recount further. From the Tang onward, I shall briefly set forth the present age."

Let all earnestly remember and swiftly prepare defenses. After the floods of Yao came the fires of Tang, and thereafter, small-scale floods and fires spread across the land—calamities summoned by grave sins, yet not the great *yang* nine or great hundred-six cycles. Within these great nine-six cycles, there must be great and small *jia-shen* years. The *jia-shen* marks the time when ghosts confront humanity.

Disasters vary in severity, as blessings and sins differ in weight. Since years and lands differ, their shifts are not uniform. For those of middling virtue, the appointed time arrives as foretold. For those above or below the mean, they may rise or fall, advance or retreat, ascend or descend without fixed course. Evil hastens ruin; goodness prolongs life. Without diligent progress, the Dao cannot be attained. One may only extend the appointed time in proportion to the merit accrued.

Thus, the hundred-six and *yang* nine cycles may arrive early or late, their great calendric constants adjusted by depth of transgression. Counting from the *ding-hai* year of the Tang era, forty-six years pass. Within this span, the *jia-shen* year is a lesser *jia-shen*, bringing war, disease, and fire in alternating disasters—yet no great flood. Minor floods surge widely, their severity varying by year and land.

Fifty-five years later, another *ding-hai* arrives. Within its span falls another *jia-shen* year, this a great *jia-shen* when all three disasters strike together, compounded by a great flood’s sweeping force. Whenever great or small *jia-shen* years come, the wicked are eradicated, and the good are delivered. The good become the *seed people*; the wicked become the *chaos*.

Before long, myriad omens arise in tumult. Epidemics and poisons surge from above; war and fire rage below. Floodwaters burst forth from no fixed direction, and the wicked perish in turn. For fifteen years—even up to thirty—annual disasters intensify, and the worthy and sagely go into hiding. The Great Dao and divine beings dispatch perfected immortals and superior adepts to traverse the land, guiding with patient instruction. They exhort the high and urge on the low. Those who follow become the *seed people*; those who refuse are submerged, becoming *chaos*. The wicked are utterly swept away. Of the *seed people*, the most virtuous—one in ten—remain. Of the middling and lesser good, half are destroyed by Heaven, while the surviving half flourish and grow day by day. Then, a sagely ruler and enlightened master, with great ministers, descend and manifest.

After the lesser *jia-shen* and before the *ren-shen*, the ruler of the lesser *jia-shen* is sagely and wise, stern yet benevolent, causing no harm or disorder. He extends years and prolongs life, and through devoted study, one may attain immortality. Yet he cannot deeply study the *Scriptures of Great Peace* nor long practice the affairs of Great Peace. The names of those who briefly achieve Great Peace cannot be fixed.

Those who practice it have their names inscribed in the Azure Register by the Director of Destinies; those who do not are recorded in the Black Writ. The Black Writ means death; the Azure Register means life. The ledgers of life and death reside in the Heavenly Hall of Light. The Dao of Heaven is impartial, favoring only the good. Those who cultivate Great Peace bring it to fruition. Achieving Lesser Great Peace, they align their virtue with the Lord of Great Peace.

The Lord of Great Peace, whose name is fixed, is Lord Li. In the *ren-chen* year, on the sixth day of the third month, he will manifest openly, riding the Three Pure Radiant Chariot, followed by ten thousand flying carriages and dragons. He will elevate the good as *seed people* and scholars as immortal officials. He will establish examinations and statutes, rewarding goodness and suppressing evil, cutting off the roots of sin, and urging those who cultivate blessed deeds to progress without slack. Through diligence, they will attain divine perfection and align their virtue with the Emperor. Those who slacken and fall into evil will have their names daily recorded in the ledgers of wickedness, destined to become *chaos*.

Scholars and lofty scholars, wise and enlightened, thoroughly clear and without doubt, diligently refine their progress, preserving and practicing the Emperor’s teachings, ever mindful of the great divine Lords’ assistance—none dare forget.

The sagely Lord and his luminous aides, the numinous officials, protect the people, who thereby attain deathlessness and remain forever as *seed people*. Ascending as immortal officials of the perfected, they ultimately attain the rank of *Later Sage*. The *Later Sage* Lord Li’s Grand Preceptor bears the surname Peng. He studied the Dao before Lord Li and held the position of Left Perfected of the Grand Tenuity. During the era of the Human Sovereign, he safeguarded the Dao Lord of the Emperor and was regularly commanded to confer investiture upon the multitudes, serving as Grand Preceptor to Lord Li. His governance resides in the Northern Pond Palace of the Grand Tenuity, upon the Numinous Upper Radiance Terrace. Every two thousand five hundred years, he transforms his name, traversing the Great Void and circling the Eight Obscurities—ascending to the Utmost Above, descending to the Utmost Below. Few among the perfected officials have ever beheld his radiant countenance.

The *Later Sage* Lord Li’s Chief Minister is the Azure Lad of the Fangzhu Palace.
The *Later Sage* Lord Li’s Chief Guardian is the Primordial Lord of the Southern Culmen of the Great Cinnabar Palace.
The *Later Sage* Lord Li’s Chief Instructor is the Grand Simplicity Perfected of the White Mountain Palace.
The *Later Sage* Lord Li’s Chief Steward is the Governor of the Perfected of the Western Citadel Palace.

The five persons above: one preceptor and four aides.

The aides are fathers, supporters. They are revered as fathers, and through their support, the Way is enacted—thus they are collectively called *aides*. When distinguished by position: left aide and right assistant, front advisor and rear attendant.

The *attendant* voices proposals and initiates affairs, fills omissions and completes matters, enacts judgments and proclaims decrees—this is the *steward*. The *advisor* ponders what is not yet grasped, illuminates and brings to clarity—this is the *instructor*. The *assistant* settles uncertainties and resolves doubts—this is the *guardian*. The one who *supports the lord and follows the preceptor*, encompassing all to enter the Dao—this is the *chief minister*.

Through the four and five phases of divination, they together deliberate right and wrong, aiding and magnifying the true transformation—thus they are called *aides to the preceptor*. In moments of leisure, when facing doubts ahead, one inquires of the *instructor*. When looking back and fearing omissions, one inquires of the *attendant*. When something on the right remains obscure, one inquires of the *assistant*. When something on the left is not yet clear, one inquires of the *aide*. Consulting the four aides—guardian, instructor, steward, and minister—success depends upon the preceptor; none may be lacking. The sagely emperor set this model for later generations to follow.

Inwardly, there is the *guardian*, who attends to affairs—this pertains to the right, the treasure of quiescent truth. Outwardly, there is the *preceptor*, who attends to affairs—this pertains to the left, where movement returns to stillness. This is most difficult, and so the discussion of aides and ministers has centered on the preceptor.

Ahead, there is the *instructor*, who expounds teachings and discusses principles. Behind, there is the *steward*, who decides and judges right and wrong. Beyond these, there are three hundred sixty-one officials—ducal ministers, bureau chiefs, transcendents, sagely ranks, and great officers—with thirty-six thousand under their command, leading thirty-six myriad, while the people number ten, a hundred, a thousand, ten thousand, and myriadfold more.

Twenty-four perfected persons are ever dispatched to secretly instruct those of sincere heart, all subordinate to the Chief Minister of the Fangzhu Palace. This cannot be fully recounted; one must carefully preserve the great and personally investigate the small.

"Excellent! Today my doubts have been questioned, and I have heard the command anew."

The disciple asked: "What constant practices did Lord Li undertake to attain this rank of High Perfected? May I hear of the studies of the Grand Preceptor and the Four Assistants?"

"Excellent! You are one of the deluded—lost in disbelief of the Dao, your learning unsteady, advancing and retreating without constancy, sinking into lowliness and suffering—thus you earnestly inquire. Now I shall tell you.

From time without beginning, deeds have accumulated over ages—every good and every evil cannot be fully recounted, and speaking of them brings no benefit. I shall speak only of recent practices that led to attaining nobility through the numinous scriptures and purple texts, which are essential.

It begins with the Eastern Flower Jade Guardian, the High Dawn Master, the Azure Lad Great Lord. The Great Lord purified himself in the Cold Numinous Elixir Hall, within the Yellow Chamber, for three years, then ascended to the Golden Portals of Supreme Purity. There, the Four Celestial Emperors reside, with the Grand Lord of the Peaceful Dao at their side.

He dwells in the Jade Tower of the Great Void, in the Cavern-Real Palace, the Level Jade Chamber, within the Golden Flower. Five myriad attendant perfected maidens surround him. Poisonous dragons and lightning tigers, simian sentinels of the heavens, array themselves in venomous postures, guarding the gates and thresholds. Serpents a thousand fathoms long patrol the walls. Flying dragons and darting sparrows, leviathan roc and strange birds—clashing beaks and brandishing talons—fill the vast courtyard."

The celestial majesty blazes with radiance, its streaming light illuminating the eight directions. The winds stir the dark banners, whirling the feathered canopies in dance. Jade trees ring with resonant tones, their gem-like branches murmuring of their own accord. A chorus of divine songs arises, phoenixes sing in profound harmony. Divine consorts join their voices in unison, qilins dance and simurghs stride forth. The celestial harmony resounds in eightfold echoes, the ninefold concord unites in a hundredfold assembly.

The Azure Lad prostrates himself and advances, entreating to receive the *Numinous Writ of the Purple Text* and the twenty-four oral transmissions and esoteric instructions contained within the scriptures:

1. The True Record of Attentiveness—profoundly memorized in darkness;
2. The Prohibitions of Immortals—carefully observed without forgetfulness;
3. Gathering the flying root and swallowing the essence of the sun;
4. Ingesting the *Luminous Numinous Talisman*;
5. Ingesting the radiance of the moon;
6. Ingesting the *Yin-Generated Talisman*;
7. Restraining the three *hun*;
8. Controlling the seven *po*;
9. Wearing the *August Image Talisman*;
10. Ingesting the *Flowering Elixir*;
11. Ingesting the *Yellow Water*;
12. Ingesting the *Returning Water*;
13. Consuming *Ringed Steel*;
14. Consuming *Phoenix Brain*;
15. Consuming *Pine Pears*;
16. Consuming *Plum Dates*;
17. Ingesting *Water Decoction*;
18. Stabilizing *White Silver and Purple Gold*;
19. Ingesting *Cloud Fat*;
20. Crafting *White Silver and Purple Gold*;
21. Crafting *Stabilizing Talismans*;
22. Consuming *Bamboo Shoots*;
23. Consuming *Swan Jerky*;
24. Wearing the *Five Spirit Talismans*.

Mastering these twenty-four practices, one’s transformations become boundless, transcending beyond the Three Realms and roaming freely within the Six Directions. Calamities and harm cannot injure them; demons and evil dare not oppose them. All submit of their own accord, and one’s rank attains the ultimate in the Daoist lineage, bestowing grace upon all beings, both hidden and manifest, who rely upon it.

Those who do not believe, do not follow, do not know, or do not perceive choose darkness for themselves, forever estranged from the Dao. They wallow in suffering, poison, and affliction, drowned in the turbid mire of vexation. Yet the great compassion remains, though nothing can be done for them.

Alas! Noble scholars of aspiration, reflect early—reflect early! Do not betray these words of today.

The disciple said: "Excellent! Excellent! Today my doubts are resolved, and I have heard your command anew."

[Preserved] In *First Scroll of Jia Section* it states: "Scholars who study and apply this scripture will trace its roots to their source. The root and its fundamental lineage take the Three Ones as their master."

*Daoist Meaning Compendium*, Scroll 2, *Seven Sections of Meaning*, and *Cloudy Satchel Seven Signs*, Scroll 64, *Auxiliary Excerpts*, both cite this.

[Preserved] *First Scroll of Jia Section* further states: "Those who recite my scripture will find calamities and harm do not arise. This is the very text by which the ancient sages and worthies discerned success and failure." It also says: "Scriptures are of three ranks: first, the *Scriptures of the Divine Dao*; second, the *Verified Records of Affairs*; third, the *Superficial Ornamental Records*.

The *Scriptures of the Divine Dao* are those that abide in undivided essence, firmly guard the root, harmonize with yin and yang, and share the same gate as the spirits. The *Verified Records of Affairs* verify the similarities and differences of events, ensuring no errors or doubts remain. The *Superficial Ornamental Records* have strayed far from the root, are disordered, and cannot be relied upon constantly; they may be noted from time to time, hence their name."

It further states: "To pacify great chaos, merit must be lofty and virtue upright—thus it is called *Great Peace*. If this Dharma spreads and prevails, it is the era of Great Peace. Therefore, this scripture says: it manifests in response to conditions and conceals itself once the matter is complete."

It also says: "Sagely rulers govern with reverence for these texts; ordinary lords on the throne treat this canon with neglect."

*Cloudy Satchel Seven Signs*, Scroll 64, *Auxiliary Excerpts*, cites this. The three ranks of scriptures are also found in *Excerpts from the Scripture of Great Peace, Gui Section*. According to the Dunhuang catalog, it should belong to *Jia Section*.

[Preserved] *Scroll Eight of the Great Peace Section*, *Laozi’s Transmission of Scriptures, Precepts, Rituals, and Oral Instructions*, states: "Laozi is the great sage who attained the Dao, the teacher revered by both the hidden and the manifest. When conditions call, he transforms and adapts to all directions; when his work is complete, he withdraws and abides in concealment. Where he abides is not a fixed abode. The abode of non-abiding abides in the *Ultimate*. The ultimate of the Ultimate is the *Supreme Mystery*. The *Supreme Mystery* is the capital where the Supreme Ancestral Ultimate resides. Laozi dwells here, his transformations responding to the ten directions. The marvels of his teachings extend to the farthest reaches, beyond all description.

In a recent manifestation, he appeared at the beginning of the Zhou dynasty, descending to blend his light with the world. Born among the common people, he demonstrated gestation and birth to show that the truth can be learned. Though he lived in lowly circumstances, he repeatedly attained the Dao. He roamed the Six Voids and taught the Three Realms, mastering both the Dharma beyond the world and the Dharma within it, as well as all practices of action and inaction.

During the time of King Wen, he served as the Keeper of Archives. Some say he lived in the world for over two hundred years. In the forty-third year of King Ping’s reign, the year *gui-chou* (601 BCE), on the twenty-eighth day of the twelfth month, he expounded the *Five Thousand Character Scripture* to Guanling Yin Xi."

*Pearl Satchel of the Three Caverns*, Scroll 9, *Laozi as the Emperor’s Teacher*, cites this.

[Note: This account of Laozi’s deeds may derive from *Scroll Eight of the Scripture of Great Peace*. However, *Cloudy Satchel Seven Signs*, Scroll 40, *Exhortations*, cites *Scroll Eight of the Supreme Mystery Section*, *Lao Jun’s Transmission of Scriptures, Precepts, Rituals, and Oral Instructions*, with identical scroll numbers and titles. Thus, *Great Peace* and *Supreme Mystery* must contain an error—this is provisionally preserved for further investigation.]

*Collated and Annotated Scripture of Great Peace*, Scrolls 18–34, *Yi Section* (unbound)
*Excerpts from the Scripture of Great Peace, Yi Section*

To harmonize yin and yang and follow the Dao’s method is to return to youth and avoid aging. When the Great Dao is about to return, all people’s years will show signs of verification. Close your eyes and look inward—pure white radiance will appear. If it is early morning, your body should rest calmly upon the mat. If you sit in warmth and steam, at this time your sinews and bones should not move, nor should your mouth speak. Every stretch and bend brings increasing comfort; the heart rejoices, suffused with a sense of blending and moisture. The nose breathes freely, and sweetness arises in the mouth—these are the signs.

Thus, those who follow Heaven and Earth enjoy enduring governance. Those who follow the four seasons see their kingship flourish day by day. The Dao has no arcane phrases—its function lies in the alternation of yin and yang. Those who attain its governance prosper; those who lose it fall into chaos. Those who attain its governance become spiritually luminous; those who lose it find the Dao unworkable. Ponder this meaning deeply, and you will merge with the Dao.

**Method for Aligning the Body and Rectifying the Spirit**
When Heaven employs the Dao to generate humans, each person receives one method and one body, with seven interwoven yin and yang. Only when half yin and half yang combine can they achieve completion. Thus, the upper part models itself on yang, the lower on yin; the left follows yang, the right follows yin. Yang delights in life, yin delights in killing. Yang embodies the Dao, yin embodies punishment. Yang embodies goodness, and yang spirits assist it; yin embodies evil, and yin spirits assist it. Accumulating goodness without cease, the Dao’s blessings arise, bringing daily fortune.

Yang resides in the head, yin in the feet. Thus, rulers value virtue and power while employing punishment below—this is the model to follow. Petty persons invert this, placing punishment above and virtue below, yet they too follow this model. Therefore, humans are the root and handle of the Dao, the overseers of spirits. One must understand this intent and skillfully nurture oneself to attain longevity. Failing to nurture the body properly incurs the blame of all spirits. If spirits abandon a person, how can the body fare well?

In doing good, one must not deviate from the guiding cord nor deceive oneself. Whether doing good or evil, the spirits know it of themselves—not other spirits, but the spirits within one’s own body. Words emerge from the heart and belly, yet others come to know them—this is the spirits within the body informing them. Thus, calming the spirit and settling the body is the foundation of governance and the sign of longevity. The practice of non-action arises from this. First cultivate the self to discern fortune and misfortune.

Therefore, the wise and enlightened focus on cultivating the self rather than others. By deeply pondering the Dao’s intent, they achieve Great Peace. The noble person uses this to flourish; the petty person employs it to collapse.

**Method for Cultivating Oneness to Repel Evil**
When Heaven and Earth first opened, the root was prized—it is the origin of qi. To bring about Great Peace, one must contemplate the root. Failing to reflect on the root is called great vexation; undertakings will not succeed, and disasters will converge. This is not human fault but the loss of the root’s foundation. Seeking the branches while abandoning the root brings untreatable calamity—thus, one must ponder this deeply.

The One is the root of the Dao, the beginning of qi, the tether of life, and the master of all hearts. To know its reality, recognize that it resides in the center as the root, the palace of life. Therefore, one must deeply understand it and return to benevolence and worthiness to put it into practice.

The human root lies within, while branches and leaves are external. Command the One to return all externals inward, urgently tending to the internal. Pursue the distant and govern the near. Those who guard the One receive the assistance of heavenly spirits. Those who guard two receive the assistance of earthly spirits. Those who guard three receive the assistance of human ghosts. Those who guard four or five receive the protection of things.

Thus, guarding the One extends life; guarding two sets a date with misfortune. Guarding three brings chaotic governance; guarding four or five invites daily disaster. Deeply pondering this meaning is called knowing the Dao.

Therefore, the One of the head is the crown. The One of the seven regulators is the eye. The One of the abdomen is the navel. The One of the vessels is qi. The One of the five viscera is the heart. The One of the four limbs is the palms and soles. The One of the bones is the spine. The One of the flesh is the intestines and stomach. By firmly guarding it and understanding the Dao’s intent, those who attain the Dao become benevolent, while those who lose it become greedy.

**Method for Using Music to Repel Disaster**
Use music to govern the body, preserve form, follow thoughts, and focus the mind to repel disaster. What is the purpose of delighting in the Dao? Joy harmonizes yin and yang. In all matters, act in silence, enabling people to grasp the Dao’s root.

When primordial qi delights, great prosperity arises. When nature delights, things grow strong. When Heaven delights, the Three Luminaries shine. When Earth delights, it achieves constancy. When the Five Phases delight, they do not harm one another. When the four seasons delight, what they generate flourishes. When rulers delight, the world knows no illness. When crawling creatures delight, they do not harm one another. When the myriad things delight, they abide in constancy. When people delight, they do not fret or change their hearts. When ghosts and spirits delight, they benefit the emperor.

Thus, music is formed from the essence of Heaven and Earth’s good qi, summoning divine luminosity. Stillness generates radiance, and radiance is the means to await the spirits. By communicating with the divine luminosity and having the Dao as a neighbor, one attains long life and enduring existence.

Those who seek the Dao often suffer, unable to return their thoughts to the mind. Now, by transforming customs and redirecting intentions, who can contend with them?

Does the music of Great Peace emerge from the palace to expel evil? It firmly purifies the state, secures the body’s entry into the Dao, repels barbarians, and summons auspicious responses from spirits. Celestial images return, and malevolent spirits depart.

The human spirit is born within but wanders outside. If it does not return in time, it harms the body. By recalling it, one can govern oneself without failure. How to recall it? Ensure an empty room with no one nearby. Draw an image matching the viscus’s color, corresponding to the four seasons’ qi, and hang it in the window’s light while contemplating it.

Above is the image of the viscera; below are the ten villages. When lying down, focus on the nearby hanging image and contemplate it without cease. The spirits of the five viscera can report the twenty-four seasonal qi, and the spirits of the Five Phases will come to the rescue. All illnesses will be cured.

Men should contemplate male images, women should contemplate female images, all measured by a standard of one *chi*, adapting with the turning of the four seasons. In spring, ten azure lads; in summer, ten crimson lads; in autumn, ten white lads; in winter, ten black lads; and in the four seasons’ transitions, twelve yellow lads. The twenty-five spirit-persons and perfected ones together embody the Dao and virtue. When the proper method is practiced, yang transforms into yin, and yin transforms into yang; when yin and yang unite, the Dao may be enacted.

Heaven requires earth to bring forth life, and earth requires heaven to bring things to completion. Spring and summer require autumn and winter; day requires night; the ruler requires ministers to achieve governance. Ministers require the ruler to carry out their duties. Thus, *jia* requires *yi*, and *zi* requires *chou*—all complete one another. To enact the Dao and govern rightly is to follow heaven’s course, which does not conform to human desires; to act otherwise is to go against the heavenly Dao. It is like the Eastern Sea, lying low and fond of water, to which all rivers return. By attaining its Dao, leviathans emerge from its depths, and luminous moon-pearls are born—such is the efficacy of obtaining the Dao. When Daoists gather, methods for extending years and wondrous formulas emerge, and great auspicious responses arise. When the worthy gather, governance becomes peaceful; when scholars gather, minor disorders are resolved; when the five weapons gather, great defeat ensues.

The ruler should uphold the Dao, and ministers should uphold virtue. Dao and virtue are like the outer and inner layers of a garment. If heaven were not vast, it could not contain the myriad things. All things are half good and half bad; one must endure both. The ruler models this, as does the empress in the rear palace. These two exemplify the way of compassionate parents. Thus, when parents raise children, they love the good and pity the bad, and only then can the household be harmonious.

The sun symbolizes the ruler, the moon the great ministers, and the stars the hundred officials. When the worthy shine together, the myriad things live in harmony. Thus, the clear belongs to heaven, the turbid to earth, and harmony to humanity.

**Method for Harmonizing Spirit-Souls**
I wish to make the ten thousand spirits of the world harmonious and kind, so they no longer recklessly harm people. Heaven and earth will rejoice for long, all spirits will be pleased, and people will suffer nothing. When the emperor obtains heaven’s power, all undertakings are blessed—how could this be interrupted?

**Arising**
Thus, when the sage abides in the Dao and stillness, at dawn they eat, and all spirits call out and speak to them, just as people today call to guests.

**Ceasing**
The hundred spirits say they are heaven’s officials and envoys; the host of essences are earth’s officials and envoys; and the hundred ghosts are envoys of harmony. These three are the envoys of yin, yang, and harmony. They assist heaven and earth in governance and together bring benefit to the emperor.

**Method of Illuminating Unity**
**Arising**
The method of illuminating unity is the root of long life. It is the origin of the ten thousand spirits and the gateway to radiant light. When guarding unity with clarity, it is like fire at its inception—guard it urgently and do not lose it. At first it is truly red, in the end truly white, and after a long time truly azure. Profound clarity reaches the farthest extremes, then returns to govern unity, leaving nothing within unclear. All illnesses depart; guarding it without slack is the art of ten thousand years.

The method of illuminating unity possesses the brilliance of the rising sun and the clarity of midday.

**Ceasing**
This is the foremost good for attaining heaven’s longevity. Abide in tranquility and seclusion, and you will never err for ten thousand generations.

The method of guarding unity determines the excellence or inferiority of practicing the Dao. What is the Dao? It is the origin of the myriad things, yet it cannot be named. Within the six directions, nothing can transform without the Dao. Primordial qi enacts the Dao to generate the myriad things; great and small in heaven and earth are all born through the Dao. Thus, primordial qi is formless and governs the formed. To extend primordial qi, one must rely on the Dao to be born. The natural is the natural of the myriad things. Without practicing the Dao, one cannot envelop heaven and earth, nor can each attain its proper place, nor can the high be made unaware of danger.

Heaven practices the Dao day and night without rest, swifter than wind and rain, and still fears losing the Dao’s intent—how much more so for kings? The three luminaries practice the Dao without rest, thus they are fixed in the heavens and illuminate the eight directions. If they lose the Dao, their light vanishes. The king, the hundred officials, the myriad things, and all living beings dwell together, and the five stars observe their transgressions. When the king restores virtue, the virtue-star comes to guard him. When he acts with martiality, the martial-star comes to guard him. When he acts with gentleness, the gentle-star comes to guard him. When he acts with strength, the strong-star comes to guard him. When he acts with trustworthiness, the trustworthy-star comes to guard him. Though distant, their responses are near. Heaven and humanity are one—how could one not be cautious?

**Methods of Practicing the Dao with Excellence or Inferiority**
In spring, the king should be warm; in summer, hot; in autumn, cool; and in winter, cold—this is the king’s virtue. The king’s qi connects with the emperor’s qi; ministerial qi responds to the chief ministers; subtle qi responds to petty officials; resting qi aligns with the rear palace; declining qi responds to the people; and the qi of condemned prisoners responds to those in prison. They resonate from afar by kind.

If the Dao’s kingly qi does not arrive, the king’s grace cannot be bestowed. The ancient sage-kings pondered the Dao through this, thus discerning the signs of success and failure and examining their intent. When the king practices the Dao, heaven and earth rejoice; when he loses the Dao, heaven and earth send forth calamities and anomalies.

When the king stills his thoughts on the Dao and virtue, practices the Dao to secure his person, and seeks long life for self-cultivation, harmonizing the way of husband and wife so that yin and yang both attain their proper place, heaven and earth are at peace. Though heaven and the emperor are separated by ten thousand myriad *li*, they respond to the Dao—is this not wondrous? This is called *The Book of Divine Secrets*.

Primordial qi is natural and together forms the nature of heaven and earth. When the six directions and eight quarters are joyful, good responses arise; when they are not joyful, evil responses arise. Their forms resemble reflections, and their sounds harmonize with echoes.

The three qi—Great Yin, Great Yang, and Harmony—together govern, mutually influencing one another. Humanity is the pivot, and thus one must deeply understand this.

All know to value their lives and nurture their bodies, thus they know to honor their superiors and cherish their subordinates, delighting in life and abhorring death. When the three qi—Great Yin, Great Yang, and Harmony—are joyful, they unite as Supreme Harmony, and responses emerge in unison.

Yet when the worthy gather, they think only of the Way of longevity, thereby securing their ruler and becoming the state’s treasured vessel. To cultivate one’s nature is to cultivate one’s people.

Heaven bestows no private favor; its blessings are steadfast. The divine shows no partiality; the good are its reflection. Within a single person, one may become worthy, become divine, or become base—why is this? It is error, for the numinous is revealed. Thus the Way of Guarding the One is to nurture one’s nature, and this lies in learning.

Among the many, those who receive auspicious responses are trustworthy; those who receive none have erred in conduct. Through divination, right and wrong may be discerned. As the scale discerns weight, so human sentiment is weighed. Heaven’s illumination of man differs not from a mirror. Scrutinize this meaning, align your aspirations with heaven, and unite with the true spirits—how could misfortune arise?

In accomplishing affairs, not a fraction is lost, so as to attain the harmonious intent of heaven and earth. When heaven and earth are balanced, the myriad things are at peace; when the sovereign governs justly, the myriad people are well-ordered.

If one acts purely in yang, the earth will not willingly bring all to fruition; if purely in yin, heaven will not willingly bring all to life. Only when the Three Powers converge, when yin and yang are in accord, does harmony reside within.

The sages of antiquity who brought about Great Peace all sought the harmonious heart of heaven and earth. If one qi is obstructed, a hundred affairs go awry.

**Harmonizing the Three Qi to Establish the Imperial Law**
To penetrate the harmonious discourse of heaven and earth, to follow the great enterprise, to wander in harmony with the Three Qi—this is how the ruler remains without trouble, how the worthy all emerge to assist and exalt the emperor, bringing great joy to heaven.

The Perfected One asked the Divine One: *"I wish for the emperor to swiftly attain Great Peace—may I hear how?"*

The Divine One replied: *"〈Begin〉 Simply follow heaven and earth in full, not losing a fraction, and Great Peace will swiftly arrive, with auspicious responses arising together. Primordial qi has three names: Great Yang, Great Yin, and Harmony. Forms have three names: heaven, earth, and humanity. Heaven has three names: sun, moon, and stars, with the North Star as its center. Earth has three names: mountains, rivers, and level land. Humanity has three names: father, mother, and child. Governance has three names: ruler, minister, and people—all desiring Great Peace. These three must always be held close as heart and mind, not losing a fraction, sharing a single concern, uniting as one household. Then Great Peace will swiftly arrive, and longevity will be without doubt. 〈End〉*

Thus the male resembles heaven, and his thoughts turn to the female—this is the clear effect of heaven’s design. The minister resembles earth, ever desiring to ascend and unite in heart with heaven. Thus the myriad things, born from the earth, rise upward without cease, and clouds and qi fill the sky to form rain. So too the loyal minister’s concern is ever above, tirelessly mindful of his ruler—this is the clear effect of earth’s design.

The people embody the discourse of Harmony, for Harmony is what regulates the myriad things. Harmony is the infant, the child born of father and mother, whose life belongs to the father, whose lineage is above, yet who is nurtured by the mother. Thus in distress, they long for the ruler and father. These three mirror the images of husband and wife, father and child.

They should communicate freely, unite their strength, and share their concerns, so that the Three Qi merge into Supreme Harmony. From Supreme Harmony arises the qi of Great Peace. If these three qi are severed, even one obstruction prevents their flow, Supreme Harmony does not arrive, and Great Peace does not emerge.

Yin and yang depend on Harmony. When the qi of Harmony is attained, the myriad things flourish, the people are harmonious, and the king’s governance brings Great Peace.

The ruler is heaven; if his grace does not descend, things have no means to grow, and people cannot attain longevity. If the ruler’s heart is not open, heaven’s heart cannot reach below, and wife and child do not receive the father’s decree—this is a household in rebellion.

If the minister’s qi cannot ascend, earth’s qi cannot be fulfilled—how then can loyal ministers assist the enlightened king in governance? This wounds the heart of earth, leaving widows in their chambers, ever grieving and sorrowful, while worthy ministers have no means to advance.

If the people’s qi does not ascend, how can the qi of Harmony arise? Harmony must harmonize the ruler’s governance, regulating the myriad things so each attains its proper place. Now, if the Three Qi do not interact well, how can Great Peace be achieved?"

**The Law of the Peaceful and Joyous King**

The ruler must transform the myriad things through virtue and power, ensuring each attains its proper place. If one cannot transform and nurture the myriad things, one cannot be called a ruler. This is like a husband and wife who together bear a child and are thus called parents. Even as a household’s image, if they cannot produce a child, how can they be called parents? Therefore, those who cannot transform and give life to the myriad things cannot be called the parents of the people.

Thus, fire can transform the Four Elements and itself becomes the fifth, and so it is called the ruler’s image. Water’s nature is harmonious and concentrated, but when it meets fire, it scatters and turns to ash. Metal’s nature is hard and unyielding, but when it meets fire, it softens. Earth’s nature is greatly yielding, but when it meets fire, it hardens into tiles. Water’s nature is cold, but when it meets fire, it warms. Fire itself aligns with the Five Phases and can transform endlessly; its nature is active and ascends. Yin submits to yang, ministers submit to the ruler, and fire can illuminate and discern clearly, distinguishing right from wrong—thus it is called the ruler, while the others cannot.

Earth does not transform immediately but does so over time, and so it is called the Queen of Earth. The other three assist in their duties and are images of ministers. The Dao can transform all things without exception, so when primordial qi abides by the Dao, it circulates its qi, giving birth to heaven and earth. Though they stand without pillars, the myriad things arise without fixed categories, and their descendants continue in succession, speaking of categories. This is like grasses and trees growing on the earth—do they have categories? It is the primordial qi abiding by the Dao that generates them thus.

When all things naturally abide by the Dao and act accordingly, the myriad things each attain their proper place. When heaven abides by the Dao and acts, it is called spirit and has no fixed form, resembling the ruler and father of the people, able to govern and transform all things, truly embodying the Dao’s intent. When earth abides by the Dao and acts, the five directions unite with the center, and the myriad things return to it. When the Three Luminaries abide by the Dao and act, they illuminate all without exception. When thunder and lightning abide by the Dao and act, they can stir the world, riding the qi to come and go.

When the four seasons and Five Phases abide by the Dao and act, they can transform the myriad things, giving them constancy. When yin and yang, male and female abide by the Dao and act, they can transmit through the generations. In all matters, great or small, if they abide by the Dao and act, there will be no misfortune. If the Dao is lost today, great chaos will ensue. Thus, when yang is at peace, the myriad things naturally arise; when yin is at peace, the myriad things naturally mature.

When yin and yang govern through the Dao, they instruct their ministers, transform their people, receive their mandate from heaven, their form from earth, and their teachings from their teachers. Only then do they hear the essential Dao of the world. Those who guard the root become kings; those who guard the stem become ministers; those who guard the floating blossoms bring good but also chaos and inconstancy.

The emperor is the son of heaven; the empress is the daughter of earth—they are the first spiritual qi of heaven and earth. Heaven and earth always wish for joy and do not tolerate sorrow; they cherish them so deeply that the qi of heaven and earth’s heart is foremost. Thus, if the ruler is sorrowful, the qi of the four seasons and Five Phases will be disordered, and life and death will have no constancy.

**The Method of Suspending Images to Return the Spirit**
Within the body, the spirit is born: in spring, ten green youths; in summer, ten red youths; in autumn, ten white youths; in winter, ten black youths; and in the four seasons, twelve yellow youths. This is how the spirit is stored in men; the female spirit follows the same numbers. Men should visualize men, women should visualize women, all using a one-foot measure as the standard. Draw them well to make them pleasing, so that one loves them. If one cannot maintain joy and restraint, the hun and shen spirits will quickly return.

**The Secret of Resolving Karmic Inheritance**
Since the opening of heaven and earth, inauspicious qi has never ceased—once cut off, it later resurges. Why? Lifespan is heaven’s most precious treasure, privately bestowed by virtue and cannot be falsely obtained. To know this treasure, the myriad things within the six directions and eight reaches of heaven and earth must all be free from grievances and entirely joyful—only then can lifespan increase. If even one matter is displeasing, it may cause injury or death.

In human conduct, some strive to do good but instead encounter misfortune, while others strive to do evil but instead receive good. Those who claim to be virtuous when doing good but meeting misfortune are mistaken. Those who do good but meet misfortune bear the burden of their ancestors’ transgressions, as accumulated disasters flow forward and backward to harm them. Those who do evil but receive good inherit the deep accumulation of their ancestors’ great merits, which flow to them.

If one can perform great merits ten thousand times over, even if their ancestors had lingering misfortunes, they cannot reach this person. Instead, they pass on to future generations, forming a cycle of five generations. A small cycle completes in ten generations and returns to the beginning. Some may perform small good deeds but cannot overcome the disasters of their ancestors’ karmic inheritance, leading to the extinction of their lineage in later generations—truly a grievous injustice.

Karmic inheritance is divided into three realms by heaven: emperors inherit over thirty thousand years, ministers over three thousand years, and the people over three hundred years. All bear the inheritance in succession, rising and falling with the decline and prosperity of governance, never ceasing. If one can model this on the governance of the Heavenly Sovereign and cut it off, ponder deeply and never forget.

Humans have three lifespans corresponding to the three qi: the life of Great Yang, Great Yin, and Harmony. The upper lifespan is one hundred twenty years, corresponding to heaven and completing the great calendar of heaven and earth’s boundary. The middle lifespan is eighty years, corresponding to yin and yang, distinguishing the eight trigrams and aligning with earth, differentiating the myriad things—those who die depart, while those who live remain. The lower lifespan is sixty years, corresponding to the qi of Harmony, obtaining the hexagram *Dun* in the sixth month. *Dun* means escape and flight, thus governing the meeting of life and death.

If one ceaselessly does good, surpassing this lifespan is called transcending the world. If one ceaselessly does evil, failing to reach these three lifespans is called premature death. Those who die in the womb or before maturity bear the innocent burden of their ancestors’ transgressions. Those with frequent head ailments displease the qi of heaven.

Those with frequent foot ailments displease the qi of earth. Those with many internal illnesses suffer from the conflict of the Five Phases’ qi. Those with frequent limb ailments experience disharmony in the qi of the four seasons. Those with frequent deafness or blindness witness the Three Luminaries losing their proper measure. Those with frequent chills and fevers endure the contention of yin and yang qi. Those with frequent confusion and disorder see the myriad things losing their place. Those afflicted often by ghostly entities incur the wrath of heaven and earth’s spirits. Those who die of frequent warmth are slain by the qi of Great Yang. Those who die of frequent cold are harmed by the qi of Great Yin. Those who die suddenly suffer from the excessive haste of punitive qi. Those with frequent qi distension or shortness of breath experience the discord of the eight nodes. Now, heaven and earth’s yin and yang have entirely lost their proper places, thus harming the myriad things.

If the emperor’s governance is disharmonious, floods and droughts occur without regularity, bandits arise frequently, and yet punishments are made more severe, or their weight is increased, leading to endless entanglements. The people all cry out to heaven, while the officials’ governance is chaotic, losing proper measure and constancy. The myriad things are harmed, moving the Azure Heaven above, causing the Three Luminaries to rage and change, and the constellations to move erratically. Thus, only the supreme Dao can save them. I know the will of heaven does not deceive you. Once the might of heaven is unleashed, it cannot be restrained. To incur guilt before heaven is to invite premature death.

When heaven and earth first opened, the Great Sages each attained mastery in one aspect, knowing it with perfect sincerity and without doubt. Thus, each established a great enterprise for later generations to cultivate, without error. Therefore, even sages excel in but one great enterprise and cannot fully comprehend the Way of heaven, hence their virtues differ. This is like heaven and earth: how much more so for humans? Heaven and earth each excel in one aspect—heaven excels in height and clarity, earth in depth and turbidity, while the Harmonious Center nurtures the myriad things. Yet even they cannot encompass all, so how could ordinary people?

*Hai* marks the northwest extreme of heaven and earth, while *Si* marks the southeast extreme. If *Hai*’s cold does not withdraw in due time, the following *Si* will bring harm. *Zi* is the northern extreme of heaven and earth, and *Wu* the southern extreme. If *Zi*’s winter does not properly store and yield, *Wu* will bear the burden and perish. *Chou* is the northeast extreme of heaven and earth, and *Wei* the southwest extreme. If *Chou* does not timely bring forth life, the sixth month will instead bring its punishment. The nature and movement of heaven and earth are all like this.

Now, if the emperor rules within a hundred *li*, employing virtue and benevolence, his grace extends for ten thousand *li*, and the people receive his favor. Fathers are kind, children filial, households sufficient, and none turn to wickedness. If the emperor within loses his virtue, beyond ten thousand *li*, the people and ministers lose their proper roles. Though they are separated by countless miles, the cause is one. Practicing good words is not as effective as practicing good conduct oneself. [Title missing]

The Perfected One asked the Divine One: "In my life, what can I practice to always be joyful?"

The Divine One replied: "Do you yet observe the vast Perfected Ones of old? Those who age only after they have first flourished do so because they have abandoned the perverse. If one alone cherishes the true Dao, the true Dao is constantly preserved while the perverse dissipates. When all people are exhausted and impoverished, yet I alone endure forever—this is constant joy."

"Radiant and solitary in my delight, why should I resent anything? Yet if I ultimately cannot attain long life, what then?"

The Divine One said: "Accumulated practice nears completion; contemplating goodness nears life. The Dao is the scripture of the boundless. In highest antiquity, the Divine Ones governed by it, taking Perfected Ones as ministers to order the people. Thus, the people knew not that above them there was a Son of Heaven, and through the Dao’s natural non-action, they governed themselves. Next, the Perfected Ones governed, taking Immortals as ministers. The people did not perceive their ruler’s timely guidance, yet heard his teachings and revered their lord. Next, the Immortals governed, taking Daoists as ministers. Their rule was slightly marked by punishments and manifest laws, and the people’s hearts stirred with awe, giving rise to cunning and deceit. Next came hegemonic rule, where ministers were not carefully chosen. The people suffered many grievances, and disorder arose. As governance receded, chaos drew near, and it could no longer be controlled.

Thus, contemplating the divine invokes the divine; contemplating the true invokes the true; contemplating immortality invokes immortality; contemplating the Dao invokes the Dao; contemplating wisdom invokes wisdom. The essence of the sage’s thought summons the spirit of the worthy to come and aid him; contemplating the perverse summons the ghosts of fools to confuse him. Whatever one may contemplate can be invoked—it depends only on the excellence or inferiority of what is contemplated. Therefore, when a superior scholar becomes ruler, he contemplates the divine and true; when a middling scholar becomes ruler, his mind is penetrating and full of wisdom; when an inferior scholar becomes ruler, he cannot contemplate anything and merely follows fate as it unfolds." [Title missing]

The Perfected One asked, "How can one know whether a ruler’s thoughts are good or evil?"

The Divine One replied, "Is this not easily known? When a ruler contemplates benevolence and goodness, auspicious omens arise solely for him, and prophetic charts and texts manifest exclusively for him. A ruler’s benevolence and clarity emerge from Wood and Fire, martial wisdom from Metal and Water, and gentleness and harmony from Earth. Heaven’s descending signs never err."

The Perfected One asked, "In ancient times, extraordinary charts and rare methods spontaneously appeared—who was worthy to receive them?"

"Those among the officials and common people who obtained them presented them to the king. When a ruler’s *qi* aligns with the times and becomes harmonious and refined, governance grows ever more luminous. Daoist arts and worthy sages emerge to assist him, and the ruler’s Way daily waxes in strength. The barbarians are subdued and vanish; he governs with folded arms, punishments cease of themselves, and the people know no warfare. Is this not proof of a ruler’s good thoughts? Even without seeing the man, one already knows."

The Perfected One asked, "How does the Divine One come to know these things?"

The Divine One said, "Through the attainment of the soundless. When a ruler desires benevolence and cherishes life, he emulates the Way of Heaven; when ministers desire gentleness, compliance, and nurturance, they follow the Way of Earth—then auspicious responses arise. Thus, Heaven and Earth do not speak yet endure forever; their governance is uniquely divine. Divine immortals do not speak yet attain long life as immortals, for they inwardly illuminate while outwardly remain obscure—this is the origin of the myriad Ways.

"The divine and numinous come and go without fixed abode. In purity and stillness, without sound, resting peacefully upon the pillow, the radiance of spirit arises of itself—how could one not be blessed with joy? Those who speak excessively deplete their essence; those who labor excessively wear out their bodies; those who resort to force excessively harm themselves—from these arise misfortune and calamity. Heed my words and do not indulge in reckless thoughts. Good thoughts may bring virtue, but evil thoughts return to harm oneself. Between safety and peril, the difference is as fine as a hair’s breadth—beware of mixed thoughts.

"When a person loses the Dao, their fate is severed; by discerning the intent of the Dao, life may be preserved. Cultivate your essence diligently and do not consume yourself. Study under an enlightened teacher, and misfortune and chaos will not arise."

The Perfected One dared not disregard the Divine One’s words.

The Divine One said, "Scholars each act for their own sake, not for others. Therefore, each should cherish and attend to themselves. Through long accumulation in the study of the Dao, one becomes a divine immortal, utterly distinct from the multitude—such are these words."

The Perfected One asked, "How can one verify the efficacy of the Dao?"

The Divine One replied, "Resolve it through an enlightened teacher and practice it in oneself. When the body transforms and the form changes, one shares the same gate as the divine Way, becomes a neighbor to the true, and dwells in the same household as divine immortals. Seek it within yourself—why would you not see its benefits? If one loses the intent of the Dao, seeking it in the four directions will yield nothing, and one will reach old age in poverty. Thus severed from the root, one claims the world has no Dao, ever solitary and sorrowful—this is the greatest calamity.

"The great person, losing it, cannot govern in peace; the middling person, losing it, confuses their ruler; the benevolent person, losing it, has no means to act worthily; the petty person, losing it, destroys themselves. The conduct of the worthy sages of old is the same as today; the failures of the petty people of old are also the same as today—clear evidence is thus."

The Perfected One asked, "How can one know whether a person is about to rise or decline?"

The Divine One said, "When a great person is about to rise, extraordinary texts appear, and the worthy assist in governance. When a household is about to rise, those who seek find life, and the goodness of its descendants is assured."

The Perfected One asked, "How does one attract such worthy individuals?"

The Divine One replied, "All through thought—unceasing, concentrated thought brings all matters to fruition."

"Marvelous is the governance of the Dao! Can one not strive to practice it?"

The Divine One said, "The Three Bonds and Six Relations endure in good fortune because they uphold the Dao and do not lose their governance—thus they remain perpetually blessed. Heaven’s destined lifespan does not override human aspirations. The nature of Wood is benevolence; contemplating benevolence thus invokes the East, for the East governs benevolence. The five directions all follow this principle. The affairs of the world each follow their kind. Therefore, when a ruler contemplates tranquility, his governance is also tranquil—like summons like.

"The scholars of old verified it in themselves; the scholars of today verify it in others. The scholars of old sought to secure their own persons; the scholars of today pursue superficial embellishments. Instead of accumulating essence within themselves, they accumulate it in mere texts—this is to be ignorant of the root."

[Preserved] *The Pearl Satchel of the Three Caverns*, Scroll One, "On Salvation and Guidance," citing *The Scripture of Great Peace*, Chapter Thirty-Three:

The Perfected One asked, "Why do people frequently fall ill?"

The Divine One answered, "When the spirit of the liver departs and does not return in due time, the eyes lose their brightness. When the spirit of the heart departs, the lips turn pale. When the spirit of the lungs departs, the nose becomes blocked. When the spirit of the kidneys departs, the ears grow deaf. When the spirit of the spleen departs, the mouth cannot taste sweetness. When the spirit of the head departs, one becomes dizzy and confused. When the spirit of the abdomen departs, the center of the belly becomes disordered and can digest nothing. When the spirits of the four limbs depart, one cannot move on their own.

"The nature of spirit and essence is to dwell in serene and quiet places, not in defiled and turbid ones. To recall the spirits, one must fast and purify oneself, hang their images in a fragrant chamber, and all illnesses will vanish. Without fasting and purification, the spirits will not return to the person. All these are reported to Heaven together. Thus, people’s illnesses accumulate, and the dead do not cease."

The *Taiping Jing* states, as the Perfected One said: "The human spirit and essence naturally dwell in serene and quiet places, not in defiled and turbid ones. To recall the essence, one must fast and purify oneself in a fragrant chamber, and all illnesses will vanish of themselves. Without fasting and purification, the spirit and essence will not return to the person. All these are reported to Heaven together, which is why people’s illnesses accumulate and the dead do not cease."

*The Taiping Imperial Digest*, Volume 667
*Comprehensive Collation of the Taiping Jing*, Volume 35, Part Bing I
*Taiping Jing*, Scroll 35, "Method for Distinguishing Poverty and Wealth," Chapter 41

The Perfected One asked, "You have followed me for some time to study the Dao. Have you truly mastered it all, or is there still more?"
The disciple replied, "Today, the Celestial Master no longer expounds further, deeming it sufficient. Yet upon hearing the Master’s words again, I realize there is still more I lack. My thoughts are now exhausted, and I do not know what else I should ask. I only hope the Celestial Master will further enlighten me on what I have yet to grasp."
The Perfected One said, "Come, Perfected One.
〈Rising〉 What in the world is called wealth, and what is called poverty?"
The disciple answered, "One who possesses much is wealthy; one who possesses little is poor."
The Perfected One said, "Your words are correct, yet in truth, they are not.
"What do you mean?"
"Now, if one has much that is false, deceitful, flattering, thieving, or treacherous, can this be called wealth? If the common people are many and the lord is few, can this be called poverty?"
〈End〉
The disciple said, "This foolish and ignorant one, seeing the Celestial Master’s instruction, dares not remain silent, though I fear my words may fall short and contain errors."
The Perfected One said, "You yourself admit your inadequacy—how could the vulgar know the true nature of poverty and wealth?"
The disciple replied, "Now, only by the Celestial Master’s guidance can this disciple, who is as ignorant as an infant, gain knowledge, just as a child must be taught by its parents before understanding."
The Perfected One said, "Excellent are your words. You are most modest, yet not mistaken."

"Very well. The Perfected One, in your refinement, will explain this to you in full.

〈Begin〉
What is meant by 'wealth' is complete and perfect sufficiency. Heaven, in its generation of all things, brings forth abundance—thus, when the qi of the Supreme Sovereign emerges, the full twelve thousand kinds of beings are produced, and this is called 'wealth and sufficiency.' When the beings of the Middle Sovereign are slightly diminished, unable to complete the twelve thousand, this is called 'lesser poverty.' When the beings of the Lower Sovereign are further reduced compared to the Middle Sovereign, this is called 'greater poverty.' When there are no auspicious responses and good beings do not arise, this is called 'the lowest extreme of poverty.'
〈End〉

If you wish to know its great effect, consider it like a farming household: lacking rare treasures or precious goods, it is a poor household. When the ten thousand beings cannot be fully provided for, it is the lowest, most extreme poor household—this is the poverty of Heaven and Earth.

〈Begin〉
When the twelve thousand beings all emerge and the Earth nourishes them without harm, this is the Earth’s wealth. When it fails to nourish them well, causing slight harm, this is the Earth’s lesser poverty. When the harm is great, it is the Earth’s greater poverty.
〈End〉
When good beings fear to appear, harmed by the Earth’s form and unable to arise, this is the lowest extreme of poverty. Lacking precious treasures and with half the ten thousand beings harmed, this is the great cause of poverty. When all are harmed, it is the destitute household of emptiness.

Thus,
〈Begin〉
Heaven is the father, Earth the mother—when these parents are in extreme poverty, their children grieve in poverty as well. This corresponds to the governance of kings.
〈End〉

Therefore, the sagely kings of antiquity, in their rule, were able to bring forth the twelve thousand beings—these were the supremely wealthy lords. When good beings fell short by two-thirds, they were lords of middle wealth. When they fell short by one-third, they were lords of lesser wealth. Lacking rare and excellent beings, they were lords of lower poverty. When half the ten thousand beings were harmed, they were declining houses. When all were harmed, they were the lowest poor people.

The sages and worthies of old dwelt deep in secluded chambers, reflecting on the Dao and virtue—
〈End〉
what need had they to inquire about poverty and wealth? They knew it all while seated in stillness."

"Excellent! Excellent! Now, only through the Celestial Master’s compassion for the long-suffering emperors and kings, who cannot act upon their intentions—how might they attain this wealth or poverty?"

"Excellent! Excellent! Your questioning has already entered the subtle and essential."

Thus, it is by the success or failure of their conduct that these outcomes arise.

Those who vigorously practice the true Dao are aided in their transformation by the celestial spirits born of Heaven, and so all fine and excellent things are fully provided. Those who practice virtue are assisted in their governance by the spirits of nourishment, born of Earth’s yang, and so they attain half-wealth. Those who practice benevolence are aided by the spirits of harmony and kindness, and so they attain lesser wealth. Those who practice civil arts open the path to deception, and so the spirits of deceit emerge to assist them, bringing minor disorder to their governance. Those who practice martial force are aided by the spirits of bandits and thieves, and so their rule runs counter to Heaven’s will, harming the good.

The Dao is what Heaven itself follows. Heaven is most spirit-like, and so the true spirits emerge to aid its transformation. Earth is nurturing, and so the spirits of virtue emerge to aid its transformation. Humanity is benevolent, and so the spirits of kindness emerge to aid its transformation. Civil arts, however, rely on elegant deception, losing their root and foundation—thus the spirits of deceit emerge to assist them. When superiors and inferiors engage in such deception, their affairs fall into chaos.

Martial rule employs punishment and killing to subdue the people, just as bandits and thieves use violence to overpower them. Those who govern through rage, pleasure, ferocity, or intimidation are no different from bandits. Thus, when bandits and thieves proliferate, governance turns inauspicious. Since bandits and thieves often inflict harm through wealth and goods, their rule loses control over resources.

Therefore, the rulers of old who subdued the people through the Dao won Heaven’s favor most fully. Their governance was as if divine, and they knew no sorrow, for they subdued the people through the true Dao. The middling rulers subdued the people through virtue; the lesser rulers through benevolence; the disorderly rulers through civil arts; and the doomed and failing rulers through punishment, killing, and harm.

Thus, the rulers of old subdued the people through Dao, virtue, and benevolence—not through civil arts, punishment, or killing. The reason for this is that such methods are base and vulgar. The noble ruler resembles Heaven and Earth: Heaven delights in giving life and does no harm, and so is called "lord" and "father." Earth delights in nourishing the myriad things, and so is called "loyal minister" and "mother." Humanity should employ a kind and loving heart, nurturing all as Heaven and Earth do, and so is called "benevolent." These three are good, and thus together they govern the myriad things, serving as their teachers and leaders.

Deception and punishment cannot bring order; they only invite misfortune day by day and cannot lead emperors and kings to Great Peace. Therefore, they must be abandoned.

Now, if a true person entrusts this text to a ruler of Dao and virtue, urging them to practice it with diligence so that its effects manifest and align with Heaven, they may attain Great Peace and be called a house of wealth—without doubt. They will spare emperors and kings from sorrow and prevent them from being called houses of poverty.

Yet today, when people in the world speak of "wealthy households," what do they mean? Such talk is merely the reckless chatter of the vulgar. For "wealth" means complete and perfect provision. If even one thing is lacking, it is not complete. Thus, the sages and worthies of old did not demand perfection from any single person, for they knew none could achieve it, and so they did not insist on such completeness.

Now, among the eighty-one domains and states, each lacks some things and cannot always be self-sufficient, so they must obtain them from other lands. How, then, can any single household be truly wealthy? Does the true person wish to follow the empty words of the common folk?

"‘I dare not, I dare not.’

‘Since you have studied the caution of speech, do not engage in reckless talk. For reckless talk disrupts the proper patterns of Heaven and Earth and cannot serve as a model for others. Be vigilant.’

‘Indeed, indeed. Now that the Heavenly Master has shown such kindness and compassion, taking pity on the emperors and kings who, though enthroned, labor with anxious hearts and fail to align with the Will of Heaven—would you, for their sake, fully expound the way to attain the Great Peace of the Supreme Sovereign? This humble student has received many texts, yet remains as bewildered as an unlearned child. What further should I ask? I only pray the Heavenly Master will set forth all the admonitions in full.’

‘Excellent, excellent! Now, the law of Heaven: the yang number is one, the yin number is two. Thus, yang is odd, yin is even. Therefore, rulers are few while ministers are many. Yang is noble, yin is base, so two yin must together serve one yang. Thus, the number of Heaven is one, and the number of Earth is two—hence, two women should serve one man. Why must two share the duty of nourishing one? The side of the noble must not be left vacant. When one acts, another should stand or sit beside them to attend to what is lacking. Thus, one symbolizes Heaven, and two symbolizes Earth. Humanity is the child of Heaven and Earth, and so must emulate its parents.

Since the world lost the Dao, it has come to scorn women, even murdering them, causing women to become fewer than men. Thus, the yin qi is severed, no longer corresponding to the laws of Heaven and Earth. The Way of Heaven decrees that a solitary yang cannot pair, leading to withering, and so Heaven does not send timely rain. Women correspond to Earth, yet they are despised alone. The world collectively scorns its true mother, collectively harms and slays the qi of Earth, causing the qi of Earth to be severed and cease its generative power. Earth grows furious and displeased, disasters multiply, and the king’s governance cannot achieve peace. Why is this? Men are the spirit of Heaven, women are the spirit of Earth. Things of the same kind move one another. The failure of governance to attain peace is not the fault of the king alone. It is the common people who, having lost the Dao, treat matters lightly and together commit wrongs. Their transgressions are not singular but manifold, making governance difficult, disorderly, and errant.

The nature of Heaven and Earth encompasses twelve thousand things, yet human life is the weightiest. This murder of daughters deeply disrupts the king’s governance—here lies the great calamity.’

‘Now that the Heavenly Master has opened the stairway to Great Peace for rulers, and the true scripture of Great Peace has emerged—should kings but wander freely without care—yet this harm to women brings about great disaster. What is to be done?’

‘Excellent is your question, for it aligns with the heart of Heaven. The reason the world scorns and despises women lies fundamentally in the faults of their conduct.’

‘What does this mean? I wish to hear it, to record it on bamboo and silk, that for ten thousand generations it may never be abandoned.’

‘Excellent that you would record this! If the world no longer kills daughters—’

‘Indeed, indeed. I wish to record it, to remove disaster from emperors and kings, which would bring me joy, and to save the lives of wronged women.’

‘Excellent! You have already gained the favor of Heaven’s reckoning.’

‘What does this mean?’"

"Yet to preserve life is called preserving one’s own life, while to take life is called destroying one’s own life. If you cherish children, you have already gained an increase in Heaven’s reckoning, and the Deity of Fate will amend your register."

"I dare not, I dare not."

"There is no further yielding—this is the natural law of Heaven. Now, the reason the world kills daughters is that when people are young and small, their parents fret and suffer, cutting off their clothing and food to share in their upbringing. This is not only so for humans—even creatures that crawl do the same. Yet when they grow old and large, each must seek clothing and food according to their own strength, so all things under Heaven eventually leave their parents to provide for themselves. The worthy find joy, while the unworthy find suffering. Moreover, children are young, their strength daily growing and in surplus, while parents daily age, their strength waning and insufficient. Whether son or daughter, the wise and strong in ability should still repay and requite their parents’ merit and kindness by supporting them. Thus, parents should not be responsible for providing their clothing and food. This is called nurturing the strong by the weak, supporting the surplus with the insufficient—it is called perverse governance. The young bring hardship to the old, offering no benefit to their parents, so parents often kill them. Now, if they are killed for lack of clothing and food, how is this better than raising them to provide for themselves?

Perfected One! This is truly a grievous severing of the earthly lineage—how profoundly foolish the people are!"

Now, when the youth hears this, their heart is filled with great sorrow and fear, knowing that those wronged are truly many—what is to be done?

Yes, those who love learning yet lack clothing and food will surely grow lax in their studies and halt their pursuit of the Dao. But if they obtain clothing and food, then the worthy will study without ceasing. Each should be allowed their own benefit, and none should be made to turn back and bring hardship upon one another.

What does this mean?

A woman has no official post; her marriage to a husband is like a man’s appointment to office—she should thereby obtain clothing and food. When a woman joins her husband’s household, they should unite their strength and hearts to manage their livelihood, together continuing the lineage of Heaven and Earth. Even unto death, their bones and flesh remain together, and they should join their strength to secure clothing and food. This will bring joy to the worthy and suffering to the unworthy.

It is like the land: fertile soil yields good crops, and Heaven bestows its favor upon it; barren soil yields poor crops, and Heaven likewise bestows its lot upon it. It does not seize what their strength and nature produce. If even Heaven and Earth do not deprive you of your labor, how much less should men? Thus, no one will kill their daughters again.
