Excellent! Excellent! A great and deep harm is removed, and the Great Peace of the Emperor-King is at hand.

How does the Perfected One know this?

Parents and children share the deepest bond in the world; they should not be left in distress and sorrow, nor should they be killed. To kill one’s child is to invite the qi of bandits and thieves—it is a grave rebellion, utterly without the Dao. Thus, it deeply disrupts the governance of the Emperor-King. Now, if women are allowed to live without being murdered or harmed, great joy will come.

Yes, your words are correct—you may be said to understand this. Yet today, if every household in the world kills one daughter, how many hundreds of millions of households are there? Some families kill ten or more daughters; some even harm them before they are born. Their grievance and resentment rise to Heaven—how can this be without principle? Thus, I truly... deeply understand this.

If each person provides for themselves through their own labor, women will have no divided hearts, their minds will be single in their work, and they will no longer waver in doubt. But if they toil without reward, their hearts will remain discordant. This is the natural art of Heavenly nature. Perfected One, take heed: do not discard this text. Entrust it to a benevolent and worthy ruler, that it may remove this great grievance and disaster. Guard my words and show them to all people, so that none will dare kill their daughters again. This will accord with the laws of Heaven and Earth, and one man will have two women.

Thus, Heaven establishes its laws: the yang number is odd, the yin number is even. Since the Great Middle Antiquity, people have lost the intent of the Heavenly Dao, wantonly killing women, and so men have become numerous while women are few and insufficient. This greatly violates the Heavenly Dao, causing successive generations to bear its burden as a common custom. Later ages will suffer even greater evil and pain, utterly without the Dao.

Men inherit the lineage of Heaven; women inherit the lineage of Earth. Now, to sever the lineage of Earth, preventing it from continuing and transmitting life, will lead many to extinction without descendants—how grave their sin! All should mutually give life and transmit their kind. Now, to sever the lineage of Earth and destroy humanity is why Heaven, over time, will cut off their generations.

Moreover, all people are born containing the qi of Heaven, fully formed: the round head is Heaven; the square feet are Earth; the four limbs are the four seasons; the five viscera are the five phases; the ears, eyes, mouth, and nose are the seven luminaries and three lights. These cannot all be enumerated—only the sage knows them. All people possess both yin and yang; when the sun and moon are full, they emerge from the womb to see Heaven and Earth, and should grow to continue their ancestors’ lineage, assisting Heaven in generating beings and aiding Earth in nurturing forms.

Now, the gods of Heaven and Earth trust this household, so the divine lineage of Heaven and Earth comes to dwell in this person. Yet if people harm them, Heaven will greatly blame them. Since people do not restrain one another, Heaven has sent me to bring forth this text to show to later generations. If, after this matter has been revealed, one still persists in the old ways, it is called willfully violating the laws of Heaven. Their sin will be doubled, and their lineage will be extinguished without doubt.

Perfected One, take heed! Exert yourself, exert yourself!

Yes, yes.

Now that you have come to understand this matter, if you flee and hide this text, you will bear the punishment in place of others.

I dare not, I dare not.

Go now, and each look to your own well-being.

"Yes, yes."

The above section, "Arising," distinguishes the practices for the poor, the rich, and rulers—how to establish auspiciousness and prohibit the severing of Earth's lineage to restore balance between men and women and rectify royal governance. "Ceasing."

**Method of One Man and Two Women, Forty-Second**

Perfected One, step forward.

Now, as the great qi of peace and harmony is arriving, royal governance approaches great peace. Should people uphold chastity or not? And why should they uphold it?

"Chastity means restraining emotions and desires, refraining from reckless conduct."

Ah, Perfected One, your words are pure. Since the Great Middle Antiquity, the error of common people lies in their teachers' inner jealousy, which instead teaches them reckless conduct.

The Perfected One said: "What do you mean?"

"Arising: The chaste man does not emit, and the chaste woman does not transform. When yin and yang do not unite, their lineage is cut off and extinguished without descendants. Two people together sever the lineage of Heaven and Earth, coveting a petty, hollow reputation while forfeiting their posterity and losing their true essence. This is the greatest harm under Heaven. Ceasing.

Had your parents not transmitted life to you, how would you exist? Yet you sever it—this is what Heaven and Earth jointly detest, called those who cut off principle and commit great treason. The consequence is that Heaven and Earth become estranged: Heaven refuses to send rain, and Earth refuses to transform and generate. Why is this?

Arising: When Heaven does not rain, it is because the chaste man does not emit. When Earth does not generate the myriad things, it is because the chaste woman does not transform. If Heaven does not rain and Earth produces nothing, this is the greatest misfortune under Heaven. Ceasing.

How can this be considered good?"

"Perfected One, your words defy the teachings of Heaven and Earth, reverse the Dao of Heaven, and refuse to joyfully assist Heaven and Earth in generating and transforming. Instead, you seek to sever them. Do your spoken words not betray the August Heaven and Revered Earth?"

"Though not yet mature, I have faults. Having heard the Celestial Master's teaching, do I not now recognize the gravity of my transgression?"

"Let me tell you: nothing should contravene the Dao of Heaven. Yet by following the words of common people and defying the will of Heaven, the frequent estrangement of yin and yang stems from the disharmony between men and women. Men and women are the root of yin and yang. If governance loses its root, how can it be auspicious?"

"Now, Celestial Master, what should be done?"

"Indeed, when the Supreme August Heaven’s balanced qi descends, one must purely follow the Dao of Heaven. Thus, let one man be matched with two women, to mirror yin and yang. The yang number is odd, the yin number even—this is the arrival of the Great Harmony’s qi. If women are too numerous, yin qi flourishes; if men are too numerous, yang qi becomes unpaired and disordered, also inviting misfortune. Why? The count of humans must correspond with Heaven and Earth; if it fails to correspond, strength will be insufficient, and calamity will follow."

"Now, the imperial harem of the Son of Heaven corresponds to the earth—what does this mean?"

"Perfected One, your words now aid my own. Women are the spirit of the earth; the king is the spirit of Heaven. If the earth does not receive the spirit of yang, the king’s qi will not harmonize. Should the earth fail to generate life, each province must offer one woman to circulate its qi. Those who delight in transformation fear that grace may not extend fully, that the king’s bestowal may not be complete—thus they correspond to the earth and take them. When grace is universally bestowed, Heaven’s qi flows freely, timely rains fall, and the earth generates the myriad things. When the qi of Great Peace arrives, one must not esteem chastity excessively. To do so inwardly is a grave transgression, causing the king’s governance to lose harmony. Likewise, common people must not exceed proper measure—hence one man with two women."

"Excellent! Excellent!"

〈Inception〉
Aligning with Heaven and Earth, conforming to yin and yang, ensuring no grievance between men and women—this brings timely rains, enables the earth to transform and generate life, and harmonizes the king’s governance.

〈Cessation〉

**Method for Promoting Good and Suppressing Evil, Forty-Third**

Before the Perfected One:
"Now that the qi of Great Peace has arrived, we wish to ensure that the conscientious and good flourish day by day, while the wicked steadily decline. Yet there are those who harm and kill, bandits and thieves who arise—how should governance address this?"

"What do you mean?"

"When such matters arise, what is known must be acted upon. If the lord of men sits in doubt, wishing the good to flourish greatly and the wicked to swiftly decline—when bandits and thieves arise, they must be apprehended at once."

"How, then, should governance proceed?"

"Now, Perfected One, you should take careful note."

"Today, the Heavenly Master commands it—I dare not refuse. Yet with every word, I fear I may fall short of the Heavenly Master’s standards."

"Why such modesty in speech? Since ancient times, even the greatest sages have not demanded perfection from a single person. If your words today miss the mark, why be modest?"

"Very well, very well. One must simply reward the good and punish the evil, making the distinctions clear and unmistakable—then the good will flourish daily, and the wicked will decline."

"Your words are correct. But do rewards and punishments lack names?"

"Unworthy as I am, I cannot summarize it in a single phrase—I dare not elaborate further. Now, may the Heavenly Master graciously expound in full."

"So be it. Take heed, for I shall explain it to you in detail."

When the chief magistrate arrives at the designated place, he summons all the people of his jurisdiction. Former high officials and old retainers are seated facing east; those learned in the classics and men of Dao and virtue are seated facing north; the filial and fraternal are seated facing west; diligent tenant farmers and dutiful sons are placed in the southeast corner facing northwest; wicked youths are placed in the southwest corner facing northeast. The lord himself sits facing south. Why must they be seated precisely thus? Each is grouped according to their kind—this is the Way of Heaven, which accords with human nature to establish goodness.

Why are thieves and bandits easily apprehended? Former high officials and old retainers are placed where loyalty gathers; these men, though no longer in office, delight in aiding with righteousness. Those learned in the classics and men of Dao and virtue are placed where clarity gathers, so they may illuminate the classics and the Way to assist in discerning evil. The filial and fraternal are placed in their native villages, for the utmost filial piety lies in devotion of the heart—thus they are returned to their native villages. The filial and fraternal are to remain ever reverent, as if attending court. All things are born in the east, delighting in daily progress. The diligent and hardworking sons are placed in the southeast corner, for the southeast is the direction of growth and nurturance, that they may delight in cultivating the myriad things without slackening. Wicked youths are placed in the southwest, for the southwest is where yang wanes and yin arises—the abode of cunning and mischief, where punishments and crimes originate. Hence, apes and monkeys, creatures of dexterous trickery, are placed in this declining direction. Those facing east, west, and north are all seated in the front, while the negligent and wicked youths are placed behind.

If there is wine, each is granted a vessel; if there is none, those of good words are rewarded. Thus they are made to assist one another in wisdom. The lord sits in the central space, enclosed within the chamber. One by one, they are called forth—this assembly of people begins with instruction by rank. Each speaks once, and each records the name of their superior. What is spoken and recorded must later correspond; those whose words do not correspond are punished. Those whose words do not align are great flatterers and deceivers, and their deceit will later be exposed. Those whose words align are rewarded only after a long time, and their rank is advanced—not immediately. Why? To avoid provoking resentment. For a lord and father to cause his ministers and children to resent him is not the way of a benevolent father or worthy ruler.

Once the assembly is concluded, all good people are sent away. The wicked youths and officials who fail to capture the thieves are not permitted to remain. If the Perfected One employs this text and entrusts it to a lord of supreme virtue, showing it to all people so each knows of this teaching, then the good will flourish daily, the wicked will decline, and thieves, bandits, and treacherous villains will be apprehended.

"Excellent, excellent! Why must it be shown in advance?"
"When Heaven is about to bring rain, wind and clouds must first appear to inform people. The reason is to delight in their preparation and storage. Thus, showing it in advance delights in the daily flourishing of the good and the daily cessation of the wicked. Now, as the qi of Great Peace is about to arrive, I fear people may do evil and disrupt its governance—hence, I awaken them beforehand. Governing should emulate Heaven."

"Excellent, excellent! Why must the lord necessarily enclose himself within the chamber while those who speak remain outside?"
"Indeed, when one is about to hear confidential words, the mind must not be aware of what lies ahead. If faces are too close, bystanders will know, and those who speak may come to harm. For a lord to receive wisdom from others and later allow them to be harmed is called injuring the loyal and trustworthy, the worthy and capable pillars of state—after which, none will dare speak again. With wisdom cut off, governance will fall into chaos and peril.

Moreover, the lord is yang and dwells in yin; ministers are yin and dwell in yang. When yin and yang harmonize, people delight in what is said, and all proposals are fully trusted—this is the natural law of Heaven. Does the Perfected One now understand?"
"Yes, yes."

"Go now, and speak not recklessly. This is the scripture that brings Great Peace."
"Yes, yes."

[Here ends the section on "Encouraging Goodness, Suppressing Evil, Cultivating Wisdom, and Establishing Those Who Attain the Method of Loyalty and Trustworthiness."]

*Tai Ping Jing: Collated and Annotated Edition, Scroll 36, Bing Section Part Two*
*Tai Ping Jing, Scroll 36*
*Guarding the Three Realities, Chapter 44*

The Perfected One spoke: "Come forward."
"Yes, yes."
"Of all the actions of the common people in the world, which are most urgent? Which are of lesser urgency? And which, though they daily increase misfortune and calamity, are deemed not urgent? You must speak with utmost precision."
"Yes, yes. I shall speak only what my heart knows, concealing nothing."
"Proceed."
"In all matters under Heaven, what is used is urgent; what is unused is not urgent."
"Your words are correct—yet not entirely so. What is truly and constantly urgent, and cannot be abandoned, is that which, if abandoned, would leave the world barren and devoid of people. The celestial patterns, when aligned, bear no name—yet these are of the greatest urgency. What you have spoken of concerns only what momentarily aligns with human desires, yet in truth fosters the conditions from which misfortune and calamity arise."
"Perfected One, what I now ask of you is this: which are the constant urgencies that cannot be set aside?"
"Now, let the Celestial Master expound and distinguish them clearly for you. I, dull and overreaching, dare not speak amiss even once, lest I not dare speak again."
"Indeed, your words are correct. One may speak only of what one knows; to speak of what one does not know is to invite one’s own ruin."
"Matters beyond human comprehension, whether great or small, cannot be forced. What is within reach presents no difficulty; what lies beyond cannot be made easy. Therefore, since the Celestial Master has already begun to instruct one so dim and unenlightened as I, I humbly beg you to open the way and reveal its beginning, that I may listen with full assent."

The Perfected One spoke: "Under Heaven, there are two great urgencies and one lesser urgency. All else is not urgent—in fact, it wearies the ears and eyes of people, appearing good for the moment yet fostering long-term harm, summoning calamity upon them. All people thus meet with ruin and defeat. What does this mean?"
"Foolish though I am, I understand: when people first receive life and destiny, they partake of Heaven and Earth, embracing primordial qi in spontaneity. They neither drink nor eat, but live by inhaling and exhaling the qi of yin and yang. They know no hunger or thirst. Over time, they drift far from the divine Way, slightly losing their original intent. Later generations no longer comprehend this, and the true Dao becomes hollow. Day by day, they drift toward falsity, growing hungry and thirsty. Without drink or food, they die—this is the first great urgency. Heaven and Earth, in their compassion, provide sustenance for life. Once people drink and eat, the celestial mandate of yin and yang must be transmitted without interruption. This transmission should mirror Heaven and Earth, alternating between yin and yang. Thus, Heaven ensures there is one man and one woman, their forms harmonious, so that they may give birth. Why must it be one yin and one yang? When yang reaches its extreme, it generates yin; when yin reaches its extreme, it generates yang. These two alternate, like cold giving way to heat, and heat to cold—this is the natural art. Thus, they perpetuate life endlessly, preserving the celestial mandate through the ages. If men and women do not unite, there will be no descendants. Without people in the world, how can there be husbands and wives, fathers and children, rulers and ministers, masters and disciples?

Without the union of male and female, how can the mandate of Heaven and Earth be transmitted? Silence would reign, and all would be void—this is the second great urgency. Thus, yin and yang transmit the mandate of Heaven and Earth, ensuring it knows no end. Rulers and ministers govern disorder; sages and masters of disciples propagate the teachings of Heaven, assisting the emperor in transforming the world. Therefore, sustenance and the union of men and women are interdependent—these two are the great urgencies.

The Dao of Heaven has cold and heat, which do not conceal themselves; when unbalanced, they harm and kill people. Thus, Heaven generates the myriad things, which may be clothed..."

Without clothing, one could only dwell in caves and live in concealment—yet even then, half would perish from suffering, and death would not be wholly averted. This is called a *half-urgency*. What is meant by the *great urgency* of the Dao of Heaven is none other than extinction and annihilation—nothing is more urgent than this.

If people lack clothing, they cannot properly partake of food and drink or unite in yin and yang, nor can they cultivate goodness. With clothing, the worthy are born; without it, the unworthy arise. Thus, clothing serves only to ward off harm. For this reason, the sages of antiquity did not adorn themselves in black and yellow.

Food and drink, yin and yang, must not be severed. To sever them is to leave the world without people, rendering it ungovernable. By upholding these three, one may fulfill one’s allotted years, transmit the mandate of Heaven, and ensure that the end returns to the beginning in an unending cycle.

Thus, the sages of old governed by these three, casting aside all else that was not urgent and only summoned misfortune. Why is this so? These three accord with the movements of Heaven. The male is Heaven; the female is Earth; clothing is dependence. Heaven and Earth, father and mother, are what people depend upon to nourish their forms and bodies. Beyond these three, all other strange and artificial things are unnecessary for life and the transmission of generations. Instead, they breed falsity and deceit, disrupting governance, obstructing the imperial qi from reaching its fullness, and causing the Dao of Heaven to go awry. This is a grave concern for the noble person.

The six emotions that people delight in—each indulges in them without restraint, growing ever more enamored, thereby inviting calamity. The noble person loses control of governance, while petty men resort to theft, plunder, and assassination—all summoned by these non-urgent things. The world falls into poverty, distress, and suffering; disasters arise in succession; inferiors deceive their superiors—all due to this great harm.

This has been the case for a long time, and it is not solely the fault of people today or those of later generations. The error has been passed down through generations, each bearing the burden and losing the original truth. They all pursue superficial splendor, only to bring sorrow and harm upon themselves, failing to fulfill their allotted years.

Later generations engage in endless affairs, all because they treat non-urgent matters as urgent, thereby inviting misfortune. Thus, they are constantly rushing about without respite. Day by day, they drift toward superficiality, and in doing so, they invite sorrow and suffering, failing to fulfill their allotted years. They compel later generations to rush about without cease, draining the mountains and rivers, severing the primordial qi, weakening the qi of the Earth, and preventing the nurturing of the myriad things. Heavenly disasters and transformations follow, the people gradually dwindle, and deceit and falsity arise once more.

Such is the harm wrought by non-urgent things. Yet people seek only to please their eyes and ears, unaware of the profound and vast harm they bring. In high antiquity, governance was achieved through non-action because the Dao was understood and the will of Heaven was grasped—by holding fast to the root and not losing the three urgencies. In middle antiquity, affairs multiplied slightly because people became somewhat more elaborate. In later antiquity, great worries arose because people became excessively elaborate, giving rise to deceit and falsity. They competed to outdo one another, bringing sorrow upon themselves, and from this, deceit and villainy emerged.

Having lost their true essence and severed their root, they turned to harming one another, causing people to become bewildered and confused. Though the noble person grieves in their heart and wishes to correct this, the countless affairs they undertake only serve to further disrupt governance.

The Perfected One deeply contemplates this truth.

"Excellent! Excellent!"

The right way is to uphold the Three Realities, pacify qi, dispel deceit and falsity, and eliminate cunning and treachery. The Three Urgencies and the Laws of Fortune and Misfortune, Chapter Forty-Five.

The Perfected One asked, "Among the crawling creatures before me, how many have great urgencies? How many have small urgencies? And how many have no urgency at all?"

"Indeed, each has its own urgencies—thousands of strands, ten thousand threads—all designated by what kind of urgency they are. Crawling creatures each have their own aspirations, yet they cannot be named."

The Perfected One sighed, "You have grown weary and confused. Why do you feign ignorance so persistently?"

"In truth, I do not grasp it fully."

"If even you say you do not grasp it, how much less can the common people, who have lost their way? Their failure to grasp it is certain."

"Only the Heavenly Master, in your compassion, might resolve this ignorance for me."

"Very well! All crawling creatures receive the governance of Heaven and Earth, yin and yang, and come into being. They all share two great urgencies and one small urgency—what do these mean? When crawling creatures first receive the governance of yin and yang, they all breathe in unison, containing the qi of spontaneity, yet they do not yet know food and drink. Over time, they drift far from their root. As the Great Dao wanes and Heaven’s qi can no longer constantly follow and protect them, hunger and thirst arise. Heaven generates food and drink, which are also transmitted through the governance of yin and yang. Thus, there are male and female, and generation after generation, they propagate without end. To sever their food and drink, to cut off the transmission of yin and yang—this would leave the world without crawling creatures. These are the two great urgencies.

The one small urgency is this: creatures with fur, feathers, or scales may live, and even insects may survive. Yet those with fur or feathers are constantly good and lovable, shielding them from cold and heat. Those with scales constantly ward off harm. These are not essential for survival, and so they are called the small urgency. All other movements are sources of misfortune. If one does not uphold these three roots but acts recklessly without cause, one will surely perish. This is the natural law suspended between Heaven and Earth.

Perfected One, you should ponder this meaning. Those who uphold these three ways will harmonize with the central harmony of Heaven and Earth. Those who lose these three and multiply their affairs will all suffer misfortune and harm."

"Excellent! Excellent! Since the Heavenly Master has expounded this, I humbly beg to ask one more question."

""

"To proceed in balance."

"Now, for those like creeping roots and drooping branches—those that neither eat nor drink nor wear clothing—what is to be done?"

"Alas! Your learning does not advance day by day but instead regresses into ignorance. Why is this?"

"Is there also a great urgency and a small urgency for them? What are they?"

"Listen clearly."

"Yes, yes."

"All things require rain to live—this is their food and drink. They must have day and night, one scorching and one shaded: by day, the yang qi brings warmth; by night, the yin qi brings moisture. Only then can they grow and abide in their place. This is their union of yin and yang. Their drooping branches and spreading leaves are their clothing. Whether they have many leaves or few, they still live—this is their substance and adornment.

Thus, without timely rain, the myriad things under Heaven would not grow. If not a single thing existed under Heaven, it would be a great calamity—this is the first great urgency. Without day and night to harmonize the qi of yin and yang, things would have no means to mature. If nothing under Heaven bore fruit, it would be a great calamity—this is the second great urgency. Whether a plant has sparse leaves or many, it still bears fruit; both may fruit, and it need not be a set number of leaves—this is the small urgency. The fruit is its kernel.

Therefore, the sages of old upheld these three kernels, governing to bring about Great Peace. They attained the heart of Heaven and enjoyed long fortune, fulfilling their natural span. Substance alone sufficed; there was no need for elaborate adornments of many hues.

Thus, those lost in the branches should return to the center; those lost in the center should return to the root; those lost in adornment should return to substance; those lost in substance should return to the root. The root shares its origin with Heaven and Earth—hence, it governs.

Those bewildered in the later ages should reflect on the middle ages; those confused in the middle ages should reflect on the high antiquity; those disordered in high antiquity should reflect on the celestial patterns of Heaven and Earth; those who doubt the celestial patterns should reflect on the forms of the natural; those perplexed by the natural should reflect on the primordial numinous qi.

Thus, the sages and worthies of old who ‘ate qi’ and governed dwelled in secluded chambers to contemplate the Dao, pondering the images of gain and loss, never daring to transgress the bounds of Heaven’s law. Abiding in purity and stillness, they grasped its meaning, and their governance swiftly brought peace, resembling Heaven and Earth!

Perfected One, deeply ponder my words of the Dao—do you comprehend them?"

"Excellent! Excellent!"

"Go now, for you have awakened. If you model your governance on my writings, you may test it and see results in no time.

Do not conceal this text, so that all people may recognize where they have lost substance or adornment. Let them deeply reflect on its meaning and return to the three truths. Do not bring sorrow upon yourselves through falsehood and deceit. Perfected One, be vigilant!"

"Yes, yes."

The right explanation: all things preserve their root, gaining the three urgencies brings fortune, losing the three urgencies brings harm.

**Chapter Forty-Six: Serving the Dead Must Not Exceed the Law of the Living**

The Perfected One stepped forward.
"Yes, yes."
"When a filial child serves their parents, after the parents’ passing, should they serve them as they did in life?"
"No. They should serve them even more than in life."
"Why?"
"People are born through their parents and grow to greatness. When they see their parents die, with no hope of return, their hearts cannot forget them for even a moment. In life, they saw them daily, received their teachings and commands, and could repay them in going out and coming in. But in death, they can no longer behold them, and their longing grows ever more sorrowful—thus, they should serve them even more than in life."
"The Perfected One speaks rightly, yet this is already a great departure from the true Dao of Heaven, growing ever more distant. If even the Perfected One speaks thus, how much more do the benighted common people err, clearly transgressing Heaven’s law!"
"What do you mean, Heavenly Master?"
"Indeed, in life, humans resemble Heaven and belong to Heaven. In death, they resemble Earth and belong to Earth. Heaven is the father; Earth is the mother—one must not serve the mother more than the father. The living are yang; the dead are yin—one must not serve yin more than yang. Yang is the ruler; yin is the subject—one must not serve the subject more than the ruler. To serve yin in excess of yang is to invite rebellious qi. A slight excess brings minor rebellion; a great excess brings great rebellion—this is called rebellious qi, called perverse governance. Its harm allows yin qi to overpower yang, the lower to deceive the upper, and malevolent ghosts and spirits to rise in great numbers, overwhelming the human Dao and moving about in daylight without fear of people. This is why illness does not cease, and wandering ghosts do not desist. The great fault lies here—do you understand, do you comprehend?"
"This foolish one was greatly ignorant and in error. Now, having heard the Heavenly Master’s words, I am suddenly awakened with deep sorrow. I pray the Master will forgive my diligence and caution in service, and enlighten me where I have failed to grasp. How could such a small and subtle transgression lead to this?"
"To serve yin in excess of yang, the lower in excess of the upper—this is the greatest of transgressions. How can you call it small? The Perfected One still does not fully grasp. Moreover, the living are yang; ghosts and spirits are yin. The living belong to day; the dead belong to night. Do you wish to know the profound consequences of this? If day grows long and flourishes, night becomes short; if night grows long, day becomes short. When yang flourishes, it overpowers yin, and yin hides, not daring to appear recklessly—thus, ghosts and spirits conceal themselves. When yin flourishes, it overpowers yang, and yang hides—thus, ghosts and spirits appear in daylight. The living accompany the sun; malevolent ghosts and spirits accompany the stars. The sun is yang; the stars are yin. Therefore, when the sun appears, the stars flee; when the stars appear, the sun sets. When yin prevails, ghosts and spirits together cause harm so profound it cannot be named—this is called the flourishing of yin and the decline of yang. It causes governance to fail and harms the living. This transgression is most grave—ponder it deeply."
"Yes, yes."

[Appendix] The Perfected One further asked the Divine Person: "When a filial son serves his parents, after their passing he continues to serve them—should this be equal to when they were alive? Or is there a difference? Some serve them even more than when they were alive, while others serve them less. A person is born of their parents, grows to adulthood, and when they see their parents depart with no hope of return, unable to receive their teachings or repay their kindness in daily life, their thoughts and longings cannot cease. To serve them more than when they were alive—is this permissible?"

The Divine Person replied: "Your words reflect only the filial piety of the common world, not the intent of the Great Dao. A person’s life resembles Heaven and belongs to Heaven; a person’s death resembles Earth and belongs to Earth. Heaven is the father; Earth is the mother. One cannot serve the mother more than the father. Life is yang; death is yin. One cannot serve yin more than yang. Yang is the Way of the ruler; yin is the Way of the minister. One cannot serve a minister more than one’s ruler. To serve yin more than yang is to cause the qi of yin and yang to rebel, giving rise to disaster. To serve the lesser more than the greater is to cause governance to rebel, bringing great misfortune. When yin qi overpowers yang, the lower deceives the upper, and malevolent ghosts and spirits flourish, appearing in daylight along the human path. Epidemics never cease, and yang qi is obstructed. The Way of the ruler declines while the Way of the minister grows strong.

Thus, the enlightened emperors and kings of antiquity exalted yang as their utmost priority and humbled yin as their duty. The day is yang; the night is yin. When the day grows long, the night becomes short; when the night grows long, the day becomes short. When the day flourishes, the living flourish; when the night flourishes, ghosts and spirits flourish. The living accompany the sun; ghosts accompany the stars. The sun is yang; the stars are yin. Therefore, when the sun appears, the stars flee; when the stars appear, the sun sets. When yin prevails, ghosts and spirits cause harm—this is the harm brought by yin.

Thus, the Dao of Heaven establishes the law: the duty of yin must always be weaker than yang. Just as a minister must be weaker than their ruler, only then can the minister serve the ruler with obedience; a child must be weaker than their parents, only then can the child serve their parents with filial piety. If they grow strong and unyielding, the harm will be profound and severe. Therefore, though a filial son’s love and affection for their parents cannot be forgotten, they must not serve them more than when they were alive. Does the Perfected One not understand this?"

"Yes, yes."

"Be cautious! Be most cautious! In all matters, one must not indulge in reckless actions."

"Yes, yes."

"If one serves the dead more than they served the living, this exceeds the bounds of Heaven—how can this be?"

"This is to show disrespect to yang while revering yin, to turn one’s back on what is above and face what is below, thus transgressing the Way of Heaven. This foolish student bears great fault—may the Heavenly Master forgive me!"

"Not so. Simply reflect carefully: all actions must accord with the law."

"Yes, yes. The Heavenly Master has enlightened me; I wish to fully understand why one must not exceed what was done in life. In burial rites, clothing, grave goods, and mourning practices, nothing should surpass what was done while alive. All such excess is perverse governance, and even the dead may incur punishment for it. To send off the dead in a manner not recorded in the underworld’s ledgers, to be questioned for falsehoods—this is deceitful conduct, and the punishment will be even more severe. To honor the dead with excessive mourning rites instead brings misfortune: malevolent spirits arise, plagues spread, strange calamities multiply. How can this be explained?"

"Excellent question! From ancient times, the sages conducted funerals with utmost sincerity alone, never daring to overdo them. Death is the most inauspicious of all affairs. To amplify inauspicious matters invites harm, so sincerity alone suffices. Food and drink should resemble what was offered in life, without excess. Thus, people of that era enjoyed good fortune and health, living out their natural years.

In the middle antiquity, funeral rites slightly deviated from the law, though sincerity remained the core. Yet, losing sight of its true intent, people began to show superficial reverence, drifting into extravagance to appease the living. Their hearts only half-reached the dead, so the dead’s spirits only half-returned to partake. With mourning rites slightly at odds with truth, sacrifices summoned spirits—yet no one knew which ghosts or deities came to consume the offerings. They lingered to afflict the living, causing minor illnesses.

In later antiquity, people inherited the minor faults of the middle era and amplified them into grave errors. They no longer acted with sincerity toward the dead but sought to overwhelm the living with displays of mourning, emulating the ancients’ glory while violating the law. Their conduct became false, failing to move Heaven or summon the dead. The spirits no longer came regularly to partake, so people expanded sacrifices beyond all bounds, strengthening yin to the detriment of yang. Countless unknown spirits gathered to feast, then ran amok, wreaking havoc and killing without end. Seeing such excess go unpunished, why would they not indulge in it?

Thus, evil qi multiplied daily, turning to attack its hosts. Accustomed to feeding on the living, it followed them relentlessly. With yin overpowering yang, the living were oppressed; ministers deceived their rulers, children deceived their parents. Governance became unjust, yet the people remained unaware. Evil grew ever more severe, no longer restrained. Therefore, the sages and worthies of old never dared to serve the dead more than the living—this was their clear prohibition. Does the Perfected One now understand?"

"How profound! How profound! Had the Heavenly Master not revealed this, this foolish student would never have known it."

"Perfected One, you and I share the same heart—Heaven must have sent you to preside over these questions. Do not take this lightly. This is why I have told you everything. The reason is this: the era of balanced qi is about to arrive. All matters must follow the natural order; a single act of reversal will prevent its arrival. What does this mean? The Dao of Heaven calls for strengthening yang and weakening yin to achieve harmony. To instead strengthen yin and suppress yang is to act against the Way. To honor the dead with excessive rites invites inauspicious qi, causing governance to falter and order to collapse—this is no minor transgression.

In high antiquity, people managed funerals with sincerity alone, sending off the dead no more grandly than in life. Human hearts were pure and simple, illness was rare. In middle antiquity, rites gradually lost their proper measure, drifting into extravagance. Resources were exhausted on funeral goods, sacrifices grew lavish, and ghosts and spirits multiplied. The people suffered plagues, and malevolent spirits ran rampant, unstoppable. In later antiquity, sacrifices to other spirits flourished, yin was exalted, ghosts and deities were served to the harm of the living. Ministers usurped their rulers’ authority, women dominated households, warfare erupted violently, treachery and factions arose, flattery spread, governance decayed, and the ruler’s Way was obstructed. All this stemmed from exalting yin over yang, which the Dao of Heaven detests, bringing these disasters. Can one not be cautious?

Perfected One, do not conceal this text. Share it so that all may know the difference between gain and loss. When governance is disordered, the fault does not lie with Heaven, Earth, or the ruler alone. The blame rests with the people, each bearing their own transgressions, mutually compounding them, multiplying their errors. All this arises from abandoning truth.

What does this mean? Life is the root; death is the false. Why is death called false? The dead cannot be seen or desired, yet the living fabricate things for them, vainly adorning their likenesses beyond what they had in life. They cling to emptiness, not to truth. When a person dies, their hun-soul returns to Heaven, their bones and flesh decay into the earth. How can one, without thought, summon their spirit to partake of offerings? Their bones and flesh no longer remain, entrusted to the earth. The earth is humanity’s true mother. Born between Heaven and Earth, one’s essence differs from life—do they know their proper duty? Thus, the filial child serves the dead according to the root, and only then do they act with truth.

What the living do not enjoy should not be given to the dead. One must not exceed what was done in life, or strange calamities will run deep."

"Enlightened One, do you understand? Be cautious, be most cautious."
"Yes, yes! Excellent, excellent! The truth has indeed emerged!"
"You may be said to have grasped it. Go now."
"Yes, yes."

*Right: Matters of life from beginning to end must correspond with the essential teachings.*

**Tai Ping Jing Combined Collation, Bing Section, Part Three**
**Tai Ping Jing, Scroll Thirty-Seven**
**Test of the Writ: The Great Faith Method, Forty-Seventh**

The Great Foolish and Ignorant One prostrates twice and says: "Now I have further doubts and humbly ask the Heavenly Master, the Supreme August Divine Person."
"What matter do you inquire about?"
"I beg to ask: In this written text, what is its general essential purpose? For what duty was it revealed?"
"Excellent, excellent! Your question may be said to have attained the heart of August Heaven. This is the great essential explanation of its purpose.

*It begins:* Since the opening of Heaven and Earth, emperors, kings, and the people have borne the burden of mutual responsibility—this is why it was revealed."
*It ends:* "Now that it has been revealed for this purpose, why does it instead first speak of nurturing one’s nature?"
"Ah! Enlightened One, you are truly ignorant, truly benighted, and fail to comprehend. Earlier, when I heard your words, I took them as humble deference—why have you now truly fallen into darkness and confusion?"
"Very well."

"Enlightened One, lend your ears and listen clearly.

*It begins:* Now, the reason all people incur blame and responsibility is that they fail to properly nurture themselves, entirely losing their fundamental principles—thus they bear the burden of mutual responsibility. For example, if parents lack the utmost virtue and power and commit offenses against their neighbors, their descendants may later suffer harm at the hands of those same neighbors—this is a clear instance of bearing mutual responsibility. When former kings governed, if they did not align with the heart-mind of Heaven and Earth, they were not alone in disrupting the harmony of Heaven. Heaven grew greatly enraged and displeased, bringing forth myriad afflictions and disasters. Those who later held office then inherited this burden—how could this not be thoroughly examined?

Thus, this text was revealed precisely for this purpose. Therefore, the great worthies of antiquity all knew the Dao of self-nurturance, and so their governance accorded with the Way, resulting in few failures of mutual responsibility. However, the teachers of later generations often concealed or discarded the essential texts of the true essential Dao, transmitting only superficial and ornate learning, thereby deviating from the essential intent of the Heavenly Dao. This caused later generations to grow increasingly shallow, unable to properly nurture and cherish themselves. Over time, this accumulated, and they drifted ever farther from the Dao, claiming there was no method to preserve safety in the world. They then grew careless in their affairs, contended for rank and emolument, and thus brought about the disasters of mutual responsibility.

*It ends:* Do you now comprehend this intent?"

"Excellent, excellent!"

Hearing the Heavenly Master’s words was like parting clouds to behold the sun—no different indeed.

"You may now be said to have grasped the intent of the Dao."

"This foolish student, favored by your grace, has gained great understanding. Yet I shall have no end of questions—only may the Heavenly Master admonish and caution me again and again."

"Indeed, only one who deeply nurtures the self can nurture others. Only one who deeply cherishes the self can cherish others. If one neglects one’s own body and fails to nurture oneself, how can one generously nurture others? If one cannot cherish and preserve one’s own body, carefully guarding the ancestral lineage of one’s forebears, how can one cherish and preserve others? How foolish! Do you now deeply comprehend this?"

"Indeed, indeed. Excellent, excellent!"

"Very well. You seem to doubt that my writings can be trusted. Then take the writings of those from the high antiquity who followed the Dao and won the heart of Heaven, enjoying long-lasting fortune; then take the writings of those from the middle antiquity who followed the Dao and won the heart of Heaven; then take the writings of those from the lower antiquity who devoted themselves to the Dao, won the favor of Heaven, and long preserved themselves. Examine them all, from beginning to end, and you will find they align perfectly with my words, like matching compass and square. Only now have you gained great understanding, and only later will you come to trust my writings completely.

Nowadays, people grow ever more reckless, and the younger generations daily become more frivolous, contending over fate and testing their talents. The most foolish even claim that Heaven has no Dao and that Heaven does not respond. Yet even the earth does not deceive: plant millet and you reap millet; plant wheat and you reap wheat. The more effort and toil one invests, the finer the harvest. How much more so with Heaven?

Now Heaven has accumulated resentment, while the ignorant below teach one another to treat matters lightly, calling it wisdom. The younger generations grow ever more perverse, and thus arise calamities, anomalies, and strange omens—not just one or two. Heaven’s kindness to the lord of men is as deep as the bond between father and son, and it instructs him accordingly. Yet fools, seeing this, do not admonish their lord in due time; instead, they conceal and obstruct, severing the path to Heaven. Heaven grows ever more indignant, and later generations inherit the burden, worsening it beyond remedy. Though the emperor may possess the goodness of ten thousand men, he will still suffer harm without cause. Thus, those who do good are left in obscurity, as if their efforts were of no benefit. Is there not reason, then, for the foolish to claim that Heaven is without knowledge?"

"Now, hearing the Heavenly Master’s words, my heart feels as though it has been reborn—no different indeed. Excellent, excellent! Though this disciple has often troubled the Heavenly Master, risking death to ask these questions—beginning as if in error—I have now gained understanding and am overjoyed, with no regrets. For without knowledge, one does not ask, and without asking, one cannot attain clarity."

"Your words express the right intent. Very well. The writings are complete in every part—head, feet, belly, back, surface, and core—just as they were composed together with the many worthies. Do not ask further."

"Indeed, indeed."

The above documents addressed to the Heavenly Master span many matters from beginning to end, with decisions rendered. *The Forty-Eighth Method: Explanation of the Law of Karmic Inheritance*

An ignorant disciple bows twice and says: "The greatly wise, upon hearing the Master speak of one aspect, understand the explanations of the four aspects; the lesser wise, upon hearing the Master speak of one karmic burden, understand the explanations of the four burdens—thus is it easy for them to comprehend. But those who are foolish, benighted, and dull-witted, even when matters are shown and explained to them, still harbor doubts in their hearts. Therefore, I dare to present my questions to the Heavenly Master in full.

*Beginning here:*
Since the Master has resolved the karmic debts of retribution for High Heaven, lifted the karmic calamities of retribution for the Earth, dispelled the karmic misfortunes of retribution for emperors and kings, absolved the karmic transgressions of retribution for the common people, and relieved the karmic obligations of retribution for the twelve thousand beings..."
*Ending here.*

Moreover, this dull disciple ventures to inquire of Heaven, not daring to conceal any transgressions but to lay them all bare. I wish to hear in full: what is the meaning of this?

"Speak plainly."

"Now, if emperors, kings, and the people bear karmic inheritance, do all matters likewise possess their own karmic inheritance?"

"Excellent! You inquire of Heaven with such sincerity and care."

"Whenever I meet with the Heavenly Master, I always say that this disciple ventures to ask about matters of doubt on Heaven’s behalf—thus I dare not be anything but thorough."

"Excellent! You possess a mind both cautious and upright, and may be entrusted with affairs. Now, do you wish me to explain everything in full? I do not begrudge the difficulty, but fear the text may be too vast, making it hard to apply. To fully expound the karmic inheritance of the world would require no fewer than ten million words. Since this would be difficult to bear, I shall instead outline its general principles for you, so that all worthies may grasp the intent together—no different from a written contract."

"As the Heavenly Master says."

"Open both ears clearly, sit calmly, and listen with a settled mind."
"Yes, yes."

"Now then—Heaven and Earth give birth to all things, yet if one harms them without virtue, the world becomes clouded in chaos: households grow poor and wanting, the old and weak suffer cold and hunger, the county collects no taxes, and granaries stand ever empty. This misfortune originates in the harm done to things by Earth, yet people instead bear its burden. This is the first general principle—listen again with greater clarity.

If one master teaches ten disciples, and that master’s teaching is false and insincere, those ten disciples each go on to teach ten more, and already a hundred have heard falsehood. Those hundred each teach ten, and a thousand are misled; those thousand each teach ten, and ten thousand embrace false teachings. When ten thousand speak in all directions, the world is filled with error. Moreover, as the number of speakers grows vast, their words spread and confirm one another, becoming irreversible—hence they become the accepted doctrine. This began with a single person’s misstatement, yet it has caused all ordinary people to lose the true standard, throwing Heaven’s correct scriptures into disorder, shifting customs and altering mores. The world takes this as a grave affliction, yet cannot put a stop to it. Later generations suffer even more severely—this is the calamity of karmic inheritance, and clearly not the fault of those who come after.

Later ages, unaware of how distant its origins lie, instead blame their contemporaries, thus compounding the injustice. The resentment festers, the qi remains unresolved, and the harm grows daily worse. This is the second principle—Perfected One, listen again with greater clarity.

Suppose one man in a bustling city spreads a great deception, walking through the marketplace in all directions, wailing as he declares that the earth is about to collapse into a vast flood. The people of the city return and repeat his words, and ten thousand households learn of it. The old and young, great and small, all spread the tale, until the whole world knows—and thus the whole world is deceived. Later generations embellish the story, and those farthest removed suffer the most. This began with one man’s words—this is the burden of bearing responsibility for empty falsehoods. What fault lies with those who come after? Yet they are blamed instead. This is the third principle—Perfected One, listen again with greater clarity.

There stands on South Mountain a great tree, its canopy spreading hundreds of paces across the earth, yet its trunk is but one. Above, its branches, leaves, and fruits are beyond count; below, its roots do not hold firmly to the earth. When great wind and rain assail it, the countless branches, leaves, and fruits above are all damaged and die. This is the great karmic burden borne by the grasses and trees of the world. The fault lies in the root, not the branches, yet are those branches not wronged by being blamed? Now the branches bear no fault, yet suffer the flowing disaster of death without cause. Such is the nature of karmic inheritance—how can later generations be held guilty?

This is the fourth principle—Perfected One, listen again with greater clarity.

On South Mountain there is a poisonous qi. The mountain fails to contain it, and when the spring south wind blows, it carries the qi forth, obscuring the sun and moon. The world bears the blame for this, and the dead from its harm pile up in great numbers. Yet this poisonous qi originated solely from South Mountain’s release—why then do the people of the world bear its burden, falling ill and dying? Contemporaries say, ‘You are evil, therefore Heaven kills you,’ blaming the people. Is this not grievous injustice? These people bear no fault, yet suffer this disaster. Their souls cry out in grievance, and the living further blame them, their resentment congealing into qi that rises to move Heaven. The fault lies originally in the mountain’s evil wind—such is the burden of karmic inheritance.

This is the fifth principle—Perfected One, sit upright once more and listen carefully to my words.

The primordial Dao is always correct, never false or deceptive. Yet people, following the teachings of their ancestors, rulers, teachers, and fathers, have allowed small deviations from correctness—deviations in speech, in the correct Way of self-nurturance. They imitate one another, and later generations grow daily worse. The cause lies here. Over time, as teachings are passed down, none grasp the truth, and the world is filled with error, unable to restrain itself. Thus disasters and anomalies arise in countless forms, beyond reckoning—this is the result of long and ever longer accumulation.

The foolish, knowing nothing, instead blame their contemporary rulers and hold their own generation responsible. Are they not deeply wronged? The world is filled with error, yet none realize it. Though an emperor may possess the virtue of ten thousand men, what can he alone do? Yet now, how can people’s conduct be resolved? If food is exhausted and one desires more, yet the sick cannot eat and so perish—how can this be resolved? Now, in the interplay of yin and yang, all find complete joy. Yet though one has descendants who make offerings to the spirits seeking blessings, one remains childless—how can this be resolved?

People live in perfect joy, doing good and growing strong, yet suddenly become unworthy and evil—how can this be resolved? All these are the great effects of karmic inheritance. Yet people blame their contemporaries, and so governance cannot be made equitable. The transmission of error and falsehood has gone on too long—how can it be suddenly corrected? Thus the injustice continues, becoming entrenched over time, and Heaven takes pity.

Therefore, the August Way descends in response to the primordial qi. Do not find this strange.

What is the beginning? It is to contemplate and guard the One. Why? The One is the beginning of numbers; the One is the Dao of life; the One is the origin of primordial qi; the One is the guiding principle of Heaven. Thus one is made to guard and contemplate the One, from above to below.

When the affairs of the myriad things grow too great, and their branches do not return to their root, they become deeply confused and cannot be resolved—thus they must return to the root.

To resolve the burden of karmic inheritance, nothing is better than guarding the One. Guard the One for long, and Heaven will take pity. The One is the guiding principle of Heaven, the root of the myriad things. Contemplate the root, and its influence will extend to the branches.

Thus, when the sages of antiquity were about to undertake great deeds, they always looked up to observe the celestial patterns and looked down to examine the earth’s principles—clearly demonstrating the luminous efficacy of returning to the root."

"Does the Perfected One understand?"
"Yes, yes."
"Now you seem troubled—having just raised the initial cause of karmic inheritance, all matters under Heaven that involve karmic succession are like this. Do you comprehend?"
"Yes, yes. Now that the Heavenly Master has fully expounded the initial cause, this foolish student’s mental knot is untied."
"Good. Let me tell the Perfected One one crucial teaching: those in high antiquity who attained the Dao and were able to bring order to their governance simply excelled at self-cultivation, guarding their root. Those in middle antiquity who slightly lost it merely grew somewhat negligent in self-cultivation, losing their root. Those in later antiquity, failing to consider carefully, treated their bodies lightly, believing they could regain it again—thus they greatly lost it and threw their governance into chaos. Yet this is not the fault of the people of later antiquity; it is due to the adversity of karmic succession. The text has already repeated this heavily—I shall not speak further. A hundred words would be a hundred repetitions, to no benefit. Do not add more writing to the text. Today, the discourse has already been clearly entrusted to the Perfected One."
"Yes, yes."
"Go now, reflect on its essentials, and transmit them to a virtuous lord. Write the essentials to resolve karmic inheritance."
"Yes, yes."

**Right Inquiry on the Formula for Karmic Succession and Qi-Binding**

The Master said: "My name's eleven characters signify *stopping at illumination*: *Shi* (Master) refers precisely to the Master of August Heaven and the Divine Persons. *Yue* (says) is speech—my words ascend to Heaven, where I personally received the mandate, then descended to fully expound them for emperors, kings, and the myriad people, resolving the karmic retributions of *chengfu* that span hundreds of thousands of generations.

*Wu* (I) is myself; I am the divine person urgently dispatched by Heaven. Now, the disasters of *chengfu* flow in all four directions, tracing back to their root. Those who govern afterward all lose their way in following them, unable to sever or halt the cycle. Instead, they harm one another, causing profound suffering. Heaven regards this as a grave concern.

*Zi* (character) refers to the accumulated characters of the Heavenly Scriptures I now set forth. *Shi* (ten) means the scripture aligns perfectly with the true sincerity of Heaven—ten times ten, without a single falsehood. Those who obtain it, the many worthies, will each reflect deeply: their ancestors all bore *chengfu*. If they recite it without cease, the calamities of *chengfu*, great and small, will all be eradicated.

*Yi* (one) signifies that the essential Dao is upright and begins with *guarding the One*. If one guards the One without wavering, their understanding will grow daily, and profound delusion will dissolve. *Ming* (illumination) *zhi wei zhi* (stops at stopping): *zhi* (stopping) means sufficiency. Sufficiency enables life to proceed. Those who practice this Dao will only grow clearer with each day, never again sinking into ignorance and darkness.

The eleven characters form *shi* (scholar-official). *Ming zhi wei zhi* (illumination stops at stopping) is *chi* (crimson)—it means that when crimson *qi* attains this, it will flourish anew, and the king’s great illumination will shine. *Zhi* (stopping) is the sufficiency of the myriad things. When the myriad things first sprout, they spread their roots to establish their foundational sufficiency. Practicing this Dao restores the original *qi*, aligning with the heart of Heaven and Earth. It is the foremost and most excellent, thus called the Dao of the Supreme Sovereign.

*Bingwu ding-si* mark the ancestral beginning: *Bingwu* and *ding-si* are fire, crimson. *Bingwu* is pure yang; *ding-si* is pure yin. Yin and yang govern harmony. In all matters concerning yin and yang *qi*, they should harmonize and revitalize the world. *Wei* (to be) means to benefit emperors and kings by eliminating misfortune and peril. *Zu* (ancestor) means the first, embodying the virtue of the Three Sovereigns. *Shi* (beginning) means returning to the original source. Thus, practicing this Dao will restore the era of the Supreme Sovereign.

*Si kou zhi shi wanwu li* (Four mouths govern affairs, the principles of the myriad things): *Si* (four) with *kou* (mouth) means speech. Those who daily recite my scripture will obtain the true celestial characters, grasping their ultimate meaning. This aligns with the heart of Heaven, allowing the myriad things to each find their proper place without disorder—hence, the principles of the myriad things.

*Zi jin yong jiao zhi qi you* (The child’s kerchief uses the horn to govern its right): This refers to recitation. Reciting this scripture without cease will rectify all matters in an instant, aligning with Heaven’s will. Joy will be constant, with no lingering regrets.

*Qian long wu yong kan wei ji* (The hidden dragon is not used; *kan* serves as the record): The *qian long* (hidden dragon) is the returning *qi* of the first nine, the *jiazi* year. It is the day of the winter solstice, when Heaven and Earth begin anew. The dragon is the lesser yang of the east, the spirit of wood. Thus, the Dao of Heaven emerges through wood to activate the fire phase. When things are about to flourish, they must first open their gates.

When the Perfected One reaches the appointed time and the month is full, this scripture should be cast into an open and luminous place. *Kai* (open) means to clear, to unblock, to reach. Opening the south will further harmonize the yang *qi*, dissolving the calamitous gatherings of *chengfu*.

*Qian* (hidden) means to conceal, as the Dao, having reached its destination, retreats and hides. *Wu* (not) means dare not or not yet. Those who first see the text do not yet know how to practice it. *Yong* (use) means to govern, to act. Heaven now intends this scripture to eliminate disasters.

If it emerges in a *xuanjia* year, the ruler of that time may not deeply fathom its meaning or be able to apply it. Thus, it says *wu yong* (not used)—seeing the celestial patterns, one dare not rashly implement it. Those who trust and apply it will see immediate results, a clear resonance. This alignment with Heaven is why there is resonance.

*Kan wei ji* (*kan* serves as the record): *Zi* (child) is called *kan*. *Jia* is Heaven, the guiding principle, yang. *Kan* is the child, water, yin, the record. Thus, Heaven and Earth are always united, their guiding principles recorded in the initial emergence of *xuanjiazi*. This can serve as the guiding principle for a virtuous ruler—hence, *kan wei ji*.

This is the Supreme Sovereign’s Heavenly Scripture, revealed to virtuous rulers as the true canon. The scripture severs deviance with a cord, taking *xuanjia* as its subtle beginning. All things that arise take *jia* as their head and *zi* as their root—thus, it is presented in sequence from *jiazi*.

Those who see it will enjoy long life: *Ren* (person) refers specifically to the emperor, the one of supreme virtue who readily awakens to and practices the scripture. According to the auspicious signs, they do not doubt the Dao of Heaven. Deeply grasping its meaning, they attain longevity. *Shou* (longevity) means fulfilling one’s heavenly years. *Chang* (long) means boundless. *Jiu* (durable) means enduring.

*Dwelling between Heaven and Earth, merely alive*: *Ju* (dwelling) means to reside. To reside between Heaven and Earth and merely be alive is to study the true Dao. Fleeting and ornate texts cannot sustain life. The calamities of *chengfu* all stem from insubstantial doctrines—Heaven now severs them.

*Governing a million people, immortality awaits*: *Zhi* (governing) means to rectify. Heaven uses this scripture to rectify the hearts of the many worthies, each healing their illnesses, guarding the true and expelling the deviant. *Xian ke dai* (immortality awaits) means that when the world hears of it, the true Dao will flourish and emerge, rushing to assist the virtuous ruler. Practicing the true Dao is the method to enliven people—hence, immortality awaits.

*Those who skillfully heal illnesses must not deceive or endanger*: All people are foolish, failing to consider their own well-being. They all use false and deceptive texts, needlessly deceiving and endangering themselves—how lamentable!"

Reversing their fate, they incur Heaven’s severe punishment and bear the great burden of *chengfu*. Thus Heaven compels them to abandon florid texts and each hold fast to what is true and real, preserving it through diligent practice day and night. This enables every person to benefit their own body, so that none will again deceive or endanger themselves.

*"Joy in the Chang’an marketplace"*: *Joy* means nothing brings greater joy than the advent of the Supreme Peace *qi* from the Heavenly Emperor. *Hu* expresses awe at the singularly vast and unmatched virtue. *Long* signifies that those who practice this Dao will see their virtue and goodness endure without end. *An* means no further peril or ruin. Those who enact this Dao will see all *chengfu* punishments from Heaven and Earth dispelled, and thus abide in boundless, expansive peace, free from care. *Market* refers to the place where all under Heaven gather together. Those who practice this scripture will see the nation’s people flourish abundantly, like the throngs in a bustling marketplace.

*"Granting people a lifespan like the Queen Mother of the West"*: *Granting people* refers to emperors and kings who possess Heavenly virtue and delight in enacting upright texts. *Ru* means compliance—those who fully comply with this scripture follow the Heavenly Dao, and those who attain it will know great fortune, free from misfortune. *West* signifies that all people dwell in the true Dao within their hearts. *King* denotes that emperors who govern by upholding the Heavenly Dao will flourish and reign, their governance so excellent it is peerless. *Mother* is the proof of long life, the elder of the spirits.

*"Like the four seasons returning in cycle"*: *Bi* means comparison—just as the four seasons succeed one another, generating and completing each other without mutual harm or injury, so too will their governance be free of punishment.

*"The ninety-character talisman is transmitted to the fangshi"*: *Nine* signifies thoroughness and completion—those who practice this will see their virtue thoroughly harmonize with the hearts of Heaven, Earth, yin, yang, and the myriad things. *Ten* means tenfold resonance, free of contrived texts. *Character* refers to the celestial script above and below, circulating fully through the Dao. *Transmit* means trust, and thus written proof is created to transmit it faithfully. *Fang* signifies great rectitude—holding fast to this Dao and swiftly conveying it to a virtuous ruler can dispel the misfortunes of *chengfu*, and their governance will be upright and greatly correct. *Shi* refers to those of resolute will and single-minded purpose—such individuals, with sincere hearts, can be instructed and entrusted with this task, sent forth to propagate this Dao.

The efficacy of my talisman’s teachings will soon be witnessed. 〈End〉

Over time, these accumulated, and now later generations, though innocent, suffer their consequences, inheriting their misfortunes. Thus, what precedes is *cheng*, and what follows is *fu*. As for *fu*, the flow of calamity does not arise from the governance of a single person—it connects and compounds, with earlier and later generations bearing it in turn. Hence, it is called *fu*. *Fu* means that ancestors impose upon their descendants. Illnesses and misfortunes are passed down in this way, and disasters cannot be easily eradicated. When one is cut off, another arises. I reverently received this scripture from Heaven, for this Dao alone can wholly sever such cycles. Thus, it is most precious and without equal. Do you, Perfected One, understand?"

"Indeed, indeed."

"Most wondrous! Most wondrous!"
"Go now, ask no more."
"Yes, yes."

*Right: Explanation of the Master’s Cipher Text of Ninety Characters*
*True Contract Formula Fifty-First*

The Perfected One stepped forward and asked, "Of all matters under Heaven, which are right and which are wrong?"
"When tested, they yield immediate response, affairs reach fruition, and those afflicted with knotted illnesses find relief—these are all right. When tested, matters fail to respond, actions bear no success, and those with knotted illnesses remain unresolved—these are all wrong, and not the fault of any single person."
"Excellent! Your words are truly so. Though few, they suffice to resolve ten thousand myriad affairs. I have nothing to add to your words. If one wishes to discern right from wrong, all must be measured by this standard. Cast aside all doubt, for this is the talisman that summons truth."
"What does this mean?"
"In all matters, whether trustworthy or not, why must one necessarily investigate and question? The sages and worthies of old simply observed the evidence of a person’s conduct to know the truth—clear as the sun and moon. Your teaching on the accumulation of good is immutable. If you wish to understand my scripture, take all proof and verification from this. Do you understand, Perfected One?"
"Yes, yes."

"Go forth with this, and call it the True Contract. Guard it well, and do not cast it into the lower realms—let it serve as your decisive strategy and written decree."

**Right: Summoning-Truth Talisman, Verification Script, and True Contract**
