*Tai Ping Jing, Scroll 40: "Exerting Effort in the Good Dao, Fifty-Second"*

"Perfected One, how many adversities do the people of the world generally face?"
"What do you mean?"
"I speak of those who are ordinary and unmatched—how many pressing adversities do people endure? Though their adversities are many, are none of them named?"
"They cannot be named."
"You do not yet know. The people of the world face four adversities."
"What are they?"
"First, when one is born of parents, in youth one cannot bear to leave their side—this is the first adversity. Next, as one grows and matures, a woman wishes to marry, a man to take a wife; unable to overcome their passions, they become bound by love and cannot part—this is the second adversity. Then, having fallen in love and borne children, as husband and wife age, their appearance becomes unlovely, while their young children are dear and must be cared for—this is the third adversity. Finally, when the children have grown and no longer need support, one ages further and can no longer move about—this is the fourth adversity. After these four adversities, if one finds a wise teacher and reflects deeply to uphold the Dao, it is still possible. Those of exceptional talent with heavenly mandate may attain liberation; others may gain longevity; still others may enjoy brief happiness in life, while their hun and po dwell below the earth, where they may once more experience joy."
"What does this mean?"
"In the underworld, the newly deceased are all questioned about their actions and experiences in life. Based on these, their names are recorded in the registers, and they are held accountable for their deeds. Thus, one must take precautions in all matters, for safety and peril are both determined by one’s own actions. Perfected One, be vigilant. Do you heed this warning?"

""Yes, yes. The Celestial Master has instructed me with teachings unseen before."
"So it is. The reason I instruct and teach you is that I see you constantly harbor good intentions. I fear the Perfected One may grow weary, thus I clearly demonstrate these admonitions."
"Yes, yes."
"Perfected One, what do you now seek in your studies?"
"I seek to reach the very end of my years."
"Excellent is your aspiration—this may indeed be called grasping the intent of the Dao. Yet, in all human conduct, one takes the end of life as the limit, differing only in whether good or evil is exhausted."
"What does this mean? I wish to hear it."
"Those who maintain goodness in their studies, pass their lives in joy and pleasure, become joyful wandering ghosts, and by law do not encounter sorrow or suffering. Those who exhaust themselves in sorrow become sorrowful ghosts, while those who exhaust themselves in evil become evil ghosts. These are all manifest matters, knowable to all. Yet people refuse to do good and delight their hun and shen—truly, their transgression is grave."
"What does this mean?"
"Human life receives the true qi of Heaven and Earth, the four seasons and five phases, uniting to form a person—this is the inherited body of one’s ancestors. This body may dwell within Heaven, Earth, the four seasons, and the five phases. The bodies of the ancestors ever delight in goodness and know no sorrow, cycling endlessly through rebirth. Yet later generations, unworthy, instead long afflict the body of Heaven, Earth, the four seasons, and the five phases, causing it to suffer unjust death, still grieving their hun and po. Thus, the foolish scholar, failing to consider deeply, cannot long endure. Therefore, they hasten toward death, and upon dying, harbor no regret. The spirit merely pities itself in vain, needlessly incurring sorrow and resentment among these lesser beings. For this reason, the great sages of antiquity, considering deeply and planning far ahead, knew this well—thus they studied without cease.

Those who, as rulers, delight in contemplating great peace, align with the heart of Heaven, and their merit is doubled. Their hun and shen ever wander in joy, uniting with the good qi of Heaven. Those who cannot bring order to their governance fail to align with Heaven’s heart, do not gain Heaven’s favor, and achieve no merit in the heavens above. When their end comes, their hun and shen are held solely accountable in the underworld, dwelling with evil qi. Thus, the supreme sages of highest antiquity knew this well—hence their diligence. The foolish, failing to consider deeply, incur punishment from Heaven in life and from Earth in death—how terrifying!

"Your disciple is dull and ignorant; I do not wish to hear this."
"Excellent! Since you have come to study, if you do not wish to hear this, then strive earnestly to do good."
"Yes, yes. Celestial Master, dwelling in this realm, you have allowed me to know Heaven’s mandate and receive profound instruction. How may one escape this fate?"
"Well said! You need only urgently transmit my writings on the Dao, so that all under Heaven may practice them, all contemplating their true essence, their thoughts aligning with the Great Dao. Then, knowing the source of their transgressions, the burden of inherited responsibility will be lifted. Heaven and Earth will rejoice greatly, and the years may return to the age of highest antiquity, even doubled."

"Enough!" "Excellent, excellent!"

"Go now, the minor discourse is complete. Divine One, exert yourself diligently; return another day."
"Yes, yes."

"Having received the writings, ponder them thoroughly from beginning to end. To study without mastery is to remain in vagueness; seeking affairs without form or image, thoughts unrefined, the spirit has no means to proceed."

"Excellent, excellent!"

**Right: The Celestial Master’s Admonition—On the Burden of Inherited Responsibility for Those Who Fail to Exert Themselves in Life and Die as Wandering Spirits**
**Method for Resolving Origins and Ends, Fifty-Third**

"Divine One, step forward. Since you have come to study, should one broadly comprehend the intent of the Dao—is it better to follow few or many?"
"Indeed, one fully equipped with abundance may follow many."
"Alas! You have not yet broadly grasped the essential intent of the Dao."

"Now, Heaven is One, yet in reverse it becomes Earth as Two—what is the meaning? Earth is Two, yet in reverse it becomes Man as Three—why? This foolish student wishes to hear the intent of their mutual operation."
"Very well. Earth serves as Heaven’s agent, and Man serves as Earth’s agent. Thus, when Heaven is pleased, it commands the Earth to make all things upon it greatly flourish this year. When Heaven is not pleased, though Earth may wish to nurture, it causes things to turn foul. When Earth is good, those dwelling upon it—its people—turn to goodness. This is the clear effect of their mutual agency.

Thus, the causes of order and chaos are manifold. When one fails to align with Heaven’s heart, one must return to the root. When a person’s words are excessive yet fail to reveal truth, one must return to the essential root—only then may their words and affairs stand firm.

Therefore, a single word that succeeds is its original text; a second iteration halts at forming phrases. A third word halts and instead becomes an explanation of difficulty, drifting far from truth—hence the need for clarification. A fourth word halts and reverts to rhetoric; a fifth reverts to falsehood; a sixth to deception; a seventh to destruction; an eighth to dispersion, estrangement from the Dao, and ever-greater distance; a ninth to great chaos; a tenth to annihilation and ruin.

Thus, classics change at ten, and further transmission leads to corruption and collapse. In all matters of ruin, one must return to the root—revert to the One as the primordial beginning. Therefore, Heaven’s numbers begin at One and end at Ten; this is the natural nature of the Heavenly Dao.

Thus, the sages of antiquity, when inquiring into affairs, first divined once—its auspice or inauspice was so, guarding the root, for the Celestial Spirits descended to inform them. A second divination was informed by the Earth Spirits; a third by the Human Spirits. Beyond this, all is deception and unfit for divination. Thus, hexagram numbers miss the mark, and excessive human rhetoric loses its value."

"Excellent! Excellent! Now, as the Celestial Master always pities those who fall short, I humbly beg one more word!"
"Proceed calmly!"

"Why do numbers end at Ten?"
"Excellent! You have grasped the essence of this question’s method. Now—Heaven’s numbers begin at One and end at Ten—why?

Heaven is initially One, descending to unite with Earth as Two, where Yin and Yang are complete and jointly generate. All things first sprout in the North, the primordial *qi* arising at *zi*, turning to the Northeast to spread roots at *jiao*, turning to the East to emerge and flourish, turning to the Southeast to grow branches and leaves, turning to the South to thrive, turning to the Southwest to incline toward abundance, turning to the West to mature, turning to the Northwest to conclude.

When things conclude, they must return to the beginning—thus *hai*, where two embrace One, becomes the origin of the Three Sovereigns. Therefore, *hai* is the kernel, the first coagulation of the seed—hence water begins to congeal in the tenth month. *Ren* is *ren* (to bear), for once borne, it must grow daily greater. Thus *zi* is growth, and at Three, the *qi* of Yin and Yang achieves harmony, all fully formed, returning to the initial arising—hence reverting to the root, named *jiazi*.

The Dao of Heaven in generating things must circulate completely, observing the *qi* of Heaven and Earth, the four seasons, and the Five Phases to achieve completion. If one *qi* is insufficient, there is immediately deficiency. Thus, the root lies in the circulation of Heaven and Earth through the eight directions—all numbers reach completion at Ten."

"Divine One, do you now understand?"
"Yes, yes. Excellent, excellent!"

"Truly, I have received profound grace."
"Do not express gratitude, why so? The merit of master and disciple is vast and weighty—comparable to parents giving birth to a child, which cannot be repaid or dissolved through thanks."

"Pray, what do you mean?"
"Before parents give birth to a child, fools may cast their seed carelessly into the wild, where it takes root in the earth and grows into grasses or trees, unaware that it was meant to become human. How could such a reckless offering ever speak? Thus it becomes mere vegetation. Only when Yin and Yang unite does a child come to be—how could this compare to becoming grasses or trees?

Once born, if a person fails to seek a worthy master and instead follows a base and foolish one, they are taught evil, led into depravity, and may even cause death and destruction. Their own transgressions remain, and their entire household is ruined. Some are born yet never pursue learning, becoming fools. Such ignorant ones live in sorrow and die in suffering, their sins lingering even in the underworld. Their souls, unable to roam freely or find joy, cannot even become benevolent spirits after death.

Yet a worthy master teaches even the lowliest and most ignorant, transforming them into good people. If they persist in goodness without ceasing, they become virtuous; if they persist in virtue, they attain wisdom; if they persist in wisdom, they gain deep understanding of the true Dao; if they persist in guarding the Dao, they attain immortality; if they persist in immortality, they become perfected beings; if they persist in perfection, they become divine; if they persist in divinity, their virtue equals that of Heaven; if they persist in equaling Heaven, their virtue equals that of primordial *qi*. Primordial *qi* envelops the eight directions of Heaven and Earth—nothing exists that does not receive its breath and come to life.

Virtue then extends to cover the eight directions of Heaven and Earth, and the spirit draws sustenance from them. All under Heaven offer sacrifices and partake in its bounty, yet they remain ever fearful of negligence, unable to fully attain it. Such is the merit of a worthy master who cultivates a good disciple—how could one ever express sufficient gratitude?"

"Most astonishing! This foolish one has spoken carelessly, transgressing taboos."

“””Why so unceasingly modest? You are a perfected being indeed. Master Xingjue has made you understand whether gratitude can be expressed or not.”

“Indeed, indeed.”

*Here ends the discourse on the essential principles of merit between fathers and sons, masters and disciples.*

**Chapter 54: Lesheng’s Attainment of the Heavenly Heart Method**

[Opening]
The perfected one continued, “In the conduct of ordinary people and the governance of kings, what is the most excellent?”

“To extend compassion without harm—this, like the movement of Heaven, is the most excellent.”

“Your words may be said to grasp the intent of the Dao. Yet in governance, nothing surpasses emulating Heaven. That said, there must be an order of precedence.”

“What do you mean? This foolish one may strain to speak once, but will not presume to do so again. May the Heavenly Master expound it?”

“Very well. The conduct of ordinary people and the governance of kings—what is most excellent in human affairs? Nothing surpasses constantly desiring to delight in life, eagerly as one parched with thirst. Only then is it permissible.

Next, nothing surpasses delighting in accomplishment, ever yearning to bring things to fruition as though grieving for one’s own body. Only then is it permissible.

Next, nothing surpasses excelling in benevolent bestowal—when seeing others in poverty and want, to feel sorrow for them as though grieving over one’s own hunger and cold. Only then is it permissible.

Next, nothing surpasses skillfully establishing laws, not delighting in harm but merely acting out of fear. Only then is it permissible.

Next, when people commit transgressions, nothing surpasses governing them without driving them into crime. Only then is it permissible.

Next, when people have already fallen into crime, to refrain from deeply harming them in one’s heart. Only then is it permissible.

Next, when people commit capital offenses and matters are beyond remedy, to ensure their punishment does not extend to their families or neighbors. Only then is it permissible.

Next, when crimes reach families and neighbors, to wish to single out only the guilty, taking care never to exterminate an entire lineage. Only then is it permissible.

For humans are the divine lineage of Heaven and Earth. Extermination is called severing the divine lineage of Heaven and Earth, inflicting grievous harm upon the very body of Heaven and Earth. The damage is profound, and in time, Heaven will exterminate the human world in turn.

It is no easy matter to become the ancestor of a family. One ought to consider posterity and not impose the calamity of inherited burden upon descendants. Thus, the sage in governance constantly contemplates great peace, ensuring that punishments are established but unused. The reason for this is to consider posterity.

Now, perfected one, have you grasped these subtle words?”

“Indeed, indeed.”

[End]

[Appendix] Someone asked: “Among the ways of governance by emperors, kings, and feudal lords, which is most excellent?”

The reply: “To extend compassion without harm—this, like the movement of Heaven, is most excellent.”

“In governance, nothing surpasses mirroring the great image of Heaven. Yet there must be degrees of priority.”

“What does this mean?”

“Of all things most excellent, nothing surpasses delighting in life, hastening to it as if parched with thirst—only then is it permissible. Next is to rejoice in others’ goodness as one’s own. Next is to bestow upon others: when seeing the destitute, to regard their sorrowful hearts as if suffering hunger and cold—only then is it permissible. Next is to establish laws, merely to instill fear and thereby restrain—only then is it permissible. Next, when one commits a grave offense, in governance, to avoid driving them into transgression—only then is it permissible. Next, when one commits an offense or violates the law, if the matter is unavoidable, to ensure it does not implicate their family or neighbors—only then is it permissible. Next, when punishment extends to neighbors, to single out only the guilty, taking care never to cut off their lineage.

Humans are the divine lineage of Heaven and Earth. To harm the body of Heaven and Earth is to invite profound calamity. Do not impose the calamity of inherited burden upon descendants. Constantly contemplate great peace to dispel the need for punishments.”

“Perfected one, proceed.”

“Yes, yes.”

“Perfected One, Perfected One, have you nothing more to say? Are you merely being modest?”

“In a single word: my lineage is bound to the earth, my fate tied to Kunlun. Today, the Celestial Master’s mandate resides in Heaven, in the Purple Palace of the North Pole. Now the earth stands in emptiness; I reverently receive Heaven’s dispensation. As a disciple, I must comply and submit, emulating the earth’s empty heart to respectfully receive the Celestial Master’s teachings. Only then may the essential words of the supreme Dao be... ... ... ... without the bond of master and disciple. Merely calling it an exchange... ... ... ... ... would be to confuse learning with impurity. ... ... ... ... ... ... If decrees and teachings obscure the Dao, if every matter is reduced to a single right or wrong, such discourse cannot be transmitted as a model for emperors and kings—thus I dare not speak.”

“Why be so modest! I wish to discuss and deliberate with you on what is good; there is no harm in speaking. ... ... ... ... Why hesitate?”

“Living beings emerge in sequence: some know much, others little; conduct has its hierarchy, dwellings their rank. What I might say cannot compare to the Celestial Master’s words. The words of a petty man are not equal to the vision of elders who have witnessed the Dao, to the clarity of those who lead. The Celestial Master, transcending the dull and ignorant like me, enables us to awaken, to discern the difficulty of good and evil—how could this be achieved in a single moment? I pray you do not abandon me midway, but act for the sake of the August Heaven and Revered Earth.”

“Very well. Since these are Heaven’s words, I shall not defer to you. But you have seemed somewhat reticent, so I asked.”

“I dare not be reticent. Now, hearing the Celestial Master speak, I am both overjoyed and astonished. Why? I rejoice at having met you; I fear that my dull and shallow learning is incomplete, and that you will depart. Now I long to question you urgently, as one parched with thirst craves drink. I pray that the Celestial Master transmit the Dao to this disciple, entrusting it to a virtuous ruler who can put it into practice. Then yin and yang will each find their place, and all the great afflictions of inherited burdens under heaven will be wholly cured.”

“Excellent are your words! Upon careful examination of my writings, the Dao is nearly complete. Ordered from highest to lowest, it shines brighter than the sun and moon, each part mutually reinforcing. If one contemplates and practices it today, all illnesses will be dispelled and resolved, and all will exclaim in joy and admiration.”

“Yes, yes.”

“On the Right: The Sequence of Treatment and the Method of Restoring the Celestial Mind—Discourse on Humility Between Master and Disciple
*Comprehensive Collated Edition of the Scripture of Great Peace, Scroll Forty-One, Part Seven of the Bing Section*
*Scroll Forty-One of the Scripture of Great Peace*
*Fifty-Fifth Text: Ancient Writings and Named Methods*

“Day by day I grow more foolish and benighted, my understanding ever more obscured. With reverence I bow twice and ask to inquire of one matter.”

“Speak plainly.”

The Perfected One then said: “I have renewed my efforts in study without ceasing, to question matters on behalf of Heaven.”

“My duty is to transmit the Perfected One’s teachings; I dare not withhold anything. Speak quickly.”

“Very well. Now, the lesser scriptures of the Dao are regarded as the Celestial Classics. We have collated the words of sages from the high, middle, and low antiquity to form the *Sacred Classics*; collated the words of those of great virtue from the high, middle, and low antiquity to form the *Virtue Classics*; and collated the words of the worthy and enlightened from the high, middle, and low antiquity to form the *Worthy Classics*. Yet reflecting on the Celestial Master’s words, I cannot deeply grasp the intent behind this collation. I pray the Celestial Master illuminate its gate and threshold, clarifying the proper sequence, so that a virtuous ruler may obtain it as a solemn teaching, and command all worthy ones to cultivate and refine their intentions within it.”

“Indeed! How refined is the Perfected One’s inquiry—ever should it be thus. Excellent, excellent!”

“Very well, I shall expound it fully. Perfected One, follow along and record it yourself—take care not to lose my words.

To begin: I speak for Heaven and Earth, composing this for the ruler of supreme virtue, that it may dispel the accumulated calamities of karmic inheritance since the opening of Heaven and Earth. This is no idle speech; should I speak falsely, I would incur the wrath of August Heaven and Mysterious Earth, and betray the noble and enlightened rulers of high virtue and power. The gravity of such transgression would be profound—do you understand?”

“Indeed, indeed.”

“Now, regarding the collation of Daoist texts from the high, middle, and low antiquity: suppose all the worthy ones together read and examine the Daoist writings of past and present. If in one scroll they find a single virtuous character, or a single virtuous formula or matter, they record and extract it. One scroll yields one virtue; ten scrolls yield ten virtues; a hundred scrolls yield a hundred virtues; a thousand scrolls yield a thousand virtues; ten thousand scrolls yield ten thousand virtues; a hundred million scrolls yield a hundred million virtues. If one scroll yields ten virtues, that is ten billion virtues; if one scroll yields a hundred virtues, that is a hundred billion virtues.

To proceed: they transcribe and record these, gathering them in one place. All the worthy ones together examine the writings of past and present, transcribing everything in full. They then assemble them by category, each according to its school, removing repetitions and redundancies. Following this, they arrange the essential texts in order, and thus the investigation is complete, deeply comprehending the essential intent of Heaven, Earth, humanity, and the myriad things from antiquity to the present. From this, they compose the text, and the *Celestial Classics* are formed. Do you understand?”

“Excellent, excellent!”

“You have now grasped it.”

“Collating the sacred scriptures of high antiquity, middle antiquity, and recent antiquity, if one scroll yields one virtue, then ten scrolls yield ten, a hundred scrolls yield a hundred, a thousand scrolls yield a thousand, ten thousand scrolls yield ten thousand, and a hundred million scrolls yield a hundred million. If one scroll yields ten virtues, that is ten billion; if one scroll yields a hundred virtues, that is a hundred billion. The worthy and enlightened together record and transcribe these, gathering them in one virtuous place. Having fully collated them, they arrange them by category, allowing the worthy and enlightened to jointly order them, removing repetitions and redundancies—thus the *Sacred Classics* are formed. Do you understand, Perfected One?”

“Indeed, indeed.”

“You have now grasped it. Collating the words of the worthy and enlightened from high antiquity, middle antiquity, and recent antiquity, if the most virtuous among them yield one virtue per scroll, then ten scrolls yield ten, a hundred scrolls yield a hundred, a thousand scrolls yield a thousand, ten thousand scrolls yield ten thousand, and a hundred million scrolls yield a hundred million. If one scroll yields ten virtues, that is ten billion; if one scroll yields a hundred virtues, that is a hundred billion. Once this is complete, they again arrange them by category, allowing them to follow one another. The worthy and enlightened jointly order them, removing repetitions and redundancies, compiling and setting them in place—thus the *Classics of the Worthy* are formed. Do you understand, Perfected One?”

“Indeed, indeed.”

“You have already understood this. Now, if we gather and collate all Daoist texts and scriptures, along with the writings of the many worthies and the virtuous words and decisive matters from the mouths of the people—recording all that is good and assembling them together in one place—once this is complete, we then deliberate with the many worthy, enlightened, and greatly virtuous, refining them by category to illuminate subtleties, removing repetitions and redundancies, ordering their words and texts, and setting them in place. This is called obtaining the writings of Heaven and Earth and the words of human nature, thoroughly and definitively settled, so that their virtuous and decisive matters suffer no omission, not even as slight as a hair’s breadth. This Dao of the Dao is named the *Scripture of the Utmost Profundity of Heaven and Earth’s Yin and Yang*, which for ten thousand myriad generations cannot again be altered.”

“Excellent! Excellent!”

“Proceed! Perfected One, you may be said to have awakened.”

“This foolish student falls short. Now I wish to ask one further doubt.”

“Speak.”

“Since the opening of Heaven and Earth, long ages have passed. The Yellow River and Luo River have produced writings and diagrams; now and then divine scriptures have emerged, or sacred birds and beasts have brought them, spitting forth writings that accumulate in great number—originally not of one source. The works of sages and worthies have likewise accumulated in abundance, each ultimately having its own matter. Master, what doubt, what observation, what insight led you to instruct the many worthy and enlightened of later ages to jointly gather and collate the writings and words of the literati from ancient and modern times?”

“Indeed, there was something observed and seen. I dared not idly and falsely trouble the worthy and virtuous of later ages. Now I have been sent forth into the world to relieve the great moral lord of his *chengfu*—the accumulated disasters and lingering poisons of Heaven and Earth’s judgments since the opening of the world. The celestial writings, sacred scriptures, and words of worthies from ancient and modern times are already fully sufficient, but I worry that they are scattered, each excelling in but one matter. Now, if we follow the method of a single school, we cannot entirely eliminate the calamities and transformations of Heaven and Earth. Thus, disasters continue to flow unceasingly, passing on their burdens to later generations, who suffer increasing afflictions and illnesses. Therefore, Heaven pities the virtuous lord and bears the *chengfu* for them. The harmony of Heaven is for the sake of later generations, who cannot live alone, for they inherit the accumulated disasters and faults. The true fault lies with the former sages and worthies, each excelling in one thing yet all failing to comprehend fully, all having some deficiency. Heaven, knowing their incompleteness, thus periodically produces the writings and diagrams of the Yellow and Luo Rivers and other divine scriptures, which likewise differ in their words. The great sages and worthies, appearing in different ages, each accomplished one matter, their words likewise differing. Thus, each has its shortcomings, each its strengths and weaknesses. This makes clear that none could fully and thoroughly know the ultimate meaning of the utmost profundity. Therefore, between Heaven and Earth, residual disasters persist, continuing without end, varying only in severity.

This is why Heaven has calculated and now produces these writings, exhaustively complete in their upper and lower limits. Only then will sages be born again, with nothing left to create, nothing to add, no room for further words, nothing to contribute to the great virtuous lord of Heaven and Earth. Even if Heaven were to produce another sage, his words would still excel in but one endeavor, leaving residual disasters and poisons as before, no different from the former sages and worthies. Therefore, Heaven has commanded me to deeply instruct the Perfected One and entrust the virtuous lord with these writings, to show them to the many worthy and enlightened, to gather and collate all the words and decisive matters from the writings and mouths of the world, so that upper and lower may complement one another. Removing repetitions and redundancies, we set down their essential words, essential texts, and decisive matters, recording them to form scriptures. Only thus will the true writings and correct characters of Heaven and Earth’s virtuous words fully emerge. Once all that is false and deceptive is entirely removed, the great illnesses of Heaven and Earth will be wholly dispelled, lingering disasters utterly extinguished, and the people and all things will each dwell in their proper place, no longer suffering misfortune or hardship. Therefore, Heaven has instructed me to gather and collate them. My compilation of these writings is not mere words—it is proof and verification. Follow my writings and act accordingly, and the calamities, strange transformations, illnesses, treacherous ministers, inauspicious omens, and false and deceptive things of Heaven and Earth will all be removed, no different than clearing away clouds on a dark day. By this, my words and writings are verified, □□ with not a single error in ten thousand. But if my writings are not diligently employed, though I respectfully receive Heaven’s words and utterances and see its writings, if they are not used, how can Heaven idly dispel disasters? If the writings themselves are in chaos, people will likewise be in chaos, and disasters will have no means of being removed. Do you understand, Perfected One?”

“Indeed, indeed.”

“Proceed! You have already understood.”

“May I venture to ask about a matter of doubt?”
“Speak plainly.”

“Since the opening of Heaven and Earth, all divine sages and worthies have been born of Heaven, and those who have successively presided over the words of Heaven and Earth have all established laws for rulers to dispel disasters and pacify the world. Now, when emperors and kings follow and employ them, they do not deviate from the hidden intent of Heaven or the norms of yin and yang, and the writings they produce each bear their own titles. Should the writings on the Dao and virtue composed by the Celestial Master be ranked among these?”

“Excellent indeed is your question, Perfected One.”

“Then, they are called *The Governance of the Great Cavern Reaching Heaven*—why is this the correct name for *The Governance of the Great Cavern Reaching Heaven*?”

“Well, *great* means great; those who practice this achieve governance that is most excellent, supreme, and unparalleled. *Cavern* means that its Dao and virtue, whether good or ill, thoroughly harmonize with the yin and yang of Heaven and Earth, the inner and outer of the six directions, and nothing fails to respond. All is governed with careful goodness, and every being attains its proper place. This Way gathers and examines all the finest writings since the opening of Heaven and Earth—those of Heaven, Earth, humanity, and the divine—compiling them into the *Scripture of the Cavern’s Ultimate*. When emperors and kings follow and employ it, commanding all worthies to join in practicing it, then within the four seas and four borders, disasters are entirely swept away and removed. Such governance is as luminously clear as the Cavern itself, resembling the state of Heaven, Earth, and the divine spirits. Thus, it is named *The Governance of the Great Cavern Reaching Heaven*. Do you understand, Perfected One?”

“Indeed, indeed.”

“How astonishing! How astonishing indeed!”

“Excellent, you have now awakened to this understanding.”

*Right: Collated Texts of Ancient, Middle, and Recent Eras—Human Writings and Oral Instructions*
*Comprehensive Collation of the Scripture of Great Peace, Scroll Forty-Two, Part Bing, Number Eight*
*Scroll Forty-Two of the Scripture of Great Peace*
*Method Fifty-Six of the Nine Heavens for Dispelling the Disasters of Former Kings*

“In the principle of Heaven, nine kinds of people govern yin and yang—how is this so?”

“Now, humanity is the chief regulator of the myriad things. The formless spirit-people of entrusted qi are charged with governing primordial qi; the great spirit-people are charged with governing Heaven; the Perfected are charged with governing Earth; the Immortals are charged with governing the four seasons; the Great Dao-people are charged with governing the five phases; the Sages are charged with governing yin and yang; the Worthies are charged with governing writings and transmitting teachings; the common people are charged with governing grasses, trees, and the five grains; and servants and slaves are charged with governing wealth and goods. How is this so?

All matters are governed according to their kind. The formless spirit-people of entrusted qi resemble primordial qi, thus they govern primordial qi. The great spirit-people possess form and resemble Heaven in their great divinity, thus they govern Heaven. The Perfected are devoted and trustworthy, resembling Earth, thus they govern Earth. The Immortals transform and change, resembling the four seasons, thus they govern the four seasons. The Great Dao-people excel in divining fortune and misfortune, resembling the five phases, thus they govern the five phases. The Sages preside over harmonious qi, resembling yin and yang, thus they govern yin and yang. The Worthies manage writings and articulate speech, resembling texts, thus they govern writings. The common people are confused and ignorant, resembling the myriad things, thus they govern the myriad things. Servants and slaves produce wealth, resembling goods and currency—for when rich, they possess them, and when poor, they do not, yet they may circulate freely—thus they govern wealth and goods.

Now, the August Heaven appoints offices without overriding their will, each following its kind without error. To act contrary to this brings great harm.”

Thus, in appointing offices, August Heaven ensures that all common people must follow this principle. The Sages of antiquity deeply understood and upheld this, never deviating from Heaven’s intent and thereby securing Heaven’s favor.

“Do you, Perfected One, now comprehend this?”
“Excellent! Excellent!”
“What I have spoken is to admonish you, Perfected One, that you may not err.”
“Indeed, indeed.”
“Go forth and strive diligently.”
“This humble student’s heart remains entangled and unable to resolve this: these nine kinds of people each perform different tasks—how do they benefit the king’s governance?”

“When governance aligns with Heaven’s intent, these nine qi harmonize, and the nine kinds of people unite in purpose, thus bringing about the Great Peace of the Supreme Sovereign. If these nine matters diverge and conflict, the Great Peace cannot be achieved. These nine matters are interdependent, each giving rise to and completing the others. Yet people fail to deeply understand this, for even the former Sages and Worthies did not fully expound it—thus it has long remained obscured and severed.”

“Now, if even one matter is not properly governed, peace cannot be attained. Why is this?”
“The qi of the Supreme Sovereign arrives in full force, and these nine kinds of people all come to assist the king in governance. If even one qi is disharmonious, there will be deficiencies, and thus yin and yang cannot be fully harmonized to bring order to governance. How do they come? The formless spirit-people come to inform the king, and his heart grows daily brighter. The great spirit-people appear from time to time to instruct him in the principles of governance. The Perfected Ones, Immortals, and Great Dao-people all come as teachers to aid in transformation. The Sages and Worthies emerge, and reclusive scholars come to serve as ministers. The common people and servants all follow goodness and do no evil—this is the sign of Heaven and Earth’s great joy.

If even one qi is disharmonious, there will be those who do not arrive. How so? If the primordial qi is disharmonious, the formless spirit-people do not come. If the qi of Heaven is disharmonious, the great spirit-people do not come. If the qi of Earth is disharmonious, the Perfected Ones do not come. If the four seasons are disharmonious, the Immortals do not come. If the five phases are disharmonious, the Great Dao-people do not come. If yin and yang are disharmonious, the Sages do not come. If writings and speech are not truthful, the great Worthies do not come. If the myriad things are not harmoniously obtained, the common people grow chaotic, wealth and goods diminish, servants flee, and all matters lose their proper function. This is precisely the harm that arises.”

“Now, Perfected One, since you wish to rescue the chaotic qi of Heaven, you must strive diligently to harmonize it, never growing weary or negligent. Be cautious.”
“Indeed, indeed.”

“When the qi is attained, these nine kinds of people all uphold the Dao, and the disasters inherited from former kings of myriad generations are entirely dispelled. If these people all lose their proper roles, the harm of inherited burdens will daily increase. These nine kinds of people range from the formless above to servants below, each regulating one qi, and thus the nine qi and yin and yang are harmonized.

For people, when Heaven intends for them to harmonize qi, they must first consume qi. Thus, superior scholars who are about to enter the Dao first cease eating tangible food and consume qi instead, thereby uniting with the primordial qi. They should be nurtured in thatched chambers, where they observe purification rites, avoid witnessing evil, daily refine their forms, and have their desires unobstructed. They can then traverse without hindrance, ascending to assist the governance of the Immortals, Perfected Ones, and primordial qi of Heaven. These are the spirit-scholars, the officers of Heaven. There should be no prohibitions or restrictions; those who sincerely pursue this are called Heaven’s scholars. Heaven examines and selects the good, rejoicing greatly, and in turn brings benefit to people. What does this mean?

Though those who attain the Dao and depart may not serve immediate, visible purposes, they all contribute to harmonizing the qi of yin and yang. This is what the ancient emperors and kings meant when they sacrificed to the spirits of Heaven above and consumed offerings below.”

[Appendix]
When these nine kinds of people are obtained, they can dispel the disasters inherited by emperors and kings across myriad generations. These nine kinds of people range from the formless above to servants below, each regulating one qi. Thus, superior scholars cultivating the Dao must first consume qi, desiring to harmonize with the primordial qi. They should observe purification rites in thatched chambers, avoid witnessing evil, daily refine their forms, have their desires unobstructed, and be able to traverse without hindrance, ascending to assist the governance of the Immortals, Perfected Ones, and primordial qi of Heaven. These are the spirit-scholars, the officers of Heaven. There should be no prohibitions or restrictions; those who sincerely pursue this are called Heaven’s scholars. Heaven examines and selects the good, rejoicing greatly, and in turn brings benefit to people. Though those who attain the Dao and depart may not serve immediate, visible purposes, they harmonize the qi of yin and yang to benefit the myriad things. This is why the ancient emperors and kings sacrificed to the spirits of Heaven above—it was for these spirit-officers.

“But do the spirits of Heaven and Earth themselves descend to consume offerings?”
“Excellent! Your words are correct. Yet these people serve as officers of Heaven, and the spirits of Heaven are their sovereigns. Sovereign and officer act as messengers for one another; the officer’s duty is to carry out tasks. In all matters, if the Dao-people and officers perform well, they render merit. Thus, when the sovereign and his subordinates descend, they bring joy. This dispels the inherited burdens of people. If the officers are displeased, the Dao-people incur fault before Heaven. If both sovereign and officers refuse to descend and partake in human offerings, their transgressions multiply daily, and they themselves incur grave faults—how then can they dispel the lingering disasters of former kings? Do you, Perfected One, also understand this?”
“How terrifying!”

“Great is my fear and dread; I feel as though I have lost my qi. Now I come to ask the Celestial Master, never expecting to hear such words.”

“Go, then, and strive with diligence. When our discourse is complete, I shall depart.”

“Understood.”

Verification of the Dao’s Authenticity, Fifty-Seventh Formula
The tasks at hand will soon be complete.

“Perfected One, come forward and receive these teachings in detail.”

“Understood.”

“Since the practice of this Dao began, the inherited burdens of old have grown ever more distant, yet accumulated hardships and knotted qi, along with disasters and lingering poisons, are indeed many—none can be dispelled in but a moment.”

“Once one knows and practices this, the hardships of inherited burdens diminish day by day, dissolving month by month and vanishing year by year. How do we know this?”

“Excellent is your inquiry! You have grasped the intent of the Dao. Now listen closely: after this practice spreads, all documents under Heaven will be set right, and all people will likewise be rectified, entering the true Dao. No longer will there be falsehood or deceit; all spurious texts will vanish, and each person will exercise self-discipline. Those born afterward will be even more so, emulating one another and all understanding the inner Way. Seeing their own bodies, they will cherish and honor themselves. Those born later will be filial and long-lived, skilled in caring for the aged. Their complexions will differ from those of the Dao-less era, and the later generations will daily comprehend the profound intent, making it the foundation of their households. Their learning will surpass that of their predecessors, growing ever more sincere and affectionate toward one another. They will revere those who embody the Dao, and weapons, deceit, and treachery will cease to exist. Thus, the hardships of inherited burdens will daily dissipate—this is the natural art. □□ Not a single instance will fail; this is the great efficacy of my texts. They are not mere empty words of goodness but arise from tangible verification, resonating with Heaven and Earth. How could they be spoken falsely? Therefore, the texts have emerged over time, not hoarded by a single individual to obscure the truth. This is why my Dao is rooted in sincerity.

You have asked □□ in due course, eager to know its great efficacy. This efficacy is like the opposition of cold and heat: when heat abounds, cold recedes; when cold abounds, heat recedes. Since the opening of Heaven and Earth, the masters who taught others have often concealed the true Dao, instead propagating superficial learning that yields but slight benefit—yet it impoverishes later generations, worsening day by day. The reason lies in the transmission of false learning, which, though the Dao of Heaven is vast and distant, was first crafted by earlier writers as a great ladder of deception. Once deception takes root, it is later exploited for gain. Thus, those above have nothing left to trust, and those below have nowhere to entrust their lives, leading to mutual suspicion and disorder. Later generations inherit these burdens in succession, and the hardships of their predecessors accumulate—hence the worsening.

Heaven now resents this injustice, which is why I tell you □□. Perfected One, strive and take care to exert yourself. You will remove illness for Heaven and dispel hardship for the Emperor-Kings. The heavens above will know of your great merit.”

“I dare not, I dare not.”

“Right: Methods for Testing Actions and Verifying the Dao to Discern Truth from Falsehood—Four Actions, Root and Branch, Formula Fifty-Eight”

“Perfected One, step forward.”
“Yes, yes.”

“How many kinds of actions do humans have?”
“A hundred actions with ten thousand variations.”
“Not so. Perfected One, your words nearly resemble those of the common folk! Humans have four actions.”

“What is the first?”
“Indeed, if a person’s actions are not good, they are evil; if they are neither good nor evil, they are floating, level actions. If they are partly good and partly evil, they are impure and inconstant actions—neither can be relied upon, and fortune or misfortune cannot be determined.”

“Excellent. How many kinds of fortune and misfortune are there in actions? A thousand paths with a hundred million variations?”
“Perfected One, your words again nearly match those of the common folk. There are four kinds of fortune and misfortune in actions.”

“What is the first?”
“Indeed, in all matters of action, if they are not greatly fortunate, they will be greatly unfortunate; if they are neither fortunate nor unfortunate, they are floating, level destinies. If they are partly fortunate and partly unfortunate, they are mixed, impure, and inconstant—fortune and misfortune cannot be divined.”

“Excellent. In the nature of Heaven and Earth, how many kinds of good and evil are there in years, months, and days? Are they beyond counting?”

“You are thoroughly drunk—your words are mist and haze. In the nature of Heaven and Earth, years, months, and days, there are four kinds of actions. The first is impure, governing transformations and anomalies.”

“What does this mean?”
“Indeed, Perfected One, listen closely. In the nature of Heaven and Earth and the years, if they are not greatly auspicious, they will be greatly inauspicious; if they are neither auspicious nor inauspicious, they are floating, level years. If they are partly auspicious and partly inauspicious, they are years of celestial anomalies and delusion. Likewise, in the days and months, if they are not greatly good, they will be greatly evil; if they are neither good nor evil, they are floating, level days and months. If they are partly good and partly evil, they are deluded actions, governing strange disasters and calamities. I have merely outlined the essentials to reveal the beginning—all things under Heaven follow this pattern.”

“What does this mean?”
“Indeed, among the ten thousand things and the people of the world, if they do not enter into goodness, they must fall into evil. If they are neither good nor evil, they are mediocre, level actions. If they are partly good and partly evil, they are deceitful, false actions—nothing can be established upon them. Mediocre, level actions cannot be encouraged, while great goodness and great evil achieve renown.”

“Why are there precisely these four kinds of actions?”
“Excellent! Your questioning is profound and truly grasps the intent of the Dao. Indeed, great goodness is the pure action of the Supreme Yang; great evil is the destructive action of the Supreme Yin. The blending of good and evil is the action of harmonious balance. The inconstant actions arise when Heaven and Earth, ruler and subject, the people, and the ten thousand things lose their proper Way. Thus, in action, one should seek correctness: those who follow the Yang attain goodness in abundance; those who follow the Yin attain evil in abundance; those who follow harmony remain in floating equilibrium; and those whose fortune and misfortune are inconstant act without returning to law or measure. For this reason, the ancient sages and worthies deeply observed Heaven and Earth, the years, months, and days, the people, and the ten thousand things—examining their rise and decline, their floating equilibrium, their advance and retreat—to know for themselves whether their actions were successful or not. They used the luminous mirror of clarity to reflect themselves, and their forms and appearances could not be concealed.”

“Excellent! Excellent!”

“Now what is to be done?”
“Thus: in action, guard the root and model oneself on Heaven—this is the beginning. To model oneself on Earth is to invite many harms. To model oneself on harmony is the next best course. Those who act without constancy have not yet begun to act truly.”
“Why then do people now arrive at this inconstant action?”
“Because their forebears first made small errors, then minor transgressions, then greater ones, and finally grave mistakes. The root of the Way becomes ever more confused, their intentions find no support, and so they turn to inconstant action, altering their words to suit inconstant times. This shows that the corruption of the Dao has not yet reached its limit—one must return to the root. The ancient sages saw this as the degeneration of the end-times, and when it reached its limit, they turned back, thus never losing governance and preserving their Heavenly mandate. The great worthies and sages, seeing matters clearly, therefore always remain uniquely fortunate. Does the Perfected One delight in knowing the true efficacy of this?”
“It is only through the Celestial Master’s instruction.”
“When the root of the year flourishes but its end turns evil, this is the extreme of Yin and Yang. When later generations grow increasingly wicked and shallow, this is the extreme of the age. When the root of the ten thousand things flourishes but their end yields no harvest, this is the extreme of things. When later generations’ speech is full of empty deceit without substance, this is the extreme of words. When documents are amassed and piled high yet lack truth, this is the extreme of writing. All these abandon the root for the branch, forsake substance for ornament. Thus Heaven and Earth generate the ten thousand things, yet most have roots without branches—the fault lies in abandoning the root and flowing toward the branch, forsaking truth for falsity, depth for shallowness, and taking this as the norm. Customs become so ingrained that people no longer recognize their mutual harm, and alone among all things, they accumulate violations against Heaven’s law. Later generations grow ever more frivolous in affairs, creating deceit and falsehood, until habit hardens into nature and they can no longer restrain themselves. They claim to understand matters, yet only pass on burdens to one another, bringing Heaven’s blame and Earth’s calamity, spreading chaos in all directions, beyond all restraint. Though a lord or king be benevolent and wise, how can he sever this flow of errors accumulated over ten thousand generations? The initial loss was small, each error no larger than a grain. Yet when Heaven’s Way is lost by a hair’s breadth, the error extends a thousand miles. Grain by grain they follow and gather, until they fill the great granary with tens of thousands of bushels. Raindrop by raindrop they follow one another in ceaseless flow, becoming a hundred rivers that accumulate into the four seas—such abundance cannot be contained. Thus one must measure with the true Dao, reverse the extreme of the branch and return to the root, reverse ornament and return to substance, reverse falsity and return to truth. When the branch is exhausted, one should return to the root; when action reaches its limit, one must return to the source—this is the Way of Heaven. To lose the correct Dao is no minor illness. Even after life ends, the burden of error is passed on, and later generations grow ever more confused and lost. The correct Dao grows ever dimmer, darkness deepens and the Way is lost, Heaven’s qi turns contrary—how can governance be peaceful? People suffer its poisonous harm—how can they live long? The ten thousand things are injured and die young in great numbers. Therefore I repeatedly instruct the Perfected One to transmit my writings, so that each person may reflect on their loss of the Dao, recognize their own illness, and take up their own cares and labors. Then Heaven and Earth, lords and kings, the people and the ten thousand things will all be at peace. The Perfected One, in accord with Heaven’s heart, must not be remiss or negligent.”
“Indeed, indeed.”

“Might I venture to ask one further doubt: Is the Master’s present fortune or misfortune merely a matter of the times?”

“Excellent indeed is the Perfected One’s inquiry into the Dao. What reaches its utmost above must return below; what extends to its farthest outward must turn inward. Thus when yang reaches its extreme, it reverts to yin; when it sinks to its lowest, it returns above. Therefore when yin reaches its extreme, it reverts to yang; when it strays to its furthest end, it must return to its root. Since the opening of Heaven and Earth, minor and repeated losses of the Dao’s intent have been passed down, each bearing the burden of the last, until falsehood and deceit have reached their extreme.

How do we know this? Observe that among the ten thousand things and the people, many are good at first but evil later, accomplishing little and speaking of what came before—how could it be otherwise? What was once substantial has become empty and hollow. The sages of old constantly observed the movements of the people to know this, and thus they never lost the Way.”

“Excellent indeed! [Rising,] Might I beg to ask one more matter?”

“Speak.”

“According to the Master’s words, things have a lowest and a highest extreme. Among the nine ranks of humanity, the highest extreme is the *weiqi* divine person, and the lowest is the slave or servant. If those below study and ascend, can those at the highest extreme also descend again? Is this not so?”

“Excellent indeed is your question. Yet the Perfected One still seems unenlightened, not yet penetrating the Dao of the Great Ultimate. The *weiqi* divine person unites form and power with primordial qi, coexisting with the four seasons and the five phases. All spirit in humanity is received from Heaven’s qi, and Heaven’s qi is received from primordial qi. Spirit rides upon qi and moves; thus where there is qi, there is spirit, and where there is spirit, there is qi. When spirit departs, qi is cut off; when qi perishes, spirit departs. Therefore, without spirit one dies, and without qi one dies. Would a *weiqi* divine person ever enter a person’s belly?”

“Indeed, indeed.” [Pause]

[Appendix:] All, from sages to the lowest, have their extremes—the highest being formless divine persons, the lowest being slaves and servants. Divine persons ride upon qi and move; thus where there is qi, there is spirit, and when qi is cut off, spirit perishes.

“The five phases arise and flourish from primordial qi, and spirit moves in unison with primordial qi, sharing the same body. Now, if the five phases enter and become the human viscera, does this not mean that among the nine ranks, the highest may descend again, reentering the human body?”

“Excellent indeed! Though you have studied long, only now do you glimpse this teaching.”

“”
“Indeed. You must study this with precision—without precision, there is no benefit.”
“Yes, yes. Having heard the Heavenly Master’s words, does the Dao of Heaven truly follow a cyclical path?”
“Indeed. You may be said to have already understood it. Go now, and if you have doubts, do not hesitate to ask.”
“Yes, yes.”

[Manuscript:] *The Four Agents of Heaven: Their True Origins and Ends, Returning to Governance through the Great Ultimate*

*Great Peace Scripture: Collated and Annotated, Scroll Forty-Three, Part Bing, Number Nine*
*Great Peace Scripture, Scroll Forty-Three*
*Minor and Major Admonitions and Rectifications, Fifty-Ninth*
The Perfected One bowed and said: “This foolish student is benighted and truly does not comprehend the Dao. Now that I have been charged with observing Heaven’s weal and woe, fortune and misfortune, I dare to inquire fully into the essentials of the Dao. In this age, do the divine laws of spirits and deities also include admonitions and rectifications?”
“May the Heavenly Master instruct and enlighten me, revealing the profound intent of the supreme Dao.”
“How wondrous and profound is the question you have posed!”
“I have observed that people admonish and rectify one another, so I ask: does Heaven also admonish and rectify?”
“Excellent indeed! Your question has grasped the true essence of the Dao of Heaven. The celestial spirits have emerged, and the deities rejoice.”
“Now I shall fully expound its great essentials for you, so that for ten thousand generations it may never be forgotten.”
“Yes, yes.”
“Thus: when Heaven offers a minor admonition, its countenance alters; when it offers a major admonition, Heaven itself trembles and its body splits. If its admonition is unheeded, it will thereby fade and perish. The Three Luminaries, when offering a minor admonition over small matters, cause the stars to change color; when offering a major admonition, the Three Luminaries lose their proper measure and cease to shine. If their admonition is unheeded, they will thereby fade and perish. Earth, when offering a minor admonition, trembles and shakes; when offering a major admonition, mountains collapse and the earth splits. If its admonition is unheeded, it will thereby fade and perish. The Five Phases, when offering a minor admonition, bring forth calamities; when offering a major admonition, creatures arise in the east to slay people, poisons arise in the south to slay people, tigers and wolves arise in the west to slay people, aquatic creatures arise in the north to slay people, and in the center, officials and commoners contend with venomous malice to slay one another. If their admonition is unheeded, they will thereby fade and perish. The Four Seasons, when offering a minor admonition, cause slight irregularities in cold and heat; when offering a major admonition, cold and heat reverse their positions, and the seasonal qi lose all measure. If their admonition is unheeded, they will thereby fade and perish. The essential qi of the Six Directions, when offering a minor admonition, repeatedly bring disorder and inversion, giving rise to calamitous creatures—some flying, some walking—with many clouds and winds but no rain, empty and insubstantial. When offering a major admonition, there is no regularity in floods and droughts, and they harm and slay the myriad things and the people. If their admonition is unheeded, they will thereby fade and perish. Flying and walking birds and beasts, when offering a minor admonition, bring calamity to people; when offering a major admonition, birds and beasts devour people, and locusts arise in great swarms. If their admonition is unheeded, they will thereby fade and perish. The spirits of ghosts and deities, when offering a minor admonition, repeatedly bring subtle afflictions and illnesses to officials and commoners; when offering a major admonition, they cause families to be torn apart and destroyed. If their admonition is unheeded, they will thereby fade and perish. The Six Directions, when offering a minor admonition, send forth chaotic winds and rains, accompanied by vicious poisons that harm people; when offering a major admonition, they act perversely and contrary to reason, causing tiles and stones to fly, the earth to rise and support the August Heaven, houses to collapse, and mountains and hills to quake. If their admonition is unheeded, they will thereby fade and perish. The minor admonitions of Heaven and Earth’s voices manifest as sudden thunder and lightning; major admonitions cause people to engage in widespread corruption and evil, leading to frequent thunderbolts. If their admonition is unheeded, they will thereby fade and perish. Officials and commoners, when offering a minor admonition, alter their countenance; when offering a major admonition, they harm and injure one another. If their admonition is unheeded, they will thereby fade and perish. When Heaven and Earth, the Six Directions, and the Eight Extremities all offer a major admonition together, they seek to rectify the Luo River writings and the Yellow River diagrams, making Heaven’s proofs manifest and the auspicious signs of the world appear, thereby admonishing and rectifying the lord of men. All under Heaven respond in unison. If their admonition is unheeded, they will thereby fade and perish. The cyclical meetings of the Dao of Heaven must be employed and followed in due order. Thus, the sages and worthies of antiquity, upon perceiving matters, always reflected deeply upon their import, never daring to be remiss, even for the space of a hair’s breadth, thereby perceiving the subtle and knowing the manifest. Thus, they did not lose the heart of August Heaven and were able to preserve their persons, secure their dwellings, remain free from care and misfortune, and avoid peril and ruin. No calamity could befall them, for their calculations and assessments were in truth aligned with the heart of Heaven.”
[End]

“Excellent indeed! This foolish student has now understood. Now that the Heavenly Master has expounded the law, I wish to hear the meaning of ‘thereby fading and perishing.’ Pray, elucidate it.”
“Excellent indeed is your heart!”
“Thus: the Dao of Heaven aids those who are easily taught, aids the utmost sincere, aids the reverent and compliant, aids those who are easily enlightened, and aids those who are easily admonished. It seeks to enrich the lord of men, and so instructs him. It does not seek to enrich those who are not thus, and so does not instruct them. The pattern is like that of people: those who are closely and deeply bound teach and show one another matters, but those who are not thus bound do not teach or show one another. If one teaches but is not heeded, one becomes indignant that one’s words are not employed in due time, and so abandons and sets aside the other, no longer teaching or showing them again. Thus, the strange calamities and portents cease and no longer admonish or instruct people. In this way, even the worthy and sagely become deaf and blind, bereft of knowledge; their wisdom is obstructed, and Heaven and Earth, spirits and deities, no longer admonish or rectify them.”
[End]
“Day by day, calamities and anomalies increase and are not dispelled; people daily decline and perish, losing their proper offices.”
[Appendix:] “What Heaven aids are those who are easily taught, the utmost sincere, the reverent and compliant, those who are easily enlightened, and those who are easily admonished. Heaven’s favor toward the emperor and king is most profound, and so it employs every manner of misfortune and change to guide them. If its teachings are not heeded, it abandons and sends them forth, and Heaven and Earth, the divine and luminous, no longer admonish or rectify them. Calamities and anomalies daily increase, and the people daily decline and dwindle, losing their proper offices.”
“Thus, the sages and worthies of antiquity, from dawn to dusk, remained serene and composed, able to ponder deeply, never daring to lose the heart of Heaven. Thus, they were able to serve August Heaven as a father, serve August Earth as a mother, serve the sun as an elder brother, serve the moon as an elder sister, rectify the celestial patterns, protect the Five Phases, follow the Four Seasons, observe their advances and retreats, and thereby illuminate and rectify their own conduct, deeply understanding Heaven’s gains and losses.”

“〈Stop〉 Now, only Heaven and Earth preserve the essential Dao in solitude, taking the celestial response diagrams and sacred texts as their great mandate. Thus, all their actions receive divine correspondence, as if by spirits—this alone is to profoundly grasp the intent of Heaven. It is like a double mirror aligning with the carpenter’s square, speaking face to face. Therefore, when the numinous spirits are stirred, if one resists and refuses their admonitions and rectifications, Heaven and Earth will invert their principles, the Five Phases and Four Seasons will fall into chaos and rebellion, and the proper order will be lost. Thus, one’s actions will miss the mark, and great misfortune will follow—this is what it means. Do you understand?”

“Indeed, indeed.”

“Therefore, the nature of Heaven and Earth is such that the lower also admonishes the upper, and the upper also admonishes the lower. Each has its strengths and weaknesses, and by complementing one another, all things under the Dao attain their proper place. Thus, though August Heaven is divine and sagely, it has its shortcomings, which do not match the strengths of Earth. Therefore, all things receive their mandate from Heaven but are nourished in their bodies by Earth. The Three Luminaries have their shortcomings, which do not match the strengths of fire; though the Three Luminaries are divine and bright, they cannot illuminate the depths of inner chambers, whereas fire shines within them. The greatest sages have their shortcomings, which do not match the strengths of the worthy. Human shortcomings do not match the strengths of the myriad things. Thus, when admonitions extend downward, even to the most minute and subtle, the Dao is not lost, and the heart of Heaven is attained. Therefore, Heaven generates all things, causing their seasons to undergo transformations, all to admonish and rectify the ruler, revealing the signs of utmost virtue. One cannot but be greatly cautious!

The transformations of Heaven, Earth, and the myriad things—this is their language.”

“Indeed, indeed. Since the Heavenly Master has made this clear, I wish to apply it to humanity.”

“Very well. Listen carefully to my words and ponder them deeply. When a minister possesses loyalty, goodness, sincerity, and trustworthiness, and admonishes and rectifies his ruler, but the ruler does not heed and instead seeks to harm him, the minister, struck with fear, falls silent and becomes mute, and the six directions become blocked and impassable. The worthy and learned, fearing trouble, thus conceal themselves, loyalty and trustworthiness lie hidden, and the true Dao cannot be seen. Though the ruler may be sagely, he hears nothing, thus becoming deaf and blind, and no marvels can be perceived. Day by day, darkness deepens; the ruler is deaf, the ministers are mute—calamity knows no bounds. When ministers are benighted and the ruler is blind, treachery and villainy run rampant. When ministers are mute and the ruler is deaf, the world is cut off, good and evil are indistinguishable, celestial disasters converge, the Six Extremes wage war, and the world is wholly plunged into misfortune. Can one not be cautious?”

“Indeed, indeed.”

“Thus, 〈begin〉 the sages and worthies of antiquity took omens and anomalies with utmost seriousness, using them to measure and correct themselves. Thus, they never erred in the slightest. 〈Stop〉 This truly aligns with the essential texts and the great Dao. In all affairs, they exhausted their loyalty, and misfortune never befell them. Take this as a grave warning and heed my words carefully.”

“Indeed, indeed.”

“Now, the height and clarity of Heaven are not the achievement of a single essence’s virtue. When an emperor governs in accord with the heart of Heaven, it is not the work of a single worthy minister. My words here merely outline the guiding principles and beginnings; all matters cannot be fully written or explained. You must deeply ponder their meaning yourself.”

“Indeed, indeed.”

“Go now. How could such discourse ever end? Ask no more.”

“Indeed, indeed.”

**Right Section: The Heavenly Admonition’s Correct Methods of Scriptural Secrets**
*Collated and Combined Text of the* Taiping Jing*, Volume 44, Bing Section, Part Ten*
*Taiping Jing, Volume 44*
*Examining the Scriptures: The Methods of Punishment and Virtue, Chapter Sixty*

The Perfected One bowed with utmost reverence and said, “Your disciple now asks these questions, knowing full well they may incur profound reproach. Yet when I reflect upon the words of my master’s texts, all are true—none can be altered. Only this humble one is foolish and benighted, grieving that I do not know from whence the August Heavenly Spirit-Person derived these models and methods. Now, the master’s words have accumulated into vast [omission], and I humbly beseech you, out of compassion, to reveal the celestial proofs of the yin-yang secrets, the essential efficacy of the divine oracle. At present, I remain unenlightened, my heart greatly troubled and disordered. What I say must surely offend the master’s taboos. Yet though I wish to speak, I cannot restrain myself. Even if the Heavenly Master reproves me, I pray you grant me the luminous evidence of Heaven’s methods, that they may be transmitted for ten thousand generations, resplendent and unquestioned—like the brightness of the sun at noon—unchanging and immutable from beginning to end.”

“Indeed, do you truly still not believe my words? You yourself remain obstructed, failing to comprehend the heart and intent of Heaven. Are you not foolish? You differ little from the common crowd. You think my words may be violated—yet those who violate them fall into chaos, and those who oppose them meet ruin. What I now tell you has all been verified against the celestial patterns, aligned with the great secrets of yin and yang before being spoken. You come to inquire of Heaven’s affairs, and I transmit Heaven’s words to establish its laws—not daring to utter idle, false, or flattering speech. You have lived through many years and days, yet have you not seen how the myriad creatures, all without exception, follow virtue in their dwelling and, conversely, shun the qi of punishment? 〈Rise〉 This is the luminous and essential proof of August Heaven. It is why Heaven sternly instructs the ruler in governance, revealing the effects of success and failure.”

“Indeed, indeed. Though I now begin to awaken, I am not yet fully awakened. I humbly request further instruction and admonition.”

“Very well. Punishment and virtue are the manifest effects of Heaven and Earth’s yin-yang divine governance, the standards for the myriad creatures and the people. Thus, in the eleventh month, great virtue resides in the *nine-one*, dwelling beneath the earth. The season of virtue is within the chamber, so there is inner qi, and the myriad things return to it. The season of punishment is in the *six-four*, in the distant wilds, so externally there is no qi, and all is clear and empty. The myriad things and the multitudes of people all return, and the king’s virtue follows them into the Yellow Springs below.

In the twelfth month, virtue is in the *nine-two*, in the *chou* [earth-branch], dwelling in the midst of earth, not yet emerged. The season of virtue is in the Bright Hall, and the myriad things follow virtue upward, yet dare not emerge to appear, for above there is punishment.

In the first month, the *yin* [earth-branch], virtue is in the *nine-three*. There is nothing among the myriad things that does not follow the flourishing virtue, delighting in gazing upon Heaven and Earth to be born. The season of virtue resides in the courtyard.

In the second month, virtue is in the *nine-four*, in the *mao* [earth-branch]. It has departed from the earth but not yet reached Heaven, lingering at the boundary. Virtue is at the gate, so the myriad things all delight in emerging to gaze at the gate.

In the third month, flourishing virtue is in the *nine-five*, the *chen* [earth-branch], ascending to the center of Heaven. The season of flourishing virtue is in the outer roadways, so the myriad things all emerge to dwell outside.

In the fourth month, the *si* [earth-branch], virtue is in the *nine-six*, reaching the six distant and eight borderlands. Flourishing virtue pervades the eight directions, and the good qi and yang qi all respond and generate one another. The myriad creatures depart from the inner chambers to dwell in the wilds. The season of punishment is at the roots of the myriad things, dwelling within the inner chamber, so below is empty and devoid of things, while above is lush and flourishing. There is nothing that does not delight in following virtue to govern. This is the great luminous proof of governing through virtue.”

“Now that I have reverently heard of the use of virtue, I wish to hear of the use of punishment.”

“Very well. In the fifth month, punishment is in the *six-one*, in the *wu* [earth-branch], beneath the earth. Below and within, all is clear and devoid of qi. The earth below is empty. The season of punishment is within the chamber, so internally there are no things—all dwell outside.

In the sixth month, punishment resides in the *six-two*, in the *wei* [earth-branch], dwelling in the midst of earth, not yet emerged. The season of punishment is in the hall. The qi of punishment is within, while the qi of virtue is without. There is nothing among the myriad creatures that does not delight in baring its body, returning to the one of flourishing virtue.

In the seventh month, punishment is in the *six-three*, in the *shen* [earth-branch]. Punishment is in the courtyard, and the myriad things dare not enter, stubbornly delighting in dwelling outside.

In the eighth month, punishment is in the *six-four*, in the *you* [earth-branch]. It has not yet reached the boundary of Heaven. The season of virtue is at the gate, and the myriad things all delight in gazing at the gate, joyfully entering and following virtue in returning.

In the ninth month, punishment is in the *six-five*, in the *xu* [earth-branch], ascending to the center of Heaven. The season of punishment is in the roadways, and the myriad things are all on the verge of death and distress, following virtue to conceal themselves. Thus, within, things daily flourish, while externally, all is empty and perishing.

In the tenth month, punishment is in the *six-six*, in the *hai* [earth-branch]. The season of punishment reaches the six distant and eight borderlands. The myriad creatures in the four wilds all conceal themselves and flee, following virtue to the Bright Hall. Crawling creatures carry their young within, dwelling internally, while the wilds outside are empty of people. Is this not because those who favor the use of punishment and penalties are abandoned and depart? Yet if one’s heart and intent desire to embrace punishment internally to govern the multitudes, then daily they will dwindle. Thus:

In the fifth month, if one internally embraces one punishment, one group of people rebels.
In the sixth month, if one internally embraces two punishments, two groups of people rebel.
In the seventh month, if one internally embraces three punishments, three groups of people rebel.
In the eighth month, if one internally embraces four punishments, four groups of people rebel.
In the ninth month, if one internally embraces five punishments, five groups of people rebel.
In the tenth month, if one internally embraces six punishments, six groups of people rebel.

Thus, externally, all is devoid of things—they all flee within. This is the luminous proof and effect. Therefore, those who govern through punishment are outwardly reverent and cautious, yet inwardly rebellious, so the multitudes daily diminish.

For this reason:
In the eleventh month, if one internally embraces one virtue, one group of people enters and follows.
In the twelfth month, if one internally embraces two virtues, two groups of people enter and follow.
In the first month, if one internally embraces three virtues, three groups of people enter and follow.
In the second month, if one internally embraces four virtues, the multitudes from the four directions enter and follow.”

In the third month, if one internally embraces the five flourishing yang virtues, five groups of worthy people enter and follow. In the fourth month, if one internally embraces six virtues, the myriad things all emerge and appear, none failing to stir and gather, both within and without turning toward them. This is the luminous proof and effect of Heaven’s law.

When it comes to the second and eighth months, virtue and punishment are evenly matched. Thus, in the second month, things are half-damaged by cold, and in the eighth month, things are also half-damaged by cold. At this time in the second month, virtue seeks to lead its multitudes out through the gates, while punishment seeks to draw its multitudes in through the gates—both stand at the boundary. Therefore, in the second and eighth months, the myriad things encounter the meeting of punishment and virtue, with life and death evenly divided, hence the half-damage.

Now, you delight in knowing the constant laws of Heaven and Earth, the luminous proofs of yin and yang—this is precisely it. Punishment daily harms and kills, causing dread and aversion, yet it fails to gain the strength of the multitudes, and instead is said to have no people. Virtue, however, daily unfolds and grows, free from punishment and fear, so the myriad things do not dread it; instead, they submit and descend, all returning to assist the king in governance. This is the luminous proof of Heaven, clear and beyond doubt.

Now, if people do not hold awe and reverence, they cannot be governed—what is to be done? Yet the sages and noble ones of antiquity overawed people through the Dao and virtue, not through physical force or punishment. Those who take no joy in doing good, whose virtue is deficient, instead seek to overawe and startle with punishment to aid governance—this is like seeing them depart.

Punishment can only be used to dispel hardship and relieve burdens; it is insufficient to give life to the myriad things. Clearly, the stirring multitudes belong to the one who presides over them. Now, if people do not inwardly submit but instead deceive and cheat, the great fault lies here.

In the second and eighth months, virtue and punishment are evenly matched, so the myriad things are half-damaged by cold. Punishment daily harms and kills, causing dread and aversion, yet it fails to gain the strength of the multitudes. The sages of antiquity overawed people through the Dao and virtue, not through physical force or punishment.

Now, you have repeatedly come to study in recent times, and though the matters you inquire about are many, you have accumulated much written knowledge, yet you still cannot fully trust my words—have you truly understood this?

Pure bowed his head in reverence and said, “My transgressions are grave indeed. I have failed the words of my enlightened teacher and divine person, and inwardly I am ashamed, my sweat flowing. Yet my virtue is meager, my station lowly, and though I have studied for many days, my mind remains dull and cannot fully grasp the words of my enlightened teacher. Thus, I dare not refrain from asking again and again—my lack of humility is great, and I have long caused you, my teacher, concern.”

“It is only that your learning is not yet refined—take care.”

Heaven sets forth images and establishes laws for people, and for emperors and kings, it sets teachings and commands that can be taken as models for governance, never failing even once. If you wish to know its meaning, this is precisely it.
