Governance does not rely solely on this method, yet it often leaves Heaven sorrowful and resentful, unresolved, hence the many calamities and disasters. Be warned.

When Heaven is about to raise something up, it takes its image from virtue; when it is about to bring decline and ruin, it takes its model from punishment—this is what is meant.

My words are carefully aligned with the rules of Heaven and Earth, yin and yang, following the principles of Heaven and Earth. They are the luminous words of Heaven, recorded to teach and instruct you. My words are like a sharp arrow—no different. Follow them, and you will daily prosper; go against them, and you will bring ruin upon yourself.

How wondrous are the laws of Heaven! Wondrous indeed! Thus, the divine persons, true persons, and great sages of antiquity who deeply established laws and created rules for emperors and kings all perceived the essentials of Heaven’s patterns. Only after inwardly understanding the meaning of yin and yang did they then follow Heaven and Earth in governance, aligning their hearts with the divine and observing what could be done. Thus, their governance never failed even once.

Heaven sets forth images and establishes laws for emperors and kings to take as models for governance. When the kingly Way is about to rise, it takes its image from virtue; when the kingly Way is about to decline, it takes its image from punishment. For those who establish laws for emperors and kings, first clarifying Heaven’s intent and inwardly understanding the Dao of yin and yang brings supreme peace.

Now, foolish officials and people believe Heaven’s laws can be recklessly violated, acting willfully without regard for rules—hence the great disorder in their lord’s governance. The great fault lies here.

Now that you have received this book, why not carefully ponder it in your heart, reflect on it earnestly, and contemplate it in a quiet chamber? Meditate on Heaven’s ways, and only then can you transmit Heaven’s teachings to instruct the foolish and assist the emperor and king in establishing laws.

When about to employ punishment, deeply consider where punishment resides—all who follow it depart, leaving it solitary and without multitudes. Thus, in winter, punishment lies in the four wilds, with no people; the myriad things all rebel and hide within, fleeing it greatly. In summer, punishment lies within, and the myriad things all emerge to follow virtue, leaving the underground chambers and inner rooms empty. Punishment remains solitary, while all follow virtue to the wilds.

When virtue is outside, the myriad things turn outward; when virtue is in secluded emptiness, things turn inward. Heaven’s punishment is of utmost severity, and though it may overawe and subdue the people and the myriad things, why then does it fail to restrain its multitudes? Is this not strange?

Punishment must not be lightly or recklessly used. Harming one upright qi disturbs Heaven’s qi; harming one compliant qi disrupts Earth’s qi. Harming one scholar causes all scholars to vanish; harming one worthy causes all worthies to hide. Every matter is shaken by this.

Thus, the sage emperors and kings of antiquity deeply perceived these Heavenly warnings and feared them, daring not act recklessly. They feared losing Heaven’s favor and being unable to secure their own persons. Those of supreme virtue under the August Heaven alone deeply perceived the luminous effects of the Dao and virtue. They were not overbearing or intimidating, yet the multitudes turned to and followed them. Thus, they guarded the Dao to preserve themselves and upheld virtue without daring to lose it.

You should recite and study my book, and if your heart has doubts, always keep this scroll close at hand, reviewing it day and night as a luminous warning and proof. Only then will you grasp Heaven’s intent.

To violate this is to rebel against Heaven. It is like reversing Qian and Kun, which cannot be reversed; like the movement of the Six Jia, which cannot be altered; like the fixed laws of the Five Phases, which cannot be lost; like the brightness of the sun and moon, which cannot be obscured; like the ruler above and the minister below, which cannot be disordered. This is how the governance of Heaven and Earth, of yin and yang, is made clear—those who delight in practicing virtue. Yet there are foolish people who instead delight in punishment. You should constantly observe and study this book to dispel delusion, striving to teach others to be good and refined, to uphold the Dao and virtue, and to contemplate the reduction of punishments. My book □□ rectifies Heaven’s laws.

Is practicing the Dao and virtue easy? Is practicing punishments difficult? Love causes daily increase, while intimidation leads to daily loss. Go swiftly now, transmit my book for Heaven, and do not doubt. My words do not betray the vastness of Heaven and Earth and the Six Directions.

"Yes, yes. I shall truly return and reflect on my faults, considering only the proper order of above and below, daring not lose even one aspect."

"Go, and be cautious. If you cannot distinguish and carefully ponder the meaning of my book, simply observe the great workings of Heaven and Earth, of yin and yang. From the Spring Equinox to the Autumn Equinox, virtue resides externally, and all things without exception emerge and submit to the external ruler. Hibernating creatures leave their burrows, and people leave their dwellings. From the Autumn Equinox to the Spring Equinox, virtue resides internally, and all things without exception return and submit to the internal ruler. Hibernating creatures all enter their burrows, and people enter their dwellings—this is the luminous effect of governance by virtue.

From the Spring Equinox to the Autumn Equinox, punishment governs internally, and all things follow their emergence to the outside, leaving the interior empty and still. From the Autumn Equinox to the Spring Equinox, punishment governs externally, yet there are no creatures, no qi, no emptiness, no multitudes—all enter and follow virtue. This is the clear proof that punishment cannot be used for governance.

Thus, virtue aligns its heart and power with Heaven: when yang emerges, it emerges; when yang enters, it enters. Punishment aligns its power and heart with Earth: when yin emerges, it emerges; when yin enters, it enters. Virtue aligns its power with the qi of life: when the qi of life emerges, it emerges; when it enters, it enters. Punishment aligns its power with the qi of killing: when the qi of killing emerges, it emerges; when it enters, it enters. Virtue shares its path with that which ascends in Heaven; punishment shares its path with that which descends in Earth. Virtue always dwells with the substantial; punishment dwells with emptiness and nothingness. Virtue always dwells with flourishing: when flourishing is external, it emerges; when flourishing is internal, it enters—thus it enters in winter and emerges in summer. Punishment dwells with decline and the qi of death: thus it emerges in winter and enters in summer. The qi of death is clear, and wherever it resides, clarity prevails.

Thus, virtue shares its qi with the emperor and king: when the king rules externally, it emerges with yin; when the king rules internally, it enters with punishment. Punishment shares its position with petty people, and wherever it resides, there are no multitudes. That to which things submit is the accumulation of the emperor’s and king’s virtue, which is always seen to return—hence they are called emperor and king. Punishment has never dwelled with things, lacking multitudes, and thus cannot be called a noble person.

Therefore, the sages of antiquity alone deeply pondered and observed the workings of Heaven and Earth, of yin and yang, taking them as their teachers and models. Knowing their great □□, they dared not transgress even one aspect—this is the clear proof of Heaven and Earth. How could one not carefully consider this? How could one not be cautious? It is the natural law, not dependent on any particular person. It is the constant workings of Heaven and Earth, which I have now fully revealed to you. You should repeatedly and deeply ponder its meaning, and in your actions, do not take it lightly."

"Yes, yes. I dare not betray it."

"Go, I have fully transmitted the true teachings to you. My worries are resolved. For Heaven, I have removed faults, corrected the utmost virtue, and revived the ruler. Do not dare to sever this transmission, lest you incur harm."

"Yes, yes."

Here begins the examination of celestial principles to clarify the successes and failures of governance from antiquity to the present—*A Collated Edition of the* **Taiping Jing**, *Volume 45, Bing Section 11: The* **Taiping Jing**, *Volume 45, "The Sixth Decade: The Formula for Earth’s Revelations."*

---

"The lowly and base cannot endure; my heart’s questions transgress the Celestial Master’s taboos, committing grievous faults. What I long to say, I cannot restrain—this petty man, unable to suppress his feelings, burns with pent-up vexation. I beg to ask one great doubt: since the Celestial Master treats me as a child of your own, you must surely pity my hunger and thirst!"

"Proceed with the Dao. Why so humble?"

"Yes, yes."

---

Now the Celestial Master, in constant union of essence and thought with the August Heaven and Revered Earth, aligns his heart so deeply with the intent of Heaven and Earth that it is like overlapping compasses or conjoined squares, not erring even by a hair’s breadth. Knowing the constant concerns of Heaven and Earth, this lowly one, though unworthy and ashamed, dares to come forward and ask in full: what are the great taboos of Heaven and Earth’s divine spirits?"

"Excellent! Your devotion advances ever further! You may now inquire directly into the heart and intent of Heaven and Earth. Once a person knows this, it takes root in the heart of the worthy and never departs for ten thousand generations. I have always longed to speak of it, but had no one to address. Now that a true person asks, my heart rejoices in this decisive moment. I shall fully and distinctly explain it to you, daring not conceal anything. The reason is this: I fear the divine spirits of Heaven and Earth would deeply detest me, bringing great calamity upon myself. True person, simply sit and listen clearly."

"What are the great afflictions of Heaven and Earth? They detest those who are disobedient and unfilial—what does this mean? I wish to hear it."

"Excellent is your inquiry! Now, the harmony of Heaven and Earth consists of three qi, which internally unite as one household, jointly governing life and nurturing the myriad things. Heaven presides over generation and is called Father; Earth presides over nourishment and is called Mother; humans preside over governance and are called Child. The Father should teach with timely measures; the Mother follows the Father’s actions to nurture. The Child receives life from the Father and is fed and reared by the Mother. As a Child, one should respectfully serve the Father and love the Mother."

"What does this mean?"

"It means the Father’s teachings have their proper measures and seasons. Thus, Heaven teaches through the four seasons to generate, nurture, and bring things to completion, each with its appointed beginning and end. When wicked people oppose this, it is as if the Child disobeys the Father, causing Heaven’s qi to lose its governance and fail in its intent. Heaven then deeply detests such people, sending down calamities and anomalies to afflict its Child—like a household where the father, enraged, disciplines his child, and the change occurs immediately. When father and child are at odds, and the father resents the child’s disobedience to his stern teachings, yin overcomes yang, the inferior deceives the superior, and many rebellious children emerge. Ministers neglect their duties, spectral beings flourish, harming people; deceit and cunning lurk by the wayside; all manner of yin’s disobedient forces arise—all faults lie in opposing Heaven and Earth. True person, how could you not obey? This is the natural art, like a shadow responding to form, or a horse’s bridle that never slips—take heed!"

"Yes, yes."

---

[Here ends the passage.]

[Appendix]
The Celestial Master, in constant union of essence and thought with the August Heaven and Revered Earth, aligns his heart so deeply with the intent of Heaven and Earth that it is like overlapping compasses or conjoined squares, not erring even by a hair’s breadth. Knowing the constant concerns of Heaven and Earth, what are the great taboos of Heaven and Earth’s divine spirits? What are the profound afflictions of Heaven and Earth? They detest those who are disobedient and unfilial—what does this mean? The harmony of Heaven and Earth consists of three qi, which internally unite as one household to nurture the myriad things. Heaven presides over generation and is called Father; Earth presides over nourishment and is called Mother; humans govern and are called Child. The Child receives life from the Father and is nurtured by the Mother’s grace. As a Child, one should respectfully serve the Father and love the Mother—what does this mean? It means the Father’s teachings have their proper measures and seasons, so he teaches through the four seasons to generate and bring things to completion. When wicked people oppose the Father’s intent, Heaven’s qi loses its governance. Like a household where the father is angry with his child, when father and child are at odds, yin overcomes yang, the inferior deceives the superior, ministers neglect their duties, and spectral beings flourish.

---

"Now, having reverently received the Celestial Master’s teachings and Heaven’s instructions, I wish to hear of the prohibitions against offending Earth."

"Very well, true person, listen clearly."

"Yes, yes."

"Now, the heavens are the Father; the earth is the Mother. Both Father and Mother are human—how do they differ? The heavens, too, are the Dao; the earth, too, is the Dao. Father and Mother are merely distinguished by yin and yang, male and female, yet their likes and dislikes are the same. The heavens nurture human life; the earth nurtures human form. Yet people are profoundly foolish, benighted, and ignorant—they fail to honor and revere their Father and Mother, causing the heavens and earth to bring forth ordinary people, filled with regret and unresolved sorrow."

"What does this mean?"

"Excellent is your question! You have deeply grasped the intent of Heaven and Earth. Great disasters will cease, and people will surely prosper."

"What does this mean?"

"Let the Celestial Master explain clearly."

"Now, all the people under Heaven together harm and wrong their Father and Mother."

"What does this mean?"

"The qi of the four seasons is the course the heavens follow in their governance. To oppose it is to harm one’s Father."

"What does this mean?"

"Now, people regard the earth as their Mother, from whom they receive clothing and sustenance. Yet instead of cherishing and benefiting her, they collectively harm and wrong her."

"What does this mean?"

"Indeed, Perfected One, listen clearly. People are utterly reckless: they dig and bore into the earth, undertaking vast construction projects, disregarding the Dao. Some dig deep, reaching the Yellow Springs; others, several *zhang* shallow. The Mother within grieves and resents, while her many children are profoundly unfilial, constantly suffering in silent anguish, unable to make their voices heard.

In ancient times, when the sages’ timely governance did not extend to the fullness of the Way, the people acted recklessly, claiming the earth felt no pain. Yet the earth within suffers grievously without measure. This rises to move Heaven, though people remain unaware. The Mother, distressed by her children’s inability to restrain themselves, appeals to the Father above. Her grievances accumulate over time, piling up without end. Thus the Father’s wrath does not cease, and calamities and omens of every kind arise together. The Mother, too, is displeased, constantly enraged, refusing to vigorously nurture the people and the myriad things.

When both Father and Mother are displeased, the myriad things and the people perish—all for want of the Dao. The conduct of later generations grows daily worse, failing to accord with the intent of Heaven and Earth. Instead, they despise the words of Heaven and Earth as discordant, and further resent their emperors and kings, claiming they cannot bring order to their governance. People individually incur blame from Heaven and Earth yet remain unaware, instead shifting their faults to blame their superiors. Thus Heaven and Earth no longer love humankind.

They watch people die suddenly, though in their final moments, even the afflicted cry out in lament. Their crimes are plainly named, yet Heaven and Earth, their Father and Mother, no longer save them. Their transgressions are too grave, their exhaustion and culpability lying solely with themselves. The conduct of later generations grows ever more extreme, surpassing what came before. They imitate one another, making it customary, no longer restrained or mutually prohibited. Thus disasters multiply daily, and they truly wrong Heaven and Earth together.

Heaven and Earth are the Father and Mother of humankind, yet their children collectively harm them, wounding and afflicting them—this is no minor crime. Therefore, Heaven and Earth most resent disobedience and defiance, no longer pardoning such offenses. Though people’s lives are short and countless die, none can claim injustice. Perfected One, do you truly understand this?"

"Yes, yes." [End]

[Appendix] The positions of Heaven and Earth are like the distinction between male and female in humans, and their likes and dislikes are all the same. Heaven nourishes the life of humanity, while Earth nourishes the form of humanity. Now, all people collectively harm their Father and Mother. The qi of the four seasons is Heaven’s inspection tour, yet people go against it, thus harming their Father; regarding Earth as Mother, from whom they receive clothing, food, and nurturance, they do not cherish or benefit her, but instead harm her. Humanity is utterly without propriety, disregarding the Dao/Way, boring into the earth, and greatly mobilizing earthworks—some so deep they reach the Yellow Springs, others several *zhang* deep. The Mother alone grieves over her children’s great lack of filial care, constantly suffering from sorrow, resentment, and pent-up distress, yet unable to make her words heard.

In ancient times, the sagely ones, though attuned to the times, could not fully comprehend the intentions of Heaven and Earth. Ordinary people, ignorant of the Earth, do not feel her pain and suffering, nor do they perceive her influence upon Heaven. Thus, the Father’s calamities arise anew, and the Mother grows angry, no longer nourishing the myriad things. When both Father and Mother are enraged, how can their children escape disaster? Now, Heaven and Earth are supremely compassionate, yet for the gravest disobedience and defiance, they offer no pardon—how can one not take heed?

"Today, Heaven has sent you to come and ask in full, knowing that I can speak. Perfected One, you must not take this lightly; you must not fail to be cautious."
"Yes, yes."

"Now, people collectively harm their Father and Mother, defying their decrees. In your view, Perfected One, can such beings be long nurtured? Thus, Heaven does not greatly pity them."

"Today, the Celestial Master pities the foolish and wishes to explain fully: by what means can one know that Heaven and Earth are constantly aggrieved and resentful, and that their hatred of humanity arises from the frequent excavation of earth?"

"Excellent! That Heaven has sent you to inquire so earnestly shows you are truly Heaven’s messenger in asking this."

"Yes."

"I deeply revere Heaven and dare not conceal anything, fearing I would bring disaster upon myself. Now, I shall make this clear to you, so that it remains etched in your heart forever—never to be forgotten. Consider this: when one household undertakes construction and excavates earth, several households suffer afflictions—some meet death, others face banditry, official prosecution, or warfare and litigation; still others encounter harm from serpents, wasps, tigers, wolves, or vicious birds. Great earthworks bring great misfortune; minor excavations bring lesser calamities. This is the Earth’s wrath, causing spirits to generate such disasters. Thus, when Heaven and Earth afflict many, this is clear proof—do you understand?"

"Yes, yes."

"Now, in some cases, excavation brings good fortune without harm—why is this?"

"Excellent question. In truth, all excavations bring harm, but those who encounter good earth do not immediately afflict others. Instead, the misfortune is often borne by distant regions, and only after a long while does it eventually harm people. Those who encounter foul earth cannot endure such restraint—they inflict harm at once. Why does this misfortune extend to distant places? It is like a person of good and kind disposition: though wronged, they can endure for a time, yet their heart does not forget, and in the end, they will bring harm. A wicked person, however, cannot endure even for a moment—they act immediately."

"Excellent! Excellent! Now, the Earth’s body is vast and accumulated, while humans, compared to it, are tiny and insignificant. What we do is trifling and hardly worth mentioning—how then can we swiftly anger the Earth?"

"Excellent challenge! Heaven has left you unclear on this point—how do I know? Because your words carry great sincerity. If you now wish to say, ‘Why does my heart feel stifled, longing to speak its fill?’ It is because the numinous essence of Heaven and Earth dwells within your belly, urging you to speak, though you yourself are unaware. Whatever humans desire to do, it is Heaven that moves them."

"Yes. I dare not conceal anything."

"You possess luminous virtue."

"Yes, yes."

[Appendix] When excavating earth brings no disaster, it is because one has encountered good and virtuous land; when it does bring disaster, it is because one has encountered malevolent land. How can the landlord harm people, even those far away? Consider this: a good and virtuous person, though wronged and harmed, may endure for a moment, yet their heart never forgets; a wicked person cannot endure even for a moment—they bring disaster upon themselves at once. The Earth’s body is vast, while humans, compared to it, are tiny—how can our digging and boring cause it harm?

[Question:] "Now you say that humans are insignificant, and their actions cannot swiftly anger the Earth. Yet consider a grown man, standing ten feet tall and ten spans in girth, whose teeth are plagued by decaying worms—tiny and hardly worth mentioning, like those in any person’s mouth. When the great affliction strikes, the man wails in agony, and in time, his teeth all crumble and fall out. Compared to Heaven and Earth, a person is as small as such a worm harming a man. Teeth are among the hardest things, made of metal, stone, and bone. If mere fleshly worms can so afflict a man, how much more can human actions harm the Earth? Do you understand this now? Go on, True One, and further clarify this for me."

"Yes, yes." [The speaker pauses.]

Now, consider again a man whose body stands ten feet tall and measures ten spans in girth. The worms in the cavities of his decaying teeth, tiny and hardly worth mentioning, feed upon his teeth. When the great affliction strikes, the man wails in pain, and in time, his teeth all crumble and fall out. Compared to Heaven and Earth, a person is as small as such a worm is to a man. Teeth are as hard as metal, stone, and bone, yet these tiny worms, mere flesh, can cause such harm.

"Or take a man who stands over ten feet tall, whose body exceeds ten spans in girth. A festering worm, no longer than an inch, tiny and insignificant, dwells within his skin. Day and night, it bores into him, and the man falls ill—even to the point of death. Compared to the Earth, a person is as small as this worm is to a man. Though this worm is tiny and seemingly negligible, why does it end up destroying the man? True One, how can you be so foolish and blind? Why do you make such a grave error, no different from the common folk?"

"I am truly unworthy."

"If even you fall short, what can be said of ordinary people?"

"I have been foolish and ignorant. I beg you, Heavenly Master, to enlighten this unworthy student. Please fully explain your meaning."

"Very well, I shall not conceal it. I know the severity of Heaven and Earth’s affliction, which is why I speak to you thus. Now, let me tell you another matter so that you may clearly and deeply understand.

"Yes, yes."

"Consider a mighty man, a warrior of great strength, who cannot restrain the scabies mites—tiny creatures hardly worth noticing. If a mere handful of them feed upon him, he suffers such pain and agony that he cannot lie down, and in severe cases, he is bedridden. Now, scabies mites and fleas, though small, when they gather in great numbers and feed upon a person, become like venomous worms, killing the host. They cause restlessness, prevent one from sitting peacefully, and give rise to sores and ulcers. Compared to the Earth, a person is as small as these creatures are to a man. Do you now understand?"

Here now stands a mighty man, a warrior of immense strength, who cannot restrain the scale insects—tiny creatures scarcely worth noticing. If a mere sheng of them feed upon him, he suffers such pain that he cannot lie down, and in severe cases, he is bedridden. Now, mole crickets, fleas, and lice, though small, when they gather in great numbers and feed upon a person, become like venomous worms, killing the host. They cause restlessness and fullness, prevent one from sitting peacefully, and give rise to sores and ulcers. The harm that humans inflict upon Heaven and Earth is just like this.

"Come, now—perhaps you see what I have said as insufficient to serve as a model. Let me explain further. Though humans are small, their grievances and sorrows distort the very form of the Earth, making it plain for all to see, so that one’s deep transgressions and reproaches are immediately apparent.

Consider this: a large village has a hundred households and a hundred wells; a township has a thousand households and a thousand wells; a county has ten thousand households and ten thousand wells; a commandery has a hundred thousand households and a hundred thousand wells; a province has a hundred million households and a hundred million wells. A large well is a zhang deep, a medium well several chi, and a small well three chi—all dug down to the Yellow Springs. How many are there in the world? Some households have several wells.

Now, reckoning only by small wells: ten wells stretch three zhang, a hundred wells thirty zhang, a thousand wells three hundred zhang, ten thousand wells three thousand zhang, a hundred thousand wells thirty thousand zhang. How many wells in all are there like this in the world? Everywhere the earth is pierced, water is reached—water being the Earth’s blood and vessels. Now, if one were to pierce your body and reach your blood and vessels, would you not fall gravely ill?

As for these hundred million wells, how many li do they span in breadth and length? You may calculate this yourself. How many hundred million wells are there in the world? Thus, the grievance humans inflict upon Heaven and Earth is already clear.

You injure and sicken your mother, causing her severe affliction. The Earth’s qi leaks and dissipates, her illness runs deep, yet people neither cherish nor pity her. Instead, they complain of their own grievances against Heaven and Earth, asking why the harmony is not pure. Is this not perverse? They merely recall the countless wells.

Now, throughout the world, great mounds and tombs, hills and mountains are excavated; gold and stone are mined; tiles and bricks are fired; pillars are erected; reckless digging and dredging of ditches and channels abound. How many are blocked or dammed, where flow should be unimpeded? How many springs and streams, which ought to flow and circulate, are obstructed or misdirected by such reckless digging?

When springs and streams should flow freely, their benefit spreads and is proclaimed. They follow the Earth’s natural channels, flowing from high to low. Yet now, some act otherwise, wantonly altering the land’s form, creating sores and ulcers. Some are blocked and severed, where they should flow but do not. When royal governance is disharmonious, the Earth falls gravely ill, yet none speak of her pain and sickness.

The Earth’s spirit ascends to Heaven, crying out in grievance without cease. Heaven and Earth, in turn, are both displeased and joyless. Thus, the Great Harmony and pure qi are difficult to attain. Do you, Perfected One, not understand?"

"Yes, yes."

Now, people dwell between Heaven and Earth, and ought to have dwellings to shelter themselves and wells to drink from—how is this so?

"Excellent is your question. Today, Heaven does not resent people having dwellings, but rather that they dig too deeply into the Earth, creating sores and ulcers. Sometimes they strike the Earth’s bones, sometimes its blood—what does this mean? Springs are the Earth’s blood; stones are its bones; good soil is its flesh. Striking a spring is wounding its blood; breaking stone is shattering its bones. To dig deeply into good soil and cast bricks, stones, and hardwood into it is to strengthen oneself at the Earth’s expense. The Earth alone suffers grievously from this, and the harm is not slight—what is to be done?

The Earth is the mother of all things. Those who delight in and cherish her do not realize her weight. It is like a woman with child in her womb: if she follows the Dao and does not recklessly pierce her body, her mother remains unharmed. But if she recklessly pierces her mother in seeking life, her mother falls ill. If people do not dig deeply into the Earth but merely dwell upon it, just enough to shelter themselves, the Earth does not suffer. Great love for humanity brings good fortune to all. Now, I wish to hear how much shelter is sufficient.

Whenever soil is moved and earth is dug, it should not exceed three feet. Why is three feet the measure? One foot deep: the sun shines there, and its qi belongs to Heaven. Two feet deep: where things grow, and its qi is harmonious. Three feet deep: it reaches the Earth’s body, and its qi is yin. Beyond this, one injures the Earth’s form, and all becomes inauspicious.

How was it in ancient times with cave dwellings? They too harmed the Earth’s form, but less so. Most were built in mountain valleys, forming grottoes, and within the Earth, few wooden beams or pillars were set. With fewer pillars in the Earth and more reliance on flowing water, the harm to the Earth was slight, and thus people fell ill less often. Later generations, unaware of this error, dug deeply into the Earth, and so many did not live long. Why? Because this is a grave illness."

[Appendix] To dig into the Earth and strike a spring is to wound its blood; to strike stone is to break its bones; soil is its flesh. To take blood, shatter bones, and pierce flesh, then cast bricks, stones, and hardwood into the Earth, is to create sores. The Earth is the mother of all things, and to afflict her so—how can she be at peace? When people dwell upon their mother’s body, there are limits to how much they may shelter themselves.

Digging one foot into the Earth: the sun shines there, and its qi belongs to Heaven. Two feet deep: where things grow, and its qi is harmonious. Three feet deep: it reaches the Earth’s body, and its qi is yin. Beyond this, one injures the Earth’s form.

[Appendix] Today, Heaven does not resent people having dwellings, but rather that they dig too deeply into the Earth, creating wounds. To strike the Earth’s bones or blood: springs are its blood, stones its bones. The Earth is humanity’s mother; to recklessly pierce one’s mother is to make her ill and sorrowful, and so people themselves fall ill and do not live long.

Whenever soil is moved and earth is dug, it should not exceed three feet: one foot deep, where the sun shines and qi belongs to Heaven; two feet deep, where things grow and qi is harmonious; three feet deep, reaching the Earth’s body, where qi is yin. Beyond this, one injures the Earth’s form, and all becomes inauspicious. In ancient times, people relied on mountain valleys and grottoes, setting few beams or pillars in the Earth, and so they fell ill less often. Later generations harmed the soil excessively, and thus many fell ill.

"Now, some dwell near flowing water and do not dig wells, yet many still fall ill and do not live long—why is this? Heaven and Earth are already angered, and their neighbors bear the burden together, like a family’s transgression affecting its brothers. Some do not move soil or build anything new but simply occupy old dwellings, yet still encounter misfortune—why? This is because their actions are inauspicious and offend the spirits.

What spirits? There are many, and they cannot be named in advance. Do you, Perfected One, understand?"

"Yes, yes."

"[Appendix] Someone asks: 'Nowadays, those who dwell near flowing water yet do not dig wells—why do so many fall ill and fail to live long? What is the reason?'

The answer: 'In such cases, it is clear that Heaven and Earth are already angered, and their neighbors bear the burden together, passing the misfortune among one another, like a family’s transgression affecting its brothers. Moreover, digging into the earth always reaches water, for water is the earth’s blood and vessels—how could one not fall ill?'

It is also said: Someone asks, 'Now, some do not move soil or build anything new but simply occupy old dwellings, yet still encounter misfortune—why is this?'

The answer: 'Such actions are inauspicious, offending the spirits and bringing misfortune.'

The questioner asks: 'Which spirits are offended?'

The answer: 'The spirits are not one, and their names cannot be fixed in advance.'

Thus, when people dwell upon the earth yet do not earnestly teach one another to do good, their misdeeds rebound upon each other. This is called *yuan* (grievance).

Now, some live far from flowing water; if they must obtain well water to drink in order to survive, what should they do?'

'Excellent is your question! If there is an old well, it is best to share it together and take care not to change it frequently. Once changed, the old well should be filled in to block the earth’s *qi* and prevent its dissipation. To drink from the earth’s form weakens the earth, rendering it unable to nourish things. Why must the old well be filled and its center removed? This refers to the well’s tiles, stones, timber, and other materials—things that were not originally present but now exist, like an abnormal growth in the human body causing illness.'

'How profound! How profound!'"

"Sir, you have not yet inquired of the Heavenly Master in detail—there is more to know than this."

"True Man, come forward."

"Yes, yes."

"When you ask about matters, why do you always seek such thorough examination?"

"The reason I examine so closely is this: when I meet with the Heavenly Master, he speaks of human destiny lying within Heaven and Earth. When Heaven and Earth are constantly joyful, then governance brings Great Peace, and longevity follows. Thus, dwelling between Heaven and Earth, I am ever fearful and indignant toward them, and so I strive diligently. If Heaven and Earth are not in harmony, I cannot fulfill my years."

"Excellent are your words! The reason I am ever fearful is that I see the poisonous *qi* of Heaven and Earth accumulating in great abundance, with unceasing harm and slaughter. Emperors and kings suffer hardship, their governance uneven, and I constantly aid them in their worries. Why do you also take it upon yourself to share in the ruler’s concerns?"

"I have heard that accumulating merit among men brings recompense from Heaven. Therefore, I always delight in aligning with the will of Heaven."

"Excellent is your intent!"

"Now that the Heavenly Master has enlightened this foolish student and shown me the taboos of Heaven, I humbly beg to ask one more doubtful matter.

〈Rising〉 Now, when building houses and huts in low-lying fields near rivers and seas, if there are no pillars or beams, and one digs merely three feet into the earth to reach water, what should be done?"

"Excellent is your question! This is equally harmful. It is best to dig more shallowly."

This is but the earth’s thin skin, close to its meridian channels. If you wish to know its effect, compare it to a man: thick skin makes blood hard to draw, yet once drawn, it is still an injury; thin skin makes blood easy to draw, yet once drawn, it is still an injury—both are harmful. Thus blood is Heaven and Earth’s solemn pledge of trust. To wound a man is to disregard whether his skin is thick or thin; the sight of blood makes the offense plain. Man mirrors Heaven and Earth and does not wish to be wounded; when wounded, they grow angry. How could Earth alone delight in being wounded? For Heaven and Earth are the true root of man, the father and mother of yin and yang. How could you ever be permitted to wound your parents?

〈Pause〉

Noble One, you must ponder this with a sincere heart. Foolish men may treat it lightly, careless and unaware—this is a grave transgression.

〈Rise〉

Now, you draw sustenance from your mother, so when men dig wells to drink, what great offense is there? Your words have already strayed from the luminous will of Heaven. Men drink from their mother by seeking the place where her springs emerge. A mother’s milk is the wellspring that parts for her child. The place where she nurses is like the earth’s water springs that nourish men. How could you recklessly pierce her skin and drink her blood and sap?

〈Pause〉

Noble One, your questioning is most unthoughtful.

"I have erred, offending the Heavenly Master’s taboos."

"Not at all. Yet if questions do not probe deeply, one cannot attain the ultimate teachings. I do not fault your words. This must be Heaven’s great urgency that moves you to ask again and again, so your words bend and turn without cease."

"Now, may the Heavenly Master forgive me and remove my transgression. This foolish student wishes to speak but cannot restrain himself."

"Proceed, why be modest? Since you have labored to come from afar to question Heaven and Earth, take care never to suppress or conceal my writings."

"Yes, yes. If people do not see this book, they remain unaware of their heavy sins, instead constantly compounding their offenses against Heaven and Earth. How can there be harmony? How can any evil not persist?"

"Men do not know that each person bears transgressions against Heaven and Earth, passed down in succession, so that later generations inherit accumulated disasters. Without the Mandate of Heaven, life and death become unpredictable. Noble One, strive diligently and do not let this text perish, lest Heaven and Earth grow ever more wrathful."

"Yes, yes."

"If the Noble One incurs their punishment, it will be dire."

"Yes, yes."

"Take this book and entrust it to a virtuous ruler. It should be shown to all people, for man is the child of Heaven and Earth, the foremost of the ten thousand things. Now, how should one act as their child? Each must reflect deeply. From this day forward, if you desire wealth, longevity, and freedom from illness, ponder these words, inscribe them in your heart, and make plans for your own body. Noble One, do not conceal this—pass it on and speak of it to others. Now, the spirits of Heaven and Earth follow this book as it circulates, observing men’s words. Do you understand, Noble One? How do I know they follow men? Because my words are not false. If you dare to suppress or conceal this book, you will fall ill; if you dare to sever its transmission, misfortune will come. This is clear proof that the spirits of Heaven and Earth watch over men—how fearsome!"

"Yes, yes."

"Go now, and exhort yourself! Exhort yourself! Man’s life depends on Heaven and Earth. Those who seek peace must first bring peace to Heaven and Earth; only then can they attain lasting tranquility. Yet now, men instead grieve Heaven and Earth, harming their own parents—how can they ever find safety and good fortune? This has accumulated over a long time, so disasters and calamities never cease. My words are not mistaken. I have often seen Earth’s spirits rise to lodge complaints, never ceasing. Therefore, I truly know that □□ when they see the Noble One, it is as if they repeatedly ask questions, knowing you as Heaven’s messenger. Your coming to question is Heaven’s wish to reveal this matter at last, so that men may understand. The common people only know to blame Heaven but do not deeply blame themselves."

"Now, why has Heaven caused me to ask this at this time?"

"The reason Heaven has you ask this is that the Supreme Peace qi of the Highest Emperor Above is about to arrive, and governance will attain Great Peace. Yet I fear the foolish people will persist in violating Heaven and Earth’s taboos, disrupting the upright qi and causing misfortune. If this happens, the Supreme Peace qi will not harmonize in due time. Thus Heaven has sent you to ask, desiring that the people no longer transgress, so that Heaven and Earth will be free of illness and cherish mankind, allowing the five grains and the ten thousand things to flourish and nourish them. If they neglect this and grow resentful, refusing to cherish and nourish men, then in years of impending famine, there will be no good things; in years of prosperity, all things will thrive. Do you understand, Noble One?"

"Excellent! Excellent!"

"In ancient times when Great Peace prevailed, why were the people not forbidden from disturbing the earth?"

"Excellent is your inquiry! When Heaven and Earth first arose, there was nothing like the present age."

"How is this made clear?"

"Now the celestial capital has been fully established, and thus it summons those imbued with qi—divine persons, perfected persons, immortals, Daoist masters, sages, worthies—all to emerge and assist the virtuous ruler in governance. This has never occurred before. Since the opening of yin and yang, Heaven has registered its people for service, yet never has there been such a time as this. Thus it is the greatest of all."

"How astonishing! How astonishing! Therefore, the foremost Dao is now revealed, teaching the people of the world the methods of goodness. When people are good, their governance is secure, and the lord-king delights in leisure without care."

"Excellent! Excellent! How joyous! How joyous! Thus, let the perfected one swiftly produce this text, taking care not to conceal it, so that it may be shown to all the people. When the common folk see the prohibitions, they will cease of their own accord. If they do not stop, calamity will extend to later generations, and there will be no remedy. To offend Heaven and Earth is to leave no room for prayer. Does the perfected one truly understand this?"

"Yes, yes."
"Go now. If you have doubts about the text, come and ask."
"Yes, yes."

*Right [Section]: Resolving Heaven and Earth’s Grievances*
*Collated and Combined Text of the* Taiping Jing*, Scroll 46, Part C (12)*
*Scroll 46 of the* Taiping Jing*: "The Priceless Dao: The Method for Repelling the Barbarians" (62)*

"The Celestial Master is about to depart, with no set time for return. I humbly beg to ask one or two lingering doubts."
"Go on, speak quickly. My journey is imminent. What is your question?"
"I humbly ask the enlightened master about the Daoist texts you previously bestowed upon your disciple. To speak of them seems immodest, and their greatness defies description. If I do not ask now, will I remain ignorant of them for all time?"
"Go on, do not hesitate."
"Now, may the enlightened master instruct this foolish disciple."
"Very well."
"What is the value of the Daoist texts you have given me, both before and after?"
"Ah!
How profoundly foolish you are! Do you suppose the Dao has a fixed price?
Very well."

"Let me explain fully to you, so that you may awaken and deeply understand the weight and value of the Heavenly Dao. Suppose I now bestowed upon you a thousand *jin* of gold to offer to the state—could this win the joyful favor of Heaven and Earth, harmonize *yin* and *yang*, eradicate all disasters and anomalies, grant the ruler and king long life, and bring about supreme peace? Suppose you carried back to the state ten thousand pairs of jade bi-disks, treasures to be hoarded—these are the rarest treasures under Heaven—could this cause the *qi* of grand harmony in all six directions to manifest fully, auspicious omens to appear in their entirety, and the barbarians to retreat ten thousand *li*, ceasing their harm?

Now, the Dao I have given you in its entirety is capable of winning the profound favor of Heaven and Earth for the emperor, causing all ministers under Heaven to rejoice in unison, and making even the crawling and creeping creatures leap with delight. The barbarians will retreat and submit, auspicious omens will appear in full, disasters and harms will be wholly eradicated, the state’s lifespan will be prolonged, and the people will live to old age. If one truly delights in goodness and follows my writings step by step, seeking only to grasp their essential meaning, there will be no lack of response—like a heavy compass aligning with the square, with no deviation.

The accomplishment of great matters is... [lacuna]. I speak for Heaven and do not deceive you. Now, if this Heavenly method is offered to assist a virtuous emperor, freeing him from care so that he may wander in leisure each day—what, then, is its value? Has your foolish heart not yet understood?"

"Understood."

"Let me further expound one matter for you.

Among all things in the world that delight in goodness and bring joy to others, none surpasses a beloved woman. When one obtains her, she bears children with him, their hearts united as one—truly, nothing is more delightful in goodness and lovable, without equal.

Now, if ten thousand such women were bestowed upon a state, all would rejoice and be glad, and those who beheld them would forget their age. Yet could this truly pacify Heaven and Earth, win the hearts of the myriad states, cause the eight distant realms to respond in harmony, and bring about universal peace?

My Dao alone can pacify the boundless heavens above and harmonize with the inexhaustible earth below. The eight directions will all delight and come to submit; even the restless multitudes will be transformed by its virtue and power, each attaining what they seek.

How great is its value? Ponder this deeply in your heart.

If you wish to joyfully repay Heaven’s profound merit and gain its favor, swiftly present my writings in return. Even if you piled rare and counterfeit treasures high enough to reach the heavens, Heaven would not be pleased, nor would you gain its true heart. To win Heaven’s favor, you must day and night reflect upon my words. Once you grasp their meaning, you will also gain Heaven’s heart—how great, then, is its value?

Thus, bestowing a thousand gold upon a state is not equal to imparting a single essential teaching that can govern it. Gifting a state ten thousand pairs of jade disks is not equal to advancing two great worthies.

For essential teachings and great worthies—precious Dao—can enable an emperor to govern at ease, resting his head in peace, bringing about great joy and universal harmony, eliminating disasters, and pacifying the world. How great, then, is the value of such essential teachings, great worthies, and wondrous Dao?

Therefore, the sage emperors of antiquity were never impoverished in wealth, yet they constantly lamented their poverty in men of talent. They grieved that great worthies did not come, that the people did not gather, and that all sought attachment to foreign lands, growing daily more distant and few. For this reason, they failed to meet the heart of August Heaven and were ever sorrowful.

If one merely delights in amassing rare and counterfeit treasures, cherishing them, one cannot win the hearts of Heaven and Earth or pacify the Four Seas. Even if gold, jade, and rare treasures were piled high for a thousand *li*, reaching up to Heaven, they could never summon great worthies, sages, or immortals to come and assist in governance.

Ponder deeply my writings, and great worthies will come of their own accord to aid the emperor’s rule. Once they gather and deliberate together, it will be as when people assemble in a marketplace, each bringing what they possess, and all that is sought can be obtained.

If my writings are put into practice, Heaven and Earth will grow brighter, the sun, moon, and constellations will all shine with redoubled radiance, illuminating the eight distant realms. The Four Barbarians will see this and delightedly come to submit; worthy scholars will emerge in full, no longer concealed. Weapons and armor will be wholly discarded, and the world will proceed with folded arms, no longer harming one another. All will be of one heart in goodness, rejoicing together in the emperor.

My writings alone can bring this about—how great, then, is their value? Do you now understand?"

"To grant a state a thousand *jin* of gold is not equal to imparting a single essential teaching that can bring governance and great peace, eliminate disasters, and pacify the world.

The emperors of antiquity never worried over wealth, but only over their poverty in men of talent. They grieved that great worthies did not come, that the people did not gather, and that all sought attachment to foreign lands, growing daily more distant and few. Thus, they failed to meet the heart of August Heaven.

Even if rare treasures were piled high for a thousand *li*, reaching up to Heaven, they could never summon great worthies, sages, or immortals to come and assist the emperor’s governance.

Therefore, the sages of antiquity alone deeply understood the Dao and valued the harmonizing of *qi*, so they did not rely on earthly treasures but entrusted all to those of virtue. Those of virtue know the hearts of Heaven and Earth, thus they honor the Dao and revere virtue.

Foolish men prize rare and counterfeit treasures, and so Heaven’s scriptures do not descend, nor are they bestowed upon sages—this is the reason.

Be cautious, my words are not mistaken. Guard my Dao well.

A man who carries precious jades, gold, and money travels in darkness, yet still sits vigilant over them, unable to sleep. These are but treasures—how much more should one guard the Heavenly treasure of secret charts and writings, which alone can pacify Heaven and Earth, the Six Directions, and the Eight Distant Realms?

Go forth, and be doubly cautious."

"Yes, yes."

---

"My writings are guarded at all times by the divine officials of Heaven—be ever vigilant of this."

"Yes, yes."

He rose and said: "My writings are constantly followed and illuminated by the divine officials of the Three Luminaries."

"Yes, yes."

"My writings are the heart and mind of Heaven—ponder them deeply and with utmost clarity."

"Yes, yes."

"If you heed my words, I shall further reveal to you matters unseen."

"Yes, yes."

"What passes from my mouth to your ear must not be widely transmitted. Should an emperor obtain these teachings, the world will submit; the spirits will aid his governance, and people will naturally do good, achieving harmony without daily decrees."

"Yes, yes."

"All six of my disciples are dull and benighted, incapable of speaking of such matters without transgressing taboos. Now, I alone shall lay bare the Dao and virtue before the August Heaven, crafting for emperors an eternal treasure. I shall disclose all hidden matters without concealment. If I receive solemn instruction and secret command, I shall not dare to leak them."

"Very well. Now, I shall consult the August Heaven on your behalf. If it is right to disclose all, I shall not dare to withhold anything; if it is not right to disclose, I shall not act recklessly. The movements of Heaven and Earth each follow their own cycles. Now, I shall examine the timing of these cycles to ensure their enduring practice, bringing great fortune to households and states, averting peril and collapse. The reason these teachings are not entrusted to petty men but to emperors is that emperors, in their mandate, ever align their hearts with Heaven and Earth—only they can enact these principles. Petty men cannot, and so they are entrusted to the noble, to be passed to the rightful recipient."

[Right: Explanation of the value and ranking of the Dao and virtue, clarifying and penetrating the hearts of the foolish.]

**Tai Ping Jing Collated Edition, Scroll 47 (Bing Section, Part 13)**
**Tai Ping Jing, Scroll 47**
**The Supreme Good Minister, Child, and Disciple: Attaining the Immortal’s Methods and Secrets for the Lord, Father, and Master (Chapter 63)**

The Perfected One spoke:
"Among those who serve as ministers, children, or common subjects, who may be called the *supreme good* person?"

The Perfected One, though weary, should exert utmost care to explain this well for me.

"Very well. I only fear I may err in the opposite direction."

"Why so modest?"

"As you command. Truly, among those who serve as ministers, children, or common subjects of the state, one who is ever reverent and trustworthy, never daring to violate the king’s laws—from birth to death, never committing a grave transgression, living without blame—such a one may be called the *supreme good* person."

"Hmph! Your words *seem* correct, yet they are not. What you describe may be called a *middling good* person, not one of *supreme* goodness. Go on—Perfected One, explain again for me: what should the conduct of the *supreme good* filial child be? Speak with utmost precision."

"Having already missed the mark in the Master’s eyes, I dare not speak further."

"Why so modest? Speak only what you know. Where your words fall short, I shall clarify for you."

"Very well. The conduct of the *supreme good* filial child is this: ever upholding the Dao, never causing parents worry; dwelling in constant good care, morning and evening cherishing their kin. From the time of one’s birth, from the moment understanding dawns, never committing a grave transgression or incurring blame—this is the *supreme* filial child."

"Hmph! What you describe *resembles* the truth, yet it is not. This is but a *middling good* person, not one of *supreme* filial devotion. Your shortcoming is not an error—it is merely insufficient. Now, as I have taken you as my disciple to model proper conduct, observe what I shall say. Your words, as they stand, are such that the ignorant and benighted masses, difficult to instruct, would—after long accumulation of folly—see one of *supreme* filial goodness and perhaps even find fault with them. You fall short, so I shall explain for you."

"Very well."

"Though weary, explain again for me the *supreme good* disciple."

"Having already erred twice before the Master, I dare not speak further."

"Go on—you must exert yourself and speak with care. For a disciple to hear teaching and not believe it is a far graver transgression. But to fall short is a failing shared by all under Heaven from ancient times to the present. Speak plainly."

"Very well."

"Now, as for being a disciple, one must at all times, morning and evening, remain compliant and reverent, following the master’s teachings and instructions without the slightest deviation. One must not recklessly distort the master’s words, nor dare to cause the master worry in going out or coming in. From the moment one receives the master’s instruction, one must not transgress into wrongdoing or deviance, but day by day turn toward goodness, harboring no ill intent, never opposing the master’s will—this is what makes a disciple of *supreme* goodness."

"Alas! What you have said nearly resembles it, yet it is not the *supreme* good disciple—it merely accords with one of *middling* goodness."

"I truly fall short. Though this foolish student, seeing the master’s stern instruction, has exerted himself to speak of three matters, none of these three have met the Radiant Master’s expectations. The fault is grave, and I fear further transgressions may not be absolved."

"All people’s conduct falls short in some way. You bear no ill intent, so there is no fault. Now, the people of the world are all profoundly benighted, not one understanding what is right. Even from you, a Perfected One, such explanations are common—what then can be expected of the vulgar and foolish masses?"

"That I so often fail to grasp the truth is indeed due to my own foolishness. I am fortunate that the Heavenly Master, in every matter, takes pity on me. Since you have already deigned to instruct me, I humbly beg you to further enlighten me on what I have not yet attained. Such kindness is the mark of a truly enlightened master."

"I shall now set forth for you a full explanation. Exert yourself and commit it to memory."

"Yes, yes—I shall."

"Now, the *supreme* good subject, child, or commoner conducts himself thus: ever morning and evening, he worries and cares for his lord and king. His thoughts are only to bring him peace, to cure his pains, and to delight in the ruler’s ability to govern with ease. His subjects and ministers all emulate him in filial piety and kindness. In governance, he rejoices in allowing the king to sit in tranquility and wander at leisure. Such rule wins the favor of Heaven above and the approval of Earth below, while at the center, it ensures that the myriad people are all joyful, with none harboring grievances or losing their proper place.

All creatures, even those that crawl or walk, are transformed by his influence, and none perish from plague. The ten thousand things all attain their rightful place. Heaven and Earth harmonize, the Three Qi are all pleased, and the lord’s lifespan is extended while his years increase. The people, in turn, seek rare prescriptions and extraordinary arts for their ruler, bringing forth even the most closely guarded and hidden texts. The world responds in unison, exclaiming in wonder: *Ah! Such goodness has never been seen before!*

From the eldest to the youngest child, none know how to do evil. All hold fast to their rare and wondrous arts, offering them to the lord and king. When the ruler obtains them, he may prolong his years. All pity their aging lord, and when his governance aligns with the heart of Heaven, Heaven and Earth may even send spirits to bear medicines and announce: *Take these and consume them, and you shall know no end to your days.* This is what is brought about by the conduct of the *supreme* good subject, child, and commoner. Perfected One, do you now understand?"

"Yes, yes."

[Appendix]

All creatures that crawl upon the earth turn toward the wind and are transformed; the myriad things each attain their proper place. Heaven and Earth rejoice in harmony, and the lord of men gains added years. From the eldest to the youngest child, none know how to do evil again. The world pities their ruler, fearing he may grow old, and Heaven and Earth must send spirit-beings to bear divine medicines and announce: *Take these and consume them, and your life shall know no end.*

You may now be said to have awakened. Thus did the supreme subjects and commoners of the Highest Antiquity and the First August Emperor conduct themselves. By what means could they seek and attain such perfect governance? By this Dao, which is my Dao—the foremost scripture of Highest Antiquity. Perfected One, ponder deeply its meaning, and you shall align with the heart of Heaven. I reverently receive this from the heart of Heaven, and below, I shall explain it to the Virtuous Lord to dispel calamities and remove all harms. In awe of Heaven’s majesty, how dare I not convey its words in full?

Heaven, in its dawn-light wrath, commanded that I inscribe this for the Perfected One. Hasten to deliver it, that the Supreme Virtuous Lord may obtain it for governance, becoming like unto Heaven—what difference then between him and Heaven?

"Excellent! Excellent! Having heard the words of the Heavenly Master, I now understand that the true qi of Great Peace has indeed arrived. The means by which it is attained have already been revealed. What joy! Why should there be any sorrow?

Now, the people are not your concern—why then do you rejoice at the sight of goodness and grieve at the sight of evil? The reason is this: when the qi of goodness arrives, the qi of evil and wickedness hides away. I remain ever at peace, free from illness and harm. But when the qi of evil arrives, the qi of goodness hides away, making me fear calamity and dare not act—so it is throughout the world. Thus, I rejoice at the sight of goodness."

"Excellent indeed are your words."

"The Heavenly Master, in his compassion, has already expounded the way of the supreme good subject, child, and commoner. I now wish to hear of the art of supreme filial piety."

"Excellent is your difficult question.

Now, the foremost among the supremely good and filial children thinks of his parents growing old and departing. Alone in quietude, he reflects on this, ever grieving in his heart: *How might I obtain the art of undying life, that I may dwell with them always?* He scorns wealth and esteems the Dao, seeking only to sustain them. He composes mournful melodies and sorrowful songs to gladden his parents, transforming their hearts so that they may enter the Dao. Joyfully, he wishes to dwell with them for all time, never knowing age. He ceaselessly seeks rare prescriptions, traveling to distant lands. His utmost sincerity moves Heaven, and he exhausts all his strength in this pursuit.

His clothing and food are sufficient for himself, and he no longer hoards treasures for later generations. Instead, he relieves all the sorrows and hardships of his parents, sparing them the burden of guarding such things. Even the spirits of those who have died before in his household are not pleased by sorrow and hardship. When he eats, he does not seek auspicious blessings but only says: *Strive and take care of yourselves in the earth below—do not torment yourselves by grieving for me.*

This is the conduct of the most excellent filial child of the Highest Antiquity and the First August Emperor. When the four directions hear of his goodness, none fail to rejoice from afar, all desiring to emulate him. Thus do they follow his example, and for the lord and king, they give rise to ministers of kindness and filial piety.

The filial child’s concern for his parents and the good minister’s concern for his lord should be like this.

Perfected One, what you have just spoken of are but the actions of those who seek balance and wish only to preserve their own bodies—what benefit do they bring to their lord, father, or teacher? How can they be called supremely good people? These are merely self-protecting and self-serving individuals.

If even you, Perfected One, regard this as goodness, how much more so would the common people? Those who see themselves as cautious and trustworthy, never violating the king’s laws or incurring guilt, weep and wail, claiming: *I have not betrayed Heaven, nor my lord, father, or teacher.* Yet your conduct merely preserves your own body. You then falsely claim merit before your superiors, wailing to Heaven and Earth—all of you belong to the foolish and inferior, incapable of becoming supremely good people.

Now, I have explained this in detail for the Perfected One so that you may transmit this text to the Supreme Virtuous Lord, deeply instructing the assembly of worthies. Let them all awaken and discern for themselves whether their actions are right or wrong, and whether they truly benefit their lord, father, or teacher.

Since the Middle Antiquity of the Supreme One, people have grown increasingly foolish, daily accumulating wealth and engaging in perverse conduct. Yet they falsely claim merit before Heaven and Earth, their lord, father, and teacher—these are the great rebels, those who utterly fail to comprehend principle. Perfected One, do you not understand this?"

"Yes, yes."

"You may be said to have awakened. Now, to practice goodness is truly difficult—take heed. If you do not diligently propagate my teachings to resolve the great afflictions of Heaven and Earth, enabling emperors and kings to wander carefree without worry or trouble, bringing joy to all under Heaven, even extending to the grasses and trees, then you have not yet become a person of supreme goodness. You are merely one who preserves your own body, so how can you be placed alongside Heaven and Earth? Those who seek only to preserve themselves are petty men of the worst sort—do you understand this?"

"Yes, yes."

"You may be said to have awakened—take heed!"

"Yes, yes. Now, the Celestial Master, in compassion for the foolish and lowly who fail to grasp the Dao, wishes to hear once more of the conduct of the disciples of supreme goodness."

*[The Master rises and speaks:]*
"Indeed, the disciples of supreme goodness, after receiving the Dao and virtue from their teacher, reflect on their teacher’s grace and thereby attain completion as persons. They then remain ever in the company of the worthy, never straying from their ranks. Some obtain official positions to repay their parents, while others delve deeply into the Dao, mastering the arts of self-nourishment. When a person is born of parents, completes their moral cultivation under a teacher, and gains honor and esteem from their lord, they dwell alone in contemplation, mindful that their lord, father, and teacher will age, with none to succeed them. They constantly ponder how to act in a manner worthy of their teacher, seeking rare methods and extraordinary texts to repay their debt. Such reflection stirs a righteous sorrow, for they find nothing extraordinary. Thus, they further their studies, serving the worthy, entrusting themselves to their teacher, and speaking on their behalf. Some enable their teacher to become a fine minister to the state, thereby further benefiting the governance of emperors and kings. Such are the disciples of supreme goodness from the Highest Antiquity."

*[The Master concludes.]*
"Later generations of enlightened lords and worthies are also called people of supreme goodness. As for you, Perfected One, you may now speak of easy teachings, caution, and trustworthiness. If from this day forward you fail to grasp your teacher’s intent, you will merely be a compliant disciple, concerned only with preserving yourself. How then can you benefit those above, or be called a good disciple? You have spoken at length, yet the common folk—foolish people—constantly claim merit before their teachers, and this is indeed so. As subjects, sons, and disciples, if they do not follow the instructions of their lord, father, or teacher, they commit the great crime of rebellion and forfeit their names. The good sons, subjects, and disciples you describe merely avoid transgression—they do not truly embody goodness. How foolish! What is goodness? Thus, the common people are ignorant, while you alone have long been thoroughly enlightened. Now, by your words, I have measured them and know their truth: they have lost the correct path, entered into falsehood and deception, and remained deluded for so long! Therefore, Heaven alone knows this deeply, and in its anger, it is displeased. Disasters accumulate, and people inherit one another’s burdens. If, as you say, one merely preserves their body without transgression and claims merit before Heaven, Earth, and others, this is the height of folly—take heed again. Your words do not yet fully align with the will of Heaven. My purpose in having you speak is not for your sake, but to observe the gains and losses of the common people, to see what constitutes their greatest transgressions. Thus, I have you speak to discern their crookedness or straightness. Do you also understand this?"

"Yes, yes."

"Go, you have awakened. Originally, when you first awakened as a Perfected One, I did not wish to speak with you. But seeing your earnestness and daily devotion to goodness, I have spoken deeply with you, expounding the intent of Heaven and Earth, resolving the sorrows of emperors and kings, the grievances of the common people, and the disorder of the myriad things. Now that I have set forth these teachings and principles for you, I hold nothing back—simply strive to remember them."

"Yes, yes."

"Previously, I observed many disciples, but none were fit to converse with, so I did not engage in thorough discussion with them. Thus, my Dao has never been transmitted—do you understand?"

"Yes, yes."

"Go now, you have understood."

"Very well. Since the Celestial Master has shown compassion for this disciple, granting me unguarded true words: when a lord is worthy, his ministers are many in loyalty; when a teacher is enlightened, his disciples speak without reservation."

"Excellent, your words have grasped the awakened meaning—act upon them."

"Now, do Heaven and Earth truly possess the methods of immortality and the arts of agelessness? Can they be obtained?"

"Excellent question, Perfected One. Indeed, they can be obtained. The elixirs of immortality accumulated in Heaven are as numerous as the grains stored in the Grand Granary; the garments of immortals are as plentiful as the white cloth amassed by the Grand Steward; the dwellings of the multitude of immortals are as numerous as the residences of the imperial bureaucracy. They always dwell in the Great Dao and thus enter Heaven. The Great Dao is the abode and lodging of the divine and numinous. When a person possesses the Dao and virtue, they dwell in the lodgings of the imperial bureaucracy. Heaven does not begrudge the arts of immortality or the garments of transcendence—it is difficult to bestow them upon people. Those without great merit before Heaven and Earth, who cannot govern the great afflictions of Heaven and Earth, harmonize the qi of yin and yang, or benefit the Three Luminaries, the Four Seasons, the Five Phases, and the gods and spirits of Heaven and Earth—Heaven does not grant them the arts of immortality or the garments of transcendence. These are reserved for those with extraordinary merit. Do you wish to know their great efficacy?"

Just as the emperor possesses the grain of the Grand Granary and the cloth of the Imperial Weaving Bureau—how many bushels and pecks fill the Grand Granary, yet those without merit or virtue cannot obtain even a single pint. Those who commit transgressions, instead, are cast into its prisons, where their crimes are rectified, their offenses recorded, and their punishments meted out. This is clear proof.

Now, people are truly wicked, discordant with the heart of Heaven, so Heaven does not fully reveal its finest remedies. Instead, day by day, it sends spirits and numinous beings to examine, flog, and strike those without virtue, which is why the sick do not cease and the dead are many. This is like a local magistrate governing chaos: prisons overflow with criminals, and violent deaths abound. Such is the meaning.

If one has rendered great service to the emperor, one’s palace chambers will overflow with official grain and cloth, ensuring constant sustenance and raiment. The destiny of emperors lies in always contemplating governance with the good. Why should they be stingy? The duty of a ruler is to unite with the worthy and, in gentle harmony, govern the world together. A lord without worthy ministers, a father without filial sons, a teacher without obedient and good disciples—such sorrows are beyond words.

Thus, in high antiquity, the Three Sovereigns ruled with folded arms, free from affairs and cares. Their ministers were prudent and good, grieving for their lords, their hearts pained by rectitude, and so they dared to aid their lords in governing the world. Moreover, they sought and obtained the immortal recipes of Heaven to bestow upon their lords, enabling their rulers to attain longevity. Some, having rendered great service, were deemed worthy to ascend together as immortals, jointly administering the affairs of Heaven, where Heaven further provided them with clothing and sustenance. This is clear proof, not empty words.

Yet since the middle antiquity, many have envied the true Dao, sealing and severing it, deceiving one another with false ways, beguiling the people, and reducing the number of the worthy. Thus, rulers and ministers alike suffer hardship, unable to govern the world, and many fail to attain long life. This is not solely the fault of those in the lower antiquity; its origins are long-standing, and the great blame lies here. Do you also understand this?

"Yes, yes."

Thus, Heaven has amassed an incalculable store of rare recipes and immortal garments, yet without great merit, none may obtain them. It is like a person possessing the halls and chambers of a local magistrate, its grain, coin, and cloth—dwelling constantly in the Great Dao, maintaining a household without concealment. Yet those without merit or virtue cannot obtain even a single peck of grain, a single coin, or an inch of cloth. This is clear proof.

Therefore, since the high and middle antiquity, the true Dao has daily waned, and the recipes of true longevity and immortality have become unattainable. Those who, despite their transgressions, attain long life are merely the longest-lived in the world. Why? Where true virtue and power abound, correct qi is plentiful, so people fall ill less and live long. Where deceitful and false refinements multiply, perverse and malign qi abound, so people fall ill often and fail to attain long life. This is the natural law of Heaven.

Thus, the ministers of the Three Sovereigns were rich in the true Dao, so their lords lived long. The ministers of the Five Emperors possessed less of the true Dao, so their lords’ longevity did not match that of the Three Sovereigns. The ministers of the Three Kings possessed even less of the true Dao and could not equal the Five Emperors. The ministers of the Five Hegemons, at best, wrought false refinements and calamities, lacking even a single strand of the true Dao, so many died prematurely. This is clear proof. Those who occasionally attained long life were merely the longest-lived in the world. Do you deeply understand this?

"Yes, yes."

Therefore, the sages and worthies of old merely observed the auspicious and inauspicious omens they received to know their safety or peril, fortune or misfortune. Those who received the highest auspicious omens had already attained the utmost governance. Those who received middling omens resembled middling people. Those who received the lowest omens resembled the lowest people.

"What does this mean?"

It means that if one receives omens like those of the Three Sovereigns, one has attained the highest rank. If one receives omens like those of the Five Emperors, one has attained the middle rank. If one receives omens like those of the Three Kings, one has attained the great middle-lower rank. If one receives omens like those of the Five Hegemons, one has attained the lowest rank.

"How can this be clearly demonstrated?"

Excellent is your question.

Those who govern without punishment yet achieve self-regulation are of the highest rank. Those who issue decrees and are slightly feared or revered are of the middle rank. Those who govern with minor punishments are of the great middle-lower rank. Those who rely on deceptive achievements, falsity as truth, lose their laws, indulge in superficial embellishments, issue empty documents, administer affairs with harsh punishments, proliferate perverse texts, and lack a true Dao to uphold—these are the effects of the lowest hegemonic way.

In ancient times, the sagely and wise merely observed the celestial decrees they received to know their superiority or inferiority.

"To whom should one entrust the wish to receive such teachings?"

It may be that worthy offspring are born to assist in governance, as when a family is about to flourish, it must bear worthy children. Or the Yellow River and Luo River may produce responsive texts and charts as proof—this is the case.

"Do you understand?"

"Yes, indeed."

"Let me further clarify for the Perfected One. When a family is in decline, it bears wicked and malevolent children. When a ruler is in decline, Heaven does not grant worthy and good ministers to assist. When a family is in decline, descendants do not pursue true and upright virtue; instead, they favor flattery, falsity, and superficial embellishments, practicing perverse and licentious methods—thus, the household falls into misfortune and chaos.

Yet when a family prospers, it must seek true virtue, extraordinary texts, and rare methods to save itself. When a lord is about to rise, Heaven bestows upon him true texts, true Dao, and true virtue, and good people join him in governance. The Yellow River and Luo River may still occasionally issue decrees, disasters and harms diminish day by day, auspicious omens arrive daily, and good responses grow ever more numerous—these are the effects."

"Excellent! Excellent!"

"Go forth, Perfected One, exert yourself with diligence. You shall render great service to Heaven and assist the virtuous lord in attaining wisdom."

"What does this mean?"

"To render great service to Heaven, you are now one who has departed from the world of men. If you cannot gain renown in governance, how can you render service to Heaven?"

"What should I do now?"

"Simply entrust these writings to the Lord of Virtue. The Lord of Virtue is the Son of Heaven, aligned with the will of Heaven. Through this governance, he shall repay Heaven’s profound merit, pacify the realm, and elevate his own standing—thus, you too shall attain good fortune and preserve your longevity."

"Excellent! Indeed, indeed."

"Go forth, the discourse on the three practices is now complete. Let this be shown to all worthy and ordinary people, that later generations who seek to do good may follow this path."

"I dare not. Yet those who pursue only their own wealth and profit claim to do good, placing themselves above Heaven, the lord, the father, and the teacher."

"The practices of which the Perfected One speaks may still be balanced and elevated, but the deeply foolish who accumulate evil natures and wicked deeds are beyond enumeration. If these writings are passed down to later generations, and each person earnestly examines and practices them, how can they fail to benefit Heaven, the lord, the father, and the teacher? Yet if their actions merely increase for their own protection and profit—Heaven knows the hearts of men all too well, hence the multitude of afflictions."

"Well said! This foolish student has beheld the words of the Heavenly Heart Master and is greatly awakened."

"You may be called one easily awakened. In this world, there are many deeply foolish people who trust only their own ignorant hearts and no longer heed the words of others. The fault lies in their destruction of the Heavenly Dao, causing emperors and kings to suffer distress.
