This arises precisely from such deeply foolish scholars, who envy true Dao and virtuous power, dismissing what is worthy while trusting their own unbenevolent hearts. Heaven is pained by this, and thus has sent forth these writings for lords of supreme virtue, that they may attain this Way, secure their persons, and bring order to governance. Those who align with the will of Heaven—the sovereigns of the Great Antiquity and the August Emperors who were deeply favored by Heaven—precisely followed this path. Does the Perfected One not understand?"

"Indeed, indeed."

"Go now, you have understood—depart and reflect upon it."
"Indeed, indeed. I humbly ask to inquire one more matter."
"Speak."
"Master of Heaven, you have expounded these teachings and texts—why are they so numerous?"
"Excellent, your question! It may be said you have grasped the intent of the Dao. Yet the world’s preferences for good and evil are equal in principle but differ in application. Thus the Dao is largely the same but varies in minor ways. This single matter is divided into fifteen hundred and twenty characters, yet even this is but a small portion of the Heavenly Dao, a mere outline of the kingly Way. If one were to encompass all that exists between Heaven and Earth, above and below, the eight directions, the six conjunctions, and inner and outer realms, this text could not contain its power. Does the Perfected One understand?"
"Indeed, indeed."
"Go now, you have understood. Entrust this text to a lord of virtue and power, that he may promulgate it and enable all people to reflect upon their conduct and its gains and losses, thereby relieving the afflictions of Heaven and Earth and bringing peace to emperors and kings—then governance will swiftly be ordered. Does the Perfected One comprehend?"
"Indeed, indeed."
"Go now, be diligent and do not neglect this."
"Indeed, indeed."

Here is the translation:

**Section Sixty-Four: Distinguishing the Right Conduct of Rulers and Ministers, Fathers and Sons, Masters and Disciples, and Discerning Good and Evil, Gains and Losses in Their Actions—Governing People Through the Dao, Not Through Coercion**

The Perfected One stepped forward. "Should ordinary people govern others through stern authority, fear, cunning, and constant coercion? Is this not improper? Speak with precision."

"Indeed, people ought to govern others through stern authority, fear, cunning, and coercion. Why? Because only thus can one rectify and rule others."

"Alas! The Perfected One speaks as a mere commoner, unworthy of the title *Upper Perfected One*. Your words are those of the vulgar, failing to align with the heart of Heaven. The discourse of an *Upper Perfected One* must harmonize with the heart of Heaven. Now, to govern others through stern authority, fear, cunning, and coercion—this is detested not only by ghosts and spirits but also by the gods of yin and yang. Indeed, since the opening of Heaven and Earth, the shared affliction of the world, the very disorder that all seek to remedy, arises from this coercive governance. It does not bring true submission.

Thus, those who submit under duress harbor resentment, and ghosts and spirits, Heaven and Earth, come to their aid. People, too, resist those who coerce them and assist those who are coerced.

Therefore, the ancient Three Sovereigns and supreme sages governed others through the utmost Dao and virtue. They did not rely on stern authority, fear, cunning, or coercion. Those who govern through stern authority, fear, cunning, punishments, and penalties are no different from bandits and thieves. Bandits and thieves, too, rely on such means to coerce others. How, then, can the noble distinguish themselves and manifest their difference? Yet the Perfected One advocates this—is this not folly?

Such governance has been the source of disorder in Heaven and Earth since the middle antiquity. Do you understand?

Thus, in high antiquity, rulers of virtue and power did not govern the people through stern authority, fear, cunning, or coercion. In middle antiquity, such methods were symbolically established but not dared to be employed. In later antiquity, stern authority, fear, cunning, punishments, and penalties were used sparingly to govern the people, yet disorder still arose.

When foolish generals of the lowest order rise, the way of hegemony flourishes. They intimidate their officers and soldiers with authority and punishments, and so officials and commoners repeatedly rebel.

Therefore, those who govern through the Dao live in clarity and purity. Those who govern through virtue advance and retreat with measured balance. Thus, the people of later antiquity are difficult to govern, for they are full of cunning.

Heaven is governed by the Dao, and so its form is clear; the Three Luminaries shine brightly. Earth is governed by virtue, and so it endures humiliation. Humans are governed by harmony, and so they advance and retreat with ease, their words ever-changing and inconstant.

Heaven’s rectitude lies in its beginning, Earth’s in its middle, and humanity’s in its lowest position. Being at the lowest extreme, it turns upward.

How do we know it has reached the lowest extreme? By its words, which shift without constancy, and its speech, which varies with entry and exit.

These three qi have reached their lowest extreme. When the lowest extreme turns upward, it returns to the Dao, and only then is Great Peace achieved, resembling Heaven. When it turns to virtue, it attains middle peace, resembling Earth. When it turns to harmony, it achieves minor order, resembling humanity."

"When one resorts to stern awe, cunning deceit, and punishments, chaos arises daily, resembling the hegemonic rulers who wielded severe penalties. Now, if the Perfected One advocates stern awe, cunning deceit, and punishments, this is to violate the celestial principle."

"Yet the Celestial Master says one should not rely on stern awe and punishments. Why then does Heaven at times send thunder and lightning to strike people down?"

"Excellent! Your question has grasped the essence. The reason for such strikes is that rulers, through their reverence and authority, may inflict harm, thereby wronging others. Though humans are most noble, they may reduce others to the level of livestock, and thus Heaven punishes them. It aids those who submit to human sustenance, for this is what people detest.

Therefore, in the world, whether great or small, those who lightly wrong others will all be seen and punished, while Heaven pities and assists those who submit. Thus, the noble person who subdues others should rely solely on the Dao and virtue, not on predation or harm to wrong others.

Stern awe and cunning deceit can only subdue the lawless, not those of moral integrity. Those who wish to act without the Dao should be placed below such measures. It is like the Thunder Duke striking the lawless—this cannot be a constant practice. To act contrary to the will of Heaven and Earth, yet seek their favor, one must follow the Dao and virtue.

Thus, the sages of antiquity valued the Dao and virtue, using benevolence and love to prevail over others, not stern awe and punishments to startle and subdue. Those who rely on crooked power to intimidate and subjugate others prevent the qi of the Supreme August One’s Great Peace from aiding human governance.

The reason is this: when governance is unknown to the people, or when great grievances are bound yet none dare speak out—like bandits stealing clothes, where people know the wrong yet dare not speak, instead praising them as generals or lords—this is the case. Or when the weak lack the strength to defend themselves and dare not speak, all is blocked and cut off, causing the yin and yang of Heaven’s qi to fall into disharmony.

Heaven’s mandate to rulers is fundamentally to govern the strong and assist the weak. Yet predatory officials instead use stern awe and threats, employing cunning deceit to startle and frighten, causing the balanced qi to arrive. When a virtuous ruler governs, they fear such actions will disrupt the proper qi, and thus this is shown to the Perfected One.

It is entrusted to the ruler of supreme virtue to demonstrate to the worthy and the common people, so that officials and citizens may reflect on governance and benefit their superiors. Take care not to disrupt it. Does the Perfected One now understand?"

"Yes, yes."

"Go, you have now awakened. Depart, and always be cautious in speech; do not speak recklessly, for Heaven is not human."
"Yes, yes."

"When people fall short, it is better to ask questions."
"Yes, yes."

*Right: Methods for distinguishing victory and submission among Heaven, Earth, humans, ghosts, and spirits—what they oppose and what they assist.*

*Collated and Annotated* Taiping Jing*, Volume 48, Bing Section 14*
*Taiping Jing, Volume 48*
*Chapter 65: The Threefold Union and Mutual Communication*

Chunjin bows again and says, "I venture to ask one matter."
"What does the Perfected One doubt?"
"From morning study to evening return, I constantly dwell in quietude, pondering its essential meaning, and dare not grow lax. Yet in the Celestial Master’s writings, there is often mention of the *shanghuang* ‘Supreme August’ *qi* of Great Peace being about to arrive. What is meant by *shang* ‘supreme’? What by *huang* ‘august’? What by *tai* ‘great’? What by *ping* ‘peace’? And what by *qi* ‘qi’?"
"Perfected One, why do you now suddenly wish to question such subtle and profound meanings all at once?"
"The reason I venture to ask the Celestial Master to fully explain the meaning of the text is that the writings frequently speak of the *shanghuang qi* being about to arrive, yet I have not grasped its essential meaning. If I do not now seize the opportunity to ask the enlightened Celestial Master, I fear I may never have another chance to know it. Thus, I dare not fail to ask in full."
"Excellent are your words, unchanging for ten thousand generations! When the time of Heaven’s perfect Dao, great virtue, and flourishing benevolence has arrived, the numinous power of the August One delights in humanity’s swift compliance. Thus, Heaven’s qi stirs your heart, prompting you to inquire day and night. Heaven’s laws are meticulous—I marvel at this."

"Very well."
"Perfected One, sit at ease. I shall fully explain the meaning of these characters so that they may be transmitted without end. Now, the character *shang* ‘supreme’ is written with one stroke, then another vertical stroke in the center, and above it another embracing stroke. One above becomes three ones, ascending without cease, never descending again. Thus, it is called *shang*—its form admits nothing above it. Reversed, it becomes *xia* ‘below’: one stroke, another vertical stroke in the center, then a stroke embracing downward. Its movement descends without end, never ascending again. Thus, it is called *xia*. Those whose will constantly tends downward will, over time, sink to the lowest point, with nowhere further to descend. This is like the turbid, which delights in descending to become Earth—thus Earth is the lowest, with nowhere further to descend. The character *shang* constantly ascends, never descending again. This is like the pure, which delights in ascending to become Heaven—thus Heaven admits nothing above it. Therefore, in Heaven’s laws, each name is determined by its own form, and all things under Heaven follow this principle.

*[Start]*
Thus, the sages established laws, all modeled on Heaven’s intent. To guard the One and delight in ascending divination—divination means inquiry. To constantly delight in ascending and inquiring without cease is the most auspicious and supreme path. Thus, the character *shang* is written with one stroke ascending in divination. The character *xia* descends in one stroke of divination—divination means inquiry. Those who constantly think and inquire while descending will reach the lowest point, and those who delight in descending further will never ascend again.

*[End]*
Thus, the character *shang* admits nothing above it, signifying that governance should daily ascend, aligning with Heaven’s heart, with nothing above it."

"Excellent! Excellent! Fortunate is the enlightened Master who pities and explains the character *shang*. *[Start]* I now wish to hear about the character *huang* ‘august.’"
"To be king for a day: the stroke above is Heaven. Heaven is numbered as one; when Heaven receives the sun, it shines with great brilliance and becomes king. Thus, the character is formed by combining one and the sun with king, creating *huang*. One is Heaven, and Heaven is a ruler; the sun is also a ruler, and king is also a ruler. Three rulers combine to form the character *huang*. *Huang* signifies its numinous power, resplendent and radiant—thus it is called *huang*. The August One is the first under Heaven, with nothing able to surpass it."

*[End]*
*[Appendix]* The character *huang* is formed by one, the sun, and king. The stroke above is Heaven’s number; when it attains one and receives the sun’s illumination, it then shines with great brilliance and becomes king. One, the sun, and king combine to form *huang*. One is Heaven, and Heaven is a ruler; the sun embodies the ruler’s virtue, and king is also a ruler. Three rulers together form *huang*, signifying flourishing virtue, resplendent and radiant—the first under Heaven, with nothing able to surpass it.

"Excellent! Excellent! Fortunate is the Master who pities and explains the character *huang*. *[Start]* I now wish to hear about the characters *taiping qi* ‘Great Peace qi.’"
"*Tai* means great, signifying its accumulated greatness, vast as Heaven. All things are great, with nothing greater than Heaven. *Ping* means that its governance is greatly balanced, all affairs properly ordered, with no selfishness or deceit. *Ping* is like Earth, which dwells below and maintains balance—this is Earth’s balance. It is like a person who plants goodness and reaps goodness, plants evil and reaps evil. If people exert effort in goodness, their possessions multiply. If you favor goodness, people will respond with little, and their possessions will be meager and poor. *Qi* signifies Heaven’s qi, joyfully descending to generate life, and Earth’s qi, obediently ascending to nurture. The law of qi operates between Heaven and Earth: yin and yang unite, intermingling to create harmony. Together with the central harmonious qi, the three qi mutually nourish all things, loving and communicating without harm. *Tai* means great; *ping* means upright; *qi* governs nurturing and communication through harmony. Attaining this in governance brings Great Peace and harmony, and supreme greatness—thus it is said the *taiping qi* arrives."

"Excellent! Excellent! Does this refer solely to the harmonious qi of Heaven and Earth uniting and communicating to govern? Should all affairs be handled through the union of the three?"
"Excellent! Excellent! Your words have grasped Heaven’s laws. Emperors and kings model their governance upon them—you are like a spirit!"

"Now I shall explain this fully to you, Perfected One, that you may follow and record it."
"Yes, yes."

"The primordial qi and the natural qi of Great Harmony communicate, joining forces with one heart. In that fleeting moment before form arose, the three qi congealed and together gave birth to Heaven and Earth. Heaven and Earth communicate with the central harmonious qi, joining forces with one heart to give birth to all things. All things communicate with the Three Luminaries, joining forces with one heart to illuminate Heaven and Earth. The five phases—hard and soft—of all things communicate with the central harmonious qi, joining forces with one heart to complete and perfect the myriad things. The qi of the four seasons—yin and yang—communicate with the central harmonious qi of Heaven and Earth, joining forces with one heart to bring forth the benefits of Heaven and Earth’s creatures. The three months of each season communicate, joining forces with one heart, each completing one aspect. The high and low, level and uneven of the Earth communicate, joining forces with one heart to produce and nurture the creatures of Heaven and Earth. The male and female of creeping and moving creatures unite, together giving birth to harmony, communicating, joining forces with one heart to propagate their kind. Man and woman communicate, joining forces with one heart to bear children. Three people communicate, joining forces with one heart to govern a household. Ruler, minister, and people communicate, joining forces with one heart to complete a state. All these originate from the primordial qi and the natural mandate of Heaven and Earth. In all matters, only when the three communicate can the Dao be accomplished."

*Tai* means great, signifying its vast accumulation like Heaven—nothing is greater than Heaven. *Ping* means governing with Great Equality, where all matters are settled without imbalance, just as the Earth, dwelling below, upholds levelness. It is like a person sowing and reaping: sowing good yields good, sowing evil yields evil. The labor of plowing is repaid with abundant harvests. The qi of Heaven delights in descending; the qi of Earth delights in ascending. The two qi communicate, forming the central harmonious qi, which receives and nurtures all things without harm—thus it is called Great Peace. Heaven and Earth, with the central harmonious qi, share one heart to give birth to the myriad things. Man and woman share one heart to bear children; father, mother, and child share one heart to complete a household; ruler, minister, and people share one heart to complete a state. In harmonious generation, the three constantly communicate, joining forces with one heart to govern one office, to complete one task. If even one is lacking, misfortune arises.

Thus, with yang alone and no yin, nothing can be born, and governance perishes; with yin alone and no yang, nothing can be born, and governance perishes; with yin and yang but no harmony, nothing can propagate its kind, and all perishes. Therefore, with Heaven but no Earth, all things have no place to rest; with Earth but no Heaven, all things have no place to be born; with Heaven and Earth connected but no harmony, things cannot mutually sustain and nurture themselves. Thus, a man cannot give birth alone, nor can a woman nurture alone. Without man and woman, how can children be born? Without children, how can a household be formed, or how can one be called father and mother? Therefore, Heaven’s law always requires the union of three to accomplish anything.

Thus, the sages of antiquity deeply understood Heaven’s principles and modeled their governance upon them. The ruler is as father, symbolizing Heaven; the minister is as mother, symbolizing Earth; the people are as child, symbolizing harmony. Heaven’s mandated law decrees that all bustling creatures must communicate as three, joining forces with one heart to govern and complete one task, to complete one household, to become one body. This is Heaven’s command to rely upon one another—none can be lacking. If one matter is entangled in grievance and not resolved, the three are ruined, and the three misfortunes arise.

Thus, the ruler needs the minister, the minister needs the people, the people need the minister, and the minister needs the ruler—only then can one matter be accomplished. If even one is lacking, the three cannot be completed. Therefore, a ruler without people and ministers cannot be called a ruler; with ministers and people but no ruler, they cannot be called ministers and people. Without a ruler, ministers and people fall into chaos, unable to govern themselves or become good ministers and people. These three rely upon one another to stand; only when they come together can they be accomplished. Thus, ruler, minister, and people must follow Heaven’s law, communicating as three, joining forces with one heart to become one household. It is like husband, wife, and child forming one household—none can be without the others. This is Heaven’s essential Dao.

This is like a person having head, feet, and abdomen to become a complete body—nothing can be removed. Remove any, and it is incomplete, no longer a person. This is the natural principle of Heaven and Earth. Thus, the sages of antiquity took their model from Heaven: a man must obtain a compliant and good woman to govern with, and then they may have good children. The man is the ruler; the woman is the minister; the child is the people. Therefore, Heaven’s mandated way of governing a state is to befriend worthy and enlightened ministers, and only then can the people be harmonized. A good woman can then bear good children, and good ministers can then nurture good people. When both ministers and people are good, they can long secure peace for their superior.

Perfected One, if you wish to know its effects: Heaven is the ruler; Earth is the minister. When Heaven’s rain flows everywhere, the good earth gives birth to good things, while the bad earth gives birth to bad things—this is the meaning. Now, fathers, mothers, rulers, and ministers merely uphold the great guiding principles. The essential truth is that they rely upon their children for clothing and food. Without children, there is no posterity; when a ruler lacks people, there is insufficient clothing and food, causing constant worry and distress. Thus, the way of governing a state takes the people as its foundation. Without people, ruler and minister have nothing to govern, nothing to order. Therefore, the great sages of antiquity, in governing, devoted day and night to the people as their greatest urgency, worrying for their people. Like parents worrying over having no children—without children, how can one be called father and mother? Without people, how can one be called a ruler? Thus, Heaven’s law always makes ruler, minister, and people share the same fate, the same life, the same fortune and misfortune."

"A single office or matter losing its proper course becomes a great misfortune. Since the middle ancient times, the guiding principles of governance have often been lost, and this failure has been passed down through generations. Those born later thus suffer even more severely from its consequences, truly because ruler, minister, and people have erred in their plans, failing to deeply reflect and consider, to mutually care for and communicate with one another, to join forces and unite in purpose. Instead, they only bring sorrow and suffering upon each other.

The ruler is but one person, yet he may dwell in profound seclusion, with grievances from the four distant quarters accumulating and blocking all passage, governance failing to align with Heaven’s heart. Disasters, anomalies, and strange omens pile up without remedy. What Heaven and Earth wish to say, the ruler cannot know—this is the great fault. Without the three—ruler, minister, and people—joining their strength, wisdom is cut off, and perverse qi congeals without resolution.

Above, this makes one an enemy of Great Heaven; below, it brings great blame upon Earth. It is the great sorrow of emperors and kings, with disasters swarming unceasingly. It is the great harm to the people, the great affliction of all things. Such has accumulated over a long time—it is not merely the fault of those in the present or recent past.

Do you, Perfected One, understand this?"

"Long have I known this to be so, yet truly I know not how it came to pass—thus my earnest inquiry, for it is grievous indeed. What then is to be done?"

"Now, the qi of Great Peace from Heaven is about to arrive. When governance aligns with Heaven’s heart, all these evils will vanish of themselves. Thus has Heaven sent me to expound this fully. It desires that I remedy these failings and set forth the correct writings, which is why it has sent you, Perfected One, to inquire so thoroughly. This is how misfortune arises: by failing to model the natural laws of Heaven and Earth’s primordial qi, by failing to ensure the three—ruler, minister, and people—communicate and join strength with one mind. If the three communicate, joining strength with one mind, great peace and joy will be established at once, and disasters will vanish."

"I wish to hear how governance should proceed."

"Hasten to model Heaven’s laws, as I have described above. Heaven’s law decrees that all matters require the three to join strength with one mind. Thus does Heaven take the Three Luminaries as its pattern: the Three Luminaries ever communicate and shine together without ceasing. Since the Heavenly Contract was issued, humankind has used writing to govern, modeling the Three Luminaries. Thus does Heaven frequently cause the River Chart and Luo Writings to emerge, reinforcing the written patterns of human governance. It delights in modeling Heaven’s all-pervading, divine methods of governance, so that goodness daily flourishes and evil daily perishes.

Writing is simply the circulation of documents along three pathways. The ruler should skillfully guide those below, issuing clear decrees and instructions, teaching the people to remain in their places and submit memorials, fully reporting all they know of good and evil. They may send them by return post, or entrust them to passing merchants’ carts, or even come in person with their names and details clearly stated. When the method is thus, the good and evil of the realm will be fully revealed.

The ruler channels Heaven’s qi downward to communicate; the minister channels Earth’s qi upward to communicate; the people channel the qi of harmony upward to communicate. Perfected One, transmit this writing to a ruler of virtue. If he carefully heeds my words, great peace and joy will be established, and anomalies will vanish—not a fraction will be lost. My writings are reverently received from Heaven’s laws; they are not empty, false words. If Heaven were to execute my disciples, would you not know the gravity of this punishment?"

"Indeed, indeed."

"If you wish to obtain my writings, once you trust them, put them into effect and observe the results. When they resonate in response with Heaven and Earth, that is the proof of my words’ truth. By this great and clear verification, you may cast aside all doubt.

The Dao of governing the state, which delights in aligning with Heaven’s heart and finds security therein, lies simply in implementing this method and resonating in response with Heaven. This is the bright contract by which Heaven and humankind converse. I have seen that you, Perfected One, constantly delight in aiding virtuous rulers, wishing to repay Heaven’s great merit—thus have I spoken these few words.

I know the fault lies in this blockage and lack of communication. Once you receive this writing, the ruler should create clear teachings and good decrees. Proclaim that from this day forward, officials and people should remain in their places and diligently submit memorials, fully reporting good and evil to illuminate the governance of emperors and kings and to communicate with Heaven’s qi. None may obstruct this; those who do shall be punished for their offense for three years. Those who submit memorials in utmost sincerity, without deceit in their words, shall be summoned and employed.

How shall they be employed? Each shall be questioned regarding their talents and abilities, and appointed to a post within the scope of their strength. Why must they be appointed only to what their strength can bear? Heaven deals with people according to their abilities. To appoint someone beyond their capacity is to wrong them, and this will only congeal qi and increase disasters. The reason is this: what a person cannot do, even if you raise them from the dead, they still could not accomplish.

What people delight in most is obtaining fine things—gold and jade. Suppose a wise ruler issued a decree: whoever can clap their hands and obtain all the gold, silver, and rare treasures of the realm’s officials shall have them all, without limit. The person would be overjoyed to receive them, yet if their strength could not reach the objects, even if you bound their hands and exhausted them, they still could not obtain them.

Now, as parents and rulers, when appointing ministers and children to office, if you do not employ them according to their strengths but instead force them into positions that kill them, they will be unable to manage their duties. This will only disorder their offices, bringing sorrow and suffering to the people. When offices are disordered and the people and ministers grieve, they will look up and cry out to Heaven, proclaiming their grievances. This will move Heaven and increase anomalies.

Thus did the sages and worthies of old, wishing to align with Heaven’s heart, take great care in appointments, ensuring all were in accord with the people’s hearts. Thus were they able to accord with Heaven’s heart. What does it mean to accord with Heaven’s heart? When governance elicits a response from the people, and officials daily grow more good, faithful, and loyal—that is the proof. Then they should be promoted in due time; these are the people who aid the state in aligning with Heaven’s heart.

Some, however, seek only pleasure, greedily obtaining office for its name, yet their conduct yields no results and does not accord with Heaven’s heart or elicit a response. The emperor and kings govern by inheriting Heaven’s heart; they must accord with it. Failure to do so is a fault. If their governance yields no good response, they should be demoted to reflect on their errors. When this is done, Heaven will rejoice, and throughout the realm, none will fail to be utterly loyal and faithful, exhausting their abilities. Even those in distant, hidden places will hear of it and conceal their talents no longer.

For those who urgently submit memorials: human life is of the utmost weight and cannot be delayed for even a moment. If people continue to wail and cry out their grievances, anomalies and strange changes will only increase. Resolve and report them swiftly. Matters that can be endured should wait until autumn and winter. Why must they wait until autumn and winter? Because in autumn, all things reach completion, and in winter, all things are stored away—Heaven’s qi is settled. When things ripen in the eighth month of mid-autumn, their fruits and kernels can be distinguished. Thus should one follow the laws of Heaven and Earth, beginning in the eighth month to examine and distinguish them. The ninth month is the culmination of Heaven’s qi; by the ninth month, all things are ready to die. Thus should one thoroughly examine and read them in the ninth month, observing the abundance of good and evil.

The number ten is the end of all numbers, so by the tenth month, things return to their beginning. Heaven’s norm takes the eighth month as the tenth month, thus all things reach completion; Earth’s norm takes the ninth month as the tenth month, thus all things reach old age."

The human norm takes the tenth month as the month of *hai*, thus all things reach their death. The Three Norms are complete, and things should be reborn. Therefore, the *Gan* resides in the northwest, and all things begin their kernel in *hai*. Heaven’s law distinguishes them in the eighth month, examines them thoroughly in the ninth month, and verifies their kernels in the tenth month. Thus, the Three Norms of Heaven, Earth, and Humanity all conclude, their kernels verified in *hai*. Therefore, in the tenth month, their kernels are verified and handed down for return. The reason for this is that these three months—eighth, ninth, and tenth—are when the norms of Heaven, Earth, and Humanity all reach their culmination and should revert to their beginning. If they are not verified and their kernels not confirmed, their meaning is not attained. Heaven and Earth will not be pleased, their disasters will not be dispelled, and harm will befall the coming year. Thus, in the eighth month, one distinguishes and examines them; in the ninth month, one thoroughly examines them; and in the tenth month, one verifies their kernels and hands them down for return. This allows officials and the people to reflect anew on their transgressions and dare not repeat them. In the coming year, officials and the people will be more vigilant, and all things will be good. If they are not made to return and reflect on their transgressions, the people and ministers below will lose governance and decrees, unaware of their faults, and their hearts will not change. The Dao of Heaven is unyielding; evil will not change. Therefore, they must be made to return.

If the True Person wishes to know its efficacy, let them take what is handed down for return this year and record one copy for themselves, and also instruct officials and the people to each record one copy for themselves, observing the abundance of good and evil—this is called the "Heavenly Contract." In the coming year, when handing down for return, record another copy and observe the abundance of good and evil. Do this again the following year, recording another copy and observing the abundance of good and evil. Compare the records below with those above, and they should correspond—this is called the "Heavenly Signs Aligning in Accord." This will make officials and the people change their hearts and do good, aligning with the Will of Heaven. What is submitted should then be mostly good; if great change is made, there should be great goodness. If they remain obstinate, unchanged and unyielding, what is submitted will remain obstinate. If they persist in evil without cease, what is submitted will grow worse. If officials and the people greatly deceive and defy Heaven, what is submitted will be greatly evil and increasingly severe. Thus, this is the mirror that brightly illuminates the hearts of Heaven—it does not err by even a fraction, clearly revealing the conduct of officials and the people.

Heaven and Earth are like echoes and shadows, following what people do without fail. True Person, if you have good intentions, strive to complete this and be vigilant. Though you have come to ask about this, if it were without purpose or benefit, Heaven would silently observe. What can your words clarify? When people speak, if their words are detailed and good, others respond with goodness, and the echo likewise answers with goodness. If their words are inauspicious and evil, others respond with evil, and the echo likewise answers with evil. All things that correspond and harmonize are made so by Heaven. Do you understand now?

"Yes, yes."

Heaven is lofty, distant, and revered—how could it speak with people below on every matter? Thus, its laws all respond naturally in harmony. Has your heart now opened?

"Yes, yes. I understand. I wish to ask the Heavenly Master one more question."

"Follow the Way."

"In the middle antiquity, the August Emperor had no texts, and the Three Norms were not interconnected. How could stability be achieved?"

Excellent is your question. The movements of Heaven made the people of that time upright and simple; they all embraced the Dao, and their faith was unwavering. They communicated through oral transmission, each person desiring utmost sincerity and trust, seeking to align with the Heart of Heaven—there was not a single instance of deception. Thus, ruler, minister, and people joined their strength and united their hearts, enabling governance. If they had not been of one heart like a single family, there would have been chaos. Now, we bear the weight of the past, and texts are numerous. Yet, with increasing texts, deception grows, and even the worthy and learned are deluded, collectively losing the Heart of Heaven. Since Heaven has given rise to texts, oral transmission is no longer possible. One must verify and attain their true essence, and when the Three Norms are interconnected, the qi of Heaven will be balanced.

The laws of Heaven vary by the hundreds of millions, differing from time to time. Governance is distinct in each case, and methods vary. Now, as the qi of Great Peace is about to arrive, one must verify the original, correct characters of texts to align with the Heart and Will of Heaven. If you cannot distinguish, since Heaven and Earth established affairs, their governance has had countless approaches. Those who carry out their affairs and receive Heaven’s response are correct; those who do not receive Heaven’s response are not. This is the great clarity of the Heavenly Contract’s signs and proofs. Do you understand now?

"Yes, yes."

"Go now, and do not ask further. Though I could recount for you all matters since Heaven and Earth established affairs—explaining each character of the world’s texts—yet the proliferation of writings would overwhelm memory, serve no practical use, and bring no benefit to the king’s governance. Thus, I have only imparted the essential Dao in guidance.

For when governance falls into disorder, it stems from the patterns of Heaven—this is the great affliction of Heaven and Earth, what the sages and worthies of ancient times jointly despised. Therefore, when a virtuous ruler emerges by the Dao, he dares not create new texts but instead returns to upholding reality, seeking its root, preserving its origin. Only then may the Dao of Heaven be ordered, and the state naturally find peace.

Though you, Perfected One, are fond of inquiry, do not allow writings to proliferate further. Go and reflect upon this."

*Right [Section]: Enveloping the primordial qi, the spontaneous harmony of Heaven and Earth, all affairs in triadic resonance, united in strength and shared purpose—Heaven’s luminous contract and the harmonious, imperial governance of Great Peace.*

*Collated and Combined Scroll 49 of the C-Section, Fifteenth Chapter of the* Scripture on Great Peace
*Scroll Forty-Nine of the* Scripture on Great Peace

**Urgent Study of the True Methods, Sixty-Sixth [Section]**

Before you, Perfected One, the harmonious qi of goodness is now arriving in full. Yet people merely wander without duties—how then may their hearts be illuminated and their intentions rectified, so that they suddenly forget evil and daily grow fond of goodness, without knowing why? How may the Emperor sit with folded arms, nothing left to govern, while those of supreme virtue fill his court, and loyal, trustworthy, filial sons are all complete? By what means may this be achieved?

You, Perfected One, possess a Heaven-born heart that delights in goodness and constantly strives in concern for the Dao of Heaven. You should refine yourself and set forth a full explanation.

"Indeed, one must urgently study the true Dao, true virtue, and true benevolence."

"Why must one study the true Dao?"

"The Dao alone can guide and transform without limit, cherishing life beyond measure. Those who possess the true Dao bear the name of supreme goodness; those without the Dao bear the name of utmost evil—decay, misfortune, transgression, death, and ruin."

"Perfected One, your words on true goodness are perfect—I have nothing to add. Why must one study true virtue?"

"Those who possess true virtue can envelop and nurture without end. Those without virtue bear the name of the most inferior, weak, distressed, and impoverished."

"Excellent indeed are your words, Perfected One—I have nothing to add, for they are truly true. Why must one study the Way of benevolence?"

"Benevolence alone can embrace all with kindness, delighting in boundless giving. Those without benevolence reverse goodness into hatred and stinginess, bearing the name of great greed and baseness. Their aspirations are no different from beasts, and they cannot distinguish themselves."

"Excellent! Perfected One, I have nothing to add to these words."

"Now, Perfected One, you have spoken of three matters—I have nothing to add. Should people today strive to do good, or should they not?"

"One must exert effort to learn and do good."

"In doing good, does it not also bear a name and designation?"

"Your disciple does not yet grasp this—pray, Master, enlighten me."

"Very well. Those who do good align their actions with the heart of Heaven and do not contravene human intent—they are called good. Goodness is utterly supreme, sharing its name with the Dao. It is what Heaven loves, what Earth nurtures, what emperors must urgently attend to, and what ministers and rulers must unite in heart and strength to uphold. As for evil, it runs counter to the heart of Heaven and constantly harms human intent. It inverts the Dao of Heaven, disrupts the four seasons, incurs the hatred of spirits and deities, and is what people most despise—like the greatest harm to parents, the sorrow of the noble, and the most wretched and ruinous name under Heaven. Thus, in human conduct, losing good fortune leads to misfortune, while departing from misfortune leads to good fortune. One moment of good, one moment of evil—such are the ways of the impure and careless. Do you understand this?"

"Indeed, indeed."

"In your view, Perfected One, how should people conduct themselves?"

"Now, if people do not exert effort to study the Dao, they are deemed ignorant of it and are called people without the Dao. Those without the Dao are the most wicked and calamitous of people. If they do not exert effort to study virtue, they are deemed ignorant of it. Those without virtue who delight in harm and injury are omens of ruin. If people do not exert effort to study benevolence, they are already without benevolence. Those without benevolence walk the same path as beasts; if people share the same heart as beasts, they are but slightly better than the dead. If people do not diligently study goodness day and night, losing goodness leads them into evil. Evil is the dwelling place of death and misfortune. Thus, if people do not exert effort to study good fortune, they inevitably fall into misfortune. Misfortune is the most despised name under Heaven."

"Excellent! You have deeply entered the true Dao and will no longer revert to evil. Perfected One, you have long concealed wisdom and feigned ignorance—why is this?"

"I dared not act presumptuously."

"You are fortunate to have such ability. Speak fully of what you know—I am greatly pleased. Now that you have reached this point, having heard my words, will you turn away and abandon them?"

"I dare not. Having received your repeated instructions, I spoke only as far as my understanding allowed, not daring to exhaust the matter."

"Excellent are your words, ever so humble."

"Now, with all my heart, I seek the true gate—pray, Heavenly Master, instruct me in what I have not yet grasped."

"Very well. What you have just said is entirely correct. Thus, the great sages of antiquity, the Three Sovereigns, diligently studied the true Dao day and night. Those who did not study the true Dao were called people without the Dao. The conduct of those without the Dao is boundless, incurring Heaven’s greatest resentment. Those without the Dao are not desired by Heaven to be covered, nor by Earth to be borne. Spirits, deities, and ghosts do not wish to protect them, and all under Heaven suffer because of them. Sages, worthies, and noble persons deeply detest those without the Dao. Therefore, in the era of the Supreme Sovereigns, people all studied purity and stillness, deeply understanding the utmost essence of Heaven and Earth. Thus, they all studied the true Dao and thereby aligned with the heart of Heaven and the intent of Earth. Those who did not exert effort to study virtue were called people without virtue. Those without virtue are not loved by Heaven nor favored by Earth; people do not wish to draw near them. Their conduct is always devoid of virtue, bringing harm to rulers and disaster to noble persons. Ghosts and spirits, following Heaven’s decree, do not long support them. Thus, the worthies and sages of antiquity, upon seeing those without virtue, would not even exchange words with them. If one does not diligently study benevolence day and night, one will soon neglect affairs and become without benevolence. Those without benevolence speak in ways that contravene all matters, wounding human hearts and opposing the intent of Heaven. They resemble beasts, and thus the sages and worthies of antiquity did not walk the same path as them. Now, if people do not serve a teacher and exert effort to study goodness, they will remain ignorant and benighted, unaware of how to do good. Instead, they indulge their ignorant hearts and lightly commit evil. The conduct of evil people—those benighted and foolish—does not accord with the Dao of Heaven and Earth. They bring trouble to noble persons, disgrace their parents, grieve their clans, and act lawlessly. Ghosts and spirits, following the heart of Heaven, are displeased with them, bringing severe harm in three ways. By law, they deserve execution. The sages of antiquity regarded them as the greatest enemies. Thus, in ancient times, all verified and examined their learning, ensuring it aligned with the heart of Heaven and entered into the Dao, virtue, benevolence, and goodness. Their conduct had to accord with the heart of Heaven and Earth, not relying on superficial or flowery words. The reason for this is that losing the law of Heaven leads to misfortune, calamity, and short life, or even harm to later generations. The Dao of Heaven does not err—it has its standards and measures. Those who do not exert effort to study the great and auspicious Dao but instead treat matters lightly and carelessly will inevitably fall into misfortune. Misfortune is detested by Heaven, Earth, people, and all things; it cannot endure long. It is the root of great disaster, the gateway to calamity. Once one falls into it, death follows, and there is no return or repentance. All under Heaven know this, yet petty scholars and the greatly foolish often mock the Dao, unaware of guarding it and avoiding misfortune early. They pass on their folly, burdening one another. Later generations grow even more ignorant than those before. Thus, the true Dao is obstructed and does not spread, causing people to treat it lightly and carelessly, unable to fulfill their Heaven-appointed years. The great fault and error lie precisely here. Perfected One, upon seeing my writings, you should ponder them deeply. Take care not to conceal them, but pass them to the worthy, the gentle, and the enlightened, so they may awaken. Thus, the ancient Dao accords with the heart of Heaven and follows the intent of Earth."

There exists an ancient and great true Daoist method, which ever instructs its disciples to study the Dao, study virtue, study longevity, study goodness, study caution, study auspiciousness, study antiquity, study equilibrium, and study immortality. The reason for exhaustively expounding goodness is this: Heaven’s method ever opens the gate of the Dao; Earth’s method ever opens the door of virtue. The methods of the ancient sages ever open the path of benevolence. Thus, the ancient sages, sharing the heart of Heaven and aligning with the intent of Earth, jointly nurtured the myriad twelve thousand beings. They ever transmitted these with the intent of Dao, virtue, and benevolence, whereby the ten thousand things flourish. If transmitted with malevolent intent, all things daily decline and diminish.

Where Dao, virtue, and benevolence reside, the people daily multiply and incline toward goodness. Where Dao, virtue, and benevolence are absent, the people daily dwindle, their governance grows impoverished and bitter—this is the unchanging law of Heaven and Earth. Those who possess the heart of utmost Dao, luminous virtue, benevolence, and goodness ascend to correspond with the celestial stars and calendars, and the spirits illumine their conduct.

Thus, the ancient sages ever pondered boundless goodness, striving to the utmost so as not to harbor evil thoughts or tread the path of misfortune. The greatly foolish, their hearts ever obstructed and truly ignorant, must not be recklessly led onto the inauspicious path of decline and malevolence. They know not their great transgression against the Dao of Heaven, habitually following one another in evil, their customs so ingrained they cannot retreat.

Therefore, I reverently received the Heavenly Scriptures’ teachings and decrees, complying with Heaven’s heart to open and expand the great path of ancient Great Peace, enabling people to delight in goodness and no longer know the arts of evil. The aspirations of the people under Heaven are ever lofty, yet their accomplishments remain base, unable to fulfill their original intentions.

Thus, the superior person, indignant at death and delighting in life, studies immortality and, through diligence, attains longevity—this is the foremost among the aspiring. The middling person, aspiring yet grieving their ancestors’ early deaths, indignantly seeks the Dao to study longevity, striving to fulfill their Heaven-appointed years—this is the foremost among the resolute. Those next in rank, afflicted by frequent illness and unable to maintain equilibrium, indignantly study to halt their suffering. Through diligence, they may restore their former state, yet already slightly distressed by illness, they study to suppress it—already gravely ill. Those even lower, gravely ill and in crisis, seek Daoist arts to save themselves—already dead.

Thus, my scriptures teach people the Heavenly method of longevity, urging them to exert themselves day and night, whereby they may barely attain equilibrium. If they study only the method of equilibrium, the common person has already entered misfortune. The foolish know not that the common person’s original aspirations, ever striving for lofty goodness, cannot fulfill their intent. Thus, to elevate them highly, ascending to immortality, they may only preserve their Heaven-appointed years.

The greatly worthy, their aspirations ten out of ten fulfilled, must correspond with my Daoist scriptures. The middling worthy, their aspirations ten, may falter and slacken, attaining only five. The petty person, aspiring in the morning, forgets by evening. Thus, the greatly elevated delight in enabling the superior, middling, and inferior each to fulfill their heart’s aspirations.

Now, the people of this later age are greatly foolish, far removed from the true Dao. If they diligently study the correct Heavenly texts and methods, they may barely avoid falling into deception. If they study only the texts of equilibrium, they are already greatly deceived. If they study only elegant words and fine speech, great falsehood and treachery arise.

Heaven regards the emperor as its child and detests deception from below. When people’s conduct is rife with deceit and falsehood, the virtuous and benevolent ruler above has nothing to trust, and the common people below have nowhere to entrust their lives. If one diligently teaches and studies the true Dao day and night, they may barely attain the Dao of equilibrium. If they study only the Dao of equilibrium, they have already entered superficiality. Entering superficiality, the common person becomes greatly deluded and impoverished, thereby treading the path of great misfortune. The emperor grows sorrowful and vexed, and the people cannot be governed.

If the Perfected One wishes to know this truth, consider this analogy: a kind father and mother daily teach their child to be good, enduring hardship and denying themselves clothing and food to nurture them in old age, yet the child stubbornly persists in evil. How much more so when common people are taught with superficial and flowery texts? If they do not believe my scriptures, let those who see them reflect on their own failings.

Since the middle ancient era, those who possessed the good Dao all taught in secret, unwilling to transmit it to their disciples, instead instructing them with superficial and false texts. Through this prolonged accumulation, the Dao of Heaven has now fallen into great disorder. The calamities and prodigies of Heaven and Earth, the myriad kinds—none are without cause. The worthy and learned should deeply ponder this.

Though I do not dwell among the common people day and night, I clearly know this. The world suffers greatly, so I issue these words to instruct and entrust them—I do not act in vain. Perfected One, you must take this seriously, for Heaven’s punishment looms.

"Yes, yes. I dare not."
Whenever I hear the Heavenly Master’s words, I tremble with awe.
"Your words are correct, and Heaven will be greatly pleased and delighted, sparing you harm."
"Yes, yes."

Though one diligently studies day and night, receiving instruction in true virtue, they may barely attain the virtue of equilibrium. If they study only the virtue of equilibrium, they have already entered false and deceptive virtue. If they study false and deceptive virtue, the foolish person is already beyond reckoning. Without true virtue, they act wantonly—these are the pure destroyers of the noble person.

If one strives to study the highest benevolence, they may barely attain middling benevolence. If they study only middling benevolence, their conduct is merely equilibrium, devoid of benevolence. If they study non-benevolence, the foolish person becomes a bandit and thief, unaware of the countless killings and injuries they inflict. Acting wantonly, disregarding reason—this is the very resentment of Heaven and the blame of Earth, the great destroyer of humanity.

Those who strive day and night to study the Way of Great Auspiciousness may barely attain middling auspiciousness. If they study only middling auspiciousness, they may barely attain minor auspiciousness. If they study only minor auspiciousness, they have already entered the path of misfortune. If they study the path of misfortune, there is no longer any salvation. All are utterly benighted, knowing nothing; seeing the Way of Heaven, they call it untrue, merely deceiving and gullible. Their foolish hearts speak recklessly, disrupting the celestial patterns above and throwing the earthly principles below into chaos, bringing calamity and harm to the common people.

Thus, the scriptures of my Way are studied by all people—one must study them deeply, enabling them to ascend and join the ranks of the true immortals. If they cannot attain true immortality, they may still achieve peace, sparing the virtuous ruler from worry. True persons should deeply ponder my words and never again dismiss them in doubt."

"Indeed, indeed."

"Now, I shall discourse on behalf of Heaven, fully elucidating the responsibility of inherited burdens since the opening of Heaven and Earth. If one cannot greatly expand the methods of the Great Dao, the power of supreme virtue, the arts of longevity, and the path of supreme goodness—if people lose themselves in darkness, stubbornly clinging to their foolish and deluded hearts, gathering to do evil without restraint—then they will remain unable to comprehend the inherited transgressions and heavenly punishments of Heaven and Earth. Do you, true person, understand my words?"

"Indeed, indeed."

"Now, when sages, worthies, and lofty scholars encounter written teachings and study them, they must align perfectly with the essence of my texts, not deviating even by a hair’s breadth. Those of middling capacity, with half their intent awakened, will grasp half the truth. Those of lesser capacity, through their own effort and diligence, may still preserve the method without loss—thus does Heaven broadly raise its people.

All who delight in the teachings of the upper, middle, and lower paths without losing the method will attain the true Dao. Each will cherish themselves, daring not to treat lightly matters that bring great sorrow. The superior person, having obtained my Dao and studied it without cease, may become a state’s worthy minister. Over time, grasping its essential meaning, they may transcend the world, no longer contending in disputes or coveting power.

The middling person, studying my Dao, may become a good and upright minor official, fulfilling their allotted years. The petty person, studying my Dao, may cultivate constant reverence: fathers kind, mothers loving, children filial, elder brothers respectful, younger siblings obedient, husbands and wives in harmonious counsel, refraining from harming one another. Even unto death, no resentment lingers. Their hun and po spirits, dwelling below the earth, endure long, no longer seen to act wrongly or be called wicked offspring, nor do they suffer early death or violent demise.

In the ancient era when primordial qi first gave birth to Heaven, people all delighted in studying to become immortals, yet still could not attain longevity. At the very least, they made people fear death and avoid transgressing laws. But in this later age, people are profoundly foolish, reciting vain and florid teachings, collectively studying arts that do not prolong life. In life, they act recklessly, claiming as if they will never die, teaching one another to hold nothing dear, jointly stirring up calamities, mourning the dead with greater extravagance than celebrating life. Life belongs to Heaven, death to Earth—serving Earth in a manner that inverts Heaven is a grave harm.

By this conduct, I have observed and divined that their accumulated folly has endured so long that not one among them possesses true understanding. When misfortune arises, ghosts flourish mightily, collectively hastening to kill people, preventing them from fulfilling their Heaven-appointed destiny.

Those who strive to study the true Dao may only attain a counterfeit Dao; those who strive to cultivate true virtue may only attain a semblance of virtue. How much more so for the people of this later age, who teach one another through vain and ornate texts—how far they have strayed from the Dao! Beset by hardship and unable to restrain one another, they instead instruct each other in drafting memorials and legal codes, debating cleverly to assert superiority.

To teach them to be humane, one already fears they will not be humane—yet now they are taught to study the path of inhumanity. Heaven has bestowed laws upon humanity, calling itself the Great Dao, while Earth calls itself virtue. The reason is this: Heaven and Earth are the parents of the myriad things, the sovereigns of all affairs. Thus, they constantly guide with goodness, never daring to open wide the path of misfortune and evil—how much less should humans do so?

Humans are the children of Heaven and should model their conduct after it. Yet now they have lost the method, making governance difficult. To instruct them in the Dao and virtue is to enable them to know self-respect, self-cherishing, self-love, and self-governance. Instead, they are opened to the path of punishments and laws, causing them to view death as fleeting and to esteem brute strength while belittling themselves. They are made to govern one another in turn, thereby entangling and oppressing each other, reciprocally harming and plundering, heaping sorrow upon sorrow. Thus, no one in the world loves another—the great fault lies here.

Does the true person understand this? Be vigilant."

"Yes, yes."

"Now, when forcefully instructing in benevolence, even then they suffer from lack of benevolence. In later ages, people instead teach one another to study books—already a grave decline—yet their mutual hatred and resentment cannot be severed. When forcefully teaching them to seek good fortune, even then they suffer from misfortune. In later ages, people instead admonish one another to study the implements of death and mourning, preparing for misfortune in advance. They die before their time, nearly extinguishing their households, yet remain unaware of their errors and faults. When the moment comes, they cry out to Heaven and wail to Earth, calling themselves wronged, blaming the king’s governance for being unjust, claiming it has robbed them of their years and inner attainment.

The foolish do not guard their root; only when punishment is certain do they regret—yet regret is futile, for though they cry out in death, nothing can save them. Thus, I now forcefully instruct in the Great Immortal’s Daoist scriptures, merely opening the steps to longevity. When one studies virtue, one becomes benevolent; when one studies benevolence, one attains peace and security; thus, they dare not deceive or plunder others’ possessions. When one studies peace, one has already lost the method; when one studies the method, one has already lost mutual harm; when one studies mutual harm, one has already entered great conflict. Once in great conflict, the people, though innocent, are deceived, and poverty drives them to become thieves and bandits.

Therefore, following Heaven’s Daoist method, I open the gate of great fortune and close the path of misfortune and evil. I open the steps to Heaven’s great peace, so that all may recite and each be vigilant—no further governance will be needed. This allows the celestial cycles to turn smoothly, and the joyous king may wander at ease without trouble.

Thus, my writings thoroughly examine the root and origin of all matters, only then attaining their essence. Examining their essence, one has already grasped their foundation; studying those below the foolish only leads to great chaos. In this later age, though emperors and kings possess the virtue and benevolence of ten thousand people, their thoughts aligned with Heaven’s heart, misfortune does not cease. This is because the accumulated disasters and calamities of long-standing *chengfu* have piled up. Though they grieve and torment themselves, desiring to bring order to even one aspect, monstrous thieves and bandits of all kinds, and barbarians invading the Central Kingdom—these are the failures of former kings, not the fault of one person alone. One must deeply understand their root.

Thus, Heaven has sent forth my writings to absolve emperors and kings of the transgressions of *chengfu*. "The true Dao is upright; great virtue flourishes with benevolence, and each attains their proper place. In governance and peace, nothing strays from this unity. Does the true person understand? "Yes, yes."

"Now, this foolish student wishes to ask further but dares not speak hastily."

"Speak plainly."

"Excellent question. Observe their conduct and words."

"Very well. When one sees a person of the Dao and reacts with anger, rejecting them—this reveals a person utterly devoid of the Dao. When one sees virtue and reviles it—this reveals a person utterly devoid of virtue. When one sees benevolence and rejects it—this reveals a person utterly lacking in benevolence. When one sees goodness and vigilance and rejects them—this reveals a person who is neither vigilant nor good.

By nature: those of like minds love one another; those of differing minds hate one another. Good people also suffer from the wicked, and the wicked also suffer from the good. Does the true person understand?"

"Yes, yes."

"In ancient times, the sages and worthies, upon seeing someone, would not immediately speak with them. Instead, they keenly observed and examined their likes and dislikes to understand them. Using this as a mirror for their conduct, they never erred."

"Excellent!"

Thus the Dao shares the same bone-structure, laws, and bloodline as August Heaven; when the Way of Heaven abhors cruelty and delights in killing, to oppose it is to incur Heaven’s deepest enmity. Earth shares the same bone-structure, laws, and bloodline as virtue; when the wicked inflict harm, they commit Earth’s gravest offense. Benevolence shares the same bone-structure, laws, and bloodline as the sages and worthies; thus the sages and worthies delight in bestowing benevolence and detest plunder, making those who seize and lack benevolence the bitterest foes of the sagely and benevolent.

Therefore, the sages and worthies of old deeply understood these as the three norms governing conduct. In establishing their laws, they dared not deviate from the true Dao, virtue, or benevolence. Thus, the workings of Heaven join forces with the four seasons: when Heaven moves qi, the four seasons also move qi, acting in unison with one heart. To defy the four seasons is to incur Heaven’s enmity. Earth joins hearts and forces with the Five Phases, together nurturing all things; to harm what has not yet reached its natural end is to commit Earth’s gravest offense. The sages and worthies join hearts and forces with benevolence, thus in their travels and dwellings they ever honor the Dao and esteem virtue, relying on benevolence in their conduct. If one delights in plunder and lacks benevolence, they become the enmity and foes of the sages and worthies.

Fire corresponds to the heart, and the heart to sagacity. Fire ever dwells leaning upon wood, for wood embodies benevolence and possesses a heart. Fire bears light and can discern right from wrong; the heart is sagely and luminous. Thus the great sages of old ever dwelt leaning upon benevolence and clarity, returning to rulers of Dao, virtue, benevolence, and luminosity. Therefore, I earnestly caution: True One, entrust this book to a ruler of Dao, virtue, benevolence, and luminosity, who will surely delight in and cherish my Way, deeply comprehend its meaning, follow and emulate it, becoming no different from the divine. I do not boast to you, True One; if practiced and answered, it will surely fit like concentric circles or aligned squares, and only then will people of later ages remember my words.

"Yes, yes."

"Go now, exert yourself and strive diligently. Devote yourself to studying the Dao, virtue, and benevolence—nothing else is worth pursuing. Take this book forth; do not allow it to remain hidden."

"Yes, yes."

Here the *Illuminating the Wise and Resolving the Ignorant and Doubtful* is presented, to be consulted for decisive answers.

**Moxibustion and Acupuncture, Chapter Seventy-Four**

Moxibustion and acupuncture serve to regulate and harmonize the three hundred and sixty meridians, unblocking the qi of yin and yang to eliminate harm. The three hundred and sixty meridians correspond to the three hundred and sixty days of a year, with each meridian governing its day, moving in accord with the four seasons and the five phases, circulating externally throughout the body and converging at the crown of the head, while internally connecting to the organs.

Their decline and flourishing shift with the four seasons; when illness arises, they fail to correspond, their cycles of coming and going lose regularity, becoming knotted or injured, flowing in accord or opposition—thus, they must be treated. Moxibustion is the essence of greater yang, the clarity of impartial justice, used to examine and eliminate evil and harm. Acupuncture is the essence of lesser yin, the radiance of Venus, employed with righteousness to cut and subdue.

When treatment is effective in a hundred out of a hundred cases, or ten out of ten, this aligns with the celestial meridian prognostic texts, truly corresponding to the meridians, with spirit as its agent. When nine out of ten are cured and one is not, it corresponds to the yin meridians, with essence as its agent. When eight out of ten are cured, it is a human method, with human intention as its agent. Beyond this, it cannot cure illness and may instead harm the spirit.

Treating the *jia* meridian for a disease in the *yi* meridian is called confusion, failing to recognize the meridian’s unique injury and severance. Therefore, to discern whether the celestial Way is spiritually efficacious or not, whether it corresponds or not, simply place a patient before you—this is the meridian’s foundational text, akin to the foundational text of the Daoist scriptures.

Gather many worthy individuals to discuss the illness; some may excel in the upper body, others in the lower, and each of the three hundred and sixty meridians has its observable aspects. Record the methods of those who excel in treatment, focusing on those whose success rate is ten out of ten—those who fail are not reliable. Compile the collective methods of those who succeed, and use the cures as scriptural texts; thus, no treatment will remain unresolved.

---

The Way of Heaven governs the meridians, whether externally or internally, and cannot be fully known. Where treatment is effective in ten out of ten cases, that is the meeting point of the meridians. People vary in size, their measurements differing, yet the degrees are the same; only by dividing according to the cavities and principles can correspondence be achieved.

Daoist texts, accumulated over time, vary in their teachings, creating what is called chaotic meridians. If yang meridians are unbalanced yet yin meridians are treated instead, people suffer misfortune, harming the innocent and shortening lives. The meridians correspond to Heaven, Earth, and the myriad things, rising with the qi and cycling back to their origin.

Those who grasp these principles use them to cultivate their nature, knowing whether the seasonal qi has arrived or not, and pacifying any imbalances. The sages of antiquity sat in pure tranquility, holding their own pulses, observing the cycles of coming and going, and from any irregularity, they knew the gains and losses of the four seasons and five phases, thereby understanding the decline and flourishing of their own bodies. This is how they pacified the state, nurtured life, and preserved their allotted span—how could one not be cautious!

People, deluded, follow indiscriminate moxibustion and acupuncture, injuring the correct meridians and harming the upright qi, disrupting the four seasons and five phases, bringing forth calamities and anomalies. Great persons suffer greatly, lesser persons suffer less, and all may be moved or unsettled from their places—this is the natural course of things. Thus, the ancient sages and divine emperors valued this greatly, residing in their places, observing the movements of the meridians to prognosticate the auspiciousness or inauspiciousness of the six directions. This is what is meant by knowing the distant through the near, and the external through the internal—hence, it is the essential and divine Way.

---

**Divine Incantations, Chapter Seventy-Five**

In Heaven, there are constant divine and sagely essential words, occasionally bestowed upon people as speech, employing divine officials who respond to the qi and come and go. The people who receive them call them divine incantations.

An incantation that cures a hundred out of a hundred, or ten out of ten, is the transmission of the foundational text of the celestial scriptures. Such incantations can summon spirits to eliminate illness, and when all are effective in ten out of ten cases, there is no illness they cannot cure in the direction they are applied.

---

Merely speaking to cure illness—these are the divine prognostic words of Heaven. They are what good teachers and emperors should employ, compiled into scrolls and named the *Book of Incantation Prognostics*. These are used to summon the host of spirits, hence their tenfold efficacy.

When nine out of ten are cured, the true spirits do not arrive; the intermediate spirits do, and these are the domain of great ministers. When eight out of ten are cured, human spirits arrive, and these are the domain of those who govern the people. These are the words of the celestial spirits, originally meant to summon spirits. Their names and times occasionally leak down to earth, and Daoist practitioners, having learned of them, transmit them to one another, enabling the treatment of illness. Like sending a messenger with words, they cannot cure illness.

In matters of change, one cannot rely on others even for a moment. Heaven values human life, fearing that rare remedies are difficult to complete in haste, and that great physicians may lose the meridian scriptures, failing to comprehend matters of life and death. Thus, it places essential methods in people’s mouths—this is the art of emergency relief.

To obtain these essential words, simply place a patient before you as the foundational text of the incantation, and have each person recite the secret words from their mouths. If the illness is immediately cured, it is genuine; if not, it is entirely false, mere deceptive and reckless speech, not to be taken as a model.

Some may use incantations to cure alone, yet others applying the same fail to achieve results—such words cannot be recorded. These are the leaders of ghosts and spirits, naturally employed by people, called "solitary words," not the true Dao of summoning divine beings. Though humans are distant from heaven, how can one discern the authenticity of the Way? That which is true will harmonize and respond, fitting like tally tokens; what does not is false.

**Burial and Residence, Chapter Seventy-Six**
Burial is the original hillside dwelling of ancestors, called the "initial planting of roots." A residence is the earth where the hun-souls return to nurture descendants; a good site allows the hun-souls to return and nourish, while a bad one causes them to return and harm. When the qi of the Five Ancestors ends, it reverts to become human again. The Dao of heaven follows qi, cycling back to its origin.

To test the efficacy of a site, plant a small, lowly seed in the earth: if later days bring flourishing growth, it is a greatly generative site; if a fine seed is planted yet later days bring ill fortune, it is a contrary site; if days wane and diminish, it is a consumptive site. Test with twenty-five families’ burial mounds: if ten, a hundred, or a thousand correspond, it is the *Earth’s Hidden Treasure Scripture*; if nineteen correspond, it is the *Earth’s Hidden Treasure Record*; if eighteen correspond, it is the *Disordered Earth Scripture*, not to be used regularly; anything below this is heterodox writing, harmful texts of the common folk.

To verify its accuracy, record past events and test against future ones—only then can truth and falsehood be distinguished. Know that my writings are like heaven’s *jia* and earth’s *yi*, immutable for ten thousand generations. The testing of root matters where humans dwell must not be treated lightly. Once a matter is settled, relying on heterodox texts brings harm, causing disasters and misfortunes to arise frequently, bringing great suffering to the worthy and the people.

Thus, whether noble or humble, those who wish to transmit knowledge to descendants must carefully examine the correctness of burial sites, understand their principles, and divine future events. Take twenty-five burial mounds as the foundational text, compare them with past events, record outcomes to test the present, and use past evidence to inform the future. True masters should thoroughly ponder the text’s upper and lower sections to dispel confusion—this is called the *Yin Concealment Divination Text*, which reveals ancestors and benefits later generations, to be transmitted for ten thousand generations. Take care never to conceal it.

**Discerning the Authenticity of Ancient Texts, Chapter Seventy-Seven**
All music serves to convey sound and transform the qi of the six directions and eight extremities. When its tones harmonize, responses come in accord with goodness; when they do not, responses arrive in conflict and opposition. Sounds each have their own affiliations—east, west, south, north, *jia*, *yi*, *bing*, *ding*—the twenty-five qi each have their own domains. At times, sounds gather and form coherent phrases, thus revealing their nature.

By listening to sounds, one discerns subtle words, divines fortune or misfortune, and when the raised tone aligns with the *Blowing-Hair Pitch-Pipe*, one knows the stringed sounds—*gong*, *shang*, *jiao*, *zhi*, *yu*—distinguishing the six directions’ distances and naming their good or ill. Only the refined can perceive the spirit’s response to affairs.

Thus, the sages of antiquity regulated music to move all things, harmonize yin and yang, and stabilize the four seasons and five phases. When yin and yang are balanced, their sounds are pleasant to hear; when yin and yang are disharmonious, discordant and chaotic, their sounds are difficult to bear. Strings must also be tuned: one should use the nine-nines method, ordering the silk strings so that high and low tones harmonize, reflecting upon them without harming the viscera’s spirit. If untuned, the dance becomes disordered, lacking proper sound, unbearable to hear, and injurious to the viscera’s spirit. Thus, divine omens and auspicious responses do not arrive.

Only those who are capable and skilled in sound can harmonize and transform yin and yang. How does one know this? When the numinous and bright respond, auspicious omens and beings gather—this is the person. Otherwise, all is chaotic sound, unable to move or summon, and thus no response comes.

Therefore, in all matters, one must find the right person—like a spirit. Without the right person, it is like reckless speech. With the right person, matters great or small can all be accomplished; without them, nothing can be done. Thus, the ancient sages valued actions and sought the worthy, leaving no obscurity, becoming models for antiquity. With the right person, there is order; without them, chaos.

Ancient texts are too numerous to record in full. Use one matter to analogize ten, ten to analogize a hundred, a hundred to analogize a thousand, a thousand to analogize ten thousand, ten thousand to analogize a hundred million, a hundred million to analogize the boundless. Matters each have their own categories and affiliations. Place their foundational texts before one, so that the knowledgeable may grasp the root, and those skilled in application may expound upon them. Observe their harmonious responses: what aligns and fits is true; what does not respond or fit is entirely false.

To discern whether the writings of the ancient sages truly embody the Dao, this is like calling a person: those who know their surname and given name will respond. Ghosts and spirits are the same—they do not respond without the correct name. Though one may wish for harmony, there is no means to reach them, and thus no response comes.

Thus, the ancients called learning "pursuing essence." Essence means to focus intently on the image of the matter and appropriately reconsider its words. Exhaustively ponder these writings, and all matters will be complete. The texts above and below are numerous, each with its own subject—one should read them carefully, supplementing one with another, to fully grasp their meaning. Without deeply understanding their essential meaning, words of the Dao are ineffective, and one cannot resolve the conflicts of yin and yang.

My writings are for the benevolent and worthy, to be passed on to those with virtue. Those with virtue who receive them should treasure them. If one receives them but cannot read them well, dismissing them as not the Dao, they cannot bring joy to their person or avert calamities.

When the great Dao is about to manifest, does it not seem flavorless?

Shall its use ever be exhausted? When all worthy ones trace its origins, can they not harmonize hardness and softness, exhaust the positions of yin and yang? Once all texts and writings are fully settled, each finding its proper place, will confusion not cease? All evils having departed, the Supreme Lord rejoices greatly, and the people are free from misfortune. Does its beneficence not extend to the smallest and most subtle, all things teeming and bustling without losing their qi?
