Do they not return to the Great Beginning, the positions of Heaven and Earth established? With perverse texts vanished, is the primordial qi not preserved?

The One is the warp of the Dao;
The Two is its weft in motion;
The Three is already chaos—
no clarity remains.

〈Rising〉
My Dao begins with *jiazi* and *yichou*,
the six *jia* cycles succeeding one another.
The Five Phases turn in mutual accord,
the four seasons revolving to their origin.
Though the scrolls are many,
each has its own record.
Like the human body,
head and feet move in concert.
One word departs, another arises in its place—
the worthy order them to complement one another.
Unite yin and yang in speech,
inner and outer responding like compass and square.
At first recitation, it seems flavorless,
but with long and unbroken practice,
the proof of its truth will manifest.
Disasters depart from the body, spirits return in assembly,
people naturally become prudent and good, free from evil—
this is called the absence of punishment,
the perfection of Dao-transformations.

Examine my texts to avert misfortune:
treachery and calamity cease of themselves, the people live long.
Trace back to the origin—there is no end or beginning.

Ten matching ten: the text of Great Yang;
nineteen matching nineteen: the text of Great Yin;
eighteen matching eighteen: the text of Central Harmony;
seventeen matching seventeen: the text of Ruin and Chaos;
sixteen matching sixteen: the text of Encountering the Central Writ;
fifteen matching fifteen: the text of Ignorance—
this may be called the text of half-fortune, half-misfortune;
fourteen matching fourteen: the perverse text;
thirteen matching thirteen: the text of Great Chaos;
twelve matching twelve: the discarded text;
eleven matching eleven: the alternating text;
ten matching ten and below: unusable,
texts that lead people astray.
The harm they inflict varies in degree,
but in the end, they bring harm to people.
If used without cease for long,
the law is severed, posterity extinguished, the family destroyed—
this is the text of ten matching ten.

〈End〉
Above: Methods of texts for repelling the perverse and attaining the correct.

**Tai Ping Jing Collated and Combined, Scroll Fifty-One, Bing Section Seventeen**
**Tai Ping Jing, Scroll Fifty-One**
**Collated Texts on the Methods of Rectifying the Perverse, Chapter Seventy-Eight**

Pure prostrates in trembling reverence, bowing twice.

**"What further would you inquire?"**
**"Pure has now beheld the true and numerous texts of the enlightened master—these are the discourses of Heaven. Yet I fear [lacuna] and shock, unaware of what should come first or last. By what means may one truly rectify and obtain these texts?"**

**"If you delight in attaining their truth, simply observe the sacred words of the high antiquity, the sacred words of the middle antiquity, and the sacred words of the lower antiquity. Examine their utterances and behold their deeds—thus may it be known. Further, observe the Daoist texts of high antiquity, the Daoist texts of middle antiquity, and the Daoist texts of lower antiquity. When these three are united by like kind calling to like, it may again be known."**

**"Now, all texts and writings are discourses of Heaven—why then do they bring order at times and chaos at others, never equilibrium? I wish to hear of this."**

**"Indeed, to rectify their words and clarify their texts is to bring order; to fail in rectification and clarity is to bring chaos. Upright speech and meticulous discourse must lead to goodness; perverse speech and inauspicious discourse must lead to evil. Now, your ceaseless questioning shows your desire to know and to attain goodness. To achieve this, simply rectify the root. When the root is upright, it aligns with the patterns of Heaven and accords with the sacred words. Turning once more, it aligns with the principles of Earth; turning thrice, it becomes the patterns of humanity; turning fourfold, it becomes the patterns of the myriad things. Yet when the myriad things generate superficial flourishes, such flourishes bring chaos and ruin.**

**The celestial patterns and sacred texts emerge in their time to examine the primordial and correct the beginning, removing errors and establishing truth. To clarify and order all texts is the Dao of Heaven. Those who grasp upright speech align with the heart-mind of Heaven. Perverse speech brings perverse and malign qi, causing Heaven and Earth to fall out of harmony. The myriad things lose their proper places, and the emperor’s heart-mind is beset with sorrow and suffering. Chaos arises once more—thus, one must urgently examine and rectify these texts.**

**From antiquity to the present, all texts and writings are already complete. Yet we lament that they are gathered together without purity, jumbled in confusion. This causes the worthy and enlightened to share in doubt and delusion, uncertain of what to follow or trust. Thus, the utmost sincerity of Heaven is lost, and each follows their own contrary path. They drift far from the subtle words and great intentions of the Heavenly Dao, all becoming perverse speech and perverse texts. Such texts, being perverse, fail to rectify yin and yang. Disasters arise in succession, and the fault lies herein.**

**Seeing your earnest questioning, I cannot bear it and thus expound these matters repeatedly for you. Swiftly record my words and ponder them deeply. For in all matters, to obtain something yet fail to practice it single-mindedly is of no benefit. If one can practice it, great calamities may be averted."**

**"When the celestial patterns are in chaos, and one desires to see order restored—is this not like a person gravely ill, longing for healing? How may this be achieved?"**

**"Ah, are you truly so ignorant? A grave illness left untreated leads to death; celestial patterns left unrectified lead to great chaos. The four seasons lose their qi, the Five Phases turn against one another in strife, the Three Luminaries lack proper brightness, all deviating from their true paths—thus do they bring ruin. The people are thrown into turmoil, all losing their dwellings. The old and weak bear burdens, half perishing prematurely. The state is plunged into darkness and confusion. The supreme Dao and virtuous power are severed, the worthy are concealed and cannot aid one another—is this not a grave illness indeed? Thus, one must strive to rectify it.**

**Now, the foolish daily study superficial and floating texts, each contradicting the other to vie for superiority, unaware of the great harm they cause, dismissing it as a trifling matter. How could they know that within, it is a grave illness for yin and yang and Heaven and Earth? That the world cannot be governed and rectified stems precisely from this. The spirits and deities suffer affliction, which is why they have sent you to question me repeatedly. You must examine these texts day and night, deeply contemplating their essential meaning. Do not treat this lightly, for it is not a matter to be taken lightly by the August Heaven. Now, the emperor has no refuge for his heart-mind—his fault is grave indeed.**

**Though I now speak with you alone, this is no trifling matter. Within, I speak to rectify the words and judgments of the August Heaven. I dare not utter empty or reckless speech, for the fault would rest upon me, heavy and inescapable. The punishments of spirits and deities cannot be evaded or fled like those of mortals. Do not dare to follow my light words as if they were mere worldly chatter, vying for superiority in contradiction."**

**"Indeed, I dare not. Hearing the words of the Heavenly Master, I am both awed and overjoyed. I shall strive with all my might, hoping to align with the heart-mind of the spirits and deities, to resolve the world’s sorrows, to pacify the emperor, and to allow the myriad things to each find their proper place. This is my wish."**

**"Your wish cannot be for your own solitary good. Yet the reason I alone retain good intentions is that my learning stems from reflecting on goodness. Thus, while others age and perish, I alone endure. Though the descendants of my ancestors have all passed, I alone have not died. Truly, I have received a profound mandate, and I am ashamed before the August Heaven, unable to repay it. I constantly think to exhaust all my strength, yet I know not how to make recompense. Seeing Heaven and Earth out of harmony, wind and rain untimely, I know this is a grave illness for the world, and I ever pity it."**

**"Now, having heard the words of the divine person, I am greatly awakened. I shall strive to the death to offer myself to the enlightened Heaven, to resolve this grave illness, to pacify the principles of Earth, to firmly establish the emperor, and to allow the myriad things to each find their proper place. I hope thereby to repay and fulfill the profound merit of Heaven. Yet I know not whether I am capable. I humbly beg to ask further, for I am unworthy of the enlightened master."**

**"Excellent are your words! Hearing them, I too rejoice—what need is there to speak of Heaven? My texts [lacuna]—not one in ten thousand shall be lost."**

"Only strive diligently without slackening to govern it, and you may indeed restore the work of Heaven—doubt it no more. If even emperors and kings practice this, they shall swiftly gain its power, how much more so for you? Having heard your words again and again, I dare not hold back my utmost effort; though I am your elder, my resolve does not match yours. Now, together with you, I share this Heaven and Earth, and I wish to join you in pacifying them. I wished to say no more, but I fear I would incur grave fault before you and suffer heavy punishment from Heaven. Listen carefully once more, and I shall explain it to you again in full detail.

The true text is the very heart of Heaven and Earth, preserving the primal qi and its principles. In ancient times, sacred scriptures emerged in their time, examining the original correct characters. The Dao is transmitted through mutual dependence: subtle words elucidate it, all being essential to the primal qi. The second transmission yields esoteric phrases; the third forms chapters and verses; the fourth becomes ornate embellishment; the fifth diverges into disparate meanings, each asserting its own opposition; the sixth becomes deceptive rhetoric. Chapters and verses still retain some semblance of the original, but beyond this lies grave illness. This is what causes the Dao of Heaven to lose its way, emperors and kings to suffer long sorrow, and the profound principles to remain unattained—this is the very reason.

You, fortunate one, wish to repay Heaven’s grace and restore its great work. Heaven does not delight in people offering their wealth or rare counterfeit goods; it delights only in people jointly governing its texts without disorder. When I first saw you come to study, I thought you would ask but one or two things and depart—how could I have imagined you would seek to master the Dao of Heaven in its entirety? Though my words may not be perfect, the Dao of Heaven may yet be glimpsed.

If you delight in rectifying Heaven and Earth, take the subtle words and trace them back to verify their origin; when they align with the primal source, you shall grasp the mind of Heaven and may thereby pacify the world. Collate the texts of high antiquity, middle antiquity, and recent antiquity, summoning them by category to assemble and follow one another. Let one person hold fast to the root, for each has its own fundamental matter. All texts and writings have their own lineages; let all people bring forth their talents, gather together to expound them, and the true essence of the original words shall naturally emerge. Collect and assemble the essential sayings to form their explication, calling it ‘chapters and verses,’ and you shall attain the true heart of the Dao.

This may be called resolving Heaven’s sorrow, removing the great illness, ending the suffering of Earth, allowing emperors and kings to wander in accord with Heaven’s mind, and enabling the myriad things to each find their proper place. In this, not one in ten thousand shall be lost."

"Seeing the profundity of your words, I know you are Heaven’s messenger; I dare not deceive you. To deceive you now would be to deceive Heaven itself. Should Heaven be displeased, it would instead diminish my years, bringing harm upon myself and shame before the August Sky, while offering no benefit to the myriad people. The fault would be grave indeed. You must strive to remember this: know only that I dare not hold back any effort."

"Indeed, indeed! Hearing your words, my heart trembles with awe. Since this is Heaven’s inquiry, I dare not delay or linger—only press on to its completion. I pray you, Master, forgive my shortcomings and instruct me on what is difficult or easy, that I may dare to ask in full."

"Now, with so many texts accumulated, I wish to know their truth or falsity—just as you asked before. Those that resonate in tenfold or hundredfold accord are true; all else is false. Those that govern and yield results are true; all else is false practice. To obtain such results, the people and ministers must all be good, loyal, and trustworthy.

Why say this? If a child is virtuous, parents remain at peace and find their proper place. If a wife is virtuous, her husband avoids transgression and gains her strength. If a minister is virtuous, the state enjoys enduring stability. When emperors, kings, people, and ministers are all virtuous, Heaven knows no disasters or omens—this is the principle. Do you understand? Or do you not?"

"Very well, I now wish to discuss a matter with you. If you were to select and extract from my texts, would you thoroughly comprehend and master them?"

"I am but a youth, still unenlightened—I have not grasped their meaning."

"Try to explain it, and I shall see whether you fully understand or not."

"As this humble student sees it, one should assemble and apply them in their entirety, with upper and lower mutually sustaining each other. By examining each matter, comparing a hundred to a thousand, a thousand to ten thousand, and cross-referencing them, one may deem them sufficient. Otherwise, I fear the ancient texts cannot be fully encompassed."

"Indeed, what you say is true. Have you not recorded in my texts before: 'From one compare to ten, from ten to a hundred, from a hundred to a thousand, from a thousand to ten thousand, from ten thousand to a hundred million'—this is precisely the principle."

"Yes, yes. But whom should we appoint to carry out this comparison?"

"Let each act according to their station. Those who understand the roots of affairs rely on their foundations. Those skilled in knowledge and application shall gather to deliberate, circulating their discourse. From emperors and kings down to the common people, all shall abandon their old ways and unite in consensus. Those of lesser understanding shall first assemble among themselves, then submit to those of middling understanding; those of middling understanding shall assemble and submit to those of greater understanding; those of greater understanding shall assemble and submit to the emperor and kings. Then, all the worthy shall gather to harmonize their interpretations, refining and stabilizing them. This is how counsel reaches even the lowest ranks—no calculation is missed, no word is wasted, no text is discarded.

The lesser worthy shall collate and assemble the texts, then pass them to the middling worthy; the middling worthy shall collate and assemble them, then pass them to the greater worthy; the greater worthy shall collate and assemble them, then present them to the emperor and kings. Once the texts are □□ and their principles complete, free of error, truly aligned with Heaven’s will, and the divisions of yin and yang properly ordered, the emperor, kings, and all ministers shall together recognize their truth. Only then shall they be disseminated among the people, so that all under Heaven may recite and study the correct texts. Thus, Heaven’s qi shall be attained, Great Peace shall arrive, the qi of supreme harmony shall descend, songs of praise shall arise, all things shall abide in peace, the people shall have no complaints, false texts shall vanish of themselves, Heaven’s afflictions shall be cured, Earth’s maladies shall disappear, emperors and kings shall wander in leisure, yin and yang shall rejoice, perverse qi shall be concealed, bandits and thieves shall be eradicated, the Central Kingdom shall flourish, its glory shall rival the Three Sovereigns of old, the barbarians shall retreat, all things shall flourish, and all under Heaven shall be most fortunate, all proclaiming 'ten thousand years!'

Do not suppress my texts!"

"Yes, yes—I dare not conceal or obstruct them."

Having received the master’s instructions, you must sincerely return and report them, for to conceal them would risk incurring grave transgression and bringing matters to ruin.

"Excellent indeed are your words. Having aligned with Heaven’s will, your name shall be recorded as one who has repaid Heaven’s great merit."

"Yes, yes. I shall truly withdraw to a secluded place, ponder their profound meaning, and never slacken in diligence."

"Go now, and doubt no more."

---

*Right: Textual Examination and Secrets*
*Collated and Annotated* Taiping Jing*, Scroll 52, Ding Section I*
*The Diagram of the Womb’s Yin-Yang Rules and the Rectification of Conduct to Dissolve Evil*

The divine being speaks, the perfected one internalizes: you have already understood. To diminish the self is to fulfill the intent. External principles rectify themselves; close your eyes and gaze inward, communing with the spirit. Utter no words, and you merge with the Dao. Yin and yang enfold one another, sealed by Heaven. The art of longevity may open your eyes—do not strain the bowels, but embrace harmony and magnanimity. Heaven and Earth receive harmony as the deaf and blind receive light.

To grasp its meaning, consider the child within the womb: after ten months without eating, the spirit communes. The natural Dao has no superior; without looking, qi dwells in the twelve chambers. Thus, to revert to infancy is to avoid misfortune; to grow old and return to youth is to commune with the Dao. For this reason, the twelvefold image is drawn: the upright attain goodness, while the unworthy meet misfortune alone.

The Dao of Heaven endures, never lost or destroyed. Its form is like the four seasons, cycling back to their origin, returning to the beginning in old age—hence, longevity. Ponder its meaning without deviation; accumulate virtue, practice the Dao, and cultivate yourself. Yet no effort surpasses the Dao’s return to its rightful recipient. If one is not the proper vessel, the Dao does not act in vain.

The Dao is like the wind, silently abiding beside you. Employ it, and it exists; neglect it, and it vanishes. The worthy have their domain, the unworthy their place. Life and death reside within the self, ever fixed in conduct. Heaven commits no error; humans bring ruin upon themselves. Reflect deeply on its meaning, and you shall act without recklessness.

Heaven grants longevity to those who guard the Dao and act with vigor; humans refuse to do so and thus perish. Heed my warnings well: when you transmit the Dao to its proper recipient, it flows with ease. In ancient times, sages and worthies transmitted the Dao, swearing blood oaths. The Dao of Heaven is weighty in accumulation, yet fools treat it lightly. The Dao is the teacher of all things: those who attain it gain clarity, while those who lose it fall into confusion.

Though Heaven and Earth are vast, they do not overlook even the slightest detail. The wise and knowing nurture themselves, conversing with the divine as equals—this is the essence of yin and yang, the pivot of Heaven and Earth. The sages of old deeply understood this and thus made it their standard, distinguishing the essentials of Heaven’s Dao. Internally, it governs the self; externally, it dissolves calamities. To fail in this is to share in the sorrows of Heaven and Earth.

*Collated and Annotated* Taiping Jing*, Scroll 53, Ding Section II*
*Taiping Jing, Scroll 53*

**Distinguishing the Four Methods of Governance, Scroll 79**

The Perfected One, Pure and Reverent, bowed in trepidation: *"I now wish to ask something further, though it is no matter of the Dao. Having heard the enlightened master speak, there is nothing that remains unresolved—thus I dare, despite my shame, to press forward with a question that lingers in doubt: what is it?"*

*"Speak plainly, and I shall explain it to you."*

*"When the Son of Heaven employs great ministers, they ought all to be elders; the young are fundamentally unfit to govern the age."*

*"Why do you ask this? I observe the qi of Heaven—of late, it has repeatedly fallen into disharmony. The fault may lie with officials who fail in their duties, causing the seasonal qi to lose its balance. The lord of men lacks clarity, calamities arise in concert, and even Daoists are harmed. Now, the Three Luminaries of Heaven and Earth suffer affliction, their radiance obscured. Where can the Daoist flee to escape unscathed? Though I alone have long been favored by Heaven’s grace and endured, I dare not presume my own safety."*

*"From my earliest years, I have served masters and inquired of affairs, yet none could fully resolve my doubts. Now, undeterred by shame, I ask again of the Heavenly Master to clarify the essential meaning, lest I never come to understand it."*

*"Since the enlightened master has deigned to instruct, I, your disciple, can do no other than explain what you have not yet grasped."*

*"Excellent indeed are your words!"*

"Today, upon hearing your words, I know that the governance of Great Peace has arrived. Yet, I shall now explain it fully, and you shall record it in detail."

"Governance has four methods: the governance of Heaven, the governance of Earth, the governance of Man, and when the three qi reach their utmost, all things that walk and crawl are governed. I wish to hear their meaning."

"The governance of Heaven: when its ministers are aged, the lord treats them as fathers and teachers. Though the ministers’ positions are humble, why treat them as teachers and fathers? It is because their positions are lowly, but their virtue and power are esteemed. To treat them as teachers and fathers is to serve their virtue and power, to join with them in counsel and bring peace to the world.

The governance of Earth: the lord treats his ministers as friends, as if sharing the same aspirations and heart. Earth is yin and compliant, like mother and child in one rank, sharing the same embrace and sorrows. Though the ministers’ positions are humble, their virtue brings harmony, harmonizing the lord’s governance.

The governance of Man: the lord employs the young and small, like a father raising his child. The child is young and cannot yet devise strategies for the father, so this governance is slightly disordered.

When all things that walk and crawl are governed, the lord regards his ministers and subjects as dogs or grass and trees, no longer carefully selecting them for office. He appoints whoever fills the post, treating them as mere semblances of men without understanding. Why is this so? Such semblances only mimic human form, barely sufficient for the task, and do not consider the lord’s interests. Thus, they contend for advantage.

To emulate Heaven’s governance: all ministers under Heaven become the lord’s teachers and fathers. Thus, he treats them as fathers. People love their children—what danger could there be? If teachers and fathers can resolve the eight directions’ calamities for their children, how could there be failure?

To emulate Earth’s governance: all ministers under Heaven become the lord’s friends. With shared aspirations and counsel, they share sorrows and seek to secure their positions. Earth is compliant and follows above, fully aligning with Heaven’s will, all attaining Heaven’s favor—how could there be instability?

To emulate Man’s governance: it attains the qi of central harmony. Harmony is difficult to discern, advancing or retreating unpredictably, like a young child who cannot yet plan for his father, deceiving him. Young ministers cannot deeply plan for their lord, so they deceive him. The young have been nourished by the sun and moon for few days, their learning is shallow, and they inspire no awe—thus, they deceive. Hence, this governance is slightly disordered.

To emulate the governance of all things that walk and crawl: such creatures lack propriety and righteousness, and all things possess little wisdom and no virtue. Their nature knows no hierarchy, seeking only victory—thus, they bring chaos and ruin.

Heaven’s governance is benevolent, cherishing life and avoiding harm. Earth’s governance is compliant and good, causing minor harm. Man’s governance is mutually beneficial and desirous, frequently injuring one another, deceiving and neglecting. The governance of all things that walk and crawl ultimately achieves nothing, regardless of scale, seeking only victory.

Observing these modes of governance suffices to know whether the qi of Heaven, above and below, has reached its utmost without losing order. Those who desire the first joy should emulate Heaven; those who desire the second, Earth; the third, Man; the fourth, all things.

Emulating Heaven, one alone attains long life, gaining Heaven’s favor. Emulating Earth, one’s life is slightly shortened, gaining Earth’s intent. Emulating Man, one’s life is further reduced. Emulating all things, one dies without fixed time or number.

Emulating Heaven, the three Dao align with the scriptures. Heaven has three patterns: the luminous are the Three Luminaries—sun, moon, and constellations. The sun examines yang, the moon examines yin, and the stars examine the center. Thus, the three Dao must circulate writings, striving for wisdom. When writings arrive for the departed, they bear only the master’s name—do not ask who delivered them.

Emulating Earth, two Dao circulate writings. Emulating Man, one Dao circulates writings, barely lingering. Emulating all things, words are merely uttered, with no writings at all.

Is this now Heaven’s decree, or do men act of their own accord? Is it the course of time? Nevertheless, when an emperor’s governance approaches Great Peace, he aligns with Heaven’s likes and dislikes, emulating Heaven’s governance. For moderate peace, he emulates Earth’s governance. For minor disorder, he follows Man’s governance. For great chaos and disorder, he follows the governance of all things that walk and crawl. Why is this so?

Now, how shall we remedy this? When Heaven wills a rise, auspicious omens and prophetic writings emerge, bestowed to awaken him and grant him the mandate. When decline is willed, Heaven conceals its writings, and he is made disinclined to seek them.

Are worthy ministers merely those who are aged? No. The aged are those venerable in years and rich in virtue, emulating Heaven by steadfastly upholding the Dao without losing the slightest measure—thus, they secure their emperor. The aged who possess no wisdom are unfit for office.

How, then, does one treat them as teachers and fathers? As friends? As children? And how does one treat all things?"

To treat them as fathers is to take instruction from them as a son does from a stern father, or as a disciple receives teaching from an enlightened master. One must grasp the profound strategies and secret words of sacred texts from their heart, thereby pacifying the realm, repaying the ancestors, and offering sacrifices to the ancestral temples. Through such virtue, one repays Heaven’s great merit, thus winning the hearts of all under Heaven. Yin and yang harmonize, and disasters cease.

To treat them as friends is to join in loyalty and trust, pooling strategies to weigh good and evil, difficulty and ease.

To treat them as children: if a father conceals something, he does not dare inform his son; if a son hides a fault, he does not dare tell his parents. Both deceive one another, using this as a pretext.

As for all things—when great chaos abounds without number—creatures in spring and summer vie for life, while in autumn and winter they vie for death, no longer granting one another even a moment’s respite.

Chun prostrated himself again: “The questions I have asked are many, my transgressions grave and weighty. This is most improper; I have truly overstepped before my teacher. Moreover, I dare not conceal this text. Yet if I see it and do not act upon it, I fear I will offend August Heaven. Where, then, should I place this book?”

“Since you have asked, you must exert yourself to practice it. When you encounter one who can comprehend it, entrust it to him, that he may deliver it to a virtuous ruler. If the emperor and kings model themselves upon it and take it as their governance, they will surely become as divine. But if one receives it and fails to ponder and apply it deeply, Heaven will no longer hold you accountable.”

“Indeed, I dare not oppose my teacher’s words.”

“Yet my words must not be greatly opposed either. This is Heaven and Earth’s desire for peace, and thus the supreme Dao emerges, prompting you to journey far and inquire of this method. Heaven has sent me to speak, to transmit these words to you—I do not speak idly. If Heaven did not wish it spoken, and I recklessly revealed Heaven’s essential Dao, I would be held to account. But since you have received my words and will deliver them, there is no harm and no doubt.

I tell you in utmost sincerity: Heaven will bestow even greater favor upon the emperor and kings—thus I admonish you. Heaven’s movements have their appointed times for fortune and misfortune. Those who obtain and practice this will meet with unquestionable good fortune.”

“May I humbly ask: who is the person that will carry this out—what is their name?”

“Now, Heaven bestows upon all things without partiality. The one who asks and is first to practice it—that is the person. The great Dao is of utmost weight; it cannot be entrusted to private hands. Those who practice it will prosper; those who do not will falter.”

“May I further ask: what does Heaven and Earth observe? At this moment, would you speak a single word?”

“Truly, there is something to observe—this is not empty speech. Heaven rejoices in peace and stability, free from illness; it delights in supreme harmony. Thus, it causes the people to remain tranquil, without evil clamor or strife. Each dwelling in their proper place, free from sickness and filled with joy—then Heaven speaks and does not utter falsehood.

But if now yin and yang clash in opposition, disorderly and entangled, harming one another; if the myriad things cannot abide in their places; if the sun and moon lack good brightness and the constellations move in chaos—then Heaven is afflicted with illness, distressed and unresolved. It does not transmit its words, and the malady persists. Thus, in times of disorder, discourse arises—minor disorder calls for minor discourse; great disorder, great discourse.

Therefore, from ancient times to the present, divine perfected sages serve as Heaven’s envoys, receiving Heaven’s intent and acting as Heaven and Earth’s interlocutors. Since Heaven and Earth established their work, this has been the constant principle. Thus, the sacred texts of the sages, past and present, speak for Heaven, articulating Heaven’s affairs.

What do these words and discourses address? They attend to what is afflicted and suffering. Where texts are deficient, the Dao’s substance is applied; where substance is not understood, the Dao’s texts are used. Where wickedness and evil are afflicted, the Dao rectifies and purifies, awakening them.

Now, Heaven and Earth are most revered and divine, their divinity luminous, their position supreme. Why do they not eliminate illness themselves, instead transmitting words to humans? Heaven and Earth are the parents of the myriad things. Though the parents may be good, if their children act perversely, dwelling at the center and presiding over their wickedness, governing above and below in rebellion and chaos—though the parents are good, the household becomes evil.

It is like a son who rebels against his father, a minister who rebels against his lord, a disciple who rebels against his teacher, a wife who rebels against her husband. In such cases, mutual harm and great disorder arise, and no goodness is to be seen. Heaven, Earth, the people, and the myriad things fundamentally govern one affair together. When good prevails, all rejoice; when misfortune strikes, all suffer—thus they share the same sorrow. If they did not govern together, they would not willingly take turns bearing one another’s sorrows.

Therefore, when Heaven and Earth desire goodness and peace, they must send divine perfected sages to transmit their words, reveal their sacred texts, and communicate with one another—just as when an emperor or king seeks joy in goodness, there are good teachings. This is what is meant here.

If you wish to joyfully know Heaven’s intent, to repay Heaven’s merit, and to rescue from calamitous qi, this book of mine is the way. Receive it, ponder it well, and Heaven’s intent will be known to you.”

“Indeed, I dare not be negligent. I humbly beg my teacher to admonish me once or twice more.”

“Now, good and evil each pertain to the self. The good benefit themselves; the evil harm their own bodies. Since you possess such a flourishing good intent, grieving over Heaven and Earth’s illness and the ruler’s unease, your merit is already immense. But consider this carefully: your practice of goodness is peerless—do not cease or be discouraged. Let your thoughts dwell on goodness and follow the constant Way thus.”

“Indeed, I dare not be remiss, dare not be remiss.”

**Right Method for Dispelling Anger, Distinguishing Governance, and Ensuring Peace and Security**
*Collated and Combined Text of the* Taiping Jing*, Volume 54, Ding Section III*
*Taiping Jing, Volume 54*
*Method the Eighty-First: Ensuring No Litigation Through Aptitude*

---

“My questions have accumulated in great number, and hearing the Celestial Master’s words brings boundless joy. Yet my inquiries know no end—may I humbly beg one or two more admonitions?”

“Proceed with balance.”

“Now, I wish to grasp the intent of Heaven and Earth, yin and yang, the people, the crawling creatures, and all things under the sun, so that they may perpetually delight in goodness without cease. Let them wander each day without office or duty, their bodies each rectified, no longer turning to grieve or reproach one another. Might I hear how this may be achieved?”

“Your words now are most excellent and singular—what questions you ask, what peerless goodness! Yet if you inquire thus, you must still align with affairs, each attaining their heart’s desire. Follow their capacities and limits, never forcing what they cannot do. Thus, each attains what they wish. When each attains their wish, none will grieve or suffer. Each will fulfill their heart’s intent—this may be called wandering without office or duty.

**〈Rise〉**
Between Heaven and Earth, it is ever the way to assign tasks beyond one’s ability, to compel what one cannot achieve, and to make difficult what one cannot do. When one sees another’s inability to act or speak, instead of pitying and teaching them, one turns to reproach, causing grievances to knot and anger to breed litigation. The people grow sorrowful, distressed, and impoverished. Then they lift their faces and cry to August Heaven: *Truly, this is injustice! Truly, this is injustice!* Their qi stirs the six directions. Thus, calamities and omens arise in profusion, accumulating in myriad forms, impossible to swiftly dispel. The harm is grave—this is the loss of the world’s heart and intent. In the end, no success is achieved, and anomalies never cease. How then may the qi of Great Peace arise? Thus, Great Peace cannot be attained—this is precisely the fault.

**〈End〉**
Though one may call it ‘constant balance,’ how can internal disorder be cleansed and governance achieved?”

“You now ask this—do you wish to know it deeply and truly? The nature of Heaven and Earth is such:

**〈Rise〉**
All things have their own proper place. One must employ their strengths and what they can do, never forcing what they cannot. Though all things receive the qi of yin and yang, it is like fish that cannot live without water, nor swim upon high mountains. Yet when water is present, regardless of depth or shallowness, they may swim freely. Great trees cannot grow without soil, nor thrive in the midst of rivers and seas. Thus, the sage-kings of antiquity, when assigning tasks, took from the five soils what was fitting. Only then did things flourish and prosper, each in its excellence. The state grew wealthy, the ancestral temples offered rich flavors, and the world knew peace, free from suffering. Malign qi ceased, no longer causing harm.

If one does not divine and observe the land before planting, the myriad things cannot fulfill their natural lifespan. All will harbor unresolved grievances, perishing prematurely. This alone moves August Heaven. When nothing can be reaped, the state falls into extreme poverty. Food lacks rich flavor, the ancestral temples hunger and thirst, and the world is filled with sorrow. The people turn to mutual harm, ruler and minister deceive one another, inner and outer realms speak in discord. This is where fault first arises.

If even the myriad things cannot attain their proper place, how much more so for humans? The world cannot be governed rightly—this is the very reason. This is the root of great harm, the path to peril and ruin. **〈End〉** Can one not be cautious? Can one not deeply ponder this in heart and mind?

Thus, the great sages and worthies of antiquity, when appointing others, first tested their strengths and weaknesses before assigning office. They then entrusted them accordingly. If one erred, they reproached them, questioning their strengths but never their shortcomings. This does not offend Heaven. Instead, it fosters the refinement of their learning. Thus, they won the hearts of the world.

Later generations, neglecting affairs, failed to deeply ponder the words of the ancient sages. They appointed those unfit for office, reproached what they could not achieve, and questioned what they could not perceive. The blind cannot see the sun; the mute cannot speak. Yet they hastened to seize upon their faults, deeming them grave transgressions, and punished them. They did not seek mutual benefit and aid but instead schemed to manipulate above and below, harming one another in turn. This is the great ruin of the world.

The lords of Great Peace in antiquity possessed no extraordinary or divine Way. They simply employed each according to their heart’s capacity. Thus, they attained the qi of Great Peace and left no grievances among the people.

When calamity and chaos are about to arise, it is always because one appoints those unfit for their abilities, assigns tasks beyond their office, and heavily reproaches them. Though punishment may bring death, it cannot rectify their duties. Disasters and omens arise in succession, impossible to suppress. Thus, chaos and ruin follow. Good and ill fortune, peace and peril—all arise from this.

Therefore, when the ancients selected officials for the emperor, they first examined and tested their abilities. Did they align with the auspicious responses of Heaven and Earth, yin and yang? Those who did not align were deemed false in conduct. How did they align? The great attained great responses; the small, small responses. Wind and rain came in their proper seasons; the myriad things flourished; the hundred clans spoke no complaints; birds and beasts, crawling creatures, all rested in tranquility. These were the signs.

Thus, those who govern and wish to pacify the state must carefully consider their appointments. Heaven gives birth to the myriad things, each with its own talents and proper place. It is like the dragon ascending to the heavens and the fish swimming in the abyss—this is what is meant.

Since the establishment of Heaven and Earth, governance has taken myriad forms. As the times change, so too do Heaven’s transformations. The essential task is to accord with Heaven and Earth, attaining their intent and fulfilling their desires.”

The heavens inscribe their patterns through the Three Luminaries, marking each rise and decline, with the wind serving as the ruler of men. The earth inscribes its veins through mountains and rivers, furrows and paths—mountains exhale qi, waters course through channels, their waxing and waning, shifting and collapsing, merging and parting, all governed by the winds of change as ministers to the sovereign. Humankind transmits meaning through speech and language, through written records and evolving texts. The myriad things speak of their flourishing and decay, allowing people to perceive and understand them.

Humankind stands at the center of yin and yang, as the teacher and elder of all things, capable of the most abundant creations. Embodied like spirits yet possessing form, advancing and retreating in transformation, they must carefully record these changes and anomalies to report them to their lord. Thus, if one word remains uncommunicated, grievances become knotted; if two words remain uncommunicated, blockages arise; if three words remain uncommunicated, separation follows; if four words remain uncommunicated, harmony fails to respond in due season, and the birth of things becomes irregular; if five words remain uncommunicated, the circulation of qi leads to conflict; if six words remain uncommunicated, the six directions breed malice; if seven words remain uncommunicated, ruin ensues; if eight words remain uncommunicated, governance becomes fragmented among contending factions; if nine words remain uncommunicated, mutual harm arises; if ten words remain uncommunicated, mutual upheaval follows. Therefore, one must strive to ensure the free flow of words.

In ancient times, there were no written records—how then was communication achieved? Writing arose precisely for this purpose, though it later ceased. How often have Heaven and Earth arisen, how often have they ceased? It is only that later generations have not witnessed it. In the middle antiquity of the Three Sovereigns, words were established without writing. In later antiquity, the qi of Heaven and Earth rose and fell in cycles, yet even the divine and transcendent could not fathom their origins. Having endured many vicissitudes, they understood the principles of division and order, and though writing must have existed internally, later generations have not seen it. To claim it never existed—why then does writing appear at some times and vanish at others?

As Heaven’s qi declines, people grow foolish, weak, and short-lived, unable to inscribe and record. Thus, writing was commanded to be created, allowing transmission across time and knowledge of ancient affairs. Without writing, disputes could not be settled, each party insisting on their own rightness. Therefore, writing was devised for the sake of the ignorant, as Heaven issued its covenantal texts.

---

The disciple said, “I have heard the master’s words and now understand. I wish to know how to ensure the free flow of qi in the present age.”

The master replied, “Simply let the Three Ways circulate the writings of the eight directions, and the words of the people, officials, and commoners—do not arbitrarily obstruct them. Urgent matters should be resolved in their time; non-urgent matters should follow the rhythms of Heaven and Earth, the myriad things. Wait until the seventh month, when things reach their end, then review them in the eighth month, rearrange them in the ninth, and by the tenth month, those who have not returned should be noted. After three years, those who submit writings of utmost sincerity should be sought out and appointed. Such individuals are the state’s finest ministers, keen of hearing and sharp of sight, able to observe and listen without missing the signs of the four directions. When the emperor or king obtains such a one, governance becomes secure and enlightened—such a person must be entrusted.

---

The disciple asked, “How should one entrust them?”

The master replied, “Each must be questioned on the extent of their abilities, allowing them to record what they can do, what they can analyze, and what they excel in. Appoint them according to their innate nature, and their governance will be without error. Thus, they will win the hearts of all under Heaven, and their rule will daily advance toward Great Peace—without punishments, without exhausted resources, without grievances among the people. Heaven and Earth will achieve perfect harmony, and all things will flow unimpeded. This is how one attains the longevity of the Supreme Sovereigns. Those who live long do so because they avoid punishments and harm; those who inflict much harm will in turn harm themselves.

Thus, the sages of high antiquity refused to favor punishments. In middle antiquity, punishments were used sparingly, and lifespans were halved. In later antiquity, punishments were used extensively, and lifespans became short indeed. Punishments are evil—they offend Heaven, disrupt yin and yang, and accumulate as malevolent qi, which returns to harm people. The sages of high antiquity avoided their heavy use out of care for their own lives. The people of middle antiquity were half-foolish, using punishments lightly and thus harming half of themselves. The people of later antiquity were greatly foolish, treating punishments as routine, and thus most did not attain long life—the fault lies here.

Those who read this text should ponder it repeatedly, value it, and handle it with care. Life and death are weighty matters; they must not be treated lightly. A worthy and enlightened father plans deeply for his son; a worthy and enlightened minister plans deeply for his lord. An unworthy son does not plan deeply for his father; an unworthy minister does not plan for his lord. The young are like their own selves—whether they encounter fortune or misfortune will influence later generations. This is the established pattern.

Therefore, when the sage emperors and kings of high antiquity were to appoint ministers, they carefully selected those of the Dao and virtue who did not delight in killing or harming—not merely for the sake of the people, but for the sake of their own lives. Thus, they aligned with the will of Heaven and Earth, their actions moving as if in concert with the spirits. This is what is meant by ‘careful selection yielding the right person’—a ruler who gains the strength of others.

Such rulers move the gods and spirits, and the true spirits of Heaven above come to love them, granting them long life. Those who favor punishments align with yin qi, and yin is associated with killing—thus they do not attain great longevity. The Mandate of Heaven can be glimpsed and known; the aversions of Heaven, Earth, and humankind are the same.”

Right—when a state gains the favor of Heaven and Earth, the people, and the myriad things, the nation prospers, families are secure, and the world knows no disputes or litigation. *Tai Ping Jing* Combined Collated Edition, Scroll 55, Ding Section IV. *Tai Ping Jing*, Scroll 55: "The Decisive Method of Diligent Practice and Broad Learning," Chapter Eighty-Two.

“Now, can the Great Mandate be known or not?”
“Though it may be known, having met a luminous teacher and heard his words, my great confusion has dissolved—yet I cannot help but ask once more for your earnest instruction.”
“Very well. The intent of my Dao may now be glimpsed. Rise and take up this text to read it. I have long lamented that it is not mastered; only when mastered can its full meaning be grasped. If one does not deeply ponder its profound intent or study it with precision, even obtaining this text will be of no benefit. To possess it yet fail to practice it diligently—how is this different from never having obtained it? To see food yet not eat—how is this different from having no grain? To see water yet not drink—thirst cannot be quenched. This does not harm others but only oneself. Can one not reflect carefully upon this?

Thus, the sage exerts effort in contemplation, the noble person in study, ceaselessly day and night, ever delighting in emulating Heaven, which turns and moves without cease. The hundred rivers flow and gather to form the great seas. Take heed of my words and remember them well. I have admonished you repeatedly; your earnestness is plain to see.

When doing good, share it with the multitude of worthies. Take care not to monopolize the marketplace, for a marketplace with few people yields nothing sought. Thus, if one does not study broadly, what one perceives remains unclear. This is why, though one may glimpse the true Dao, its essential meaning is not grasped. Without faith in the Dao, doubt cannot be dispelled—each person’s self-imposed limitation lies here. Therefore, one must deeply ponder its intent to enable self-rescue and mutual aid.”

Here the *Indications of Lifespan*: Knowing the Method of Prosperity, Decline, and the Return of Years—Chapter Eighty-Three

Heaven’s bestowal of affairs follows its own laws. Destiny may be entrusted, and the Dao may be practiced. Though emergence comes sooner or later, its gradual signs are foreseen. For instance, the myriad things sprout in *zi*, grow in *mao*, branch in *wu*, mature in *you*, and conclude in *hai*. Though affairs are foreseen in advance, they cannot be assured.

Each matter has its practicable aspect. When the radiant sign appears first, the affair has not yet manifested—one must prepare its path in advance. Heaven’s hanging of images always precedes, never following behind. When the right person is found and the way is opened, those who receive aid and assistance are revealed. If the way is not opened nor made passable, action yields no success—such is not the right person.

This serves as clear proof. The Dao, when examined and spoken of, never errs by even one in ten thousand. For such a person, the way is opened with clarity; for one who is not, it remains closed. When the right person is truly found, illnesses may be dispelled, calamities and anomalies dissolve of themselves, and barbarians submit without need of arms—they all vanish naturally.

The arising of the myriad things each has its proper arrangement. With the right person, it unfolds of itself; without, it conceals itself. In all affairs, if the right person is not found, one must not force action. What is not one’s own must not be forcibly taken. What is not suited to the land must not be forcibly planted—if planted, it will not grow. To speak of poor seed: if it does not find its proper place within, how can it endure long? The six poles and eight directions each have their suitable things, all manifest yet differing in every affair.

Thus, metal resides in the west, wood in the east. Each in its proper place flourishes; out of place, it perishes. Therefore, the myriad things take root in the earth to live—they cannot cling to heaven. The sun, moon, stars, and celestial markers, by contrast, cling to heaven to generate light and brightness. Such is the Dao. Thus, when the right person’s star is in the sky, the time is bright; if it falls to earth, it loses its light—this is not its proper place. It disrupts the constant Dao.

There are practicable aspects that do not act recklessly. For the right person, it is clear; for one who is not, it cannot be enacted. The Dao is profound and distant, beyond measure. Those who lose it fail; those who attain it flourish.

To know one’s own prosperity and decline, observe where the Dao takes root—spiritual numen may then arise. Within, there are signs of longevity to verify it, and by this, not one in ten thousand is mistaken. This is a divine scripture, a method for returning years. Its Dao is most weighty—how can one not reflect upon it? Therefore, transmit it to the benevolent and wise, testing them to see if they may practice it and preserve their lives.

When the right person appears, worthies and sages emerge together, divine scriptures and wondrous methods arise of themselves, all bringing joy—such is the person. This is the proof. If it does not accord with these words, or if only premonitions appear without practicable results, it must be left to later generations. The Dao does not emerge recklessly.

There are indeed those for whom it is fitting. One need only question the person and let them reflect for themselves. The Dao’s return cannot be forbidden, nor can it be compelled. One must allow what is fitting, observe its success—the Dao cannot be empty.

Yet talent is not as good as effort, and effort is not as good as unceasing action. All affairs under heaven are tested through trial and failure. Heaven and earth’s spirits test people, so people also emulate the heavenly Dao in testing one another. Those who encounter goodness have good destinies; those who encounter evil have doubtful fates.

From ancient times to the present, nothing moves heaven without utmost sincerity. To demand it forcefully is called coercion—sometimes it may still be obtained. If coercion fails, it truly is not one’s own. How can one forcibly take what is not? Such affairs are inharmonious, perverse, and disordered.

Human destiny has three grades: the Dao is entrusted to the wilds, given to those who can employ it. Those who cannot employ it are entrusted to the capital, cast into the marketplace—take care not to cut it off. If later generations have no heir, transmit the scripture to sages, worthies, and Daoist masters. Without an owner or name, entrust it to those who can employ it. The Dao has its own fitting recipients—it cannot be attached to just anyone’s words.

It is like great trees returning to the mountains, water flowing to the sea—it cannot be stopped, for it is the nature of heaven. Those who follow it flourish; those who oppose it perish. When a divine scripture wishes to emerge, it cannot be concealed. With the right person, it will surely spread; without, it remains dark, deaf, and blind, the body displeased, the eyes without light.

To study this strategy with joy—within it lies the key to extending life’s span. All the signs of Great Peace are already manifest: the people’s kindness, love, caution, and goodness all arise from it. The wise and sagely are pleased; wondrous texts from distant lands are all entrusted here. With unrelenting practice, one aids oneself. Enlightened kings and sagely rulers flourish; barbarians retreat and depart. The myriad people are most fortunate, all without complaint. Heavenly longevity is enacted—no more self-resentment. The old depart by fate, the young are preserved whole.

The scripture is transmitted through ten thousand generations without end, passed down among descendants. Daily, they teach one another—this is the true text, unchanging through the ages, bringing good fortune to people. When the Dao is fully accomplished, it becomes natural. Blessings arrive of themselves, and none dare refuse.

The great person who obtains it governs the state in peace; the middling person becomes a worthy minister; the small person uses it to escape peril.

Here ends the *Strategy for Discerning the Dao’s Right and Wrong*

[Preserved] In *Ding* Section Four: To know the great efficacy of my Dao, entrust it to a wise and virtuous ruler, who will apply it. Immediately, it will resonate with heaven and earth—this is its great and luminous proof.

*Yunji Qiqian*, Scroll 64, "Auxiliary Excerpts" (Note: This excerpt resembles text from the forty-eighth scroll, *Threefold Correspondence and Mutual Communication*, seventh leaf of the original)

*Collated and Combined Text of the Taiping Jing*, Scrolls 56–64, *Ding* Sections 5–13

**Untitled Text: Responding to Heaven’s Principle, Harmonizing Above and Below, Eliminating Heavenly Disasters, and Severing the Roots of False Prognostication**

In high antiquity, people’s hearts were open, their eyes bright, and their ears penetrating. They foresaw events before they occurred, pondered deeply on what had not yet come to pass, and moved even the insentient. Standing apart from the common, none of their undertakings failed. Whatever they spoke or expounded was sincere and thorough, never straying from the imperial void of the heart. They yearned for boundless wisdom and boundless words. They knew the ebb and flow of human lifespans, each with its allotted portion, and constantly aligned with yin and yang to discern their waxing and waning. They grasped the essentials of above, below, and center, and made covenants with the myriad spirits. Yet none dared transgress the great taboos of heaven and earth. What they revered and received had to accord with Heaven’s will. Documents were exchanged, ascending to the Heavenly Lord. Upon receiving them, the Heavenly Lord saw their clear self-discipline and issued decrees to prevent self-reproach. Uprightness advanced of itself, and without report, their voices resonated clearly. The laws and norms of above and below never missed their appointed times. Fearful of falling short, they never failed to reproach themselves, ever anxious that errors might be recorded and scrutinized. Spirits reported to one another without negligence, and those found at fault were demoted or dismissed.

Thus, commands were reiterated, and documents repeated, lest their words be disobeyed. This was what Heaven rightfully upheld, what the gods and spirits looked up to—all in accordance with the law, never daring to rest. Fearful of miscommunication, they received multiple instructions, all of which they took to heart, lest they miss their appointed times. Spirits had their ranks, serving above and below. If they failed to act as decreed, they were immediately recorded as estranged. Their hearts were heavy with sorrow, ever as if starving or parched.

When the Heavenly Lord spoke, his teachings were issued, appointing overseers. Documents were numerous, but once their intent was grasped, each bore its own trust. The people of high antiquity, in matters of gain and loss, observed the inner and outer, above and below, and surveyed the four directions and beyond. They discerned the guiding principles, as months and years advanced, and spirits communicated anew—when would this ever end? The degrees of celestial bodies each had their reason, never shifting. Affairs unfolded in succession, leaving no room for doubt. They knew the origins of fortune and misfortune, and thus established calendars and records.

Three hundred and sixty days were calculated in great and small cycles, held without the slightest discrepancy—such was the short month. Spring, summer, autumn, and winter each had their allotted principles. The clepsydra’s rise and fall, the water’s swiftness or slowness, the division of old and new—all were made clear, never missing even a fraction. Each month was set, with thirty-four solar terms, and the markers for seven or eight terms before and after. There were also seven or eight long days, used for entering and exiting, sacrificing to the heavenly spirits and earthly deities, and ensuring that officials adhered to the clepsydra’s schedule. To err was to fail in duty, and the offenses were many.

Thus, day and night were divided, following the lengthening and shortening of days. A hundred *ke* marked the period, with no room for error. In a virtuous state, the days were long, the water slow. One *cun* equaled ten *fen*, conforming to the numerical pattern. Today, most states disregard this: days and months are slightly shorter, with one *ke* reduced to eight or nine *fen*. Thus, the elderly, who should weaken with age, instead grow robust, while their years diminish. How could they endure for long? If a state has many ministers, its pivotal mechanisms move sluggishly. Later generations receive blessings, barely sustaining life. Not only do they incur misfortune, but they also invite attack.

The brilliance of heaven and earth resides in the south. *Si* and *Wu* share the same domain, with *Li* as the true eye. In the affairs of the Hall of Light, the sun shines from the south toward the north. The advance and retreat of yang *qi* never stray from the norm. Yin and yang press against one another, reaching toward the *Zi* direction. Cold and warmth align, their illumination penetrating naturally—how delightful! The Way of nurturing life: lesser yang and greater yang, wood and fire flourishing together, each attaining its desire—what conflict could there be? Inner and outer support one another, never losing their names. Above, it reaches the imperial radiance; below, it extends to the soundless. In stillness and spontaneity, the myriad things bloom in splendor, all clearly discernible. Without effort, they achieve completion—this is what Heaven reveres. They receive their names, and the pivotal mechanisms point the way. Life and death have their appointed times. The Controller of Destinies holds the registers, and the records of accounts are communicated in writing, never failing to respond to summons. When seeking verification from the spirit registers, the matter ascends to the Heavenly Lord, who has overseers. The reporting spirits never leave his side, and both within and without, they are revered. They dare not act on private authority. What ascends and descends never misses its time. The officials of greater yin never dare to slacken.

The gates and chambers of the central encampment fear self-promotion. Instead, they support one another in goodness and essential ways. Their names are recorded on documents, and upon receiving instructions, they act without missing even a fraction. In high antiquity, those of wisdom and foresight saw all without obstruction, receiving the Way of the divine luminaries. Their clarity was manifest, and they had their own laws and norms, never straying from the constant. From the Great Beginning onward, calendars had their lengths and brevity, profound and essential subtleties. From ancient times to the present, the essentials of calendrical systems lie in their establishment and completion. With focused thought and calculation, all that was accomplished below was achieved, and the numbers aligned with the plumb line. Years, months, and days were tallied, with major divisions accounted for.

**Untitled**

Now, heaven and earth are in great joy, and the seasons are abundant. The emperor should sit in peace, free from worry. The people need only wander without toil or minor duties. The five grains will no longer be as before, and their value will vanish.

**[Beginning]** The world will brew fine wine to drink together, and markets will reach extremes—this is called the "Water Mandate and Fire Phase," harming the transformations of yang. When a person drinks wine to intoxication, their pulse becomes erratic. They neglect their trades, fight to the death, or injure others. Some arrive at the market early, only to return empty-handed. Some fall prey to villains, or tumble from heights, or are harmed by carts and horses. The harms of wine are myriad, beyond counting. Consider the markets within the four seas—how many are there? In a single month, they consume tens of millions of *dou* and *hu* of the five grains. People are killed or injured daily without cause. Some are left orphaned, their descendants cut off. Some incur their parents’ enmity, bringing harm upon them. Some pass calamities to their descendants.

Local officials and magistrates, unable to redress these wrongs, beat their breasts and cry to Heaven, moving the august spirits to disrupt the qi of yin-yang, the four seasons, and the five phases. This obstructs the governance of the August Sovereign of Great Peace, causing the qi of Grand Harmony to flow in reverse. All because, without cause, they mobilize the people to brew wine, wasting the five grains and bringing about such calamities.

If only a virtuous ruler were to issue clear edicts and commands, declaring to officials and commoners: "From this day forward, should any dare to purchase and drink a single *dou* of wine without cause, they shall receive thirty lashes and three days of penal labor. For two *dou*, sixty lashes and six days of penal labor. For three *dou*, ninety lashes and nine days of penal labor." The duration of penal labor shall correspond to the measure of wine consumed. Wine-sellers shall be subject to the same penalties.

All shall be made to repair city walls, roads, and government buildings—this penal labor being a great earthen work. Earth overcomes water, thereby suppressing and extinguishing its excess, preventing water from harming yang beyond measure. Water is the Greater Yin, the people; to allow it to rise and dominate is to injure the essence of yang—a grievous harm indeed.

Repairing roads fosters the flourishing of the Great Way. By correspondence in kind, this gradually establishes Great Peace.

[Appendix] *Essentials of Rituals, Precepts, and Vinaya Excerpts*, Scroll Fourteen: On the Origins of Wine-Drinking

From the *Scripture of Great Peace*, the Perfected One asked: "Throughout the world, wine is brewed for drinking, and the marketways are overrun with it. When common folk drink to intoxication, they grow wild and reckless—some brawl to the death, others maim or murder, or commit adultery under its influence, or fall from heights in their drunkenness. The harms of wine are beyond counting. Consider how many markets exist within the Four Seas: in a single day, they consume hundreds of millions of *dou* of the five grains. This not only brings ruin in its wake but also implicates the magistrates, leaving descendants to lament, disturbing the August Heaven above, and throwing the yin-yang and the qi of the four seasons and five phases into chaos. Why then craft this madness-inducing draught for people to consume? Should it not be prohibited?"

The Divine One replied: "Excellent question! Food and drink sustain human life. My words may be heeded or disregarded, but let a virtuous ruler issue this decree: from this day forward, anyone who drinks one *dou* of wine without cause shall receive twenty lashes; two *dou*, sixty strokes of the rod; three *dou*, ninety strokes; and one *hu*, three hundred strokes. Let this scale be promulgated throughout the realm, so that the wise and noble, knowing the law and fearing disgrace, will never dare transgress. The foolish who violate it shall be punished, and wine-sellers shall share the same penalties as drinkers."

The Perfected One asked: "What of travelers from a thousand *li* away, or households with the elderly and infirm, or those offering libations to the spirits?"

The Divine One replied: "If a gentleman from afar knows the kingdom’s prohibitions, he will not lightly offend, nor may he gather in groups. As for households with the elderly or sick, medicinal wine shall be permitted."

**Untitled**

To examine the interplay of Heaven and Earth, yin and yang, and the myriad things—where above and below love and govern one another—is to establish merit and renown, to unify the heart in ruling a household, and to ensure that people no longer harbor hatred or malice, ever delighting in harmony of mind and shared purpose. Thus, the qi of Great Harmony shall issue forth daily, and grand peace shall flourish. The Six Directions shall unite in heart, the Eight Quarters in counsel. Where governance aligns with human intent, none shall fail to respond with joy.

This originates from the primordial qi of Heaven and Earth, uniting the positions of yin and yang. Wickedness and evil shall silently vanish; the rebellious shall all submit. The luminous and numinous Supreme Dao is cherished by gods and spirits.

I, therefore, above expound the Dao and virtue to August Heaven, below distinguish the measures for mountains and rivers, and in the midst establish laws and regulations for emperors and kings, that the worthy may cultivate good intentions. Thereby, the great grievances and resentments of Heaven and Earth shall be resolved, sparing emperors and kings from sorrow and suffering. The people shall love one another, the myriad things shall each attain their proper place, and the constant standards of Heaven’s law shall remain unhidden.

In ancient times, sagely emperors and enlightened kings revered great ministers, cherished recluses, and benefited the people without harm or injury. Ministers, in turn, were loyal and trustworthy, never deceiving their rulers, so that governance was as if divine. Thus, a wise father constantly sought to bring peace to his son, and the son constantly sought to bring joy to his father. When the two joined forces with a single heart, no household affair went unaccomplished. But if they failed to unite in heart and strength, the household’s way fell into disorder. Neglecting their duties, they became impoverished and destitute, leading to strife, division, and separation—turning to mutual harm and injury. Even parents and children, born of the same flesh and blood, bound as limbs of one body, may thus part. How much more so when gathering men of disparate surnames to serve as rulers, teachers, and fathers?

Thus, the sage, perceiving the subtle and knowing the manifest, takes heed and exercises caution. The teacher, yang in nature, loves his disciples and guides them in the good Dao, teaching them to revere Heaven and cherish Earth, honor superiors and benefit inferiors. The disciples, in turn, respect and serve their teacher with diligence, loyalty, and trustworthiness, never deceiving. When the two join forces with a single heart, they study the ancient laws and institutions, practice the words of the sages, and clarify the divisions and principles of Heaven and Earth, ensuring the myriad things each attain their proper place. Accumulating worthiness without cease, they become the emperor’s worthy aides, joining in counsel to govern and bring about Great Peace.

But if they fail to unite in heart and counsel, refusing to transmit the essential Dao, instead pursuing vain and superficial words, deceiving and endangering one another, defying Heaven’s divisions and disrupting the sages’ teachings, the Six Directions shall grow indistinct, and great calamity shall befall the realm. If the emperor and his teacher lose the principles of governance, they shall become the great enemies of Heaven and Earth, failing to align with the will of the divine spirits—a grievous harm to the world.

**Untitled**

Human life is endowed with both yin and yang; movement and stillness, anger and joy all have their proper times. Before the union of male and female, yin and yang must take charge to effect the work of generation. The Dao of Heaven is completed through threefold union, and so a child walks at three years of age. Three times three makes nine, and therein the harmonious Dao reaches its culmination. Before the union of male and female, the timely impulse within cannot be expressed.

The number of Heaven is five, the number of Earth is five, and the number of humanity is five. Three fives make fifteen, and the internal qi stirs. Four fives make twenty, aligning with the qi of the four seasons and giving rise to the impulse to procreate. The four seasons govern generation, and thus the impulse to generate arises. Five fives make twenty-five, and the qi of the Five Phases is fulfilled, enabling procreation. Five sixes make thirty, and strength is attained. Thus, Heaven causes the constant impulse to procreate, to connect with the lineage of Heaven and Earth, to propagate kindred beings. After thirty years, one is exempted. In old age, one declines; the young must cease seclusion within the chamber. Among the crawling creatures of the world, humans alone mirror Heaven and Earth in their completeness; the rest cannot.

Thus, in a single day and night, Heaven and Earth together generate twelve thousand things. Night is deep, day is dry. Depth pertains to yin; dryness pertains to yang. Heaven and Earth daily nourish these twelve thousand things to fullness. By Heaven’s law, yang unites its essence to form a dual-yang effusion, which descends into the Earth to join with it, together generating the twelve thousand things. Of these, two thousand are auspicious and virtuous beings.

The twelve thousand things each possess their own spirit and have their own rulers. Only when they follow a single great Dao can they circulate freely. The Dao of Heaven moves above and below, all coming to pay homage to their ruler—just as people following a single great Dao come to pay homage to their king. The spirits of the twelve thousand things, born together with Heaven and Earth, emerge along a single great Dao, some great, some middling, some small.

What does this mean? It means that among the twelve thousand things, some are great and some are small, and their Dao likewise varies in scale. Each generates, contains, and moves in its own way. Thus, the supreme Dao spans ten thousand paces as its standard; the next spans a thousand paces; the next, a hundred paces; the next, ten paces; and the last, one pace. These five Dao correspond to the Five Directions. Together, they descend to generate upon the Earth, together they ascend to pay homage to Heaven, and together they proceed along a single Dao.

Therefore, the great Dao spans ten thousand paces, accommodating the middling Dao of a thousand paces, the lesser Dao of a hundred paces, the fine Dao of ten paces, and the minute Dao of one pace. Things vary in size, each containing its own coming and going. All receive Heaven’s effusion above and, in turn, generate and effuse below upon the Earth, then together ascend to pay homage to Heaven.

Thus, the great Dao may be extended but must not be arbitrarily constricted; constriction prevents mutual accommodation. Some may fail to be born, others may be injured or die, unable to emerge—causing people to be cut off without descendants. The injured harm others; the dead kill others. The sages of antiquity dared not abolish or sever the great Dao, for they clearly beheld Heaven’s prohibitions.

How could one injure Heaven’s Dao? The Dao is Heaven, yang, and governs generation. Virtue is Earth, yin, and governs nourishment. If the myriad things largely fail to be born, it is known that Heaven’s Dao is injured. Where some fail to be born, it is known that Heaven’s lineage has been severed. If one thing fails to be born, one lineage is severed; if many fail, many lineages are severed. The extent of severance follows the number of things, revealing the injury to Heaven’s lineage.

When the Dao flourishes, it governs generation, and the myriad things all come to life. When virtue flourishes, it governs nourishment, and the myriad things and people are all nurtured, free from grievances and entanglements.

**Untitled Passage (Beginning):**
Why in my writings do I have the black ink serve as the base and the vermilion characters inscribed upon it? My Dao is the truth of vermilion and black: black embodies life and benevolence, possessing a heart; red is the great yang, the true color of Heaven.

**Untitled Passage (End):**
My Dao is the Dao of the great yang, the Dao of benevolent governance, which does not wish to harm.

The Son of Heaven is the heart of Heaven; the Empress is the heart of Earth. The heart governs the upholding of rectitude. Heaven covers all without exception, generates all without distinction, whether great or small, all receive the mandate to be born—thus it is called Heaven. Heaven is the true essence of the supreme Dao, never deceiving others. All things should cherish and love it. In its intentions and mind, one ought to accumulate sincerity and trust, ever desiring to benefit and not harm, never failing any being—thus it is called Heaven. The emperor and king are the children of Heaven, the leaders of humanity; their conduct should emulate this. The son ought to inherit his father’s teachings, strictly adhering to and enacting them, so that his affairs align with his father’s will and intentions—thus he may become the head of a good family. If he does not inherit his father’s teachings, his household, great and small, will fall into disorder, becoming a poor family. Wealth scatters in all four directions, never gathering, affairs become chaotic, disasters and calamities arise in succession, and profound suffering ensues—all faults lie here. In ancient times, when emperors and kings were about to act, they first looked up to the heart of Heaven, received its teachings, and only then proceeded.

The conduct of the Empress should rightly accord with the Earth. Earth bears all without exception, great and small alike return to it, neither good nor evil, all are embraced and nourished. The Empress is the child of Earth, the heart of Earth. The heart concerns itself with all matters; the child should emulate the mother’s conduct as the mother does—thus becoming a filial child. The correspondence between Heaven and Earth and the Empress is like the echo to the sound: if the error is small, the consequence is small; if great, the consequence is great. Even a deviation as slight as a hair’s breadth, if the mother’s will and intentions are not met, will result. In ancient times, when the Empress was about to act, she first contemplated the Earth, which embraces and nourishes all without exception. Nothing is unbearable, all has constancy; thus she finds peace and aligns with the heart of Earth. If she errs, disasters and calamities arise in succession, punishments cannot be restrained, yin overwhelms yang, the myriad things do not flourish—all faults lie here.

When these two act with rectitude, the divine and true appear, the true Dao emerges, the worthy and enlightened all hold office, and good things gather in the state.

**Primordial qi** is yang and governs generation; spontaneity and transformation are yin and govern the nourishment of all things. Heaven, yang, governs generation; Earth, yin, governs nourishment. The sun and day are yang, governing generation; the moon, stars, and night are yin, governing nourishment. Spring and summer are yang, governing generation; autumn and winter are yin, governing nourishment. *Jia*, *bing*, *wu*, *geng*, and *ren* are yang, governing generation; *yi*, *ding*, *ji*, *xin*, and *gui* are yin, governing nourishment. *Zi*, *yin*, *chen*, *wu*, *shen*, and *xu* are yang, governing generation; *chou*, *mao*, *si*, *wei*, *you*, and *hai* are yin, governing nourishment. All nines are yang, governing generation; all sixes are yin, governing nourishment. Men are yang, governing generation; women are yin, governing the nourishment of the myriad things. The male is yang, governing generation; the female is yin, governing nourishment. The ruler is yang, governing generation; the minister is yin, governing nourishment. In all matters under Heaven, there is one yin and one yang; only then can they generate and nourish one another. If yang does not bestow generation, yin is left empty and void, with nothing to nourish. If yin does not receive transformation, yang has no lineage of generation to bestow. If the yang qi’s lineage is severed and cut off, it is a great grievance to Heaven. If yin does not receive transformation and cannot generate, it is a great fault.
