Yet even the Perfected One upholds rectitude thus—how much harder for the common people to awaken, long lost in delusion as they are."

I have erred, only the Heavenly Master can enlighten me.

"Indeed. In assisting the Emperor and kings in governance, there are in essence ten methods:
First, governance by primordial *qi*;
second, governance by spontaneity;
third, governance by the Dao;
fourth, governance by virtue;
fifth, governance by benevolence;
sixth, governance by righteousness;
seventh, governance by ritual;
eighth, governance by culture;
ninth, governance by law;
tenth, governance by military force.
These ten mark the end—why is this?
All things begin with primordial *qi* and conclude with the military, for the military severs and strikes, thus it is the lowest.
Therefore, things arise from the Great Mystery, flourish in the Great Yang, and perish in the White Tiger.
Thus, primordial *qi* resides in the North, while the White Tiger dwells in the West—this is what is meant.
Heaven employs governance by primordial *qi*, sending forth the winds to nurture all things.
Earth employs governance by spontaneity, so that following goodness yields goodness, and following evil yields evil.
Humans, in turn, follow the harmony of Heaven and Earth, governing by the Dao, and thus preside over the active Dao.
All affairs flow and circulate—these three methods correspond to the omens of Heaven, Earth, and humanity.
Beyond these three, virtue and benevolence serve as mere ornamentation; below benevolence, much harm arises, making governance difficult.
Thus, my Dao is ever joyous, fundamentally aligning with Heaven’s nature of restraint, and discarding the nature of premature decay.
The fundamental principle of all living things is constant order: they take form in the middle and descend into chaos at the end. Once lost to chaos, order cannot be restored—thus one must begin with the highest.
Therefore, Heaven eternally guards its root, Earth guards its center, and with one revolution, humanity guards its lower nature. With three revolutions, the Dao is thus disordered.
Perfected One, have you now understood this?"

"Yes, yes."

"Master, I now have doubts."
"When following a teacher, one may speak freely—do not hesitate to voice your doubts."
"Perfected One, when Heaven aids the emperor and kings, by what is this made manifest? When it benefits ministers and the people, what is the proof?"
"Only the Celestial Master—now I fall short in understanding. My words often miss the mark, and I incur many faults, so I dare not speak further."
"Ah, proceed."
"Yes, yes.
When Heaven aids the emperor and kings, it bestows upon them wondrous scriptures, which can be used to govern, their efficacy surpassing all bounds, aligning with yin and yang. This benefits lesser ministers.
It grants them worthy officials to benefit the people, enabling them to bear virtuous children."
"Perfected One, your words are sound—could there be further marvels?
This is the utmost.
When Heaven desires to elevate a virtuous ruler, it causes the birth of divine sages, who transmit the discourse of Heaven and Earth and comprehend their intent.
Thus, Perfected One, you have come to study this—it should be entrusted to the most prudent and virtuous of the people, awakening their hearts and guiding their thoughts.
It should be presented to rulers of great virtue, to be shown to all worthies, so that together they may grasp its meaning and convey it to the common folk.
When the people receive it, fifteen will follow one another, discussing and governing, rectifying all that is unjust—not for the sake of Heaven, Earth, or the ruler alone.
Yet the root of all faults lies in humanity’s leaders. If leaders themselves bear grave transgressions, they invoke the wrath of the August Heaven and Earth, and all stems from a single person.
There are those who first learn the true Dao but do not strive to transform and teach others.
Great fortune befalls those who first know virtue, yet they do not exert themselves to transform others.
Households with accumulated wealth refuse to practice benevolence through generous giving.
People born with the capacity to learn do not strive to study, nor seek the true Dao to attain longevity.
Those capable of learning virtue to transform themselves do not exert themselves to study virtue and refine their nature.
Those with strength do not labor diligently to improve their lot, instead inviting hardship and poverty.
These are the six great transgressions, long accumulated by Heaven and humanity.
Since the opening of Heaven and Earth, each generation has borne the burdens of the last, and later generations grow ever more grievous. When many gather, great harm arises.
This causes Heaven and Earth to lose their proper order, and emperors to endure prolonged sorrow in their governance, leaving past and present in disorder. Heaven deeply abhors this.
Thus, I hasten to transmit the words of Heaven. From the most ancient times to the present, Heaven and Earth have suffered afflictions, stifled and obstructed. Ordinary people cannot know this—only divine sages transmit these teachings. It is not I alone; Perfected One, do not find this strange.
Now that I am about to depart this world, I may no longer appear freely among the people. Thus, I transmit this text to you, Perfected One. Once you receive it, you too will depart the mundane world and may no longer serve as a teacher among the people.
Therefore, I charge you to seek out the most virtuous and discerning of the people and entrust it to them. Now, hasten to deliver it to a ruler of virtue. Dare not delay or obstruct its passage—how weighty is this task!
Today, Heaven seeks to alleviate suffering and bring peace to the emperor and kings. Let the enlightened ruler display this to all worthies, to transform the people. Let each reflect on their faults, to dissolve the inherited burdens of their ancestors, so that all may act for their own sake and not grow negligent. Then Heaven will rejoice greatly, and governance will achieve peace.
If you harbor doubts, suspecting my words lack utmost sincerity, know that this text is but a trial of truth.
Why is this so? Ancient texts number in the millions, yet governance has never attained great peace.
If the wise and enlightened remain skeptical, dismissing these writings as false, how can one know their power?
A warrior untested—how can his strength be known? A text unseen in practice—how can its divinity be discerned?
I have received the words of Heaven to test you, Perfected One. From now on, when you receive any text, put it to the test at once. Do not idly fabricate falsehoods.
Heaven deeply abhors this; Earth suffers greatly, deeming it a grave affliction, a true grievance of resentment.
This causes the flourishing of all things to falter, bringing many disasters and premature deaths, preventing them from fulfilling their natural lifespans.
Emperors grow despondent, officials and people descend into chaos, no longer governing one another. The great calamity lies here—these are the six transgressions.
Those who possess the Dao envy it and do not strive to teach the foolish.
Those who possess virtue envy it and do not strive to transform the foolish.
Those who hoard wealth envy it and do not practice generosity, though Heaven births all people to give.
Those with knowledge do not strive to study the true Dao to enlighten themselves, instead mocking those who teach.
Those with ability do not strive to study and teach, instead reviling them.
Those with strength do not labor diligently to cultivate wealth and benevolence, instead growing idle and lazy.
When parents teach them, they reject their instruction.
Thus, I command you, Perfected One, to swiftly present this text, so that all worthies may deeply reflect on the people and contemplate their great faults. Perfected One, do you now understand this instruction?"
"Yes, yes.
Since the divine person has expounded the laws of Heaven, why merely entrust it to individuals? Should it not be disseminated among the people, beginning with those above and below?"
"Excellent! Excellent!
Today, the qi of great peace from the highest reaches of Heaven is about to arrive. All matters must follow its order—thus, it begins with those above and below.
Without this order, it becomes rebellious qi, causing governance to falter. Most failures stem from rebellious qi, from disobedience.
Perfected One, do you wish to add to this?"
"I dare not.
Thus, it must begin with those above and below. Do not ask further."
"Yes, yes.
Go forth and act with care, each considering your own conduct.
These six great transgressions are sternly judged by the Dao of Heaven. Do not act recklessly—Heaven, dwelling above, watches over humanity."
"Yes, yes.
I humbly ask one more question: when a person has obtained the essential Dao and essential virtue, where should they place them?"
"They should present them to their ruler."
"Why must they be presented to the ruler?"
"The essential Dao is that by which the ruler is pacified. When applied in governance, it wins the favor of Heaven."

"The essential virtue is that by which the ruler is nourished. When applied in governance, it wins the favor of Earth.

Truly knowing this yet refusing to present it to those above is disrespectful—such transgressions cannot be absolved."

"Why is this so severe?"

"Observing your manner of speech, one would think you know nothing at all. As a son, this is disobedience; as a subject, this is disloyalty and faithlessness—such offenses defy description.

Perfected One, why do you ask which is the graver? Why has your learning not deepened with each passing day, but instead grown more shallow?"

"Your foolish disciple truly does not see it."

"You claim not to see, yet even the common people conceal and hoard their essential Dao and virtue, causing their ruler distress and suffering in ignorance. The fault lies in the obstruction of true Dao and virtue, leaving them uncommunicated.

Moreover, the essential Dao is that by which Heaven is honored; the essential virtue is that by which Earth is honored. Fools sever these connections—Heaven abhors them, Earth detests them, and their transgressions cannot be absolved.

Perfected One, you alone have been favored by Heaven with longevity, yet your learning remains incomplete, even transgressing Heaven’s prohibitions. Those who serve must take heed."

"Yes, yes."

Here follows the translation:

---

**"The Scripture of Heaven’s Teachings on Harmony for Humanity’s Perpetual Auspiciousness and Distant Misfortune"**
*Collated and Harmonized Great Peace Scripture, Scroll Sixty-Eight, Ding Section Seventeen*
*Great Peace Scripture, Scroll Sixty-Eight*
*"Admonition to the Six Disciples" (One Hundred and Fourth Discourse)*

**〈Opening〉**
As my departure draws near, I leave you, the Six Disciples, with a single admonition.

The Dao is all-pervading—without above or below, without exterior or interior. Guard its harmonious qi, and it is called the numinous.
Seek it near, and you shall greatly attain; seek it afar, and you shall lose it.
Thus, the ancient sagely kings who governed well began within the belly, truly employing the Dao, and governance came of itself.
Move without transgressing its measures and standards, and the myriad things order themselves. It lies near in the heart-mind, yet scatters to fill the Four Seas.
The ancients called this the Essential Dao.

**〈Closing〉**
Govern with joy and desire for non-action; take heed not to lose this, for it is the plumb line that corrects the worthy.
Now I exhort you again to make this clear.
You six have questioned me about my writings day after day. Though the Dao branches into different tendencies, it shares a single matter.
Yet the tongue, able to traverse the Six Directions, completes the kingly Dao, explaining the myriad things, each with its distinct meaning.
Heaven and Earth attain great peace; the lord-king attains non-action.
My writings know the numinous heart, penetrating the Six Directions and Eight Corners. From on high they descend and submit, all harboring good hearts, without evil intent.
Their essential knot resides near, dwelling within—like the myriad things, the heart lies within, while branches dwell without.
When the inner flourishes, the outer flourishes; when the inner declines, the outer declines.
Thus, the ancient August Dao Emperors and sagely kings, desiring to rectify the all-penetrating Six Distant Directions and Eight Corners, first rectified the inner.
By rectifying the inner to order the outer, ten thousand upon ten thousand respond, a hundred million upon a hundred million do not fail.
But by ordering the outer to rectify the inner, ten thousand are lost.

**〈Opening〉**
Therefore, the great sages of old taught people to ponder deeply and contemplate afar, closing their nine apertures, resting their four limbs, rendering themselves undifferentiated—like a ring without end, or an embryo in the womb without duties—only then could they attain its principle.
My Dao takes this as its great essential.

**〈Closing〉**
Thus, it returns to making each guard its root.
When Heaven generates humanity, it endows each with the true Dao, complete in all things.
If a teacher opens, guides, and instructs them, they may be made to know all; but if the gates and doors remain unopened, though they receive Heaven’s true Dao, they shall know nothing.
It is like a newborn infant placed in a chamber—without guidance or instruction in affairs, nothing can be known.
The difference among people lies only in the varying customs of the Eight Directions, hence their knowledge and learning differ.
If one person studies, circulating within and without, all can be known.
As I shall soon depart for distant parts, there may yet be those to whom I can transmit, and I cannot always remain seated, guarding all my disciples.
You six must carefully read my writings. From beginning to end, they form a knot. If you do not understand my intent, examine the ancient texts to clarify it.
Those who practice the Upper Dao are known by the Mysterious Perfected; those who practice the Lower Dao, by the Compliant Perfected; those of the East, by the Initial Perfected; those of the South, by the Grand Perfected; those of the West, by the Lesser Perfected; those of the North, by the Obscure Perfected.
The Dao is largely the same with minor differences, thus it can distinguish yin and yang without limit, transforming into one myriad, one thousand, five hundred, and twenty characters.
Though the harmony of the myriad things is slightly complete, it has yet to exhaust the yin and yang of Heaven and Earth, utterly penetrating without exterior or interior.
Therefore, examine its absence, grasp its warp, perceive its beginning, and it may be modeled and recorded.
Record the ancient and the present—its essentials, though disordered, align with what the divine and sagely have recorded, like overlapping compasses and matching squares. Though separated by a hundred million myriad years, it is as if speaking face to face.
Thus, it may serve as the constant scripture of Heaven and Earth, as the numinous Dao of yin and yang. Do not wonder at the repetition in my writings before and after.
The reason for repetition is fear of loss.
Moreover, the Dao of Heaven is most stern. Having spoken, one dare not omit anything. To communicate incompletely is called a "trifling Dao," a grave transgression.
I truly pity this, hence the repetition.
It is like the sages of the high, middle, and low antiquity, born in different ages, whose words follow one another, repeating and expounding, further examining and clarifying—only then can the Dao of Heaven be fully known. This is the meaning.
Go forth! I have urgent matters. Take great care to hold Heaven’s treasure and transmit it to the proper person.

---

Here the Master admonishes his six disciples.
*Tai Ping Jing* Collated and Combined, Scroll Sixty-Nine, Wu Section, Part One.
*Tai Ping Jing*, Scroll Sixty-Nine.
"Celestial Prognostications: The Method of Stem-Branch Correspondences," One Hundred and Fifth.

The Perfected One bowed twice and said:
"Though born lowly, I have been treated by the Heavenly Master as a newborn child, with kindness and affection so profound that I am granted audience even in haste, morning and evening. The works of Heaven are vast beyond gratitude. Now I venture once more to inquire about its most recondite mysteries—the arcana of Heaven—yet dare not speak abruptly."

"Speak plainly. Since you are charged with questioning Heaven’s affairs, you must pursue them to the end. You may not abandon them halfway."

"As you say. This humble one has observed that the Heavenly Master’s teachings are boundless. Thus, we disciples, awakened by Heaven, fear that should we one day part from our Master, there would be none to whom we might address our doubts. Therefore, we venture—bold and unrelenting—to ask about the prognostications that can perpetually secure the state and bring peace to the realm, so that the lord of men may govern with folded arms, free from care. He would then ever play the zither and lute, delighting in music and leisure, as stable as Heaven and Earth, never again facing peril. Might we hear of this?"

"Indeed. Do you Perfected Ones seek true progress? Profound and subtle is your question—you seek the esoteric charts and prognostic texts that penetrate Heaven and Earth, a single word of which cannot be altered for ten thousand generations. Does the Lord of Heaven, grieved by manifold disasters and sorrows, now send you Perfected Ones to resolve these doubts?"

"Just so."

"Then I shall fully expound for you the great essentials of Heaven’s compass and square, its secret texts and decisive instructions, that they may be... [lacuna] The Perfected Ones shall follow and record them themselves."

"As you say."

"Now, the August Heaven takes the four seasons as its branches, while the fertile Earth takes the Five Phases as its body. The branches govern decline and flourishing; the body governs the compass and square. These nine spirits pervade the world, penetrating above and below to their utmost limits, their transformations difficult to perceive. They are the double treasure of Heaven and Earth, the gateway of all spirits. They possess an inherent constancy; one may not recklessly transgress them. Those who follow them enjoy enduring fortune; those who disrupt them remain forever at odds with Heaven and Earth."

"Would that I might hear its meaning—can it truly be perceived?"
"Excellent, words of the Perfected Ones! Now I shall expound it fully for you. Only compose yourselves, sit in stillness, and ponder my words."
"Yes, yes."

"Now, the celestial prognostication models take the south as the ruler’s domain. Thus the sun in the south is the ruler; fire in the south is the ruler; the Great Yang in the south is the ruler; the four seasons and the height of summer in the south are the ruler; the Five Domestic Sacrifices and the stove in the south are the ruler; the Five Viscera and the heart in the south are the ruler. The ruler, by model, should wear red, for this is the phase of fire. Therefore, when the ruler encounters anomalies, they invariably correspond to the Yang—never to the phases of others. The Yang is the sun at its brightest, chief among all lights, so celestial prognostication always uses the sun to divine the ruler’s flourishing or decline. Do you Perfected Ones understand?"
"Yes, yes, we now understand."

"The model for the ruler of men is ever to seek kinship with the benevolent and to govern with those who possess a heart. Those with whom one may share governance must ever practice the Dao and cherish life. Even the young and weak, or those ministers and worthy men who are still maturing, the ruler should nurture, not harm. Thus the east cherishes life, while the south cherishes nurturance. Those who are unbenevolent in their intentions cannot long share affairs, and those who are unenlightened cannot serve as rulers. Thus the east is wood, benevolent and possessed of a heart, while the south is fire, luminous.

The celestial model holds that those who govern as emperors and kings must ever act through the Dao and virtue. Thus the east is the Dao, and the Dao governs life; the south is virtue, and virtue governs nurturance—hence the south governs nurturance. Those who govern must emulate Heaven by civilizing through culture. Thus the east is culture, borne by the dragon’s appearance. The south is refinement, and thus rectitude becomes the pattern of culture.

Refinement is great luminosity, so culture arises in the east and is illuminated in the south. Thus celestial culture is red, and red is fire. Benevolence and rulership move upward, and the sun should stand high and bright, serving as a model for people. Thus when wood and fire move, they invariably ascend—this is the image of the ruler. Therefore, dwelling in the east, one relies on benevolence to ascend, and those who govern must thus reside in the south.

Thus the east is Lesser Yang, the ruler’s beginning of life, and so the sun rises in the east. The south is Greater Yang, the ruler’s height of brilliance. Lesser Yang is the ruler’s family and parents, while Greater Yang is the ruler’s person and position. Lesser Yang is the ruler’s family, wood is fire’s parents, and the ruler takes Lesser Yang as family, so fire is called wood’s child. Do you Perfected Ones understand?"

"Yes, yes."
"You have understood it well.

Lesser Yin is the minister, and ministers bend and submit in righteousness, yielding to Greater Yang. Thus metal follows fire in bending and submission. Among people, what is desirable is that ministers always submit in righteousness to assist their ruler—this is what is desirable. Therefore, Lesser Yin is called the minister.

Do you Perfected Ones understand?"
"Yes, yes."

"Greater Yin is the people, and the people move without ceasing. Thus water flows without knowing rest. The people are charged with managing livelihoods for the state, kings, and lords. Therefore, water should follow in nurturing and sustaining wood. The east is the ruler’s family.

Do you Perfected Ones understand?"
"Yes, yes."
"You have understood it well.

Now, the celestial portents: Lesser Yang fears Lesser Yin. Thus ministers may seize control of the state, kings, lords, and officials. Greater Yang fears Greater Yin; therefore, when a state possesses the Dao and virtue, and its ruler and ministers are worthy and enlightened, the people follow. When a state lacks the Dao and virtue, the people rebel. Thus the great essentials of governing a state lie in abundance of people as wealth, and scarcity of people as great poverty.

Do all you Perfected Ones comprehend this?"
"Yes, yes."

"Well then, you have awakened to this."

"The celestial patterns and laws divide into six parts. The southeast and above belong to Heaven, thus all things in generation ascend, and the crawling people all emerge and dwell without, belonging to Heaven. Therefore, Heaven’s color is outwardly azure, resembling wood, and inwardly red, resembling fire. Do you Perfected Ones understand this?"
"Yes, yes."
"Well then, you have comprehended it."

"The celestial and terrestrial portents: the west and the north belong below to Earth. Thus, when all things reach autumn and winter, they all fall and return to the soil. When the crawling people reach autumn and winter, they all enter caves to dwell. Therefore, Earth’s color is outwardly yellow and white, resembling soil and metal, and inwardly contains water and is black, resembling the northward movement. Do you Perfected Ones understand this?"
"Yes, yes."

"The celestial portents: the east and the south are noble in position, belonging above to Heaven, governing as rulers, sovereigns, teachers, and fathers. The west and the north are base in position, belonging to Earth, serving as ministers, the inner palace, and the people. Thus, *ji* (己) is the inner palace of *jia* (甲). *Jia* is Heaven, the fundamental position of the king, thus *jia* is the Heart Star. The Heart Star is fire, representing the king. Therefore, the east is also the precursor of the king. The Heart Star is fire, and its movement belongs to the south. Do you Perfected Ones understand this, as the sun rises in the east yet its position is in the south?"
"Yes, yes."

"Excellent, you have understood this."

"The celestial portents: *bing* (丙) is the chief of fire, the most radiant of all, the position of the ruler. *Xin* (辛) belongs to *bing*, for *xin* is the inner palace of *bing*. Do you Perfected Ones understand this?"
"Yes, yes."
"Excellent, you have understood this."

"Now, *ji* (己) is also the empress, and *xin* (辛) is also the empress—what does this mean?"
"Excellent is your inquiry, for you have grasped the meaning of the celestial portents. Now, *ji* is paired with *jia* (甲), and *jia* is the father of *bing* (丙). Thus, *ji* is the palace of the Grand Empress. *Xin* is paired with *bing*, and *bing* is the son of *jia*. Thus, *xin* is the palace of the Lesser Empress. *Bing* is the rightful son of *jia*, the ruler who receives the mandate. Do you Perfected Ones understand this?"
"Yes, yes."
"Excellent, you Perfected Ones have understood this."

"*Geng* (庚) belongs to *yi* (乙), representing the feudal lords and kings of the state. *Ren* (壬) belongs to *ding* (丁), representing the sisters of the emperor. *Gui* (癸) belongs to *wu* (戊), representing the family of the state’s Grand Empress."

"Now that the ten Celestial Stems have been explained, each with its proper affiliation, we wish to hear how the twelve Earthly Branches correspond to them."
"Excellent question! The Dao of Heaven operates thus: though yin and yang move in their courses, the affairs they govern each have their own fixed domains. The Dao of Heaven is uniform, yet it does not compel all domains to follow in unison.

*Jia* (甲) takes *yin* (寅) as its domain; *yi* (乙) takes *mao* (卯) as its domain; *bing* (丙) takes *wu* (午) as its domain; *ding* (丁) takes *si* (巳) as its domain; *wu* (戊) takes *chen* (辰) and *xu* (戌) as its domain; *ji* (己) takes *chou* (丑) and *wei* (未) as its domain; *geng* (庚) takes *shen* (申) as its domain; *xin* (辛) takes *you* (酉) as its domain; *ren* (壬) takes *zi* (子) as its domain; *gui* (癸) takes *hai* (亥) as its domain.

Thus, the Way of Heaven moves in reversal to govern; the Way of Earth is stillness. Therefore, there is division of land but no division of people—there are states with territory but no states as such. Thus, Heaven and Earth do not shift: Heaven completes one revolution in a day and night, moving in this as its constant. Therefore, the twelve Earthly Branches each reside in their place and do not follow the ten Celestial Stems in their movement. Do you Perfected Ones understand this?"
"Yes, yes."

The Dao of Heaven and Earth, the four seasons and five phases, operate through mutual fulfillment, revolving yet differing in their manifestations. They cycle through darkness and obscurity without end, known only to the great divine sages of antiquity. To exhaustively explain this to you would strain resources and prove overly elaborate, only deepening confusion—leaving rulers of the earthly virtue bewildered and uncertain of the path to follow. Thus, I have refrained.

Yet it is not that I惜 to expound for you, but rather that the explanation knows no bounds. Do you, Perfected Ones, understand this?"
"Yes, yes."

"Go forth, for you have gained some insight. The Virtuous Lord governs by my celestial omens, and in ten thousand matters, not one shall err. Thus, the Dao of Heaven indeed has its fixed boundaries: the east and south serve as emblems of the sovereign, belonging to Heaven—hence the title 'Son of Heaven.' The west and north represent the rear palace and the people and ministers, belonging to Earth—hence Earth is called the rear palace. Do you, Perfected Ones, understand this?"
"Yes, yes."

"The celestial omens decree that the east fears the west. Since the opening of Heaven and Earth, when rulers have followed military strategy, fostering the qi of metal, the martial aspect leaves the sovereign’s emblem devoid of vitality. Fire then greatly declines, and governance becomes inauspicious and chaotic. If you, Perfected Ones, wish to truly know the certainty of celestial omens, observe from high antiquity through middle antiquity to recent times: when rulers abandoned the Dao and virtue, favoring the qi of metal and military strategy, their governance was entirely inauspicious, plagued by bandits and misfortune.

Thus, the sages of high antiquity deeply understood Heaven’s fixed patterns and symbols, and dared not govern by arms or martial force. If emperors and kings desire lasting peace and good fortune, they should heed these celestial omens: swiftly restrain and abolish metal, weapons, and military preparations, and urgently promote the Dao and supreme virtue, aligning with Heaven’s law to accord with the will of August Heaven. Thereby, they will suppress and eradicate all treacherous and inauspicious elements, and the response shall be immediate and unmistakable. Do you, Perfected Ones, understand this?"
"Yes, yes."

The celestial omen-patterns and models decree: though the Great Yang is the ruler, it deeply fears the Great Yin—the movement of water. The sweetest and finest of waters is wine. Wine arises as the king of waters, its elder, the finest of all beverages, its qi belonging to the Kan position, presiding over theft and bandits by night. Thus, from its name, wine is called "indulgence," for it is the king and elder of waters, and when water reigns, the Great Yang wanes.

Do you, Perfected Ones, desire to know the truth of these celestial omens? From the highest antiquity down to the middle ages, rulers who indulged in wine could not achieve great peace; their governance instead fell into chaos, their offices rife with strife, and bandits arose—this is clear proof. Therefore, when a virtuous ruler of great peace governs, the essence of fire should shine brightly; one must not follow the Great Yin, allowing the power of water to reign and thereby suppress and harm the governance. Thus, wine must be prohibited.

[Appendix] Wine is the king of waters. When water reigns, it ought to overcome fire. Fire is the ruler’s virtue; one must urgently prohibit wine to preserve the power of fire.

"I wish to hear: what is to be prohibited, and which wines are to be cut off?"
"Only market wine is to be prohibited."
"Now, Heavenly Master, what have you observed to uniquely prohibit market wine?"
"Indeed, the market corresponds to the movement of water. Thus, the people and goods of the four directions all gather there. The rivers and seas, too, are the kings and elders of waters, and so all streams and wealth likewise flow and gather there. Water is the movement of the Dark Warrior of the north, and thus it is greedy, frequently seizing others’ wealth. The market, too, is where the five directions converge to trade and profit, giving rise to bandits, rogues, and deceitful elements—all under the dominion of Kan, ruled by water.

Heaven’s law operates by resonance through kindred categories, and so the market is the movement of water. If wine is indulged and distributed in great measure, it is again called the reign of water. Market-dwellers, too, rejoice in wine and call it king, creating a double reign of water. The fault is sixfold: it suppresses the fire-qi of the Great Yang, causing the ruler’s governance to weaken and treacherous ministers to arise. Do you, Perfected Ones, understand this?"
"Having heard the Heavenly Master’s explanation, we are dazzled and confused. We wish to hear the great essentials."
"Excellent is your question. Now, all you Perfected Ones have come from afar to inquire of Heaven’s affairs, seeking to resolve the harms of karmic inheritance for virtuous rulers and emperors. I shall not withhold anything. Be seated in peace, and I shall distinguish and explain everything for you, clarifying the essential meaning."
"Yes, yes."

"The celestial prognostication’s decree: when metal and jade prevail in governance, if the military departments flourish excessively, the wood-qi’s primordial vitality is severed, and earth gains sovereignty. When earth is greatly exalted, it becomes the palace of the Grand Empress. Its qi belongs to the northwest, and when the Great Yin attains great sovereignty, treacherous ministers arise, the rear palace intrigues, and the path is lost in tumultuous ascent. When earth rules, metal serves as its minister, and together they rise in tumult. The qi of *si* and *xin* both gain sovereignty, surging forth in great ascendancy. According to heaven’s regulatory law, this breeds many treacheries in the rear palace—yet this is not the fault of the rear palace itself, but rather what is called a failure in governance to align with celestial prognostication, a loss of the great celestial divisions. Thus, disasters return and overturn one another. This has been so since the opening of heaven and earth; the transmission of celestial timing and fortune has not yet been fully distinguished and explained. Now, emperors and kings lose the celestial method of governance, giving rise to these calamitous transformations. Do you, Perfected Ones, deeply understand this?"

"Yes, yes."

"The celestial prognostication: to indulge in wine is of the water class. The marketplace is the domain of water, the great gathering place of the kingly and the common. To indulge in wine in the marketplace is called the great sovereignty of water and wine. When water rules, fire’s qi diminishes; when fire’s qi diminishes, it transforms into ashes; when it transforms into ashes, it changes into earth, and thus fire’s qi is entrusted to earth. When earth gains sovereignty and rises from the ground, it aligns with metal and water in the northwest. The Great Yin pertains to the people, and ministers gain sovereignty in turn. Treacherous ministers arise again, the *si*-qi once more takes action, the rear palace transgresses, and turmoil stirs anew. The resulting disasters bring theft and banditry without respite. All this lies in the indulgence of water, which injures the yang-virtue. Now, the reason I distinguish and explain this for you, Perfected Ones, is that I see your earnest inquiry, your deep concern, and your desire to assist the virtuous ruler in accord with the will of August Heaven. Thus, I clearly expound for you the great divisions of heaven and earth’s governance, that which you must emulate. Do not transgress again, for transgression will bring only confusion and chaos. Do you understand?"

"Yes, yes."

"Permit me to ask one doubt."
"Speak."

"Now, the capital gathers a multitude of people and wealth at its center—does the capital then correspond to the water phase?"
"Ah! Perfected Ones in learning—how can you be so clear at one moment and so benighted at another? You fall short. Yet how could one ever fully grasp it all? Nevertheless, the capital corresponds to the center of earth, the place where fire may securely rest. It is not like a marketplace, merely a place to amass wealth. The capital ought to gather together the Dao and virtue, benevolence and worthies, to govern the world in concert. Why would you say the lord of the capital should merely amass wealth? How profoundly foolish! If you doubt my words, let me explain for you.

From ancient times to the present, wherever the capital has gathered those of Dao and virtue, worthies and the wise, the world has been entirely at peace under its governance. But where only treasures and wealth are amassed without worthy and enlightened ones, all falls into chaos. In your view, Perfected One, should the capital be like a marketplace, merely a place to gather wealth? Do you understand?"
"Yes, yes."

"Now, for the various Perfected Ones, I shall further elucidate the celestial prognostic patterns and cosmic principles.

The sun arises from Lesser Yang and flourishes in Greater Yang; the moon arises from Lesser Yin and flourishes in Greater Yin. The sun is the essence of Heaven and the radiance of Yang, thus it is called the sovereign, its position in the south. The moon is the essence of Earth and the radiance of Yin, thus the moon is the minister, its position in the north. The south is for day, the north for night. Therefore, when the sun reigns and governs, the moon and night wane and diminish; when the moon reigns and governs, the sun and day wane and diminish. Thus, when the qi of the north prevails, the qi of the south declines; when the qi of the south prevails, the qi of the north declines. Hence, one must urgently cease the reign of wine, to sever the decline of water and metal.

Do the Perfected Ones clearly understand this?"
"Yes, yes."

"The cosmic principles are thus divided: Yang is Heaven, male, sovereign, father, elder, and teacher; Yin is Earth, female, minister, child, the people, and mother. Therefore, the southeast is Yang, and the northwest is Yin. If the Perfected Ones wish to know the truth of celestial prognostication, from the very opening of Heaven and Earth, whenever rulers have indulged in military might, allowed sovereigns to indulge in wine, or followed the governance of women—greatly heeding their words—such rulers, being of Lesser Yin, Greater Yin, and Earth, belong to the northwest. From such commands, all have later fallen into chaos and met with calamity.

Perceive this with benevolence."

"The virtuous, the wise, and the sagely all belong to the southeast, to Yang, to Heaven. Those who follow such words later all attain good governance."

"I wish to hear why the worthy and the sagely belong to the southeast."

"The essence of fire is the heart, and the heart is sagely; the essence of wood is benevolence, thus its symbol resides in the east. The southeast nurtures and fosters all things, and the worthy and the sagely, being gentle and luminous, likewise nurture all things without harming them. Therefore, the nature of the sagely and the worthy is gentle and luminous, all benevolent and bright. Benevolence resembles wood, brightness resembles fire, thus they all reside in the southeast."

"Excellent! Excellent! Having heard the Celestial Master’s words, I am greatly enlightened."

"Moreover, in the celestial prognostication and cosmic patterns, the southeast is where the handle of the Northern Dipper points, and in reckoning the four seasons, it is where kings receive the Mandate. The northwest belongs to Earth and is the Dipper’s bowl, where those bound to it meet with qi of death and extinction. Thus, when Lesser Yin, Greater Yin, and Earth allow one to reign, overcoming Yang, this is called ‘reversing Heaven and Earth,’ and so often leads to chaos. Do the Perfected Ones understand this?"

"Yes, yes."

"Several foolish students, moved by the Celestial Master’s compassion, have been taught the celestial prognostication formulas. I wish to ask one matter with a single word: now the south is Yang, yet it may reverse to yield *Xun*, *Li*, and *Kun*; the north is Yin, yet it may reverse to yield *Qian*, *Kan*, and *Gen*."

"Excellent! Your question is profound. You perceive the subtle intent of Heaven. Now, the *Yi* (Changes) is rooted in the subtle qi of Heaven and Earth’s Yin and Yang, taking the primordial qi as its beginning. Thus, the south, being utmost Yang, generates Yin, and so records its Yin; the north, being utmost Yin, generates Yang, and so records its Yang. These subtle qi have not yet the power to govern affairs. Therefore, in the *Yi*, the first *Nine* of *Zi* is the ‘hidden dragon—do not act,’ for it cannot yet govern affairs, and so one does not act. This is merely the inception of primordial qi."

"Excellent! Excellent!"

"Go on, Perfected One, you have understood. Now, what I record in the celestial prognostication are the great divisions of Heaven, those that govern the qi of celestial governance and serve as the guiding principles for the world. Do the Perfected Ones understand?"

"Yes, yes."

"Now, what I have spoken is precisely what the rulers of the world should follow as the method of governance. What you asked concerns the inception of the correct qi. If the Perfected Ones still harbor doubts upon hearing my words, I shall explain in full the eight boundaries of Heaven and Earth."

"Yes, yes."

"The boundary of the sun is determined by its rising in *Mao* and setting in *You*, with the south as Yang and the north as Yin. The boundary of the Heavenly Gate and Earthly Door is determined by *Xun* arising in the southeast corner and *Qian* arising in the northwest corner, with the northeast as Yang and the southwest as Yin. The first *Nine* of *Zi* and the first *Six* of *Wu* take the east as Yang and the west as Yin. *Lichun* (Beginning of Spring) is established in the northeast corner, and *Liqiu* (Beginning of Autumn) in the northwest corner, with the southeast as Yang and the northwest as Yin. These are called the eight boundaries of Heaven and Earth, which distinguish the positions of Yin and Yang. Do the Perfected Ones now understand?"

"Yes, yes."

"Go on, you have understood."

Thus, the Great Canon takes the southeast as Heaven and the northwest as Earth, with Earth yielding in compliance. If a king subdues his Heaven, it is called "Heaven and Earth reversed," hence inauspicious. When Heaven fulfills its affairs and the king subdues his Earth, each attains its proper place—hence auspicious. Perfected One, receive this text and ponder it deeply. Entrust it to a ruler of superior virtue, and if he enacts my teachings, he shall differ not from the gods, and Heaven shall aid him beyond due season.

Go now, for I have expounded to you the minor completion of celestial portents and proofs. I would further reveal to you, Perfected One, the vast expanse of Heaven above and Earth below, the farthest reaches of the eight poles, and the array of stellar lodges—all to be explained in part. Yet should I expound the subtle wonders of the celestial Dao in full, some might grow dizzy, losing their way, and the true Dao would thereafter fall into disuse, leaving no means to resolve ancient calamities, thus plunging the exalted into sorrow. Therefore, I have spoken to you only of the Great Canon’s most accessible truths, that you may awaken and no more. I do not speak of the profound and abstruse—not out of reluctance, but for good cause.

"Yes, yes. I humbly request to inquire further on one decisive matter."

"Now, the Celestial Master shall explain to this unenlightened student the ten Celestial Stems of Heaven, each with its corresponding pair, and the twelve Earthly Branches of the Earthly Dao, likewise possessing yin and yang, odd and even—why then does only Heaven attain such pairing?"

"Excellent! Your question truly grasps the essentials of the Dao. Yet Earth, though purely yin and dwelling alone, inherently possesses its own yin and yang. The laws of Heaven and Earth correspond above and below: Heaven has *zi*, Earth also has *zi*; Heaven has *wu*, Earth also has *wu*; Heaven has *kan*, Earth also has *kan*; Heaven has *li*, Earth also has *li*—their correspondence is thus.

Therefore, *chou* and *wei* are the rear palaces of *yin*. *Shen* belongs to *mao*, the son-in-law of the feudal lords and kings. *Hai* pairs with *chen*, and *mao* pairs with *xu*. *Chen* and *xu* are the household women of the Grand Empress. *You* belongs to *wu*, the Lesser Empress. *Zi* belongs to *si*, and *si* is the son-in-law of the Emperor’s younger sister. Do you understand, Perfected One?"

"Yes, yes."

"Thus, the Stems are the Emperors and Kings, and the Branches are also Emperors and Kings. Therefore, *yin* is the Branch of *jia*, so *chou* and *wei* are called the rear palaces. *Wu* is the Branch of *bing*, so *you* is called the rear palace. *Mao* is the Branch of *yi*, so *shen* is called the son-in-law of the feudal lords and kings. *Chen* is the Branch of *wu*, so it is called the household of the Grand Empress. *Hai* is the Branch of *gui*, so it is called the household woman of the Grand Empress. *Zi* is the Branch of *ren*, so it is called the son-in-law of the Emperor’s younger sister. *Si* is the Branch of *ding*, so it is called the Emperor’s younger sister. Such is the law of Heaven and Earth’s mutual correspondence and harmony."

"Excellent, excellent! I wish to inquire further: why is it that these *chen* and *xu* lords, when unmarried, gather together, and when women, they marry collectively?"

"How subtle! Your question is most profound."

"Now, Heaven is the utmost *yang*, while Earth is the utmost *yin*. Earth is multitudinous, for it is the chief of all *yin*. *Yin* is always even in number, hence the pairing."

"Yet *wu* and *si* share the same earthly position—why are they not paired?"

"Excellent question! *Wu* and *si* are the fifth stems, the *yang* of Earth, their positions belonging to Heaven, and thus they are not paired. Does the Perfected One understand this?"

"Yes, yes."

"Go then, for you have grasped it. Your inquiry is most apt. Now, the Five Phases’ characters rotate and complement one another to encompass all matters under Heaven. Having received my writings, you must reflect upon their categories and hidden meanings—above and below, the six directions, all is complete and profound. Thus the sage, seeing one, knows ten thousand; the great worthy, seeing one, knows a thousand; the foolish, straining to comprehend, remain confused and fail to attain the true Dao. Therefore, the Way and its *virtue* are entrusted to the Perfected One. Does the Perfected One understand?"

"Yes, yes."

"Go then, for you have understood. I now wish to inquire further on one more matter."

"Now, the four seasons of the heavens above and the Five Phases of the earth below—do they all extend to the households of the Thearchs, Emperors, feudal lords, kings, and the inner palaces? The celestial Dao exhaustively matches them all. But is there also a matching for the myriad commoners and the ten thousand things?"

"Excellent indeed is your question! It may be called perceiving the essentials of the great Dao. Yet this matching is all of a kind. As for the Five Phases, at their apex are the Thearchs and Kings; next are the ministers; next, the subtle qi. The Kings occupy the position of Thearchs and Kings. The ministers occupy the position of great officials. The subtle qi occupies the position of petty officers. After the Kings comes the aged qi, which is the position of feudal lords. After the aged qi comes the declining qi, which is the position of the imperial clan. After the declining qi comes the ailing qi, which is the omen of the imperial clan violating the law and losing its succession. After the ailing qi comes the imprisoned qi, which is the omen of the commoners and the myriad people. After the imprisoned qi comes the dead qi, which is the omen of slaves and bondservants. After the dead qi comes the vanished qi, which is the tombs of the dead. Thus, Heaven displays its signs: the four seasons and Five Phases cycle through, each rising and declining in turn. The people and the ten thousand things all follow the celestial pattern, also rising and declining in turn. Therefore, the myriad commoners are all descendants of the hundred kings—when flourishing, they become lords of men; when declining, they become commoners. Does the Perfected One understand this?"

"Yes, yes."

"You have grasped it."

Here the *Tianchen* prognostications are employed to govern the state of Chang’an, to suppress treacherous ministers, and to eradicate deceit, cunning, and falsehood. *Tai Ping Jing: Collated and Annotated Edition*, Scroll Seventy, Wu Section, Part Two. *Tai Ping Jing*, Scroll Seventy. "The Secret of Scholars’ Gains and Losses," One Hundred and Six.

The Perfected One respectfully inquired: "I now wish to compile and rectify all the texts written by my master, both prior and subsequent, so that scholars may not speak recklessly. May I hear of this?"

"Excellent! How your mastery grows day by day.

Now, my Daoist methods proceed by measuring yang when going forth and measuring yin when withdrawing; they proceed by measuring conduct when going forth and measuring spirit when withdrawing; they proceed by measuring the multitude of texts when going forth and measuring the multitude of charts when withdrawing; they proceed by dispelling calamities when going forth and rectifying the self when withdrawing; they proceed by measuring the learning of the court when going forth and measuring the inner chamber when withdrawing. In all matters, they impose limits. Those who strive diligently in their studies each employ their own talents and abilities, yet if they deviate from the constant method, those who study externally will fall into superficiality and be unable to restrain themselves, while those who study internally will fail to align with the correct path and instead plunge into great deviation.

Scholars invariably suffer from a grave affliction: they are unable to recognize it themselves. Those who favor external learning and whose talents exceed the proper measure often fall into superficiality, causing the Dao to become greatly deviant and devoid of correct texts, yet they falsely claim it as the true Dao and deceive one another. Those who favor internal learning and whose talents exceed the proper measure often plunge into great deviation, believing they have attained it. They do not speak with others, thus losing the proper method and transmitting false teachings.

Now you harbor doubts, which is why you have come to ask again. Since your intentions are earnest and unwavering, I shall establish rules and limits for you, so that each may have boundaries to discuss and adhere to.

Ancient and modern texts are too numerous to be confined. In all learning, those who delight in attaining the true essence must not deviate from the root. Those who learn from the oral instructions of their master must not deviate from their master’s words—this is the great essential principle.

The greatest harm in learning lies in this: when external studies align with superficial chapters and phrases, they become increasingly shallow, leading to empty words and reckless speech. When internal studies align with charts and prognostications, they fail to deeply grasp the essential meaning and instead speak erroneously. Those who study longevity and go forth, aligning with superficiality, deceive one another; those who align internally but fail to grasp the essential meaning instead fall into great deviation.

Now that you have come to ask repeatedly, I shall expound these texts for you and reveal their limits. What aligns with the method is correct; what does not align is incorrect—this is clear. You may thus come to understand it.

All texts are the discourse of Heaven. Those where ten correspond to ten are correct; those where nine correspond to ten are slightly deviant; those where eight correspond to ten are slightly disordered. Anything below this is not true and cannot be employed. They are called texts that disorder the celestial patterns and earthly principles, displease yin and yang, cause the myriad things to struggle, and bring great misfortune upon the people.

The method of nurturing one’s nature involves inwardly perceiving one’s form and appearance—what is manifestly clear is correct. Outwardly perceiving the spirits of the myriad things is incorrect.

In studying all matters, one must constantly uphold the original text and seek the explanations of many worthies to stabilize it—this is correct. Upholding the multitude of chapters and phrases while forgetting the original matter is incorrect and loses the intent of the celestial Dao.

What enables a person’s body to transform into spirit is correct. A body without the Dao that does not become spirit yet claims to command spirits is incorrect—it is merely a technique for manipulating them through texts.

Explaining all matters such that their root, branches, and center resemble one another is correct; what does not resemble is incorrect.

Entering seclusion, initially eating little, and over time consuming qi until one departs and vanishes—this is correct. Seeking the Dao, claiming to have attained it without returning, and refusing questions—this is incorrect.

All who depart must return; those who teach and answer questions are correct. Those who do not teach or answer questions yet feign death are incorrect.

Abiding in purity and stillness within a secluded chamber and achieving success—this is correct. Claiming to have attained the Dao and conduct while speaking with anger—this is incorrect, for such a person has lost their essence.

Entering learning and daily improving, surpassing one’s former state—this is attaining the Dao. Entering learning yet daily worsening, lacking loyalty and trustworthiness—this is incorrect, for one has fallen into great deviation.

Reading books and perceiving their meaning, then upholding the master’s instructions to seek explanations and clarifications—this is correct. Reading books without the master’s instructions and instead claiming deep, solitary understanding—this is incorrect, for one has inwardly lost the guiding intent of the great Dao.

Having attained the Dao, one must steadfastly serve many masters and worthies without negligence—this is the way of daily progress.

Thus, the ancient sagely masters, having attained the Dao, still served their masters as before and dared not cease. After leaving their masters, they continued to read the texts diligently. Those who study yet claim to have attained the essential meaning on their own, no longer striving to read the ancient texts and sagely words, and who claim correctness without serving the many enlightened sages—these are foolish people.

In all learning, thoroughly investigating what can be sought—this is correct. All things are thus: once born, they all can fulfill their lifespan and bear fruit—this is correct. Merely being born yet failing to fulfill their lifespan, lacking trustworthiness and substance—this is incorrect.

Doing good and attaining its proper fruition—this is correct. Failing to attain its proper fruition, appearing correct outwardly yet being incorrect inwardly—this is false.

Reading my books in their entirety without deviating from the guiding principles and attaining their true essence—this is correct. Reading books and producing oddities, possessing much talent yet failing to grasp their essential truth—this is incorrect.

Heaven has wind and rain, and the myriad things are born in due season—this is correct. Wind and rain yet the myriad things are harmed—this is incorrect, for it contains poison.

Practicing the Daoist classics and daily flourishing—this is correct. Not daily progressing but instead daily declining, inwardly losing the intent of one’s conduct—this is incorrect.

Thus, the nature of Heaven and Earth is such that when one does good, if it is not immediately manifested in one’s person, it flows to later generations to illuminate one’s conduct."

Those who do evil will likewise not be immediately halted in their persons, but will inevitably flow to later generations, thereby revealing their misguided conduct. Thus, the consequences of good and evil will invariably manifest.

Yet those who do good are like the sun rising at dawn—ever more radiant and luminous. Those who do evil are like the sun setting at dusk—ever more obscure and dark. Such is the natural disposition of Heaven and Earth’s yin and yang.

Heaven generates the myriad things, each made manifest according to its conduct, never concealed. Thus, the good ascend and their fate belongs to Heaven, just as the living belong to Heaven. The evil descend and their fate belongs to Earth, just as the dead, being impure, descend to the Yellow Springs—this is what is meant.

To those who obtain my books, I entrust them to the noble lord of supreme virtue. I possess these writings and dare not obstruct or withhold their transmission and study.

The Dao of Heaven governs Heaven, yet it cannot be fully known; one must not heed the words of a single person. Therefore, I have now established the texts of the ancient sages for you, once more distilling their essential concord, clarifying how the earlier and later passages mutually corroborate.

Since the opening of Heaven and Earth, though the worthy and sagely have lived in different eras, separated by vast stretches of time, what they detested was the same. Together they discoursed on Heaven’s behalf, remedying the world’s gains and losses. Their words resemble one another like overlapping compasses or aligned squares, mutually illuminating—this could not be otherwise.

For things of the same kind gather and arise together; their principles all operate through resonance by likeness and image—this is evident proof. What was lost in the past is regained in the future; examining their similarities and differences completes the text.

By adhering to antiquity to illuminate the present, collectively deliberating their matters, one may take inner texts to clarify outer texts, and outer texts to verify inner texts. Thus may they be transmitted for ten thousand generations, without ever again offending Heaven.

The words of one person cannot be followed alone. The words of many, deeply examined and drawn from the sayings of the ancient worthy and sagely, inwardly accord with Heaven. Together they are established and set forth.

When the emperor daily clarifies the decisive principles, all confusions, disorders, calamities, and evils are dispelled. Heaven has no repeated sorrows; those who work in concert prosper, while those who resist and rebel find their misfortunes unremoved.

*Here ends the decisive principles on scholars’ gains and losses.*

**The Combined Collated Scroll Seventy-One, Wu Section Part Three**
**Scroll Seventy-One of the Scripture of Great Peace**
**The Ninefold True Dao: Textual Decisions on Gains and Losses, One Hundred and Seven**

The Perfected One bowed twice and said, "I beg to ask one matter."
"Very well, speak."
The Perfected One began: "Now the Celestial Master has issued forth the qi of Great Peace to bestow the Dao and its virtue, thereby raising up the supreme emperor. Above, there is a ruler who delights in the Dao and its virtue; below, even the foolish and humble common folk are reached. Its grace penetrates the six directions, harmonizes the eight limits, and enfolds all without exception.

Yet now, though the worthy receive the Master’s literary teachings and apply their thoughts to the Dao, what is the ultimate aim above, and what is the final limit below?"
"Excellent! How subtle and essential is the Perfected One’s question. Does he wish to hear of the utmost extremes, to know the advance and retreat of the numinous?"
"Truly, I am benighted and dull, unequal to the task. Only the enlightened Master may record and instruct me."
"Very well.

The Dao has nine degrees, each distinguished by different names. Now I shall set forth their meanings in full for the Perfected One. Follow along and record them, lest anything be lost."
"Indeed, indeed."
"Thus:

The first is called the Primal Qi of Non-Action.
The second, Concentrated Stillness and Emptiness.
The third, Numerical Measurement and Distinction.
The fourth, Numinous Excursion—Departure and Return.
The fifth, the Great Dao’s Spirit, akin to the Four Seasons and Five Phases.
The sixth, Piercing Joy.
The seventh, Community Deliberation.
The eighth, Overflowing Spirit.
The ninth, Ancestral Forebears.

Each of these nine is further divided into nine, yielding eighty-one sections. Though their forms differ and their texts vary, when employed in secrecy, they unite as one great root, with the numinous as their agent and humans as their gateway.

Now, I shall arrange them for you in ordered decisions. It is impossible to record them all in advance; you must ponder their meanings yourself. The upper three nines—twenty-seven in all—can transcend the world. The central three nines—twenty-seven in all—can command the Perfected Spirit Officials. The lower three nines—twenty-seven in all—abound in perversity; their spirits and essences cannot be constantly employed. They cause people to grow confused and disoriented, and among them, there are often those who lack precision, uttering many reckless words, like one who has lost their qi."
"Now, this foolish student has heard the Master’s words but is dazzled and knows not east from west. I beg you to explain them separately for this dull and ignorant one."
"Very well.

The first, the Primal Qi of Non-Action, is to contemplate one’s body, doing nothing at all, but only envisioning it as utterly luminous, like qi relinquished and formless. Constantly take this as the method. Once perfected, there will be nothing one cannot do, nothing one does not know. Thus, when a person is without the Dao, they are merely human; when they attain the Dao, they transform into divine immortals. Their spirit ascends to Heaven, following Heaven’s transformations—this is the meaning of ‘nothing one cannot do.’

The second, Emptiness and Spontaneity, is to guard the form, penetrating emptiness and spontaneity, without any strangeness. The body’s interior shines white, above and below like jade, without flaw. Practiced over a long time, this too is a method for transcending the world. It is the image following the Primal Qi of Non-Action.

The third, Numerical Measurement, is to accumulate essence and inwardly observe oneself, counting from the hair down to the feet, distinguishing the five fingers, the body’s external and internal forms—nothing is left uncounted. Knowing its meaning, one should constantly take this as their contemplation, not losing even a fraction. This too is a lesser method for transcending the world, following Emptiness and Spontaneity.

The fourth, Numinous Excursion—Departure and Return, is to visualize the spirits of the five viscera, which by day go out and enter, seeing their movements and travels. One may speak with them. Contemplating and following the spirit’s comings and goings, one also clearly perceives the body. This enables knowledge of good and ill fortune, following Numerical Measurement.

The fifth, the Great Dao’s Spirit, is when the human spirit emerges and becomes akin to the Five Phases and Four Seasons. Green, red, white, yellow, and black—all correspond to the spirits of the viscera. As they go out and enter, come and go, the spirit officials of the Four Seasons and Five Phases serve the person. This is called the Complete Dao, capable of subduing all perversities.

The sixth, Piercing Joy, is to pierce and strike the earth. Each Daoist spirit has its own canon, and by the family’s methods, the spirits are summoned to wander. Half resemble the Perfected, half resemble perversities, and they often make people fond of cleverness. They cannot be constantly employed, and over time, they bring sorrow to people.

The seventh, Community Deliberation, involves the spirits of Heaven and Earth, the Four Seasons, the altars of soil and grain, mountains and rivers—all are spirits that descend to humans. They cause people to grow confused, desiring to recklessly speak of their spirits, which are violent, vengeful, mad, and perverse. They must not be recklessly invoked.

The eighth, Overflowing Spirit, refers to spirits that overflow, their Dao having nothing to which they may be tethered. They are the essential qi of the world descending to humans, causing people to speak recklessly. Half resemble the Perfected, half resemble perversities.

The ninth, Ancestral Forebears, involves purely seeing ghosts, without any true Dao. Those who summon them call forth only the ghosts of the dead.

This is the lowest extreme of the Dao, called the path of the inferior scholar. Those who attain the upper Dao can also employ the lower, but those who attain the lower Dao cannot employ the upper."
"Now, I wish to hear why there are these upper and lower distinctions."
"Ah, this arises from the conduct of people. Those who guard the root attain the upper; those who delight in the spirit’s excursions in and out of the body attain the middle. Foolish people damage their root and guard the branches, and those who wander with other spirits attain the lower.

Those who guard the root can fully perceive them; those who guard the middle can perceive half; those who guard the branches cannot return to mirror and perceive the Dao. Thus, all who study must obtain an enlightened master. Without an enlightened master, they lose the way.

Therefore, the transmission from master to master is firmer than metal and stone. Without transmission from a master, it is called reckless practice, which invites misfortune and perversity. Perfected One, be cautious, be cautious!"
"Indeed, indeed."
"Thus, in ancient times, those who studied the sagely and worthy and obtained an enlightened master were called ‘reborn.’ Those who did not obtain an enlightened master were called ‘confusers of the scriptures.’"

Thus, the worthy and sagely all serve masters to achieve completion; without a master, the Dao does not arise of itself.

"Excellent, excellent!"

"Perfected One, if you wish to know its effects: consider a person dwelling in a village of the greatly worthy—they become greatly worthy; dwelling in a village of the moderately worthy—they become moderately worthy; dwelling in a village of the unworthy—they become unworthy, ever falling short. This is what is meant. Those who study this Dao must examine and deliberate upon it—this is the essential Dao of Heaven. Be cautious, be cautious!"

"Indeed, indeed."

"Go forth, for the Dao returns to its rightful person, to be entrusted to the worthy and enlightened."

"Indeed, indeed. This is the divine formula and essential Dao."
