*Right [Section]:* The Nine Chapters of the True Dao on Gains and Losses
*First of the One Hundred and Eight Texts on Receiving the Dao’s Precepts to Attain Goodness and Dispel Evil*

The Perfected One asked the Divine Person, "By what does one receive the Dao’s precepts?"

The Divine Person replied, "The Dao has great precepts—one must not fail to be cautious. When one is about to attain the Dao, on the verge of its completion, one then engages with all spirits, dwelling as neighbors to essence and spirit, meeting and seeing one another in entry and exit, loving one another as father and son. The Dao is a weighty matter. Some may regret bestowing it upon others and seek to seize another’s Dao, so they first test a person to see if they are steadfast. They come together to deceive, causing one to speak recklessly. If you obtain their words, guard them firmly and take care never to transmit them—then you may attain longevity. With time, you may attain the true Dao. To transmit them is to invite daily dissipation. Moreover, it makes one cherish life and detest harm."

The Perfected One said, "I wish to hear the meaning of ‘daily dissipation.’"

"When essence and spirit dissipate, the body dies. The Dao of emptiness and absolute profundity constantly urges one to cherish life and detest killing, to seal the mouth and prevent leakage—then one may endure for ten thousand times ten thousand years."

The Perfected One asked the Divine Person, "I wish to hear the prohibitions against leakage."

The Divine Person said, "If a great person leaks it, they lose their position; if a middling person leaks it, their qi is severed; if a petty person leaks it, their lineage is extinguished. The reason is this: Heaven and Earth use this to distinguish themselves and maintain their privacy, so the divine particularly values it."

"If Heaven and Earth did not profoundly know the Dao of absolute profundity, how could they be divine? How could they be long-lived?"

"Remember this—I tell you: value its essence, guard it, and be cautious."

The Perfected One assented repeatedly, not daring to speak recklessly.

The Perfected One bowed deeply and said, "I wish to hear further: when they seek to corrupt a person, what is to be done?"

The Divine Person replied, "When there is malice in a person’s heart, great evil comes to deceive. If one can firmly seal their ears and not listen to their words, it is auspicious; if one listens to their words, it brings misfortune and harm. If a ruler listens, they will despise their ministers, claiming they are disloyal and intend rebellion. If ministers or children listen, they will despise their ruler or father, and the deceivers will come, saying, ‘Now you shall become a sage’ or ‘Now you shall become a ruler.’ If petty people listen, they will make one boast of their own greatness. If a father listens, he will despise his son; if a son listens, he will despise his father. Their words shift and change, confusing the heart and mind, speaking now of good, now of evil, disrupting governance. One moment joy, the next anger—this is the great flattery of evil, bent on harming others. From ancient times to the present, those who study long life have all failed to overcome these words."

The Perfected One asked, "What is to be done?"

The Divine Person said, "Seal your ears and do not listen; seal your mouth and do not speak. These are but flattering evils—there is nothing worth hearing. To listen is to lose the true Dao, and once it departs, death follows. If you wish to endure, be cautious of these words. I have already warned you beforehand, for how often have you been ensnared by this great evil? I constantly rectify my own heart and no longer heed them. This great evil constantly accumulates, seeking to observe whether a person is steadfast. The cunning evil may even enter a person’s abdomen, stirring their heart to reckless action. Sometimes joy, sometimes anger, unable to restrain oneself—all are misled by evil, pushed by evil, and many perish. Those who accumulate much in this way must carefully observe these weighty precepts; the heart must not be swayed. This is not only for those who study the Dao—common people, too, are subject to unpredictable joy and anger. You must be cautious and refine yourself."

The Perfected One assented repeatedly.

The Perfected One said, "I myself have been afflicted by great evil, making me wish to boast, saying, ‘I shall become a ruler, and later ascend as a flying immortal to Heaven.’ I believed their words and rejoiced greatly. Later, I suffered from madness for three months. When I saw the Divine Person and Heavenly Master, my heart was filled with great joy. I have personally experienced such affliction, nearly succumbing to severe illness. Later, the madness ceased and I recovered, thus attaining several thousand years of life. Now, by good fortune, I meet the Divine Person again, receive the Dao’s precepts anew, and behold the gateway, hoping to endure long and become an official of Heaven."

The Divine Person said, "If you maintain such firmness of heart and will, what worry is there that you will not ascend to the Nine Heavens and traverse the Twenty-Five Heavens? All those who attain the heavens now do so by holding fast to a firm and secret heart, allowing no error. Those who can be confused and misled all die prematurely and fail to transcend. If you wish for long life, study this text as a weighty precept—this is the precept of life and death, and you must not fail to be cautious. Thus, the ancient sages and worthies who first transcended the world did not rely on this power. Those who study the Dao yet fail to attain it and do not transcend all sit and listen to this, falling prey to its harm. The great gods of Heaven cannot be usurped by such deceivers; they cause one to suffer this harm and subjugation, thus forfeiting great fortune."

"To turn life into death is to become a celestial thief. Now, all the teachings I impart to you, Perfected One, can grant you great longevity. Some may transcend the world, but you must hold fast and guard yourself, lest this become harm. If you can focus your heart with utmost care, you may attain boundless years." The Perfected One assented repeatedly. "I dare not act wrongly; I humbly receive your luminous precepts."

The divine being said, "Your devotion to the Dao is thus—when you accomplish this, you will ascend the steps to Heaven. Perfected One, do you inquire about precepts only in this regard? Are there deeper ones? There are also the precepts of the Upper Heavens, which are steadfast in restraining people. Those who preach precepts with deceitful words exalt themselves as noble, using them to mislead others. Thus, they cause people to violate prohibitions and incur execution. They repeatedly test people with jade maidens, enticing them to wander together, then mock those who succumb as base, only to bring ruin upon their bodies. Yet if one remains ever silent, lives ten thousand years without heeding such things, and guards their fate alone, what harm could befall them? Between life and death, this is the crux."

The Perfected One assented repeatedly. The Perfected One asked, "Why does Heaven specifically send evil spirits to test people?" The divine being replied, "The Dao is weighty and difficult to share with others. Only those whose resolve is unshakable, who would die before abandoning their aspiration, will not have their wishes stolen. Those who transcend the world in Heaven are not covetous of honor or nobility; they simply delight in life itself. There is no extraordinary Dao here. Remember my precepts, and you will... My words must never be forgotten for ten thousand generations. Even if you ascend to traverse the boundless heavens above, the precepts remain thus—there is nothing extraordinary beyond them."

The Perfected One assented repeatedly, saying, "I dare not stray from the guiding line." The divine being said, "If you truly speak thus, you have already attained the Dao. The auspicious will advance daily, while the wicked will cease their ascent. Holding your heart in this way, you fulfill the divine precepts. When you accomplish this, you will ride clouds and mount dragons, roaming the eight directions. The Great Dao is vast and smooth—you have already attained it. Your life will be everlasting and boundless."

The Perfected One said, "Indeed." The divine being continued, "The Dao is truly great, without inner or outer bounds. Yet I constantly fear it may be harmed by great evil, for if one does not heed even a single evil, how could evil ever prevail? Thus, the ancient emperors and kings who loved the Dao and studied it, refusing to listen to evil, all attained boundless years. Those who heeded and followed evil words all brought ruin upon themselves. My Dao has myriad facets, and you must understand their benefits and harms."

The Perfected One assented repeatedly. "Now that I have received the divine being’s words, can I attain long life in an instant?" The divine being replied, "Without deep precepts, your accomplishment will... be inauspicious, and the Dao will not be attained."

The Perfected One said, "Is my life fated to have such fortune? Is it mere luck that I have encountered a divine being?" The divine being replied, "Yes. The lives of the Six Kinds of People each have their own destiny: the first are divine beings, the second are Perfected Ones, the third are immortals, the fourth are Daoists, the fifth are sages, and the sixth are worthies. All assist Heaven in governance. Divine beings govern Heaven, Perfected Ones govern Earth, immortals govern wind and rain, Daoists govern teachings of fortune and misfortune, sages govern the people, and worthies assist sages in managing the records of the myriad people, supplementing the deficiencies of the Six Directions. Thus, each person’s life has its own destiny. The noble cannot become base, nor can the base become noble.

If you wish to know the truth of this, consider the fish: though it dwells in water, it cannot soar without the water’s qi. The dragon, too, dwells in water, yet only by relying on the water’s qi can it ascend to the azure clouds and become Heaven’s messenger. Nobility and baseness are truly matters of destiny—fools speak recklessly. The ancient sage-kings and emperors, in their great wisdom, never heeded false words, knowing their... and that it was impossible to achieve. This is like teaching a person without the Dao to suddenly fly—how could they truly soar? Only those who attain the Dao and become immortals can fly. When the common people idly claim, 'I can fly,' yet cannot, their reckless words are just like this."

The Perfected One said, "Excellent! I have awakened to this." The divine being continued...

"Can one, being foolish as you are, forcibly attain Heaven’s mandate?" The Perfected One said, "Then can this Dao also be studied?" The divine being replied, "Indeed. Those with Heaven’s mandate who study it will surely attain great capacity; those of middling virtue who study it may also attain long life; even the foolish who pursue it may gain modest longevity. Do you wish to know its effect? It is like the common man who studies: the greatly virtuous who study may attain high office; those of middling virtue who study may attain middling office; the foolish who study may become petty officials. Are petty officials not still set above the common folk? Thus, one should still strive to study."

The Perfected One assented, "I shall practice it and never dare grow lax." The divine being said, "Then exert yourself and trust in the Dao. Between Heaven and Earth, each takes what is fitting—there is no falsehood in this." The Perfected One assented again, "I shall revere Heaven and honor Earth, respect my superiors and cherish my inferiors, follow the four seasons and the five phases in all I do, and never dare transgress."

The divine being exclaimed, "Excellent! Excellent! You have grasped the meaning of the Dao. I need not instruct you further."

"Method for Fasting, Meditating on the Divine, and Rescuing from Death, One Hundred and Ninth"

The Perfected Writs of the Six Directions prostrated again and inquired: "Previously, we received the Celestial Master’s teaching that the Qi of Great Peace is about to descend, and that the harmonization of yin and yang depends first upon harmonizing with the divine spirits, each returning to their proper places. Reflecting deeply upon the Celestial Master’s words, we find that those who can reverse illumination and penetrate with clarity may perceive all things one by one. Yet such people are numerous—how can this be achieved? Can all Daoist adepts who possess penetrating reverse illumination gather them together?"

"Ah! Excellent indeed! The August Qi of Heaven is soon to arrive, and the Emperor-King shall govern with folded arms, free from care. Thus, Heaven has sent the various Perfected Ones to inquire in full about the essentials of the supreme Dao, which may serve as the great virtue of an enlightened ruler to eradicate the lingering disasters and inherited burdens of former kings, as well as the malevolent qi, demonic entities, treacherous spirits, and baleful influences that bring harm between Heaven and Earth. Therefore, the Perfected Ones have come to inquire in detail about these essentials of the supreme Dao. Do your disciples not already know this of themselves?"

"We suddenly do not know it of ourselves."

"If you suddenly do not know it of yourselves, why do you ask?"

"Reflecting upon the Celestial Master’s teachings, there are points we do not understand. Since we do not know of ourselves how to gather these rare, profoundly tranquil, reverse-illuminating adepts who can perceive the strange and uncanny, we have come together to ask about it."

"Excellent! The Perfected One’s dedication advances ever further, for you now question this. Heaven has sent you to inquire fully on behalf of a virtuous ruler about what may resolve these doubts."

"Very well."

"Now, I shall explain in full for the Perfected Ones, distinguishing and clarifying the essential meanings of the Dao. Sit calmly and record it together."

"Yes, yes."

*(Rising)* "Heaven and Earth possess their own divine treasures, each with its own divine essence and radiance. These follow the five phases in color and wax and wane with the qi of the four seasons, serving as Heaven and Earth’s envoys to bring forth the myriad people and things. Between Heaven and Earth, within yin and yang, none are not born through the transformative power of their virtue." *(Ceasing)*

Those who grasp its meaning may immediately perceive it; those who fail to grasp its great essentials have no gateway to knowledge. Those who can greatly open and apply it shall attain great fortune, able to dispel the afflictions, sufferings, malevolence, and evil that plague people between Heaven and Earth. Those who do not know its great method cannot recklessly summon or employ the divine in vain.

"We wish to hear its meaning, that it may be transmitted for ten thousand generations without error."

"Excellent is your question! Yet to await and obtain its technique, there is a great method: the qi of the four seasons and five phases enters the human abdomen to become the spirits of the five viscera, their colors corresponding to those of Heaven and Earth and the four seasons. When depicted as a person, let the three be united: the qi of the ruling phase covers the exterior, the qi of the ministering phase follows, and the qi of the retiring phase resides innermost, with their collars and sleeves visible.

First, fast and reside in seclusion, in a tranquil place. Meditate upon and contemplate it, then create its painted image, its length as you will. For five persons, depict them together upon five feet of plain silk. Let them be of good virtue: men should meditate upon men, women upon women—thus shall the painted images be made. These writings are already numerous, not merely one version. From top to bottom, discuss their meanings and create them accordingly, transmitting the texts to mutually elucidate their subtleties. Though my writings are many, they have a great division: texts are grouped by category, and characters clarify one another, so that their essential meaning is fully attained."

"Yes, yes."

"This spirit of the four seasons and five phases enters to become the spirit of the five viscera and emerges to become the divine essence of the four seasons and five phases. Those close to humans are called the spirits of the five virtues, resembling the visceral spirits of humans. Those distant from humans are called the Yang Registers, styled the Four Seasons’ Troops and Horses, which may repel malevolence and act in accordance with the waxing and waning of the four seasons’ qi.

The method for depicting them in full: let the person be clad in triple-layered robes, with the ruling qi on the exterior, the ministering qi next, and the retiring qi innermost. All wear caps and headbands and ride horses, the horses also depicted in the colors of the five phases. First, paint the image on one side, two zhang in length. On five silks, loosely depict twenty-five riders in five groups of five. Craft them well.

The riders of the East hold spears; those of the South hold halberds; those of the West hold bows, crossbows, and axes; those of the North hold shields, bucklers, and swords; and those of the Center hold swords and drums. In meditation, one should first perceive these inner spirits, then perceive these outer spirits. Alternatively, one may first see the yang spirits and then the inner spirits. To perceive them thus is to follow this method, which has no fixed form. One must also receive the master’s oral instructions and teachings. There is a crucial point at the outset: those who know it may easily transmit it, saying that it is easily attained and easily accomplished. It is fitting to practice it far from others, in a secluded place, for it is easily gathered when near people but difficult to accomplish.

When the Dao is accomplished, it is called the Gathering of the Great, Utterly Reversed, Penetrating Illumination. If the manifestations of illness are not numerous, many is auspicious, few is inauspicious."

"In cases where the treatment is insufficient, the resolution unclear, and the cure not achieved, how many should be gathered to suffice?"

"At the highest, ten thousand; at the middle, four or five thousand; at the lowest, several hundred, or a hundred and several tens."

"Why so many?"

"Ah!"

Should the Perfected One yet remain in former ignorance? Be seated, and I shall now expound for you its great essential meaning.

In the aftermath of inherited burdens, Heaven and Earth suffer abundant calamities. Ghostly beings, ancient spirits, malevolent forces, and corpse-borne misfortunes are manifold. Moreover, there are wind-damp sores, scabies, and in this late age, countless flowing disasters—too many to name. Some bear a hundred illnesses; others, several dozen. Suppose each person harbors fears, some of which may shorten life. If each could dispel but one affliction: the diviner skilled in hexagrams might remove one baleful malady; the master physician versed in formulas, another; the acupuncturist adept in channels and vessels, yet another; the moxibustionist, one more; the exorcist, still another; the invoker who commands spirits to guide and inspect ghosts, one further; and the sacrificer, one last. These seven, each removing one illness, would together dispel seven. Yet in this late age, people suffer many diseases—some claim ten or more, even a hundred—all bearing unrelenting distress. Though every skilled artisan may remove one affliction, together they dispel but seven, leaving the rest untouched. When the seven artisans have exhausted their strength, the remaining illnesses persist, still tormenting the sufferer. Over time, they bring exhaustion, and thus many perish, unable to escape their dire straits.

How many years of natural span does a person enjoy? How many illnesses do they witness? They encounter calamities, meet with decline and prosperity, advance and retreat. Heaven’s standard follows the waxing and waning of the four seasons and five phases. The eight trigrams, Qian and Kun, embody Heaven and Earth, yet even they have times of rest, imprisonment, decay, and depletion of qi—how much more so for humans? Humans mirror Heaven and Earth, following the four seasons, five phases, six conjunctions, and eight directions, ever alternating between flourishing and decline, without respite. Thus, one must prepare in advance, remedy the sources of fortune and misfortune, remain vigilant in peace, mindful in survival, orderly in governance, and ever aware of chaos. Only then can one endure.

Therefore, in the method of treating perverse influences, the Daoist’s illnesses are not numerous. If one person can dispel one illness, ten people dispel ten, a hundred dispel a hundred, a thousand dispel a thousand, and ten thousand dispel ten thousand. How could one body bear ten thousand illnesses? Thus, all may be decisively cured. Do you understand?

“Indeed, indeed.”

“Hence, instruct them to prepare in advance and gather those who have accomplished the Dao.”

“Indeed, indeed.”

“Go forth, for you now understand. Proceed, Perfected One, and clearly set forth these teachings.

The illnesses treated here are great perverse influences of ghostly beings, acting as thieves and bandits. When the emperor and king enjoy peace, they maintain armies and generals. Weapons, meant to guard against others, may instead become instruments of treachery. Thus, one who dares to die cannot be withstood by ten; ten who dare to die, not by a hundred; a hundred, not by a thousand; a thousand, not by ten thousand. Ten thousand who dare to die may advance unhindered in all directions. To prepare for illness, injury, and harm, an army of twelve thousand is maintained for emergencies. The two thousand serve only to replace those resting or in retreat, ensuring their submission. Do you understand, Perfected One?”

“Indeed, indeed.”

“Excellent, you have understood.”

**110. Against Grand Words Without Effective Methods**

The Perfected One asked, “May I inquire of the Heavenly Master: now that the qi of Great Peace is about to arrive, should not perverse qi be thought to dissipate and depart?”

“Indeed, what you say is both correct and incorrect. When the qi of Great Peace arrives, perverse influences should naturally vanish. Yet since the opening of Heaven and Earth, perverse qi has accumulated over long ages, vast and numerous, passing down burdens through generations. Though the governing qi of Great Peace has come, how could it suddenly and completely eradicate all this? Thus, one must prepare in advance. To wait until adversity has trapped one in distress before seeking skilled masters is already far too late.

In the highest antiquity, each person knew the true Dao, and perverse qi was scarce. From the middle antiquity of the Most High onward, people grew foolish, delighting in superficial adornments and neglecting the true Dao. With rampant perverse qi, mad spirits, and calamities, many died prematurely, their Heaven-appointed years cut short. All this arose from benighted minds, unable to foresee and guard against the root.

Now, the ruler of supreme virtue governs, and Heaven cherishes him, unwilling to let his people suffer like those foolish multitudes. He must swiftly perfect his great virtue and align his heart with Heaven. Thus, Heaven has sent the various Perfected Ones to seek answers, bidding me expound the methods that can suppress and repel inauspicious and malevolent influences. For this, I have explained everything to the Perfected One in full. Yet now you say that perverse influences will vanish on their own and no preparations are needed—this is incorrect, a grave misstatement that misleads the noble-minded. Your words cannot be heeded.”

“What do you mean?”

“When a great emergency arises and one seeks remedies afterward, they cannot be swiftly obtained, leaving people in dire straits. Thus, your words are gravely mistaken and cannot be followed.

Now, grain fills the granaries to prepare for famine. I have made these teachings clear for the Perfected One, so they may endure for ten thousand generations without being forgotten.”

“Indeed, indeed.”

“If one waits until hunger strikes to teach people to plant grain, instructing them to till and cultivate, waiting for the rice to ripen before cooking it—would this not be too late? By then, they would already have starved. Or if one fails to sow in spring and, when winter hunger strikes, seeks to plant grain, yet the seeds do not sprout—could this save lives? Not only would the individual perish, but the entire household would be destroyed. This is one great folly of the Perfected One, the profound effect of utter ignorance.

Let me explain another matter: people dig wells to prepare for thirst. One should dwell near springs to guard against thirst. Yet if one waits until parched and near death to dig a well in search of water—how could this suffice? One would already be in dire straits. This is the Perfected One’s second folly, another mark of benightedness.

Let me explain yet another matter: in ancient times, people lived in caves; now, they build houses to guard against wind and rain. When there is no wind or rain, dwelling in the wild brings utmost joy. But when clouds gather, wind and rain arrive, and one then builds a house—by then, the cold rain would have already brought distress. This is the Perfected One’s third folly.

Let me explain one more matter: from the middle antiquity onward, sages established governments, building walled cities and deep moats to prepare for the unforeseen. In times of quiet peace, when all was well, if disorder arose and petty men sought to cause chaos, and only then did the noble-minded order the people to build walls and moats—would this not be too late for an emergency? This is the Perfected One’s most grievous folly, the effect of profound ignorance.

Let me explain one final matter: armies and generals are instruments of misfortune. The noble-minded should not possess them, and the lowly despise them. Thus, they should be sheathed, securely stored, and never prized or employed. They exist only to prepare for the unforeseen. Yet in an emergency, one would first have artisans strike stone to extract iron, smelt it into liquid, then have master smiths forge it ten thousand times to create a Moye blade for battle—would this not be too late? One would already be subdued, life and death decided. Is this not the sixth great folly of the Perfected One?”

“Very well, very well.”
“What may seem a fault is no fault—ponder matters thoroughly in your heart and mind before speaking, and thereafter do not speak lightly or recklessly.”
“Very well, very well.”
“Let me tell the Perfected One a small decision that, when reversed, illuminates the great. In ancient times, the sages and worthies devised combs and fine-toothed lice combs to prepare for tangled hair and lice. If a person is born and never combs, their hair becomes irreparably matted, and nits and lice grow beyond restraint. Only then would one seek fine wood from the southern mountains or rare ivory fit for comb-making, and have master craftsmen fashion them. By then, the hair is irreparably tangled, the lice in the head too numerous to count, all feeding on the person until the scalp festers with sores. Only then does one obtain combs and lice combs—already at the end of one’s resources.

Now let me present this small decision to the Perfected One, using the small to illustrate the great. By rivers, seas, and the five lakes, near the water’s edge swarms of mosquitoes and horseflies abound, yet one does not prepare in advance what might shield and defend against them. When mosquitoes and horseflies all emerge and take flight, coming together to feed on people, oxen, and horses—oxen and horses toss their heads and stamp, unable to eat; people grow deeply distressed, even to the point of death, with no respite—only then does one seek what might repel and defend against them. By then, one is utterly at the end of one’s resources. Does the Perfected One not clearly understand this?”
“Very well, very well.”

“Excellent, you have now awakened. The finest remedies can repel scabies mites; fine clothing and proper dwellings can repel fleas and lice. If one does not prepare these in advance, and only when afflicted by them seeks what might dispel them—by then, one is already deeply distressed, impoverished, and ailing. Do you understand this?”
“Indeed, indeed.”

“These are but the smallest of provisions among all things under heaven—how much more so for the greatest? Between heaven and earth, at all times there are violent ghosts, malevolent spirits, calamitous omens, and murderous specters. When they descend upon a person, it is as if arrows from blades, bows, and crossbows have struck the body. The pain they inflict is unbearable; in the most severe and sudden cases, one cannot even gasp for breath, cannot stand upright, and the body is seized by violent madness. It is like being in a desolate pavilion, far from the emperor’s officials, where one’s words are blocked and obstructed, unable to report an emergency. Only then does one seek skilled masters and elders to save oneself—by then, it is already too late. Words can no longer reach them; nothing more can be said.”

"Do you understand this?"
"Yes, yes."

"Good, you have awakened. Therefore, I am especially urgent. This death is the greatest misfortune under heaven. Thus, I have written these texts to instruct virtuous rulers to prepare in advance. The most wise, upon seeing my words, will fully awaken; those of middling wisdom will partially awaken; the foolish and unenlightened will not awaken but instead mock my writings for lacking fundamentals—thus, they have already reached their limit. For heaven, earth, and the emperor, nothing surpasses this in importance.

Now, as the qi of Great Peace arrives and the Yang virtue ruler governs, one may attain longevity. Yet death among all under heaven is no small matter: once dead, one never again sees the heavens, earth, sun, or moon—flesh and bone become dust. Death is a weighty affair. All people between heaven and earth receive but one life; none may be reborn. Only those who attain the Dao may be reborn after death, or achieve liberation through *shijie*. These are the ones heaven and earth favor—among ten thousand, not even one succeeds.

Thus, for ordinary people, once dead, there is no rebirth. Therefore, one must prepare thoroughly. Even in the era of Great Peace and abundant years, malevolent qi still exists. It is like a household that is generally good yet still harbors wicked individuals—one merely endures them. For this reason, it is all the more necessary to gather those skilled in the Dao and its arts: when the unwholesome arises, it must be swiftly eliminated. If not removed quickly, it will take root.

Thus, I teach that one should prepare by gathering many such people in advance. The purpose of great learning is to accumulate those of virtue and power, so they may be sought when needed. Without prior preparation, they cannot be obtained in haste. If an unforeseen event occurs and one wishes to consult past and present precedents, without those of great virtue and power already assembled, none will be able to respond or resolve doubts in time. Should a ruler be benighted and suddenly face a crisis, yet find no timely resolution to their distress, and only afterward seek wise masters from afar—how could this suffice when the matter is already at hand?

Perfected One, do you understand?"
"Yes, yes."

"Good, you have fully awakened."

"Though I may be reproached for speaking too much, if I do not ask, I will remain ignorant. I wish to clarify one matter: if the scale is vast—tens of thousands at the highest, thousands in the middle, or hundreds at the lowest—how can one swiftly gather and complete this?"

"Excellent, your question is apt. Simply teach a dozen people to perfect it, and let them in turn instruct others. In urgent cases, some will achieve success. Have the ruler of supreme virtue and power value and cherish them, rewarding those who succeed. The people will then aspire to it, and as their aspirations grow, they will follow willingly. Those who succeed will be universally respected and loved.

The spirits of the four seasons, five phases, heaven, and earth—seeing such reverence and love—will all rejoice, bringing good fortune to people. The virtuous ruler will long enjoy this blessed fortune, and from the wise down to the foolish, none will not vie to participate."

As those who practice grow daily more numerous, in time, both great and small will all be transformed. When every person can do this, then select and gather those with the greatest merit among them. Those with great merit shall be appointed to office, while those with lesser merit shall be rewarded. Thus, none under heaven will not desire to do this. Yet one may fear their numbers will be too vast to record—how could one worry there are too few?

O Perfected One, how profoundly foolish, benighted, and deluded you are! Those who make grand pronouncements without practical application are of no benefit to others. Simply follow the model, and those who consistently succeed are the ones who grasp the intent of the Dao and are greatly trusted. Those who know but a few words yet achieve no great results have not grasped the intent of the Dao and speak falsely—they are great flatterers, unfit for use, and only bring disorder to the Way. Do you understand, Perfected One?

"Yes, yes."

Go now, and be cautious and vigilant. Recite and study my writings, pondering their overarching meaning, grouping like with like, and using each to verify and complement the other. Then you will attain great understanding and know the direction in which my Dao points.

"Yes, yes."

The One Hundred and Eleventh Formula of the Five Spirits

"May I humbly inquire of a great formula: Why does the spirit of the East hold a spear?"

"Ah, there is no need to ask—Perfected One, you must already know this."

"The reason I ask is that the Heavenly Master might graciously pity later generations and establish a method. Without asking, future ages would not understand the intent and formula of the Heavenly Dao."

"Very well. This is the image of Heaven, for all things follow their kind.

The East is where things first sprout, their heads breaking through the soil, all growth sharp and piercing. Its essence resembles a spear, hence the spear. When the spirit-officials of the East arrive, they take this as their token.

The South is where the myriad things extend their branches and spread their leaves like halberds, so its essence holds a halberd. When the spirit-officials of the South arrive, they take this as their token.

The West is represented by the bow, crossbow, and axe. The West is the image of Heaven’s crossbow of killing. The bow, crossbow, and axe are the greatest instruments of harm. Thus, when its spirits arrive, they take these as their tokens.

The North is represented by the shield and sword. The North is where things hide and flee. The shield is for self-preservation, while the sword is wielded by petty men, often used to evade and harm others—it is not the possession of noble gentlemen. Thus, when its spirits arrive, they too take these as their tokens.

The Center is thunder, the drum, and the sword. The Center is Earth, the ruler of the Five Phases. The drum is the chief of the five weapons, and the sword is also borne by virtuous gentlemen—it too is the chief of the five weapons. Thus, when the spirits of the Center arrive, they take these as their tokens.

These are the true and natural credentials of Heaven and Earth. Just as a person must have a head, so too must they hold their proper token. Only with these genuine credentials may one respond to the spirits. Without them, one does not act as a true spirit. If one responds to other spirits falsely, all becomes disordered governance. Over time, such chaos is difficult to pacify, which is why all seek the true credentials.

Do you understand, Perfected One?"

"Yes, yes."

---

"This teaching appears shallow yet runs deep. Even those deemed unworthy of the Way nonetheless align with the qi of Heaven and Earth, the four seasons, and the Five Phases, resonating in harmony."

"Excellent! Excellent indeed!"

"Proceed, Perfected One—you have grasped it."

**Right: Methods to Suppress the Wicked and Transform All into the Dao to Save Lives**

**Comprehensive Collated Text of the *Classic of Great Peace*, Scrolls 73–85 (Wu Section, 5–17)**

**[Missing Title]**
To guard virtue, accumulate goodness, and thoroughly harmonize with the qi of Heaven and Earth, ghosts and spirits, the people, crawling creatures, the myriad things, and the qi of the four seasons and Five Phases—ever in accord, none fail to recognize their goodness.

**[Missing Title]**
**First: Great Compassion and Filial Piety**
Compassion and filial piety arise from inner reflection, concealed yet flourishing, attained without study—this is the art of spontaneity. Conduct aligns with the heart of Heaven; intent merges with Earth. Above, it benefits the sovereign; below, it leads the people to prosperity, fostering harmonious qi and serving as the foremost model for all. Its practice is as vivid as cinnabar and ink, hence its primacy.

**Second: Illuminating Virtue and Great Gentleness**
To clarify the Dao and virtue, to lead the hundred clans, to study and love the Way, to amass goodness and virtue, to prevent theft and banditry—this most truly benefits the sovereign’s transformation. Most auspicious indeed!

**Third: Filial Piety and Fraternal Love as the Beginning of Learning Goodness**
Those who begin learning to do good harbor hope in their hearts, turning from depravity toward rectitude. Though their benevolent conduct has yet to transform others, they are on the path.

**Fourth: The Diligent Farmer’s Son**
The diligent son of the farming household rises at dawn and rests at dusk, sparing no toil. Day by day, he accumulates, fostering harmony at home to nourish his parents. He gains the earth’s bounty, follows Heaven’s Way, dares not transgress, and benefits the local authorities.

**Fifth: The Greatly Unbenevolent Son and the Righteousness-Lacking Youth Who Love Weapons and Gather Villains**
The unrighteous, the unbenevolent son—devoid of principle, they curse Heaven and strike Earth, neglect their parents, and wield weapons in all their deeds. They terrorize their villages, reckless youths who harm Heaven and Earth’s transformation, becoming grave threats. They must be captured through concerted effort, discarded into ditches, and denied burial.

**Sixth: The Household Lacking Harmony, Deceiving the Elderly and Favoring the Young, Sharing Meals but Hoarding Wealth**
A household bound for ruin—its kin at odds, unable to instruct one another, spreading reckless rumors, shirking and evading, turning from roots to frivolities. Such calamity admits no remedy.

**Seventh: Repenting Wrongs and Abandoning Weapons**
Born in destitution, seldom witnessing or hearing of goodness, ignorant of right and wrong, their conduct offends Heaven. Yet by the grace of a wise ruler, they are guided toward goodness. Unlearned in youth, they repent in maturity. Let the virtuous and worthy, with pillars five feet high, swiftly expel them from the ranks. Scholars must examine this: one day, all the people may become good.

**Eighth: Repenting Wrongs and Returning to Goodness**
Failing in their studies, calamity and chaos arise. Yet by the grace of a wise ruler, their circumstances are understood. Commanded to repent, they reverse course and become teachers of others.

**Ninth: The Greatly Wicked, Deceitful, and Greedy Who Corrupt Transformation**
Those who devour emoluments, wicked and rapacious, deceiving superiors and harming inferiors—great flatterers, thieves in official guise, human in form but beastly in nature. They benefit neither Heaven nor Earth, yin nor yang. Their deep disasters warrant execution and annihilation.

**Tenth: Correcting Wrongs, Restoring Rectitude, and Repenting Deeds**
To repent wrongs, reform conduct, and renew the heart—though goodness was absent in youth and disasters frequently arose, morning’s errors are amended by evening. Such a one is called a good person.

These ten ranks are the methods of ancient sages and worthies, delighting in others’ goodness and preventing mutual harm. They ensure each completes their Heaven-appointed years, returns to the Dao, severs the roots of corruption, and beholds the qi of Great Peace.

**[Missing Title]**

The divine all operate through rectitude, their root being the Supreme Correlation. The Supreme Correlation is bound to the emperor, through whom the celestial movements are rectified. Next, its root is bound to the empress, through whom the terrestrial principles are harmonized. The middle root is bound to the multitude of sages, through whom yin and yang are ordered. The subtle and minor roots are bound to the common people, through whom the myriad things are governed. The great person who acts accordingly attains greatness; the middling person, middling results; the petty person, small gains—yet all may achieve rectitude.

When the emperor practices virtue and power, the sun shines with great brilliance; with little virtue, little brilliance. When the empress practices virtue and power, the moon radiates great light; with little virtue, little light. When the multitude of worthies practice virtue and power, the stars and celestial cycles blaze with great splendor; with little virtue, little splendor. When all four roots practice virtue and power together, the world is at peace, auspicious signs emerge, and great light extends afar. Gazing from afar at the celestial signs, wind and rain arrive in due season, the barbarians submit in sincerity, and disasters naturally dissipate.

Now, having received the Celestial Master’s writings on the Dao and virtue, they are entrusted to the reverent people, that the reverent may return to the Way. Above, there is a sovereign of great benevolence and virtue, who can govern the world in peace and secure the body for long tranquility. The emperor is the first noble son of the August Heaven above; the empress is the first noble daughter of the Earth below. These most divine and sagely noble persons, whose office should reside within the hundredfold ranks, instead bear the cares of the world beyond ten thousand *li*, receiving the celestial mandate to uphold the unity of yin and yang, the six directions, and the eight quarters. In the exalted positions of Heaven and Earth, they are entrusted by the divine spirits, and all beings—from the highest to the crawling creatures—submit in sincerity.

Thus, they compose the *Wushang Lingbao Petition*, able to comprehend the will of Heaven and illuminate the officers of the celestial cycles, known as the Grand Scribe. Their duties brook no evasion: day and night, they alternately observe and report the waxing and waning of celestial *qi*, the gains and losses of the Three Luminaries, delighting in receiving Heaven’s admonitions to secure their own peace. In the eleventh month, they cultivate the Yellow Bell, guiding the *qi* from below the earth to ascend and communicate, delighting in harmonizing with the intent of the Earth Queen to secure their own peace.

They construct the Hall of Light in the *bingwu* position of Great Yang, opening eight windows to allow passage in four directions, delighting in the circulation of the *qi* of the eight directions and four seasons, seeking to align with the auspicious *qi* of the eight winds and four seasons to secure their own peace. They open the four gates, delighting in receiving the world’s rare texts, extraordinary strategies, seldom-seen treasures, worthy and enlightened arts, and unusual techniques that can secure the world’s long peace and dispel calamities and anomalies.

In ancient times, when sages held office, they constantly sought reclusive worthies of gentle virtue to share in governance. It is desired to hear of the four seasons’ honored positions, yet the kingly *qi* is the chief of the insubstantial *qi*, to which all other *qi* are bound, the lord of all honored sovereigns. The kingly *qi* is Heaven, the August One, the Emperor, the King, the Grand Year, the Monthly Establishment, the Dipper’s Ridge, the Azure Dragon, Great Virtue, Prosperous Flourishing, the Emperor-King, the Supreme King, the Lord of Generation and Completion.

Thus, wherever the kingly *qi* resides, the myriad things submit to its rule; where it dwells, all things thrive and grow; where it turns away, all perish—this is the work of the primordial *qi*. Therefore, when the kingly *qi* resides in yang, yang prevails; when in yin, yin prevails; when in Heaven, Heaven rules; when on Earth, Earth rules. Wherever it resides, that place is governed and receives the mandate to order. Thus, the ancient sage-kings faced east in spring, south in summer, west in autumn, north in winter, and the center in the sixth month, completing the cycle of *qi* to present themselves before Heaven—then the kingly *qi* is honored above all.

When the Monthly Establishment is named "Great Expenditure and Ruin," and the kingly *qi* is opposed, it is called "Death and Annihilation." The primordial *qi* establishes the position, and the kingly *qi* is the first of all *qi*, majestic and not to be rashly confronted. The position after the Monthly Establishment is called "Closure," for Heaven seals what follows, lest the retiring yin *qi* advance deceitfully to disrupt the kingly *qi* of the Monthly Establishment—thus, it is closed off. "Opening" is Heaven’s principle, which delights not in harm or injury. Thus, to open what follows is to instruct the retiring *qi*, for those who act deceitfully delight in being allowed to retreat. If they do not retreat, they will be seized; upon seizure, they are interrogated and found guilty, and their guilt cannot be absolved, leading to perilous death. Thus, the fifth position after is "Peril," which approaches death. The sixth position after is "Destruction," where the Dipper’s destruction brings death—thus, the Chief of the Dipper presides over death, leading to peril.

Therefore, the kingly *qi* arises from Lesser Yang, and Greater Yang constantly guards the Dipper’s Establishment. The *qi* of death arises from Lesser Yin, and Greater Yin constantly guards the Dipper’s Chief. Thus, the sixth position after is where Heaven regularly retires and empties, aligning with Earth’s *qi*, presiding over closure and concealment. There, treacherous rebels and evil spirits dwell together, and it must not be rashly opened. The ancients, who cherished life, placed all *qi* before the Dipper, aligning with the celestial movements—thus, the day is auspicious and possesses *qi*. All who act deceitfully, treacherously, as yin thieves, or with evil and perversity resemble yin *qi* and belong to the Dipper’s rear—thus, the day is in decline, and their actions are inauspicious.

The primordial *qi* is indistinct and nebulous, naturally coalescing into one, called Heaven. Dividing to generate yin, it forms Earth, called the second. Thus, above is Heaven and below is Earth; yin and yang unite to generate humanity, called the third. The Three Powers together generate and nurture all things, called wealth. Wealth generates desire; desire generates perversity; perversity generates deceit; deceit generates treachery; treachery generates harm. If harm is unchecked, disorder and ruin follow; if ruin is unchecked, it cannot be governed again, and thus returns to its root in exhaustion—this is called "inherited burden."

The Dao of Heaven is without intent: when it encounters the unworthy, disorder arises; when it obtains the worthy and enlightened, order is restored. In ancient times, when emperors obtained worthy and enlightened ministers, the Dao flourished. They dared not employ the foolish and unworthy as close advisors. Swiftly transmit this text to a sovereign of superior virtue to practice it. The penetratingly enlightened shine brightly. When the Three Powers mutually manifest and inquire, their divination is ten for ten, and all they govern is well-ordered—this is the foremost clarity, fit to serve as the emperor’s agent.

Those whose divination is nine in ten—with one qi in disorder and ungoverned—may serve as agents for the feudal lords. Those whose divination is eight in ten—with two qi in disorder and ungoverned—may serve as agents for common people. Beyond this, it is called "disordering Heaven’s correct Dao," and grievances must accumulate. Ghosts and spirits conceal themselves and flee, becoming unseen; it cannot be governed, nor can the qi of Great Peace be harmonized.

If you seek the Dao, ponder the written texts. The method of seeking the Dao takes stillness as its root. As the root, accumulating essence without cease is the gateway to spirit. When the Five Virtues harmonize and unite, the hun and po become visible; the heart-spirit is already luminous, and the Great Dao unfolds. First, know safety and peril, observe the four neighbors, and the host of spirits will gather like clouds. If this is unceasing, you shall be a long-lived lord.

Ah! The Great Dao does not require toil. Let the form be like dead ashes, guarding the hun-spirit. If the hun-spirit does not depart, you shall long endure. The cyclic returns to its beginning, an endless loop. To abandon the root and seek the branches brings affliction to the Dao. The multitude, having lost it, cannot be whole. Ponder its meaning, do not lose the true words. Stillness is the root, not the expenditure of wealth. Can you not deeply cherish the words of the enlightened teacher? Follow the teacher’s instructions, and you shall not die.

The foolish, opposing the teacher, dwell near ghosts. They do not attain the correct Dao but enter the gate of misfortune, never to return to spirit. Their bones and flesh rot in the earth, called ancestors, their lives already extinguished in great exhaustion.

**Untitled Section**
The arts of the common and foolish all emerge from within. They possess their own laws, with profundity as their root. When they perceive spirit, they live, free from suffering and sorrow. Spirit detests strenuous exertion; calm the heart and settle the mind. Beware of sudden violence. With prolonged stillness, the myriad Dao all emerge. Long abiding without death, you shall unite with Heaven. In practice, harmony is essential, becoming one with the Dao. The worthy hold fast without wavering, and all matters are complete. Worldly thoughts are cast aside, and you commune with spirit. Riding clouds and driving dragons, you share a chamber with the Thunder Duke. The body transforms into spirit, its form like the Great One.

Ponder deeply the words of this text; be careful not to lose proper measure.

**The Dao of Profound Reflection**
The Dao of profound reflection is perfected in seclusion. Do not seek honor or rank; let your resolve grow daily more refined. Open the obscured to reveal clarity, like the brightness of day. When not learning, it is as if gazing into blackest lacquer—east, west, south, north—lost within your chamber. The worthy and sagely are alarmed, the heart alone trembles in fear.

If the Five Guardians are strong, you shall not die. Content with poverty and delighting in lowliness, you may endure long. To scorn lowliness and seek nobility obstructs the Dao. Covet no exalted office or heavy emolument. To forcibly seek official rank is to lose the Dao—better to lie abed in long repose. Without eating, you become luminous; the hundred evils all depart, and calamity is far removed. Guard stillness without cease, and you shall not perish. Fortunate is the one who may live long and endure, never daring to indulge the will and lose constancy.

Seek without cease, and you shall be a king of the Dao. The arts of governance and life differ in method; they do not obstruct the people’s distinct affairs. When superiors cherish life, the people’s lives are long. The worldly teachings place the Dao above, and there are benevolent kings. The sagely ruler ponders the Dao, and its transformative influence flows downward, making the people pure and incorrupt. Forever free from calamity, the people do not die—this is the clarity of the superior.

When the superior lacks a luminous ruler, teachings do not spread. Unwilling to practice the Dao, they instead favor warfare. Every household has a wicked son, and families perish. Wielding weapons, they waylay travelers by the roadside, waiting for an opening to seize their belongings. The magistrates are not at peace, and bandits roam. Observe the people, and the superior may be known as luminous. When the ruler cherishes benevolence, the people below seek long life.

When the superior is not benevolent, the people below incline toward wickedness, all meeting early deaths, knowing no joy in life. When the people below cherish virtue, it is the teaching of the superior. When the people love the Dao, their lord is luminous. To desire long life wholly is to distance calamity. To not eat yet remain incorrupt is to cast aside all weapons. To sit in tranquil nonaction is to discard misfortune. When the sagely ruler greatly flourishes, the people cherish one another. When kindness extends even to the foolish below, this is the true king. The Dao of Heaven cherishes life to secure the superior. When the foolish below do not contend for the superior’s blessings, the world is most fortunate, and all turn toward the king.

When the people do not love the Dao, it is because the superior is not luminous. Harboring treacherous hearts, they feign upright conduct. Not cherishing virtue, they instead favor warfare. Fathers and sons are separated, dwelling by the roadside. They do not attain long life, accumulating only death and loss. Households have impoverished sons, like tigers and wolves. When the superior lacks virtue, it brings the calamity of war. When the foolish rule below, transformative influence does not spread. When the people greatly love immortality, the emperor is luminous. Heaven sees their governance, and kindness flows downward. Creeping things and panting creatures all bask in its light.

**Untitled Section**
Heaven cherishes the Dao of life, thus it is the Heavenly Canon. Those who accumulate virtue become the Earthly Canon. Earth cherishes nurturance, thus it is the Earthly Canon. Those who accumulate harmony and cherish giving become the Human Canon. Harmonious qi mutually communicate and interact. People possess wealth and interact, giving and receiving—thus harmony is the Human Canon.

In ancient times, those who would study and inquire all rectified their roots. It is like planting a tree: seek a good seed and place it in good soil, and its growth—root, trunk, branches, and leaves—shall all be good. The root is the original teacher; the branches and fruit are the disciples. Thus, in ancient learning, all first pondered and reflected upon the root before studying the Dao. Therefore, those who can practice this align with Heaven’s heart, and thus it is auspicious.

If one plants a tree without selecting a good one and places it in poor soil, how can its branches, leaves, flowers, and fruit be beautiful? This is like first aligning the body, rectifying the nature and the Dao of the mind, ultimately returning to primordial qi to settle the body. Reflect upon the ancient methods, the duties practiced by former teachers—how can one govern oneself? Plan and settle the mind to the utmost, and you shall attain it yourself.

First, settle the form, then begin practice, like an infant at play, not employing sinew or strength, but only good intention. Ponder deeply how the ancients alone attained longevity, how their governance relied solely on intention—how did they achieve this? Only through the utmost Dao, restraining wickedness and eliminating treachery. It is like a spirit, without strange anomalies. When the root is rectified, this is how it is practiced. Thus, one aligns with Heaven’s heart, does not betray Earth’s intention, completes the four seasons, harmonizes the Five Phases, and descendants do not inherit burdens. Each cherishes the utmost virtue, no longer knowing wickedness or evil.

The Perfected One of [Preserving] Authenticity asked: "What is the Heavenly Canon? What is the Earthly Canon? What is the Human Canon? What is the Dao Canon? What is the Sagely Canon? What is the Worthy Canon? What is the Auspicious Canon? What is the Inauspicious Canon? What is the Canon of Life? What is the Canon of Death?"

The Divine Person replied: "Cultivating and accumulating the true Dao—this is the Heavenly Canon. Heaven cherishes life, and the Dao likewise cherishes life; thus it is the Heavenly Canon. Cultivating and accumulating virtue—this is the Earthly Canon. Earth cherishes nurturance, and virtue likewise cherishes nurturance; thus it is the Earthly Canon. Cultivating harmony and delighting in bestowal—this is the Human Canon. Harmonious qi flows and intermingles; when people possess wealth, it too should circulate and intermingle; thus harmony is the Human Canon.

"Accumulating the teachings of the Dao from the High, Middle, and Lower Antiquities—this is the Dao Canon. Accumulating the sagely writings of the High, Middle, and Lower Antiquities—this is the Sagely Canon. Accumulating the worthy discourses of the High, Middle, and Lower Antiquities—this is the Worthy Canon. That which follows an auspicious teacher is the Auspicious Canon; that which follows an inauspicious teacher is the Inauspicious Canon; that which follows a teacher of life is the Canon of Life; that which follows a teacher of death is the Canon of Death.

"The dharma is made manifest by sages; the Dao is entrusted to humans for its flourishing." *Essentials of Cultivation: Excerpts from Precepts and Rituals, Scroll One*

**Untitled**

To enter a chamber and dwell alone, contemplating the roots of the scriptures and the Dao—what one requires in going out and coming in—is first grasped in meaning by the worthy, and those who follow after will likewise enter the Dao, far removed from the perverse.

Entering the chamber to meditate and preserve, the five officials shift and transform, aligning with the yin and yang of the three months as brothers, moving in accord with qi, and following the changes of the four seasons and five phases as the constant Way of Heaven. To lose qi is to die; to possess qi is to live. The myriad things follow this, and the human Dao stands supreme.

Thus the five officials are established, rising with qi, and the Way of Heaven soars as the supreme qi. The Perfected accumulate qi and gather spirit and illumination, so the Dao ultimately travels alone, while the common people, losing qi, perish.

The dead are base; the living are noble. The child who guards the Dao may endure long; to follow qi is to transform. Heaven is constant, free from haste for fame or profit—the Dao moves of itself.

The Way of Heaven constantly gives life without loss; the Way of Earth sustains both yet presides over death. The sages and worthies of high antiquity served in office; the middling scholars retired to the mountains; the lesser scholars, like insects, died among the people.

The worthy, upon seeing these words, ponder them deeply. First difficult, then easy, they bring no harm to the body. Guarding virtue, they complete the great Dao, and through study, having passed through the nine chambers, become spirit-people. Their thoughts are ever distinct from those of ordinary folk, never from dawn to dusk contemplating earthly matters, but desiring to hear the affairs of Heaven. Only when their minds dwell on the duties of Heaven may they descend through the nine chambers.

Accumulating essence with utmost sincerity, they transform of themselves, altering their form and appearance, becoming the sages of Heaven above, no longer able to attend to the affairs of the world below—this is clear.

My writings enable the lofty scholar to live on unseen, while the lesser scholar dares not act or speak recklessly. My writings serve the Dao, exhausting human aspirations, enabling the worthy and unworthy alike to fulfill their talents, so that even at death there is no regret—each has fulfilled their Heavenly mandate.

Those who desire long life and lasting joy should ponder the true meaning of the Dao and proceed; those who do not desire lasting life should attend to worldly affairs, content merely to preserve themselves.

**Untitled**

To examine one’s conduct is to mirror the body, knowing for oneself the methods of gain and loss. The wise and enlightened encompass Heaven and Earth, accumulating boundless writings, yet cannot extend their own lives—this is called emptiness, devoid of true Dao.

The masters of arts and techniques, though long in study, ultimately confine themselves. They may master the patterns of Heaven and Earth, fully comprehend the nature of the myriad things, and amass all manner of texts, yet if they cannot serve their parents or honor their lord, such knowledge is of no benefit.

Pondering these words, good and ill fortune become clear. Practicing this in simplicity enables one to know gain and loss for oneself.

**Untitled**

What in learning is most urgent? Thus I set forth two matters, clearly distinguishing the signs of a scholar’s loss and gain.

Since the beginning of creation, there have been two urgent concerns; the rest may be known or unknown as one wishes. What Heaven and Earth and the sagely and enlightened attend to—what must be practiced to achieve great gain—are longevity and filial piety.

Longevity shares Heaven and Earth’s concern; filial piety shares their power. Thus longevity is long life, aligning with Heaven’s essence. Filial piety is to submit below and follow above, harmonizing with Earth’s voice. These two matters accord with the intent of Heaven and Earth, and misfortune naturally departs.

Pondering this deeply is the principle of Great Peace and the essence of long life. Yet few who desire goodness seek to live thus.

Parents are the root of life; the lord is the gate of honor and esteem; the teacher is the source of wisdom and the inexhaustible vocation. These three are the gateways of virtue and power.

Parents transmit the ancestral lineage of Heaven and Earth’s yin and yang; the teacher clarifies the intent of Heaven and Earth and resolves the knots of worldly affairs; the lord upholds Heaven and Earth, follows yin and yang, constantly striving to grasp their intent, and takes ordering the Dao as his duty. Thus these three are the gateways of nature and destiny.

Pondering these words deeply, all harm is dispelled. Longevity and filial piety are beloved by spirits and numina; those who lack them attract a hundred calamities. This Dao is natural, requiring no effort. To know its efficacy, observe how it follows human intentions, good or ill.

The heart’s intentions devise matters within, and echoes respond without. To know this Dao is to understand the correspondence of reflection and echo. The heart and intention are the gateways of good and ill fortune.

The rulers of Great Peace in antiquity governed by focusing their hearts and intentions on goodness, and their ministers were likewise good; if their intentions were misguided, their ministers followed suit. Heart and intention are the pivot of Heaven and Earth—do not move them recklessly, lest harmonious qi be disrupted and disasters arise daily.

*Great Peace Scripture: Collated Edition, Scroll Eighty-Six, Ji Section One*
*Great Peace Scripture, Scroll Eighty-Six*

Six Perfected Ones of the Six Directions respectfully bow again, stating: "Previously, we received the Celestial Master’s instruction to compile and submit a joint memorial under strict orders. Returning to our respective posts, we focused our thoughts and pondered its meaning for seven days and seven nights. The Six Perfected Ones convened thrice to deliberate, yet all remained perplexed.

Regarding the three revelatory discussions: we witnessed three celestial omens of streaming stars and shifting light.
First, we saw a streaming star emerge from the Gate of Heaven and enter the Portal of Earth.
Second, we saw a streaming star depart from the Great Yang and enter the Great Yin.
Third, we saw the constellations stream into the Celestial Prison.

Considering these three together, we feared that the Celestial Master’s Three Dao Missives might be severed below, preventing their ascent, thereby provoking the Celestial Wrath to deepen in fury, and the Primordial Qi of the Supreme Sovereign to fail in its descent. This would cause the virtuous rulers of emperors and kings to perpetually inherit the lingering disasters of former kings, plunging them into sorrow and hardship."

"Alas! The Six Perfected Ones have come together on behalf of the August Spirit to inquire—how diligent you are in advancing the Celestial Way! I have heard the words of many disciples, yet none surpass those of the Perfected Ones. Now, try to explain the meaning of these streaming stars yourselves."

"The six disciples, dull and benighted, dare not withhold our words. First, a streaming star emerged from the Gate of Heaven and entered the Portal of Earth. The Gate of Heaven is yang, the ruler; the Portal of Earth is yin, the subjects and ministers. Now, the conduct of subjects and ministers does not flow upward in allegiance; instead, the ruler descends to bestow favor below. The gate and portal are meant to facilitate communication—yet now, the lower portal does not ascend, while the upper gate opens downward. This signifies that the lower realm’s petitions are severed, unable to ascend."

"Excellent are the words of the Perfected One—I have nothing to add. Though the task is arduous, proceed to explain the next two omens."

"Yes, yes. The second omen: we observed the Great Yang star streaming into the midst of the Great Yin. The Great Yang is the ruler; the Great Yin, the subjects and ministers. The Great Yang is brightness; the Great Yin, darkness and obscurity. Now, darkness and obscurity ought to flow upward into the midst of great brightness—this is like subjects and ministers, benighted and ignorant, beset by hardship, who ought to ascend and attach themselves to a luminous king and sagely lord, seeking to have their grievances redressed. Yet now, the great brightness descends into the midst of darkness and obscurity. This symbolizes that imperial edicts bestowing favor, descending to the lower realm, are severed and cut off. The darkness and obscurity remain unilluminated; the governance below is in solitary chaos, obscuring and concealing what lies above. It further resembles those among the common people below, whose local officials jointly conceal the portents of Heaven and Earth, preventing them from ascending and communicating in the unseen. Together with the subjects and ministers, they deceive their superior, serving as evidence of their collusion in wrongdoing."

"Excellent, excellent! I have nothing to add to the words of the six disciples. Though the task is arduous, proceed to explain the third omen."

"Yes, yes. The third omen: we observed the constellations streaming into the Celestial Prison. The constellations are stars of goodness and rectitude, yet they stream into the prison of Heaven. The prison is where Heaven metes out punishment and judgment. I fear that the virtuous and upright, wishing to serve the Emperor and expend their efforts, submit memorials to communicate the discourse of Heaven and Earth—yet they are instead resented and despised by local officials in distant regions far from the capital. Later, these officials harm them on other pretexts, and so the constellations stream into the prison.""

"Excellent and precise! I have nothing to add to the words of the six disciples."

"Now, why is it that the six of you ask these matters with such indignation? Do you alone never grow weary or slacken?"

"We dare not. We have always heard the Celestial Master say that when perfected ones come from Heaven to inquire, if we were to cease, we fear the words of Heaven would not be conveyed. Now, the lives of all people belong to Heaven and Earth. If Heaven and Earth are displeased, they will instead bring harm to people, and we would not fulfill our allotted heavenly years of longevity."

"Excellent! The words of the perfected ones are correct and without error. Now, I shall speak to all the perfected ones—I dare not omit, slacken, or cease. I and all the perfected ones alike—our lives belong to Heaven and Earth. If we were to close off and not speak, or speak and then cease midway, Heaven and Earth would together bring harm to me. Thus, I too dare not recklessly stop in my discourse. Proceed, and I shall explain in full for the six perfected ones. Now, the six perfected ones have newly emerged from the cavern, thinking of Heaven, so that they may remove Heaven’s afflictions; thinking of virtuous rulers, so that they may resolve calamities and secure their persons. The six perfected ones must together fully express their intent, exhausting all that they wish to say, so that nothing is cut off or obstructed."

"Yes, yes. We dare not fail to exhaust even the wisdom of sparrows and mice—shall we not speak all?"

"Most gratified."

"Yes, yes."

〈Rising〉 Now, what the world fears most is the sealing of mouths, lest they dare speak recklessly. Even the sun, moon, and stars—those celestial spirits in the heavens’ ranks—stand in mutual awe. Thus, when the sun rises, the stars flee and hide, not daring to appear before its majesty. Within the four borders, where a stern emperor reigns, the world trembles in fear. Though some dwell far from the capital, they dare not speak when imperial decrees arrive. If a province has a powerful governor, the entire province dares not speak. If a commandery has a strong magistrate, the whole commandery dares not speak. If a county has a harsh magistrate, the entire county dares not speak. Even if a single ward has a stern ward chief, the whole ward dares not speak. This ward chief is but the lowest of officials—how much more so for those who serve him? All fear harm and seek only to avoid it, suppressing even good intentions, unable to convey them upward. Thus, the Dao is cut off and obstructed here.

Now, if but a single village has a strong-willed man who holds sway, the whole village dares not speak, fearing later resentment and harm. Even within a single household, if a fierce and domineering man holds power, the whole family dares not speak. 〈Rising〉 Even within a family—those bound by blood and kin, born of the same kind—such mutual aversion and fear exist. How much more so between different generations? Since the Highest Antiquity and Middle Antiquity, the Dao and virtue have been largely lost, replaced by governance through might and force. Coercion and oppression prevail; those who do not obey later suffer grave harm, wounds so deep they afflict descendants. Thus, though the people witness celestial portents and strange calamities, they dare not speak rashly, fearing those in authority near them. This silence accumulates over time, each generation bearing the burden of the last. By the Lesser Antiquity, the situation has grown even worse. If one wishes to submit a memorial to the emperor, those who control his fate kill him at once. Even if not harmed immediately, they later conspire to injure him through connections. Thus, ministers and commoners all seal their tongues and shut their mouths, living in darkness. Though they see suffering and injustice, witness evil, they dare not report it upward. Though emperors today are said to be of unmatched wisdom, celestial omens multiply daily—clear proof of this.

Now, the people are born of their parents and receive their lives from Heaven and Earth. Taking Heaven and Earth as their parents, when they see disasters or auspicious signs, it is as if Heaven and Earth are speaking, wishing to convey these words. Yet all are terrified, fearing harm from those to whom they are bound, and dare not speak or reveal the truth. They admonish one another, turning their backs on Heaven and Earth, cutting off communication, and blocking the words Heaven and Earth wish to convey. They conceal the grievances of Heaven and Earth, preventing their words from reaching above, leaving Heaven and Earth long resentful and unheard.

Though an emperor may be divine and sagely, he is but one man, surrounded by layer upon layer of others, far from the edges of his realm. Even if those within the layers wish to convey words to him, they are coerced by those near them and cannot reach him. 〈Ceasing〉 Though an emperor may possess the benevolence and wisdom of ten thousand men, each person is constrained by fear. Heaven and Earth, the most sacred of all, are merely gazed upon from afar or observed nearby, yet even they can only resolve matters before them. How can an emperor be more divine and sagely than Heaven and Earth?

We six fools once encountered a fierce tiger in a distant wilderness. All six of us froze, not daring to move our feet, speak, turn our heads, or even blink our eyes. Such is the fear and coercion that constrain people.

"Excellent, excellent! Now, hearing the six perfected ones speak, I understand that Heaven alone has long suffered grievous injustice, its words unable to reach above. Though it creates myriad strange signs as messages, these are blocked below and cannot ascend, leaving it long pent-up and resentful. Thus, I exhort the perfected ones, instructing them earnestly in the matter of this scripture. Therefore, the perfected ones are vigilant and diligent—this is Heaven’s will."

"Yes, yes."

"I fear Heaven’s majesty and shall now ponder the essential meaning for you. What is the most pressing matter the six perfected ones ask about?"

"We six fools have pondered this scripture for seven days and nights, convening three times to discuss it. Thrice we saw meteors, taking them as Heaven’s admonition and instruction, urging us to inquire. We six all ingest qi, yet it does not descend smoothly, rising instead in rebellion. At that time, our ears and eyes grew dizzy and dim, and we were all astonished, deliberating together. We knew not what great terror this was—only the Heavenly Master can explain it to us."

"Excellent! The ancient changes have revealed their full meaning to the perfected ones. From your words, I now understand: the three scriptures of the Dao will again face obstruction and severance—why is this?"

"I wish to hear the decisive meaning."

"Very well. The nine orifices correspond to the divisions of the nine provinces. Now, the perfected ones say that when they ingest qi, it does not flow smoothly, and their vision grows dim without light. This is because the nine provinces, great and small, oppress one another, preventing urgent words from reaching above. Qi is that by which the lives of Heaven, Earth, and the myriad things are connected. Heaven and Earth use qi and wind to transform the lives of the myriad things. That qi does not flow smoothly is clear proof that the Dao of Heaven is obstructed and cannot reach through. Heaven wishes the perfected ones to attend earnestly to this matter, thus stirring and moving them with qi. Do you understand?"

"Yes, yes."

"Excellent, you have understood."

"Understood."

"Heaven has instructed the Six Perfected Ones to teach me to speak fully of this! Let the Six of you sit at ease, and I shall explain the Way to all your disciples. For those who fear the officials of their prefectures and dare not speak: let all the good and wise scholars within a prefecture gather together and jointly deliberate, then submit their case to another prefecture. If they fear their commandery, let them deliberate and submit to another commandery. If they fear their county, let them deliberate and submit to another county. If they fear their township, let them deliberate and submit to another township. If they fear their village, let them deliberate and submit to another village. All shall be accommodated in their respective locales. Those who prohibit or intimidate others from doing so shall be punished according to the severity of the transgressions and omens they suppress, with an additional degree added to their original offense."

"Why is the penalty so severe?"

"It should not be considered severe—one might even fear it is too lenient. Now, Heaven and Earth cherish virtuous emperors and wish to fully inform them. Yet men, born of Heaven and Earth, turn their backs on Heaven and Earth, severing the celestial discourse, causing Heaven to fall ill. This accumulated obstruction remains unresolved, their grievances unexpressed, their words unanswered—this is a grave act of rebellion, a most grievous offense. As for the people and ministers, they are the envoys and limbs of the emperor. They ought to clarify the sovereign’s understanding, ensuring that those above may rest without worry, aligning with the will of Heaven. When Heaven rejoices, the sovereign’s years are prolonged. Yet now, those below act disloyally, turning their backs on Heaven and Earth, blocking the emperor’s wisdom, causing him distress and self-reproach for governance gone awry. Disasters and omens multiply, peril and unease abound—all this amounts to great disloyalty, unfiliality, and treachery, crimes that by law should not be pardoned. How can such penalties be deemed excessive?

When the celestial discourse is obstructed, Heaven and Earth grow enraged, harming all living things, as though seeking to destroy Heaven and Earth—such is a year of utmost calamity. A state deprived of wisdom is a state in grave peril. This crime defies description; thus, it is deemed a capital offense."

"Perfected Ones, do you understand?"

"Yes, yes."

"Excellent, you have understood. The reason I dare not... is that seeing the Six of you come to inquire, I recognize you as Heaven’s envoys. How could the Perfected Ones dare not...? Do you understand?"

"Yes."

"Yes, yes."

"Now, the reason for not [concealing] such names is to avoid misleading the sovereign. When the virtuous ruler sees the documents, he commands that those who submit memorials—especially those with great [merit]—be rewarded with virtue and gifts. In this way, none under Heaven will fail to rejoice, delighting in exhausting their strength to jointly submit memorials and present matters. No longer will there be only a solitary voice speaking; all must gather to deliberate. If a single person speaks, it may be false, flattering, or deceptive, leading the sovereign to lose grasp of reality. Such grave errors must not be heeded.

In recent years, those who have submitted memorials have repeatedly proven trustworthy, including those with great merit. Yet the number of superior gentlemen who gather remains lamentably few—only two or three assembling. Why is this so? Precisely because when few gather, deceit and falsehood abound. How could there be no deceit?

"I wish to hear more."

"Indeed, when many gather, those submitting memorials naturally restrain one another, fearing leaks, exposure of strengths and weaknesses, or being turned into tools of deception against the sovereign.
