Only when matters are thoroughly verified [and confirmed] do they dare speak; without [verification], they dare not. Moreover, they dare not conceal anything, ever wary of future consequences. Thus, all is trustworthy.

Consider a village of a hundred households colluding in deceit: among men, women, children, and elders, there will always be someone who leaks the truth, and neighboring villages will come to know of it. The wise and cautious in that village will not dare conceal it, fearing implication in the affair. How much less so for a prefecture, commandery, county, township, or post station? If a commandery harbors extraordinary matters, how could they remain hidden? They will inevitably be exposed by others, and thus all good and evil will come to light. Heaven will rejoice greatly, disasters will vanish, and the flow will be as unimpeded as running water. Do you understand?"

"Yes, yes."

Moreover, when great assemblies deliberate, none dare deceive, for if one or two attempt deceit, the others will not follow. Should anyone seek to deceive or act in bad faith, the multitude will immediately record and report it. Such is the law for those who betray Heaven and Earth, deceive the sovereign, or commit great treason and impiety. Heaven resents them, and people despise them; their crimes admit no pardon. Do you, Perfected One, understand?"

"Yes, yes."

"Good. You have now awakened. Having submitted your memorial, return home, but beware of those who resent your actions. Should anyone submit a memorial seeking to harm you, their name will be inscribed on the left as a 'Memorial of Resentment,' and their offenses will not be absolved. Thus, the three channels for memorials will remain open, and none will dare obstruct them. In this way, Heaven and Earth will be pleased, the disasters of karmic inheritance borne by the sovereign will be largely dispelled, and the world will attain Great Peace. The primordial qi of the Highest August will fully descend, aiding the virtuous ruler in governance, and... will not fail the Six Perfected Ones."

"Yes, yes."

"Good. The essence of the Six Perfected Ones has greatly advanced, removing illness from Heaven and dispelling calamities for the sovereign. Their merit is already manifest in Heaven, and the king’s rule grows daily stronger and clearer. The Six Perfected Ones have fulfilled their measure of goodness; they should strive diligently and be ever cautious!"

"Yes, yes. I humbly ask one great secret: may the Celestial Master reveal whether the memorials’ circulation fully harmonizes with the divine spirits? May I hear of this?"

"Indeed, there are great proofs—Heaven’s Dao does not deceive."

"Each seeks its kind, and the virtuous ruler should frequently dispatch trusted officials to inquire among the people: how many suffer from ulcers, pestilence, or scabies? If the memorials’ circulation has not fully harmonized with the divine spirits, there will be an excess of worms devouring people—worms that feed on humans are themselves the cure for humans. Indeed, those below who lack virtue and power among the subjects are like worms, turning to feed upon the people. This is the effect of worms governing humans. Where there are no ulcers, pestilence, or scabies, it is because all in office are good people, and no worms remain. In this, not one in ten thousand will fail."

"Excellent! Excellent! Is this the only proof? Are there others?"

"All calamities and anomalies under Heaven arise in response to governance, each with its own cause. Simply reflect deeply on the matter, and you will understand—why single out ulcers, pestilence, or scabies? Other disasters are merely seen in the myriad things, but worms turning to devour humans is the most severe, so I use it as proof."

"Excellent! Excellent! Had I not earnestly questioned the Celestial Master, there would be no way to know this."

"Now that the Perfected Ones have spoken, I already understand—this was merely a show of humility."

"Far from it, far from it. We six foolish students, having received the Celestial Master’s solemn instruction, shall each return to our residences and dwell in quietude, pondering only the essential meaning. Yet the Celestial Master’s writings demand that all, from the great to the small, down to servants and slaves, gather to deliberate and jointly memorialize the Dao regarding calamities, anomalies, good, and evil—is this not overly burdensome?"

The other student wished to hear his intent.

"Excellent! You six were chosen to inquire of Heaven’s affairs—how carefully you must attend to the words of the Perfected Ones! The reason for including even commoners, servants, and slaves is this: within the present bounds of Heaven’s domain, conditions vary across ten thousand *li*; at five thousand *li*, they differ slightly. Across a thousand *li*, winds and *qi* shift; at five hundred *li*, they vary again in small measure. Within a hundred *li*, yin and rain diverge; at fifty *li*, the difference is subtle. Even within a single county, transformations, calamities, strange omens, good, and evil are not uniform.

Now, when the August Heaven manifests calamities, anomalies, or transformations, they do not always appear in the imperial palace, the halls of local officials, or before high ministers. Rather, such signs are often first seen in the wilderness and among the common folk, where the lowly and base perceive them earliest. Yet each conceals them for fear of their superiors, and officials, in turn, conceal them for fear of their lords, collectively severing the discourse between Heaven and Earth. Each seeks to flatter their superiors, desiring their names to be praised and their achievements swiftly promoted, and so they collude in wrongdoing, suppressing Heaven and Earth’s calamities, anomalies, and strange omens, blocking them from reaching the emperor’s ears. Thus, the emperor, cut off without cause, deprived of wisdom, fails to grasp the intent of Heaven and Earth. His governance grows perilous and chaotic, difficult to stabilize, and he is left with sorrow and hardship.

The emperor is born by the mandate of Heaven, with Heaven as his father and Earth as his mother. As the Son of Heaven, when the people and ministers together act without the Dao, severing the discourse of his parents and preventing it from reaching their child, is there any greater crime? To jointly obstruct the discourse of Heaven and Earth, to deceive one’s superior, to be unfaithful and untrustworthy as a minister to the people—how could such offenses be named lightly? Do you now perceive this?"

"Yes, yes."

Moreover, all people, ministers, servants, and slaves are born of Heaven, nurtured by Earth, and governed and sustained by the emperor. These three matters constitute their very lives—without them, there would be no means to be born, to grow, or to nourish and order themselves. Yet they all conspire to deceive their superior, collectively ignorant of Heaven and Earth, leaving the emperor bereft of wisdom and cut off. Their crimes warrant ten thousand deaths, and even then, their guilt would not be exhausted—how grave is this?

"Perfected One, why do you remain so dull and uncomprehending? People are born of Heaven and nurtured by Earth. When Heaven and Earth suffer distress and illness, they manifest strange omens to inform their child, desiring to see order restored. Yet the foolish people jointly sever the discourse of Heaven, incurring the great wrath of Heaven and Earth. The emperor is the father and mother of the people and ministers, yet they conspire to deceive their parents, causing them constant sorrow and hardship, unable to bring peace to their governance. Is there any greater fault?

Since the opening of Heaven and Earth, the accumulated calamities of inherited burdens have amassed, all arising from this. Thus, the people are permitted to submit memorials. Now, the Radiant and Virtuous Lord governs, and Heaven, grieved by these hardships, has sent me to speak."

"Excellent! Excellent indeed!"

"Come, let me explain this to you, Perfected One. Today, a solar eclipse occurs—the greatest of all celestial omens—yet some witness it while others do not. The myriad strange omens and calamities of the world are all the transformative discourse of Heaven and Earth, the interplay of yin and yang. Some nations do not see them, but their provinces do; some provinces do not, but their commanderies do; some commanderies do not, but their counties do; some counties do not, but their townships do; some townships do not, but the common people do; some in one village do not, but those in another do.

Thus, in the governance of the ancient worthies and sages, even the lowliest were glad to receive unusual reports, aligning with the intent of Heaven and Earth to secure their well-being. Therefore, their rule alone remained perpetually peaceful, in perfect accord with Heaven. Now, as the qi of Great Peace arrives, if even one matter is amiss, disharmony arises, and the upright qi of Heaven fails to descend. It is like foolish people draining the water to catch fish—then the dragons vanish. This is what it means.

For this reason, all in the realm are now permitted to speak. Thus, not a single thread of Heaven’s intent is lost, and governance may be stabilized. The people, of their own accord, gather and submit memorials. Local officials, fearing they may lag behind the people’s words, must swiftly dispatch officers to inquire about what the people have witnessed and promptly report it upward. In this way, no omen or calamity will be overlooked.

Thus, the August Heaven and Revered Earth will rejoice greatly and cherish their emperor."

"How is this made clear?"

"There is proof. The sun and moon serve as its great illumination: the constellations maintain their courses, neither erring nor straying—this is the sign of Heaven’s joy. When Earth rejoices, the hundred rivers flow in order, not recklessly overflowing, and all things are nurtured, growing well and flourishing—this is the sign of Earth’s delight. Do you understand, Perfected One?"

"Yes, yes."

"Master, in your kindness, take pity on this foolish student. Those who have grasped these matters may come forward with questions. Since I have been treated with such generosity, I may now ask all my doubts. How should the people record omens, calamities, and strange phenomena?"

"Indeed! A fine question you ask. When such events are observed, record them at once, whether at dawn or dusk. At the month’s end, gather and deliberate together. What is fit to report, report upward; what is not yet sufficient, wait for further omens in the following month. In this way, the magistrates of each county and village will attend to the people’s observations at dawn and dusk, and it may be said that not even a hair’s breadth of Heaven’s omens will be lost. The officials will stand in awe of the people, and the people in awe of the officials. Both fearing one another, what is reported will all be truthful, not missing even a fraction’s weight. Thus, the emperor may sit in his secluded chamber without worry. All people, from ministers to commoners, great and small, will be loyal and trustworthy, their true sentiments fully conveyed. The realm will rejoice without exception.

If there are those who obstruct this, record them together—these are the treacherous ministers, the disloyal and unfilial people, those ignorant of Heaven and Earth, who deceive their superiors and sever the emperor’s clarity of perception. This is a grave transgression. Therefore, they must be swiftly recorded together. Do you understand, Perfected One?"

"Yes, yes."
"Go now, and if you have doubts, come and ask."
"Now the Six Perfected Ones all return in reverent contemplation, while the Celestial Master instructs the local officials and the people to jointly record calamities, anomalies, and strange occurrences—what exactly should they record?"
"Excellent! The Six ask with such thoroughness, not deviating from the heart of Heaven nor failing the Virtuous Lord. This is meritorious before Heaven and Earth, and all things under creation will benefit from it. The reason is this: in their questioning of Heaven’s affairs □□, they exhaustively investigate and clarify all details, thus missing not even a fraction’s weight. Whatever Heaven and Earth, yin and yang, the Three Luminaries, the Five Phases, the Four Seasons, the spirits, and the myriad things wish to express will all be made manifest—hence their great merit. Do you understand?"
"Yes, yes."
"Go now, and expound this clearly for the Six Perfected Ones, recording it carefully as you follow along."
"Yes, yes."

"Now then, the great calamities, anomalies, and strange occurrences are the grand discourse of Heaven and Earth; the moderate calamities, anomalies, and strange occurrences are their middling discourse; and the minor calamities, anomalies, and strange occurrences are their lesser discourse. If you wish to grasp their essential meaning, it is like this: great matters call for grand discourse, middling matters for middling discourse, and minor matters for minor discourse. These, whether great or small, all have something to convey—they are not empty manifestations, for Heaven and Earth do not recklessly deceive humanity.

When great auspicious omens appear, it is their profound joy; when middling auspicious omens appear, it is their moderate joy; and when minor auspicious omens appear, it is their slight joy. When great inauspicious portents and misfortune appear, it is the great wrath of Heaven and Earth; when middling inauspicious portents and misfortune appear, it is their moderate wrath; and when minor inauspicious portents and misfortune appear, it is their slight wrath. When all is tranquil, with neither auspicious nor inauspicious changes, it is their state of equilibrium—neither joyful nor angry. Do you understand?"
"Yes, yes."

"Disasters, anomalies, strange transformations—whether great or small—must be recorded without the slightest omission. Why so thorough?"
"How foolish you are, Perfected One! All transgressions, great and small, must be observed; likewise, the magnitude of good and evil must all be seen and known. For good deeds, one should acknowledge their merit and reward them with greater blessings; for faults, one should repeatedly admonish them to align with the intent of Heaven and Earth. Do you wish to know their effects? Heaven is like a ruler or sovereign: if a minor word is disobeyed, it incurs slight resentment; if a middling word is disobeyed, it incurs greater resentment; if a major word is disobeyed, it brings harm. Thus, all must be recorded, great and small, so as not to provoke the resentment and wrath of Heaven and Earth."
"Excellent! Excellent! I wish to hear the purpose of such records."
"Record anomalies, disasters, illnesses—whether great or small, numerous or few—unseasonable winds and rains, and the sufferings of the people and all things, great or small, all gathered and recorded through deliberation. The reason for having them collectively recorded is this: officials will know each other’s strengths and weaknesses, and the people will know one another’s strengths and weaknesses. Those dwelling near mountains and hills will know the changes in mountains and hills; those near markets, cities, and walled towns will know the changes in markets, cities, and walled towns; those near level lands will know the changes in level lands; those near low-lying fields and waters will know the changes in low-lying fields and waters. High and low, inner and outer—all will be known, and thus nothing will be lost. This is the method to swiftly attain Great Peace, the principle that emperors and kings should employ, the way to never lose the great intent of Heaven. Do you understand, Perfected One?"
"Yes, yes."
"Go, for you have understood."

Since the opening of Heaven and Earth, the prevalence of inherited disasters stems from the failure to record, collectively and comprehensively, the great and small affairs of the common folk. When strange anomalies occur, officials from other jurisdictions are dispatched to investigate. Those in nearby jurisdictions, each guarding their own borders, conceal the truth and collude in silence, thereby severing the words of Heaven and Earth and preventing them from reaching the emperors and kings. This inflicts profound harm, causing Heaven’s sorrow to deepen and disasters to multiply—all fault lies here.

When officials from other jurisdictions come to examine matters, how can they know the long-standing sufferings of the people? Some, bound by deep ties of favor, repeatedly collude to conceal the truth. Others, harboring old grudges against certain households, fabricate disasters, falsely amplify misfortunes, and jointly suppress the facts. Thus, the discourse of Heaven and Earth is cut off, and the innocent are wronged anew, while those below follow in pursuit of bribes and wealth.

These three matters all give rise to great harm, knotting the qi of grievance and further compounding disasters. For this reason, governance becomes utterly unbalanced. Yet when the Great Yang arises, the qi of peace flourishes, and a virtuous ruler governs, the world attains Great Peace, and all find their rightful place.

Therefore, the Six Perfected Ones have come to inquire in full, and I have answered them completely. Do you understand, Perfected One?
"Yes, yes."

〈Beginning〉

Thus, when Heaven intends to support and bless an emperor or king, it first instills in him a will of his own. From ancient times to the present, whenever Heaven has sought to bestow its favor, it has invariably presented him with wondrous texts and extraordinary strategies, enabling him to govern by their guidance—whereupon all his undertakings prove greatly auspicious.

When Heaven does not intend to bless or benefit a ruler, it severs all such wondrous texts and extraordinary strategies, preventing him from obtaining them. Even if he should chance upon them, it renders his mind dull, so that he fails to recognize their value and apply them. But when Heaven intends to bring benefit, it opens his mind wide and bright, so that he delights in employing them.

This is the unchanging law of Heaven, which never deceives humankind.

Therefore, those who are about to rise invariably favor goodness, while those about to decline favor evil. Those destined for good fortune are easily guided, while those destined for misfortune delight in offending others and cannot be guided.

Do you understand this, Perfected One?
"Yes, yes."

Thus, Heaven constantly aids the good, and the Dao inclines toward those of virtue. Heaven refuses to aid the wicked, and the Dao refuses to cling to those who are foolish and benighted.

〈End〉

Therefore, it constantly instructs the Perfected Ones to entrust these matters to rulers of virtue. The reason for meticulously recording all portents—great and small, good and evil, internal and external, near and far—is to enable virtuous rulers, together with their worthy ministers, to trace the origins of these anomalies.

All the world’s strange portents and calamities arise as reflections of events, imitations of conduct, and manifestations of their kind. When worthy ministers gather to deliberate, their minds open wide to the matter, and by examining the phenomena in light of their categories, they arrive at the truth. Then Heaven and Earth rejoice daily, and the emperor and king attain daily peace. In this way, virtue thoroughly harmonizes with the spirits, and all respond in kind.

To witness its great efficacy: the world’s sufferings and anomalies vanish entirely, ministers and people all act with goodness, and they follow imperial edicts to the letter, not erring by even a fraction. This is the clear proof that those below do not deceive their enlightened ruler.

Where there is much harm, there is much deceit; where there is little harm, there is little deceit; where there is no harm at all, there is no deceit whatsoever. By constantly observing what is presented from below, one may gauge the loyalty or disloyalty of ministers and people, great and small. Matched against the facts, it is like gazing into a bright mirror while speaking face to face.

How wondrous! To practice the Dao in this way—this is the bright mirror by which Heaven aids the ruler of supreme virtue to govern the world.

Do you understand this, Perfected One?
"Yes, yes."

Go now and swiftly deliver this to the ruler of virtue. If a single person submits a memorial alone, it is called "casting a document"—to entrust governance to one man’s word is called "great deceit," which incurs profound resentment from August Heaven and disrupts the constant order of the Dao.

If two people submit a memorial together, it is called "Great Yin," a collusion of treachery and deceit. Two cunning men firmly caution one another; or, if they share some grievance, they jointly submit falsehoods, thereby offending Earth and throwing the Earthly Dao into great disorder.

If three people submit a memorial together, their words remain fundamentally untrue. Though three may caution and instruct one another, if they share some grievance and submit it together, using public office to settle private scores, they fundamentally deceive their ruler, becoming enemies of harmony and throwing the qi of peace into great disorder.

If four people submit a memorial together, there is often one among them who fears the truth, whose words are seized upon by others to exploit his weaknesses. Though their account may seem plausible, its falsehood disrupts the four seasons.

If five people submit a memorial together, it may seem true but lacks certainty; its falsehood disrupts the five phases.

If six people submit a memorial together, it approaches truth but remains uncertain; its falsehood disrupts the six harmonies.

If seven people submit a memorial together, it appears trustworthy; eight approach truth; nine approach reality; ten achieve a measure of reliability.

"Why, Heavenly Master, do you harbor so many doubts?"
"I wish to hear the essential point."
"Indeed, the reason for so many doubts is that in the five directions, cunning men each harbor private grievances. Using public office to settle private scores, they firmly collude to commit great deceit, disrupting the Dao of Heaven and Earth to mislead their ruler. Thus, I dare not readily trust them, but treat them with caution.

Therefore, gather people of all ages—worthy and unworthy, men and women, down to servants and slaves—to deliberate together. In this way, falsehoods cannot prevail, nor can public office be used to settle private scores.

Among them, there may be some who feel uneasy and speak out: some may be unworthy, some may have loose tongues and fail to conceal the truth, some may be elders whose lives hang by a thread and who no longer fear consequences, or women and children may speak carelessly, unable to hide the truth. Thus, their collusion is exposed, and all deceit is revealed in its true form. When the truth is obtained, the hearts of Heaven and Earth are harmonized.

Do you understand this, Perfected One?"
"Yes, yes."

The reason emperors and kings have repeatedly inherited and borne the burden of past transgressions, and why governance constantly loses the favor of Heaven, is that disasters flow unceasingly. When one is cut off, another arises; August Heaven is not at peace, and harmful qi and illnesses abound, preventing longevity. Great joy is fleeting, and joy soon turns to sorrow—the root of this great fault lies precisely here.

Cunning and treacherous men jointly betray Heaven and Earth to deceive the emperor. Yet people regard Heaven and Earth as their destiny and the emperor as their father and mother. Fools who betray their destiny and jointly deceive their father and mother incur the hatred of Heaven and Earth and the emperor’s wrath. Their punishment is a vile death, and their remaining sins will be visited upon future lives.

Thus, disasters do not cease, harm increases daily, human lifespans shorten, and all things are constantly in disorder—the root of this fault lies precisely here.

Have you now fully awakened to this, Perfected One?"
"Yes, yes."

"Truly, you may be said to have understood this. Therefore, I know that August Heaven deeply abhors evil, and for this reason, I have repeatedly composed these writings to establish equilibrium. To omit even a single matter is to invite its resurgence—what was lost in the past may be recovered in the future, yet this matter is especially grave, for Heaven greatly detests it. I know its [omitted characters], and thus reveal and instruct the Perfected One, entrusting it to a ruler of supreme virtue and power. If he obtains and practices it, he will differ not from the divine, and the upright qi of the Great Peace and Highest Sovereign will arise of itself. My writings dare not betray Heaven and Earth, nor the ruler of supreme virtue, nor the people of future generations and later ages, nor the myriad things. Once practiced, their effects will be immediate."

"Excellent! Excellent! I wish to hear: why does one man’s memorial to the throne disrupt Heaven, and why do two men disrupt Earth?"

"This arises from their households, where aligned strategies resonate and stir one another—such is the natural law. Do you understand?"

"Yes, yes."

"Go, for you have now understood. All matters under Heaven follow their own kind."

"I venture to ask, Master of Heaven: if these words are put into practice, can they be fully verified, so that all under Heaven will believe?"

"Yes, all under Heaven will believe."

"I wish to hear the essential meaning."

"Very well, let me tell you the great essentials, Perfected One."

"Now, the current rulers and local officials fear that the people will expose their affairs, and thus they employ the six examinations to verify truthfulness, thereby securing trust. The people, too, fear the county authorities and, upon discovering their faults, likewise trust them. The county authorities and local officials, along with the residents, also fear those who travel to other regions to submit memorials, for if their faults are exposed, they too will be trusted. Those who submit memorials likewise fear that the county authorities, local officials, and residents will uncover their faults, and so they too are trusted. Each fears the other, and none dare speak falsely, nor can they conceal anything. Therefore, when memorials are submitted from three sources—the county authorities, the residents, and the travelers—they all align at dawn, not deviating by even a fraction. How wondrous is the Dao when practiced thus! I wish to hear the outcome."

"When should those who gather to deliberate assemble?"

"Excellent! Your words shall all be recorded beneath the abode of *Tai Ping Lai Shan*. Why must it be there?"

"Indeed, for there are extraordinary methods and singular texts that may be deposited in the *Tai Ping Lai Shan* abode, where good and evil are deliberated beneath it, and matters from all directions are collectively submitted. If only one person deliberates, they may regret and halt, or be stopped by others. If a memorial is submitted but then abandoned midway, the concealed matter shall be punished as a crime. Through such writings, all under Heaven will be obtained, and the emperor and kings will long wander in leisure."

"Excellent! Excellent!"

"Now that the Celestial Master’s writings have accumulated in great number, where should they all be deposited?"

"Those writings that are produced solely for the ruler shall remain with the ruler; all that are produced for the affairs of the world shall be made public. Do you understand?"

"Indeed, indeed."

"Go then. The ruler of supreme virtue is naturally moved by Heaven to possess a sagely mind. Moreover, through this, he naturally forms good intentions and naturally establishes good ordinances and rituals—this is the celestial law, not erring by even a hair’s breadth. Yet the matters are too numerous to record, and the texts are ever burdensome. Go now."

"Indeed, indeed."

*Here ends the Heaven’s decree to the Six Perfected Ones, instructing them to further comprehend the three methods for circulating written texts.*

**Scroll Eighty-Seven, Ji Section, Part Two**
**Perpetual Talisman Diagram, One Hundred Twenty-Eighth**

The celestial talisman returns essence when inscribed in cinnabar. Once inscribed and taken into the abdomen, one shall perceive the writings within the abdomen—greatly auspicious, and all evil departs.

The Five Offices and Five Kings are the inception of the Dao, the ancestors of spirits. Carefully seal them, closing the gates and doors. Though darkness reigns without, light shines within—how could one not see clearly? Guard this long and steadfastly, and the celestial physicians shall descend of themselves; all illnesses shall be dispelled, and one shall thereby attain longevity.

The foolish discard it, while the wise treasure it as a priceless gem—this may be called the Way of Perpetual Existence. Alone it honors the natural, with form and spirit mutually safeguarding. When these two embrace one another, strange thoughts shall instead bring misfortune. If you lose the natural, you cannot attain longevity. The infant’s five essences return to preserve themselves.

**Collated and Combined *Tai Ping Jing*, Scroll Eighty-Eight, Ji Section, Part Three**
**Tai Ping Jing, Scroll Eighty-Eight**

**Method for Establishing Houses of Goodness, One Hundred Twenty-Nine**

The Six Directions Perfected Ones bowed twice and said, "We humbly ask to resolve a doubt."
"Speak," came the reply.
"Previously, the Celestial Master instructed us to compile and collate essential texts from the High, Middle, and Low Antiquities, as well as the oral secrets of the wise and enlightened. Now, within and beyond the four borders—whether ten thousand *li* from the imperial court or farther—some possess good writings, though their texts are scant and insufficient, and must be carried from afar to the capital. Others hold rare texts, extraordinary methods, or wondrous arts; reclusive scholars and cave-dwelling worthies, though loath to travel ten thousand *li*, journey to the Son of Heaven to offer their Dao and virtue for sale. Still others—common folk, the young and weak, the old and small, farm children, and women—each harbor some good characters, oral secrets, or a few lines, yet their offerings are too meager to warrant sending someone to the capital. And among the barbarians of the four borders, the hidden peoples, the Hu and Mo tribes, though some know profound and secret Dao, even if they recognize the great luminous virtue of the Chinese ruler, they cannot bear the journey to present their rare texts, good strategies, or extraordinary methods.

Yet the Celestial Master has now gathered all ancient and modern spirit writings from the Yellow River and Luo River, along with the oral secrets of the wise, to form this *Sutra of Penetrating the Ultimate*—a work unparalleled since the opening of Heaven and Earth. With it, all disasters may be dispelled, the Emperor may wander in joy, and governance may proceed with folded arms and no cares. If even one matter is left unprepared, calamities may yet remain; thus, all must be gathered together.

But how are these rare methods, extraordinary strategies, and good characters to be obtained in full?"

"Excellent! Excellent! The Perfected Ones ponder deeply, and the celestial spirits have already informed them. The qi of the Supreme August One now aids the virtuous ruler □□. Go—now that the Perfected Ones have asked on behalf of the August Spirit of Heaven, it is my duty to expound fully for the world. How could I dare be remiss? Very well. Let the Perfected Ones be seated, and I shall explain all to them."

"Indeed."

"Entrust this text to the August Emperor of Supreme Virtue. When he sees the celestial patterns, he must grasp their essential meaning and command the provinces, commanderies, and distant regions of the four borders—every county, village, and hamlet—to each establish a fine House of Goodness along the great thoroughfares of the cities. Let it stand three *zhang* high, with a breadth and depth of three *zhang* as well, and construct openings on all four sides, level with a person’s face. The gaps between the openings should allow hands to pass through, shielding the doors so none may enter recklessly. Hang writings outside, making the texts clearly visible, and inscribe the four sides of the house as well. The texts shall proclaim that the Emperor seeks good people, rare and extraordinary methods, good strategies, oral secrets, and whatever wisdom the people hold in their hearts—whatever they can articulate. Let all write these down and deposit them in this house, recording their names. Thereafter, summon them, and according to the magnitude of their virtue and ability, appoint them to office. For those whose words are many but whose abilities cannot be verified, let the local officials of the counties and commanderies temporarily employ them. For the elderly, the weak, and women with good words, let the overseers reward them. For those whose merits are great but who cannot serve, let them be exempted. For those beyond the four borders who present good and extraordinary strategies with great efficacy, let them be richly rewarded.

Thus, within and beyond the four borders, all shall unite in a single day to rejoice and strive for the Emperor’s sake. From top to bottom, from within to without, no rare method, good character, or extraordinary strategy shall remain hidden. In a single day, all shall turn to delight in goodness. Hidden scholars and cave-dwelling recluses shall emerge into the cities, and upon seeing the Emperor’s Houses of Goodness for the coming of Great Peace, none shall conceal themselves. Wind and rain shall arrive in season, the Three Luminaries shall shine brightly—these are the signs of Heaven’s great joy. Among the eighty-one domains of the four barbarians, the good, the worthy, and the sages, hearing of the great virtue of the Chinese ruler’s governance, shall all delight in coming to submit. Bearing their rare treasures, they shall arrive in unbroken procession. Not one in ten thousand of my words shall be lost—how could this not be a cause for great joy? With governance of such great virtue, do the Perfected Ones now understand?"

"Indeed."

"Indeed, you have now awakened. In those houses where the written works are too numerous, the overseers shall further open their doors, gather the texts within, and bring them to be arranged together with the senior officials and the assembly of worthies. Among these, the good shall be grouped by category, the evil removed, and repetitions eliminated, ordering them by sequence. They shall then be presented to the Emperor. The Emperor shall again have the assembly of worthies arrange them, removing repetitions and what is evil or improper, grouping them by category, and placing them in a secluded repository. He shall further await the arrival of texts from the four directions, ordering them sequentially, again grouping them by category, and awaiting the arrival of later texts.

When the good houses from the four directions have produced rare and excellent writings, wondrous methods, and fine strategies, these shall again be carefully sealed. Where their accumulated stores are abundant, they shall again be arranged and presented. As the texts from the four directions diminish day by day, what is presented shall be largely the same. The assembly of enlightened worthies shall gather and arrange them, compiling them into the *Scripture of the Utmost Cavern*. Thereupon, the greatly awakened worthies shall transmit them downward to return to the people. The hundred clans and the myriad peoples shall all at once be transformed toward goodness, no longer knowing the ways of evil. This is what is called fully winning the hearts of Heaven, Earth, humankind, and the four barbarians—great joy arriving daily, all uniting as one family to together accomplish one governance.

Do the Six Perfected Ones understand this?"

"Indeed."

"Go forth, for the Six Perfected Ones have now understood. When the barbarians hear of this, they shall retreat day by day, and the Central Kingdom shall daily expand, growing stronger without warfare or conquest. Heaven and Earth shall assist in eliminating evil—this has never been seen since the opening of Heaven and Earth. Thus is the great joy of the world. The spirits of Heaven and Earth shall together eliminate the Emperor’s inherited burdens, and calamities and omens shall vanish. His governance shall be no different from that of the gods.

The people of the world shall greatly obtain the wondrous methods of the Dao and virtue, all contemplating good writings and correct words, no longer engaging in wickedness or evil. What is presented shall grow ever better with each year. Thereafter, a minor compilation shall be made every three years, and a major compilation every five years, arranging them. These shall then be appended and returned to the people, causing them each to delight in goodness and be unable to restrain themselves. From among them, the most excellent matters that benefit the Emperor’s correct governance shall be retained and not transmitted downward.

Do the Perfected Ones understand?"

"Yes, yes."

"Now then, Perfected One, Heaven has sent your disciples to inquire—since this is already a matter of Heaven’s questioning, you shall compose the *Scripture of Great Joy* for the Virtuous Lord. Exert yourself and do not slacken. Heaven shall repay your merit: you shall remove illness for the August Heaven and Earth, and dispel the calamities, poisons, and inherited burdens that afflict the Emperor. Your lifespan shall surely be extended. My words do not dare deceive the Perfected One—heed them well."

"Yes, yes."

"Go now and return. Strive with utmost diligence. If you have doubts, come again."

"Yes, yes."

"Perfected One, when you came forward to ask your questions, I had long wished to depart. Thus, I had already composed the text of our parting. Yet seeing your earnestness, I knew you were aided by the yang essence of August Heaven. The reason for this is that I perceive your sincerity: the Central Kingdom shall flourish in great peace, and the eighty-one domains shall send forth good people to return and submit to it. Therefore, I stayed longer for you, exhaustively expounding all matters. The reason for this is that I saw your unceasing inquiries on Heaven’s behalf, and feared you might incur great transgression, bringing censure from Heaven and Earth. Thus, I dared not abandon the Dao and depart midway."

"Do you understand, Perfected One?"

"Yes, yes."

"Go now, and strive to perfect this to the end. Do not abandon the Dao or neglect even a single precept."

"Yes, yes."

"I humbly request that you expound on this matter: Master of Heaven, what did you observe in the bustling crossroads of the cities when you established the chamber for the coming of good writings, wondrous strategies, and secret methods of the Great Peace?"

"Excellent, Perfected One, your difficult question has grasped the essential meaning. Has the Emperor tasked you with this arduous inquiry? How skillfully you have framed your words! Yet from my dwelling in Heaven, I have observed what may be seen—it was not in vain that I established this abode of August Peace at the crossroads.

When the Lord of Heaven asked, 'Why is it so difficult for the world to attain peace and tranquility?' The divine officials of the Five Phases replied: 'Now the Emperor dwells within a hundredfold enclosure, tens of thousands of *li* distant from the four borders. Those far away are often entangled in grievances, and good and evil cannot ascend to reach him. Wondrous methods, extraordinary writings, and uncommon strategies are cut off and never arrive before the Emperor. The people and ministers, bound by grievances, cannot petition or communicate. Over time, the four directions become obstructed and blocked. The worthy and learned conceal themselves, harboring the Dao and virtue in their hearts, yet perish in sorrow. The Emperor, deprived of their extraordinary strategies and uncommon words, cannot pacify the world. The great fault lies in the closure and disconnection of the distant frontiers in the four directions and eight boundaries.'

Thus, in accordance with Heaven’s will, I have established this abode for the coming of good writings on behalf of the Emperor of the Great Peace and virtue, bringing the qi of the Supreme August One and the balanced governance of antiquity to the crossroads. I wish to gladden the four directions, so all may know that the Virtuous Lord has issued these teachings. In joyful unison, they shall each bring their good offerings and uncommon methods, coming to submit them from near and far, without obstruction or severance."

"Excellent! Excellent! Without the Master of Heaven’s efforts in inquiry, this could not have been known."

"Indeed, what the Perfected One says is true. By nature, humans possess innate knowledge—this is the highest; those who cannot know innately must inquire through effort—this is the next best. Do you understand this?"

"Indeed, indeed. I humbly ask to pose one question: why must it be made three *zhang* in breadth and three *zhang* in height?"

"Excellent is your question! First, the number one is the beginning of all numbers. The celestial numbers also culminate in ten, the terrestrial numbers also culminate in ten, and the human numbers also culminate in ten—thus it is made three *zhang*. To bring joy and harmonize Heaven, Earth, and Humanity, so all may be pleased together, it is modeled after Heaven, Earth, and Humanity."

"Now I ask: why do the three numbers all culminate in ten?"

"Thus: Heaven possesses the Five Phases and also has its own yin and yang; Earth possesses the Five Phases and also has its own yin and yang; Humanity possesses the Five Phases and also has its own yin and yang. Therefore, all reach ten."

"Excellent! Excellent! Are only Heaven, Earth, and Humanity like this? Are all things in the myriad realms also thus?"

"All things in the myriad realms model themselves after Heaven, Earth, and Humanity. Thus, Heaven, Earth, and Humanity all follow the Four Seasons and Five Phases in waxing and waning. Does the Perfected One understand this?"

"Excellent! Excellent!"

"Now you may be said to have understood this."

"I humbly request to ask one matter."

"Speak."

"Why must the registers be made for the four directions, and why must they be level with the face?"

"Thus: the registers are made so that worthy scholars may inscribe them. The registers allow the four directions to be open and unobstructed, no longer closed off, so that the worthy may each record their words and submit them to this Chamber of Great Peace and Goodness. As for being level with the face: the face is the finest part of a person, the portion of the Great Yang, modeled after the Dao of Heaven. It delights people to each follow the heart of Heaven, contemplating goodness, joining forces with the virtuous ruler to together bring peace to the world—thus they are made level with the face. The face has the Seven Orifices: ears, eyes, mouth, and nose through which qi may pass, and through which spirits and deities come and go. It delights the great worthy to inscribe them, so that the distant lands of the four directions and eight extremities may all become perceptive and come forth. Now, though the emperor dwells within a hundredfold enclosure, separated from the people by ten thousand leagues, his radiant teachings and commands all reach and penetrate, never losing the heart of Heaven and Earth, thereby securing his person."

"Excellent! Excellent!"

“May I ask, what sort of officials should be appointed to guard this dwelling?”

“Senior officials shall be directly assigned, and upon their proclamation of its name, it shall be called the Dwelling of Great Peace, the Office of Delighting in Goodness.”

“Excellent! Now that I, a foolish student, have come to know the will of Heaven, I rejoice greatly. Earth, too, is deeply pleased and moves with caution. The people have attained the governance of Great Peace, and the myriad things have each found their proper place.”

“How does the Perfected One come to know this?”

“I, a foolish student, have witnessed the Heavenly Master, as the Virtuous Ruler of Great Peace, constructing this grand dwelling of joy to facilitate the discourse between Heaven, Earth, and humanity. Now, it enables the common people and subjects to each present their words to their sovereign, allowing the emperor to obtain extraordinary strategies and rare texts of singular methods that ensure his long-term security. Moreover, Heaven and Earth may now communicate their discourse, and the humble and lowly among the people can convey their virtuous words, thereby dispelling the gloom of Heaven and Earth and aiding their ruler in becoming perceptive and enlightened. Heaven, Earth, and humanity, as the foremost of all things, are now fully interconnected—hence the great joy.”

“What the Perfected One has said is true. Excellent! I have nothing to add. Your words on this matter deeply enter the true Dao.”

“May I ask one further question?”

“Speak.”

“Now Heaven is gloomy and desires to speak—why then does it instead cause *people* to discourse?”

“Excellent! Your challenging question has grasped the essence. Yet, the Dao of Heaven turns and interrelates, mutually employing one another. Thus, *dui* (the trigram of openness) serves as the mouth of Heaven and Earth, and so too do humans. Like seeks like, and thus people become the voice of Heaven and Earth. Does the Perfected One understand?”

“Indeed, indeed.”

“Go now, for you are easily enlightened. Strive, strive!”

“Indeed, indeed.”

“Very well, this minor discourse is concluded; ask no more. The written teachings of the Dao are difficult to comprehend and may only deepen confusion.”

“Indeed, indeed.”

“Go now, and let me caution the Perfected One on one matter: you have already collated rare texts and singular methods. Roll and present one virtuous method—a foundational art of nurturing inner nature—beneath the scrolls, so that the multitude of worthies may recite and study it. This shall serve as the culmination of the *Dongji* scripture. Let each gather these methods for self-cultivation, recite these arts for self-preservation, and thus delight in long endurance. The most worthy may serve as state advisors, the moderately worthy as minor officials, and even the lowliest, who cannot hold office, may long nurture their parents and steadfastly guard their descendants.”

“Excellent! Excellent! The world shall know great joy and delight, and goodness shall have no equal—no more shall there be evil people.”

“You have already understood. Go now, and reflect upon this. Since you have inquired of Heaven’s affairs, do not grow lax.”

“Indeed, indeed.”

Here follows the translation:

---

To the right: *Seeking Virtue to Attain Great Peace and Unify All Under Heaven in a Single Day, That All May Converge in Heart at the Abode of the Supreme August One’s Great Joy*—Text of the *Scripture of Great Peace: Collated Edition*, Scroll Eighty-Nine, Ji Section Four. *Scripture of Great Peace*, Scroll Eighty-Nine: “Recitation on the Eight Trigrams’ Return of Essence,” One Hundred and Thirtieth.

Mysterious brightness illumines within; the great darkness abounds in qi. Sharing rank with the worthy, it dwells in the abodes of *ren* and *gui*. *Hai* and *zi* share a body, circulating and embracing one another. When utmost yin gives birth to yang, it is called *Initial Nine*. Once united, it generates beings: yin halts, yang arises. Receiving bestowal from *hai*, conceiving in *ren*, it flourishes in *zi*. From child to grandchild, yang enters yin’s midst—its generation knows no end.

Contemplate the outer to penetrate the inner; lifespan doubles. This cannot be swiftly attained—it is fitting for long endurance. Lesser yang holds qi, sharing rank with the liver, in *jia*, *yi*, *yin*, and *mao*, where azure hues are akin. The essence of the myriad things emerges in profusion, front and back intermingling. Benevolence and kindness settle in the heart.

When a valiant warrior is about to set forth, let him contemplate and behold this character: its radiance is like the sun at first light. A hundred illnesses are cured, and years increase threefold. Greater yang, abundant in qi, resembles the heart, dwelling in the house of *bing* and *ding*, nurtured in the positions of *si* and *wu*. Beholding it, a hundred evils depart, and the body daily grows upright. One should cultivate a gentle and luminous intent—this must not be forcibly sought. Upon seeing the character, one gains longevity, its light like the brightness of the sun at midday.

The qi of central harmony connects with the spleen, extending to the four seasons’ quarters before returning to *wu* and *ji*. It resides centrally in *chen* and *xu*, with *chou* and *wei* as its root. Raise and follow it, contemplating its intent, and apply it to cure illness—its essence is like the Yellow Dragon. Upon seeing this character, one’s illness vanishes, and years increase fivefold. It makes people compliant and filial, ministers loving toward their lords, and children loving toward their fathers.

In the period of lesser yin, it joins with the essence of the teacher. The numinous fan emits qi, its position belonging to *geng* and *xin*. In *shen* and *you*, righteousness executes; crafty evildoers and thieves do not arise, and evil cannot harm people. The qi of the flourishing kidneys increases lifespan a hundredfold. When utmost yin gives birth to yang, the state greatly prospers. Constantly contemplating it, one knows not death.

Yin ascends, yang arises—thus the Dark Warrior marks the beginning. The virtue of the dragon is born in the north, its position in the east, and thus follows thereafter. The Vermilion Bird governs illness; the yellow qi rectifies the center. Should the ruler practice this, his lifespan shall be boundless. Ascending to uphold equilibrium, a hundred evils perish. The Eight Trigrams reside within, and the spirits form ranks in procession. The White Tiger follows behind, executing calamities and annihilating misfortune. The true Dao arrives daily, and perverse qi vanishes. Contemplate essence without cease—this is the record of extended years. Should one embody and internalize it, what sorrow could there be?

Following below what is above is called *Compliance with the Dao*. Without fault or transgression, a myriad illnesses heal themselves. Contemplate the character and behold its form; love it as father and son. It makes one perpetually joyful, penetratingly illuminating without end. Those who examine and apply it shall await its effects at once. Long accompany the text, and daily wander with the spirits.

The Dao takes spontaneity as its profound emptiness. It does not come of itself in a single day—its Dao is benevolent and good. Children practice filial piety for it; ministers offer loyalty. Those who truly know it come to cherish their bodies, dare not speak recklessly, and guard it without cease—thus their lives know no end. The text does not emerge in vain; contemplate it in connection with the Dao. Deeply grasp its intent, and the spirits shall come of themselves.

At the inception, contemplate the character’s form, and return to the origin of the Dao. Essence attains spirit illumination, and thus there is no spontaneity. The Dao of Heaven has myriad beginnings—what lies with humans may be enacted. When the Dao accomplishes its work, □□ does not act wrongly. The concern is that people do not exert themselves—whence could upright qi be obtained? Practicing without ascending, the days grow auspicious and danger recedes.

Should a great person practice this, his state attains Great Peace. Should a petty person practice it, he averts calamity and invites blessing. Contemplate its subtle depths, and all inclinations become complete. Should a child guard the Dao, whence could disorder arise? Contemplate without cease, and Great Peace comes of itself. The heart unconfused, without perverse inclinations, guard it without cease, and the days generate themselves. The Dao does not emerge recklessly—it is entrusted to those with virtue and returns to its proper person.

To the right: *Recitation on the Eight Trigrams’ Ascent to Peace, the Six Jia’s Pursuit of the Dao, and the Return of Essence*—*Scripture of Great Peace: Collated Edition*, Scroll Ninety, Ji Section Five. *Scripture of Great Peace*, Scroll Ninety.

**Grievance, Calamity, and the Pursuit of Extraordinary Methods: First Scroll, Section One Hundred Thirty-One**

Before the Perfected One, you study this. In all matters, accumulate knowledge, and you shall understand the great principles by which the world is ordered. Only afterward may affairs be discussed—then doubt shall no longer remain.

Now, when common folk die, they wail in great grievance, beating their breasts and crying to Heaven, flinging themselves to the ground and wailing to Earth. Is this right? Or is it wrong?

One ought to refine the Dao with utmost care, so that it may be recited and read for ten thousand generations, becoming an enduring law never to be forgotten.

Today, the Celestial Master has issued strict teachings—how dare this foolish student not strive to speak a word?

Proceed without doubt.

Yet death is a grave matter for mortals. To wail in great grievance, beating the breast and flinging oneself down, exhausting all strength in endless sorrow—this does no harm to life. But for whom, then, should one grieve? And why grieve for all?

When a person dies, they are utterly extinguished, reduced to ashes and dust, never to be seen again. Since the opening of Heaven and Earth, each person is born but once, never to be reborn. From the moment they are named as human, they are the foremost of all creatures, harmonious and balanced, noble and honored, akin to Heaven and Earth. Yet upon death, they vanish forever, never again to rise or walk as one called human. Thus, the grief is great, and the grievance profound.

Alas! Your words align with the vulgar, yet they are not truly so.

This foolish student fails to grasp the meaning. What, then, should one do when a person dies? I beg to hear it, O Celestial Master.

All things that live must come to an end; human life, too, must end in death—this is the ordained pattern of Heaven and Earth. Even Heaven itself sometimes mourns those who die unjustly or perish young.

Heaven and Earth are the parents of all things. Fearing that some may die in grievance, weeping and wailing to Heaven above and knocking their heads upon the Earth below, mourning their short years, Heaven has thus bestowed the true Dao and extraordinary methods for self-preservation, allowing some to attain modest longevity.

All living things naturally age and perish, yet foolish people refuse to diligently study the true Dao and virtuous methods. How, then, can they slightly extend their years, delaying death and deferring old age? Instead, they treat themselves with careless disregard, seeking no extraordinary methods, and together mock and belittle the true Dao. They turn to deception and falsehood, disrupting the Dao of Heaven, deceiving their superiors, and competing to prepare burial mounds, tending to them in anticipation of death. They prearrange funerary contracts and mourning garments, seeking death and thus obtaining it. What, then, is there to grieve?

When one’s years are spent and their fate exhausted, it is like the sun rising and inevitably setting. Why, then, does the Perfected One grieve?

The Perfected One’s words often align with the vulgar—it seems you know nothing of humanity. Why is this?

For whom, then, should one grieve? I wish to hear it.

One should grieve for those who die young, before gaining any knowledge, who never had the chance to seek means of self-defense. Thus, they are to be grieved.

One should also grieve for those who are ever cautious and good, who fear dying young and thus endure hardship in their conduct, seeking the true Dao, virtuous power, and extraordinary methods. They act with constant goodness, never harming in secret, yet may encounter calamity and die prematurely, or reach old age with strength exhausted, never having met a wise teacher, even briefly, to fulfill their natural lifespan. These are the truly grievous cases, worthy of sorrow.

But those who grieve without cause, who do not seek extraordinary methods or the true Dao yet die, only to beat their breasts, weep, cry to Heaven, and knock their heads upon the Earth—such people bring this upon themselves, rebelling against Heaven and Earth. They are rebellious folk, and Heaven deeply resents and despises them.

If the Perfected One grieves for these, it would be better to mourn early for failing to learn the true Dao, for not understanding the great principles of Heaven and Earth, yin and yang, and their divisions. Long have you suffered without a wise teacher, harboring sorrow as your natural years draw to a close. This is truly lamentable—do you understand?

Indeed, indeed! This foolish student is deeply alarmed. My fate rests with the Celestial Master.

I now impart the true Dao to you, wishing you to exert yourself without cease. What in the world is unattainable? It is only that you do not seek with sufficient diligence. When utmost sincerity moves Heaven with flowing tears, Heaven will not withhold its gifts. If you do not slacken in your pursuit of the Dao, you shall obtain it before long. Do you understand?

Indeed, indeed!

Foolish people do not cherish and love themselves. They do not strive to seek extraordinary methods that might grant them even a brief respite. Instead, they prepare their funerary vessels and burial places in advance, seeking death. Heaven’s laws are like those of a compassionate father, a wise mother, or a sagacious ruler—they do not deprive one of what may be sought.

It is the natural and constant pursuit of what is sought that earns its name. Thus, one may not grieve excessively.

Therefore, in ancient times, sages and emperors who greatly cherished and feared death would day and night ponder and seek rare knowledge and extraordinary methods. They revered those who practiced the Dao, exhausting their wealth in the pursuit. With utmost sincerity and flowing tears, they moved the August Heaven, which then manifested auspicious signs. Masters of the Dao and its arts all came to their aid. Thus, many attained long life, and some transcended the world.

Yet there were those who sought but did not obtain, for their sincerity was not steadfast. They favored worldly affairs, treated their lives with careless disregard, and claimed they could be reborn. Today, Heaven and Earth regard humans as their children, and emperors as the most honored of Heaven’s children. How could they begrudge the true Dao and extraordinary methods?

Do you understand?

Indeed, indeed!

Thus, the sages of antiquity pondered deeply and planned far ahead, knowing that the wealth of the world is not eternally possessed.

While one lives, wealth and possessions are merely entrusted to the body.

When the body perishes, wealth and possessions pass to others. Thus, there is nothing to cling to—exhaust all wealth to aid oneself in seeking the true Dao and rare teachings. In this way, the body may endure long, while wealth remains, ever belonging to others. Therefore, one should strive to empty all wealth. Wealth is but a fleeting pursuit, gained in an instant. To lose it is merely to return it to the world, for it was never truly one’s own to keep. This is what marks the wise and sagacious: they nurture the body with the Dao, understand the proper use of wealth, and thus often attain long life. Do you understand?"

"Indeed, indeed!"

"Go forth. Those who would be teachers face many hardships and slander, yet the true person remains steadfast. Let me explain further for your sake. The Dao of Heaven has its principles and laws, not favoring any by familiarity. If you wish to truly know its workings, consider this: after the winter solstice, Heaven brings great cold that kills; yet in the fifth month, the first signs of yin qi appear in the well, growing clearer day by day. By the time the winter solstice arrives, the cold becomes so severe it harms and kills those without clothing. The wise prepare in advance and thus enjoy great joy, unharmed by the cold and free from worry. But the indolent, who do not exert themselves or make preparations, suffer hunger, cold, and destitution—this is the meaning. Heaven commits no error; it is people who bring this upon themselves. Do you now understand more deeply?"

"Yes, yes."
"Good, you have awakened."
"The laws of Heaven do not favor anyone by sudden familiarity—it is the foolish who bring trouble upon themselves by reckless disregard. May I ask: what kind of grievance is even greater than this?"
"The greatest grievance is that of the great worthy. From youth, they study goodness, follow what is right, and possess true virtue and power, destined to assist the emperor in governing the yin and yang. If the emperor obtains such a one, he will be at ease in heart and mind, ruling effortlessly without worry. But if such a person is obstructed and blocked, their true virtue and power persisting until old age and death—this is a grievous sorrow. Yet if the emperor fails to secure such a great worthy and enlightened advisor, and instead governs alongside the foolish, the yin and yang fall into chaos, myriad calamities arise, and he toils day and night in suffering, beset by great sorrow. This is an even greater grievance, a profound cause for lament.

Thus, in ancient times, the sagely and enlightened, those of great understanding, saw all worthies emerge and gather to serve as their aides. Therefore, neither ruler nor minister suffered grievance. Heaven and Earth, too, were governed by this principle, free from affliction and grievance—how much more so for humankind?

Have you grasped this, Perfected One?"
"Yes, yes. Excellent!"

"The Celestial Master speaks thus."
"By what is this deemed good?"
"Indeed, this is what Heaven attains—to resolve suffering and affliction. When the emperor attains it, he governs with folded arms, free from sorrow. The worthy, too, fulfill their loyal and faithful hearts, aiding their lord in governance, and exert their utmost efforts tirelessly. Together, they resolve the great sorrows of Heaven and Earth, and the myriad people and all things likewise attain it and flourish. Thus, it is called *excellent*."

"Excellent! The Perfected One’s words leave me nothing to add. Therefore, for all who may seek and act, there is no grievance or entanglement—each attains what they pursue of their own accord. If what one seeks is not attained, it becomes a great grievance. Now, if one seeks death and obtains death, seeks evil and obtains evil, seeks goodness and obtains goodness, Heaven follows their heart—this is great fortune, for what is sought is attained. If one deliberately places themselves in mortal peril, makes a death pact, and thus meets death, it is so. If one daily seeks misfortune, obtains calamity, and dies, it is likewise so. In all false and mundane affairs, what one seeks is granted by Heaven and Earth—there is no greater betrayal of this person.

Perfected One, have you not yet fully awakened?"
"Yes, yes."
"Go, you have awakened. Now, I wish to expound for you the complete text of its benefits. I have already outlined its great principles for you. Reflect upon its meaning, and present it to the lord of virtue and power, that it may be shown to the multitude of worthies. Let each exert effort in their pursuits. If what is sought is not attained, it is because one has not yet reached utmost sincerity. For Heaven and Earth are like echo and shadow—they do not deceive. The sorrow lies in the foolish, each deceiving themselves, belittling and neglecting themselves. The great fault lies here. The multitude of fools together disrupt Heaven and Earth, not merely bringing sorrow upon themselves. Their transgression is thus, and Heaven is greatly aggrieved by it. When the foolish seek and attain their ends, yet in destitution turn to wail and cry out to Heaven and Earth, their accumulated folly over time deeply grieves Heaven and Earth. Thus, I have been sent down to fully explain and resolve the intentions of the world’s people, that the multitude of worthies and enlightened may together deliberate upon my words. My words are the discourse of Heaven and Earth. I do not idly speak of these matters with the Perfected One—it is the instruction and command of Heaven, which I have descended to convey. Let each know the origin of their transgressions and no longer blame one another. Thus, I have spoken fully. I dare not speak falsely. The reason I exhaustively expound is that I alone understand the heart of Heaven and Earth. Therefore, I have been sent to descend and discuss the world with the Perfected One, to distinguish right from wrong, that the virtuous lord and the worthies may together reflect upon it. Let it be transmitted for ten thousand generations. Those of later times shall chant and recite it as a constant law, never to be forgotten.

Thus, whenever I see the Perfected One inquire of matters, I always delight in resolving them for Heaven, and with each resolution, a sorrow is dispelled. Therefore, whenever I behold the words of Heaven, I receive the heart of Heaven and the intent of Earth, and distinguish and expound the Dao accordingly. I dare not be remiss. If you have doubts, come again to discuss them. Since I have been entrusted and sent down to speak, I truly revere the majesty of Heaven and hold nothing back.

Have you deeply and clearly understood?"
"Yes, yes."
"Go, you have grasped the intent of Heaven and Earth. May you comprehend matters and give rise to life! People accumulate folly, failing to early learn the true Dao, the extraordinary methods of goodness and virtue, dismissing them as trivial. They do not know their transgressions accumulate greatly, disrupting Heaven and Earth and bringing sorrow to their emperor. Their bodies yet meet death by Heaven’s decree, failing to complete their allotted years before perishing.

Perfected One, reflect deeply upon my written words. Is there any transgression in the world greater than this death?"
"Excellent! Excellent! This foolish one has now fully awakened."

"Have you, by awakening early, become one who comprehends matters and life, drawing near to fortune while distancing misfortune? Yet if one awakens but does not persist, is the true Dao ever fully attained? Is gaining the favor of kings and lords not inferior to encountering an immortal? Now, if you come upon a thousand pounds of gold or ten thousand pairs of jade discs, is that not less valuable than finding an enlightened teacher? Though an emperor may have countless foolish ministers, is one great sage not worth more? Though parents may bear a hundred unworthy sons, is one virtuous son not better? Though a village of a hundred households may neglect study, is residing near one of great virtue not preferable? Though ten thousand eyes may strain, is one great guiding principle not superior? Though the world teems with chaos and all things exist, is any of it not surpassed by Heaven alone—divine and sagely, riding qi to soar through the skies? Though things may be many, is any not inferior to the single qi that alone sustains life?

Thus, I now command the Perfected One and all learners: swiftly cast aside superficial adornments, devote yourselves to essential matters, and seek the true Dao. Does one who desires supreme fortune not emulate Heaven? Heaven and Earth, free of affliction, remain eternally joyful—does the true Dao, with its wondrous and extraordinary methods, not emerge to protect humanity? Therefore, the sages of antiquity constantly emulated Heaven, never daring to slacken, and so they alone were perpetually fortunate. When worthy scholars gather their strategies, the Dao of Heaven is complete. Each speaks of one good, and yin and yang are ordered; the spirits rejoice. Disasters and harms all lie subdued, never to arise again. This is what it means to govern in accord with Heaven’s will, so that treacherous ministers vanish. How divine is the Dao—it is the art of spontaneity itself!"

"Excellent! Excellent! This foolish one previously did not exert himself in inquiry and thus had no means to know these truths."

"Indeed, your words are correct. If one studies but does not exert effort in inquiry, how can daily progress be made? If one walks but does not frequently move one’s feet, how can the Way be reached? If one studies but does not find an enlightened teacher, how can understanding be awakened? If one governs a state and desires peace and stability, yet does not employ great worthies, how can order be achieved in a single day?"

"Excellent are the Celestial Master’s words!"

"Indeed, you have glimpsed the subtle intent. Thus, ninefold walls of a golden fortress are not equal to serving one great worthy. Therefore, the sages and worthies of antiquity all served enlightened teachers to resolve their cares and troubles. Thus, sages and worthies all had their teachers and methods. Perfected One, take heed: in all matters, cherish yourself, for the gates of fortune and misfortune may be seen!

"Perfected One, heed this one word."

"Yes, yes."

"What people seek and obtain, Heaven grants in accord with their seeking, never failing them. Do not wait until death’s approach to weep to Heaven and wail to Earth. This is called obtaining what one has sought for oneself, then turning to blame Heaven and Earth—such a one is called a great rebel. Heaven does not favor them, Earth does not delight in them, and ghosts and spirits will not protect them. Those who suffer grievances alone bear their grievances; those who seek and do not obtain have only themselves to blame."

"Yet all things obtain what they seek—why should one bring grievance upon oneself?"

"Perfected One, ponder deeply my words: are they true or not? My writings do not err. They are greatly... [lacuna], not missing even one in ten thousand. Now, Heaven detests and swiftly punishes such errors, so I reiterate the Dao. Though I have spoken of this above, I again admonish the Perfected One below. Thus, I deliberately cause later generations to rejoice repeatedly, to deeply ponder, admire, reflect upon, transmit, and transcribe these words, sharing them without concealment. These are Heaven’s admonitory writings, meant to be seen and propagated, not to be hidden."

"Yes, yes."

"Go now."

Here the collected queries address whether the dead encounter grievance, whether their desires are fulfilled, whether their fate aligns with the nation’s safety, and whether their learning meets with enlightened masters or unworthy teachers.

*Tai Ping Jing* Collated and Annotated, Scroll 91, Ji Section 6
*Tai Ping Jing*, Scroll 91: "Collating and Verifying the Three Ancient Texts," Chapter 132

**Opening:**
"Permit me to ask: the Celestial Master’s writings collate and verify all texts since the opening of Heaven and Earth—those of past and present sages, the river charts and Luo scripts, divine writings, and even the words of common folk, servants, and distant barbarians. They gather all extraordinary phrases and rare strategies, uniting them into a single discourse to clarify the Dao of Heaven. Is this not laborious?"

"It is precisely because distant matters are cumbersome and inaccessible that each is addressed where it arises, seeking the abode of Great Peace within its own domain—town or village. Those in charge prepare for what lies afar but cannot attain it themselves. Thus, I establish stations along the Way, where they may submit unusual words, excellent strategies, and singular methods. From these, the central affairs are selected and conveyed to a ruler of virtue above, whose ministers jointly examine and categorize them. The finest are chosen, their heterodox phrases removed, to form the *Dongji Jing* (*Scripture of the Penetrating Ultimate*), named *Celestial Governance of the Penetrating Ultimate*. Thereafter, the ailments of Heaven and Earth are entirely dispelled. The governance of emperors and kings attains perfect great peace, and the accumulated calamities of ten thousand generations are wholly eradicated. Then, the myriad things and spirits will have nothing to report, nor will they again accuse humanity’s evils before the Highest Heaven. Therefore, those charged with collation and verification are Heaven’s envoys, sent to deliver my words below. Though laborious, how could one not exert every effort?

All writings under Heaven, though each person speaks but one word—or ten or more—resolve all doubts across the world without undue burden. Each simply remains in their place, speaking and conveying their words upward. This is called gathering the world’s words into a shared discourse, to penetrate the intent of Heaven and Earth, to harmonize the *qi* of Heaven and Earth, to eliminate the disasters of emperors and kings, and to benefit the common people and all things, each finding their proper place. Only then will Heaven and Earth be wholly and greatly joyful. Their ailments wholly dispelled, their joy will protect emperors and kings, allowing them to wander at leisure without concern."

"I wish to ask: why does Heaven and Earth at this time command the people of the world to collectively gather words, strategies, and the writings of ancient and modern divine sages to form the *Dongji Jing*?"

"Excellent is your question. Indeed, Heaven and Earth suffer from severe disorder and illness, never having attained proper governance. Thus, they instruct humanity to convene and jointly produce correct words and extraordinary strategies to cure their ailments. Hence, they command this great gathering of words and affairs."

"I further wish to ask: when Heaven and Earth are in chaos and afflicted with severe illness, why not instead bring forth good sages? What use is it to repeatedly produce later sages?"

**Closing:**
"Alas! How foolish you are, Perfected One!"

"I have heard that this has been spoken of before."
"The lowly and benighted are born, accumulating ignorance and obstinacy, unable to perceive clearly."
"If even you, Perfected One, speak thus, how can the common people possibly understand? They will surely cast aside my words in mutual resentment, and greater celestial disasters will arise, beyond remedy. Thus, Heaven has made you ask repeatedly. Does it wish me to explain further in full?"
"Very well. I have witnessed the mandate myself, descending for this matter. I dare not conceal anything or defy Heaven. Come, Perfected One, listen closely. I shall elucidate for you point by point, expounding fully from beginning to end. Simply sit in peace."
"Understood."

"Come, the sages of past and present differ in excellence, each excelling in one domain. All speak the language of Heaven and Earth, yet their works vary. Thus, the many sages who have appeared before and after pursue different paths. All delight in aligning with the will of Heaven and Earth, eliminating evil and achieving goodness, yet their words are not entirely alike—some align, some do not, though broadly similar. Therefore, the multitude of sages cannot fully grasp the intent of Heaven and Earth. Hence, Heaven and Earth often suffer from severe ailments that are not entirely cured, and even if more sages were born, the outcome would be the same. Heaven has long been disheartened. Thus, it sent me down to fully articulate these words and convey them to you, Perfected One. The reason I address you, Perfected One, is that the gods above have declared: among those below who delight in goodness and seek to accord with Heaven’s will, only you, Perfected One, exist."
Thus, I convey the truth of these words to you, Perfected One. I do not speak empty words. Do you understand?"
"Understood."

"Come, you have grasped it yourself."
"Come, the reason for compiling the divine texts of the high antiquity, middle antiquity, and recent antiquity is this: what the divine texts of high antiquity did not address, the divine texts of middle antiquity did; what the divine texts of middle antiquity did not address, the divine texts of recent antiquity did. Arranging them by category to complement one another, they form a single excellent discourse. Thus, they are gathered together. Thereafter, the intent of Heaven and Earth in the divine books may be discerned. Do you understand, Perfected One?"
"Understood."

"Come, you have comprehended it. Come, what the sages of high antiquity lost, the sages of middle antiquity gained; what the sages of middle antiquity lost, the sages of recent antiquity gained; what the sages of recent antiquity lost, the sages of high antiquity gained. Arranging them by category to complement one another, they form a single excellent discourse of the sages. Do you understand, Perfected One?"
"Understood."

"Come, you may be said to have achieved great understanding. Come, when the great sages err or fall short, the middling sages attain it; when the middling sages err, the lesser sages attain it. Again, arranging them by category to complement one another, they form a single excellent discourse of the sages. Do you understand, Perfected One?"
"Understood."

"Come, you have comprehended it. Come, when the great worthies err or fall short, the middling worthies attain it; when the middling worthies err, the lesser worthies attain it. Arranging them by category to complement one another, they form a single excellent discourse of the worthies. Do you understand, Perfected One?"
"Understood."

"Come, you may be said to have achieved great understanding. Come, when emperors and kings lose it, ministers and sons attain it; when ministers and sons lose it, the common people attain it. Arranging them by category to complement one another, they form a single excellent discourse. Do you understand, Perfected One?"
"Understood."

"Come, you have achieved great understanding. Come, when the aged lose it, those in their prime attain it; when those in their prime lose it, the young attain it. Arranging them by category to complement one another, they form a single excellent discourse. Do you understand, Perfected One?"
"Understood."

"Come, you have comprehended it. Come, when men lose it, women attain it; when women lose it, servants, bondmaids, and barbarians attain it. Arranging them by category to complement one another, they form a single excellent discourse. Do you understand, Perfected One?"
"Understood."

"Come, you have understood it. Come, sometimes the writings of high antiquity lose it, while those of middle antiquity attain it; sometimes the writings of middle antiquity lose it, while those of recent antiquity attain it. Arranging them by category to complement one another, they form a single excellent discourse. Do you understand, Perfected One?"
"Understood."

"Come, you have achieved great understanding. Come, sometimes the people of high antiquity lose it, while those of middle antiquity attain it; sometimes the people of middle antiquity lose it, while those of recent antiquity attain it. Arranging them by category to complement one another, they form a single excellent discourse. Do you understand?"
"Understood."
