There is no comparing their numbers. If, without cause, a person were to harm or kill even a hundred or so of them, their families would cry out in grievance, petitioning the emperor. Upon hearing this, the emperor would fly into a rage, issuing decrees to investigate and punish the offenders. The commotion would spread through provinces, commanderies, and counties, treated as a matter of grave consequence, and many would be brought to ruin as a result. Do you understand now?”

“How terrifying! How terrifying!”

“Excellent. You now grasp the great terror—thus shall you attain long life.”

“Indeed, indeed.”

“Therefore, the sage-kings of antiquity, knowing the celestial patterns and luminous models, dared not recklessly employ punishment. Theirs was the utmost depth of thoughtful foresight. Thus their governance remained ever balanced, requiring no exertion of force, yet winning the heart of Heaven—all through their reverent caution. Now, the minor lapses of former kings have borne consequences through generations, each with its gains and losses, making governance difficult to balance. Do you understand?”

“Indeed, indeed.”

“Now, as the qi of Great Peace arrives, Heaven cherishes the virtuous ruler. Thus I set forth these warnings in full, making transgression difficult. Take my writings and present them to the ruler of supreme virtue, that he may reflect upon his ill intentions.”

“Indeed, indeed.”

*Right: Collected Difficulties on the Mandates of Medicinal Substances and Their Belongings*
*Each Has Its Own Lord and Superior*
*Yang’s Honor and Yin’s Humility: Secret Formula One Hundred Thirty-Eight*

“May I ask why Yang alone attains honor and nobility, while Yin is solely named lowly and base?”

“Excellent indeed is your question! You nearly perceive the intent of the Dao and virtue. Yang is called honorable and noble because it guards its root, ever full and replete with substance. Yin is called lowly and base because it is hollow and empty, devoid of substance—hence it is despised and scorned.”

“This foolish student, receiving Heaven’s mandate yet feeble and ignorant, remains shrouded in darkness, slow to comprehend. I beg the Heavenly Master to fully explain its meaning.”

“Why have you not yet fully perceived the intent of the Way of Heaven? Even perfected beings struggle to grasp it—how much more so the benighted common folk!

Now, the names Yin and Yang, male and female, arise from the primal qi at its very inception—the gateway of Yin and Yang. Where humans receive their mandate and life is their root. Thus, the male receives his mandate full and overflowing, with surplus. Below and to his left and right, each still holds a kernel of substance. Above, he is full and overflowing, ever bestowing upon the Yin below. His surplus accumulates, ever substantial. The bestowing above corresponds to the movement of the Great Yang of Heaven—nothing it cannot generate, nothing it cannot complete. The accumulation below corresponds to the Great Yin, to Earth, with its patterns and veins like field boundaries. The left substance corresponds to humanity; the right substance, to the myriad things. *Substance* means kernel, the essence—thus benevolence delights in bestowing, and it possesses kernel and essence. Therefore, Yang is called honorable and noble. Do you understand?”

“Indeed, indeed.”

“Yin becomes woman, and thus she is deemed lowly and base. The place where she receives her mandate is hollow and empty, without fullness or surplus, and moreover without kernel or substance—hence she is seen as lowly and base.

Originally, the names Yin and Yang, male and female, referred to these two matters. Yet in the body’s upper and lower parts, there is nothing that can be named as such. The original names Yin and Yang are distinguished by these two matters.

Consider the woman: her head, eyes, face, ears, and limbs are all the same as the man’s. In her love of goodness, she may even surpass men—yet she is deemed lowly and base for this very reason. The man’s head, face, and limbs are no different, and in his love of goodness he falls short of the woman—yet he is called honorable and noble precisely for this reason.”

“Excellent, excellent!”

“Indeed, you may be said to have awakened to this truth. Thus the Dao of Heaven values the root and guards the origin, and so the sage observes the patterns of Heaven and their radiant clarity. Therefore, one must return to the root, guard the primordial, rectify characters, and examine texts to resolve confusion. Only thus can Heaven and Earth be made enduringly secure and the state joyful.

Thus, to guard the root and possess substance, to delight in bestowing—this is the good person. To be rootless, hollow, and without kernel or substance, ever deficient yet ever covetous—this is the evil person, the base person. This is what is meant.”

“Now I wish to ask one final question.”

“Proceed.”

“When a woman conceives as the Celestial Master foretold, why is there no substance?”

“Alas! You are inwardly hollow, much like one without the Dao. Yet Heaven sees your earnest and single-minded devotion, and so permits you to come and inquire. Now, in the conception of your wife: the yin root is empty, but the yang comes to bestow and transform, filling the yin. Yin, being humble and base, reveres yang, submits to it, and nourishes it, not daring to cast it away.

Yang is Heaven, the ruler; yin is Earth, the minister. Thus, it honors and reveres the bestowal of yang and thereby nourishes it, not daring to cast it away. If you wish to know its truth, consider this: when a lord has a guest who lodges in a humble household, the household nourishes him and does not dare send him away. The guest, in turn, grows robust and attains full stature—this is precisely the same principle.

The common saying goes, ‘Yang gives birth, yin brings to completion,’ but in truth, yin merely follows and nourishes, bringing the yang’s substance to fulfillment. My writings often explain it in this way. I see that you, a true person, delight in knowing the kernel of the true Dao and the utmost essential intent of Heaven, and so I have spoken to you in concise terms. Do you understand?”

“Indeed, indeed.”

“Go then, for you have awakened.”

“Now I wish to ask: only humans have male and female—can this distinction of yin and yang’s substance be made? Does it apply to all things under Heaven and Earth?”

“Alas!”

“You remain as if deluded and uncomprehending. Excellent! The true person’s questions are indeed difficult. Yet the nature of Heaven and Earth applies to all things without exception. Let me tell you something that penetrates from the highest above to the deepest below. You, as you speak, must now open both ears and listen—do not miss a single fraction.”

“Indeed, indeed.”

“Very well. When yang resides in the outer realm, all things conceive and gestate among the upper branches and leaves. At that time, Heaven’s yang qi lingers outside and has not yet returned to the roots below, so all comes to fruition at the surface. Creeping creatures, the multitude of beings, and the people all accumulate and gather outwardly. But when the yang qi returns inward to the earth below, every kind of thing above becomes empty and devoid of substance, while all conceive and bear fruit below. The earth nourishes the roots and leaves, and creeping creatures and the people likewise enter and accumulate inwardly—this is the great luminous proof by which August Heaven demonstrates the true kernel of yang’s substance. Thus, those who hold to the Dao of yang possess the true kernel, while those who cling to the Dao of yin lack it. Therefore, the sages of antiquity governed by emulating Heaven and dared not emulate Earth.”

“I wish to hear: what does it mean to emulate Heaven?”

“To emulate Heaven is to gather the benevolent, the worthy, the enlightened, the Confucian scholars, the Daoist masters, and the sagely wise—this is called emulating Heaven. To amass wealth and goods, petty men, the unworthy, and those ignorant of culture and refinement is called emulating Earth.”

“Excellent, excellent! I wish to hear: how do the benevolent, the worthy, the enlightened, the Confucian scholars, the Daoist masters, and the sagely wise emulate Heaven?”

“Heaven is the benevolent, the worthy, the enlightened, the Confucian scholars, the Daoist masters, and the sagely wise. Moreover, Heaven can ride the qi and soar—these six kinds of people, those of superior talent who remain unwavering in their devotion to the true Dao, may also attain the ability to ride the qi and soar. Thus they belong to Heaven and emulate Heaven. For this reason, the sages of antiquity alone deeply understood the intent of August Heaven and dared not lose it.”

“I wish to hear: how does gathering wealth and goods, along with petty and unworthy men, emulate Earth?”

“Indeed. Wealth gathers below and forms mud; mud transforms into dung; dung transforms into earth. The petty, the foolish, and the unworthy gather in deafness and blindness, ignorant of the Dao and its arts, entering inauspicious gates. They are destined to dwell early beneath the earth. If they are not buried, in time they become a profound harm to Heaven and Earth. To govern with them is to disrupt the patterns of Heaven and Earth, the Five Phases locked in daily strife! The four seasons lose their order, the Three Luminaries dim, Heaven and Earth detest them, and the hundred spirits do not love them. They bring no benefit to the proper ordering of things and should meet their end as swiftly as that wealth. Do you, true person, understand?”

“Indeed, indeed.”

“How terrifying! How terrifying indeed!”

“If you recognize what is terrifying, you may long endure; if you do not soon awaken to terror, you will compound Heaven and Earth’s gravest fault.”

“This foolish one stands in great awe.”

“If you revere this law of Heaven, Heaven will preserve you; if you do not hold it in awe, you will share the same principle as all that lives. For good and ill do not originate with Heaven—they are transgressions, sought and obtained by people themselves. Do you understand?”

“Indeed, indeed.”

“Go forth, and be ever vigilant.”

“Indeed, indeed.”

---
*Right: A Collection of Difficulties Concerning the Root Causes of Male and Female, Noble and Base, Yin and Yang—The Essential Distinction Between the Superior Person and the Petty Person. Formula One Hundred Thirty-Nine, of Which There Are Too Many to Count.*

**Opening:**
“May I ask one matter?”

“Speak plainly.”

“I wish to know how many states exist in the world.”

“Profound! Wondrous! The question you ask. Now, within the central region lie eighty-one domains. Beyond them, encircling once more, the world holds ten thousand states, extending even to the boundless reaches of the Cavernous Void, where the three divisions together comprise twelve thousand states.”

**Closing:**
“Why then are there twelve thousand states?”

“The celestial reckoning begins with one and ends with ten. Ten multiplied yields the Way of Heaven, which reaches five and then returns. Thus it arrives at ten thousand states. The remaining two thousand correspond to the alternating reckoning of yin and yang, as when numbers end at ten. The reckoning of years and months stands alone at twelve, with an intercalary month added every five years. This reflects the cyclical arising of Heaven and Earth, the inner and outer of the Cavernous Void of Heaven. It accords with the combined reckoning of Heaven and Earth, so that twelve months return and merge into one year, with the intercalary month following within. These twelve months are the reckoning of the primordial qi’s hidden depths, the alternating inception of yin and yang. It is as when the myriad things perish in *hai*, and the celestial stems begin their cycle, establishing position at the Gate of Heaven. The first coagulation occurs in *hai*, gestation in *ren*, and formation takes shape. The first nine returns on the day of *zi*; the second nine in *chou*, where yin and yang revolve; the third nine in *yin*, when Heaven, Earth, and humanity—all things—turn from yin toward yang, gazing toward *yin*. Thus the myriad things first spread their roots in the northeast and show their heads in *yin*. The greatest of things take wood as their elder, so *yin* marks the beginning of wood’s birth. *Jia* is wood’s primal stem, so all things appear in *jia-yin* and perish in *gui-hai*. Thus wood receives its mandate and life from the primordial qi within the Great Yin’s water, and so *jia-zi* is taken as the beginning. The celestial reckoning of change revolves through fivefold multiplication, so five thousand added to the twelve earthly branches makes sixty, with *gui-hai* as the reckoning’s end. Do you, true person, understand?”

“Indeed, indeed.”

“I have not yet grasped its meaning.”

“Now you wander in darkness—ponder it long and deeply, and the meaning will come to you. Go, ponder it.

Why does the true person constantly ask how many states there are under Heaven?”

“This foolish student has received the Celestial Master’s writings, which can repay Heaven and Earth’s profound merit, heal Heaven and Earth’s illnesses, and relieve the virtuous emperor of the accumulated disasters and calamities since the founding of Heaven and Earth. Now, with the Celestial Master’s scripture of the One Dao, I entrust it to a single virtuous state. Yet even if that state’s ruler possesses the virtue of ten thousand men, how can he alone resolve the boundless disasters of yin and yang in Heaven and Earth? How can he circulate throughout and govern the inner and outer realms of Heaven and Earth, cutting off the illnesses of the infinite, hollow, and distant?”

“Ah! Well said. Did Heaven prompt you to ask this? Alas! How astonishing! Alas! How astonishing! I wished to remain silent, but now I fear that failing to remove this great misfortune would be my fault. True person, how did you come to ask this?”

“This foolish student, having received the Celestial Master’s teachings, returned to my dwelling to reflect upon their meaning. Where I found uncertainty, I asked.”

“Now you understand only that a single state has a virtuous ruler—why do you ask this?”

“If the Celestial Master’s scripture merely resolves the disasters of one virtuous state, it would only heal a single realm. How then could it heal the illnesses of Heaven and Earth and repay the August Heaven’s profound merit?”

“Excellent! Your words are well spoken.”

“There is nothing I can add to your words. True person, pray expound your meaning.”

“Very well. Now, the Celestial Master speaks of Heaven and Earth as vast and hollow, containing twelve thousand states. If only one virtuous state receives the Dao, how can it resolve the disasters of all twelve thousand states and bring universal peace to Heaven and Earth?”

“Excellent! Your words are most apt. Did the Lord of Destiny indeed prompt you to ask this?”

“Indeed.”

“Now, for the true person, I shall explain in full, that the matter may be made clear and all illnesses and disasters under Heaven may be wholly eradicated. I stand in awe of Heaven’s majesty and dare not conceal anything. Apply your strength to record my words.”

“Understood.”

“Attend: the celestial reckoning begins with one and ends with ten. One multiplied by ten is ten. Each ten multiplied by ten reaches one hundred; one hundred multiplied by ten reaches one thousand; one thousand multiplied by ten reaches ten thousand. One is the beginning of numbers; ten is their end. One hundred represents the virtuous states and regions. You need only take my scripture and go forth to teach one state of great virtue. Those who transmit my scripture shall carry the original and never exhaust it, circulating it to bestow upon one hundred virtuous regions. When one state receives my scripture, its good people will all turn toward it, and its virtue will spread to the four directions. One hundred states will all be transformed by its influence and become good. Thus, Heaven and Earth will both be at peace, disasters will be removed, and by bestowing it upon one hundred virtuous states, the ten thousand states will suffer no harm, and all illnesses of Heaven and Earth will be eradicated.”

“Excellent! Excellent! I wish to hear why you do not teach this to me so that I may instruct others.”

“Ah, the reason it cannot be taught in such a manner is that states without virtue are those Heaven has doomed to decline and cannot practice the true Dao. Thus, they must turn toward the virtuous states. Now, if the virtueless states all turn toward those with virtue and power, they too will naturally be governed.”

“Excellent! Excellent! I wish to hear why you take precisely these one hundred virtuous states as the model.”

“Excellent! Your question strikes at the heart of the matter.”

“Now, the numbers of Heaven, Earth, and humanity follow this principle: Heaven’s number begins with one and ends with ten. When Heaven distributes its bounty upon Earth, life emerges, and only after the numbers are complete do they manifest—fittingly forming one hundred. When Heaven, Earth, and humanity are all present, and these three unite in a single heart, then virtue is achieved. If even one matter is not in harmony, then virtue and power cannot be realized.”

“I wish to hear why Heaven’s number begins precisely with one.”

“One represents the time when primordial *qi* is utterly pure. Primordial *qi* coalesces without pattern, just as wind has no fixed form—thus it is collectively named ‘one.’ When one congeals, it forms Heaven. Heaven possesses above and below, the eight directions, hence it is ten. Additionally, there are the five directions, each with its own yin and yang, thus the number is ten. Below, it corresponds to Earth. That which descends to correspond with Earth—its numbers, too, are complete at ten before life arises. Thus, humans mirror Heaven’s number, being born only after ten months. One is precisely the time when its bestowal is harmonious and all-pervading. Those who have already received this bestowal must in turn mirror Heaven’s number, emerging only after ten months—hence the number concludes at ten. Therefore, one multiplies ten. The Way of Earth is the mother; it aligns with the center, thus uniting with harmony and connecting to humanity. Only when Heaven, Earth, and humanity mutually attain one another is virtue and power achieved—hence the one hundred virtuous states. Thus, Heaven governs birth, Earth governs nurturance, and humanity governs completion. If even one matter strays from correctness, all three fall into error. Therefore, if Heaven acts wickedly, it brings misfortune; if Earth acts wickedly, it brings misfortune; if humanity acts wickedly, it brings misfortune. When all three act wickedly together, Heaven, Earth, and humanity are extinguished and their numbers begin anew. When all three act with goodness, virtue pervades emptiness and unites as one. Thus, only when the three unite is virtue achieved—fittingly, the one hundred states.”

“Excellent! Excellent!”

“This is the guiding principle of the ten thousand states, the realm where Heaven, Earth, and humanity unite in virtue. Do you understand?”

“Indeed, indeed.”

“Thus, the Perfected One has now eradicated illness from Heaven and Earth and removed the burden of inherited transgressions for the Lord of Virtue. Though you endure hardship in upholding my scriptures and transmitting them to the hundred virtuous states, all afflictions of yin and yang shall vanish, and the calamities of emperors and kings shall all be dispelled.”

“Excellent! Excellent! Had this foolish student not pressed his inquiries with diligence, there would have been no means to attain this knowledge.”

“Your words are apt. To study without diligent inquiry is no different from not studying at all. Thus, the sages and worthies of antiquity questioned their teachers day and night without daring to slacken, and so they came to comprehend the Dao of Heaven.”

“Indeed, indeed. With earnest inquiry, I dare not grow remiss.”

“In this way, you have already grasped the Dao.”

“I wish to ask: today, the customs of the world vary—if one were to teach and admonish them with a single Dao, would there be no doubt?”

“Alas! In speaking thus, you reveal yourself to be even more foolish, benighted, and ignorant. Why is this? The rites and propriety of these customs are but false conduct, not their true nature. All under Heaven receive the nature of Heaven and Earth, with the Five Phases as their storehouse and the four seasons as their qi. They harmonize yin and yang to propagate their kind, all delighting in life and abhorring death, all partaking of food and drink to nourish their bodies, all loving goodness and detesting evil—there is no difference among them. As for those who do not comprehend the Perfected One’s scriptures and fail to grasp them, when instructing them, the Perfected One should employ their local language and customary teachings, adapting to their ways so that they may commit the words to memory through their own effort. In this manner, all under Heaven will know how to apply them without doubt. My Dao is like the sun and moon, circulating and illuminating all beneath Heaven, each perceiving its brilliance clearly, vast and luminous in full measure. If you wish to further verify its truth, consider the myriad creatures—even the crawling insects—all share one Heaven and Earth, the Six Jia, the Five Phases, and the four seasons, and this is more than sufficient. Thus, all are taught according to the standards of Heaven and Earth, yin and yang. Do you understand?”

“Indeed, indeed.”

“Go forth. If difficulties do not cease, the explanations will be endless. Now, the great scriptures of the Dao are, on the contrary, difficult to fathom.”

“Indeed, indeed. I wish to ask one more matter and then desist.”

“Speak.”

“What of the twelve thousand states?”

“These are included within the reckoning, like intercalary months. If you wish to know the details, consider this: in counting, ten marks the end, yet a year concludes only after twelve months, with an intercalary month sometimes added, making thirteen. This is what is meant. But when the hundred states practice virtue, the ten thousand states will be free of calamity, and the illnesses of Heaven and Earth will be entirely dispelled—this, too, is removed as one.”

“Excellent! Excellent!”

“If you exert yourself and circulate my scriptures among the hundred virtuous states, adapting the teachings to each custom, then the twelve thousand states will all be at peace, the illnesses of Heaven and Earth will be greatly dispelled, and your years will increase without limit. If you find peace in your youth, you will attain youthful longevity; if you find peace in middle age, you will attain middle-aged longevity; if you find complete peace, you will attain boundless years. Since the Perfected One harbors good intentions, Heaven has ordained that you ask these questions in full—you should thus attain full peace, without subjecting yourself to great toil. For Heaven, though supremely divine and luminous, without peer, still constantly practices the Dao with arduous effort, completing one circuit each day. All things find peace in this, and thus alone attain perpetual fortune and long life. Earth, too, follows Heaven’s actions and nurtures accordingly. If Heaven were to cease its daily movement, the sun, moon, and stars would not shift, and there would be an imbalance of qi—Heaven would then perish. Since Heaven practices the Dao without ceasing, it attains long life—how much more so should you? Strive, each bending effort for your own sake, not for others. My unceasing explanations are also for my own sake, not for yours. All beings, from the Six Extremes to the myriad creatures, each calculate for their own benefit and cannot do so for others. Do you understand?”

“Indeed, indeed.”

“Having received the Heavenly Master’s words and deeds, I have had them recorded in the state of the virtuous, never daring to slacken.”

“Excellent. You have already grasped this. All of you, strive, strive—once your tasks are complete, we shall meet again.”

“Indeed, indeed. Before departing, I wish to ask one matter.”

“What is it?”

“Now the six of us will return to our quiet dwelling to ponder the Heavenly Master’s words. At times, we seem on the verge of profound understanding, yet at others, we fall into confusion and negligence. We wish to seek the Heavenly Master’s resolution of these doubts. Though I hesitate to trouble you further, fearing separation until the end of our natural years without another chance to learn, I overcome my shame and venture to request one more word.”

“Proceed. Heaven has ordained that I meet and speak with you six—do not decline.”

“Indeed, indeed. Now I wish to ask: of all the states under Heaven, are there only twelve thousand? Or are there more?”

“Ah! How profound your question! Since the opening of Heaven and Earth, none have asked thus. Yet these twelve thousand states are but one great division; what limit could there be to the rest?”

“Why are they so numerous?”

“Ah! You now ask what lies at the very bounds of knowledge, yet you remain shrouded in darkness—truly, you do not yet comprehend. Still, observing your questions, I see you have not fully fathomed the Dao of Heaven. You seem on the verge of grasping it, yet inwardly, you fall short. The common folk dwell in ignorance and confusion—this is their nature. Compared to a Perfected One, I do not fault you. Yet I shall open your ears further and explain for the six of you.

Heaven extends upward and downward without limit, and outward without bound. Wherever it converges, it forms a division of boundaries—how could there be an end to its divisions? Now, tell me: where does the uppermost Heaven reach its limit? What lies beyond it, and where does it find its ultimate boundary? Where does the lowermost Earth reach its limit? What lies beneath it, and where does it find its final boundary? Where does Heaven and Earth extend outward to their limit, and why do they turn back upon reaching the middle? These six directions—where do they find their end? Thus, the Dao of Heaven is without limit or cessation. In great use, it suffices; in small use, it suffices. In great use, it abounds; in small use, it abounds. Do you Perfected Ones understand this?”

“Indeed, indeed.”

Alas! How astonishing! Alas! Had you not pressed your inquiry with such vigor, there would have been no way to attain this knowledge.”

“Indeed, you may be said to have glimpsed a small awakening. Go now, and ask no further. I fear the Six Perfected Ones would be startled and undone—for this lies beyond the reach of human effort, and to force the question is to invite great harm. Yet the burden of a teacher is heavy, and seeing your distress, I shall clarify further for you. Go, and listen with open ears. Sit calmly and attend.”

“Very well.”

“If you wish to delight in understanding its vast effects, consider this: a single household has a father, a mother, and a child—this, too, is a complete family under the Dao of Heaven. The father resembles Heaven, the mother resembles Earth, and the child resembles the harmony between them. Their gathered possessions, all that the household contains, resemble the myriad things—thus forming a single family. The father is as the ruler, the mother as the minister, the child as the people, and their wealth circulates to nourish one another, just as the myriad things do. This one family shares a single great concern. A single district of ten thousand households likewise forms one family, sharing one great concern. Ten districts unite to form a commandery, also one family, sharing one great concern. Ten commanderies unite to form a great province, also one family, sharing one great concern. Ten provinces unite to form a great state, also one great family, sharing one great concern, and thus forming one great boundary.

When the emperor possesses virtue, his concern extends to the twelve provinces; when his great concern reaches the thirteen provinces, they too become one great family, sharing one great concern. Beyond this boundary, in distant lands not subject to human rule, if a realm possesses the Dao and virtue, its good people come; if it lacks the Dao and virtue, they do not come; if its virtue is inferior, they come to harm others. This is one division, one boundary—the demarcation of Heaven and Earth—so that the restless multitudes of the world each have their place and do not prey upon one another.

Thus, what is called the Great Ultimate, the Central Ultimate, and the Small Ultimate? The Great Ultimate governs what has no further outer boundary; the Central Ultimate governs the central division; the Small Ultimate governs each division’s boundary, where it must halt. They may only seek one another through the Dao and virtue, not through mutual predation. Heaven resents this—hence, this is called ‘sharing one family,’ and thus each shares one great concern.

If you wish to know its true essence, consider a household of father, son, husband, and wife: they worry only that their own family may not prosper, and do not concern themselves with other households. A single district shares concern for its ruler—if he is good, they promote him to higher office, each striving to advance their local officials; if he is evil, they wish to remove him together. A district, a commandery, a province, a state—all follow this principle, sharing one great concern.

Now, I record the twelve thousand states as one great division, to share one great concern with the Perfected Ones, one boundary. The remaining states beyond these twelve thousand are beyond counting. Thus, the sages of antiquity all recorded only small divisions—why did they not record the great boundaries? Heaven did not permit it. The great transformation had not yet emerged, and what they produced differed, so they could not follow the same method. Thus, they did not record it.

Now, the great transformation has emerged, and the twelve thousand states have completed their cyclical revolutions. Therefore, Heaven has sent the Perfected Ones to inquire into the scripture of the boundless and the governance of ultimate penetration. Thus, I entrust this text to the hundred states possessing virtue, where one virtuous state transforms ninety-nine others. The twelve thousand states are counted together, like the twelve months of a year forming one division, with the thirteenth month as an intercalary month—this is what is meant. Do you understand?”

“Very well.”

“Go now.”
“Very well.”

“Guard it with reverence for the divine spirits of the Heavenly Dao. Do not recklessly corrupt or destroy it.”
“Very well. Now that I have received the solemn decree of the Heavenly Illuminated Master, my heart trembles with awe. Though I have only grasped a fraction of the great scripture, I wish to hear of even a single small realm—to be shown and told of this boundless land.”
“Very well. Since the Perfected One is anxious, I shall speak briefly. Take careful note. Now, I intend for the Perfected One to amass wealth and resources, supporting the sun and moon above and the earth below. Spanning ten thousand *li* in breadth and length, I fear that resources will still be perpetually scarce and troubled. I cannot recount the names and numbers of all its lands. Do you understand?”
“Very well. This foolish one dares not press further on the Heavenly Dao. Hearing the Celestial Master’s words, I feel as though my *qi* has scattered, my soul as if lost. I dare not ask again.”
“Indeed, you may be called a student who understands matters. If you wish to repay the profound merit of Heaven and Earth and attain boundless life, simply traverse the twelve thousand lands of this great scripture, and your longevity will already be without limit. As for the six directions above and below reaching their utmost extremes, Heaven does not task the Six Masters alone with their concerns. Those who worry over them belong to another realm, and you will not be held accountable or blamed for transgressions. Their safety or peril, good or ill, have their own masters. This discourse on the scripture is concluded. Do not ask further.”
“Very well.”

“Go now. The Six Masters, exert yourselves—pray continue. The Perfected One’s learning has attained minor penetration, yet the great vision of the Heavenly Dao’s intent remains unseen. Apply greater focus and do not slacken.”

“Very well.”

“Learning without precision is no different from madness; precision without attainment is like being mute and deaf, pointing west only to ask about the east. Thus, when all the masters under Heaven engage in debate and disputation—though they may ●●●●—it is of no benefit, for they remain ignorant. It is like an infant still swaddled, not yet emerged from the womb, following its mother’s body in movement, how could it know the vastness and boundlessness of the Heavenly Dao? Therefore, lesser masters, in their anger and wild enthusiasm, expound recklessly, thereby wounding the Dao of Heaven and Earth. Losing the Dao’s intent, they cannot bring peace to their lord and king; the realm’s ●●●● all suffer their errors, their words diverging wildly. This allows calamities to spread unchecked, beyond restraint or prevention. Though books may number in the billions, the world’s disasters and harms remain unceasing, ever recurring in the same patterns—all arising from forced exposition, from the error of not knowing the essentials of the Dao. Does the Perfected One understand this?”

“Very well.”

“If I were to fully expound this for you, it would be endless and exhausting in both effort and resources, and moreover, overly burdensome—thus I shall pause here for now. If doubts remain, return to ask again.”
“Very well.”

*Right: Collected Difficult Questions and Transmitted Scriptural Secrets of the Various States and Regions*
*Reverently Serving the Spirits: Fifteenth Year of Great Peace, Secret One Hundred Forty*

“May I ask one matter?”
“Speak plainly.”
“Now that the era approaches Great Peace, can this be foreknown?”
“Yes, it can be known. By observing the five Celestial Emperors’ *qi* of Great Peace, one may know whether the coming year will be harmonious and balanced.”
“What does this mean? I wish to hear it.”
“Thus: in spring, when the Green Emperor’s *qi* is at peace; in summer, when the Red Emperor’s *qi* is at peace; in the sixth month, when the Yellow Emperor’s *qi* is at peace; in autumn, when the White Emperor’s *qi* is at peace; and in winter, when the Black Emperor’s *qi* is at peace.”
“By what means is this made clear?”
“Thus: Great Peace means that not a single thing is harmed—this is the meaning of the *qi* of Great Peace. If all matters proceed without a single injury or affliction, each attaining its proper place, then it is called ‘balanced.’ If one thing is harmed, it is immediately unbalanced; if two things are harmed, it is immediately subject to punishment; if three things are harmed, it is immediately a harm to all things; if four things are harmed, it is immediately a harm to the four directions; if five things are harmed, it is immediately a harm to the five directions, and the world suffers great calamity; if six things are harmed, it is immediately an evil that pervades the six directions; if seven things are harmed, its baleful *qi* spreads unchecked; if eight things are harmed, the worthy and the unworthy diverge in purpose and do not unite in effort; if nine things are harmed, evil thoroughly disrupts the balance of *yin* and *yang*, causing all things to churn in chaos; if ten things are harmed, the great principles are injured, and the celestial reckoning is exhausted, giving way to a new cycle. Therefore, the ancient supreme sages merely observed whether the five Celestial Emperors’ *qi* was balanced or not, and thereby knew whether governance was successful and whether peace had been achieved.”
“I wish to hear the essential meaning of this balanced secret.”
“Thus: when all things in spring are born without a single harm, it is the Great Peace of the Green Emperor. When all things in summer grow without a single harm, it is the Great Peace of the Red Emperor. When all things in the sixth month are nurtured without a single harm, it is the Great Peace of the Yellow Emperor. When all things in autumn mature and are harvested without a single harm, it is the Great Peace of the White Emperor. When all things in winter are stored without a single harm, it is the Great Peace of the Black Emperor. When the five Emperors arise in Great Peace for one year, the people rejoice and act with goodness; for two years, the earth is filled with joy; for three years, their beneficence reaches to Heaven; for four years, the winds and *qi* flow in harmony; for five years, the nine spirits do not contend, and malevolent forces are subdued; for six years, the six principles are fully established; for seven years, the Three Luminaries shine with greater brilliance; for eight years, their grace extends to the eight directions; for nine years, *yin* and *yang* are both content; for ten years, the myriad things each attain their proper place. This completes the lesser cycle, and when the three are conjoined, Heaven, Earth, and Humanity are complete—thus, thirty years bring Great Peace. Now, the *qi* of the Supreme Sovereign has emerged, and the true Dao has arrived to govern, so Great Peace comes in fifteen years. If one does not diligently practice the true Dao, how can Great Peace be attained in vain? This fifteen-year path to Great Peace refers to the emperor, his ministers great and small, all following the true Dao, jointly dispelling falsehood and deceit—thus, in fifteen years, peace is achieved. Do you understand, Perfected One? Therefore, to know whether peace is approaching or not, simply observe whether the five Celestial Emperors’ *qi* is balanced or not—this is sufficient for clarity, sufficient for understanding. Thus, all omens first appear among the celestial spirits. If the celestial spirits are not at peace, how can humans alone claim to be at peace? Therefore, as the five Emperors take turns governing, each can bring about Great Peace. Those who lose the celestial spirits’ favor cannot bring peace to their rule. Thus, one must carefully follow the four seasons, attend to the five phases, and ensure the nine spirits do not contend. Therefore, one must revere their conduct and serve their spirits. Now, the foremost *qi* of Great Peace is approaching, so I instruct the Perfected One to revere the four seasons and five phases, and to have all people, great and small, together engage in the service of the spirits. In ancient times, merely revering the four seasons and five phases brought Great Peace, though it took thirty years to achieve. Now, by also revering their spirits, peace is swiftly attained in fifteen years. Do you understand, Perfected One?”
“Very well.”

“How astonishing! How astonishing!”

“Yet you have already perceived it.”

“I wish to ask: if a person’s conduct is loyal and upright with true substance, can this be known?”

“Excellent! The question you ask. When one associates with them, if their words and deeds grow daily more harsh and resentful, yet others long remember them, and by the next month they have become good; if in a month they are harsh and resentful, yet by the next year they have become good; if in youth their actions seem most wicked, yet in old age they become most good—if all turn to their words, delight in their conduct, and cherish their Dao, then this is a person of utmost loyalty, trustworthiness, and goodness, one of true and solid substance.”

“Excellent! Excellent! I further wish to ask: can one also recognize those who are disloyal, untrustworthy, and given to flattery?”

“Yes, this too can be known. When one associates with them, observe their words and deeds: day by day, month by month, they align with others’ hearts. If they appear compliant and good, yet when long remembered and put into practice, by the next month they make others grow more wicked; if in a month they seem good, yet by the next year they turn wicked; if in youth they seem good, their words appearing loyal and trustworthy, yet in old age, when their actions are long remembered and put into practice, they reveal themselves as most wicked—this is entirely the conduct of a false, flattering, disloyal, and untrustworthy person. In old age, when their words and deeds are thoroughly examined, they are held in utmost contempt. Disaster befalls their wives and children, and calamity flows to later generations.”

“Excellent! Excellent!”

**Method of Disaster from Matching Words but Not Deeds, One Hundred Forty-First**

“Since the Highest and Middle Antiquity, people have often matched words but not deeds, thus inviting disasters, harms, illnesses, and accumulated misfortunes that cannot be dispelled—thereby bringing ruin upon themselves. Therefore, I reverently received this Dao from Heaven, matching only truth and sincerity, not empty words.

Those who grasp the One and practice the Dao in my writings—though people of later ages may say daily that my Dao is harmful and of no benefit, by the next month it proves good; though they say monthly it is of no benefit, by the next year it proves good; though they say yearly it is of no benefit, by old age it remains constantly good, enduring without departure. Later generations will take it as the learning of their age. Those who do not know to act swiftly suffer only in vain, enduring hardship for a lifetime.

Thus, I instruct and admonish the Perfected Ones to be ever diligent and earnest. The Dao emerges for those of virtue; the first and the last are equally without special favor from me—I receive them all alike. Therefore, only those who obtain and strive to practice it are such people; there is no distinction between the first and the second. Do you understand?”

“Indeed, indeed.”

“Act! The Way of Heaven is impartial, returning to humanity; the virtue of Earth is selfless, bestowed upon the reverent. In human relations, there is no before or after—only love for those of true sincerity. Thus, the ancient emperors and kings had palaces to employ the virtuous, not to employ ministers without merit. The virtuous are beloved by Heaven and Earth and can assist rulers in pacifying the myriad things; the virtueless are resented by Heaven and Earth, thieves of yin and yang.”

“Why is this so weighty?”

“Are you still so foolish? The virtueless, in their countless deeds, go against Heaven and Earth—thus becoming their enemies; they disrupt yin and yang—thus becoming their thieves. Do you understand?”

“...”

“Indeed, indeed.”

“Go now, ask no more—good and evil may be seen for yourself.”

“Indeed, indeed.”

“Go, for I am troubled on your behalf. Let me now distinguish and explain the conduct of people in later ages. Every person claims to be wise and well-versed in affairs, yet when their conduct is examined, it contradicts the virtue of the moon—evil. Every month, each claims to have performed good deeds and not betrayed Heaven, yet when the year is reviewed, they meet with many disasters, misfortune, and early death. In youth, each declares themselves good and greatly virtuous, surpassing even their father and mother, yet as they grow old, not one proves truly good or virtuous—all become unworthy. They share in poverty and lowliness, their lifespans grow ever shorter, and not one knows the true Way. Thus, in later ages, the good and evil, the worthy and unworthy, are revealed in this. Why must one claim to be virtuous and knowledgeable? Simply observe the signs, and you may know for yourself—discern what is enduring and true, what is real and false. Why argue further? The matter is already settled.

The true person, through my written words, shows this to awaken them, lest they remain lost in delusion for ages and incur the deep resentment of Heaven and Earth. Go now—my words here are briefly concluded. If later you have doubts, return, and we shall discuss them together.”

“Indeed, indeed.”
