**Right Collection: Difficult Questions on the *Tai Ping Jue* Regarding the Sincerity or Deceit of Human Conduct**
*Collated and Combined Text of the* Tai Ping Jing*, Scrolls 94–95, Ji Section 9, Part 10*
*(Title Missing)*

The Divine Person addressed the True Person, saying: “In the earliest days of seeking the Dao, the spirit wanders yet guards softness to preserve itself. By accumulating virtue without cease, the Dao leads one to transcendence—riding clouds, mounting dragons, entering the gates of Heaven, following the celestial revolutions as if in an endless cycle.

The True Person, through single-minded devotion, attains longevity, their fate linked to Heaven. The Yang Dao, through steadfast accumulation, reaches its singular and faithful culmination. Without contending for glory or rank, one ascends to high office. By serving the teacher with filial reverence, the Dao comes of itself. The spirits then recognize one’s goodness and engage in discourse.

The teacher is the one who dispels darkness to reveal the Dao’s beginning. Ruler, father, and teacher—these are the gates of destiny under Heaven. To revere and serve these three is to invite the Dao’s great unfolding. To neglect them is to seal one’s chamber, leaving no door; all blessings and virtue flee, while calamity and chaos take pity.

Examine these matters closely, and do not stray from the written word. Parents give life, the teacher imparts its proper course, and one serves in kinship and office—how could one not be cautious? The noblest under Heaven abandon rank to pursue transcendence, for the immortal’s time is boundless, their fate linked to Heaven.

Local officials govern the people; immortal officials serve as Heaven’s officers—what business have they with the mundane? Their duties differ. Local officials govern the people and the myriad spirits; all matters under Heaven have their own lords. Strive to cultivate goodness, and your person may remain whole. Thus departing, you do not betray your ancestors.

My illustrated texts are now exhausted; nothing more remains to be set forth. Exert yourself in study, and scrutinize their words carefully.”

The Divine Person was about to depart, so he admonished the True Person: “Be cautious, be ever cautious. Do not transmit this recklessly. If the recipient is unworthy, guard against revealing it. Conceal it in the depths of the abyss, in the hidden dark, for the Dao does not drink blood, nor does it speak of essential texts. All that should be known, inner and outer, has been made clear—nothing more remains to be said.”

*Collated and Combined Text of the* Tai Ping Jing*, Scroll 96, Ji Section 11*
*Tai Ping Jing, Scroll 96*

“The Six Ultimates and Six Culminations of Filial Piety and Loyalty, Scroll 151

The True Person stepped forward, saying, ‘You and I have long studied the texts of the Heavenly Dao—could we have exhausted their vast divisions and boundaries? How many divisions does our Dao comprise? What constitutes its ultimate? What marks its great culmination?’

‘Within the texts lies the Dao,’ I replied. ‘The Six Ultimates and Six Culminations—though I now speak of them, I do not know what they truly are.’

‘Alas!’ he exclaimed. ‘Your foolishness remains unopened, and your learning, though earnest, has not yet attained refinement. Thus you do not grasp where the Dao reaches its utmost.’

‘I have failed my Heavenly Master,’ I said. ‘This fault cannot be erased—I do not deny it.’

‘Why does the True Person reproach himself so severely?’

‘I have heard: if a son is unfilial, he cannot exert himself to nourish his parents; if a disciple is disobedient, he cannot devote himself to illuminating his master’s Way; if a minister is disloyal, he cannot fully respect and serve his lord. Failing in these three deeds incurs an ineradicable guilt. Heaven and Earth abhor it; ghosts and spirits harm it; all people despise it. Even in death, the blame lingers below the earth—such a one is called a son of the three unrighteous deeds. Each month’s end and new moon, he is arraigned before Heaven, which governs the rectification of yin and yang. The spirits and officials of the noble and base grieve for his soul, and this continues until his destruction.

Thus, knowing my own lack of refinement, I acknowledge my unabsolved transgression against my master.’

‘Excellent! Excellent! Where did you learn these words?’

‘From my former master. Moreover, I glimpsed the Heavenly Master’s teachings and received his methods. I saw the celestial signs: Heaven and Earth are the parents of the four seasons and five phases. If the four seasons and five phases do not exert themselves to supply what Heaven and Earth desire to generate, they are unfilial sons—such years yield few good things and become inauspicious. Humans, too, are the children of Heaven and Earth. If a child does not diligently nourish what Heaven and Earth produce, he is called an unfilial son. Thus, those who favor harsh punishments bring constant disorder, peril, and ruin to their states.

All things wax and wane with the four seasons and five phases, growing and nurturing themselves—these are their disciples. If they cannot fully follow the seasonal qi to mature and bear fruit, they are disobedient disciples. The year’s harvest harms people, and the blame is reversed. If the seasonal qi is disharmonious, the fault lies doubly with the seasons.

The people are the disciples of sages and worthies. Now, foolish disciples recklessly steal and forcefully expound, causing sages and worthies to incur blame—this is called collectively disrupting and rebelling against the Heavenly Dao. The crime is grave and unforgivable; thus, my fault remains unabsolved.

Wind and rain are the loyal ministers of Heaven and Earth. Receiving Heaven’s mandate, they distribute qi and moisture. If they fail to regulate them evenly, the world becomes unbalanced. This is like a minister receiving the emperor’s command, yet turning against his superior and favoring subordinates, using his mind unevenly. If many ministers act disloyally and deceive their ruler, the world becomes rife with contention, and the state’s governance falls into peril and chaos.

Compared to these three matters—sons who are unfilial, disciples who are disobedient, and ministers who are disloyal—none of their crimes merit pardon. Heaven detests them swiftly; Earth abhors them deeply. They are deemed grave affairs, great calamities. Ghosts and spirits condemn them, making them the most vile and base of deeds.’

‘Ah!’ he sighed. ‘The True Person has long concealed wisdom, feigning foolishness, causing me to speak recklessly—my words have overstepped Heaven and Earth. What I have said does not compare to the depth and breadth of your present words.’

‘My thoughts have merely reached this point,’ I replied. ‘I can say no more.’

‘Great humility! Yet even this is not excessive. To be lowly without humility—such a fault is also grave.’

‘Indeed, indeed—I dare not, I dare not. As a disciple, I cannot clarify the boundaries of the master’s Way. Knowing my fault is grave, I have spoken of the celestial signs to reproach myself.’

‘Excellent! Your words leave me nothing to add.’”

“Now, comparing with your words, you have already understood—you have grasped the boundaries of the written teachings, yet in truth you have not yet attained them. Since you truly have not attained them, I shall explain them in full detail for you, arranging them in proper order with clear boundaries, so that they may never be forgotten for ten thousand generations.

The True Person has said that if a person’s three actions do not accord with cultivated goodness, their hun and po souls will face the most precise reckoning. From whom did you receive this teaching?

“It is like when the Celestial Master met with the former masters, who themselves spoke of the precepts of the Ancient True Persons. I have taken these words to heart, and have also seen them recorded in the Celestial Master’s writings, thus confirming their weight. I asked: in the time of the Ancient True Persons, were there not doubts or uncertainties about these matters?”

“Indeed, the words of the Ancient True Persons are correct—I have nothing to add.”

“Now I wish to ask the Celestial Master to clarify this meaning. Listen carefully.”

“Very well. The reckoning at the end of the month and the end of the year does not apply only to the hun and po souls of those who, in life, were unfilial, disobedient, disloyal, or committed great rebellious evils—it is the same for all spirits under Heaven and Earth.

Heaven takes fifteen days as a minor boundary, thus the moon turns back after reaching the fifteenth day. A month is taken as the middle boundary, and a year as the great boundary. Between Heaven and Earth, all spirit-essences assist Heaven in nurturing and sustaining the twelve thousand things, and thus all spirit-essences receive their allotted emoluments.

It is like worthy ministers assisting the Emperor in nurturing and sustaining the common people and the myriad things—all receive their emoluments. Therefore, following Heaven’s model, there is a minor reckoning every fifteen days, a middle reckoning every month, and a great reckoning every year.

Those with great merit are promoted and raised in rank, while those without merit are demoted or dismissed, or even punished. Those who disrupt the order are the spirits of perverse evil. The spirits of perverse evil act accordingly.

Thus, when an evil person is alive, their hun and po souls are both subject to reckoning, but the hun and po souls of good people refuse to serve them. Therefore, the disloyal, unfilial, disobedient, and disloyal are made to serve them, together disrupting Heaven’s order and defiling Heaven’s governance. Thus, their evil spirits are seized and punished, and their guests are seized and punished along with them.

It is like rebellious and evil ministers committing outrages—even their guests are implicated in their crimes. This is what it means.”

“Excellent! Excellent! I now understand.”

“Thus, from the moment of birth, as a child one must be filial, as a subject one must be loyal, and as a disciple one must be obedient. If filial piety, loyalty, and obedience never leave one’s person, then after death the hun and po souls and the spirit-essence will not be subject to reckoning. Do you understand this?”

“Indeed, indeed. How astonishing! How astonishing! Now, only through the Master’s gracious instruction have I glimpsed the vastness of Heaven’s laws and patterns. I pray you do not abandon me midway, but reveal to me the full extent of the scriptures and their divisions as they reach their destinations.”

“Very well. The general outline of your question I shall still address. If I did not speak of it, that would be called begrudging the Dao, halting the work of study and thus incurring Heaven’s displeasure.”

“Understood. Let the Six Perfected Ones be seated at ease while I distinguish their divisions for you. There are six branches under one great collection. Those who guard the One follow their kind, and from ancient times to the present, those who guard the One find their texts largely the same. The greatly worthy who see my texts and guard and practice them without ceasing, who delve into them to grasp their essential meaning—such as those who study to become filial children, those who study further to become loyal subjects, and those who study to the end of their days without pause or slackening—all may attain deliverance from the world. There are yet further methods: if one practices without ceasing, one may even penetrate the six directions and eight limits, and when all affairs are complete, what could be lacking? Above, one may then assist the virtuous Imperial Lords in harmonizing Heaven and Earth, and their grace will extend downward even to the grasses and trees. All things, from the teeming multitudes to the smallest creatures, will be perfectly ordered. Heaven and Earth will rejoice, and the Emperor will enjoy long leisure, playing the zither and singing in joy, free from all care. Do you understand this?”

“Indeed, indeed.”

“The moderately worthy who guard and practice with diligence, reflecting day and night on their meaning, may still become filial children in youth and good ministers in maturity, aiding the state in achieving great peace. The whole world will submit, and none will fail to praise them. Outwardly respectful and inwardly sincere, each will examine and correct themselves, daring not betray Heaven and Earth nor deceive their superiors. If all the worthy join together in striving to practice thus, they will enable the ruler’s governance to resemble Heaven’s, modeling their conduct on Heaven’s Way. Their kindness and love will extend downward even to the grasses and trees, the mosquitoes and gnats, all finding their proper place. Do you understand this?”

“Indeed, indeed.”

“If all people guard and study these teachings, jointly striving to practice them, yet still indulge in frivolous pleasures and cannot restrain themselves, they will cause fathers to be kind, mothers loving, children filial, wives obedient, elder brothers virtuous, and younger brothers respectful. Neighbors and villagers will all delight in doing good, no longer harboring malice or theft nor inflicting harm upon one another. When all people delight in loyalty, obedience, and filial piety, aspiring to emulate the moderately worthy and the greatly worthy, they will cease to commit evil. Each household and each person will admonish and govern themselves, thus enabling governance without punishments. When the high, the middling, and the low all practice this, the world will immediately attain peace without delay. Do you understand this?”

“Indeed, indeed.”

**Chapter 152: Entering the Chamber to Guard the One and Know the Divine Precepts**

“Thus, the Dao of guarding the One gathers those who have guarded the One throughout past and present, assembling them by kind. The greatly worthy who exert themselves in this may transcend the world; the moderately worthy who exert themselves may become good ministers and virtuous officials to emperors and kings; even the petty who exert themselves will be free from joy and anger, and the world will harbor no resentment or blame. This is the foremost and greatest section of my writings. Fearing that the common people, long benighted in ignorance, may remain deluded and disbelieve my words, I have therefore instructed them to compare these teachings with the texts on guarding the One from past and present, grouping them by kind to serve as mutual verification.”

“Excellent, excellent! Your foolish disciple has now awakened.”

“Now, as for guarding the One: the great person who guards it finds it more than sufficient; the middling person who guards it finds it more than sufficient; even the petty person who guards it finds it more than sufficient. When all three kinds of people guard and practice it, their goodness pervades the six directions and eight distant realms, and their kindness and love are reckoned equal to Heaven and Earth. As for the most benighted fool who takes no joy in guarding and practicing it, he is called the most wicked and violent person in the world—Heaven and Earth detest him, and spirits no longer protect him.

Generally, when people over time do not together delight in what is beneficial, this is the method by which the celestial writings distinguish good and evil. Those who delight in reading and gazing upon them are known by Heaven as good people; those who are shown them yet do not wish to gaze upon them are known by Heaven as violent and wicked people. Judging people by this, not one in ten thousand will be mistaken.

I compose these writings for the Lord of Supreme Virtue, above not betraying Heaven, below not betraying Earth, and in the middle not betraying the Lord of Virtue, nor deceiving the perfected. Those who guard this and grasp its meaning have completed the Dao in its entirety. Let the Six Perfected deeply ponder its meaning—I cannot exhaustively record all its goodness.”

The One is the very throat and collar of the supreme Dao. The superior scholar delights in its virtue; the middling scholar echoes and knows it; the inferior scholar detests and reviles it. Do you understand this?

“Indeed, indeed.”

Thus, when the superior scholar attains it, great joy arises, and they cannot restrain themselves from acting upon it. When the middling scholar attains it, they cannot cease their pursuit, ever desiring to speak of it with gladness. When the inferior scholar encounters it, it becomes their greatest taboo. Observing these three types of people through my writings, the distinction between good and evil in the world becomes clear. Do you understand?

“Indeed, indeed.”

This text is Heaven’s contract for rectifying the hearts of ordinary people, for eliminating the lingering disasters of inherited burdens from ancestors in the lower ages, for resolving Heaven’s afflictions, and for lifting the inherited retributions of the Lord of Supreme Virtue. Do you understand?

“Indeed, indeed.”

Excellent, excellent! Go forth, for you have awakened.

**Rising:** As for the second boundary of its divisions, those who read my writings on the Dao, aligning them with past and present and arranging them by category, will grasp their essential meaning. The most worthy and enlightened will rejoice in unison and be unable to restrain themselves from doing good. They will ascend to the point of daring to enter the thatched chamber, steadfastly guarding it without fail, and will surely attain deliverance from the world and depart. Their aspirations will merge completely with the divine spirits, and they will no longer be praised for worldly affairs. Their goodness will thoroughly permeate Heaven and Earth, and their spirit will assist Heaven and Earth, aiding the emperor in transforming evil. Their grace will extend downward to the smallest blades of grass and the most minute creatures, none failing to be enveloped in their virtuous transformation. Thus, the wise and virtuous teachers of antiquity who aided emperors in achieving Great Peace were all such people.

**Halt:** Therefore, their words and deeds are entirely in accord with goodness and loyalty. This is the excellence of the Dao they received from their teachers. Do you, Perfected One, understand?

“Indeed, indeed.”

Within this...

**〈Rise〉** Those of middling virtue shall join their efforts to study my scriptures, aligning them with the Daoist texts of past and present, arranging them by category and studying them without cease. Those of worthy talent among them may ascend to become the emperor’s good ministers and virtuous officials, aiding the virtuous ruler in transforming evil, their grace extending downward to the smallest blades of grass and the most minute creatures. Yin and yang will harmonize, and there will be no more warfare. The emperor will wander at leisure without cares, while all his ministers and subordinates will instruct and assist one another, none failing to act in accord with goodness and loyalty. Governance will proceed without punishments, and their virtue will be too vast to record in full. Do you, Perfected One, understand?

“Indeed, indeed.”

**〈Rise〉** If all the common people together study my scriptures and Daoist texts, with high and low communicating as one, uniting their plans and strategies into a single whole, none will know how to commit wickedness. They will collate and compare the Daoist texts of past and present, arranging them by category to illuminate one another, and take them as the learning of the age, passing them down from father to son without end. If the three ranks—great worthies, middling worthies, and lesser worthies—and the common people all engage in divination by these means, the malign qi of Heaven and Earth will be entirely dispelled, and there will be no more calamities of inherited burdens. Virtue will harmonize yin and yang, the auspicious qi of Heaven and Earth will emerge in full, and they will roam through the emperor’s capital—this is the sign that the August Heaven and Earthly Soil are pleased and delighted. Therefore, those who study my texts should examine them with utmost care.

**〈Halt〉** From the highest to the lowest, ponder their essential meaning, grasp their secrets, and you will differ not at all from the divine spirits. Do you, Perfected One, understand?

“Indeed, indeed.”

**〈Rise〉** As for the three ranks of attainment: those who attain the Dao will frequently encounter divine powers and be able to employ them. The most worthy and enlightened among them will govern with perfect success in ten out of ten cases and may serve as the emperor’s ministers, driving away evil and dispelling wickedness. Some, after a long time, may again enter the thatched chamber and depart this world, no longer praised for worldly affairs. Thus, only after guarding the One will one fully know the locations of good and evil, transgressions and errors; only then can one guard the Dao. Only after entering the thatched chamber to cultivate refinement can one guard the spirits—this is the third rank. The worthy will collate and compare the divine scriptures of past and present to verify one another. Do you, Perfected One, understand?

“Indeed, indeed.”

Those of middling virtue who guard the One and enter the Dao will also personally perceive the spirits. They will govern with nine successes in ten cases and may become the great ministers of kings and marquises, jointly driving away and eliminating evil. After a long time, they too may hope to enter the thatched chamber. Do you, Perfected One, understand?

“Indeed, indeed.”

Those of lesser virtue who guard the One, enter the Dao, and study the scriptures may also perceive the spirits. They will govern with eight successes in ten cases and may join the common people in driving away evil and dispelling wickedness. They too should collate and compare the Daoist texts of past and present to verify one another. Only then will the foolish become enlightened and fully comprehend and believe in the Dao.

**〈Halt〉** If one merely reads a single scroll without such verification, one will surely fail to believe. One may even speak against it and explain it away, allowing evil to flourish daily and harm people. **〈Rise〉** But if the great worthies, middling worthies, lesser worthies, and common people all guard the divine Dao and act accordingly, then the spirits of Heaven and Earth and the four seasons will all arise, and evil will vanish of itself. Do you, Perfected One, understand?

“Indeed, indeed.”

In this way, the spirits of Heaven above and Earth below, of the four directions, the six directions, and the six relations will all be pleased and greatly arise to assist people in auspiciousness, **〈Halt〉** dispelling evil and harm. Above, they will eliminate disasters and illnesses for the emperor; in the middle, they will remove sicknesses for the worthy; below, they will dispel malign qi for the common people, preventing malevolent ghosts and spirits from acting.

“Excellent! Excellent! There must be great secrets and precepts for encountering the spirits and divining affairs.”

“To say ‘ten successes in ten cases’ is to be in accord with the spirits of Heaven. To say ‘nine successes in ten cases’ is to be in accord with the spirits of Earth. To say ‘eight successes in ten cases’ is to be in accord with the spirits of humanity. Those below this level are not to be employed. Some may initially perceive the spirits and achieve perfect accord, but over time their success may decline—this is because the divine Dao is testing them, causing their failures. If they see this and renew themselves, striving to correct their errors and become more refined, without evil intentions, their conduct will daily improve. If they align with the spirits’ intentions, they may again achieve perfect success, or exceed ten, or hit ten out of ten. Those who daily improve in their successes are those who daily strive for goodness and grasp the meaning of the Dao. Thus, it is called ‘advancement.’ Using this to divine for oneself, one will not err in ten thousand cases.

Some may initially encounter the spirits and fail in divination, but later their successes will daily improve—these are people who refine themselves in the Dao and daily advance in accord with the spirits’ intentions. Others may remain as they were, neither advancing nor retreating—these are people whose refinement is insufficient. Those who daily decline are the indolent. Divining by these means, one will not grasp the meaning of the Dao. If one is tested and fails to awaken, stubbornly persisting in evil, the various spirits will jointly deceive them, leading them into evil paths. This will result in unpredictable fortunes, or falling into delusive words, or being afflicted with illness. Therefore, whether great worthies, middling worthies, lesser worthies, commoners, men, or women, all who practice the Dao should use this to divine for themselves and will not err—this is how the divine Dao tests people.

All affairs under Heaven are tested through failure. Heaven and Earth test people, so people, emulating Heaven and Earth, also test one another. Do you, Perfected One, understand?

“Indeed, indeed.”

If you wish to further understand the great proof of trustworthiness: when the Dao of Heaven, the divine spirits, and the people are in accord, their hearts unite, and utmost sincerity and trust prevail. If they are not in accord, they deceive one another. Thus, the people of high antiquity were sincere and trusting, in accord with one another, so superiors and inferiors did not deceive one another. The people of middle antiquity were half in accord, so they half deceived one another. The people of low antiquity were entirely untrusting, so superiors and inferiors made deception their sole business. Thus, in high antiquity, all undertakings succeeded; in middle antiquity, half succeeded; in low antiquity, none succeeded—hence peril and ruin.

Thus, the sages and worthies of antiquity constantly used this to divine for themselves whether they were in accord or not, so they never erred. With this, I admonish you, Perfected One: I see that you are often wearied by toil, and so I deeply caution you, for you are the eternal emissary of Heaven and Earth. You resolve the flowing calamities of Heaven and Earth and remove harms for the ruler—your merit is vast and nearly unmatched. I fear you may grow lax in the Dao, and so I use these numinous matters to warn you. You are the emissary of Heaven and Earth, and when the days are auspicious, it is because you have attained the heart-mind of Heaven and Earth; when the days are inauspicious, baleful, and ill, it is because you have lost the heart-mind of Heaven and Earth. When you commune with the spirits of the Dao and the days are auspicious and good, it is because you have attained the heart-mind of the Dao; when the days are inauspicious and baleful, it is because you have lost the heart-mind of the Dao. When you interact with others and the days grow increasingly kind and good, it is because you are in accord with their heart-minds; when they turn inauspicious, baleful, and cold, it is because you have lost accord with their heart-minds.

It is like tilling a field: when the grain you harvest is plentiful and fully ripened, it is because your heart-mind was attentive and your effort great; when the grain you harvest is scant and poorly ripened, it is because your heart-mind was lax and your effort slight. Even mere plants and trees respond to the heart-mind of the cultivator, their goodness or ill depending on the measure of effort and toil—how much more so with Heaven, Earth, the divine spirits, and humankind? Can you not be cautious?

Perfected One, this is the admonition: though it may seem slight and insignificant, ponder it deeply, and it will become profoundly weighty. This is precisely what is called the gateway to peace or peril, good fortune or ill. Do you understand?

“Indeed, indeed.”

“I, foolish as I am, have awakened—how solemn the charge, how solemn the charge!”

“Now, the virtuous and enlightened, as sovereigns of supreme virtue, compile and collate the writings of high antiquity, middle antiquity, and recent antiquity, arranging them by category and cross-verifying their proofs. Thus the Dao is rectified in a single day, no different from the sun and moon. They further gather and assemble the oral testimonies, oral instructions, and affairs of great worthies, middling worthies, lesser worthies, and all people—men and women alike—arranging them by category and again cross-verifying their proofs. The written texts then align perfectly, as if matching compass and square without the slightest deviation. The strategies of Heaven, Earth, and humankind converge as one. In this way, the sentiments of Heaven, Earth, and humankind are all encompassed, and the twelve thousand things follow likewise. Therefore, the sovereign of virtue must strive to employ this method.

Then, in a single day, disasters and harms will depart, and the world will govern itself. No remnant of perverse texts or perverse words will remain; all will be pure and rectified, leaving no trace of perverse qi. For perverse texts and perverse words are the root of calamity.

If you wish to further verify their clarity and trustworthiness, consider this: if someone records perverse texts to present to the sovereign, or if someone utters perverse words to slander another, resentment and blame will arise daily. Many people will likewise resent and slander one another, and the sovereign will heed them. Thus, true discernment is lost, and one fails to comprehend, incurring the disapproval of Heaven and Earth. Inauspicious words bring peril. Moreover, those below will use perverse texts and perverse words to deceive and confuse their superiors. Over time, when this is discovered above, sovereign and ministers will blame one another. Thus, perverse texts and perverse words arrive daily, serving as the gateway to misfortune and evil. Therefore, one must exert great effort to collate and eliminate them.

Perfected One, do you understand?”

“Indeed, indeed.”

Thus, a virtuous sovereign exhaustively employs upright words, and since the opening of Heaven and Earth, the calamities of inherited burdens are entirely dispelled, with no further disasters or harms. Perfected One, do you wish to further comprehend its great truth?

For upright texts and upright words are the true root and origin of Heaven, Earth, humanity, and the myriad things. Therefore, the great sages and worthies of high antiquity acted in accordance with upright texts and upright words, and Heaven and Earth were rectified for them, the Three Luminaries were rectified for them, the four seasons and five phases were rectified for them, and the people and all things were rectified for them. Thus, upright texts and upright words are the great proof and true root of the rectification of Heaven, Earth, the people, and the myriad things.

Do you wish to further clarify and understand their truth? It is like when someone employs upright texts and upright words to praise another before the sovereign, and the sovereign thereby attains great discernment and great comprehension. In all affairs, nothing is lost from the upright. Above and below thus attain the will of Heaven and Earth, the Three Luminaries do not deviate from their courses, the four seasons and five phases do not err, and the people are all joyful, all saying, “Excellent!” The myriad things each attain their proper place. Grace pervades the spirits, and one’s fame spreads to distant lands. The host of spirits and auspicious omens manifest in delight, and the worthies and scholars of the world all gladly come to assist the sovereign. The treasury is not sealed, and immortals and divine spirits bring the formulas of agelessness to them. Portents and omens are extinguished for them, and the people act on their behalf. When upright texts and upright words no longer give rise to mutual resentment, then blame and grievance are cut off. All goodness in the world emerges, while all perversity and evil conceal themselves. The virtuous sovereign need only sit with folded arms to govern of itself—what worry of peril or ruin could there be? This is the clear proof and effect of my upright texts and upright words as the root of goodness. How could one not strive to uphold the upright?

Perfected One, do you understand?

“Indeed, indeed.”

How astonishing! Having heard the Heavenly Master’s words, I have already awakened greatly, and this foolish student now knows the world is already at great peace. If the virtuous sovereign heeds and employs them, they have already prolonged their life.”

“Excellent! You may be called a student who comprehends matters—you have already penetrated them thoroughly. How joyous! How joyous! The Heaven’s anxieties are already resolved, the Earth’s afflictions already removed. Perfected One, how do you know this?”

“Indeed, all perversity and evil should now be seen as gone, and the great afflictions of Heaven, Earth, the people, and the myriad things have already been removed. Now that the upright texts and upright words have been gathered and rectified, I know the great afflictions of Heaven and Earth have already been removed.”

“Excellent! Excellent! You have already □□ understood this. If the emperor and king vigorously practice my texts, they will be in harmony with Heaven and Earth, and no further calamities will befall them. Excellent! Excellent! These are the crucial words spoken to the Perfected One. When a sovereign of supreme virtue obtains my texts, Heaven’s patterns and images will serve as their ministers—from divine beings above to the lowliest and most humble below, all nine ranks of people: divine, perfected, immortal, Daoist, sage, worthy, common folk, servants, and bondservants. Among these nine ranks, those who possess true faith and loyalty, who delight in the true and good Dao, and come to assist the virtuous sovereign—inquire into their abilities and employ them, taking care never to assign them duties unsuited to their station, nor to dismiss them unjustly. This is called the ‘earnest and devoted heart of those who oppose.’ Heaven is not partial to any person; it merely relies on and employs them according to their capacities. If each is asked about their particular strengths, then nothing will remain ungoverned. The virtuous sovereign should test them: promote those who daily demonstrate good results, taking care not to lose them, and swiftly dismiss those who show no results. This is called ‘defiling and disrupting the heavenly offices,’ preventing the upright qi from arriving—the fault lies with these perverse people. As for the truly good and upright, their hearts always desire to secretly assist and worry over all matters, which is why they bring about the arrival of good and upright people. The perverse, however, harbor perverse hearts and do not desire to secretly assist or benefit any matter, thus bringing about perversity. This is the natural standard and law of August Heaven. Therefore, they must be dismissed at once. If they are not dismissed, they will anger Heaven, causing the Earth’s killing qi to emerge. Thus, they must be swiftly removed—this is a matter of great importance. Perfected One, do you understand?”

“Indeed, indeed.”

“This foolish one fears it greatly.”
“That you know to fear it—this may be called understanding the matters of life. Heaven will then protect you.”
“I dare not, I dare not.”
“There is no need for modesty here. It is not I who cause you to be protected by Heaven, but your own goodness that naturally brings this about. Thus, the sages of antiquity in their conduct dared not deviate from the plumb line, for they observed Heaven’s warnings and clearly knew good from evil, each for their own person. Therefore, they constantly sought to govern with the worthy, ever fearful of angering Heaven. To offend Heaven is to have no place for prayer.

For this reason, the ancient sage-kings, their hearts bright and penetrating, dared not recklessly employ the foolish in their service, and so they alone enjoyed enduring good fortune. Perfected One, do you understand?”
“Indeed, indeed.”

“Since the middle antiquity, half of humanity has been foolish, regarding selection and appointment as a trivial matter. Without careful examination, half of those chosen are unfit, half disrupt the heavenly offices, and governance is half inauspicious. In later antiquity, inheriting the carelessness of the middle era, they further allowed matters to become easy, failing to examine closely. Thus, in selection and appointment, they often do not obtain the right people. Defiling and disrupting the heavenly offices, the Three Luminaries become unbalanced, and evidence appears in the heavens—Heaven is displeased. Hence, inauspicious years never cease, and when they do cease, they arise again. Yet Heaven deeply resents and detests this, while people do not deeply examine themselves, instead blaming the times and fate.

Such was the case in antiquity. The Dao of Heaven is not human; they reverse matters, attributing their excesses to Heaven above. The foolish below do not reflect on their own faults but repeatedly join together to shift blame onto the emperor. Heaven thus names these ‘the great rebellious people,’ for the fault lies below, deceiving those above, calling evil good and good evil, together bringing about these disasters, then shifting blame upward to Heaven. Those who shift blame to Heaven then further reproach their ruler, making the realm’s worthless and treacherous ministers and people utterly reckless.

Now, the spirits of Heaven and Earth together detest and abhor them. Thus, Heaven personally intervened, sending me down to be the Virtuous Lord and create new laws. In selecting and appointing people to office, one cannot but be cautious and thorough. Perfected One, do you wish to know the true nature of these wicked ministers and people? It is like a family where parents have several children, and the children together deceive their parents, behaving wickedly. The parents sit silently in a room at home, yet know of their children’s violent and thieving deeds. But others instead join together to blame the parents: ‘The parents are evil, hence they bore evil children.’

When the county officials apprehend them, they do not justly execute the wicked children but instead repeatedly blame the parents. Yet when parents bear children, they all delight in their worthiness and goodness—when would they ever delight in their children behaving wickedly? To instead blame the parents is to be the most rebellious and unfilial of children.

Now, when a ruler employs ministers, he delights in their goodness—when would he ever teach them to be wicked? Yet the ministers and people below together commit violent and evil deeds, and when Heaven and Earth bring calamities, they instead shift blame to their ruler, causing the common people to suffer hardship. Thereupon, the crafty officials also join together to reproach Heaven, calling this ‘ministers and people together committing rebellion.’ The crime cannot be absolved. Together they reproach their ruler to the utmost, and this should bring great upheaval. Yet they further blame Heaven above and Earth below. Such is the rebellion of humanity—how can their lives not be cut short and swiftly ended?

Thus, in later antiquity, all were subject to the mandate of hegemons, and life and death came without warning. It is like a household wishing to slaughter livestock: if they suddenly wish to kill them, they kill them. Even good livestock are pitied in death, while evil livestock are delighted to die of illness. Perfected One, do you understand?”
“Indeed, indeed.”

“Foolish mortals greatly fear Heaven’s majesty.”
“Excellent, you have awakened. Bring forth this text and let the virtuous ruler show it to all worthy scholars—take care not to conceal it, for Heaven urgently delights in its revelation.”
“Indeed, indeed.”

“Let me impart to you, Perfected One, a matter of great importance: when rulers of great virtue and their ministers each attain their rightful place, aligning with the heart of Heaven, then they must know the arts of governing the people and eliminating harm. Yet those who lurk in distant regions are exceedingly difficult to discern. The benighted masses, each seeking their own advantage, instead conspire to deceive their superiors. The virtuous ruler must, together with the wise and enlightened, correct this—only when all is rectified does it accord with the will of Heaven and Earth, bringing them great joy and ensuring the emperor’s enduring fortune.

Heaven, in its wisdom, knows that the people of later antiquity are foolish and difficult to govern; thus, it deliberately produced these written documents, naming them *Heavenly Scriptures*. The nature of writing is to make manifest and to clarify. All under Heaven use it to record affairs, and what is recorded must be universally practiced—it may be used to preserve the literary works of all people. Therefore, written texts are what all under Heaven ought to read together, not for the sake of a single, solitary individual. Thus, all under Heaven use writing to record all matters; sages use it to record the patterns of Heaven and Earth, and the worthy use it to preserve the words of sages. Only when ordinary people study and read these texts together do they afterward grasp their meaning.

The categories of writing are such that they must be collectively examined, collectively deliberated, collectively recorded, and collectively recited—only then can deceit be eliminated. Yet from ancient times to the present, how many revisions have the writings of sages undergone? How many transmissions? How many verifications? How many have been collectively preserved? And still, there remain superfluous, erroneous words that cannot be uniformly applied. Thus, great worthies and masters of the Dao traverse the world, scrutinizing words and studying speech, comparing differences to enlighten the ignorant. Yet even so, errors persist, misleading the innocent and causing them to speak recklessly of their learning—such recklessness renders them unfit to serve as ministers to emperors and kings.

Thus, when a single original text diverges into many variant passages, the Dao of Heaven and Earth falls into great disorder and confusion, giving rise to the disasters of *chengfu*. Perfected One, do you understand?”
“Indeed, indeed.”

“Excellent, you have awakened. Now listen further, and I shall tell you of one great precept. The reason people of later ages have long lost the favor of Heaven, causing Heaven and Earth to remain ever disconsolate, is that rulers rely on solitary words and isolated judgments, verifying matters without truth, and thus greatly miss the clarity of their intent. Perfected One, if this persists, even when all the worthy under Heaven collectively examine the words and texts, they will still err in their learning. Hence, calamities and anomalies arise unceasingly, and Heaven deeply abhors this, giving rise to chaos, illness, and the unceasing struggle of yin and yang.

Thus, Heaven commanded me to descend and correct these errors through careful collation. Since the Great Middle Antiquity, people have trusted solitary words and isolated judgments, deeming texts that review or challenge authority as disrespectful. They collectively use this as a standard for blame, and so, relying on solitary words and isolated judgments, they respond and submit documents to govern affairs—thereby incurring Heaven’s resentment and disorder. The celestial documents and records were originally meant for people to collectively deliberate on right and wrong, yet now they allow one person to secretly compose the words.

Even sages cannot alone fully comprehend the Dao of Heaven and Earth. Thus, the works of sages and worthies across generations differ, for Heaven has said that each excels in but one aspect and cannot entirely eliminate disasters. Therefore, I was commanded to gather and collate them all. Now, to trust the words of a single person—how can this be acceptable? Thus, I teach the Three Dao Methods of circulating documents, wherein the great and the small, the worthy and the unworthy, men and women, all intermingle, collectively deliberating on right and wrong, ensuring that all attain the truth of the matter □□ before it may be elevated.

If one among them seeks to deceive, it is immediately recorded. In this way, the illnesses of Heaven and Earth are eradicated, and emperors and kings are freed from the burdens of *chengfu*. Then:

Heaven and Earth, freed from illness, rejoice;
emperors and kings, secure in their rule, rejoice;
the worthy, able to fulfill their potential, rejoice;
the common people, freed from unjust suffering, their households prosperous and their needs met, rejoice;
servants and maids, finding good masters and refraining from wrongdoing, rejoice;
the four seasons and five phases, flowing in harmony, with the people reverent and untransgressive, rejoice;
the myriad creatures, each in its proper place and unharmed, rejoice;
ghosts and spirits, seeing the virtuous ruler accumulate goodness, also rejoice;
evil *qi* no longer ascends to obscure the sun, moon, and Three Luminaries, rejoicing;
the Supreme Peaceful *qi* comes to govern, and the king’s rule is effective, rejoicing;
evil *qi*, once subdued and hidden, no longer manifests to incite punitive expeditions, rejoicing;
the barbarians, settled in their lands, no longer frequently wage war against Heaven, rejoicing;
generals and soldiers, their weapons at rest and unused, their troops spared from death in battle, rejoice.

In all between Heaven and Earth, such joys are too numerous to record. I, Perfected One, have raised only the great outlines and shown their beginnings; ponder their meaning yourself. For all matters, infer by analogy, and you will fully comprehend them. When a virtuous ruler implements this, all under Heaven will submit.”

Thus, Heaven urgently emphasizes the practice of these Three Daoist Writs—take heed never to abandon them, lest disasters persist. To sever the celestial patterns is to revert to governance by the deaf and blind. Such governance is the root of chaos and peril, the calamity that destroys the self. How could one not be cautious?

Now, these writs are what all under Heaven must jointly examine and practice; they cannot be trusted to the words of a single person. Since the opening of Heaven and Earth, texts and human discourses have been transmitted and cross-examined to verify their clarity. Without such verification, they cannot be practiced alone. To act solely on one person’s words is to court danger and ruin—this is the great loss and harm of all under Heaven.

Therefore, my writings dare not tolerate solitary words or isolated phrases. I instruct the Perfected One to collate and compare texts from the High, Middle, and Low Antiquities to illuminate them, and to gather and verify the discourses of all people under Heaven to confirm their covenants. Only then can all between Heaven and Earth be rectified, and the interactions of *yin* and *yang* remain free of disorder.

Examine ancient and modern celestial patterns, earthly spirit-writs, and human discourses with my writings, and they will surely resonate like an echo, no different from the divine. Thus, my Dao may be trusted. For my Dao does not rely on untested words; it seeks to be put into practice. How else could one know whether my Dao aligns with Heaven and is trustworthy? Today, if you practice it, it is as though you converse with Heaven—ten out of ten, fifteen out of fifteen, with no omissions. How wondrous is the Dao when thus practiced! Truly, it may be called the greatest joy. Does the Perfected One understand?

“Indeed, indeed.”

Go forth, and you will enlighten the living. I impart to you, Perfected One, a great secret: this begins with guarding the One and focusing on goodness to grasp its meaning, thereby entering the Dao. Thus, I follow it with the Daoist writs. To practice the Dao is to arrive at the inner chamber, to enter the true Dao, and to enter the chamber, one must know the divine. Thus, I follow it with the divine precepts.

Having guarded the One, attained the Dao, and obtained the divine, one may ascend to become a virtuous ruler or a worthy minister. Ministers must assist the virtuous ruler to jointly pacify the six directions and eight caverns of Heaven and Earth. Grasping their meaning, the state may enjoy long-lasting peace. To achieve this peace, one must rectify texts, discourses, and words. Thus, by collating and verifying texts and discourses, great rectification is achieved. Only then will the multitude of worthy and superior scholars emerge to jointly assist the ruler, serving as his keen ears, bright eyes, and strong limbs. Thus, I follow it with the nine ministerial offices. When the nine each fulfill their roles, they will jointly pacify Heaven and Earth, and all under Heaven will unite in strength and purpose as one.

They must constantly communicate, reporting good and evil to one another. Thus, I follow it with the Three Daoist Writs. Once all know to guard the One, have entered the Dao, attained the divine, and embraced correct texts, then, with the hierarchy of ministers each in their proper place, and having practiced the writs, they will unite in the six affairs. Having reached completion, all under Heaven will share one heart, with none daring to harbor hatred. All will love and benefit one another as though born of the same parents. Thus, the virtuous ruler deeply aligns with Heaven’s will, delighting in the absence of strife.

Fearing omissions in the Dao that might leave the celestial and earthly texts incomplete, I further append the *Great Collection of Difficulties* to resolve doubts. The profound are placed below, and the complete writings are revealed, entrusted to the virtuous ruler. Should all under Heaven suddenly turn to reckoning, goodness will govern itself. This is as effortless as fire spreading to high and dry places, or water flowing downward—unbidden, it proceeds naturally, unstoppable.

Thus, the transformative teachings of the Supreme August Heavenly Dao may be awaited. When the virtuous ruler practices them, he is called the divine son of Heaven, styled the Supreme August, akin to the primordial *qi* of Heaven and Earth. Therefore, all spirits under Heaven may be commanded. Since the opening of Heaven and Earth, there has never been a celestial writ or divine text like this, transmitted by the Perfected One as a record of the true Dao. Entrusted to the virtuous ruler, it is called the Mother of the Dao.

The *qi* of the Great Yang, the fire phase, exists within it. To practice it is to attain its truth; to fail to practice it is to lack authenticity. Does the Perfected One understand?

“Indeed, indeed.”

“With utmost sincerity, I entrust the people to you, to be delivered to the virtuous ruler without delay. I dare not retain it long.”

“Go, for you have understood. The celestial writ must not be kept long. Heavenly spirits examine men, and prolonged possession brings misfortune. Be cautious and depart.”

“Indeed, indeed.”

Six investigations thoroughly penetrate the seven ultimate boundaries, arranging texts by category so they correspond, eradicating all disasters and calamities, thereby manifesting the auspicious writ of utmost profundity.

**The Great Precept of Enduring Humility, Emulating Heaven and Earth, and Harmonizing with the Spirits (253rd)**

The Perfected One spoke: “Come forward.”

“Indeed, indeed.”

“Now I shall impart to you a great precept. Rise—

Our Dao is for governing Heaven and Earth, pacifying emperors and kings, and giving life to those beloved by Heaven and Earth. Thus, one must cherish the true Dao and true virtue. Therefore, Heaven is the truth of the Dao, the warp of the Dao, the fidelity of the Dao, the condition by which the Dao proceeds. Earth is the chief of virtue, the weft of virtue, the condition by which virtue abides. Thus, it endures as the mother of the myriad things, constantly enduring humiliation by dwelling below, never boasting of its toil or hardship.

In teaching the ignorant as the virtuous ruler, I take these two matters of Heaven and Earth as the foundation. Therefore, one must always follow the laws of Heaven and Earth, never deviating from their gate and threshold. My writings are the words of Heaven and the speech of Earth, deeply and uniquely resonating with the spirits as if inner and outer. Halt—proceeding step by step, they follow as if compass and square.

Thus, those who act in accord obtain the intent of Heaven and Earth; those who lose it meet with misfortune and decline. Now I precept you, Perfected One—you should ponder my words and ever be cautious.”

“Indeed, indeed.”

“Go. Seeing your devotion to the true Dao and virtue, your goodness unmatched, I shall reveal one further word to you. Now, the superior person delights greatly in the true Dao and good virtue; the middling person is half-inclined toward them; the inferior person, devoid of form, is utterly without Dao and virtue—all are those who commit great rebellion, the people of utmost misfortune and devoid of virtue. Such people, within Heaven and Earth, stand utterly apart, unknown and unrecognized, not those Heaven habitually pardons or loves. Thus, those without Dao and virtue have no destiny under Heaven and Earth; their fate and fortune are the same as birds and beasts.”

“Now I do not understand. I wish to hear the essential meaning.”

“”

“Now then, the Six Perfected Ones, listen clearly.”
“Indeed, indeed.”

“Now, Heaven is purely of the Dao; Earth is purely of virtue. These people devoid of Dao and virtue are utterly cut off from Heaven and Earth, without any likeness. Those who take Heaven as their model should possess the true Dao and delight in giving life; those who take Earth as their model should possess good virtue and delight in nurturing growth. Now, people without Dao and without virtue—thus Heaven and Earth do not pardon them. If you wish to know the clear proof of this, compare it to those of the Dao recognizing others of the Dao, and those of virtue recognizing others of virtue: each naturally gathers and embraces their own, so their destinies are mutually bound. Thus, those of the Dao delight in elevating others of the Dao; those of virtue delight in elevating others of virtue. Those with Dao and virtue do not align with those without Dao and virtue, and so they do not gather or embrace them—thus their destiny is not bound to Heaven.”

“Excellent! Excellent! I wish to hear the meaning of their destiny being the same as birds and beasts.”

“Excellent is your question, for you deeply grasp the principle. Now, the destiny of birds and beasts is bound to the four directions; their nature delights in clashing, devoid of Dao and virtue, and the stronger prevails. The foolish people devoid of Dao and virtue also delight in clashing and overstepping, and the stronger prevails. Their qi is the same as that of birds and beasts—thus their destiny is the same. The Dao of Heaven serves as the law, by which the superior and inferior of people are distinguished—thus it is known.

Generally, the names and destinies of all under Heaven follow their kind, so their destined category is known. Thus, those who embody the Five Natures in abundance resemble yang and are benevolent; those who embody the Six Emotions in abundance resemble yin and are greedy. Those who receive more yang endowment become male; those who receive more yin endowment become female. Those who receive the qi of prosperous and dominant phases become noble, honored, and long-lived; those who receive the qi of waning, declining, and imprisoned phases suffer frequent illness, die early, and are utterly impoverished.

Thus, for all people born, their destiny is bound to the qi of the phase they resemble and to the cyclical progression of the Six Jia. By categorizing accordingly, not one in ten thousand is misjudged. Therefore, the sages of antiquity deeply investigated all matters and understood human nature by this means. Do the Perfected Ones understand this?”

“Indeed, indeed. Excellent! Excellent!”

Now, the people of this later age bear the burden of their ancestors' miscalculations, gradually severing the Dao and virtue together. Day by day, over long accumulation, they cut themselves off from Heaven and Earth, their essence and qi no longer flowing through. Unaware of their destined fate, they instead share the same lot as four-footed creatures. Thus, Heaven and Earth detest them, and the qi of spirits and gods no longer protects them. They suffer countless illnesses, meet untimely deaths, and their greatest fault lies in this...

Now, the ruler of supreme virtue, whose destiny is bound to Heaven and Earth, must model himself upon them and govern through the Dao and virtue. Therefore, I have reordered and revealed the celestial Dao to bestow upon him. Heaven delights in his goodness and does not wish him to act as those four-footed people do. Thus, I reiterate and emphasize these writings, desiring that he awaken fully. Therefore, I have compiled the *Six Ultimates* and the *Great Collection of Difficulties* to entrust to him. Do you, Perfected One, understand this?”

“Indeed, indeed. How astonishing! How joyous! How joyous!”

“Perfected One, how do you know what is astonishing and joyous?”

“When I, foolish as I am, hear the Celestial Master speak of the true Dao and virtue emerging, the people will turn in a single day, all upholding the Dao and virtue, modeling themselves upon Heaven and Earth, no longer acting as four-footed creatures. Each person will follow the Way, each will embody virtue—thus I know the great joy of this intent.”

“Excellent, Perfected One! Your words are beyond improvement.”

“Now, with your permission, Celestial Master, I wish to ask one matter.”

“Speak.”

“When people seek the Dao and virtue or engage in ordinary conduct, what should be their most urgent task? How can they come to know it? How can they resonate in response with Heaven and Earth?”

“Excellent is your question! They must act with utmost sincerity, with the five inner organs genuine and true—only then can they attain it. If they do not act with the five inner organs genuine and true, they incur the resentment of the Dao and virtue. Seeking goodness will be in vain, and the spirits will not respond.”

“Now, I wish to hear how utmost sincerity moves Heaven, Earth, and the gods.”

“Alas! Perfected One, in this you are particularly unenlightened. Have you not yet fully grasped the texts I have taught?”

“Foolish as I am, my obscurity runs deep, and it is difficult to suddenly illuminate it.”

“Yet you are overly modest. Listen carefully, and I will explain the meaning of utmost sincerity moving Heaven and Earth.”

“Indeed, I heed your instruction.”

“Now, utmost sincerity is so named because when one looks up and acts in accordance with the celestial Dao, it is attainable; when one looks down and acts in accordance with the virtue of Earth, it is transformative. One reflects that Heaven and Earth, like parents, gave me life and do not wish me to delight in evil. One examines this in the heart before acting. The heart is the most revered spirit within, the sacred and purely yang, aligned with the movement of fire. Fire rises and ascends, sharing the radiance of Heaven. Thus, the sun is the ruler of fire, the essence of Heaven, illuminating all without exception. Therefore, when one acts with utmost sincerity, the heart’s rectitude responds with urgency. The spirit of the heart, most sacred, ascends to report to the sun, and the sun reports to Heaven. Thus, utmost sincerity within the five inner organs moves the spirits. How can one not be cautious?”

The Perfected One said, “How awe-inspiring! How awe-inspiring! My foolish questions have stirred great fear.”

“If you know fear, it is the root of life; if you do not know fear, it is the gate of death. Safety and peril lie within you, not elsewhere.”

“Though each time I ask the Celestial Master, I am struck with fear, yet to ask is to receive the great resolution, while not asking leaves no means to know it.”

“Indeed, your words are true. If one remains in darkness and does not ask, when will clarity ever come? Speak—what else do you wish to ask?”

“Having already heard how utmost sincerity moves Heaven, I now wish to hear how it moves Earth.”

“Excellent! Your words grow ever deeper, and you spare nothing in your inquiry. Sit calmly, and I will explain it to you. If I do not speak, I fear I will fail you. It is as if Heaven itself grieves that later generations lack utmost sincerity and has sent you, Perfected One, to pose these questions. Very well. Now I will tell you.”

“Listen clearly.”

“Yes, yes.”

“Now then, when a person’s utmost sincerity takes hold of a thought, the heart feels such pain that one cannot eat. What is thought? It is the heart and the mind. When the heart and mind do not forget, the liver—most benevolent of organs—acts as their master, and the eyes shed tears. This is the utmost sincerity of concentrated thought. The heart is the essence of clarity. To think without ceasing is the work of the mind and the spleen. The heart is pure yang, its position belonging to Heaven. The spleen is pure yin, its position belonging to Earth. When utmost sincerity is focused in thought, the heart aches and tears flow. The heart commands the mind to direct the thought, sending word to distant places. The mind is yin; when yin harbors sorrow, it must report to yang, thus ascending to inform the divine spirits of august Heaven. The spleen, as yin’s dwelling on Earth, descends to report to Earth. Thus Heaven and Earth are moved, and all spirits are stirred. If you wish to know its great effect, I do not deceive you, Perfected One. Simply sit calmly in a secluded chamber, concentrate your heart and ponder the spirits—they will all come of their own accord. Is this not clear and evident proof? This is what I tell you of the truth of utmost sincerity. I have never spoken without method. Therefore, all who seek the Dao and virtue must act with utmost sincerity, for only then will Heaven and Earth respond and the divine spirits come to inform them. Without utmost sincerity, one cannot move Heaven and Earth or stir the spirits. After the era of *chengfu*, people of later ages truly lacked faith. Without utmost sincerity, they could not move Heaven and Earth, and so they deceived both together. Thus the spirits ceaselessly harmed them.”

“How may this be demonstrated?”

"Yet there is great and clear proof in the sun and moon."

"I now wish to hear of it."

"Indeed, people of later ages are born of father and mother, yet together they neglect their parents, turn their backs on their parents—among ten thousand, not one is filial. They receive enlightenment from their teachers, having awakened and departed, yet neglect their teachers and refuse to follow them, forcing their teachers to humble themselves and endure toil and hardship. Having gained wealth and nobility from their lords through poverty and lowliness, they instead turn to instruct others. All below together deceive those above; among ten thousand, not one possesses sincerity and trustworthiness. The multitude of fools collectively deceive the Three Bonds, acting in rebellion and without faith. Their transgressions are glaringly evident, impossible to conceal below, for all are seen above by the sun, moon, and Three Luminaries. Thus Heaven and Earth deeply detest and abhor them, causing them to be short-lived and die prematurely. They do not deeply reflect tenfold upon their grave transgressions but instead weep and wail as they proceed. They say Heaven is cruel—how grievously wronged they are! Yet it is you who wrong yourselves; when has Heaven ever wronged you?"

"How terrifying! Excellent, excellent!"

"Foolish one, I have received your instruction."

"Indeed, if you uphold this as a solemn warning, then for ten thousand generations you may be free from calamity. Yet as this minor discourse concludes, doubts arise once more—come, ask again."

"Very well."

*Right: The Great Collection’s Difficulties on the Dao, Utmost Sincerity, and Heaven’s Admonitions—Shown to the Worthy*

*Secret Formula 154: On the Jealousy Toward the Dao That Prevents Its Transmission and the Recluse’s Aid to Transformation*
