"Truly, truly foolish and benighted, my confusion grows daily—I grasp nothing of the profound and fail to comprehend. With reverence, I bow twice and ask: if I act upon this, I shall surely err; yet if I do not ask, my foolish heart cannot resolve it alone."

"Speak your words."

"This foolish one has stealthily heard the essential meaning of the secret Dao—it is the treasure of Heaven and Earth, the rarest jewel under Heaven. Thus it is called the ‘Untransmitted Utmost Dao,’ for it is not fitting for ordinary people to hear, to speak, or to employ. Yet now the Heavenly Master has fully opened the path of Great Peace, commanding all to compose essential texts on virtue and the Dao, forbidding concealment. All are warned of Heaven’s punishment, that even unto death their crimes shall not be absolved, but will flow into later generations. Yet now all are granted the true Dao and secret powers—is this not excessive? It allows petty men to mingle with noble men without distinction. This foolish one believes the true Dao and secret powers ought not be heard by petty men, spoken by petty men, or used by petty men."

"Alas! What you have just spoken incurs ten thousand deaths’ worth of guilt before the August Heaven and Revered Earth—it shall never be absolved. Since the opening of Heaven and Earth, later generations have grown ever more shallow, envying the Dao. Petty men sever the treasure of Heaven and Earth, and this is counted as loss. Over time, this gives rise to karmic inheritance, causing Heaven’s disasters to never cease. It constantly renders the world within Heaven and Earth unsettled in its years, with frequent calamities, bandits, and thieves. The state is thus plunged into sorrow and suffering—all arises from this. What you have just said is precisely the cause. You disrupt Heaven and overturn Earth, plunging governance into chaos and confusion, making the people difficult to govern—this is precisely the case. What you have just uttered deeply offends Heaven, how grievously mistaken! How grievously mistaken! Your merit is undone."

"What do you mean?"

“Now, the essential Dao and perfect virtue emerge through teaching and transformation. When petty men obtain them, they uphold the Dao and virtue, emulate one another, and dare not transgress. Among them, the lesser worthy who attain good virtue may become upright and compliant officials. The greater worthy may ascend to assist the state. Even the most ignorant and base among them may still become good people. Heaven employs the essential true Dao to give life to all things, extending even to the six domestic animals and birds. The four seasons and five phases are the true essential Dao of Heaven and Earth, the divine treasure of Heaven and Earth, the stored qi of Heaven and Earth. The six domestic animals and birds all embrace it as their nature; plants and trees obtain it and then grow. If Heaven did not bestow the complete essential Dao, how could they mutually generate and grow? Yet you, Perfected One, claim that petty men ought not hear the essential Dao, ought not speak of it, ought not employ it. Are the divine protectors of Heaven and Earth to conclude that people are less good than the six domestic animals, birds, and plants? You yourself know that what you have just said incurs a ten-thousandfold deathly offense, one that cannot be absolved.”

“This foolish student has served the Master for but a short and shallow time, and does not deeply understand the Way of Heaven. Hearing the Celestial Master’s words, I now realize my offense is grave, having failed the August Heaven above, the Earth below, and the virtuous ruler in between.”

“Indeed, your self-reproach is fitting. In all undertakings, can one not be cautious? The August Heaven alone constantly observes the words of people. Why else would echoes follow human voices to determine good or ill fortune? Thus, echoes respond without missing a fraction. Have you never observed this proof of Heaven and Earth’s resonance? You ought to be cautious where you fall short, and not recklessly utter falsehoods—such harm is grave. You have just said that the ultimate Dao is not transmitted to others. How then is it to be known? The ultimate Dao of all things cannot be transmitted. The Way of Heaven is impartial—yet for whom alone should it exist?”

“This disciple has been most remiss in caution and conduct.”

“Do you wish, like the vulgar and petty, to again obstruct and envy the Way of Heaven?”

“I dare not, I dare not.”

“Perfected One, be vigilant in your conduct. Once Heaven’s wrath is aroused, the offense will never be absolved. The Way of Heaven is precisely what your words have ruined—do you now seek to compound it? That emperors and kings cannot govern and frequently suffer disasters is entirely due to those like you. If you persist in such speech, you will cause the true Dao to be severed, heterodox ways to arise, and governance to become impossible. Do you not comprehend?”

“Indeed, indeed.”

“Now that you have awakened, are you not ashamed before the Celestial Master? Always be cautious in your conduct.”

“Indeed, indeed. Now, whenever I speak, I fear I err. Yet if I do not speak, I remain ignorant.”

“Speak plainly.”

“What is it that people ought not hear, ought not speak of, ought not employ?”

“Indeed, people ought not hear what is not the true essential Dao, not the true essential virtue. Thus, when inferior teachers instruct petty men, they neglect to employ the essential, secret Dao and true virtue in their admonitions. Instead, they display and teach with florid, false, and cunning compositions. Among them, the greater worthy who learn such deceptive and cunning compositions proceed to deceive their rulers. The middling worthy who learn false compositions become crafty officials, flattering and deceiving their superiors above while cunningly oppressing the good and compliant people below. The inferior and petty who obtain these become devoid of principle, deceiving their parents, outwitting their neighbors, or even becoming unchecked bandits and thieves. The worthy and unworthy, officials and commoners, all engage in deceit and cannot restrain one another. Witnessing such perversity and disorder, they disrupt the celestial patterns above and the terrestrial principles below, harm the accomplishments of the five phases, and contravene the nurturing of the four seasons. Together, they deceive their superiors, plunging the state into chaos. The harm is so severe it cannot be fully recounted. Yet you, Perfected One, claim that petty men ought not hear the essential Dao and virtue, and instead should be taught with deceptive, cunning, and false matters, causing the people of the world to be deluded, to learn falsehoods, and to remain unaware, thus all becoming devoid of the Dao. This is why you, Perfected One, incur a ten-thousandfold deathly offense that cannot be absolved. What the world ought not hear, ought not speak of, ought not employ is precisely this false composition, the very source of great cunning and deceit. Therefore, I expound the law for Heaven and establish teachings for the virtuous ruler, never daring to approach such matters. I strive only to open the gate of the Dao and virtue while closing the paths of deceit and cunning. Thus, my writings are rooted in the Dao and virtue, discarding and excluding the methods of false composition and deceit, which are entirely absent. Do you not find this strange? This is what Heaven and Earth regard as affliction, what emperors and kings see as harm. I shall again explain it to you, Perfected One: employ the essential Dao and virtue to teach and transform petty men. The greater worthy may uphold goodness and integrity; the middling worthy may become the state’s most virtuous ministers; the lesser worthy may be transformed into compliant and good officials; and even the most ignorant may still become cautious people, unaware of how to harm one another. Thus, from Heaven and Earth, the four seasons, the five phases, the sun, moon, and stars, all employ the true Dao and essential virtue to nurture the myriad things—extending even to the six domestic animals, excrement, soil, and plants—all clothed in its secret Dao and essential virtue to obtain life and growth. If, as you have just said, Perfected One, this is the case, are such people not inferior to the six domestic animals, excrement, soil, and plants? In what you have just said, do you not realize you incur a ten-thousandfold deathly offense that cannot be absolved?”

“I have committed a deathly offense, a deathly offense. I simply did not understand. What now can be done about these mistaken words?”

“If you wish to absolve this offense, on the day of purification, go to an open field at a crossroads and bow in each of the four directions, kowtowing five times in each. First, look up to Heaven, then turn and kowtow to the Earth.”

“Indeed, indeed. Now, Celestial Master, why is this so urgent?”

“As for why this is so urgent, it is not because of you, Perfected One. Rather, your words have incurred the taboos of Heaven and Earth. Since the Highest Antiquity and Middle Antiquity, people have often been taught to envy the true Dao and virtuous power, instead instructing one another to flee and conceal them, sealing them away and cutting them off. They have turned to teaching perverse and cunning ways, guiding and transforming the foolish, causing them all to act wrongly.

Among them, the greatly worthy have distanced themselves to avoid the world, while only the lesser worthy serve as officials—possessing no true Dao, they bring chaos to the people. The most foolish among them, lacking the Dao, rise as bandits and thieves. Both the people and their ministers act perversely, gathering like mosquitoes to roar like thunder, together defying the celestial patterns, destroying the heavenly Dao, opposing the will of Earth, reversing the qi of the four seasons, and disrupting the Five Phases. This gives rise to countless calamities and anomalies, causing the Three Luminaries to lose their proper radiance. The emperors and kings are deeply troubled by this, falling into confusion and disorder, unable to govern in peace—all arising from this very cause.

Thus, Perfected One, do you not realize how grave this transgression is? Heaven will not absolve it. If I did not instruct you, you would bear this guilt yourself.”

Thus, one must dwell in the open wilderness, in places of clarity and brightness. The reason the Way extends in all four directions is that the Dao governs all affairs of passage. The reason it extends in all four directions is that it is entrusted to the four seasons. Heaven dispenses qi to enable you to ascend and commune with it. The four seasons, through their benevolence, give life and completion, thereby absolving your transgressions before Heaven and Earth. Those who err afterward merely imitate you. From this day forward, Heaven will severely punish those who do evil. Therefore, the noble person must always err on the side of great goodness and never on the side of great evil. Be cautious! Be cautious! If even you must act thus, how much more so the foolish common people?

Those who teach with jealousy and envy of the Dao conceal it—this is the way. What you have spoken is always good. Yet a single careless word may be called a great rebellion against Heaven and Earth, the very cause of the sorrow that rulers have known from ancient times to the present. How, then, could one become a noble person in your presence, Perfected One? It is all through learning. To learn the Dao is to become Dao-like; to learn virtue is to attain it; to learn goodness is to become good; to learn the supreme Dao and perfect virtue is to live long into old age, ever increasing in goodness and excellence.

Thus, those who embrace the essential Dao and perfect virtue are called the recluses of emperors and kings, the foremost and most excellent of people, capable of assisting the noble in their transformative work. Those who do not serve in office are the most prudent of people. But those who learn evil become evil; those who learn refinement become refined; those who learn deceit become deceitful; those who learn cunning become cunning. Among them, the most worthy may master eloquent speech, while those who study texts may craft artful prose—yet when petty men acquire such skills, they become treacherous. How can you, in your heart, not teach this?

Therefore, the essential Dao and hidden virtue are what align with the heart of Heaven and the will of Earth, enabling the long-term peace of the state and bringing joy to emperors and kings. To prohibit and suppress them instead of vigorously transforming the people is to incur Heaven’s censure, and the guilt will not be absolved.

Heaven acts through the supreme Dao; Earth dwells in perfect virtue. Together, they give life to the myriad things, without concealment or partiality. Thus, the sages of antiquity modeled their conduct on Heaven and Earth, using the supreme Dao and essential virtue to instruct the foolish, making them prudent and good, and thus easy to govern. Yet in this age, such teachings are often blocked and cut off, so the foolish collectively become cunning and deceitful, losing the heavenly Dao. Unaware of their own wrongdoing, they bring blame upon themselves because the true Dao and perfect virtue are not put into practice. Thus, many suffer Heaven’s censure, and their offenses, deserving death, remain unabsolved.

The foolish, lacking the Dao, disregard taboos and prohibitions, jointly offending Heaven and Earth because they do not know the essentials of Dao and virtue. I have written this text, repeating myself earnestly and repeatedly, fearing that people, sunk in ignorance, might not believe even a single word of my writing—hence the reiteration. Having long practiced evil, some may even call my words false. If the gate of the true Dao and hidden virtue is again severed and left unopened, Heaven’s wrath will not cease, emperors will suffer endless sorrow, officials and people will have nowhere to turn, and chaos will follow, leaving none able to save another. If you truly resent my words before Heaven, it is precisely to resolve and remove this that I have composed the Dao.

People are all entangled in perverse teachings, their ignorance deepening over time. Therefore, I have repeatedly instructed you, Perfected One, to bring forth my Dao and entrust it to a ruler of supreme morality, so that it may be shown to the worthy. Test my Dao swiftly, and you will know the truth of my writings, which resemble Heaven and Earth. Without use or trial, how could one know their [value]? Now, to ensure my Dao is not mistaken, I seek not merely a single scroll for testing.

Be cautious, Perfected One!

“Yes, yes.”

Go forth, and always heed my words. Do not treat them lightly or speak carelessly.

“Yes, yes.”

Do not conceal or hide them. Let all people, in their speech and learning, recognize where gain and loss lie, and no longer act recklessly.

“Yes, yes.”

The Right Explication: Matters the Common Person Ought Not Hear, Ought Not Speak, Ought Not Employ—Severing the Perverse to Bring Forth the True Text
Serving the Master as One Serves a Father: Essential Instructions, One Hundred Fifty-Fifth

“Now, when foolish disciples speak, their words often miss the mark of the Heavenly Master’s intent, and they are frequently subjected to severe reprimand. Yet if they do not venture to ask about their faults, even as the year draws to a close, they remain unable to comprehend them. I humbly request to ask one more question.”

“Speak plainly. Why be so modest? To ask when one does not know is but the natural course.”

“Now, when the foremost essentials of the supreme Dao and its paramount virtues are taught to ordinary people, do they not largely fail to comprehend them?”

“Excellent is your question! How could there be any great comprehension? Why do you doubt this?”

“I have heard that when a son’s wisdom surpasses his father’s, a disciple’s wisdom surpasses his master’s, or a minister’s wisdom surpasses his lord’s, this is called ‘the inferior surpassing the superior in wisdom,’ and it is deemed improper.”

“Your words are both correct and incorrect. That the inferior surpasses the superior in wisdom is indeed improper. If the inferior’s wisdom consists of cunning and deceitful methods, surpassing their superior, then they will turn and deceive that superior. Should you wish to see its effects, consider this: in teaching and learning, if a disciple of a crafty household surpasses his master in skill, he will ultimately harm his master. When those in subordinate positions study and master deceitful, treacherous ways, they will collectively confuse and deceive their superiors. Thus, the great sages of antiquity never recklessly imparted teachings of deceit, cunning, or falsehood. They always deeply contemplated the root and severed the branches, preventing foolish people from knowing such things. Therefore, those who govern a state with cunning wisdom are the state’s greatest thieves.

Thus, the sages of old always focused on transmitting the true Dao, never imparting superficial, deceptive, or manipulative methods. Knowing the profound harm they cause, they consistently closed off such pernicious learning and instead opened the path of good fortune, ensuring the people remained cautious and unaware of how to do wrong.

Should you wish to further verify this truth, consider that in the era of the Three Sovereigns, lords treated their ministers as they would their fathers. At that time, ministers each held the essentials of the true Dao and its virtues, free from deceitful, cunning, or false teachings. Thus, their wisdom all surpassed that of their lords, enabling them to serve as teachers to emperors and kings. Their instruction was like that of a father, and so they were treated as teachers and fathers. This is the principle by which virtue surpasses that of their lords. Thus, they could cause their lords to sit in tranquility, governing with ease and without worry.

Therefore, one whose words are ten out of ten correct can assist an emperor or king; one whose words are nine out of ten correct can aid a great minister; one whose words are eight out of ten correct can serve as a minor official. Those who fall below this standard are unworthy of counsel. Those whose words miss the mark are called reckless speakers, who bring confusion and error to their superiors. Do you understand?”

“Yes, yes.”

“Very well. If you wish to further understand its great effects, consider the Five Emperors: the Dao began to slightly decline, and thus the virtue and power of rulers and ministers could no longer mutually inquire of one another. Those who shared the same school became companions, those of like minds became friends, and though ruler and minister still shared knowledge, they could no longer surpass one another to any great degree. Essential teachings and secret powers became slightly obstructed and impassable, so there were none worthy of being treated as teachers or fathers—only as friends.

By the time of the Three Kings, those who transmitted teachings were often envious of learning, blocking and severing the true Dao and extraordinary powers. Their disciples grew increasingly foolish and benighted, turning instead to superficial embellishments, causing rulers to be dazzled and confused. Their virtue and power were so shallow and meager that they were unworthy of being treated as fathers or even as friends, and so were treated as sons. Their wisdom was scant, and thus they could not plan for emperors and kings in matters of difficulty or ease. This provoked the great wrath of Heaven and Earth, giving rise to unceasing calamities and omens that could not be suppressed. The great fault lies here. Do you understand?”

“Yes, yes.”

“Very well. Now that you have awakened, I shall further clarify for you. Consider the Five Hegemons: their ministers entirely lacked true virtue and power, all capable of crafty deceit and cunning. The means by which they deceived one another were many—ministers often knew perverse, flattering, and deceptive arts, the methods by which they startled, moved, and confused their lords, sometimes even surpassing them. As a result, they rebelled in turn: sons killed their fathers, ministers killed their rulers, subordinates killed their superiors, all harboring the hearts of barbarians devoid of righteousness. Each person possessed crafty and deceptive techniques, each harbored treacherous intentions, and none held the true Dao. Thus, rebellions occurred repeatedly. Therefore, punishments were meted out with axes and drills, and ministers were regarded as entries in a death register.

Moreover, those ministers all harbored flattering embellishments and abundant cunning. Their Dao was not weighty enough to be revered, so they were regarded as livestock—this is the clear effect. Thus, the sages of antiquity, aligning with the will of Heaven, embraced the true Dao, esteemed virtuous and benevolent men, and banished the flattering and cunning, thereby fulfilling the heart of August Heaven. For this reason, our Dao fully opens the gates of fortune and shuts the doors of misfortune, never daring to allow cunning knowledge to surpass that of their lords. Do you now clearly understand?”

“Yes, yes.”

“Be cautious of this.”

The ministers of the highest antiquity were often immortal and long-lived, thus enabling their lords to enjoy longevity; the ministers of the middle antiquity were wise and embraced the Dao and virtue, thus enabling their lords to remain perpetually free from worry; the ministers of the lower antiquity, lacking the true Dao and being foolish, often rendered their lords exceedingly ignorant. When a lord is ignorant, his governance is perpetually chaotic and confused, failing to align with the will of Heaven. The ministers of hegemonic lords are all flatterers and deceivers, full of cunning and crafty deception, collectively deluding their lord, causing him to lose the correct path of Heaven and instead enter the gates of misfortune—thus becoming a great adversary of Heaven. Do you understand this?

For this reason, their governance is entirely inauspicious and cannot endure for long. A true person serving Heaven in affairs must be vigilant daily and must not indulge in reckless or baseless speech. Words should become standards; if speech does not become scripture, it is better to remain silent. If one’s words miss the mark, the sin is profound and ineradicable.

“Yes, yes.”

“Go now, for you have understood.”

**Divine Governance of Humanity’s Adherence to the Root: Secret Method of Hidden Protection, One Hundred Fifty-Six**

“Pray, I ask about a matter of great doubt.”
“Speak your words.”

**Rising:**
“Now the Heavenly Master broadly opens the path of the Dao of Heaven, gathering and collating the texts of ancient Daoist scriptures, taking them as the true essential and secret Way. The true Way is abundant in goodness; its writings enter into the spirit, thus enabling one to behold the divine and govern alongside the gods. If what is governed enters the spirit as the divine does, then it is the true Way. Yet it often comes to fruition in secluded chambers—some are enabled to transcend within the chamber and depart, some enter and exit but cannot leave, and some merely see the divine yet remain bound to this world without ever departing.

**Ceasing:**
Of those who transcend and depart, not one in ten thousand succeeds. Of those who attain great longevity, not one in a thousand succeeds. Of those who attain lesser longevity, not one in a hundred succeeds. Only those who fulfill their allotted years compare to these. Among all the people under Heaven who study and inquire, not one in ten thousand obtains a high office, not one in a thousand obtains a middling office, and not one in a hundred obtains a minor office. As for those who till the land to sustain life, not one in ten thousand gains a hundred million, not one in a thousand gains ten million, and not one in a hundred gains a million. All affairs are thus: their roots are many, but those who transcend the world or attain wealth and nobility are few. This foolish student is deeply troubled by this.

Now, in cultivating the Way, what should be the greatest precept to ensure lasting completion? In study and inquiry, what should be the greatest precept to attain high office? In managing life and amassing wealth, what should be the greatest precept to achieve prosperity? Today, I dare not but ask the Heavenly Master to resolve these doubts, for I fear that without enlightenment, I shall remain forever benighted, never attaining understanding.”

“Excellent, excellent! All true persons who question doubtful matters—Heaven has sent you to inquire. Very well. Sit calmly, listen well with your whole being, and I shall now fully expound the true Way to you, making all things clear so that you may follow and remember them with diligence.”

“Yes, yes.”

“Go forth. When later generations obtain my writings and thereby broadly open the path of the true Way, they will surely all study the true Way. The true Way frequently intersects with the divine; the Way of the gods is solely concerned with governing humanity. The gods delight in those who are kind to people and are startled by those who are not. They do not contend in speech beside people, appearing like flocks of birds coming and going without end. Some speak of people who are about to transcend and depart, some of those who will become wealthy and noble, some of those who will become poor and base. They praise some people and slander others, bringing great joy to some and constant bitter resentment to others.

The gods are beings without form, their transformations without limit. If one can focus the mind and guard the self, refusing to heed their words, examining the heart before acting, keeping the mouth closed to avoid transmitting their words, and not following their sorrows, angers, or joys—steadfastly holding to the root without wavering, devoted to secretly aiding and protecting people and all things, never wishing to harm—then after a year of understanding the Way, one will always act with supreme goodness, seeking benefit without harm, pursuing the Way and doing good until the end of one’s years without ceasing. For this, one must never grow lax. Though ten thousand may transcend, one may not; though ten thousand gain great fortune, one may meet misfortune. Acting thus, the host of gods will turn to aid and protect one, causing one to daily delight in goodness and no longer commit evil. Do you, true person, understand this?”

“Yes, yes.”

“Go forth. You have now understood. Those who practice the Way of the true person yet fall into disorder and ruin do so because their minds and intentions are not single and pure. They are easily pleased, easily angered, easily startled, easily confused, and prone to glib, clever speech, always desiring to speak of good and evil without restraint. When they encounter something they wish to say, they cannot restrain themselves. In such a state, the host of gods come together to deceive them. If they are petty men, they may ascend with demonic words and die, or frequently engage in contentious, reckless speech, or be startled by ghosts and spirits, thereby falling ill and descending into madness.

If one’s mind and intentions are not devoted to a single purpose, joy and anger are without constancy, and actions lose their correctness, one becomes distracted and without direction. One may thus lose worthy friends and good assistants, leading to peril and ruin. The great fault lies in not loving benefit: those above do not wish to benefit those below, heed false gods, and instead desire to harm. Thus, the worthy depart, and one loses their virtuous assistance. As for petty men, they do not wish to honor and respect their superiors but instead heed false gods, deception, demonic words, and reckless speech. This is why the Way is not accomplished—it is the gateway to misfortune. I cannot foresee and record all such outcomes.

In general, when people’s minds are not single, firm, and secret, they are easily swayed. Their actions are often inauspicious, their deeds frequently harmful, and they meet misfortune. Their faults and transgressions accumulate in great number and cannot all be spoken. I have merely outlined the great principles of the Way for the true person, revealing its beginnings, so that the wise and discerning may deeply examine my writings, carefully follow and observe them, and surely come to understand. Do you, true person, comprehend this?”

“Yes, yes.”

“Go forth. You have now greatly awakened. Hold fast to my writings as a profound precept, and those who practice them may avoid misfortune for ten thousand generations. Truly... Thus, when later generations read my writings from beginning to end and fully grasp their essential meaning to put them into practice, not one in ten thousand will fail. If one guards them without ceasing, success will naturally be complete. With a single-minded and good intention, one may join with the gods. With a perverse and evil intention, the Way will surely be lost.

If a great person does not listen carefully, they may lose their rightful position. If a petty person does not listen carefully, they may join with demons. All these bring harm to the self—one cannot but take great care and caution. When people act and err, they bring it upon themselves. Calamity and change arise from within the heart and mind, not from elsewhere.”

“Does the Perfected One know this?”
“Indeed, indeed.”
“How terrifying! How terrifying!”
“If you know fear and terror, then you may be said to have truly entered the Dao. The foolish student has now awakened greatly—let this be your model for conduct. In accomplishing affairs, you will long enter the Gate of Auspiciousness and avoid the Door of Misfortune. The paths of life and death may be clearly seen for all time. Follow this in practice, and misfortune will daily recede, while good fortune will come. Since you already know this, □□ I shall not admonish you further.”
“Indeed, indeed.”

〈Rising〉
“In conducting yourself as a disciple of the Dao, if you study and attain high office, be resolute in your intent. Generally, when people pursue learning, they enter the gate of study today, apply their minds with single-minded focus, constantly seeking to aid and benefit others with love and without deceit. From youth to old age, they study without ceasing until death, never content merely to obtain office. They simply delight in learning, striving to master the classics and the Dao, accumulating goodness without end. Their conduct and reputation are established, their mastery of the classics and the Dao is complete, and they deeply understand the origins of disasters and changes from ancient times to the present. Their conduct and learning benefit those above and bring advantage to those below. Their accumulated goodness cannot be concealed, and their reputation spreads far and wide. Enlightened rulers favor them, summoning and appointing them, while the common people all say, ‘Excellent!’ and ‘Most auspicious!’ This is the sort of person whose praises others speak with joy. Such a one is a good person who studies and transcends the world.”

〈End〉

“Does the Perfected One understand this?”
“Indeed, indeed.”

The One Hundred Fifty-Seventh Admonition on the Failures and Successes in the Dao

“Let me further expound the Dao to you. Those who fail to transcend the world, though they enter the gate of learning today, take no joy in seeking the true Dao or its virtuous teachings. Instead, they crave broad knowledge and extensive observation, believing these alone can lead them to the ultimate mastery of the sages. They do not delight in putting goodness into practice but prefer the superficial embellishments of rhetoric, which they use to deceive and feign. Even after gaining entry into the classics and the Dao, their minds remain scattered, their focus never unified. They indulge in reckless speech, honing their verbal dexterity to harm others, showing no reverence for their superiors and no kindness or care for their inferiors. Their conduct and their grasp of the classics and the Dao are hollow and empty. They are unfit to be worthy ministers to emperors and kings, and instead, they become mere functionaries and petty officials. Others may assist them with wealth and goods, seeking high office to build their reputation, but they then embezzle and plunder resources, advancing private interests at public expense, betraying those above and exploiting those below. Such men disrupt and corrupt proper governance, bringing harm to Heaven and Earth and becoming traitors to the state. They are wolves among the people, wicked sons to their parents. Heaven and Earth detest them, and the spirits loathe them. Thus, when their crimes are exposed, they are often punished by emperors and kings, aligning with the will of Heaven and removing a great harm from the people. These are the schemers who obtain office through deceit.

Some, though their minds are scattered and their hearts empty of true steadfastness, ceaselessly scheme to obtain office. Office, however, is the domain of Heaven’s stellar officials, bestowed upon those of virtue and rewarded to those of merit. It is not recklessly granted to those without merit. Those without merit are disregarded by Heaven and Earth and unloved by the divine spirits. Yet the foolish, unable to recognize their own faults, persist in their vain desire for heavenly office. Malevolent spirits and entities descend upon their hearts, driving them to reckless speech and leading them to utter perverse words they cannot restrain. Thus, some meet death through their own perverse speech—this is what it means. Not only in the pursuit of the Dao, but in failing to grasp its essence, there is peril. In all human conduct, if one does not delight in goodness, all will end in misfortune.

Perfected One, strive earnestly. You are fortunate to harbor good intentions, always seeking to act with kindness and benefit others—you have already transcended. Yet, whether the Perfected One or an ordinary person transcends or not does not lie in what comes before but in what follows. All failures stem from a lack of self-love, from carelessness, from declaring oneself already transcended, only to falter midway and fail to cross over. Thus, when I speak now and cannot stop midway, it is because the Perfected One compels me to continue. If I were to halt my words now, growing careless and silent, I would fear incurring the Perfected One’s resentment. If the Perfected One resents me, he would look up to Heaven, and Heaven would then bring harm upon me. Therefore, I dare not speak lightly, nor dare I close my learning and cease midway. Do you understand?”

“Indeed, indeed.”

“This is how ordinary people bring harm upon themselves. They often fail when they do not understand, when their actions do not align with their roots, and thus they lose their way. You have already rendered great service to Heaven—strive earnestly, strive earnestly!”

“Indeed, indeed. I dare not grow careless in my studies or in ascending the Dao.”

“Go forth. You have already grasped the art of self-transcendence. I have nothing more to add. Let me now fully explain to the Perfected One: there are those who delight in managing their households and accumulating wealth, attaining riches and honor. In their youth, they are capable of labor and diligently apply themselves to their tasks. As they grow older, they continue to think and act with all their strength until they can no more. They promote goodness and conceal wrongdoing, always delighting in doing good, trembling with reverence for their superiors. In all matters of doubt, they exercise caution and restraint, daring not to act recklessly. They care for their inferiors and do not wish to harm others. They do not distort the king’s laws nor take pleasure in following corrupt customs or partaking in reckless feasting. They do not engage in matters that are not urgent. Those who possess wisdom and conduct themselves thus continue until old age without ceasing. Though their substance may seem empty, their words are never frivolous. Thus, they amass treasures and accumulate wealth, thereby becoming accomplished individuals.

People’s worthiness or unworthiness lies in the divergence of their intentions. There are those who are not good: they disrespect their superiors, harm their inferiors, delight in following corrupt customs, and frequently engage in non-essential and reckless behavior. They are glib-tongued, unable to restrain their reckless speech in the marketplace. Such people are doomed to misfortune, chaos, peril, and ruin—they do not walk the Dao. Do you understand?”

“Indeed, indeed.”

“Therefore, those who walk the Dao must concentrate their minds, seal their mouths, and refrain from reckless speech. Thus, the ancients—sages and worthies—observed the luminous laws of Heaven and were able to practice the Dao and uphold virtue. Heaven is singularly focused, moving day and night in the Dao without speech, and thus it alone attains auspiciousness. Earth moves day and night in the Dao without speech, nurturing and sustaining the myriad things, and thus it alone endures in tranquility. The four seasons move alone in the Dao, ceaselessly day and night, and thus they perpetually and singularly bring prosperity to kings. The Three Luminaries move alone in the true Dao without speech, and thus they remain eternally bright, following the revolutions of Heaven. The Five Phases move alone in the true Dao without speech, and thus they become constant with Heaven and Earth. All under Heaven who walk the Dao emulate these examples—there are too many to record. Therefore, if one cherishes and benefits from speech, refraining from reckless words, the Dao may be attained. Those who treat matters lightly and disregard my teachings will surely be harmed by the Dao—there is not a single exception.

Perfected One, you have come from afar to seek answers to your doubts, and thus I admonish you. Reflect upon and ponder these words. I have not failed you. I speak on behalf of Heaven to admonish the virtuous rulers. Heaven bestows upon virtuous rulers, and they must love the Dao. The people will then emulate their rulers, all taking this text as a great admonition. Thus, they may attain auspiciousness and distance themselves from misfortune. This text is meant to admonish the foolish below—guard it well and do not conceal it.”

“Indeed, indeed. Go forth. This admonition may seem small, yet it is vast; it may appear shallow, yet it is profound.”

“What does this mean?”

“Indeed, consider its words—they may seem small, yet their admonition is vast. Reflect upon them, and they may resemble the arguments of common sophists, appearing shallow and unworthy of transmission. Yet when one contemplates their warning to perfect humanity, they are profound.

Thus, when I compose the Dao for the Perfected One, its vastness penetrates to the boundless, its subtlety permeates to the innermost. In reverence, it reaches the highest; in humility, it extends to the lowest. Therefore, it encompasses divine beings above and servants below.

The reason for this is to ensure that whether great or small, wise or foolish, noble or common, all may find its words sufficient.”

“Why is this so? I wish to understand its meaning.”

“Excellent! Your question grasps its essence. Indeed, I compose this scripture for the rulers of Great Peace. When such rulers govern, they must take Heaven as their model, not merely presiding over a small domain confined to a single realm.

Thus, Heaven’s model is supreme without superior, humble without inferior, vast without limit, and subtle without core. It nurtures the myriad twelve thousand things—good and evil, great and small—all benefiting from its protection. It endows them with primordial qi to give life, and in the end, does not harm them. Therefore, it is called Heaven, most divine, the sovereign without peer.

Now, as the qi of the Supreme August arrives and virtuous rulers govern, they must take this as their model. Thus, my Dao ascends and descends, sinks and floats, so that all the worthy may examine it together.

Therefore, in the southeast lies the Earth’s Gate, where waters sustain the pillars of Heaven, not resisting even the smallest flow. All—good and evil, great and small—converge there. Does the Perfected One understand this?”

“Stop.”
“Yes, yes.”
“Go. I wished to continue expounding the boundless discourse, unfolding its grand patterns, but let us pause briefly, each returning to ponder it in our hearts. If one practices the Dao without grasping its meaning, it is like pointing south while asking about the north. With such a mindset, even after ages of study, nothing will be attained. I dare not proceed further—you have already understood.”
*Right: Collected Difficulties on the Dao’s Precepts, Governance, Life’s Success and Failure, and the Origins of Fortune and Misfortune*
*Verification of Longevity Texts, Scroll 158*

“May I ask one doubtful matter? Now, while I am able, I wish to inquire of the Heavenly Master about the texts’ essentials: is there a way for a person to live truly long, to share in affairs without ever growing weary? May I hear of this?”

“Indeed. Do you wish to examine the multitude of texts to discern where the worthy reside?”
“Yes.”
“Be seated, and I shall explain it to the Perfected One. To accumulate texts by the hundreds of millions cannot extend life—what benefit is there to destiny? To fill a chamber with writings yet fail to govern justly—what benefit is there to rule? To fill the court with ministers yet fail to bring the ruler great peace and joy—what benefit is there to the emperor? For one person to father a hundred children, leaving parents to hunger and cold—what benefit is there to kinship? To amass remedies by the cartload yet fail to prolong life—what benefit is there to human destiny? To endlessly expound on matters yet fail to remove the ruler’s disasters—what benefit is there to the court? Such examples are countless and cannot all be recorded. I merely raise the guiding threads for the Perfected One, that all the worthy may reflect deeply on them. Do you wish to know their effect?”

“Only the Heavenly Master may tell me.”
“Very well. Sit calmly and focus, and I shall explain it to you.
*Rise*
Among hundreds of millions of texts, only those that can lengthen life, benefit destiny, and secure the body are true texts—the rest are not. Among a chamber full of writings, only those that can win Heaven’s favor and govern justly are true texts—the rest are not. Among a court full of ministers, only those who can bring joy to their ruler and assist in achieving great peace are the emperor’s true ministers and good officials—the rest are merely functionaries. Of a hundred children born, only one who ensures parents constant joy and no hunger or cold is a worthy and filial child—the rest are mere numbers. Among cartloads of remedies, only those that can extend years are true remedies—the rest are not. Such comparisons in the world are too many to enumerate. The Perfected One must ponder their meaning deeply. My texts use one to infer ten thousand, sufficient to illuminate the Dao of the world. Thus, I instruct the Perfected One to entrust the Dao to rulers of supreme virtue, to scrutinize and verify all common texts and the words of mundane scholars, clearly demonstrating them to the worthy, so that all may awaken together from delusion and confusion. Once common texts are verified, disasters will depart day by day.

For perverse texts and perverse words are the masters of calamity. For upright texts and upright words are the officials that expel perverse and evil forces. When texts are upright and words are upright, perversity has no master and nowhere to abide. Perverse texts and words as masters of perversity are like thieves having a master’s house to lodge in. Once the master dies, thieves have no reason to return. Does the Perfected One also understand this?”

“Yes, yes.”

“Excellent.

The Dao of Heaven, as a model, uses the One to encompass the myriad—yet it cannot be exhaustively recorded in writing. Here ends the discourse.

Perfected One, having received this, you must deeply ponder its essential meaning. With a worthy and enlightened mind possessing nine apertures, understanding comes readily; upon seeing the text, great awakening arises spontaneously—no further questions are needed.

The written word, when excessive, only plunges people into darkness. It is better to lift up its single guiding principle, so that the ten thousand strands arrange and unfold themselves. Thus, the teeming masses, though numerous, are not equal to one sagely ruler. The countless stars, though innumerable, are not equal to the brightness of a single sun. The clamorous words of the crawling multitudes beneath heaven are not equal to one worthy minister in a kingdom. The Dao of Heaven is vast and boundless, without limit—yet it is not equal to the single primordial qi that upholds the mandate of Heaven as its guiding thread.

Worthy rulers of supreme virtue, deeply reflect upon my words, and longevity will naturally extend. If later generations collectively ponder my words, fathers will be kind and sons filial, their virtue daily expanding and brightening. Mothers will be loving and wives obedient, and the entire realm will become worthy and good by dawn. Great and small will vie in doing good, and the later generations will know no coercion. They will no longer recognize perverse texts, nor will flatterers find refuge in them. Disasters and omens will be entirely dispelled, and the Three Luminaries will shine brightly.

This is the art of spontaneity, uniformly practiced by the celestial spirits. Is this not the Way? What sorrow could remain in such great joy? To take this as a model is to follow the course of Heaven. Who records it? It is the numinous work of Heaven and Earth. The texts of verification resonate in harmony with Heaven and Earth—this is the Heaven-ordained tally of trust.

Sagely rulers and worthies should together examine these words. Those who practice them will daily prosper, aligning with the times as if by appointment, fulfilling the desires of Heaven and Earth—hence, auspicious indeed!

Here ends the discourse.

When yin and yang flow in harmony, winds and rains come in season, and the ten thousand transformations vanish. By the texts of verification, I do not praise myself. I truly know this—not merely embellished speech—so act swiftly upon it.

Perfected One, do you understand?”

“Yes, yes.”
“Go forth, go forth. Refine it in detail, and the Dao will come of itself.”
“Yes, yes.”

**Method One Hundred Fifty-Nine: The Secret of Male and Female Reversing Forms**

“I humbly request to ask one more doubtful matter. In the text Your Heavenly Master previously bestowed upon this foolish student, there is mention of *male and female reversing forms*—I wish to hear its meaning.”
“Ah! The text has already explained it sufficiently for one to see—why do you ask again?”
“My mind is dull and blocked, difficult to enlighten. I can only rely on Your Heavenly Master’s secret instruction.”
“Very well, sit calmly, and I shall now explain it to you.

The nature of Heaven and Earth is such that yang delights in yin, and yin delights in yang. Thus, yang ought to transform into yin, and yin ought to transform into yang. In all matters of the Dao of yin and yang, it is ever thus. They mutually delight in one another, and so their refinement and cultivation proceed swiftly each day. However, this must be □□ with graded instructions—it cannot be directly taught to others, lest they fall into heterodoxy. Now, listen carefully.”

“Yang transforms its form to become yin’s form, and yin transforms its form to become yang’s form—this is precisely using one’s own body to assume the other’s appearance. It cannot be directly attained, lest one fall into heterodoxy.”

“Indeed, indeed. Yet I remain half-enlightened and still in doubt.”

“Ah! Why do you find this so difficult to grasp? Simply use your own body as the form: yang becomes like the body of a yin person, and yin becomes like the body of a yang person.”

“Indeed, indeed.”

“You have now understood. Go and practice, and the matter will become clear.”

*Here ends the collection of abstruse texts and essential formulas, recording the successes and failures of the worthy in achieving the Dao through the reversal of yin and yang forms, embracing Heaven and enfolding Earth, and preserving qi without cessation—Formula One Hundred Sixty.*

“I wish to ask Heavenly Master one more matter before I cease.”

“Speak. What doubt remains?”

“As the Dao embraces Heaven and enfolds Earth, who sustains its qi and seasons?”

“Profound! Far-reaching! Subtle! This is indeed the question you ask. What have you observed to prompt this inquiry?”

“I have observed and witnessed the Way of Heaven and Earth, yet I do not understand its ultimate limit—thus I find it strange and ask.”

“Excellent! Your words penetrate to the subtlest meaning. The reason the Way of Heaven and Earth endures long and forever is that it preserves qi without cessation. Thus, Heaven relies solely on qi to determine fortune and misfortune, and all things take it as their model. Without qi, they perish utterly. If you wish to avoid ultimate exhaustion, you should unite with qi as the Mysterious Female, modeling yourself on Heaven—how then could you die? Yet this cannot be swiftly attained; it is achieved only in the secluded chamber. Entering the chamber to contemplate the Dao, you naturally cease eating and unite with qi. Thus, you become one with the numinous spirits of Heaven and Earth, no longer subject to the governance of the vulgar world. You ascend to follow the Great One of Heaven, pay homage at the Central Ultimate, receive the talisman, and circulate freely through the six directions and eight distances—endlessly. Contemplate the words of this text, and you will attain it yourself; the steps to becoming a spirit will be visible. Departing the world to govern in the heavens above, you will no longer be seen. If you wish to further witness its clear proof: the world cannot long endure while one alone governs. Thus, those who attain the Dao ascend to Heaven, which is also their departure from the world. Those who are unwilling to exert themselves for the Dao descend into the earth upon death, unable to long abide in this middle realm. Since the opening of Heaven and Earth, those who depart to avoid the world—though their sacred texts and constant standards remain—are no longer seen. This is the clear proof. Those who do not die and attain the Dao ascend to Heaven; those who die descend into the earth, unable to long remain on the harmonious path of the middle. If you grasp my text, ponder its meaning deeply. If you delight in ascending and wish to live forever, joining your strength with Heaven and partaking in the seasonal sacrifices and feasts of the world below, strive for the true Dao—this is its purest method. If you do not delight in eternal life but delight in death, abandon the Dao and follow the vulgar—you too will return to the earth below, no longer able to long behold the sun, moon, stars, and celestial reckoning. My text is □□—ten thousand times ten thousand, not a single word is lost. Thus, the sages and worthies of antiquity have all departed, and none are seen today—this is its great proof. Ponder it yourself: if you delight in ascending, you will ascend; if you delight in descending, you will descend. None can wrest your will from you.

Therefore, I, as the Virtuous Lord of Great Peace, have established laws and institutions without limiting them to one person. When the qi of Great Peace arrives, if even a single person remains aggrieved and unfulfilled in their desires, then the balanced qi of the Supreme August cannot fully descend. Thus, Heaven has instructed me to broadly open the path, allowing each to freely choose what they may do. The wise and enlightened who delight in life may study my text, contemplate its meaning, enter the chamber to accomplish the Dao, and attain life. The gentle and yielding who delight in assisting emperors and kings in governance may model themselves on my text to bring about Great Peace. Those who delight in managing their households, nurturing life, and accumulating wealth may contemplate my text and complete their allotted years before dying. Thus, each attains their heart’s desire, and none remains aggrieved. Therefore, the qi of Great Peace is able to arrive. ‘Peace’ means level and free from grievance—hence it is called ‘peace.’ Thus, when the Virtuous Lord governs, the qi of Great Peace arises. The reason is that the world harbors no grievances, and each attains what they delight in—this is why the Perfected One is commanded to entrust it to a ruler of supreme virtue. A ruler of supreme virtue must be benevolent, worthy, and enlightened. The enlightened do not wrest away what others desire; they necessarily win the hearts of the world, wishing to align with Heaven’s will and return to the Dao. Do you, Perfected One, understand?”

“Indeed, indeed.”

"On the Appointment of Officials: The Key to Success or Failure, One Hundred and Sixty-First"

“Perfected One, I shall now earnestly caution you with these words, that your conduct may resemble the Way of Heaven.

The Way of Heaven does not wrest away what others desire to do;
The Way of Earth likewise does not wrest away what others desire to do;
The conduct of an enlightened ruler delights in emulating Heaven and Earth, never wresting away what others do.

Thus resembling Heaven and Earth, he alone may be called their equal and win their hearts. Do you understand?”

“Indeed, indeed.”

“When Heaven is about to turn malign and the year portends great calamity, it invariably harms what people strive to do—thus the people reap nothing, and the year brings famine and cold. When Earth is about to turn malign, it injures what nourishes people, roots fail to take firm hold, and sickness spreads—thus the year yields no harvest, and the people suffer hardship and poverty.

When a declining and malevolent ruler courts disaster, he appoints officials without regard for their fitness for office. This is called deliberately disrupting the celestial bureaucracy, violating Heaven’s prohibitions, and forsaking Heaven’s principles. He reverses the proper order, meting out blame and punishment without considering whether the task exceeds their strength or lies beyond human capacity.

It is like ordering a lord to walk a hundred *li* in a single day—one fears he may not reach his destination and halt along the way. What lies beyond human capacity is precisely this.

Thus, if one does not carefully select people but recklessly assigns them to office, this is called afflicting the people and endangering the state—it is called disordering governance and ruining administration.

Heaven and Earth are supremely numinous and enlightened, yet they dare not wrest away what others desire to do. To do so would bring a year of great calamity—how much more so for man?

Perfected One, do you now comprehend and awaken?”

“Indeed, indeed. If one could follow the customs of each state and bestow upon them the Master’s text, thereby instructing and enlightening them—”

“Excellent. You may be called one who understands affairs, for Heaven does not wrest away what people desire.”

“You walk the upright Way and naturally receive Heaven’s mandate, your years and days ever increasing—how could they ever reach an end? You study not for worldly honor or glory, so why seek further? Have you not already attained Heaven’s will and prolonged your years?

Now that I have told you this, can you still say no?”

“Indeed. I receive this great favor with joy and have no further regrets. Yet I fear my strength may falter in propagating the Master’s teachings, for I cannot disseminate them all at once.”

“Why must it be all at once? Simply persist without ceasing, and like a boat carried by the current, it will not be long before you reach your destination.”

“Indeed, indeed. I accept this solemn charge and dare not deviate even by a hair’s breadth.”

“You have already grasped its meaning; I need not admonish you further. Go now, our brief discourse is complete, and the matter is settled. Should you have doubts another day, return again.”

“Indeed, indeed.”

*Right [Section]: The Great Collection’s Difficult Questions on Whether Heaven, Earth, and Climatic Qi Constitute the Dao, and on the Auspiciousness or Inauspiciousness of a Ruler’s Appointment of Officials—Text on Gains and Losses*
*Tai Ping Jing Combined Collation, Scroll 99, Ji Division, Part 14*
*Tai Ping Jing, Scroll 99*

*Riding Clouds and Mounting Dragons Diagram, First Scroll 162*
*Tai Ping Jing Combined Collation, Scroll 100, Ji Division, Part 15*
*Tai Ping Jing, Scroll 100*

*Eastern Wall Diagram, First Scroll 163*
Inscribed on the Eastern Wall

The ancient divine beings admonished their disciples and later learners to create images of good deeds, secretly aiding and benefiting others to ensure constant auspiciousness, for their merit would be doubled.

Overt goodness is met with human chatter and dissolution. Covert goodness, however, is known to Heaven, Earth, and all spirits—thus its merit is doubled.

Those who accumulate virtue are cherished by the wealthy, and their goodness comes as naturally as the sun’s rise. What people praise, ghosts and spirits also praise, thereby aiding and protecting them.

Those who embrace the Dao attain longevity, aligning their concerns with yin and yang, following the movements of the August Spirit, and harmonizing with the nature of Heaven and Earth. By grasping its principles, Heaven protects them; those who lose it fall into chaos, and Heaven does not protect them.

Seeking goodness through goodness—nothing in this is strange.

To attain it through benevolence is the beginning of the Dao;
To attain it through virtue is the harmony of the Dao;
To attain it through the Dao is the highest of the Dao.

Alas! Be cautious, be cautious—act without recklessness. Ponder deeply on this text and transmit it to later generations, that no harm may come.

To follow the turning of the four seasons is the highest of the Dao.

Goodness arises of itself; evil brings illness upon itself. Matters of fortune and misfortune all emerge from within, calling to their kind without losing their essence.

The Dao of Heaven is impartial, responding only to what one cultivates.

Thus, those who came before had disciples, and those who follow are enveloped in virtuous qi. Pursuing learning without cease ensures that one’s fate attains yang fulfillment. Some gain longevity and an unblemished body—this is the fruit of goodness.

Within and without, spirits turn to remove their harm. The disciple stands before them, and the master faces them in response.

All things have their nature; the affairs of the world each follow their kind.

*Tai Ping Jing Combined Collation, Scroll 101, Ji Division, Part 16*
*Tai Ping Jing, Scroll 101*

**West Wall Diagram 164**

Depicting the admonitions of divine persons and perfected ones from the High Antiquity to later learners—an illustration of those who commit evil, act as yin traitors, disdain compliance, and instead delight in harm and jealousy, bringing death and misfortune upon others.

The Dao of Heaven cannot be forcibly seized; those who seize it will inevitably meet death by arms, forfeiture of authority, the ruin of the world, and the destruction of the Way. Sacred texts will be lost, and what was sought as gain will turn to harm—this is the resonant response of Heaven and Earth’s nature.

Thus arises the juncture of the spontaneous. Examine joy to ensure enduring existence—be cautious, be ever cautious.

Do no harm, do no good: goodness arises of itself, and evil collapses of itself. Contemplate these two images and ponder their benefits and harms.

All matters under Heaven follow their kind; even in the space of a hair’s breadth, there is no deviation. Yet people fail to refine themselves, remaining ignorant of their own faults. Once the name of guilt is attached, nothing can be done. Failing to preserve one’s root, death comes with excess transgression.

Evil committed within summons perverse qi from without. Thus, ahead lies the harm of imprisonment, and behind lurk malevolent ghosts—all hastening to battle, unable to cease, leading to the destruction of the self.

Therefore, this illustration is made to instruct later generations. The wise and enlightened receive it as a great warning. The foolish, distrusting the Dao, remain heedless of affairs. The text is precise in its words, not erring by even a fraction.

Thus, those who embrace softness attain longevity, while those who delight in strife ensure their own demise. Matters each follow their kind, never to return. Though one may repent, it is of no avail—the ghosts have already attached themselves.

Heed the warning and awaken, returning in time. If no harm has yet been done, one may still become a person of goodness.

Goodness ascends, while evil descends. The Dao of Heaven is impartial, operating through spontaneity, and thus does not lose its *zhi* (cessation) of law—its workings are like those of spirits.

*Inscribed on the West Wall*
*Tai Ping Jing Combined Collation, Scroll 102, Ji Division, Part 17*

*The Tai Ping Jing, Scroll 102*
*The Divine Person’s Preface on the Emergence of the Scripture, the Diagram, and the Secret of Robes and Colors, Section 165*
