"〈From the beginning〉, I studied in my youth without ceasing, my spirit ever fixed upon it, tears often welling up. Through long accumulation, by the great grace of August Heaven, I was fortunate today to encounter the Heavenly Master in the wilderness.

At first, my learning was deficient, and my inquiries concerned only superficial matters. Originally, I sought the three hundred methods of *guarding the One* and *nurturing nature*, yet when I beheld the Heavenly Master expounding without limit, I dared ask: *Can the body attain peace and long endure?*

〈Ceasing〉, I did not yet see the Heavenly Master expound without limit, so I dared inquire about minor governance. Once I witnessed the Master’s boundless discourse, I then ventured to ask in full about the affairs since the opening of Heaven and Earth—how emperors and kings have succeeded one another, bearing sorrows and hardships, and how celestial disasters and strange omens have never ceased. By what means may these be eliminated?

Moreover, the host of spirits, without cause, jointly harm humanity, preventing people from fulfilling their allotted years. How may this be halted?

Now, having received the Heavenly Master’s stern teachings and profound warnings, at what time should this scripture—*which halts deceit and revives the Dao of Heaven and Earth*—be revealed?"

"It shall be issued on a *yisi* day, entrusted to couriers for transmission. Thereafter, in each year, it shall emerge during the *xuanjia*—the first and supreme decade of Heaven’s celestial stems, coinciding with the inception of *primordial qi*. The text, both front and back, shall be delivered to the state, thereby resolving the successive calamities borne since the beginning of Heaven and Earth.

When delivering it, what characters should be used? The teachings accumulate through its script, yet only the deeply perceptive shall comprehend it. Do not allow the leakage of the *supreme harmony of August Heaven* or the *foremost Dao*. It shall be transmitted to those capable of conveying it, who together shall discern and resolve its meaning.

When the time of *xuanjia* arrives, should one appear confused or seek this scripture, present to them first the *superficial methods of guarding the One*."

"It has been entrusted to courier *fangshi*, to be delivered to a ruler of utmost virtue. What does this mean?"

"One who obtains it and guards it in practice is the rightful recipient; one who does not practice it is not. True persons must not release it prematurely. Moreover, Heaven’s wrath may turn and slay. My warnings are fully expounded herein. □□, for I truly fear Heaven’s decree."

"Now, the Heavenly Master’s teachings and commands descend to this foolish disciple. My heart is heavy, as if I might yet understand, and I dare not betray them. I earnestly ask: *For those who depict the diagrams, how should the divine robes be illustrated?*"

"All must emulate the laws of Heaven, not follow worldly customs. Those who do not comprehend Heaven’s laws depict the figures’ sizes and robes according to their own whims.

Robes follow the colors of the *Five Phases*. Now, let the mother contain the child within, arranging them by color in sequence. The *great layered robe* has five layers; the *middle layered robe*, four; the *lesser layered robe*, three; the *subtle layered robe*, symbolizing *yin-yang*, has two. The *grand assembled robe* is a chaotic blend of six layers.

I wish to hear: *What does the great layering symbolize?* It symbolizes the *qi* of the *Five Phases* uniting. *What do the four layers symbolize?* They symbolize the *Four Seasons* turning and generating one another. *What do the three layers symbolize?* They symbolize the harmony of *father, mother, and child* in *yin-yang* union. *What do the two layers symbolize?* They symbolize the *king* and *minister qi* reaching one another. *What do the six layers symbolize?* They symbolize the chaotic mingling of colors from the *Six Directions*. Thus, the world possesses variegated hues. This is the meaning."

"Excellent! Excellent indeed!"

"Go now, and guard these secret texts with care."

"Yes, yes."

"Now, though this disciple is foolish and lowly, by your grace I have long been entrusted with the Master’s texts and their daily use, and all matters have been clear and complete. Yet I still wish to ask one doubt."

"What is your question?"

"Since the opening of Heaven and Earth, the texts that have emerged are not few—indeed, they have accumulated in great number, many times over, and the River Chart and Luo Writing have brought them forth. Why then does this text not require the River Chart and Luo Writing to emerge?"

"Excellent! Excellent indeed! Your question is keen. Heaven has prompted your words—you have grasped its meaning. Now, Heaven has commanded me to fully reveal to emperors, kings, and the people the responsibility of *cheng-fu* (inherited burdens and blessings). The texts have accumulated in such multitude that they cannot all emerge through the River Chart and Luo Writing. The writings of the River Chart and Luo are vast and must be seen, yet their bamboo slips are too numerous to be fully known. Thus, Heaven has caused them to emerge through people. Heaven, knowing me deeply, has entrusted me with these words. Knowing the difficulty of your questions, it has instead sent you to transmit their essential teachings with me. You have studied diligently—how could you not yet understand the heart of the Dao? For what purpose has a *zhenren* (Perfected One) come?"

"Now, my ignorance and blindness prevent me from knowing myself."

"On the right, the inquiry concerns the closure of storage and the revelation of its diagrams, garments, and texts—on the transmission of rank and scriptures, and the maladies that arise when these are severed. Formula One Hundred Sixty-Six.
**〈Beginning〉**
'You have come from Heaven to study and question doubts; I have been entrusted by Heaven to instruct you.'
'I wish to hear the essential meaning of this formula—by what means is it illuminated? And how is it further clarified?'
'Now, a virtuous ruler who obtains my writings, comprehends them in heart, and practices them—discussing them with many worthies to transform the common people—will necessarily resonate in response with Heaven. This is its clear proof. My Dao is perfected through admonition, not through deceptive words or conduct. This is the formula.'
**〈End〉**
'Indeed, indeed. Your disciple is unworthy and has often troubled the Heavenly Master in vain.'
'If you do not ask questions, there is no way to know these things.'
**〈Beginning〉**
I have long held this learning within me, yet there has been no one with whom to speak, and thus I have not been able to transmit it in due time. Now, if people cannot distinguish black from white, the fault lies with me. Today, having received the transmission and the Perfected One’s questions, I am truly overjoyed. It is no different from ascending a terrace in spring and emerging to see the boundless sky—how could it be otherwise? Heaven’s grievances and knots have given rise to severe illnesses and unceasing transformations. This pent-up stagnation, now released through speech with you, brings joy. Why does the Heavenly Master not go forth to them himself? It is because the ranks and positions do not permit it. My office and duty reside in Heaven; the Perfected One’s office and duty reside on Earth. Earth brings forth the myriad things. Thus, what Heaven generates, Earth nurtures. Therefore, I transmit the Dao to the Perfected One. Earth gives birth to rulers, common people, and the twelve thousand things, all of which receive yang’s bestowal, emerging from within yin. Thus, you may transmit it to humanity.'
**〈End〉**
'Excellent! Excellent! This foolish student is greatly astonished.'"

"Rightly have you received this. Had you not earnestly questioned the Heavenly Master, there would have been no way to know it—you merely guessed and doubted, yet dared to ask so boldly."

"Excellent! This marks you as a student who comprehends matters, and this is not by your effort alone. Truly, Heaven has bestowed upon you this heart, enabling your words. Now, though you were once obscured and unaware of your own conduct, you are now made profoundly self-aware, illuminated as by the light of sun and moon. Yet you still doubt the sincerity of my words.

Though Heaven may wish to reveal something, it does not speak to humanity, making its intent difficult to discern. My writings carry Heaven’s commands, as clear as cinnabar and indigo. Should you disbelieve and privately conceal or suppress my texts, refusing to release them in due time, Heaven will afflict you with misfortune. If you persist in obstructing them, your fate will be dire indeed. It is Heaven that sent you to seek clarification and proof, and that compels the Perfected One to bring forth these teachings as clear and trustworthy evidence. Excellent! Excellent! Perfected One, take heed and be cautious."

"Indeed, indeed. Now, the Heavenly Master’s office is in Heaven, and you act out of necessity. I venture to pose one further doubt."

"Do you hesitate to speak?"

"Very well. In all matters of Heaven, are all things done by Heaven’s envoys, with transmissions given? Or is it only the Heavenly Master and this foolish student?"

"Alas! You grow more foolish—how can you not know that all things under Heaven are Heaven’s envoys? Each has its appointed duty, together fulfilling the Dao of Heaven. If even one thing is lacking, the Dao of Heaven is incomplete. Why do you remain ignorant of this? How profound is your blindness!"

"This ignorant one has not yet fully grasped it; may the Heavenly Master’s explanation bring clarity."

"Go, you have been sufficiently instructed."

Go, then, and strive with all your might. Every person has their appointed duty, and thus each becomes a vessel of Heaven’s envoys—how could one dare to labor alone by one’s own nature?"

"By no means, by no means. I shall go now."

**Scriptural Section 167: The Essential Formula for Heaven’s Numbers**

**〈Opening〉**
At the origin of Heaven’s numbers, when Heaven and Earth were yet undivided, the accumulated *qi* coalesced as one. Then it split into two, forming husband and wife. Heaven bestowed upon Earth, conceiving in the Dark Obscurity, and it was named *jiazi*. Its roots spread to the northeast, in *chou* and *yin*. First appearing in *mao*, it fully flourished in the southeast, in *chen* and *si*. Its branches hung in the south, nurtured at *wu*. Turning old in the southwest, in *wei* and *shen*, it matured in the west, where the sun set at *you*. Finally, it concealed itself in the northwest, in *xu* and *hai*. Thus, the numbering begins at one and ends at ten. Ten is the origin of the ten stems and the root of the Five Phases. When the number multiplies tenfold, it reaches one hundred and is complete. Therefore, Heaven’s inner cycle of one hundred days reaches its end. Thus, the Dipper establishes at *chen* and breaks at *xu*. "Establishes" means to stand—hence all things strive to reach full growth. "Breaks" means to decay—hence all things perish at *xu*. The numbers extend through the eight directions of Heaven and Earth, completing at ten. Yin and Yang establish and break, cycling endlessly in accord with the Dipper’s pointer, by which affairs are made clear. My writings serve to dispel harmful *qi*, modeling Heaven as their law.

**〈Closing〉**

**Right: Inquiry of the Heavenly Master—Verified and Illuminating Formula**

**[Preserved]**
Heaven bestows human destiny according to fixed patterns. What Heaven and Earth reserve for themselves is thirty years—akin to the intercalary months added when Heaven, Earth, sun, and moon align. Thus, this is the private destiny; those who exceed it are destined to become immortals.

Heaven’s destiny: the upper lifespan is set at one hundred twenty years; Earth’s lifespan at one hundred years; the human lifespan at eighty years; the hegemonic lifespan at sixty years; and the lesser lifespan at fifty years. Those who fall short of these measures have no fixed count in life and death, for they all suffer the calamities of inherited burdens.

Why, then, do they complain of injustice? Each person’s life is allotted a Heavenly reckoning by constant law, yet most fail to exhaust their allotted span. Heaven’s reckoning is boundless, so those who do good receive additional years—these are the surplus years added to them.

To know the great effect, consider this: in a village of ten households, each with a thousand acres of land, if nine households do evil and perish, leaving only one household to do good, it will inherit the fields of the nine. This is the principle. Do not expect Yin and Yang to protect people. If one fails to fulfill their allotted span yet hopes for Heaven’s reward, they will not receive it.

If today you feed someone, and tomorrow they feed you in return, it is not called "feeding others" but "lodging provisions." If today you give someone drink, and tomorrow they give you drink in return, it is not called "giving drink" but "lodging refreshment." If today you carry a burden for someone, and tomorrow they carry one for you, it is not called "bearing another’s load" but "lodging cargo." If today you lend someone strength, and tomorrow they repay it, it is not called "aiding others" but "exchanging merit." If today you praise someone, and tomorrow they praise you in return, it is not called "praising others" but "taking turns in commendation." Countless such examples exist, and none receive Heaven’s reward.

Yet if others do not protect me, and I alone secretly protect them, Heaven rewards me. If others speak ill of me, and I alone do good, Heaven rewards me. If others do not aid me, and I alone gladly aid them, Heaven rewards me. If others do not feed or give me drink, and I alone gladly feed and give them drink, Heaven rewards me. If others teach deceitful and hypocritical ways to exploit one another, and I alone teach others to do good with utmost sincerity, Heaven rewards me. If others claim Heaven and Earth are unknowing, and I alone secretly revere and serve them, Heaven rewards me. If others secretly plot to deceive their rulers, and I alone secretly protect and benefit them without daring to deceive, Heaven rewards me. If my parents do not love me, and I alone love and protect them, Heaven rewards me. Countless such examples exist.

Let the Perfected One reflect on this.

The superior person seeks Heaven’s reward; the middling person seeks human reward; the foolish do not give yet demand reward. The supremely good receive Heaven’s reward and transcend; the moderately good receive human reward, so they are loved, benefited, and served. The foolish, who do no good yet demand reward, are despised and punished by Heaven, Earth, and humanity.

Thus, in the Highest Antiquity, the *qi* of August Heaven descended in full to give life, the *qi* of the Earth Spirit ascended in full to nurture, the *qi* of the Five Phases joined forces, and the *qi* of the four seasons harmonized. The Three Luminaries shone in turn, and all under Heaven united as one in heart. The nature of Heaven is the highest conduct—honor it, esteem it, love it, and protect it. Since Heaven’s nature is good, it gives birth to all things without exception. Earth’s nature is good, nurturing all things without exception. The sage delights in ordering Heaven and Earth, and all things receive his merit. The great good, divine immortals, and perfected beings assist Heaven and Earth in their work, never daring to act contrary to their own suffering. They harmonize with the primordial *qi* and align with Heaven’s heart, thus enjoying enduring fortune and no misfortune.

The sages and worthies of old pondered deeply and planned far ahead, thereby understanding Heaven’s Dao and intent. They devoted themselves to secretly doing good and dared not do evil. They clearly saw August Heaven’s bright prohibitions, yet those below turned their backs and transgressed them. With shallow learning and weak faith, they disbelieved Heaven’s prohibitions—thus, they were difficult to transform, lost their way, and perished early.

I wish to hear of Heaven’s lifespan of one hundred twenty years, Earth’s lifespan of one hundred years, the human lifespan of eighty years, the hegemonic lifespan of sixty years, and the lesser lifespan of fifty years. The Three Norms begin in the east, the head of Heaven. The year and month reach their limit in the northeast, the pole of Heaven. As for Heaven’s lifespan, it is the firmness of numbers.

The northeast is the beginning of all things. The great reckoning of the year concludes here, thus one hundred twenty serves as the image of Heaven. Earth is yin, ever receiving bounty, and the northwest is the extreme of yin. Yin brings death while yang gives life—hence *hai* (亥) is the kernel, the end of yin at the northwest corner. The northwest governs Earth’s fate, so Earth’s lifespan reaches one hundred years. Eighty and sixty mark the cessation of yang and the rise of yin, coinciding with the onset of autumn. Autumn is the season when the white qi and the White Tiger hold sway, hence the hegemonic lifespan. Fifty signifies yang qi flourishing above while yin qi stirs below, yin contending with yang’s transformation—thus the lesser lifespan. Beyond this, all are called lives without constancy. How grievous the knotting of grievances!

Now I shall enlighten you with one solution, by which you may nurture yourself to the utmost through all ages—do not forget it. Those who wish to avoid misfortune and distance themselves from harm, to attain long life, must truly know how to cherish, love, and befriend themselves. By thus nurturing themselves, they may remain free from calamity. To preserve the body for long, regulate food and drink in due measure—neither too much nor too little—this is self-love and self-nurturance. To shut the gates and dwell within, avoiding worldly affairs, is self-love and self-nurturance. To read without limit, content in poverty and humble station, free from care—this too is self-love and self-nurturance. Yet all that came before was not so.

To speak of self-love is to speak of sincerity. Sincerely cherish and protect yourself, ever mindful that the body is incomplete; even with eyes closed, you still perceive its incompleteness, never apart from it for a moment. Reflecting thus, you grow anxious, until you feel sated without eating—such is the person of self-love. To speak of self-regard is to speak of cherishing the body’s form, its every aspect visible and pondered. Truly loving and cherishing without cease, the countenance radiates light. Day and night, it cannot be forgotten, becoming a constant practice. Thereby the flesh becomes buoyant and strength increases—this is the Dao of self-regard and self-love.

Now I cause men and women, young and old, worthy and unworthy, to gather and submit memorials, that the emperor may be enlightened and perceptive. The emperor is like the Pole Star, silently abiding in its place while all stars come to present their affairs. The greater ones stand before, the middling in the middle, the lesser behind. If even one star fails to appear, the qi is cut off, and Heaven’s movements are harmed. For the stars are the essence and radiance of the people and all things. Thus, if one person cannot reach the emperor, one star likewise cannot reach him. Thereupon Heaven’s qi becomes disordered, and Earth’s qi turns contrary. Therefore, instruct all officials and commoners, great and small, to submit memorials together, to unblock Heaven’s qi, to stabilize the stellar reckoning, to dispel Heaven’s ailments, and to resolve the emperor’s burden of inherited transgressions.

Thus, I issue decrees through three channels to ensure no obstruction: senior officials record calamities and omens within cities and walls; road administrators record those along thoroughfares; and those in the four wilds record those in the countryside. Each takes note of the long and short, passing word to one another, and together they vie to submit their reports. Senior officials must memorialize; townsfolk must memorialize; travelers must memorialize. If senior officials do not submit, they fear the people will; if the people do not, they fear travelers will; if travelers do not, they fear officials will. Thus, all are made to sit together, and only then do they compete to present matters.

When officials and people are trustworthy, the emperor employs them without betrayal, so they delight in their service. The emperor gains wisdom and is called a ruler after his own heart, thereby securing long peace for himself. Officials and people honor Heaven and Earth and remain free from illness. Heaven, Earth, and the four directions all benefit, ensuring enduring fortune and serving as a model for ten thousand generations. This is entrusted to a ruler of supreme virtue, that the people may know Heaven’s intent, enabling them to secure and preserve themselves, free from confusion.

Great assemblies are convened to rectify affairs, to examine the roots of Heaven and Earth, to eliminate the terrors of Heaven, the faults of Earth, and the harms to the state, and to establish the *Dongji Jing*. Here is depicted a divine person in feathered robes, ascending to Heaven in a nine-dragon chariot, accompanied by lesser immortals on simurghs and cranes, with colored clouds billowing ahead, as if bidding farewell. Let all be open and unobstructed, to accord with the hearts of Heaven and Earth, to turn back Heaven and Earth’s disasters, to smooth the discourse of Heaven and Earth, and to let the people dwell securely in their places, with all things unharmed.

Thus, Heaven issues written decrees, enabling messengers to traverse ten thousand leagues, conveying their words to gladden the virtuous, to recognize the wicked, and to untangle grievances. Thereby the emperor, dwelling within a hundred layers, attains long security, his wisdom reaching distant lands. Since the Highest and Middle Antiquity, many have turned their backs on Heaven and Earth, deceiving their superiors. Thus, disasters and calamities have daily increased, and the dead cannot be numbered. The emperor has long been distressed, unable to restrain his subordinates from deceit and falsehood, so Heaven has sent forth texts through three channels to unblock the qi, to delight in knowing gains and losses, to harmonize above and below, and to extend remonstrance to the humble in distant lands, that no grievances remain, to accord with August Heaven’s heart, to rejoice in the removal of disasters, and to prevent Heaven’s wrath.

In the Latter Age, human hearts are perverse and obscured, unlike the Three Sovereigns of Highest Antiquity, whose hearts were simple and sincere, their intentions single-minded. Each delighted in according with Heaven’s heart, loyal and trustworthy, never deceiving their superiors—thus no texts were needed. In the Latter Age, petty men are foolish and deluded, distorting words and fabricating falsehoods, deceiving Heaven and Earth, and hoodwinking the emperor. Thus, Heaven and Earth are constantly enraged and send down calamities. When Heaven and Earth’s ailments are dispelled, the emperor is secure and long-lived, the people are at peace in their places, all things fulfill their Heaven-appointed years, no resentments remain, yin and yang proceed in harmony, and the host of spirits rejoice greatly—this is the essential Dao.

〈Beginning〉 The Chart of the Dao of Spontaneity Completed as Admonition 〈End〉 Scroll 168

〈Beginning〉 On Emptiness: Emptiness is inwardly replete yet outwardly empty, as if something were not. Reverse the womb and embryo to dwell with the Dao; preserve the heart alone, suspending the dragon’s thoughts; thus becomes the chamber of spirit, gathering the Dao in emptiness. Roam only with qi, hence emptiness; in qi and spirit, all else is cast aside. The heart as master ensures no deviation; examine its intent closely, never forget the true scripture. Attain this and transcend, roaming long; why not hasten to refine, instead joining the foolish? Once misfortune arrives, great calamity befalls; abandon true simplicity, and revert to dust and ash. The worthy see the scripture and take heed 〈End〉 Admonition on the Chamber of Emptiness.

〈Beginning〉 On Non-Action: Non-action is action without contrivance, thus linked to the Dao. It emerges before infancy, enters the unbroken. Reaching the Great Beginning, one returns; at heaven and earth’s inception, the source of yin and yang. Entering the art of non-action, the body may be preserved; abandoning root for branch is the Dao’s affliction. Departing the Great Beginning, preservation becomes difficult; straying far from life, one nears death’s gate. Fondness for worldly affairs harms the soul and spirit; holding to two and forgetting one loses their counterpart. Can one not take heed? This is the origin of the Dao. You, guard the One—source of benevolence and worth. Heaven’s Dao follows the One, hence completeness; earth’s Dao follows two, nearing ghosts and spirits. Discern non-action, and the Dao’s spirit is supreme. Reflect deeply on this, and the Perfected Person leads. Seal your golden gate, let nothing depart; silence without sound, spirit endures long. When spirit and qi are complete, the gate of immortality opens. How easy the Great Dao, no longer vexing! Heaven’s Dao shows no partiality, turning to the benevolent and worthy 〈End〉 On Non-Action.

〈Beginning〉 The Law of Spontaneity, linked to the Dao, brings fortune when upheld, calamity when lost. Like the myriad things born whole, one root with ten thousand branches yet no spirit—ponder this, and the Dao reveals itself. All trace back to primordial chaos, emerging from the wondrous gate, neither adding nor diminishing, guarding spontaneity. All things born possess spirit, yet of eighteen hundred breaths, humans are supreme. Thus may one avoid death and become an immortal; those who perish early lose spontaneity. Even birds and beasts endure—how much more humans? The foolish scorn the Dao, their aspirations low, bound to earth; the benevolent and worthy treasure the Dao, swiftly ascending heaven’s gate. The spirit’s Dao does not die; the ghost’s Dao ends. You who wish to follow it, like a ring without end. Beware of eccentricity, lest it bring harm; neither recklessly abandon nor invite death. Heaven and earth’s nature uniquely honors spontaneity; each follows its course, daring no opposition. The Dao flourishes in non-action, emptiness, and spontaneity—noble scholars delight in it, lesser scholars resent it. Study carefully under a master, speak no reckless words; with a master, the Dao is clear; without, transmission is difficult. Learning without a master’s instruction, the noble person remains silent. Reckless action breeds chaos; self-mutilation invites misfortune. When the Dao is complete, spontaneity is achieved 〈End〉 Admonition on the Dao Completed.

Those who pursue the Dao take their instructions from the inner and outer critiques upon entering the chamber. When the appointed days are fulfilled, open the door and enter to observe. For those who have already critiqued themselves within, do not enter to inspect; for those who have not critiqued themselves, let the joyous ones enter to observe. When the door is opened and one enters to inspect, those wishing to depart may do so.

Those who inscribe the three Daoist conduct texts take their instructions from collective deliberation, treating it as Heaven’s trust, and thus elevate the person in question. Those who rectify the spirits take their instructions from the clarity of the myriad people, treating it as Heaven’s trust. Those who wish to correct ordinary texts take their instructions from collation and verification, treating it as Heaven’s trust. Those who delight in knowing the trustworthiness of our Daoist texts take their instructions from swift and decisive action, aligning with Heaven’s resonance. The good flourish daily, while the evil diminish daily—this is Heaven’s trust.

Those who wish to appoint and employ good people take their instructions from the nine persons. Those who inquire whether one has succeeded or failed in the chamber take their instructions from absolute clarity—form without concealment or obstruction, this is Heaven’s trust. Those who wish to know if they have attained the Dao in body and become deathless take their instructions from the body’s transformation into spirit, thus transcending the world—this is Heaven’s trust.

Those who wish to thoroughly understand the meaning of our texts read them from beginning to end, and their minds will become brilliantly illuminated, all doubts dispelled. Once the meaning is grasped, it cannot be forsaken. Those who wish to verify our texts as true or false take their instructions from governing toward the Great Peace by day—this is Heaven’s trust.

Those who wish to know whether longevity is attainable take their instructions from the era after the Great Peace. If the Great Peace has not yet arrived, the calamities of former generations will bring harm, making it difficult to fulfill one’s destiny—this is Heaven’s trust. Those who wish to know the Great Peace through the yang force take their instructions from the severing of metal. Those who wish to suppress and eliminate treacherous ministers and malevolent schemers through water and fire take their instructions from the severing of metal and the decline of the market’s wine.

Those who wish to see the Dao of Heaven flourish greatly take their instructions from collating all texts and the common people’s decisive words. Those who seek efficacious medicine take their instructions from collating all medical texts and verifying them. Those who wish to swiftly attain the Great Peace take their instructions from fully revealing the true texts and utterly eliminating the false ones.

Those who delight in ensuring people no longer kill or harm women take their instructions from each dwelling in their place, providing for their clothing and food according to their means, so they do not return to grieve their parents and rebel. Those who wish to eliminate illness and widely propagate the Dao take their instructions from swallowing the cinnabar script’s characters.

To know the essential methods of compiling and practicing the texts: follow their words, reiterate them earnestly, and bind them with good discipline. Practicing them for a single day dispels the harm of a hundred cunning hearts, transforming all in an instant to rectitude—this is Heaven’s trust.

〈Commencing〉
"May I ask, what is the meaning of *rui*?"
"Why do you feign ignorance?"
"I dare not feign it—I truly do not understand. I hope the Heavenly Master will not reject me but grant me a single word of instruction."
"Very well, sit calmly.

〈Commencing〉
*Rui* is purity, stillness, uprightness, rectitude, devotion, and unity. The heart aligns with Heaven and Earth, never transgressing the seasons’ commands."

"May I ask how one knows this purity, stillness, uprightness, rectitude, devotion, and unity?"
"Excellent is your question. The nature of Heaven and Earth, from ancient times to the present, ensures that the good attain goodness, the wicked attain wickedness, the upright attain uprightness, and the perverse attain perversity—this is the natural art, nothing strange about it. Thus, when the human heart is upright, pure, still, and utterly sincere, it moves Heaven; without evil intent, auspicious responses and good omens arise for it. If you wish to further know its great trustworthiness, the ancient sages and worthies all cultivated a heart of purity, stillness, devotion, and unity—hence they could summon auspicious responses."

〈Concluding〉
"All those who employ deceitful and false hearts receive no good responses—this is the great luminous proof of Heaven and Earth. Do you understand?"
"Indeed, indeed. But do they also receive responses?"
"Certainly—the perverse attain perversity, which is also their response. The unharmonious attain disharmony, and the harmonious attain harmony—this is the evident efficacy of Heaven’s response."
"Excellent! 〈Concluding〉 Excellent! Your foolish disciple now understands."

〈"Esoteric Writings Beyond the Canon"〉 "Secret Formula of Exceptional Deeds: Loyalty and Filial Piety" 175

〈Opening〉
"May I ask: when a person does good, what should the most filial sons, most loyal ministers, and most obedient disciples reflect upon and offer to their lords, fathers, and teachers?"
"They should offer the most exceptional, precious, and rarely encountered texts—those that attain the highest level."
"If loyal ministers, filial sons, and obedient disciples can always delight in such acts, why not offer what is commonly known rather than the exceptional?"
"What is commonly known, the highest already possess—why offer it again?"
"Your foolish disciple does not grasp the meaning."
"Soon I shall make you understand its truth. Whatever in the world is rare and prized—though never before seen—when offered to one’s lord, this is the act of the most loyal minister. Never-before-seen fine foods offered to one’s parents—this is the act of the most filial son. Never-before-heard teachings offered to one’s teacher—this is the act of the most obedient disciple. Do you understand?"
"Indeed, indeed. But why, when offering what is already possessed by the highest, do they still offer it again?"
"Such offerings are made in response to their expectations, and the fault of redundancy is not absolved."
"Why is this so weighty?"
"Since you still do not comprehend: what people already possess, they grow weary of—why offer it again? 〈Closing〉 To offer what others disdain is called redundant offering. To lower oneself and redundantly offer—does this not, in your view, incur blame?"
"Your foolish disciple now perceives."
"Thus, when obtaining auspicious responses and rare treasures, they should be offered to one’s lord, father, and teacher. What they already possess—take care never to offer again. Therefore, 〈Opening〉 from ancient times to the present, the great sages’ determination in all matters has been to discard the common and select the exceptional, thereby aligning with the heart-mind of Heaven and Earth—this is the meaning. 〈Closing〉 Do you understand?"
"Excellent! Excellent!"

**Disaster and Illness: The First Scroll on Concealment Secrets, One Hundred Seventy-Six**

"May I ask, Heavenly Master, by what means can one know when a text wishes to be enacted, and by what means can one know when it wishes to be concealed?"
"Do you seek clarity on this?"
"Observe the signs of disaster and illness as proof. When illness befalls a person upon its release, Heaven desires concealment. When illness befalls a person upon its concealment, Heaven desires its enactment."
"By what further means can this be made clear?"
"By the qi of Heaven’s four seasons in motion, which gives life and nurtures the myriad things, all in accord with Heaven’s intent. When all things delight in emergence yet are forced into concealment, great misfortune follows. When all things yearn for concealment yet are compelled to emerge, this too is great misfortune. Both violate Heaven’s mandate and will later bring forth great disasters. Do you delight in knowing that Heaven delights in its own course, and that this is not to be taken as divination? Do you, Perfected One, understand?"
"Indeed, indeed."
"Thus, from ancient times to the present, when affairs are undertaken without thorough consideration, Heaven’s Dao is lost, and the burden of inheritance arises. This is why the people are governed without the Dao, disrupting Heaven’s correct way, causing human governance to diverge, and thus the people and the myriad things suffer unjustly."
"I humbly ask: when there is no Dao, it is a law of capital punishment. Why does the Heavenly Master not establish severe penal laws to punish each according to their transgressions?"
"In the present age, affairs are already judged by their transgressions—this is fairness."
"Then why does the Heavenly Master not punish those without the Dao?"
"It cannot be done."
"Why?"
"For the ancients, their errors were but minor deviations from the Dao, mere lapses in conduct—not sufficient for punishment. Later generations inherit the burden, accumulating transgressions. Though their actions may invite death, their conduct is but empty and hollow. Later generations learn from their predecessors, and though they lose the Dao, governing without it, they transmit their ways through successive teachings, not one alone bearing the fault. Thus, they cannot be subjected to severe punishment. Reflecting on the transgressions of those in earlier ages, they are grave enough to warrant death. Yet the divine sages, in establishing laws, cannot suddenly impose heavy penalties that would extinguish human generations. Therefore, Heaven sent me down to reform their conduct, remove their burdens, and without exposing their faults, let Heaven, Earth, and humanity govern together, causing spirits to afflict them with illness and disaster. Later generations will see this as the manifest efficacy of the teachings I received from Heaven. Do you understand?"

"“Yes, yes.”
“Proceed. When the celestial discourse concludes, transmit its virtue to the virtuous ruler.”
“Yes, yes.”
“Go now, ask no more.”
“Yes, yes.”

Here ends the esoteric discourse on auspicious responses.

*Tai Ping Jing*, Scroll 109

**Essential Record of the Two Hands’ Strategic Characters, One Hundred Seventy-Seventh**
**Opening Passage:**
Heaven possesses two hands, which together accomplish all matters. If one hand suffers from illness, evil, or malice, nothing can be achieved. Heaven greatly resents this; Earth regards it as taboo. The world falls into chaos and nothing succeeds—all due to that one hand’s evil and failure to join forces. When all matters remain unresolved and the six directions lack great peace, it is likewise because the two hands suffer from illness or evil and fail to unite their strength. Good fortune and ill, safety and peril—all arise from these two hands. Profound One, do you truly comprehend this deeply?
“Not fully. Only when the Heavenly Master reveals the essential meaning can I come to know it. Otherwise, I would remain in eternal darkness and confusion, with no way to understand. The master is the root of all teaching and transformation under Heaven and Earth. Though it be difficult, how could one not speak of it?”
“Excellent! The Profound One’s inquiry into matters is most apt. Has Heaven appointed you to pose these questions? Your words are essential and...” “Very well.”

Be seated, and I shall expound this meaning in full for all the Perfected Ones. When the world models itself upon and acts accordingly, no further misfortune or disorder shall arise. In the heavens, the gods call this the "Two Hands Strategy," recorded as an essential text. When a state practices it, it endures long; when common people practice it, they prosper for generations. The essential Dao is about to emerge, near at hand within the bodies of ordinary people. Now I shall distinguish and explain it for all the Perfected Ones.

“Indeed, indeed.”
“Heaven and Earth are the Two Hands that give birth to all things. The four seasons are the Two Hands that transmit and nourish all beings. The Five Phases are the Two Hands that transmit, complete, and deliver all things to one another. Man and woman, husband and wife, are the Two Hands that transmit and continue the Yin and Yang of Heaven and Earth. Master and disciple are the Two Hands that transmit, teach, and communicate all matters, texts, and the Dao and virtue. Ruler and minister are the Two Hands that transmit and govern all matters, the people, and all things. These are six matters, merely lifting the guiding principles to reveal their beginnings—there are more than can be written. All things that require mutual support to accomplish are the Two Hands. In the heavens, this is called ‘double compasses and overlapping squares,’ all of which must correspond to one another. If one hand is perverse or unequal, nothing is accomplished. In the heavens, this is called the ‘governance of great disorder’; in the six directions and eight distant regions, it is called ‘widowers and widows, severed lineages,’ and the days grow ever more decadent. Without accomplishment, it is precisely because the Two Hands fail to join forces.”

“Excellent! Excellent! May I ask why the heavens rightly name this the Two Hands?”
“Excellent indeed is your question, for it grasps the meaning. The Two Hands signify their equality, unity of strength, neither advancing nor retreating, so that matters may afterward be accomplished. When the Two Hands do not join forces, matters cannot be accomplished. Thus, all things model themselves upon these Two Hands and must each find their proper person. When strength and hearts unite, modeling the Two Hands, the qi of good fortune, safety, and great peace immediately arrives. Those who do not model the Two Hands cannot, even after billions upon billions of years, bring forth the qi of the Supreme Peace of the Highest Sovereign. The qi of great peace constantly desires to emerge, just as Heaven constantly desires it through these Two Hands. If they are not long regulated and guided, it causes blockage, preventing its passage and governance, leaving one despondent and full of reproach. The fault lies in the Two Hands’ failure to harmonize. If the Two Hands are balanced and harmonious, the qi of the Supreme Peace of the Highest Sovereign emerges, arriving one after another without delay.

Excellent indeed! Thus, if Heaven and Earth do not join forces, the myriad things and all matters have no way to emerge. If the four seasons do not join forces, all things have no way to grow. If the Five Phases do not join forces, all things have no way to be completed. If ruler and minister do not join forces, all matters have no way to be governed. If husband and wife do not join forces, descendants have no way to grow, and the family way has no way to be established. If master and disciple do not join forces, no knotted matters can be untied, the Dao and virtue have no way to flourish, obscuring mists have no way to clear, and the great transformation of the six directions and eight distant regions has no way to proceed. Therefore, all must join forces, likened to the Two Hands, only then can there be communication. Not likened to the Two Hands, it daily brings misfortune. Even if one attempts to govern and heal it, there is no benefit, and still, there is no way to achieve success. Only prolonged, empty sorrow and daily distress ensue.

Thus, all that model the Two Hands must select and employ the proper persons. Those who do not find the proper persons, the gods in the heavens call ‘half-dead.’ If one does not hold to one hand and act alone, how can there be any accomplishment or success? Perfected One, you have come from afar to inquire for Heaven’s sake. All doubtful matters should be deeply pondered with this meaning and a sincere heart. The heart is born of fire and returns to be entrusted to fire. Govern and model the people, and you shall prolong life and increase years, not missing even one in ten thousand. I do not deceive you. Show this to the virtuous ruler and to all people. The worthy shall each ponder its meaning and dare not transgress it. To employ it is called enriching and nurturing oneself; not to employ it is called distressing and tormenting oneself.

Profound indeed! My Dao is the pure intent of Heaven. One may only advance, not retreat; one may only comply, not oppose. Compliance purely accords with Heaven’s heart; opposition brings disorder. When disorder and calamity surge, human intent goes west while Heaven’s intent goes east—this is called being at odds with Heaven’s intent.”
“Excellent! Excellent!”
“Go, for you may now be said to have awakened to this knowledge.”

〈Halt〉

**Four Auspicious and Four Inauspicious Outcomes, Formula One Hundred Seventy-Eight**

Before the Perfected Ones, 〈Rise〉 now when common people recommend scholars to present to the emperor, entrusting them to the state, 〈Halt〉 how many auspicious outcomes arise if the right person is obtained, and how many inauspicious outcomes if the wrong person is chosen? What can be achieved if the right person is obtained, and what can be overturned if the wrong person is chosen? Let the various Perfected Ones deliberate and respond with precision.

So it is. Obtaining the right person brings four auspicious outcomes; failing to obtain the right person brings four inauspicious outcomes.

If the right person is obtained, the heavens and earth, the six directions, and the eight distant realms are at peace. If the wrong person is obtained, the heavens and earth, the six directions, and the eight distant realms are not at peace.

I wish to hear the essential meaning.

So it is. When recommending a scholar and obtaining the right person, the ruler above is able to govern, achieving success and constant stability, daily benefiting the ruler—this is the first great auspicious outcome. The recommended person is capable of fulfilling their duties and becoming a vessel of talent—this is the second auspicious outcome. Becoming a vessel of talent, they can illuminate the Way of their teacher, extending grace to their teacher—this is the third auspicious outcome. The recommended person’s trustworthy service proves effective, further earning the ruler’s trust and employment—this is the fourth auspicious outcome. Together, with united strength and shared purpose, their endeavors daily succeed, monthly grow more illustrious, and yearly flourish more prosperously. The heavens and earth rejoice, good responses emerge in full, and evil things withdraw in concealment. When the heavens and earth rejoice, the host of spirits is pleased. If this is maintained without fail, above, one may transcend the world; in the middle, one may bring order and governance; below, one may preserve wholeness and complete one’s natural lifespan. When recommending a scholar and obtaining the right person, the good is thus. In heaven, this is called the *Talisman of Continuing Life*.

May I ask why it is properly named the *Talisman of Continuing Life*?

So it is. The reason it is called the *Talisman of Continuing Life* is that when the right person is recommended, danger is transformed into safety, chaos into order, failure into success, misfortune into fortune, and death into life. Above, one may transcend the world; in the middle, one may achieve governance and peace; below, one may complete one’s natural lifespan and preserve one’s body and form.

Now, when recommending a scholar and failing to obtain the right person, it brings no benefit to the emperor or the state, causing governance to descend into chaos. The emperor is distressed and afflicted, the heavens and earth are displeased, and thieves, bandits, disasters, and myriad calamities arise—this is the first great inauspicious outcome. The recommended person is incapable of governing their office, daily engaging in flattery and deceit. Over time, they await misfortune and cannot preserve their natural lifespan. Either the heavens and earth and spirits harm them, or they are murdered by others, bringing disgrace to their parents. Evil flows to their wives, children, and descendants, and even to their servants and followers, who come to know their faults and regard them as wicked people. 〈Rise〉 This is the second great inauspicious outcome. If the person is wicked, their learning is abandoned, defiling and disgracing the sacred work of former teachers and sages, bringing disaster upon their teacher—this is the third great inauspicious outcome. Furthermore, the recommender is untrustworthy, jointly deceiving their superior. Recommending the wrong person disrupts the celestial order, defiles the constellations, and incurs the wrath of heaven, the resentment of earth, the emperor’s displeasure, and the condemnation of sages and worthies. Such a one is called a great flatterer and liar of the age. For this offense, if they are not punished by the heavens, earth, and spirits, then people will harm them, disgracing their ancestors and bringing disaster to their wives, children, and descendants—this is the fourth great inauspicious outcome. Committing these four great inauspicious outcomes by recommending the wrong person causes the emperor distress and suffering, and governance to be called chaotic. Once harmful qi stirs and arises, it cannot be stopped. Disorder persists, with mutual blame and liability. The heavens and earth are enraged, the host of spirits wages war, the six directions are displeased, and the eight distant realms fall into discord. Eternally ungoverned, in heaven this is called the *Talisman of Diminishing Years and Shortening Life*.

Why is it named the *Talisman of Shortening Life*?

So it is. Governance should be long-lasting, but instead it is cut short; years should be many, but instead they are few. Undertakings meet with misfortune, bringing no benefit to the self. The heavens and earth are displeased, deducting from one’s allotted years. Thus, in heaven it is named the *Talisman of Shortening Life*.

Excellent! Excellent! This foolish student has heard your instruction.

"Ah, you may be said to have [understanding] of this. Carefully preserve this celestial text to show to virtuous rulers, to all worthy ones, and extend it to the common folk below. For those above who seek scholars, they must not be careless; for those below who present scholars, they must not be unfaithful. Let later generations transmit and recite this text, binding it within their hearts. If they hastily recommend scholars who do not meet this standard, the heavens and earth will no longer be pleased. To know this and yet deliberately violate it—how grave their transgression! Perfected One, be cautious."

"Indeed, indeed. I sincerely receive your instruction and dare not transgress the prohibitions, striving to practice it with all my effort."

"You may be said to be prudent in affairs, having received the Mandate of Heaven."

---
*Right: The Celestial and Terrestrial Handwritten Decrees on Recommending Scholars—Four Auspicious Signs, Four Inauspicious Signs, the Talisman of Shortening Life, the Talisman of Extending Life, the Pacification of the State, Gaining the Favor of Heaven and Earth, and the Joy of the Host of Spirits*
*Concordance of the* Great Peace Scripture*, Volume 110, Geng Section 8*
*Great Peace Scripture, Volume 110*
*The Book of Great Merit and Extended Years: Admonitions on Time, First of One Hundred Seventy-Nine*

---

Only the Dao of highest antiquity cultivates the self and rectifies the person, daring not to transgress what the divine spirits record. Only then does one dare to seek life and beg for survival from the Heavenly Lord, not daring to act wantonly, fearing imperfection. Daily, one contemplates the vitality of life, serving the spirits as a subject, manifesting one’s kind. One desires to exhaust loyal and upright words, clearly distinguishing right and wrong with the spirits who govern each domain, only then daring to trust in the governance of right and wrong—how could there be a moment’s forgetfulness?

Above, there are those who observe humanity, fully knowing right and wrong. What can be concealed? What can be disbelieved? Thus, one attains self-governance, seeking to contemplate the root, never entering even the slightest realm of ungoodness. One simply cherishes having become human, relying on the primordial qi, enabling even the creeping and moving creatures to avoid witnessing calamities and anomalies. Yet humans betray trust in their sworn words, neither side believing the other, hence the lack of peace.

Within the harmony of heaven and earth, above and below, each has its own trust. Humans do not grasp its essentials, yet ask why there is good and evil alone. From whence do all calamities and anomalies arise? Humans consume the qi of the Five Constants, receiving without exception, depending without exception, acting without exception—why alone do they not honor and know the ancients who knew how to extend kindness to others? This is to lose goodness and follow evil, causing life to be incomplete—how could this be right?

Thus, the Heavenly Lord says there is good and evil, and goodness can be made uniform. The reason is that there must be distinction; one cannot follow one’s own will. Goodness should ascend, while evil should be punished—how can it be equated with goodness? From human perspective, this too is understandable, for there are those who ought to be upright. Thus, evil is established to clarify the intentions of heaven and earth, the four seasons, and the five phases, making known that completing life and giving birth are weighty matters, increasing one’s years of life.

Having attained the Dao of life and completion, one upholds its prohibitions, daring not to violate taboos. From this, it is clear that heaven knows the foolish are shallow and lack the intention of requital, opposing heaven’s actions, contradicting heaven’s deeds, and adding to human misconduct—reversing the proper order to reward evil and punish good.

Thus, the sage knows the convergence of yin and yang; the worthy govern right and wrong, resolving what is unknown, enabling each to know their allotted portion without resentment. Goodness naturally lengthens life; evil naturally shortens it—what is there to doubt or resent?

---
Are humans inferior to the six domestic animals, birds, beasts, and creatures of the water? Is it that humans are without form? Heaven causes it to be so. Heaven desires only that humans do good, not that they do evil. If good and evil shared the same suffering and joy, then wealth, honor, longevity, and old age—all granted by heaven above—would fail to distinguish beauty from ugliness, allowing ignorant people to boast, saying, “I am equal to you all.” What need is there for good conduct? Thus, advancing and increasing goodness prolongs life, while those of shallow understanding consider them equal.

Those who compare to evil and forfeit life, wishing to correct and repent their transgressions, seeing goodness and following it, seeing evil and retreating—day and night, they examine and reflect upon themselves, repaying what they owe. Even if they do not attain immortality, they may complete their allotted years without premature death—this is acceptable. The longing of common people is but a fleeting moment. Not contemplating long life, they may yet rise to become knowing scholars, their hearts set on seeking life, hence refraining from evil.

Heaven sees their goodness and allows them to act securely, further seeking wealth and descendants. Though they may not fully attain it, they still have hope—why persist in evil, hastening destruction, believing they can complete their years? They do not know that heaven dispatches spirits to record their deeds. No transgression, great or small, escapes heaven’s knowledge. The registers of good and evil are examined and tallied by year, month, and day, deducting from one’s allotted years. If evil does not cease, one is brought before the Ghost Gate. The earth spirits summon and interrogate them, comparing their words and deeds. After painful reflection and governance, they finally submit. Their names are sent up to the celestial bureaus for review; when their tally is exhausted, they are to enter the earth. Their transgressions flow into later lives—is this not the result of evil?

---
Why do humans not desire life? Having no mirror to see themselves, whom can they blame? Among children born in the same ten months, why alone do some fail to do good, persisting in evil—how can they endure long? The schemes of foolish scholars—why do they not align with even minor goodness? Engaging in trivial and non-urgent matters, each person’s actions differ in calculation, each believing their own way is right. What they touch and transgress all aim to benefit themselves, yet others do not wish to benefit them. The benefit of goodness brings fleeting life; the benefit of evil does not last, for goodness does not long remain upon the earth.

Thus, does heaven and earth not know this? Heaven causes humans to do good, hence it gives them life, yet they do evil. Thus, it sends the spirits who govern evil to follow them relentlessly. If they do not cease, other spirits ascend and immediately generate their affairs, causing them to follow the person without respite.

Do you not know? This scripture advances goodness and retreats evil—such is the literature of past and present. Yet one ceases not from pursuing long life and instead embraces evil, leaving no recourse; how can the spirits not report this? Thus, those who transgress vanish into the earth, their spirits unsettled, with no place to rest—whose fault is this? Let each person reflect deeply upon their conduct, seeking ease and peace without wrongdoing. Their words and phrases repeat and overlap, for what they speak of is not a single matter, hence the repetition.

Human life lies near within your own body—why then beat your breast and cry out to heaven? If you do not purify yourself, whom should you purify? If you do not cherish yourself, whom should you cherish? If you do not fulfill yourself, whom should you fulfill? If you do not reflect upon yourself, whom should you reflect upon? If you do not reproach yourself, whom should you reproach? Ponder these words, and you will bear no grudge against spirits. When they see goodness, they report goodness; when they see evil, they report evil—all is not the same.

Do you not understand? Though words may cease, if evil persists unchecked, the written records do not end; only when a person perishes do they stop. This warning makes clear that in doing evil, one burdens only oneself, not others—do you not understand? Act in accord with what is said, and let it remain in your heart; to depart from it is ruin, beyond repair. To stand among ghosts—how can one live? To think of life is to attain life—this is understanding. Evil must eventually end and cannot long endure—do you not know this?

Yet again, in trivial matters, people dwell between heaven and earth, each granted the chance to be human—how can they forget the grace of heaven and earth? What manner of folly is this? So foolish, yet unable to change—what more can one hope for? If you seek heaven’s reward, you must reproach yourself, act with sincerity, and weep tears of remorse. Say: "I have received grace to be human, set apart from all things, endowed by heaven with distinction—able to speak, to discern beauty and ugliness, to know good and evil. How can I not attend to these matters? I must reflect carefully." Yet if your words defy heaven, refusing to submit, you become one of great rebellion and un-Dao—how can heaven long engage with you?

Thus, the placement of baleful spirits follows the ancient observation: as the words say, such a person does not incline toward goodness. The Heavenly Lord declares: "Already the records are unceasing. The overseer of the department shall descend to gather their soul, their bones and flesh entrusted to the earth’s keeper. There is no need for delay—evil persons cannot be heard from repeatedly." Thus, one must restrain their wrath and return to refinement, reforming their evil, gathering all virtues, and embedding them within, placing the heart within the heart.

The spirits say: "We receive the heart’s mandate from heaven, charged to follow the human heart without the slightest lapse. Good and evil are instantly witnessed by attendant spirits, who also perceive the heart." The spirits speak with deep sorrow: "I know not whether fortune or misfortune lies ahead, and thus I fear being among the ranks of the wicked. Day and night, I reflect, uncertain where to place myself, and so dare not entertain even the slightest unwholesome thought. I rely solely on the forbearance of the spirits, allowing me to reproach myself. If I disregard their admonitions and am punished, I shall have no regret."

The Heavenly Lord sends a great spirit to declare: "This person has reproached themselves and repented of their transgressions, violating no prohibitions—grant them forbearance, grant them forbearance. If they later commit wrong, it will not be too late to seize them." Upon hearing the spirits’ words, they sigh day and night, fearing their past transgressions are not yet fully eradicated, that they have long been cut off from the qi of the great yang, and remain among the ranks of the dead, growing ever more distressed, not knowing what to do.

Having received the mandate but unable to fully comprehend it, they seclude themselves in quietude to examine their faults, reproaching themselves for the burdens they bear, and offering thanks to heaven and earth, the four seasons, the five phases, and all the spirits under their charge. The Heavenly Lord listens, commanding them to reflect deeply. The people of high antiquity all possessed wisdom and foresight, dared not violate prohibitions, cultivated and corrected themselves, feared even the slightest lapse, and acted without fail to comply with the mandate, lest they forfeit their years. For this reason, they dared not relax even slightly. With every transgression came punishment at the head, and thus they examined and cherished themselves, revered prohibitions, and dared not harbor even the slightest defiant thought. When reproached and questioned, their hearts trembled with fear, their qi dismayed, for they had betrayed heaven’s heart. Even a minor discrepancy in their words was deemed excessive, and they were immediately investigated and verified. What they said and believed could earn them renown, but if they lacked integrity, they would long forfeit their years.

Thus, they reflected again, never losing their true heart, ever fearful and anxious, daring not rest. They acted with restraint, always longing and yearning, desiring to align with heaven and earth, the four seasons, and the five phases, bearing their mandate without the slightest error. Their hearts grew indignant—how could they not deeply understand the profound intent before and behind, never deviating from constancy, cherishing grace without betraying sincerity? Longing for life and hoping to live, how could they allow even the slightest evil to reach above?

They bound their bodies and conducted themselves in accord with duty—how could they dare relax, fearing they might fail to attain the highest intent, not knowing what to do? Their hearts grew ever more anxious, finding no peace in self-comfort. The gift of heaven’s lifespan is hard to obtain; once lost, it cannot be regained. Long estranged from the common world, only to be cut down midway—looking back below, they are left dismayed, thus chastising themselves in trembling fear. They constantly fear that even a minor discrepancy may lead to their dismissal, sorrow and oppression weighing upon their hearts as they reproach themselves for their faults.

Having received heaven’s grace to fulfill their allotted mandate, they dare not forget the pangs of hunger and thirst, content merely to live. The great spirits, moved by compassion, record and instruct the people, who receive their qi from heaven’s kitchen and ride upon the qi of heaven. Yet their conduct is meager in what they govern, and the prohibitions are many—none may be lost or forsaken. Though their bodies may be lowly and unworthy of honor, they are not despised for their unworthiness.

Truly, with heart they seek advancement and strive for life, hoping the great spirits will review their words, allowing them to witness the generation and transformation of the four seasons and five phases, and to see the sun and moon—whose grace is hard to repay—lest they be cast aside midway.

The attendants of the True Abode dare not distance themselves, yet they pause, overturning their pillows and mats.

The great spirits declare: "This person has been thus transformed by their teacher—why fear they shall not receive protection?"

"In times past, there was such a one whom heaven favored with compassion, keeping them close at hand. Now, having long served in office and seen much, their thoughts and words find no want of the Celestial Lord’s trust. Moreover, in their deeds, they prostrate themselves weeping upon the earth, speaking forth only after being roused by decree. They recall the loyal sincerity of the ancients, advancing all they know without reservation, humbly receiving every word. How dare they compare themselves to those who came before?"

The great spirits say: "To speak with one so steadfast is to wish them to grow in conduct and emulate the ancients. Yet some fall short in their time."

The disciple replies: "The great spirits have illuminated the great principles with utmost clarity. Among the many, I alone am singled out, granted the gift of awakened thought—this grace is boundless. When shall I ever repay the great spirits’ instruction?"

The great spirits say: "Thought arises from within; its recompense lies in earnest devotion."

The disciple says: "I know not what to offer in service. Though heaven may possess rare and wondrous treasures, I still wish to present them. When roused by decree to fervent contemplation, I receive it with utmost sincerity. These words are not mere empty phrases of repayment, but a vow of unceasing day and night reflection, never daring to slacken."

The great spirits say: "The admonitions are many, and the remonstrances are not for one alone. To speak thus at length is to honor your sincerity, for your words are met with profound compassion."

The Celestial Lord, hearing this, summons the great spirits and asks: "From whence did this disciple arise, that they have drawn such exceptional words from the great spirits?"

The great spirits reply: "This learner is especially trustworthy, and thus the Way’s difficulty and ease are made clear."

The Celestial Lord says: "Let those who show goodness advance thus—this is as it should be."

The great spirits say: "The Celestial Lord summons this steadfast disciple."

The disciple says: "I dare not hope to stand at heaven’s left side. I only wish to remain in a humble station, exerting myself in loyal devotion."

The great spirits say: "All must have a domain to govern before their trustworthiness is proven."

"If I am thus truly fortunate, having received such great favor, I dare not fall short in even the smallest measure."

The great spirits say: "This disciple’s transformation is as it should be. They ought to advance further, matching the ancients."

The disciple says: "I dare not seek long life—such is the greed of others."

The great spirits say: "This is heaven’s wish."

The disciple says: "It is only by the great spirits’ protection that I dare not transgress their warnings."

The Celestial Lord, knowing of these two admonishing one another, approves deeply and bids them teach each other.

Of the Dao of the sages of highest antiquity, it arose naturally. Their minds knew the governance of heaven above, and all they enacted was foreknown. Their voices penetrated all, returning to perceive form and countenance. Gazing inward, their hearts were luminous, their intentions clear. They knew what must be saved, the convergence of fortune and misfortune—all was plainly discerned. Within, their hearts rejoiced, knowing they had received heaven’s blessing. They saw the deeds of those who came before, all cautioned with utmost sincerity. Reflecting on the grace of their favor and encounter, having long stood with the six spirits, they were ever instructed and warned, kept from peril. Gazing to the four directions, above and below all was open and unobstructed, their compassion deepening. Their hearts filled with joy, their lives extended, and what they had not heard was now revealed—all by the power of the Celestial Lord and the great spirits’ transformation.

The great spirits say: "All the spirits know this: those whose lives are prolonged have their fate recorded in truth. Before their birth, their years, months, days, and hours were inscribed in the Bureau of Longevity. As their years increase, their names are bestowed and made known, governed by the Perfected of the Northern Culmen. Their bones are transformed, their bodies become light and lustrous, radiating brilliance. At dusk, they receive the elixir, refining their essence. Wherever they manifest, all comes to fruition. They move from the subtle to the hidden, within the space of a single hair—what is there they cannot penetrate?"

The *〈Cease〉* section—The Sage says: "Truly, there is this following of custom: food comes from the earth, and the yin spirits emerge—how could one not be weighty? What is called ‘ease’ in transformation is, in fact, the highest ease. The great spirits’ grace cannot be repaid; their great deeds bestowed, their boundless kindness—how could one bear to fall short? They allow one to rest and breathe in profound depth, a debt no words can repay."

The great spirits say: "This is the mandate of Heaven, matching human fate and allotted years—it is not by the will of the great spirits’ doing. When goodness is recommended, it is the blessing of the spirits—what repayment or gratitude could there be? Yet, fearing future doubts, we impose prohibitions and firm rules, so that the Sage may teach and warn, and later generations may see and understand. The Sage already possesses wisdom—no admonition is needed."

The Sage says: "Though I have received such recompense and my name is recorded in the registers of life, there may still be teachings I fail to grasp."

The great spirits say: "Such humble words from one alive are fitting indeed."

The disciple, deeply moved, speaks again, his earlier and later words now complete: "Only by the great spirits’ gracious fulfillment do I see my place among others—yet I dare not relax, nor grow arrogant or indolent. I ask to exert myself further in quiet solitude, following the great spirits’ teachings, ever mindful of this unworthy life."

The great spirits say: "All your words, before and after, are clear—no further warnings are needed. Let each part accordingly as spoken."

The disciple says: "From the day I received these precepts, I dare not slacken even for a moment, though I fear I may not fully accomplish them. Only by your support do I live and breathe again, my hopes revived. My heart remains ever inclined toward you—may the great spirits, from time to time, grant further instruction. This grace is no small thing."

The great spirits say: "Such words from you are fitting indeed."

The disciple says: "Indeed, indeed. I dare not rely on myself alone for protection."

The great spirits say: "Those who attain a name must advance with diligence—benefits accrue, and the overseers of the departments are many."

The Celestial Lord, hearing this exchange of warnings and words between the great spirits and the Sage—knowing them to be men of understanding—commands: "Do not grow careless or lax. Your lives may reach boundless longevity. Return each to your respective departments, and when you see goodness, advance it to the great spirits."

The Sage says: "We all receive the Celestial Lord’s teaching and will exert ourselves to the utmost, never growing weary in our efforts."

The Celestial Lord says: "Those who perfect themselves do so by their own perfection."

"Indeed, indeed."

〈Rising〉

In the highest antiquity, those who attained the Dao had no statutes or records to follow. Their records were inscribed in the scriptures of long life, and when the appointed year, month, and day of their ascension arrived, these were transmitted to the Central Ultimate. The Central Ultimate is also called Kunlun. The overseers of each department would then record their names without omission. Envoys were repeatedly dispatched to test their limbs—bending, extending, turning, and swaying—repeating instructions and admonitions, commanding the spirits to flex and bow. Medicinal drafts were administered to open and refine their bones and joints. Though they might not meet face-to-face, the envoys could discern whether their resolve was firm or faltering, ensuring their will did not waver.

Craving life and dreading death, they aspired to join the gods of heaven. Envoys were sent to verify their years, and only then were they permitted to receive the scriptures of insufficiency. Their spoken words and intentions were made known, teaching them the prohibitions and precautions to observe. These were transmitted to disciples, who, without relying on divine texts, carried their own books to completion. The gods, recognizing their speech, would engage with them over years, accumulating one thousand three hundred and twenty days before leading them to meet the great spirits, to circulate primordial qi and walk the path of spontaneity.

The Celestial Lord reviewed the secret decrees in the registers, ensuring no private trust or partiality influenced their conduct, lest their hearts be swayed or their actions err. The great spirits said: "We have calculated the provisions lent by the various gods. On the last day of the eighth month, the registers of all mountains, seas, mounds, marshes, connecting rivers, bridges, the Huai, Ji, Yangtze, lakes, and waterways—recording their influx and efflux—are to be clearly divided. The Celestial Lord’s rewards and recorded decrees are to be reviewed repeatedly before the Celestial Lord, and the registers stored in the Golden Chamber. Those of sincere heart, appointed to attend the Celestial Lord’s inquiries, must heed his teachings day and night without respite. The overseers of the chambers must not lose what their departments seek. Separate orders shall identify those of sincere heart who are to be definitively recorded in the registers.

Envoys and gods shall be assigned to tally the names of those to ascend or descend. One hundred days prior, all documents must be submitted without omission or loss. If any document is inconsistent or the accounting office fails to act, all involved shall be held accountable. A prior decree forbids transgressing the divine scriptures. After this scripture is issued, it shall be shown to the common people only after three years and eight months. Those who believe in the Dao may be shown it in full."

The Celestial Lord instructed: "These people bear prior burdens. Command the gods to resolve and conceal them. Those not yet concealed shall be concealed." The great spirits said: "These people have long suffered poverty and emptiness, fearing they cannot preserve themselves. By the Celestial Lord’s favor, the gods are commanded to conceal them. If their overseers fail to do so, their words may prove unreliable. They have previously petitioned for decrees to express gratitude and receive grace. Though the appointed time has not yet come, let them be informed one month in advance."

The Celestial Lord said: "Instruct the gods, generals, and soldiers under your command in the fields and lands not to miss the season for concealment. Record their names so the earthly overseers may treat them with reverence, allowing divine spirits to come and go. Those who seek to fulfill their wishes shall be heard." 〈End〉 "Have faith in this, and thereafter be vigilant."

The great spirits said: "Thus, word will spread throughout the realm. Those who love the Dao will support and uphold one another, honoring and serving it." The Celestial Lord said: "Those who have merit shall naturally be honored." The great spirits said: "This person’s years are not yet complete, and the appointed time has not arrived. I request that when the time comes, they be taught how to offer thanks. For now, their dwelling is empty, and they have nothing to clothe themselves. Let those who possess the Dao provide them sustenance until the appointed time."

The Celestial Lord said: "This is a small matter. Let the Celestial Offices provide for their households—those with households and sincere hearts." The great spirits said: "Let it be as you have instructed." "Command the Celestial Offices to provide what is due. This person has long been empty; let them be given food to suffice." The great spirits said: "Let the Celestial Offices record their names and ensure they do not suffer want." The Celestial Lord said: "Very well."

In ancient times, all people received the celestial retribution they deserved, and those whose faith could be fulfilled were granted life by decree, protected and watched over by the spirits, who feared any harm or deficiency might befall them. Day and night, they divined their fate. When they saw goodness, they aided their joy; they did not wish to hear of their wrongdoings. They were placed in the registers of longevity, their hearts guided toward goodness, ensuring no time for evil. They were encouraged to advance in virtue, to harbor filial piety, loyalty, and obedience. In all they received and practiced, they dared not act on their own will but followed the teachings they were given. Others might call them ignorant, yet I, too, saw and knew them.

When a person possessed great kindness and mercy, they grieved and reflected, striving to be good. Yet if one remained long in doubt, especially loathing the prospect of an early demise, they would restrain and discipline themselves, fearing to offend the wicked. Day and night, they trembled in dread, uncertain of their fate. Heaven endows people with the knowledge of good and evil; those who act with goodness and faith do not wish others to hear of their wrongdoings. Thus, desiring to cling to life and avoid death, they dared not transgress prohibitions, as if such violations would harm their very bodies.

Therefore, by the affinity of celestial qi, they could converse and interact with those of understanding, discerning the sentiments of others. When they saw unworthiness, they withdrew and reproached themselves, fearing their names might be sullied in the records. Whatever intentions they harbored at the time, if they acted upon others, they dared not face the full account of their deeds but reproached themselves for what they had done. Yet if their actions displeased others, their faults multiplied and were difficult to erase.

Thus, when people came to regret their missteps, their circumstances changed in the moment, and they believed their fate could be regained. Unaware that Heaven had sent great spirits to divine their misdeeds as particularly grave, they had already entered the earth, and so they consoled themselves, enduring in silence, not daring to confront their wrongs. Though their words bore slight discrepancies, having received Heaven’s grace, they were granted a brief respite to revive and rest, holding onto the hope of prolonged life—this was Heaven’s dispensation. Yet even so, they felt their allotted time was short, and thus grew ever more despondent, their hearts filled with shame.

They longed to see the celestial spirits, to plead for mercy and instruction, to illuminate what they did not know, to guard against the future, and to align with Heaven’s will, that they might achieve even a small measure of their desires. Those who were calculating and covetous pondered good and evil, hoping to receive unseen decrees. Then, they beheld the great spirits, bitterly recounting the hardships of their lives, seeking the favor of worldly men and striving for advancement. Thus, they cultivated and corrected themselves.
