Only the great spirits admonished their insufficiencies, awakening them to the hope of warning and the leftward turn of fate. The great spirits alone pitied and examined those who sought life. The great spirits said: "Why惜 the prohibitions? Reflect deeply and know them yourself. Let your words freely express your true feelings, but fear they may not match your speech. Consider carefully, for thoughts arise from the heart; you must ponder them thoroughly."

The petitioner said: "I am overwhelmed with gratitude and fear, for these matters concern my very self. How dare I not speak from the heart?" The great spirits said: "Since this is your resolve, return now to a quiet place and reflect. Only when you find insufficiency should you seek further." The petitioner said: "I am slow and unlearned, not yet fully versed in the prominent precepts. I prostrate myself, awaiting your instruction, before daring to advance." The great spirits said: "If you wish to exhaust your sincerity, merit can be attained. Strive to reflect on your life from its beginning, on the progress of your deeds, and on resolving the burdens inherited from your ancestors. When these burdens are removed and your transgressions exhausted, you shall ascend—what doubt remains? Be cautious in your speech and do not let your thoughts wander."

The petitioner said: "Having received your decree and admonitions, I dare not withhold any effort in advancing goodness. If I turn from good to evil, I toy with my own fate." The great spirits said: "A good person should humble themselves further. Though the days of their life may be laborious and the present moment slightly bitter, if they do not waver in their resolve, they shall later receive blessings."

The petitioner, having received the decree, sincerely retired to a quiet place to reflect on their faults and reproach themselves. The great spirits said: "Thoughts that arise from within are known to the celestial spirits. Do not grow weary." The petitioner said: "I shall do so until the end of my years." The great spirits said: "With such conduct, why fear you will not advance?"

The Celestial Lord, having heard this, further instructed the great spirits to observe the conduct of those who wished to progress, to accumulate the days and months of their deeds, and to assign each to their proper register. Those with merit would ascend, and their names would fill the vacancies. The people of ancient times, in their hearts, words, and speech, understood human nature and governed without deception. Their inner and outer selves were in harmony, and their sincerity was fully evident; none betrayed another. Heaven’s essential decrees were such that transgressors were deemed most shameful, immediately questioned, and held accountable for their faults.

For this reason, they trembled all the more, their hearts moved by the profound grace Heaven had bestowed, allowing them to remain whole as human beings and to know the meaning of good and evil. People, reflecting on this deep and generous favor, knew not how to repay it. They could only resolve to advance, their loyalty and sincerity unwavering. In all they did, they followed the commands and dared not err even slightly, fearing that the multitude of spirits would report them, that their faults would be seen above, and that their allotted years would not be fulfilled.

Thus, they grew ever more sorrowful and anxious, not daring to relax, yet hoping to repay the grace they had received. Truly, they coveted life and wished to serve the celestial spirits in accordance with Heaven’s will. Those with small transgressions would have them erased, completing their allotted years. If they had great merit, their lives would be extended, and their years increased. Serving the primordial qi, aligning with the essence and brilliance of what they knew, they would receive great favor—beyond words to repay—leaving only their hearts uncertain of how to proceed.

Only the great spirits, in their compassion and records, could provide instruction, allowing them to perceive and consider, to know Heaven’s decrees and the multitude of prohibitions above. They were to follow these without fail. The great spirits, mindful of their insufficiencies, admonished them and dared not forget the greater dispensation, nor the grace of life they had received. The great spirits said: "You are one who knows yourself. What need is there for further instruction? Simply follow Heaven’s will and do not oppose its intent."

Upon receiving these admonitions, they should promptly comply and not neglect them—this is how one aligns with the will of Heaven. Rewards and punishments vary in weight; each must be met with due sincerity, without error or misstep. Even the slightest caution I offer should be carefully heeded. In speech, one must deliberate thoroughly to ensure its feasibility. Should minor transgressions arise, one must reflect inwardly and turn toward goodness—this is the essence of minor admonition. For all else, one must take lifelong words as profound warnings, never deviating from the intent of the spirits.

"You, still in youthful ignorance, have yet to grasp the greater dispensation. Thus, the great spirits repeatedly admonish you. Their illumination is vast, their knowledge and foresight boundless, encompassing all things. The great spirits emphasize these warnings so that you may embody their virtue and not oppose their words. You must reflect deeply and await further instruction."

The great spirits said: "These words allow one to understand the dispensations of Heaven above, the workings of the earth below, and the conduct of all beings in between—all in accord with the law, without deviation. Those who have teachers should follow their masters and not oppose them."

The disciple replied: "I am resolved to heed these warnings. Though the laws are the same, my understanding of their intent remains shallow. The will of Heaven is difficult to fathom in its entirety."

The great spirits said: "All that is required is unwavering sincerity, free from deceit. Those who can anticipate the intentions of the Heavenly Lord in advance are the foremost of people, worthy to stand at the Heavenly Lord’s left side. When rewarded for their merits, they remain humble and dare not accept all that is given, instead redoubling their efforts, exerting themselves to the utmost, and cultivating a mind of utmost subtlety. Thus, the Heavenly Lord personally instructs them face-to-face—this is the disciple’s great fortune. With many under their care, they govern with impartiality—this is sufficient in itself."

The disciple said: "I dare not aspire to stand at the Heavenly Lord’s left side; merely to live is enough. I think only of loyalty and filial piety, following principle and fulfilling my duties. I dare not accept great rewards, for I fear I have no merit to justify them. Yet when even small deeds bear fruit, my person grows brighter with each passing day, and I am granted long life. My thoughts are boundless, and I dare not allow even a moment’s lapse in reflection. To receive gentle words fills my heart and mind to abundance. The great spirits dwell with me, guiding my conduct without ceasing. Though I have received such grace—moving between Heaven and earth, occasionally admonished—this is the great spirits’ benevolence, which I can never fully repay. My heart remains ever devoted, never wavering in its longing. When the Heavenly Lord hears of this, He knows the conduct of His followers, and none fail to have their wishes fulfilled. I constantly examine my faults and shortcomings, striving to avoid even the slightest wrong. The great spirits instruct and admonish me, urging me ever upward without weariness.

"The most virtuous of people arise naturally, each with a long record inscribed in the register of goodness, known as the *Record of the Virtuous*. Their conduct is always good, never marred by ill repute. In all their comings and goings, only kind intentions are heard, never evil—hence they are called *the virtuous*. Their every action advances them among others, and the multitude marvels at what they cannot see, elevating them to honor. The honored observe them, some admiring their words, others their virtuous conduct, their sincerity, their beloved nature, their filial loyalty, the constancy of their speech, or their trustworthiness—such is the goodness of the good. Thus, they are named *virtuous*. At times, they are favored with glory, yet they still desire to wander long, to attain immortality among the spirits, to reach the station of deathlessness, to command the host of spirits—these are the desires of the virtuous.

"They look upward to goodness, aligning with the trust of Heaven and Earth, the four seasons, and the five phases. The spirits cherish them, those with knowledge instruct one another, rare texts and extraordinary strategies are shared, and vacancies are filled through mutual recommendation and assurance. Even slight dissent is corrected, and precious gifts are exchanged. Together, they ascend to the heavenly spirits, seeking reverence, admonition, and reflection on their faults, fearing they may not measure up to the great spirits of Heaven. Day and night, they advance their resolve, embracing goodness from the heart, yearning to hear virtuous words. Their loyalty and integrity are whole, and they cherish their lives and years, ever fearful of even a moment’s lapse into slight unkindness. When they hear of others’ faults, they aid in their repentance. They guide those with knowledge, admonishing with goodness, heeding others’ words, and witnessing their glory. They teach others the way to seek life and vitality—this is the pinnacle of the virtuous. They strive to merit reward, never daring to defy the wishes of the spirits, longing to remain ever in their presence and fulfill the aspirations of all they encounter.

"Only the great spirits of Heaven, masterful in speech, oversee and instruct conduct, enforcing prohibitions. Even minor faults are met with forbearance, allowing one to reflect on their intent. The grace of Heaven is vast, its compassion boundless, granting one the chance to reflect, repent, and extend their life—this is the dispensation of the greater dispensation. Yet I fear I may not fully realize this grace in the end. I pray the great spirits will pardon my shortcomings. I wish to receive unseen admonitions, to find joy in reflection, to broaden my aspirations, and to receive further instruction."

The great spirits said: "Heaven and Earth each have their own patterns. One knows how to advance but not how to retreat—this is simply their nature. They do not withhold admonition out of stinginess. When one sees the multitude of virtuous people, what further warnings are needed? Simply ponder their words carefully to ensure they align—this is the wish of the virtuous, and it should be made clear."

The disciple said: "I am unworthy, my conduct impure. Thus, I have personally sought the prohibitions of the great spirits. Repeatedly, I have received their profound favor, their constant remembrance, and their manifest guidance, returning again and again without satiety—Heaven has willed it so."

The great spirits said: "You have received a natural disposition, and Heaven has sent you to inquire. It knows your alignment—what cause for suspicion is there? Those who secretly wish to receive instruction speak only from their true feelings, without artifice or embellishment. Few can truly correct themselves from the heart, so vacancies are filled through mutual supplementation—this is your shortcoming. You must remain vigilant and not grow lax."

The disciple said: "My nature is dull and slow, my intentions not ahead of time. I rely only on written precepts for self-restraint—would that I were not so pitied."

The great spirits said: "This too arises from understanding. When one knows goodness, one practices goodness; when one knows trustworthiness, one practices trustworthiness; when one knows loyalty, one practices loyalty; when one knows obedience, one practices obedience; when one knows filial piety, one practices filial piety—how then could evil ever precede? You already possess this self-awareness, which is why we emphasize it further."

The disciple, sincerely dismayed, said: "What I have heard is most excellent. Within it lies a profound admonition. How could I dare harbor any thought of negligence when the great spirits instruct thus? This is the very meaning of preserving life. To receive such favor—how could I ever repay the great spirits' kindness?"

The great spirits said: "Observe these matters, and they are not merely for caution. If you reflect on what can be practiced, you may yet achieve renown and ascend without doubt. What is attained through one’s own conduct—how could there be any repayment or gratitude? Words alone are insufficient to convey it."

The disciple said: "This admonition grants me life and the hope of survival. I shall ponder your words in my ignorance."

The great spirits said: "You must ensure your words do not depart from your inner truth. This is how we have admonished all who come to learn."

The disciple said: "Who would willingly instruct me thus? My fate is my lot, and the great spirits take pleasure in it. Though your teachings are thorough, I have nothing to offer in return—truly, I am ashamed and at a loss."

The Heavenly Lord heard this and said: "This is goodness within goodness, the very essence of virtue. It may be applied across all departments without fail."

The great spirits then addressed the disciple: "The Heavenly Lord’s decree bestows such honor—you must not transgress it."
"Indeed, indeed."

Those of supreme virtue stand between Heaven and Earth, presiding over the work of transformation, ensuring all attain their desires. When the good inscribe the writings of goodness, they do not lose constancy or propriety—this is supreme virtue. Nothing is left unaccomplished, nothing unachieved. They do not lose their clarity, nor their substance; they do not lose the generative workings of yin and yang, nor the qi of the four seasons that govern life’s ingress and egress. They do not lose the completion of the Five Phases, nor the movements of the sun, moon, and stars; they do not lose their measurements, nor the timing of fortune and misfortune; they do not lose the signs of calamity and anomaly, nor the records of flood and drought. Human lifespans, long or short, do not lose their allotment according to the thickness or thinness of their stellar influences—these are the duties of those of supreme virtue.

Thus, those of virtue illuminate all, perceive all, harmonizing above, below, and the center, each according to its proper place. In accordance with their virtue, none lose their rightful names. This is the scripture of following the constant and attaining long life. None fail to receive glory. All things sprout and split their husks to grow, their branches and leaves unfurling like garments; mist, dew, frost, snow, and timely rain serve as their drink and food. They grow, mature, and bear fruit, covering the earth and sustaining its people. Called the "water mother" by Heaven, the "gourd" by the people, in the scorching heat of summer, they serve as water and drink—all under Heaven look up to them, and none, great or small, do not partake. Such is the virtuous person who inherits Heaven’s mandate, completes Heaven’s form, and on Earth provides sustenance for the people. Their acts of kindness and bestowal extend virtue to all, filling and satisfying themselves—this is not Heaven’s grace but their own.

Yet Heaven’s generative work is vast, and those who defy its mandate speak of "naturalness" in rebellion—this is perverse. Thus, those of virtue, understanding Heaven’s intent, teach the people to establish laws without losing Heaven’s will, nurturing and raising them to maturity, enabling them to become human. They further comprehend the patterns of culture, cultivating virtue to completion, and may ascend to join the celestial scholars. The affairs of Heaven above are graded by merit. Those of virtue preside over Earth’s matters, enabling the people to rely upon and witness their benevolence, though they cannot repay it in kind.

Those of virtue enact Heaven’s qi, above and below, at the center. When people fail to find their proper place, they belittle Heaven’s works, provoking Heaven’s unceasing wrath. The spirits do not love humanity, and lifespans are diminished—yet people blame Heaven, not themselves. How profound their folly! Thus, the lower spirits record these teachings, establishing prohibitions to firmly restrain the people from transgression.

Those who foresee the future shun evil and pursue goodness, avoiding what is forbidden, and again behold the transformations wrought by Heaven’s Dao—none fail to follow them. Thus, rulers are made their wings, guiding head and tail, completing their works like city walls, clear and discernible. They understand the great transformations, ordering the primordial qi, and comprehend human affairs. These are the people of fortune and fate, all foreknown. As they transform, their lifespans may be extended, and Heaven loves them. Good spirits follow and protect them, preventing harm. Their hearts perceive goodness, and the wicked cannot compare. Thus, Heaven values goodness, enabling them to fulfill their wishes without encroachment or conflict, as in equilibrium. Those who excel in goodness have their lifespans increased by Heaven, spared from peril and entanglement—this is great grace. How could repayment be doubted?

Those who previously performed great goodness, aligning their conduct with Heaven’s will, draw near to its left side, where no evil qi approaches. They dare not look upon it, and their lifespans extend without end—this grace is beyond repayment, not through rare treasures, but by inscribing sincerity in the heart, being true and trustworthy, and not betraying one’s words. This is repayment. Is this not repayment, is this not understanding?

To know goodness and practice goodness, to see trustworthiness and practice trustworthiness—these are a person’s strengths. You should reflect upon this and not doubt yourself. There were once trustworthy people whose lives knew no end, transforming into spirits, their virtues complete and merits abundant—do you understand this?

Thus, those of virtue who possess understanding may advance, and Heaven deeply loves them. Though their writings are not grand, they know fate and do not resent Heaven. Each conducts themselves with care, avoiding wrongdoing and perversity. Teaching others to do good, they again align with Heaven’s will, and their lifespans naturally lengthen."

All affairs issue from the Heavenly Lord—none may be detained or halted. The common folk are difficult to transform; transform them gradually, without sudden violence. Weigh carefully what you say, lest the spirits record it. Each must attend to their own duties, for documents and ledgers have their own fixed measures—do not transgress them. When you see goodness, advance it; when you see evil, correct it—let no doubt remain. Those who covet life do not forget what Heaven bestows.

Thus, those who honor this do so out of sincere care for human life. Reflect on goodness, and goodness will come—longevity will follow without doubt. Does the Heavenly Lord not love trustworthiness and understanding?

Examine the divine texts with care; do not test them on your own. Among all things under Heaven, filial piety, loyalty, sincerity, and trustworthiness are the greatest—thus, do not indulge in reckless abandon. To seize or diminish another’s allotted span will not endure long. Be cautious, be ever cautious, and do not grow lax, for laxity breeds self-doubt. Doubt renders one unworthy—do you understand? Do you understand?

*Right [Section]:* *Celestial Writ Resolving the Six Extremes, Great Compendium of Celestial Writs, Eighth Month Revision, Modeled on Heaven and Earth to Dispel Disasters*

*End of* **Tai Ping Jing Combined Collation, Scroll 111, Geng Section 9**
*Tai Ping Jing, Scroll 111*
*Great Sage’s Supreme Petition, Chapter 180*

〈Right [Section]:〉
Only those of supreme sagely virtue from the very beginning may receive the primordial qi and naturally resonate with its radiant essence, thereby becoming great sages. They fully comprehend what ought to be enacted, ever aligning with the celestial will without straying from the intent of the primordial qi. They constantly serve as grand divine ministers and assistants, akin to the dukes and ministers of a state. Their minds grasp the directives of the great spirits, and they communicate through celestial writs. Each petition they submit is duly recommended and elevated, ensuring the right individuals are chosen to safeguard matters of speech and action. They employ the Heavenly Lords in their affairs, and when the Hall of Light receives the writs, they are transmitted without delay, securing the favor of the celestial court.

The Heavenly Lord declares: "Those who do not disrupt the court’s decrees, nor entrust matters to unworthy intermediaries, shall see their documents submitted in perfect balance, free from grievances or disputes. Each receives their due portion of grace, with rewards and punishments meted out accordingly—how could there be contention over such distinctions?"

The great sages foresee the actions the Heavenly Lord ought to undertake—how could there be error? Common folk, unaware, assume them akin to mortal officials—how could they comprehend the edicts and writs that ought to descend? In the celestial realm, voices carry across vast distances—how could anything remain concealed? This is governed by the natural order of mutual verification—how could there be a moment of escape? The Heavenly Lord, day and night, foreknows all affairs, great and small, within the harmony of Heaven, Earth, and the Center. What autonomy do the spirits possess? Thus, the deeds of good and evil are recorded from beginning to end, and the spirits are tasked with transcribing them. The Heavenly Lord personally follows the monthly progress of the Dipper’s handle to govern, never deviating from the eternal intent, and all are rectified without敢 defiance. Hence, it is said: "Heaven dispatches."

The spirit within the human abdomen communes with Heaven from afar, their voices heard across the distance—how could they not know the good and evil of the people? The Heavenly Lord declares: "The virtuous and trustworthy are promoted; the wicked and untrustworthy are demoted." Not only does Heaven desire trustworthy individuals, but so too do the Center and Earth below. People, however, lack deep understanding of future matters, so those whose hearts and wills endure alongside the great spirits are deemed closest to Heaven. This is akin to a state’s loyal ministers and upright officials, who never stray from the ruler’s side. Yet people distrust Heaven—when would Heaven ever trust those of divided loyalty?

〈Right [Section]:〉
Are those who do not serve Heaven inferior even to common folk? How could insects and ants, driven by greed and attachment to life, ever align with the will of Heaven? Such individuals are not favored in their time. Transgressions arise among the people, and the thirteen [lunar phases] are gathered in the end, each with its allotted span. Those with heart and will, who disregard worldly affairs and seek advancement for the sake of life, are informed by the spirits of their innermost thoughts. Only those with heart and will may engage in dialogue and be trusted; the heartless, driven by the clamor for food, profit, warm clothing, and full meals, waste resources on empty rituals, oppress the poor and weak, and exalt themselves as superior—these are not the trusted confidants of Heaven. Their conduct lacks purity, yet they still seek the Dao and long for immortality. Such pursuit is futile, their crimes grave, and moments of pardon rare. Do you understand this?

Those who ascend to Heaven in broad daylight seek life with recorded destinies, their names inscribed in the celestial registers of the Northern Culmen Heavenly Lord, with copies of their allotments. How could those without heart and will ever have their names recorded? Those who study earnestly and earn the trust of Heaven’s heart may fulfill their celestial years. Those who exert themselves with exceptional effort and merit may have their names stricken from the register of death, gaining a brief reprieve in life. When will they ever ride the refined qi and perform Heaven’s work?

〈Right [Section]:〉
This is why one must comprehend the writs and be moved to remorse, weeping in self-reproach: "I, like the child of the tenth month, have acted, yet alone fail to meet the celestial intent, remaining among the ranks of the dead. What single act of mine has not aligned with the will above? This is my fault." Heaven, Earth, and the Center all ought to follow the grace of Heaven, yet many disbelieve—such is the gravity of their transgression. How can they harbor hope? When the celestial spirits hear of one who reproaches and repents, laboring without respite day or night for years, that person may be pardoned and reported to the Heavenly Lord. The Heavenly Lord declares: "Those who reproach themselves and repent their errors shall have their names transferred by the spirit of life’s register to the Bureau of Longevity. They shall be granted a lifespan of one hundred and twenty years, and those who were poor shall have descendants, while those of short-lived, solitary lineages—such as the wealthy and noble—shall be given heirs." Why is this? The wealthy and noble, with their strong households and abundant resources, defy Heaven and Earth, harm others, and bring ruin to the world. They hoard wealth, causing countless deaths and injuries. Thus, Heaven does not grant them descendants. If their wickedness persists, how could they be rewarded with goodness and longevity? Do you understand this?

The great spirits dispatch lesser spirits to transmit decrees, each receiving their mandate—matters of longevity or brevity proceed without doubt. Reflect again and again: the writs make clear both great and small matters. Should there be omissions or errors in later records, they must be duly noted.

*Virtue and Destiny, Chapter 181*

〈Right [Section]:〉
Only the Most High and those of virtue possess their own principles, deeply understanding affairs before they unfold. Their insight illuminates above and below, leaving nothing unopened. Their thoughts never stray from within, and they exhaust all knowledge to uphold the great transformation, rightly ordering the world. All they undertake and expound is fitting and timely. Their sincerity reaches the four directions, their intent ever in communication, rectifying the celestial net and placing the stellar lodges in their proper positions across the four quarters. Each is arrayed with its own patterns, their movements governed by constancy, their destinies bound above and below, each with its allotted span. On the day of one’s birth, the attendants in the celestial chambers record and inscribe the registers—nothing may be forgotten. Those born in the *zi* or *wu* hours shall have long lives. Those born in the *chou* or *wei* years shall not stray from the earthly domain. Those with meager destinies must avoid evil, lest they be consigned to the earthly domain.

When the allotted span is not yet exhausted, the celestial registers remain at one’s side, and though one may encounter the kingly and ministerial phases of the months, the qi of the monthly establishment will not endure. The reason lies in the earthly domain: thus, those born in the regions of *Kun* and *Gen* shall see their lifespans naturally diminished. If one’s birth occurs at the proper time, with the three earthly branches in alignment, yet the day of birth does not advance, its worth is as mere coin. From year to year, there are few favorable moments.

In the years of *chen* and *xu*, the Celestial Gate and Earthly Door stand opposite, and the celestial and terrestrial soils govern the births of their time. The celestial soil gives rise to the grasses and trees above, the terrestrial soil to those below; the celestial soil produces sages and the wise, while the terrestrial soil yields the worthy. Though there be balances, the ranks of the scales do not interfere with one another. People, unaware of this, instead claim that years in *chen* or *xu*, when the monthly establishment clashes, are profoundly inauspicious. Yet the Celestial Gate and Earthly Door face each other, yin and yang stand in alignment, and the day of birth accords with the direct governance of the year. When the day of *wu* again aligns with the year’s birth, this marks a person of great virtue, unobstructed in all things—rightly should one not be alarmed. The terrestrial soil produces the worthy to serve, and the earthly treasury becomes their dwelling. What evil could there be? People, not understanding, take earth as mere humanity, yet all belong to the earthly treasury. Lifespans have their terms: those aligned with sages attain sagacity, those aligned with the worthy attain worthiness—this is the constant law of Heaven, and one’s allotted fortune follows accordingly. Some may even emerge as immortals.

In the years of *yin* and *shen*, such persons resemble tigers. The sun and moon stand in direct alignment, yet they cannot be compared. The reason lies in *yin* being the domain of literary refinement, the region of wood, where mountain forests and fierce beasts are naturally uncontrollable. One should only maintain purity and cleanliness; Heaven sends forth the hunt, but one should not appear frequently, for many will fear them, and they shall be named tigers. Those born in the midst of *yin* shall also have long lives, and if three *yin* converge at birth, longevity may be enduring. *Shen*, however, is its opposition, utterly irreconcilable, filled with dread of the night. Though they may climb trees up and down, their fears are manifold. Their fate lies in metal, and their conduct harms and wounds others. Thus, their lifespans are short—this is readily known. Neglecting the spirits and indulging in dissipation, they are beset by malevolent influences and constant dread, with few favorable moments.

Those born in *mao* or *you* each govern their respective months, and their months are again the same. *Mao* presides over the East, its fate bound to the Eastern Star, where livelihood flourishes and the people are nourished. *Mao* thus signifies the East, with the true *mao* as its center. In spring, it blossoms in splendor; in summer, it bears fruit—nothing is not bestowed, and none are untouched by its virtue. Thus, the Eastern Star is named Benevolence, incapable of harming the center. Heaven cherishes human years and grants extended longevity. *You*, however, stands in the domain of metal, delighting in warfare and strife, and cannot endure long. Evil conduct arises naturally—how could long life follow? Though one may encounter the kingly and ministerial phases of the months, it is but a fleeting semblance. Of six or seven evils, half the days shall perish—this is readily known.

Those born in the years of *si* and *hai* each occupy their respective months, their names again reflecting their nature. With double yin and no yang, their lifespans are naturally short. When the three yin converge, the time again aligns, and thus *si* and *hai* are said to govern the opening and storing. *Hai* presides over the Northwest, *si* over the Southeast; whatever they face or undertake rarely accords with propriety. Their livelihood is difficult to advance, and their lifespans are hard to extend. Thus, the ten celestial stems circulate in mutual correspondence, their names denoting achievement, and the celestial reckoning again aligns. Calculating their short and long spans, one infers fate by mutual correspondence—how could Heaven’s movements be followed at will? Thus, those of great virtue now oversee these patterns, their registers bound to the stellar lodges, their fates recorded in the celestial bureaus. Inner and outer ledgers exist, and the eight directions all possess their own patterns—how could one act at will? People, not grasping these calculations, instead ask what they have done to wrong Heaven. By doing good, one may fulfill one’s allotted years; by doing evil, one forfeits longevity and shortens one’s span. If evil is not ceased, calamity extends even to the unborn—what can one hope for? One reaps what one sows. If one’s fate is meager and its reckoning unfulfilled, the surplus remains in Heaven to be bestowed upon the virtuous. One should admonish one’s descendants to be cautious. By rectifying one’s errors and repenting, one may yet complete one’s years—each shall be clearly apportioned. Reckon one’s conduct and do not resent the celestial spirits. Strive to do good, and one’s descendants shall enjoy extended years; otherwise, one remains as one is—blame not Heaven.

If one initially rectifies oneself but later wavers, one should restore equilibrium. The virtuous and benevolent naturally esteem their years.

**Register of Longevity, First Scroll, Section 182**
The conduct of the Most High’s virtuous ones begins with foreknowledge of Heaven and Earth’s inner and outer workings, their ingress and egress through yin and yang. They grasp the Dao’s guiding principles, arouse the thoughts within, and never forget its principles. Proceeding in accord with Heaven, they dare not doubt, and thus achieve completion, upholding Heaven’s great bestowals. Their thoughts reside within, their conduct free of transgression or fault. Subtly endowed by nature, they repeatedly receive warnings—past and future are known. If people transgress of their own accord, they have no one to blame.

Since ancient times, few have been trustworthy. Those who seek to deceive do not consider the consequences. Thus, Heaven and Earth grow dark with unceasing wrath, and even the wise and sagely know regret. Heaven instructs and teaches them. Yet they reject others’ words, return evil with enmity, and ignore admonitions, seeking only their own way. Such people are more ignorant than beasts. For this reason, they reproach themselves for their faults—how could ease arise? Day and night, they ponder others, never ceasing in their remorse for their transgressions—whom can they blame? Yet they remain unrepentant, reckless in their misconduct, acting without regard for great teachings, and thus bring short lives upon themselves—whom can they blame?

**Reflections on the Origins**
How did the immortals of high antiquity who transcended the world begin their thoughts? Examining the records, all speak of loyalty and filial piety, reverence for parents, harmony among siblings, absence of duplicity, unity above and below, and awareness of Heaven’s prohibitions. The spirits preside over governance; one confesses one’s faults without ceasing, cultivates oneself through introspection, and thus attains life. One’s allotted span has its term—how could one act at will? The thought pains the heart, tears soak the garments, and there is no respite.

Daily they cherish their years and lives, fearing they may not attain longevity. Observing those of long life, they inquire of them, and are told: "They possess loyalty and filial piety, never losing the intent of Heaven and Earth, aiding the four seasons in their generation, assisting the Five Phases in their completion, and daring not to destroy the creatures of the living world. They cease from doing good yet refrain from encroaching upon others, commit no deceit or betrayal, and maintain sincerity and trust without daring to incur debt. Their conduct wins the favor of the multitude, and they dare not fail their kin or bring harm to their village; when they go forth, they always repay what is due. They return in due season and have never lain drunk in the marketplace. The wise and worthy accompany them, while they pay no heed to fools. They hold gratitude toward Heaven and Earth yet dare not expect repayment, only reproaching themselves. If they commit transgressions again, they bear the burden of their faults, reproaching themselves for a set number of years until moved to remorse. The worldly multitude bears many faults and debts, yet remains utterly without resolution. They proceed in sorrow and bitterness, not knowing where to halt. Whenever they see others commit faults, they turn to reproach themselves, unable to find peace, yearning to behold the scriptures of righteousness and the precepts of goodness. By some stroke of fortune, they encounter the great divine precepts of Heaven, pondering them again and again, their thoughts consumed without respite. They knock their heads, beat their breasts, and weep aloud, their bodies unable to correct themselves, yet they multiply their resentments. The weight of the prohibitive scriptures is great, yet they transgress them, shortening their lives and repenting day and night. Hoping for a brief reprieve, they dare not commit further evil, instead resolving to practice kindness and bestow alms. If they grasp the principle, they utter no harsh words, only tears, their hearts stricken with sorrow. The heavenly spirits hear and descend to ask: 'Who is this person, so full of grief and distress?' They observe one of great virtue whose life is long and enduring. Inquiring further, they are told: 'This one merely acts in accord with Heaven’s intent and Earth’s will—thus they attain longevity.' Returning to their quiet abode, they reflect upon this as the words of one of supreme virtue, and thus examine themselves. When the spirits see their self-reproach and repentance, they ascend to report to the Dao of Heaven, saying: 'There is one who weeps and laments in repentance without cease, fearing they may not live, and thus reproaches themselves.' The great spirits hear and say: 'The Heavenly Lord constantly instructs the spirits that those who perform good deeds and act with loyalty and filial obedience are to be advanced—this person alone is such a one.' They then report to the Heavenly Lord. The Heavenly Lord says: 'I have heard that this person has reproached themselves for their faults for many years. Originally but a worldly person, they have ceaselessly reproached their transgressions and become one of supreme goodness. The great spirits have frequently gone to observe them, discerning their conduct and whether they harbor good intentions. If they wish to advance, their lifespan shall temporarily be recorded in the Bureau of Longevity, where their deeds may be observed to make up for their deficiencies.' The great spirits say: 'This person has reproached themselves for so long that their burdens of fault have been absolved. I request that their deficiencies be made up, and they be named one of supreme goodness, to repay those below who have fallen short.' The Heavenly Lord says: 'The conduct of one of supreme goodness must accord with these words. The great spirits shall frequently instruct and protect them, guiding them to ascend as spirits, ensuring their allotted years are not diminished.' The great spirits say: 'Originally, this person had no record in the registers. Having received the decree to be placed in the Bureau of Longevity, I request that their deficiencies be made up in order, without exceeding the proper sequence.' The Heavenly Lord says: 'On the day their deficiencies are made up in order, frequently record their name without missing the appointed time.' The great spirits assent.

Only those of supreme benevolence accumulate merit and deeds in Heaven. Heaven then heeds and trusts them, allowing them to assist the Eastern August One in arranging the creatures of the living world, providing flowers and fruits to nourish the people, ensuring warmth and fullness. Their forms grow large, and they nurture one another in turn. Yin and Yang unite, male and female take shape, the old and young follow in succession, receiving their allotted spans from the reckoning of Heaven. Among the twenty-eight lunar lodges, they revolve and complete one another; the sun and moon illuminate and inspect without fail, taking turns to generate life—how could there be respite? Yet people do not know this, believing each to be self-governing. Though they bear names as if self-governing, they in fact check and sustain one another. The reason for this is that human lives have varying lengths, and the seasons of spring, autumn, winter, and summer bring constant cycles of life and death. Thus, they are made to govern one another, transferring and inquiring in turn. Lifespans increase or decrease, passing from one to another. Therefore, it is said that the four seasons, Five Phases, sun, moon, and stars all hold sway over life. The good have their years increased, while the evil retreat on their own. The reckoning of faults, great or small, follows a constant law. If one acts in accordance with this law, how could there be escape? Above in Heaven and below on Earth, they correspond like the exterior and interior, with various spirits also dispatched to assist one another. Thus, it is said that the Heavenly Lord issues decrees to the various bureaus, each transferring and taking turns to serve as the current tally, without the slightest partiality. From above, they observe below—how could there be error?

Those of inherent nature harbor no evil intent. Though they may commit minor faults, they repent of their deeds, and their transgressions are absolved. Their names are regularly entered into the registers. The evil are consigned to the lower bureaus, while the good are reported as good, and the evil as evil. The spirits of fortune and misfortune each follow where they are assigned. If the evil repent, their names are transferred to the good bureaus. If the good turn to evil, they are moved to the evil bureaus—how could there be respite? Among the living in the world, even those still in the womb, whose names and fates are recorded in the Register of the Undying, once their years are fulfilled and their conduct complete, are taken up by those who record the living, and only when they have a guarantor are they entered into the registers. The reason for this is that their lives are difficult to await and weighty, so their guarantors are held jointly responsible. Thus, those who are disloyal, unfilial, disobedient, and without merit have no guarantors, existing only to continue the ancestral sacrifices of their forebears. If they persist in evil without cease, how could they obtain sustenance in future lives? How could those who feed on filth ever be fit to serve the great spirits of Heaven for long? Even among those in filth, there are those who respond to the scriptures of Heaven, and Heaven dispatches spirits to instruct them. When the appointed time arrives, the Heavenly Lord commands the guardian spirits of the Great Heavenly Granary to sever their attachment to material forms. They receive the qi of the Great Heavenly Granary, their food dissolving and transforming, making their spirits light and ethereal. They emerge from darkness into the unseen, and their names ascend, no longer recorded in the registers."

How could one seek life, and how could others know of it? When a person cultivates goodness without losing the heart of Heaven, the great spirits stir their mind, making them delight in life—whether Daoist or layperson, they cling to it themselves. The reason for this is that when one commits evil without a single good deed, merely coveting fine clothes and carriages, following their own desires without restraint, even Heaven and Earth do not deny their fleeting wishes. Yet the wicked cannot long behold the sun, moon, and stars of Heaven. They must return to the eternal night—how could they remain long? Those who cannot take themselves as teachers to cultivate goodness are known by Heaven to persist in evil, and so they are made to consume material sustenance. Thus, they are buried beneath the earth, becoming servants of the earth spirits, never to be reborn. This is why scriptures are shown to them, that they may know.

Some undergo *shijie* (corpse liberation), their forms dissolving, bones and body parting. Though the corpse remains in one place, the spirit becomes a wandering soul, seen by others who declare them dead. Yet those who know may still perceive them alive—such are the *shijie* immortals. Over time, as their years and merits accumulate, they ascend in broad daylight to Heaven. When their merits and years are complete, their radiance shines anew, aiding the celestial spirits in their all-pervading work. They return to dwell among the clouds, and within their domains, all *shijie* immortals oversee the affairs of humans and ghosts.

In families of the Dao, those who depart may be enfeoffed as honored spirits among the dead, known as *Dilingqi* (Earthly Numinous Spirits), and may wear the purple, mugwort, blue, and yellow insignia. Their authority has ranks, and their ascent has limits. If their evil deeds are heard even in part, they are demoted to join the ranks of ghosts—do you understand? Thus it is said: the paths of life and death diverge, how could they be compared?

Proceed, and when minor lapses or lingering attachments remain, they shall be addressed later.

〈Rising〉
Only the virtuous conduct of the Most High’s good people manifests the affairs Heaven and Earth must enact. Each has its master, each its discourse, each its cultivation, each its spiritual attainment, each its merit, each its loyalty, each its governance, each its bestowal upon others, each its path of advancement. Each aligns with the heart of Heaven and Earth, never losing the generative and transformative cycles of the four seasons and five phases. Thus, those who respond to the Most High’s virtuous are Heaven’s trust and Earth’s safeguard, all attaining the harmonious heart of the center. They understand the ebb and flow of human affairs, carrying out commands without daring to contravene the will of the great sages, nor transgress the prohibitions of the myriad spirits. Ever mindful of perfecting others, they make them delight in goodness.

They secure the hearts of Heaven and Earth, establishing inner truth from outward signs, achieving success in their persons, and attaining longevity, inscribed in the register of the undying. They serve alongside the great spirits in corresponding roles, discerning right from wrong, loyal and sincere to Heaven. They behold the sun, moon, and stars without losing the measure, nor their resolve. Ever desiring to live, they contemplate serving Heaven’s transformation, 〈halt〉 and again understand Earth’s principles. Their hearts rejoice, for they know the records of fortune and misfortune, the affairs of survival and demise, and aspire to walk the same path as the natural order.

Even slight greed or evil is seen by the great spirits’ admonitions. Moved by pity for the unknowing, they illuminate their shortcomings, guiding them to the register of long life, where they witness the Heavenly Lord bestowing life upon the ignorant, remaining long in the register of the undying. They perform the affairs of Heaven above and communicate with Earth’s principles below. What they see and hear is clear: their eyes bright, ears keen, they perceive the boundless affairs of past and future. Their writings and words are fluent, and they comprehend the essential and wondrous—such are the aspirations of the Most High’s good people.

Only the great celestial spirits perceive and fulfill their wishes, yearning for the natural, their conduct in harmony with the qi of life, endless and without limit. It is ever said: 〈rising〉 Heaven does not deny a person’s wishes, Earth does not deny a person’s peace—this is the natural order. They dare not have even a hair’s entanglement, nor trouble the spirits with deep records in ink. Day and night, they reflect on their faults and debts, fearing they may fail to meet the expectations of the Most High Lord. What do they惜惜 or love, that they would not exhaust their loyalty and filial piety?

They should declare themselves recipients of grace and favor, enjoying glory, yet seeking no repayment. Heaven’s heart cherishes them deeply, yet they reproach themselves for their faults, granting little pardon. 〈Halt〉 Only the great spirits may forgive and admonish them, but they must not cling to longing nor dare to distance themselves. Ever mindful of unrepayed kindness, their sins cling to their bodies, and they fear no words can absolve them—only sorrow remains. Though they see forgiveness and reflection, they are made to ponder their debts.

The great spirits say: "The Most High’s good people reflect on their faults and reproach themselves; their words and writings reach the highest ears. Their words extend far, yet they fear their meaning may not be understood. Heaven’s trust especially honors them, and they may attain boundless longevity. They should ever set their hearts afar, never forgetting the great gifts bestowed by Heaven’s life. The Most High Lord praises them, saying: 'Life arises from the mandate of life itself. They disregard wealth and beauty, ever desiring to share long life with those they save. When would they act recklessly or without heart, failing to repay such profound kindness?'"

"Yet they惜惜 their years since birth, for they have not seen the great measure."

Only by receiving the grace of instruction and admonition do they come to know their allotted principles. They should speak of knowing fate, neither resenting Heaven nor daring to reproach themselves and thus hinder their own lives. With hearts thus aligned, when would they ever be greedy or perverse? Yet they fear only that their years and fate may reach their end without witnessing Heaven’s great dispensation of life’s allotments.

Once more, they admonish and instruct the ignorant and benighted, granting them the boon of reflection and foresight—a kindness beyond repayment in mere words. They but restrain their hearts and keep their thoughts within, never forgetting hunger and thirst, seeking precepts to preserve life, and only by receiving pardon and reflection.

The great spirits say: "We originally advanced to the Heavenly Lord from among the spirits without the slightest fault, aiding Heaven and Earth with meritorious counsel. Our names are recorded in the Heavenly Lord’s register—how could we ever be forgotten? We request to present the words of the living who reproach themselves, whose years are numbered yet who covet Heaven’s transformation. Are such people recorded in the celestial registers?"

The Heavenly Lord says: "Those who reproach themselves act in accord with nature; they are also aided by the spirits’ goodness."

"Let those who oversee the celestial records examine them. If they find self-reproach, the spirit in charge of the living’s register shall be commanded to inspect the documents. Such a person is indeed recorded in the registers."

The Heavenly Lord says: "Those who live and act with goodness, transgressing no prohibitions, achieve this through their own conduct."

The great spirits add: "Let us examine further. We must ensure that those who act lack no names in the upper registers."

The great spirits say: "Since the Great Beginning, spirits who have gained Heaven’s favor through merit have been advanced, though some vacancies remain. Those whose conduct is fitting should have their names duly recorded above."

The Heavenly Lord says: "The duties of our offices are many and onerous. Calculate their merits, absolve their faults, and ensure they never violate what has been decreed."

The great spirits say: "These Most High people follow the correct path, and their faults and debts are few."

The Heavenly Lord says: "Reflect further. If any are unworthy of promotion, hold them accountable to fill the vacancies with trustworthy candidates."

The Heavenly Lord says: "Such matters must not be treated carelessly."

The great spirits say: "As the words have stated, before a hundred days have passed, the spirits above will vie to vouch for them. We, the great spirits, present this intent."

The Heavenly Lord says: "Let each be assigned as is fitting. Send them to attend to their duties, and they shall be further esteemed. Those who are trustworthy shall be appointed as Perfected."

The great spirits say: "We request to dispatch spirit-messengers to summon them above, first transforming their forms."

The spirit-messengers go forth, their transformations complete, radiant with abundant luminous essence.

The great spirits report back. The Heavenly Lord says: "The person has transformed into a spirit and now waits outside the gate, not yet having entered."

The Heavenly Lord commands that they be presented to the overseers’ office for an audience.

The great spirits say: "We have reported as requested."

"Very well. Let the report be as stated, and we shall observe their conduct accordingly."

The Heavenly Lord says: "Let it be as the great spirits have reported."

**Chapter 183: The Longing of the Knowing to Meet the Great Spirits**

Only those of the Most High who possess knowledge may foreknow the affairs of Heaven, discerning what is to be done and what is to be upheld. Their affairs arise naturally, the primordial qi converging to bring them to fruition, clearly and knowably. Transforming their hearts, they become natural in their conduct. Thus, the knowing understand both surface and depth, their comings and goings, their actions—nothing fails to reach completion, nothing fails to attain its proper place, and nothing fails to transform in due time. Revering the majesty of the spirits, they perfect their merit and name their virtue. Ever unwavering in loyalty and trust, never remiss, day and night they grieve and tremble, their thoughts never leaving their hearts. Inclining and yearning, they long to achieve an audience with the great spirits. Through discourse and the exchange of words, they follow the Way they know and advance what they have understood.

Ever contemplating success, they seek to repay the spirits’ kindness, to extend their years and increase their lifespan. Thus, the knowing look inward to see outward—what do they not know? What do they not perceive? Their hearts are clear and attentive. They but covet the Dao of long life, desiring to ride as envoys for the great spirits. Wherever they go, they dare not speak falsely, responding in the moment as if already arrived, longing for their hearts to open. Receiving the spirits’ words as the spirits themselves would, knowing the spirits’ actions, they proceed with self-assurance, then dare to speak, seeking only to be granted life. They dare not seek high office, only to be shown mercy. Though they witness matters of life and death, their hearts tremble with fear. Having received great instruction, they must act to communicate it, bestowing kindness and spreading beneficence, benefiting those above and those below, inscribing their names in the registers, ever abiding in the position of the undying. Their hearts rejoice and delight, dedicating their merit to the Heavenly Lord, accumulating it over the years before speaking further. Only by the great spirits’ grace are their insufficiencies made known. Knowing their words are grand, they thus covet advancement, receiving their secret decrees, anxiously awaiting the convergence of gates, never daring to rest. They long for instruction and admonition, to be granted what they lack. They wish to be examined and not contradict what is said, awaiting the great spirits’ commands.

Those of the Most High who possess knowledge see much, yet they cannot fully know Heaven’s domains—what, then, should they be admonished about? The spirits of Heaven all perceive them. The words of the Most High who possess knowledge are but to know what is said, what is followed, what is done—what doubt could there be?

The Heavenly Lord says: "Ever command the spirits to advance the names of those who are loyal, filial, sincere, trustworthy, and meritorious. These are the Most High who possess knowledge, whose allotted blessings they covet, and thus they clarify their hearts. Yet they fear their words and writings are but self-expression—why would they withhold reverence for Heaven’s instruction and admonition? They often say they suffer from having no one to record their words, fearing that inner and outer may not correspond. If they wish to advance their reflections and broaden their inquiries to deep understanding, this too is what they should know. Proceed, and heed the words of the great spirits. Heaven’s admonitions are weighty—one must be cautious, reverent, and awestruck, then one may proceed."

The admonitions are many, yet one must grasp their essence—open your ears, eyes, and heart to them." "Indeed, indeed."

Yet when emerging from this, the great celestial precepts of Heaven decree that all who seek advancement and long life must present what they know. To possess knowledge and remain silent, as if merely listening, is to lack the heart for self-advancement. When the mind holds understanding and reflection, one must advance and reveal it. If there is aspiration within, present that aspiration; if there is sincerity, present that sincerity; if there is filial piety, present that filial piety. Only thus may one become Heaven’s confidant—nothing must be withheld.

The Heavenly Lord foresees human nature: one must not fail to advance, nor withhold the Dao and its teachings. To conceal knowledge and hide one’s abilities—Heaven despises such a person, ensuring they do not appear in the Register of Longevity. Is this not so? Not only will they vanish from the Register of Longevity, but their primordial essence will dissipate, departing from the body, and their years will be lost. Can one not be cautious?

The reason the Most High possess knowledge is that the Heavenly Lord discerns the knowing from the unknowing—this they know themselves. What doubt remains? One need only reflect deeply on the words of the spirits and not betray them.

The words of the Most High who possess knowledge say: even the ignorant below, when earnestly inquiring, seek to grasp what they do not know. How dare they conceal knowledge or hide their abilities, causing the Heavenly Lord and the spirits to learn of it, leading to the loss of life and years, and a lifespan cut short? This is the root of calamity and misfortune—even the destruction of the body would not suffice to repay it. How could one dare to advance yet still withhold?

The great spirits say: "Those who seek life and shun death must also possess resolve and will—lest they falter in confusion."

The disciple says: "I myself do not know the precepts, yet by the grace of the great spirits, I have been taught thus. How dare I grow complacent and not advance what I know and say? I only hope the great spirits will record it."

The great spirits say: "To be recorded is not easy. Only those who are preserved and trusted, who align with the Heavenly Lord’s will, may hope for life. Take heed of this."

The disciple says: "I truly crave life, and so I exhaust my loyalty and sincerity, never daring to slacken. I reflect on my faults and reproach myself—how dare I waste day and night?"

The Heavenly Lord, having heard this, says: "These are the words of one who is among the Most High who possess knowledge. It is known that in the celestial records, this person’s name appears, though incomplete. Command the spirit of the Register of Life to verify: though this person’s name is recorded, and though they are virtuous and knowledgeable, their years must be fulfilled—do not let the spirit of their allotted time be lost."

"Indeed, indeed."

**Method for the Person of Heart to Accumulate Deeds and Mend the True: Scroll One Hundred Eighty-Four**

**〈Commencement〉**
Only the Most High’s person of heart knows their allotted portion, each having their own Dao, their own conduct, their own devotion, their own advancement, their own declaration, their own speech, their own attainment, their own movement. The heart is not bound within; they constantly think of exhausting loyalty, trustworthiness, and filial piety. Sincerely meritorious before Heaven, they accumulate deeds over the years, never once slackening. Though they forget gratitude and duty, they constantly long for life, gaining the protection of the host of upper spirits, never daring to offer even the slightest portion. They constantly harbor a fearful heart, never at ease, desiring the Most High’s precepts to preserve their life—how dare they forget the great dispensation?

Only the great spirits may glance upon what they overlook. Their heart constantly yearns for the affairs of the Most High, for what they must uphold, the compass and square, the plumb line and inked cord. Trust arises naturally; they survey the four boundaries, fathom the four corners. What Heaven knows, they manifest before it comes to pass. Their heart contemplates the petitions and memorials of the great spirits, what they advance and declare—never daring to judge by their own intent. They constantly consult with the assembled spirits, whether to accept or reject, ever fearful of failing to win the hearts of the gods.

**〈Conclusion〉**
They reflect: "I am one of unblemished origin." As if arising from the very center of their being, they long for the life that harms nothing, coveting its radiance. Above, it reaches the sound without essence or form; penetratingly, it fulfills the Most High’s commands. Never daring to slacken and obstruct the great transformation, they beseech the spirits to examine their longing for life, never daring to stray from the left side of the great spirits. Upon seeing the precepts, their heart opens and their eyes brighten, desiring to abide in the scripture of longevity, to increase their years and lifespan. They aspire to advance in merit, personally attending to it, never daring to trust themselves, to arrogate the Dao’s twists and turns, or to contend over what is insufficient.

They gaze upward, ever urgent, only hoping for the compassionate illumination of the precepts. When will their gratitude and love cease? Their heart longs day and night for reunion, coveting knowledge of prohibitions and transgressions to stir their resolve, so they may see what they have yet to attain. These are not matters to be repaid in words or speech; only by receiving scrutiny does the thought pierce their heart and diaphragm.

The great spirit says: "This is the conduct proper to the Most High’s person of heart. They seek to receive Heaven’s weighty precepts and prohibitions. Those who are inherently wise and clear-sighted discern principle—what need have they for precepts? Holding the heart, they aim at the heart; no private bias intervenes. From above, they observe below, knowing full well what they serve.

Now, the Most High’s person of heart is Heaven’s intimate, trusted by the celestial spirits. They need only hold fast to their intent, ever fearful of loss. The rest is known to their own heart. Strive to transmit and widely inquire; do not lose what is spoken."

"The wise discern much, but I fear they may not always live up to their words. Why hesitate to speak plainly? Such a person’s heart reflects on their own faults and debts. Simply contemplate before and after—longevity will naturally arise from within, resonating with the Heavenly Lord’s will.

I have little to admonish the person of heart. Their life began as one of the rustic and lowly. Witnessing long life and old transformations, they again encounter the prime of light and radiance. Essence flows in and out without loss; no failure is seen. Though many study, few attain—none, in fact. Why is this? Their heart is not sufficiently steadfast, and they treat their words lightly. Their allotted record is not fitting, hence their rarity.

Now, seeing the deeds of those who came before, they further correct and amend their conduct, opening their heart to retain what is good. Desiring to raise their voice, they listen well, coveting longevity and cherishing their years. Thus, they never dare to slacken, only beseeching the great spirits to examine what they overlook."

The great spirit says: "The person of heart shall be granted registration in the celestial records. Let the clerks of the registers be summoned to verify: those whose names are recorded shall be reported to the Heavenly Lord. The great spirits may not act on their own."

The person of life says: "Only the great spirits may illuminate and deliberate. I dare not distance myself, lingering outside. I will personally prove my worth."

The great spirit says: "Let the person of heart be reported. Those whose names are recorded in the registers—why hesitate to respond?"

The person of life says: "Only the great spirits may speak on my behalf. On the day of accomplishment, I will devote my life to proving myself. What need have I for repayment?"

The great spirit reports to the Heavenly Lord: "The Most High’s person of heart all hold their hearts steadfast and secret, their aspiration constantly longing for the upper realms with trust. Command the overseeing spirits to examine them. If such a person exists, advance and report to the great spirits. Command the overseers to verify: if this person’s name appears in the records, they were preordained before birth."

The great spirit returns and reports: "This person was registered before birth—only by the grace of the Most High."

The Heavenly Lord says: "Those recorded in the registers shall be seen to ascend. They shall take responsibility for their debts and burdens. The great spirits shall dispatch a divine envoy to remove their burden of debt, transform their heart, and refine them into a spirit. When their years are fulfilled, they shall advance upward."

The great spirit says: "This person’s years and allotment are complete, their reckoning exceeding the term by nearly a hundred days. Previously, there was no fixed date, so they were temporarily halted."

The Heavenly Lord says: "Command the great spirits to advance them, placing them in an interim office. Let them fill a vacancy among the true. If they can exhaust their essence and will, knowing how to remove and concurrently act, then—"

The great spirit says: "Let them advance as the Heavenly Lord commands. Reassess their essence, lifespan, and reckoning. The enlightened shall ascend in broad daylight."

The Heavenly Lord says: "This is fitting for the person of heart, desiring to give them a position."

The great spirits assent. Let the proper officials be commanded to carry out the original decree.

The great spirit says: "Report to the Bureau of Ascension."

The petitioner reports to the great spirit: "Command the overseeing clerks."

The overseers having reported: "Let them be assigned to an interim office, filling a vacancy among the true."

The Heavenly Lord says: "As the clerks have reported."

---

From *"When ascending to Heaven, one sees good deeds—whether to conceal them or not—and what misfortune and fortune bring"* to *"end."*

**Collected and Collated Texts of the* Taiping Jing*, Volume 112 (Geng Section, Part Ten)**
**The* Taiping Jing*, Scroll 112**
*On the Disasters of Greed for Wealth and Lust, and the Admonitions Within the Womb (185)*

In ancient times, the formless divine beings sought the Dao of life. They aligned their aspirations with the qi of the Primordial, constantly yearning for long life, ever mindful never to betray the intent of that qi. At dusk they settled their thoughts, at dawn they attended to their duties, clinging tenaciously to life without a moment’s forgetfulness. They often reflected and observed, offering utmost loyalty and sincerity, following and fulfilling the wishes of the Primordial qi. Thus, their conduct ascended in clarity, resplendent and audible throughout the four directions—perceiving even unseen things and faint sounds, moving above and below, all in accordance with the proper measures. The host of spirits and refined qi came unbidden to serve and attend them, fearing to displease or offend, all filled with reverent awe. Their garments and footwear transformed to suit their desires; they bestowed kindness and spread grace, their fame flowing above and below, reaching the eight directions beyond the six extremes, extending even to the sages of old. Each received rewards or punishments according to their virtues and faults. Those covered by great mercy reverently obeyed the commands, moving even the stars to respond.

---

Boundless were their resources, boundless their virtue. They selected the steadfast and good to shield and conceal themselves. Their wishes were fulfilled, their hearts at ease and joyful, attaining life without limit. Serene and unadorned, they cherished the wholeness of their bodies—how could they grow weary? Others did not know them, nor did they heed others. Without rank or merit, how could they ascend to share the same path as the Primordial qi? Thus, they treasured, loved, and nurtured themselves, and in their utmost youth, they practiced boundless generosity—how could they fail to receive blessings?

Yet they pondered: moving within the harmony of Heaven and Earth, they illuminated the sun, moon, and stars, drawing light from before them. The twenty-eight constellations took their turns, observing the people’s use of the heavenly stems and earthly branches, the patterns of fortune and misfortune. But people knew little of this, considering themselves wise. Their actions and movements brought no benefit to Heaven, and in violating prohibitions, they invited calamity—extending even to the annihilation of their families, the severing of their lineage, and the loss of their ancestors’ sacrifices. How could their lives remain whole for long? What could be done for such people?

They did not follow the ancient texts, believing themselves free from offense against spirits and gods. Yet the three qi were not in harmony, and fate had its thickness and thinness. Unable to deeply contemplate disasters and misfortunes, the three qi spirits were sent to admonish them. Those who heeded the warnings prospered; those who did not doomed themselves to the depths below, their misfortunes flowing to their descendants. Heaven’s decrees were not obeyed; evil was practiced and good abandoned—how could they endure? What the August Emperor did not wish to see was swiftly cut short in years. Yet people, unaware, blamed the Azure Heaven. When did Heaven ever wrong them? They brought it upon themselves. Utterly lacking wisdom and foresight, their lives were like those of dogs and sheep—how could they long endure? Caught in the same snares as birds, they violated the celestial net, their greed for food harming their bodies. Their kind followed one another, heedless of their years. Only the wise escaped to the unharmed lands beyond the four borders—how did they alone fare thus? It was simply the natural course of their fate. Though dwelling among the uninhabited, their lives were preserved by fate. Few in the world repaid them—such was the way of the times. Alas, what could be done?

They asked, "What have we done to wrong Heaven?" Among the ancients, not one in ten thousand matched their kind. Greedy for wealth and lust, they disregarded impending peril. Disasters reached even the womb, leaving them unseen by the sun, moon, or stars—how could they not grieve? They brought ruin upon themselves, their fate bound to the earth. Wretched were these people, yet they had their counterparts—even plants, trees, birds, and beasts were the same. They did not strive to correct themselves or purify their intentions, uttering reckless and evil words. Above, the spirits recorded their deeds; below, no numinous response remained. Nothing was hidden from the one who presided over them. Each must exert themselves to seek the admonitions of the divine spirits, the convergence of fortune and misfortune—how could there be no reckoning?

Thus, the divine beings were commanded to establish prohibitions for the people, allowing them to see the taboos of life and death. Those touched by yang qi were recorded in the registers of true immortals; those with transgressions were demoted. Those touched by yin qi were placed among the dead. Reflect deeply and consider carefully—do not lose the celestial net that extends to the patterns of the earth. Know the human condition, the inner and outer, when to advance and when to retreat. Do not bring blame upon others, and each may gain extended years, their blessings extending to their descendants.

After receiving the admonitions, be doubly cautious in speech. Evil committed below is not overlooked above. The people of the vulgar world lack filial piety and loyalty, coveting what they desire and seizing what is not theirs. Their hearts brim with murderous intent, never leaving their lips—how could they hope to live? Calamity and blame would come, sooner or later. Follow the records of the celestial texts and divine spirits, keeping far from what should be avoided. Do not test fate—testing life brings life, testing death brings death. When death comes, there is no doubt.

Thus, I reiterate and repeat: do not associate with the ignorant, nor utter even slight dissent. The Dao of long life lies close at hand in the three spirits; the three qi combine to form a person. If they do not combine, they scatter into earth, becoming like tiles and stones, shattered in unseen places, unable to compare with the whole and intact. The spirits of the three destinies reside near the heart—what is there to cherish or love? Yet they cling to the ruin of their forms, displayed in the marketplace for all to see—when will they return to life? Their parents grieve, their wives and children suffer. Distant kin rejoice, neighbors resent their belated demise, and death flows to later generations.

Those who correct themselves and do good may yet regain longevity. Sincerity moves all things to their natural state. Be vigilant within and without, between yin and yang, in the four seasons’ generation and completion—do not destroy them. Between Heaven above, Earth below, and the harmony between them, all have their masters. For those with understanding, these are the methods of mutual response. Those who live align their wishes with the Dao of Heaven; those who do evil cut short their years. How could they not be cautious?

The words of the divine beings all receive Heaven’s response—they cannot blame themselves. Those who extend their lifespan by doing good may fulfill their natural years; the wicked descend into the Yellow Springs. Ponder this, ponder it well, and do not transmit it recklessly. When the wicked receive evil, they suffer its calamities, their deaths and lives separated in different realms, none daring to speak of it. If one does not act with goodness, they must not resent others; there are always those who record such deeds, leaving no room for further complaint. Study the texts to grasp their meaning, be vigilant with sacred scriptures, for spirits and spectral agents all have their causes.

Those of destined households who encounter this text must take care not to harm themselves or deceive the good. When Heaven shortens a person’s life, bringing illness and disease, there is no need to seek aid from physicians or tormented shamans—their records will be severed, what doubt remains? Reflect deeply, contemplate, and consider: one may yet avoid calamity. But once misfortune strikes, there is no salvation. The Perfected One holds this text to enlighten the ignorant, that they may reform and do good, not malign its words. What has been said before is repeated here. The reason is this: life and death alter fate, and without speaking of its prohibitions, there is no way to preserve it—□□ is natural.

One must only know the true intent of the heart and favor these words, understanding their meaning. Thus, guard the unity of the body to fulfill one’s natural years; guard unity, reflect on transgressions, and one may yet extend their term. The Dao of Heaven is boundless, yet few attain its truth. The *Hetu* and *Luoshu* are abandoned by many. The reason is this: those who do not believe in their texts rarely achieve transcendence, becoming instead common folk. Now, through the masters of the Three Divine Beings, those whose hearts are moved anew—when divine spirits attach to a person, they do not wish for earthly qi to summon them. Thus, one must carefully ponder and consider its intent, not doubting this text.

The masters of the divine beings, having received Heaven’s teachings, transmit it to those who record and comprehend its meaning.

**Admonition of the Seventy-Two Kinds of Corpse Deaths, One Hundred Eighty-Sixth**
*(Beginning)*
Heaven has its four corners, Earth has its four corners, thus the sun and moon pass their light in succession. The stars have their degrees, illuminating right and wrong. People have their nobility and baseness, lifespans their length and brevity, each endowed with the destiny of the Six Jia. Birth comes early or late, emoluments align with duty, good and evil dwell in separate places, not losing even a fraction. Common folk do not understand, claiming there is no truth—only when harmonized with divine spirits may one be called human. Only with the divine spirit as one’s heart may one become a lord of men.

Times and seasons have their responses, divisions lie within their domains. Those who receive Heaven’s response are raised by celestial spirits. Those who receive Earth’s response are nurtured by earthly spirits. Those who receive the response of harmony are protected by human and spectral spirits. Good responses bring good, good naturally elevates itself; evil responses bring evil, evil naturally follows. All have their roots, circulating above and below. The waters of mountains and seas, each with their boundaries, each desiring those of good nature and non-opposition as their people. The spirits of the land also desire good people. Each imposes prohibitions, connecting upward to Heaven. Those who do evil and violate them bring ruin upon themselves.

*(End)*
In households of great evil, none—young or old—are favored by spirits and gods. One may only correct themselves, not slander the divine. The Dao of Heaven and the Dao of Man—prohibitions do not favor the empty good. Even the essence of divine qi can lend itself to humans, while the wicked do not escape their records, which are promptly reported above. When transgressions accumulate, the Great Yin presides over the case, judging by the severity of the law, all recorded in ledgers. People remain unaware, thinking nothing of it. The Bright Hall of the Great Yang, with its many recorded transmissions, is overseen by its own domain’s masters, who also transmit frequently.

When celestial spirits report deaths above, lifespans are reduced, and the mortal world is diminished. One cannot ponder this too deeply—repeated goodness brings goodness, while evil returns to its perpetrator. Even those who govern the heavens know little wisdom, thus they issue these texts on saving lives through good and evil, admonishing past and future. Do not take evil words lightly, nor make them the subject of idle talk. Every action and retreat brings its own misfortune. Thus, this text is presented to you, that you may ponder its meaning and not blame yourself.
