The courts enforce the law, yet people violate it themselves—do not resent the enforcers, for resentment shortens the ledger of life. When one is to be executed, the ledgers serve as evidence. Thus, they are buried, and their cases are examined. Documents are cross-referenced—who can escape? Strive to distance yourself from evil, do not make it your companion, and you may yet live out your allotted years. Those who are not loyal in suffering, though struck by madness and malevolence, may yet survive.

The prohibitions and laws of Heaven’s divine spirits are like those of the harmony below the earth, flowing in four directions, all governed by the same pattern—what doubt remains? If a person has merit before Heaven, yet their descendants act wickedly, their allotted years are erased. Though they do not die at once, once their allotment is exhausted, there is no hope for their survival. Lords of states and children of the people must be guided by teaching, directing them toward good and evil, ensuring truth is attained.

Do not cut short the mandate of Heaven and man, severing the generations of the world. Punishment follows its course, and the wise are often seen at its beginning and end. The majesty of the spirits rests upon the lord—do not act with violence. What was said before bears repeating. Lords and fathers may thus extend their years and those of their descendants, flourishing endlessly—take care not to indulge in killing. Though it may seem acceptable at the time, calamity will follow.

*(Beginning)*
Officials, great or small, and their subordinates should clarify their duties and not become a scourge to the people. Those with exceptional ability should revere the Dao, virtue, benevolence, and kindness, aligning with Heaven’s power, Earth’s intent, and the benefit of harmony. Reflect on meeting the good spirits, each having their faith—do not deceive the ignorant.

*(End)*
Those who seek long life and survival must not torment themselves with sorrow and bitterness. Contemplate the affairs of Heaven above, and the spirits will raise you—you may achieve transcendence and long life, ever gazing upon the sun, moon, and stars. This is Heaven’s great mercy. Take care not to commit even minor wrongs, lest you be sent down again.

Those who persist in evil will eventually extinguish their households, thus this repeated admonition: let there be no transgressors. Transgressors are but ill-fated youths. When one intends to do wrong, others should dissuade them from their folly, sparing them from misfortune. Those who disregard counsel will later regret it—such is the fortune of the admonisher.

The stars observe mankind; none may act wickedly. Each must account for their deeds. The virtuous enjoy long life without doubt. Instruct the young to offer sustenance to their ancestors, or else their names shall perish.

*(Beginning)*
Violate not Heaven’s prohibitions, nor Earth’s punishments. Follow the four seasons in harmony, and bear no name of slaughter. The Five Phases form all things; each must guard their place. *(End)* Let no evil name be yours.

Do not slight superiors or inferiors, for all take turns as masters. Ensure no sudden or violent acts, and you shall gain renown. Let thoughts dwell in the heart; guard your form from dissipation. When spirit scatters, malevolent ghosts startle the soul. Reflect to preserve yourself; forget not your name. Each has their joys—pursue the Dao and seek goodness to increase years and prolong life, even achieving immortality.

Be cautious, be ever cautious. Do not pervert justice in punishment. Though it may weary the mind at first, honor shall follow. Masters may be good or evil; consider the root to understand the branch. Disobedient disciples lose their names and cannot attain transcendence. Violating Earth’s punitive spirits only compounds wickedness, barring rebirth.

Be cautious again and again. Within the body, the radiance of spirit arises naturally. Inner and outer become one; actions and words align without losing sincerity. The Five Spirits reside within, knowing your shortfalls. Do not lightly transgress, for there are always records. For minor faults, confess before the Hall of Light. Body and spirit shall be bound, and your deeds examined. Grave offenses incur irrevocable loss; lesser ones reduce your years.

If the spirits do not exonerate you, the fault lies with the person. There are laws and punishments—not only for the living but for spirits and ghosts as well. The ancients, knowing this, dared not transgress. The tally of gods and humans is recorded in Heaven, Earth, and among men. Even without merit, one should not expect reward.

The hearts of the worthy and sagely should reflect upon these scrolls. The scrolls contain prophecies and warnings: the wicked act in rebellion.

*(Beginning)*
Those who cherish life are protected by Heaven; those who nurture life are aided by Earth; those who practice benevolence are beloved by all. To go beyond this is to invite calamity. Heaven knows their evil and dispatches malevolent spirits and spectral beings to await them. These enter the body, flowing outward to the limbs, head, face, abdomen, back, chest, flanks, and the Seven Governors. They ascend to the Hall of Light, manifesting in seventy-two forms—this is the corpse of death.

When the Five Viscera are afflicted, their departure has its time. Be cautious in diet; do not let wind and cold assail you. Follow virtue in all actions, and you shall live out your years. Heaven cherishes human life; Earth cherishes human nurturance; humans cherish human generosity. To do evil is to invite irremediable disaster.

Thus, this celestial scripture admonishes: *(End)* let the people violate no prohibitions. Heaven’s qi issues decrees through men; each should wash away impure conduct.

Be cautious, forget not. Later, there shall be joy. Otherwise, do not presume to remain... as stated. *Inscribing the Scripture: Do Not Needlessly Afflict Yourself with Admonitions*, Scroll One Hundred Eighty-Seven.

*(Beginning)*
The words of the divine sages of old never strayed from the fundamental principles, for they had their own laws and standards. *(End)* The ignorant must each be warned—this warning is especially profound.

The severity of punishment for transgressions arises from human actions, not mere emptiness; there is always a reckoning. Heaven’s nature is spontaneous and cannot be deceived. Reflect deeply without ceasing, and your conduct shall become that of a celestial spirit.

Transformation has its time; do not lose the fundamental principles. The qi of the four seasons must not be violated. When spirit is present, there is no negligence. If one fails to confess, Heaven employs its divining spirits to prevent false reports, and only then may one live. Otherwise, punishment is meted out: selling vegetables in the marketplace, unable to show one’s face, scorned by the base, despised by the multitude. For grave transgressions, the punishment is deep—forty years. Only then may one ascend again as a messenger of the gods. For moderate offenses, thirty years; for lesser, ten.

Their dominion is revoked, each according to their portion. If one changes their heart and self-reproaches, they may endure long. Do not alter Heaven’s words and bring blame upon yourself. Reflect deeply.

For future immortals, weigh the depth of your considerations. Blame lies with yourself; do not resent the words of the gods. In all movements, inner and outer, be cautious of error. Scrutinize what you receive. As a servant of Heaven, you may not act freely. You must immediately obey commands without delay, or face inquiry without delay.

For grave offenses, the messenger is dismissed. Earth records what is received, names inscribed as on a register. No lingering is permitted; where there is a vacancy, a lower-ranked person shall fill it. The reason is this: even those who have fully attained spirit immortality may be demoted—how much more so the foolish scholar? From this point onward, transgress no more.

Heaven punishes human faults, with ghosts and spirits as its agents. Disobeying Heaven’s teachings brings immediate misfortune and blame, not requiring whips or lashes—one reaps what they sow. Those who doubt shall be suspected and cannot remain long. Thus, these words are spoken again: be cautious and vigilant.

Do not imitate the vulgar, who cease their ways with wine and meat. The Dao of immortality is most weighty; thus, it is spoken to men. Those whose fate is to endure are dispatched by the spirits, riding clouds and dragons, traversing all before ceasing.

When Heaven issues commands, they must be carried out. Do not lose the rules or falsify records. Place evidence to the left; do not presume to act on your own. Heaven also rests, and each receives their due punishment. Bear no resentment.

When reported by the spirits, do not recklessly violate the children of Heaven above, Earth below, and the Center in harmony. Each fails to respect themselves. Do not resent Heaven’s blame or Earth’s faults. Above and below detain one another, as in human law. If decrees lack sincerity, the lower ranks grow resentful and do not linger. The gods of Heaven contend for the Dao.

*(Beginning)*
How much more should ordinary people revere and uphold Heaven’s laws, follow Heaven’s harmony, and require no recompense for sustenance or clothing? With merit, they may advance further.

〈Halt〉
Only those with matters to report may do so; the year has its fixed order, and actions must follow the texts without doubt. Each has their own report, and none may resent another equally. Those who jointly accuse shall be punished, and their status shall be further debased. Though they may not descend at once, as they are dispatched by the great spirits, they must not defy the will of the gods but hand matters to the local earth deities, with no recourse to appeal above. Thus, vacancies arise, and if one does not occupy them, the upper, middle, and lower realms align as one.

Heed these words with care, for neglect brings the loss of life and longevity, binding one to the earth. The earth here is not mere soil but is guarded by baleful spirits and tasked by the celestial earth deities. If one fails to act as decreed, suffering shall swiftly follow. Even immortals may err—how can mortals presume to act with impunity? Thus, the Controller of Fate resides near the heart, never far from man, serving as the dwelling of spirit and essence. Fortune and misfortune lie within; why seek distant refuge only to invite calamity? Haste cannot preserve life if one’s allotted span is not yet exhausted, nor can flight avert fate once the reckoning is complete.

When the world convenes with the gods, the overseers know life and death. Even spirits may falter and slip, only to suffer the consequences. Thus, mortal lives cannot endure long. Therefore, divine messengers reveal these writings. If one refrains from evil and prevents malevolent spirits from ascending with reports, one may still partake in grains and sustenance for a time. Beware: do not burn mountains or shatter stones, nor harm grasses and trees, break blossoms or sever branches, or sell their fruits in markets. Let no blade sever their stems or roots entirely. Their mother shall grow wrathful and report to their father above, sparing no thought for human years.

Yet humans too depend on grasses for sustenance—take only what is withered and fallen, not what still thrives. This is the natural order. Heaven and Earth nurture life as humans wish to live; why act with abandon, harming future generations? Those with wisdom must not transgress these prohibitions. Some harm others, but if one relies on the completion of affairs and avoids taking the young to feed others, one’s life may be slightly prolonged. Yet in the end, all are recorded in the registers. Do not raise weapons to rob, threaten, or take lives by force. Heaven has decreed that such people shall not live long. Evil begets evil, troubling the spirits, the qi, and the ghostly beings, leaving none to rest. Is this not the fault of human transgressions? Past wrongdoings bring misfortune upon descendants.

Thus, children born on inauspicious days, or conceived during thunder, lightning, the waxing and waning of the moon, or on blood-avoidance or conflicting-stem days when yin and yang conjoin—such children shall not thrive and will surely meet with disaster. Earth’s qi summons them, yet they blame the wolf and the jackal. Evil is repaid with evil—what else can they expect? Those who do not change their ways shall be eradicated, their households extinguished, and their deaths unlike those of the multitude.

Officials and soldiers of this rank, when sent to desolate and unclean places, may only be buried in the earth, devoured by foxes and dogs, their remains ungathered and discarded by the roadside. Their souls and spirits shall suffer without respite, some bound to grasses and trees, consumed by the six livestock—when shall they be reborn? The punishment of evil and reward of good are known to all; why not reform? Heaven rewards merit and withholds from the virtueless. Ponder this, and the principles of reward and punishment shall be clear.

One may die alone in extreme suffering, but the longevity of good and evil shall unfold in due course. Examine this carefully and take heed, that you may avoid blame. Thus, this solemn warning is given to prompt repentance. The convergence of fortune and misfortune may lie worlds apart, so this text is set forth to admonish and caution. Do not resent Heaven’s blame or Earth’s faults—good and evil must be distinguished.

These writings are recorded so that one may know evil and turn to good, though the souls and spirits shall labor to exhaustion. Fools remain ignorant, so the words are repeated and reiterated, passed on in turn, that later generations may not incur blame. By this, one may verify for oneself—what further resentment or fault remains? Each receives their due. This text must be transmitted without cease. The wise may shorten their years, but fools shall copy these words and ignore them, bringing suffering upon themselves.

*River Bridge Admonition on Punishment for Transgressions, One Hundred and Eighty-Eighth*
〈Rise〉
In the age of high antiquity, divine sages foresaw events and governed alongside Heaven, spreading across the four directions, above and below, and the center, each with their appointed ranks and duties. High and low regarded one another, and order was achieved without sternness, all acting with goodness. Fearing any lapse, all shared a single heart. When Heaven issued commands, they hastened to carry them out, riding chariots of cloud and qi, drawn by flying dragons. The immortals who followed formed ranks, each bearing records, aligning without need for movement. Should questions arise, their conduct was governed by rules, ensuring proper action.

In spring, they nurtured the qi of growth; in summer, they fostered maturation; in autumn, they oversaw the harvest, enabling the people to offer sacrifices; and in winter, they stored the surplus grain, ensuring continuity without lapse. The blessings of the spirits extended to all, bringing glory even to crawling creatures and grasses and trees—was this not the grace of the above? Each received what was theirs.

〈Halt〉
Whenever they ate, they ensured abundance, with the new and old sustaining one another. How could they forget this? Having received the people’s aid, they ensured the spirits bore no resentment. The good were repaid, each believing they should further provide for one another. Heaven willed it so; nothing could be hoarded, lest people suffer hunger and cold.

〈Rise〉
Thus, those with wealth were commanded to lend and aid the poor, exchanging the old for the new, enabling growth and prosperity to be passed to descendants. The spirits and deities would protect and assist them—was this not the great grace of universal bestowal?

〈Halt〉
Yet fools, lacking understanding, refused to repay or give thanks, assuming it their due. Their hearts grew unbalanced, and they seized others’ possessions to adorn themselves, lacking any thought of reciprocity or regard for hardship, believing they could live out their allotted years. Thus, this text was composed again.

Divine beings and perfected ones seek the good who can transmit these writings and apply their teachings. Such people may extend their lives, increase their longevity, and unite with Heaven and Earth, transforming into spirits. They may once more ride the clouds, traversing above and below, the center, and flowing to the six directions—is this not goodness itself?

Why not reflect deeply, keeping it within your heart? The divine abodes are where spirits dwell, ever observing human actions. Do not be self-righteous; know when you are at fault. You ought to serve and uphold one another, turning from misfortune toward blessings. Even minor deeds that displease Heaven’s will are unwise.

〈Rise〉
The gods of Heaven and Earth, the four seasons, the five phases, and the myriad spirits—along with the officials who record human destinies—how can they not be revered? Contemplate repaying their grace. Those who refuse to do good defy the celestial spirits. The celestial spirits then cause winds and rains to fall out of season, the qi of the seasons to shift unpredictably—what should be cold turns warm, what should be warm turns cold.

〈Halt〉
Sowing and planting no longer follow the proper times, and farmers grow resentful, unwilling to tend the land for others. They scorn all grains, feeding them instead to dogs and swine, and soon abandon the fields. In lands of virtue, harvests dwindle, trees wither and shed their leaves, and the people have no surplus grain. They turn on one another, plundering and contending for dominance, thinking only of victory. Forgetting the true sovereign, they become impoverished, reaping nothing, drifting as refugees. Before reaching the lands where grain is scorned, they collapse hungry by the roadside, dizzy and blinded, staggering wildly. Days pass without food, and they starve to death, unburied. No one in their households—young or old—escapes disaster. Yet they curse Heaven for their misfortune.

Their lands grow desolate, granaries empty, with little meat and no stored coin. Each year, conditions worsen, leaving nothing to offer the court. Exemptions multiply, storehouses yield no income, and the Minister of Agriculture holds only empty documents, unable to provide rations. Salaries are withheld, and the central lands lack resources. The people look to the state for aid, yet none is given. Thus, a time of suffering arises—all this is what Heaven abhors.

The earth cannot long sustain such corruption. Do the wicked not understand?

True ones, 〈rise〉 hasten to entrust this text to lands of virtue, 〈halt〉 urging each to examine themselves and awaken. Only then may they fulfill their allotted years. Those without understanding differ not from beasts. Longevity cannot be forcibly seized; it is attained through one’s own conduct, without resentment toward Heaven.

Ponder these writings carefully. Always cultivate filial piety, loyalty, trust, benevolence, and generosity. When you err, hold yourself accountable. Then you may have descendants, for these words are not empty.

In lands without virtue, Heaven offers no protection. The celestial mechanisms turn swiftly, and the sun and moon hasten, their light dimmed. In lands of virtue, the celestial mechanisms slow, and the sun and moon shine brightly. This is Heaven’s way. The mechanisms of Heaven, the sun, moon, and stars—all favor those who act with clarity. If their light wanes, it is the result of one’s own conduct. Whom can they blame?

All share the same Heaven and Earth, sun, moon, and stars. Those who witness Heaven’s retribution see its clarity. When the five planets stray from their courses, warfare rages unchecked, and barbarians invade from within. The land dispatches armies, and those with fate return; those without perish. This is the fault of great men.

When children are unfilial and the land lacks loyal ministers, when conduct is impure, mutual conflict arises, lasting until the year’s end.

Thus, this 〈rise〉 *Scripture of the Utmost Limit*, named the *Great Peace*, is bestowed. Those who practice it gain its blessings; those who do not bring ruin upon themselves. Gather your resolve, and your body will remain whole. Heaven’s retribution never wrongs the innocent; those who do not follow it inflict evil upon others.

It is said: No one, high or low, is not born of Heaven. The difference lies only in the records of destiny. Cherish this, be cautious, and take heed. Never do what you ought not, nor wrong others, nor seize what is not yours. Heaven does not reward such deeds; the earth does not nourish them. Malevolent spirits follow, and one cannot long enjoy life.

Those who neglect themselves should not hope for life. Their names are absent from the registers of immortality, yet they force their way into the halls of transcendents. They offer sacrifices to the spirits, seeking to be delivered as immortals. But when the immortal spirits consult the ledgers, they find no record of their names. Their prayers and offerings go unanswered, and the spirits grow angry.

They wander as beggars, offending the divine. 〈Halt〉 Wild beasts devour them, leaving only bones. Foxes gnaw their remains, and they never return home. Though they claim to neighbors and kin that they have attained transcendence, no sign confirms it. How can they prove it? By this, it is clear: only when there is manifest retribution, witnessed by all, can one be said to have ascended. Otherwise, they suffer punishment, their claims mere delusions. Such people are mad or deceived, yet they take it as truth. Together, they enter the realm of the dead, descending to the Yellow Springs, powerless to choose their fate.

Those destined for transcendence have their names recorded in the ledgers while alive. When their years are complete, messengers come to welcome them. How could the ignorant and unlearned attain such a fate? They waste their wealth, abandon their homes, and wander the wilds in vain. The Way naturally grants rank and destiny to each person; it cannot be forcibly sought.

Why torment yourself? Neglecting to care for parents, wife, and children—how can this be called wisdom? Fear only that you lack filial piety, loyalty, and trust. Then you may live out your years, and in the underworld, you will face no punishment, only peace. If you have surplus wealth and property, pass it to your children and grandchildren, ensuring they are provided for. Do not torment yourself. Whether your descendants are worthy or not, each lives their own life, without passing on suffering. This is virtuous conduct.

Thus, this text is recorded for the wise. Fools disregard it, indulging in reckless joy and anger. To avoid punishment and evade misfortune is the way of the worthy. If three admonitions go unheeded, it is best to desist.

Heaven aids the good and does not favor the wicked. Each must be cautious, refraining from mutual blame. Each must plan for themselves, acting with awareness. Let none transgress against Heaven or violate what is recorded in the ledgers. Do not forcibly demand what is not yours; such demands yield no benefit.

Why is this so? Heaven does not protect the rebellious and wicked. Do not abandon your homes or cities. Bones connect to form pathways, sinews govern the desire for life and fortify cities, vessels govern movement and form the body’s network, and flesh lies beneath the skin as the vessels’ covering. The spirit dwells within, overseeing human good and evil.

Why seek distant solutions? The seven regulators govern the gates of destiny. Seek the Way and attain life; do not abandon your homes. Transform and unite with the spirits in virtue. What more does the Way demand?

Thus, this virtuous text is placed in the celestial registers.

The registers of immortals differ from those of the common folk. When the time for ascension arrives, the spirits who oversee the registers and the guarantors come forth, for they know the domains they govern and the teachings they uphold. Each has their proper sequence; one must advance when it is time to depart, and may not act of one’s own accord. The host of spirits governs together, ensuring all aligns with the heart of Heaven.

Those who precede others in cultivation possess minds bright and perceptive, free from partiality. Their conduct and their lives remain unknown to others. They existed before Heaven and Earth, transforming above and below without ever straying from the Dao. The spirits do not fully manifest, yet they establish the guiding principles. The years and months extend in all directions, with attendants placed to left and right. The stars and constellations are distinct, each with its own overseer, all striving to advance loyalty and ensure the proper division of domains.

When one sees good, one should advance; when one sees evil, one should retreat. What room is there for doubt? Each acts by their own effort, and the spirits will not lead one astray. Thus, one may achieve completion and be called a Heavenly Lord. Those who govern Heaven keep meticulous records, never straying from the measure. The domain overseers and the host of spirits thus extend to the four directions.

Each direction has its *meng*, *zhong*, and *ji*, taking turns in ascending and descending order, known as the Great Year. The Great Yin follows behind, overseeing the patterns of the earth. The four seasons are also established, governing all that is born and completed. They dwell in the wilds, where grains and grasses grow early or late.

Those near do not live long, while those far endure. Yet even they may live long, and the trees of communal groves may flourish on their own. When dynasties change, punishment extends even to descendants. Why is this so? When one’s dwelling is unsettled, abandoning the old for the new, the spirits may return.

Each person has a life-tree born in the soil of Heaven, and each season has its appointed tree: in spring, the three months of life belong to the mulberry; in summer, to the jujube and plum; in autumn, to the catalpa and *geng*; in winter, to the locust and cypress. These are the trees of the common folk. Each has an official who oversees its tree. When one’s life nears its end, the tree is half-alive; when life ends, the tree withers and falls, and the overseeing official fells it. How then can the person live on? To seek long life and avoid death, one must transform one’s heart and will, transplanting one’s tree near the Gate of Heaven, where it is called the Tree of Longevity. The spirit-officials oversee it, keeping it pure, radiant, and lustrous, born of the place where Heaven’s own arise, guarded by spirits and honored with glory.

One need only preserve one’s name without blemish. Heaven has its eternal decree, and through generations, one is adorned with honor. Though one may not descend to protect, in time, one’s essence will naturally be known. Why is this so? Having departed far from the common, one must act in accordance with Heaven’s affairs, never faltering. The spirits examine one another as a carpenter’s line marks true. How could one act of one’s own will? Thus, one does not descend.

Do not find this strange. When merit is manifest, it is not equal to that of the common folk. Though others may see no benefit to their households, within, one is adorned with glory—is this not good? Thus, this is shown to later generations, that their hearts may awaken. If this text is revealed without proper concealment, there will be punishment in the year’s end.

Do not associate with the deceitful and flattering, nor make disobedience and irreverence your heart. All should act in accord with the text’s words, or face questioning and reproach. Can one not be cautious? Transmission must be to the right person, one who can be vouched for.

Do not violate the sacred texts, do not test the words of the spirits, and heed the spirits’ admonitions—all are repaid by Heaven. Do not take them lightly, for later there will be suffering. Minor transgressions bring only demotion, but grave faults cannot be saved. Thus, the spirits take turns reporting what is fitting to their superiors. Those who are not truthful will face judgment.

Matters must be interconnected, with no room for private interests. Thus, the spirits take turns examining and upholding one another. If one regrets later, what use is doubt? The middle path is also a point of examination. If one does not confess the truth, the examination will reveal it afterward, and one’s advancement or withdrawal will also be scrutinized. Otherwise, matters remain as before—this is what is meant.

One must not take these matters lightly, nor harbor doubt.

The laws of the spirits are of great weight, thus one must be cautious and deliberate, ponder and reflect upon them. The Dao of long life and enduring vitality—how could it not be held in reverence? Therefore, this text is set forth to instruct: those who fill vacancies shall perform good deeds, passing them down without fail or omission. For those who do good, merit accumulates and years extend—there is no room for doubt. The boundless nature of the natural Dao—when will it end? Yet upon awakening, one must govern in turn, for even the slightest misstep will invite suspicion.

Heaven delights in music to gladden the spirits, and the spirits, too, listen. Those who do good receive rewards, while those whose tones or melodies are discordant will also face judgment. Each has their own master; there can be no lack of origin or end. If incomplete, all draw from Heaven’s granaries and are clothed by the Minister of Agriculture. Cold and heat alternate, garments change—this too reflects the yang’s honor and the yin’s humility. Coarse and fine, all things from gold and silver to silks, pearls, and jade treasures are to be evenly distributed, with no arbitrary bestowals, granted only to those with merit. One must not receive Heaven’s clothing and food without merit.

As stated in previous texts, this is reiterated to prevent resentment and suspicion—such is the weight of Heaven’s command over the spirits. At year’s end, ledgers are reviewed and submitted. From mountains and seas to lands and waters, all shrines and communal altars report their receipts, ensuring nothing is lost or omitted. The guardians of dwellings observe the people’s transgressions, submitting monthly records. The Minister of Agriculture and the officials of the temples must then relay these documents in turn.

The Great Yin Legal Bureau calculates what one owes and subtracts the corresponding years. Once one’s allotted span is exhausted, the yin spirits of the earth and the local earth deities are summoned to reclaim the physical form and examine the hun and po souls. Detailed ledgers are prepared, verifying whether the records align. If discrepancies arise, the responsible parties are found to have engaged in deceit or favoritism, and punishments or demotions follow according to the severity of the offense. If the ledgers are not as Heaven commands, the spirits and numinous beings may not afflict people with illness. They must instead inspect and report one another, exposing transgressions.

For grave offenses, even death may be imposed, with demotions to labor on bridges, mountains, or seas, each according to the severity of the law, ensuring no omissions. Each locale—prefectures, counties, post stations—has its overseers and officials who must examine matters according to the law, ensuring no unjust harm befalls the spirits or numinous beings. Thus, from high to low, documents circulate in accordance with established decrees.

**On the Desire for Fine Clothing and Footwear (189)**
From ancient times to the present, each has their allotted domain, with ranks above and below, and proper channels for receiving and bestowing. If one adheres strictly to the guiding line, how could one fail to discern the distinction between life and death? Each must be vigilant, not offending the spirits, and fulfill their duties without neglecting their mandate. Record these matters: the good shall be promoted, the wicked demoted. In the convergence of fortune and misfortune, each receives what they desire. One may only follow, not defy. If one’s heart and intentions are impure, blaming the spirits’ messengers, the consequences are self-inflicted—whom else could one resent?

Some are difficult to transform, knowing their own deficiencies, yet still suffer calamity. Their perverse actions exceed all bounds, yet they boast endlessly. In their comings and goings, they lack foresight, seeing only what is before them and disregarding what follows, inviting disaster and severing affection. They slander and revile the good, as if Heaven had perished above and Earth ceased below, unaware of the spirits. Those who record such matters may resolve others’ grudges by offering abundant wine and meat, indulging in sweetness and self-gratification. At the time, it may seem acceptable, but later, they are spoken of with scorn—light words, curses, and vile imprecations, deceit, slander, and the abduction of others’ wives. Day and night, they lie in wait to seize opportunities, selling them for their own sustenance. Coveting fine clothing and footwear, they vie in contention and argument, disregarding reason in their pursuit of livelihood—how could such a life endure?

Fools become notorious villains. When officials learn of them, subordinates are dispatched to seize and swiftly punish them, bringing disaster upon both kin and strangers, all sharing in the blame. The poor should rely on their own efforts, not idly fold their hands. These are the records of one’s life, the endowment one receives at birth. Evil spirits follow them—how could they remain long? Such people are many, and their fates intertwine without cease. Thus, it is said: seized by evil spirits, even a slight lapse in vigilance leads to ruin. If one does not restrain oneself, evil cannot be averted, and one incurs the resentment of others. At the time, it may seem acceptable, but one does not consider the consequences. Heed the warnings and desist. One may yet live a little longer, exhausting the remainder of one’s allotted span.

There are records of good and evil, the origins of longevity, and the appointed time for extending one’s years—one must do good. Those who do not see the worthies and sages are deficient in wisdom. Cherishing life and dreading death, even immortals and transcendent beings may extend their years. Why abandon the world, inviting misfortune to flow from birth? Even the child in the womb declares, “I am born of the same parents.” Yet they blame Heaven and curse Earth, claiming evil should be separate, not mingled—pure and turbid divided, like lord and servant. Thus, those who practice the great Dao live, while those who do not become dust. This has been so from ancient times to the present. There are both good and evil, passed down through generations without end—only varying in degree.

Heaven knows of much defiance, hence this text is issued to emphasize the point. After understanding the warnings, there should be no doubt. Ten or a hundred correspond—when could one escape? Those who do not forget the admonitions will long receive the secret of blessings.

**The Secret of Long-Lasting Blessings (190)**
At the beginning, Heaven and Earth arose from the primordial origin, forming the spiritual essence. Following the natural order, all that is created and transformed attains glory. With the establishment of divisions, the sun, moon, and stars, the celestial mechanisms and their overseers, the five planets are each assigned their directions and duties. Clouds and rain are distributed, the people’s concerns and the Minister of Agriculture’s affairs are managed. The primordial qi gathers and lingers, and all grains, plants, and creatures—those that crawl, breathe, or wriggle—contain the primordial qi. Flying birds, walking beasts, and those born in water are the same, enabling the people to use them in sacrifices and for their own sustenance.

Only those that cause harm are taken for personal use. Oxen, horses, mules, and donkeys unfit for service are provided for the world. Even the earth deities have surplus, gathered to share and consume. Do not kill those fit for use or the young—this is Heaven’s decree, what the spirits and numinous beings revere.

〈Thus begins〉
The myriad people, foolish and reckless, indulge in wanton killing and harm. Some slaughter creatures still in the womb, turning life to death—this severs the thread of destiny to feed human mouths. At the moment of death, all tremble in terror, knowing they will not live. Therefore, Heaven in its sincerity pities and compassionately enacts prohibitions, punishing those who violate them. Even the six domestic animals shun wanton cruelty, unable to bear injury inflicted midlife—yet humans, who should cherish themselves, instead act as bandits and plunderers. Their predations are manifold, wielding blades to kill without consequence. Though not immediately executed, Heaven accumulates their transgressions; their slaughter and ruin never cease. Those who perish before birth or whose corpses drift downstream—none of these will encounter fortune. Ghosts and spirits despise them, and the overseers stand before them—when could they ever escape?

Thus, good and evil are recorded and weighed, that one might avoid transgression. Divine beings and perfected ones reveal this text to the people, its meaning unhidden, so they may not blame themselves. Hence, it follows custom in its script, making all clear.
〈Thus ends〉

One may know that the sagely and wise do not transgress, while the foolish do not cease. Teachers have their predecessors and successors—let none forget their roots. Cherish the root to embrace the new, longing as in the beginning: this is the Way of life. Merits may be great or small, and what one receives differs accordingly. One must awaken to the secrets of the unknown, the intentions of the unknown, the thoughts of the unknown, the words of the unknown, the aspirations of the unknown—when these two are made clear, it is Heaven’s intent. The Way of life and completion emerges from this.
〈Thus begins〉

Gain trust from Heaven, gain trust from Earth, gain trust from the Center and Harmony, gain trust from the four seasons, gain trust from the five phases—all these are the rewards Heaven bestows for trust. Not a fraction is lost—do you not understand? This is the transformation wrought by the formless, self-so qi. Thus, the Three Terraces and Seven Stars assist in rectifying Heaven’s majesty. The sun and moon illuminate right and wrong, enabling the natural order, so that none may later regret. Therefore, Heaven again commands all overseers under its jurisdiction, each to make their duties clear, to accept punishment without resentment—this is the meaning.

〈Thus ends〉
Let none impose right and wrong, for others will rectify it themselves. No warning is too great or small to serve as a model. Heed these words, and you will long receive fortune—act with care, never losing restraint. Thus, words are tested by self-sacrifice. When texts remain unused, emperors and kings do not believe. Flatterers at their side prevent the texts from being understood.
〈Thus begins〉

When disasters and calamities arise together, where can the people turn? The *Scripture of Great Peace* will not be understood again for three *jiazi* cycles—better to admonish ten times so they may know. Strive to seek understanding, for the worthy and sagely may yet attain it. The sage should promote the worthy, then seek life for themselves, not despising those who follow. The register of divine transcendents lies at the North Pole, linked to Kunlun. Within Kunlun’s ruins dwell the perfected ones, who ascend and descend by constant rule. The perfected ones oversee those recorded in the registers, their names listed in order. The exalted attain the exalted, the middling the middling, the lowly the lowly—none grovel or beg. The first to teach is called master, honored as lord, revered as father. Thus, master, lord, and father must not be unclear; ministers must not be disloyal; disciples must not be disobedient. Respect and follow your superiors, and this reverence will ascend. Thus, Heaven does not forget the master’s kindness, Earth does not forget the master’s nurturing, and people do not forget the master’s teaching.
〈Thus ends〉

Thus, those who possess loyalty, filial piety, and trust think of life without malice, drawing near to clarify themselves. Heaven’s light shines down to the Yellow Springs below; Earth’s light shines up to the space between the heavens. The light of the Center and Harmony unites above and below. Thus, the Three Lights converge and harmonize.
〈Thus begins〉

Heaven names the Three Lights as the sun, moon, and stars, which shine down upon the Center and Harmony and the depths of Earth without ceasing. In nations lacking virtue, yin qi obscures the sun, rendering it lightless. The people live in fear, grains grow scarce, water and drought strike unpredictably, and the people flee as refugees to lands with grain. Heaven pities them, guiding them to live in enlightened lands where a wise ruler brings prosperity. The refugees return to cultivate abandoned fields, and all grains are sown. Once they ripen and the people regain their sustenance, they again honor their ancestors, and the ghosts and spirits find peace. Among them are the sagely and wise who seek divine transcendents, whose names are recorded in registers and ledgers. They will ascend to become Heaven’s officials, patrolling among the people, harmonizing wind and rain, and bringing stable governance. This text is shown to later generations. Thus, one must do good to benefit Heaven. From this point onward, admonish your descendants—may they attain longevity. Though the text is weighty, Heaven deeply loves humanity and wishes them to complete their years. Its repeated exhortations are entrusted to the spirits. Good deeds are promptly recorded above, while evil erases one’s name. Do not defy this text; reflect on goodness with an 〈unbroken〉 mind, and always nurture the aspiration for life. The reason is that human aspirations must be fulfilled—strive with diligence, each according to their wish, for Heaven neither forces nor rejects. Earth extends horizontally in all four directions, and so do the boundless heavens, the boundless earth, and the boundless realms. So too are the boundless light and boundless radiance. Yet even the smallest completion is Heaven’s great division. To govern and reflect on Heaven’s affairs, Heaven governs and reflects on the Center and Harmony, and the Center and Harmony stabilizes them. To seek nobility, the spirits of nobility honor it. To seek wealth, the spirits of wealth enrich it. Between suffering and joy, always reflect carefully on your words. Heaven’s Dao is vast and myriad—it lies in human action and does not override human wishes. The Way of life and nurturing is clear to see; the Way of death is what ghosts dread. Malevolent spirits are unsettled and immediately bring calamity—this text cannot describe it.
〈Thus begins〉

In Heaven there is a text, the root of seeking life. It is what humans desire, so this text is revealed to inspire reflection.

Should one commit transgressions and repent, consult this text. If not, then desist—speak no reckless words. The divine spirits stand before and behind you at all times, without respite.

〈End〉

〈Beginning〉 The *Scripture of Great Peace* bestows prosperity upon the state, subdues rebellion, and illuminates the teachings of former sages and worthies. The Dao of Heaven and Earth rejoices, and the spirits emerge to aid in governance, granting longevity to the people and repelling the barbarians of the four directions. 〈End〉

*Collated and Combined Scroll 113 of the Geng Section, Volume 113 of the Scripture of Great Peace*
*Chapter 191: The Formula of Joy, Anger, Fortune, and Misfortune*

〈Beginning〉 When the qi of Great Peace arrives in full, the people should daily face one another in leisure, ever equipped with musical instruments as their constant practice. Through harmonious tuning, they transform one another, benefiting the state above. This harmonizes the celestial qi, perpetually delighting the state with longevity, while the world is enveloped in its virtue and teaching, free from fault.

How is it made clear whether joy is attained or not? How is the effect of harmony or disharmony demonstrated? 〈End〉

Desiring not to trouble the Celestial Master with exhaustive inquiry, yet fearing superficiality and omissions, I have repeatedly asked these questions, daring not to slacken, lest Heaven grow angry.

〈Beginning〉 Excellent! You inquire on Heaven’s behalf, daily refining your understanding and aligning with Heaven’s intent. The Perfected One shall surely gain boundless years and longevity, for Heaven protects you. Very well, be seated, and I shall once more expound its meaning in full for all disciples, making it clear and knowable.

Joy, when modestly equipped and modestly realized, delights the people. When moderately equipped and moderately realized, it delights governance. When fully equipped and fully realized, it delights Heaven and Earth.

Those who attain the method of delighting the people bring joy to humanity. Those who attain the method of delighting governance bring peace to governance. Those who attain the method of delighting Heaven and Earth bring harmony to Heaven and Earth. When Heaven and Earth are harmonious, all things remain free from illness, and the host of spirits perpetually rejoice, never growing angry.

〈Attached Note〉 Those who align with the intent of Heaven and Earth harmonize them, and humanity, following their example, finds joy. When Heaven, Earth, and humanity are harmonious and joyful, the myriad things suffer no illness, and ruler and minister perpetually rejoice.

〈Beginning〉 This is the joy of the arrival of the true qi of Great Peace, fully realized through music.

Thus, when music attains the great *jue* and upper *jue* tones, the Green Emperor rejoices greatly, and the virtue of benevolence and the Dao emerge. All things delight in life, the Green Emperor sets forth on his journey, and the qi of the liver remains free from illness. The spirit and essence of the liver manifest, appearing in the eastern direction and its kind. The malign is entirely dispelled, while the good all advance to aid transformation. Azure-clad jade maidens bearing wondrous prescriptions descend to bestow them upon humanity—this is the clear proof.

Perfected One, ponder this meaning deeply. 〈End〉

"Yes, yes."

Thus, when the upper *jue* tone is attained, transformation occurs above; when the middle *jue* tone is attained, transformation occurs in the middle; when the lower *jue* tone is attained, transformation occurs below. And through their attainment, transformation is achieved.

When the *zhi* tones of the south—great, small, and middle—are all in harmony, all things delight in growth. In the southern direction, virtue and the Dao know no joy unshared; the malign is dispelled, and the good all advance. The red qi rejoices entirely, the red spirit comes forth on its journey, and the heart remains free from illness. The heart’s spirit emerges and appears, awaiting the arrival of the crimson-clad jade maidens, who come to bestow wondrous prescriptions upon humanity—this is its great proof.

Thus, when the harmony of the yellow qi’s *gong* tone is attained, the good of the *gong* tone also all arrive, while the malign is entirely dissolved. When the harmony of the *shang* tone is attained, the good of the *shang* tone all arrive, while the malign is entirely dissolved. When the harmony of the *yu* tone is attained, the good of the *yu* tone all arrive, while the malign all depart.

Perfected One, ponder deeply the essential meaning of what brings forth these effects and their fundamental practices. The reason I do not exhaustively expound on the five directions is that their profundity is vast. The superior scholar, upon seeing this, naturally grasps its meaning, using the one to embrace the ten thousand; the middling scholar, upon attaining it, must guard against excessive joy.

When the inferior person obtains it, they may speak recklessly. Thus, I do not fully reveal it, allowing ordinary people to each contemplate its meaning. The superior scholar, with the one embracing the ten thousand, naturally comprehends its essence and needs no exhaustive explanation. The middling scholar, gradually nearing understanding, also requires no exhaustive explanation. The inferior scholar, if they obtain it, may speak recklessly—likewise, no exhaustive explanation is needed.

Therefore, I cautiously shape my words, briefly outlining the essential principles to reveal the matter, guiding ordinary people to each reflect on its meaning. In this way, understanding may flow freely from high to low without error. Perfected One, do you grasp this?

"Yes, indeed."

Thus, the superior scholar governs music to enact non-action and transcend the world. The middling scholar governs music to harmonize and regulate the common people. The inferior scholar governs music merely to entertain others and secure sustenance. These three types each follow their own intentions. When the qi of Great Peace arrives, let them act as they will, allowing them their instruments—lutes and zithers—taking care not to forbid them. If music’s qi is suppressed, governance becomes difficult to pacify. When governance is difficult to pacify, qi contends and disputes arise, leading to excessive punishments.

Music brings joy, while punishments bring suffering—like echo and shadow, not a hair’s breadth is amiss. Music is meant to quell anger, while anger is meant to quell music. These two oppose each other: thus, when music prevails, anger ceases; when anger prevails, music ceases. Anger gives rise to punishments and is the root of conflict, while joy and music are the gateway to virtue and the Dao. Therefore, one should follow this path to cultivate the root of virtue and the Dao, not suppress it. Suppression, instead, opens the door to punishment and misfortune. Here lies the source of fortune and misfortune, the rise of safety and peril.

Music belongs to yang; punishments belong to yin. Yin and yang are inherently opposed: when yang flourishes, yin wanes; when yin flourishes, yang wanes. Yang is the ruler; yin is the minister. When the ruler is strong, the minister submits, and the people are easily governed. When the minister is strong, the ruler is humiliated and order collapses. This is the natural law of Heaven.

Therefore, one should follow the ruler’s music to subdue the people and ministers, curbing their frequent anger. The people of later ages are foolish and do not deeply understand this principle, instead often cutting it off. Thus, yin qi flourishes while yang qi declines. When yin qi flourishes, thieves and criminals abound unceasingly. All things fail to thrive, often harmed by yin—this is the great fault. When the qi of music flourishes, yang qi prevails, severing this harm. When the ruler’s qi is strong, it brings extended years and prolonged life; when suppressed, it leads to premature aging.

Leisure and music belong to Heaven above; haste, anger, and punishments belong to Earth below. When the upper path is followed, all affairs are ordered; when the lower path is followed, all affairs descend into chaos.

"True Person, take heed—can these words not be deeply pondered?"
"Indeed, indeed."
"You may be said to have grasped them profoundly. Transmit them to enlighten the people of later ages, that each may reflect upon their meaning and take care never to obstruct or sever them. When music arises, the virtues and powers of the five directions all emerge; when anger arises, the evils of the five directions all emerge. When there is music, the virtues and powers of Heaven and Earth all emerge; when there is anger, the evils of Heaven and Earth all emerge. Thus, when Heaven and Earth are joyful, good responses arise; when Heaven and Earth are not joyful, evil responses arise. When the five directions are joyful and harmonious, good responses from the five directions arise; when the five directions are not joyful but angry, evil responses from the five directions arise. This is no small matter—thus it is said: do not sever it. Let all people together contemplate its meaning, all awakening to it as one, so that the qi of joy and music arrives, and the qi of haste and anger departs."
"Excellent! Excellent!"
"Go forth—you have understood it well."

Here follows the translation:

---

**Right [Section]: Heaven’s Supreme Distinction of Joy and Anger as the Source of Fortune and Misfortune**
*Collated and Combined Text of the* Classic of Great Peace, *Volume 114, Geng Section XII*
*Classic of Great Peace, Volume 114*
*Certain Formula 192*

According to the Dunhuang catalog, this should be *Filial Conduct Revered by Spirits, Formula 192*. The preceding text was originally missing.

When one suffers illness or hardship, the heart grieves deeply; bowing before the physician, one amends with words of filial piety. Serving with reverence and respect, one offers up all that the household possesses. Addressing the physician with honor, the healer, seeing this, holds the person in esteem. One spares no effort in seeking true, fresh, and fine medicines, apportioning grains by their proper divisions so that the physician may be summoned to bring relief. Constantly shedding tears, one speaks, confessing faults before Heaven, striking one’s breast to beg for mercy, kowtowing to the earth without shunning tiles, stones, or mud.

Thus, one secures the peace and safety of one’s parents, teaching sons and daughters-in-law always to remain at their elders’ side, preparing rich, sweet, and delicate foods, allowing them to eat whatever their mouths desire. When parents manage the household, if anything is lacking, one grieves for one’s children and grandchildren, exhausting all the household possesses, displaying utmost filial devotion before them. Relatives and neighbors, witnessing such filial goodness and knowing there is nothing left to give, come forth to provide further provisions, calling for physicians and spreading mats for them, together laboring day and night. They inquire after the parents’ well-being, tending to their needs, and upon hearing even the slightest word of kindness, their hearts rejoice—this is the result of filial piety.

Heaven, seeing such a filial heart, grants recovery, restoring health as before, and the heart rejoices anew. When the body is once more able to consume grains, one fasts and sells goods, offering up all possessions to Heaven, returning thanks to the ancestors. For all blessings received, one burns pure incense, never daring to break one’s word—such is the conduct proper to a filial child.

The world hears of such goodness yet cannot practice it; those who can are naturally so by nature. Heaven endows their fate, causing them to be filial and good, passing this virtue down through generations. Their livelihood improves, they do not encroach upon others, and they benefit their kin. In marriages and neighborly relations, filial ones receive recompense, never forgetting kindness—such is the excellence of this Way.

The years of one’s parents cannot be foreknown. One prepares in advance, reducing minor expenses, ensuring yearly surplus, storing it in unseen places, never letting officials high or low learn of it. When levies and requisitions come, depleting all one’s wealth, yet the heart of filial devotion remains unfulfilled, and nothing more remains to give—when the parents’ years come to an end, there is nothing to offer in farewell, and the intent of filial piety remains incomplete.

Those who practice filial piety contemplate the completion of their work. When merit is manifest and name ascends to the Supreme, reaching the imperial court, and local authorities recommend them, in a single day they are honored—is this not the result of filial piety? Descendants inherit this, and it may continue for boundless generations. This remembrance of kindness is never forgotten, and Heaven deems it good. Heaven sends benevolent spirits to constantly guard and protect—this too is the result of filial piety.

In such a household, one member may attain long life and transcend the world. Later generations revere them, free from calamity, each completing their years without premature death—is this not goodness? From such goodness, what is not accomplished? What is not achieved? What is not obtained? What is not made smooth?

Strive to practice this, never growing weary or lax. Such is the fortune of the good.

The filial and good are not encroached upon by others; should anyone encroach upon the filial and good, Heaven will punish them. This is evident before one’s eyes—thus it is known. To know goodness as goodness and filial piety as filial piety, yet find it bitter to emulate—this arises naturally.

Heaven bestows the register of the good; goodness and filial piety transmit themselves, surpassing and recommending one another without limit. The filial and good are naturally revered by others, and they do not offend or harm people. Their reputation spreads to the eight distant regions, and when vacancies arise among prefectural and county officials, the filial and good households are known in advance. The county recommends them, and local officials, desiring to hear of their filial goodness, send messengers to inquire and comfort them. Those who take it to heart visit in person, learning of their conduct and recommending them. Year after year, they are honored, wearing tokens of high virtue, their descendants carrying on the tradition. Their household is known as one of transmitted filial piety, free from evil people.

Not only do they practice filial piety at home, but it extends within and without. As officials, they are filial to their lord, increasing their loyalty and sincerity, always holding high office, filial to the court. When prefectures and counties produce rare and counterfeit goods, they use their own wealth to purchase the finest, sparing the people from trouble and labor. When prefectures and counties are filled with kindness and filial piety, the five grains flourish, and no one dies prematurely. Heaven harmonizes wind and rain for them, making the seasons timely.

Such are the filial and good of Heaven above, spared from disaster. The people follow their example, all nurturing hearts of obedience, and Heaven does not oppose them. This goodness is most good, this filial loyalty most filial—thus it is perfected. It causes the unfilial throughout the world to emulate, setting forth the intent of filial piety.

When a great mandate grants amnesty to the world, all transgressions that should not be committed are absolved. Together with the filial, the fraternal, and those who labor in the fields, they are bestowed with silks, wine, and meat. Officials pay their respects, making their filial conduct known so that others may witness it. Those who see it, if they have hearts, may advance in love; if they have good intent, they may love one another—this is the grace of the world, making the people compliant.

This is goodness begetting goodness, filial piety begetting filial piety; those unfilial in origin remain unfilial in the end, and evil in origin remains evil in the end. The good have their wishes fulfilled, living to white-haired old age. Some reach one hundred and twenty years, others over a hundred—this is the result of goodness and filial piety, not mere empty words.

Not only does Heaven love them, but the four seasons, the five phases, the sun, moon, and stars all favor them, shining upon them so they do not encounter misfortune. Such is their goodness—can it not be esteemed?

Heaven creates the people, yet few can be good and filial. Those who do so alone enjoy long life.

---

Those who attain high office do so through the practice of filial piety. This is not mere empty assurance—thus this scripture is revealed to instruct the living. Those who follow its model shall be granted longevity and transmission, their descendants safeguarded. Once this text is disseminated, filial piety must be practiced. Those who transcend the world through filial devotion may further aspire to ranks and titles.

Of all affairs under Heaven, filial piety is foremost, surpassing what most can attain. Through accumulated merit and layered conduct, past and present align without loss. Those whose names are reborn among men inherit their parents’ grace and behold the teachings of filial reverence. Heaven inscribes their registry, placing them among the undying—such is the household of filial piety. They may further attain transcendence, performing celestial duties above, recording loyalty and filial devotion in revered texts, assuming heavenly offices where honor and favor grow daily.

In Heaven, they are named "Filial and Virtuous Divine Beings," revered by all spirits. Their offerings of finest food ascend first, their filial deeds enduring—none compare. Their longevity knows no limit, their radiance ever-increasing. Above, they behold the boundless heavens; below, the boundless earth; in all directions, they traverse boundless realms. They foresee events yet to come, and all spirits heed their commands, never opposing their will, jointly recommending and proclaiming them.

The Supreme Lord, witnessing their unmatched filial conduct, draws them near, both within and without, where gods hold them in ever-greater esteem. Thus it is said: what Heaven loves, all spirits honor; what Heaven detests, all spirits endanger. This is known—let each apply their own discernment, choosing what is fitting and following what is proper.

The scripture’s words now pause, yet its later teachings must be heeded. When goodness is attained, it shall be revealed again, ensuring nothing is omitted.

**The Supreme Lord’s Personal Instructions, Scroll One Hundred Ninety-Three**

Only the Supreme Lord possesses statutes, illuminating and penetrating all, knowing all without obstruction, foreseeing events yet to unfold. Before spirits speak, He already knows their intent; before gods appear, He already perceives—none dare deceive or distort, for all is clear and evident. How could the words of the Supreme Lord fail to move all? Yet men revere in word alone, their hearts not fully devoted. Thus, their intentions remain unilluminated.

The reason is this: the Supreme Lord is wholly divine, governing all generation and transformation, determining life and vitality—all is known. The divine registry follows in order, distinguishing rank and dignity—who would dare disobey? Above the Nine August Ones stand the Nine Lords, who are the intimates of the Supreme Lord. Each has their own conduct, bestowing grace and benevolence, and all spirits follow, revering their deeds, none failing to comply.

Lesser spirits cannot fathom the intent of the Nine August Ones—how much less can worldly men? With sagacious minds and keen ears, one may observe their literary compositions and celestial decrees. When the registry’s words are directly recorded, radiance naturally arises. All are inscribed on golden tablets, their texts wrought in silver. This ledger resides within the Heavenly Lord’s inner chamber, its duplicate stored in the Central Ultimate. Other departmental documents are likewise submitted on jade slips, their texts self-generating, their essence following the characters—named "Luminous Radiance."

Whenever speech is uttered, it instantly illuminates all that is known, never contradicting what is said. When divine beings and perfected ones receive the Heavenly Lord’s words, they fully proclaim them, and spirits above and below all know the affairs of the mortal realm. The Heavenly Lord knows the spirits’ words, never deviating from the bounds of written rules. This is the natural Dao—what is unknown? What cannot be transformed? All actions and movements are free from partiality.

They partake of the celestial kitchen’s fare and wear garments of refined essence—what more could they seek? Such is the conduct of the Supreme Lord. Great and minor spirits each have their own duties, all mutually reverent, none daring to act selfishly. They freely observe those who seek, discerning the intentions of the earnest, knowing what can be achieved, ensuring no confusion clouds their purpose, so each may follow their deepest aspirations.

It is said: you shall all receive the immortal register, attaining boundless longevity. With sashes of purple scripted in gold and silver, you shall be enfeoffed as marquises with domains, further granted silks, gold, silver, pearls, and jade—whatever your heart desires. Is this not the Dao of immortality? Does it not discern whether a person is steadfast or not? Some are bestowed with the likeness of beauties and jade maidens, who serve them with pleasing appearances and convenience, their resolve unwavering. Others command great and small apparitions, their forms shifting, their thoughts following the practitioner’s intentions for future lives—this is the path of incompletion.

Some are placed in deep mountains and vast valleys, among beasts, tigers, and wolves, or in deep waters to test their resolve. Others encounter venomous creatures, compelling them to slay. Some fear ascending high mountains, entering deep valleys, or plunging into deep waters—thus their Dao remains unfulfilled. These apparitions warn the practitioner, for only those who remain steadfast in adversity, whose resolve does not waver amid delusion, who traverse mountains, valleys, and deep waters without fear, who behold beauty yet do not covet, who see family and kin yet are not detained—only they attain the path of life.

Advancing to behold the Supreme Lord, they offer utmost loyalty and filial devotion, unconcerned with worldly attachments—this is the way to completion. Let this admonish the multitude, that they may grasp its essential teachings. Heaven too trusts the good, enabling spirits and immortals to deliver them. If the person is inherently good, how could Heaven deceive them? Those who are deceived do so through their own doubt, forcibly demanding the useless trappings of immortality, seeking ease without merit—how could they not be deceived?

Heaven cherishes life, loving sincerity and unwavering resolve, emphasizing the Three Illuminations as essential. The Three Illuminations are the heart, which governs the Hall of Light, channeling the radiance of sun and moon—this is the completion of the Dao through the Three Illuminations. The heart’s resolve must remain unshaken, for there are records and decrees that cannot be forcibly sought. Those who ascend to Heaven in broad daylight possess their own authenticity. Their nature is inherently good, their hearts inherently luminous.

When admonitions stir the will, it does not incline toward evil; wealth and profit are disregarded; garments are coarse, barely covering the body—such is the conduct of those who ascend to Heaven.

Heaven cherishes their goodness, thus commanding benevolent spirits to follow and protect them, preventing them from encountering evil. The celestial gods favor them, enabling them to fulfill their merit. This arises from their conduct—such a person does not covet the vast wealth of the mundane world. Heaven recognizes their utmost sincerity, verifying their names in the celestial registers as true, and they naturally possess auspicious stars. From the moment of their birth, they refrain from evil. Heaven further approves of them, transforming their greed to assist the Heavenly Lord in governance. Their celestial documents and decrees are transmitted with clarity, their actions free from selfish concealment. Their years of practice are recorded, their names inscribed in the register of honor—this accords with the will of the Most High. They can expound upon their merits and deeds, aiding where others fall short, and thus the gods duly shelter and protect them. Heaven trusts those who are filial, sincere in goodness, and whose conduct is without flaw or blemish. Therefore, at broad daylight, they are received with welcome, their presence radiant before and behind, witnessed by all people—this is the fruition of their merit, allowing others to behold their virtue.

Among those who ascend in daylight, not one in a million attains this. Those who do are greatly protected and trusted by the celestial gods. Others cannot compare. As for those who achieve liberation through *shijie*, only one in a million emerges. Though their merits differ in magnitude, they recommend and commend one another, and such a person is cherished and esteemed by Heaven. Internally, they gain the trust of the Most High, who recommends them as proven and effective, each fulfilling their merit and renown—how could this be evil?

When the Heavenly Lord issues teachings, the gods do not distort his words. The Heavenly Lord, having received their proven sincerity, knows what is yet to come and permits not even a hair’s breadth of deception. All are granted longevity, even if only briefly, and those who achieve minor liberation later reflect upon their unfinished words, further contemplating the Dao.

**Admonition One Hundred Ninety-Four: On the Impossibility of Long Life for the Unfilial**
From ancient times to the present, the world has been filled with those who fail to meet expectations. If one merely seeks self-satisfaction without loyal devotion to duty...

Those who speak and teach delight in nothing extraordinary; when they see others doing good, they smile and speak—yet what benefit does this bring? Their words are careless and reckless, deceiving even father and son. They remain silent to one’s face, then depart and speak behind their backs, their words now good, now evil, offering no model to follow, no benefit to the world. The world is but dust and grime, their speech flowing unchecked, with none to record their good deeds. Their hearts claim virtue, yet their actions do not match; they lack steadfastness, their words drifting like flotsam, unworthy of trust. Such are the reckless—how can they endure? How can they be ranked with those of good heart and resolve?

Those who seek life and dread death wish not to see such wicked men, yet fail to recognize their own nature, boasting of their vigor, believing few can surpass them. They lie in wait day and night to seize wealth without merit, yet do not toil for it, imagining they may long abide in harmony, speaking freely among others. Those nearby witness this and reproach their words. The spirits hear and observe their every move, knowing their hearts’ wickedness, that they cannot long remain good, and report back to the heavenly gods: *"Within the harmony of the world dwells one of reckless speech and facile words, who cannot long remain good. In but a moment, their evil words resurface, devoid of trust or efficacy. They merely flatter and deceive—what benefit do they bring to others?"*

They are granted the grains to eat and silks to wear, changing garments with winter and summer, seeking food that pleases the palate and clothes that comfort the body. Though markets offer profitable ventures, they refuse to pursue them, yet claim to support aged parents. At dawn, they rise from bed, not knowing where they go. They peddle all they possess, shifting between host and guest, lounging in taverns with legs splayed, jesting and laughing, singing and dancing, making merry, boasting of their strength. They huddle together, whispering, spreading gossip and slander. Their wealth exhausted, they have nothing left to sustain themselves; bound in wickedness, they become villains, unrestrained, abandoning themselves to evil—how could they know even half a day of goodness?

Their actions bring no benefit to their households, only sorrow and poison to their parents, siblings, wives, and children, who are ever burdened with worry, finding no relief. Their plunder and theft know no end; though they see their hair turn white, they remain unaware that the spirits sent by Heaven watch at their side, enter their bodies, and hasten their deeds. They are made to meet misfortune, their years cut short—they cannot be allowed to endure. Their clamor for evil will not cease. Should their crimes reach the authorities, they will be seized and justly punished, denied long life. Death will claim them—how can they live again? Some may even be harmed by ghosts and spirits.

Parents think of them, ever seeing them weep alone in solitary vigil, with none to aid or support. In old age, they are abandoned and discarded, their food foul and meager, rarely tasting anything rich or fine. Their clothes and shoes are worn through, with none to mend them. Such is the extremity of evil—years and months pass, emptiness endures, their faces grow hideous, bearing no semblance of human countenance.

As sons of this kind, they leave their parents in old age with no one to rely upon, and even their kin refuse to acknowledge them. This is the utmost destruction wrought by the conduct of the wicked. Their kin suffer for it, and their name is shrouded in obscurity. When such a son dies, he is not given a proper burial; lacking shroud or coffin, he is simply buried. Foxes and jackals devour him, his bones cast into the wilderness—when shall he ever again know the comforts of clothing and food?

Thus the consequences of good and evil are plain to see: man brings them upon himself. Whom can he blame? How profoundly foolish are the people of the world, failing to consider the vast gulf between life and death! While alive, one possesses qi and beholds the radiance of Heaven and Earth, the sun, moon, and stars. But in death, can one ever again know the light of Heaven? In that dark and obscure realm, when shall there be light?

Fools do not ponder deeply, bringing calamity upon their descendants, disasters beyond remedy, misfortunes that flow to future generations—whose fault is this? If men do not reform, they bring about their own untimely demise. Should they not follow the Way of the virtuous and the immortals? In their actions and words, they ought to adhere to principle, bringing benefit to their parents, ensuring they are well-fed and clothed, their faces glowing with health.

Such is the conduct of a filial son, whose strength is not that of an evil man. Should he not repay the debt of his parents’ nurturing care? To be an unfilial son—when you have children, will they be filial to you? Good begets good, evil begets evil, like a mirror reflecting a person. Can you truly be ignorant of this truth?

Thus the records of good and evil share the same script, yet the difference between long life and early death—how vast is it? A living person may endure for a span of years, but when their allotted time is spent, they perish and become a ghost, no longer subject to reckoning. The wicked die young, and in the underworld, they are seized and punished, held accountable for their misdeeds. They suffer in their place of torment, never knowing joy. As ghosts, when shall they ever know reprieve?

Such is the extremity of evil: even as ghosts, they remain wicked, with nowhere to turn. Their families lack food, and they must beg for sustenance, pursued by the qi of debt and ruin, unable to endure. The underworld, too, desires good ghosts and rejects the evil. Thus, each should reflect upon goodness, not losing their proper measure—this alone suffices. Otherwise, what hope remains?

People ought to share a common purpose, aligning their wishes with life. Does Heaven not favor goodness? Why then do they turn to evil? The conduct of the wicked cannot long endure beneath the sun, moon, and stars. Thus, they are hidden away in the underworld, denied the company of good ghosts and the joy of distinction.

Where the text repeats itself, it is because Heaven truly detests the wicked and will not suffer them to live long. Those of good nature are protected by Heaven. Their descendants are born with goodness, free from taboos, born under auspicious stars and the radiance of the sun and moon. How can they not enjoy long life? Such is the reward of virtuous conduct.

In the discernment of good and evil, one may follow what brings peace. Heaven does not oppose the deeds of men. Reflect again and again, ponder deeply—whether to advance or retreat, if one does not cling to life, there is nothing to be done. The words of the text are clear; examine them closely.

Let your suffering reach its limit, yet do not grow weary of life. Be cautious in your speech. Though the words may briefly pause, let them linger in your thoughts. If they do not satisfy, reconsider them.

**Admonition Against Transgressing Evil Precepts, One Hundred and Ninety-Five**

Now, those of sagely virtue each have their words, each their speech. They distinguish their abilities, rank their merits, and accomplish what is fitting, so that their teachings may be trusted and the words of Heaven revered. Heaven loves humanity and bestows great merit, winning the heart of Heaven—this is the aspiration of sagely virtue.

All people wish to align with Heaven, to grasp its intent, and harbor no resentment. Thus, each is allowed to follow their will, without falsehood, for this is how one gains the favor of others, ensuring that trust and understanding are reciprocated, and that all follow what is fitting.

To live in this world is no easy matter. In every action, one must heed what is said, never straying from the proper path. Yet some do not reproach themselves and instead resent the words of others—this is unjust conduct. Each harbors grievances, provoking Heaven’s wrath and causing it to withhold love, declaring that life is fleeting.

Thus, there are those in the world with sagely hearts and great harmony, who speak their intent, revealing the origins of transgressions and urging reform. For the length of a person’s life arises from within, not from others. Therefore, it is said that the Controller of Fate resides near, within the heart, not far from man. It judges right and wrong, and when one errs, it retreats—how can there be delay? It immediately shortens one’s years.

For those who know the unvirtuous, Heaven desires that they hear its admonitions and find peace. In moments of fault, it urges reflection, so that they may accept punishment and lose years, without harboring resentment. Heaven is vastly patient, and punishment is not meted out in a single day. Only when transgressions accumulate greatly does it dispatch the underworld’s officials to seize the person’s hun and shen, interrogating their deeds. If these do not align with the patterns of Heaven and are instead deceitful, the deceit is exposed, and the primary offense is revealed—such sins cannot be pardoned.

Thus, Heaven again issues decrees to enlighten, explaining that the disasters wrought by evil conduct urge reform. If one ignores these words, how can they long remain among the living? Therefore, good and evil are distinguished, so that none may harbor resentment. Heaven sets prohibitions to prevent transgression. Yet if one deliberately violates them, admonishing the celestial spirits, how can they long endure among men?
