Thus, the distinction between good and evil is made, so that none may complain.

Does conduct such as this constitute the Way to prevent human death? Or does it imply that Heaven is unaware? The conduct of common folk cannot be adopted in this manner—how can one long remain within the harmony of the central qi, partaking of what is edible? Yet they turn away from the protection of benevolent spirits, and their years are cut short. When the time of celestial beings is unobstructed, this is proof of goodness. If one performs good deeds day after day, why fear not living out one’s full lifespan? Thus, it is clear that people harm themselves by failing to exert effort in goodness. How can those who commit evil alone be so reckless, believing they may long share the same fate as others? Unaware, the celestial spirits hasten their descent into the earth; once buried, when shall they ever rise again? Below the earth, they are further drawn into decay, their corpses lost—such are those who receive no heavenly blessings. Can they still be counted among the living?

Each must calculate for their own body, lest they compound the suffering of future lives—this is the mark of one who is moderately good. Otherwise, they choose to be wicked, unsheltered by Heaven, unbearable to Earth. One must be cautious, avoiding transgressions and debts, to be counted among true humans. One may become a parent or child, continuing the legacy of kindness and bestowal, thereby gaining extended years, radiant essence, robust qi, and vigorous strength—all brought about by good conduct. Evil naturally declines; what is there to doubt?

From this day forward, one must carefully weigh and discern the distinction between good and evil, reflecting on which path to follow. One will then find peace, for Heaven does not oppose human actions. Yet if one repeatedly contemplates and still acts contrary to the Way, seeking long life—how can such conduct endure before the celestial spirits, the sun, moon, and stars? Would they long continue to shine? To be sheltered by the celestial spirits yet contend against them—whose fault is this? Should this not be the conduct of those who practice filial piety and goodness?

Those who possess rank and stipend, who feed from the Minister of Agriculture, who long govern the people, ensuring the proper order between high and low—these are the most honored among the people. This is the result of goodness; evil cannot preserve the body. How great is the difference? Yet when shown this text, they disregard its words, acting solely to gratify their own desires—is this not a failure of humanity?

Those who commit evil cannot transform themselves; though they possess filial piety, loyalty, sincerity, and trust, they still expect heavenly reward. When ill, they seek healing, yet their many evil deeds remain unresolved—can such a debt long be forgiven? Thus, this text is written to ensure that common folk do not resent the punishments they receive.

Those who cherish life and seek survival must not engage in evil conduct that shortens their years. Having received this text and its warnings, they should know to avoid transgressions and not provoke misfortune. If one can reform and turn to goodness, one may long abide beneath Heaven and Earth, the sun, moon, and stars, equal to others—is this not goodness? Yet they recklessly disregard their lives, believing death allows rebirth. As if one who does not recognize their own evil could deem it acceptable! They wish to be equal to others in speech, clothing, and food—can this endure?

Those who fear death dare not violate these admonitions, and this too is the result of their recorded fate. If a person is even slightly decent, they should act with integrity when integrity is due—what is there to hesitate over? Each must be cautious and diligent, reflecting on the safety or peril of their actions. The warnings in this text are self-evident.

The celestial text aims to guide people toward goodness and not to hear of their evil. Thus, the records of life are incomplete—there is no great mystery in this. Reflect carefully and do not grow lax. Heaven’s register of life may be coveted, but Earth’s register of death is deeply detestable. The space between life and death cannot be compared—does one not understand this? Knowing evil, one must be cautious and take responsibility, lest even a moment be lost from one’s lifespan—how lamentable!

When speaking with others, let one’s words and deeds win their hearts. Heaven favors goodness; let no evil words escape, lest one invite blame. We share the same breath—choose words with equal care. Not even a minor unkind word may extend one’s life. Those who can contemplate the affairs of Heaven and grasp the essential words of the celestial spirits, applying these admonitions in their actions, may alter their life records, transferring them to the bureau of longevity.

Each should cultivate their conduct and rectify their actions, never forgetting Heaven’s bestowals. One should set their mind to repaying this great kindness, thereby easily changing their aspirations. Heaven, in turn, will remember and ensure they do not encounter evil. One may trust the words of this celestial text and attain governance without strife.

The text’s words are not exhaustive—choose what is practicable and act accordingly, without forcing what is not. Each must reflect on the goodness or evil of their own conduct. Heaven endows one’s nature; let there be no doubt. One should not deceive the good, nor should the wicked obtain fortune. These words are clear—what is there to doubt?

Those who become immortals never commit evil; each cherishes their life—this is proof of goodness. The text’s words are concise, reiterating the wishes of Daoists past and present, clarifying the Way of goodness and evil, urging reflection. If one disregards them, they have only themselves to blame. Those who blame themselves should know that their grievance stems from their own lack of understanding, which leads to suffering in old age—this is self-reproach.

The rest may follow their own inclinations. If one desires to cherish life, one must not commit evil. Thus, one must reflect on suffering and joy—who alone experiences joy, and who alone suffers? One must also reflect on this, avoiding resentful words and reckless speech. Let one think carefully, think of living as a good person—hence these repeated exhortations.

Let one’s words be discernible, not deviating from Heaven’s rules. When conduct aligns with the natural Dao, what cannot be accomplished? What cannot be transformed? All will welcome it—is this not the natural grace of Heaven?

Consider the foolish below who do not reflect on the great portion they have received in being born human, assuming they will long endure.

Nor should one presume there are no spirit-mediums or divine beings—cease all transgressions. The written admonitions are not singular; they recur upon reflection. Since the words bear duplicates, we set forth repeated warnings. Consider those who fail to heed the writings: let them reflect on living virtuously, for therein lies hope of survival. Those who persist in wicked, perverse speech shall be recorded without end. Take heed and desist; desist, then reflect further. If reflection leaves one unsatisfied or discontent, reason shall be expounded anew.

**Incantation One Hundred Ninety-Six**
Alas, the people of this world—each disobeys filial piety, rebels in treachery, and vies in conduct of disloyalty and faithlessness. They spurn the principle of requital, yet deem themselves fully grown, long abiding upon the earth. In all they say and teach, not even a minor good is found; only wicked words persist. They harbor no gratitude, no generosity, stealing what pleases them to act upon, never considering that suffering follows their speech. Such offspring do not belong in this world—they merit no trust, stubbornly foolish in their self-assurance of winning others’ favor. Their spoken thoughts are unworthy of adoption, difficult to take as models. They fear nothing, recklessly committing transgressions, acting as they please, heedless of their lives, blind to lasting wholeness. In their comings and goings, they repay not their parents, nor attend them morning and night, treating kin like barbarians. Who are these beings? From their very birth, they slight their peers, spurning food and drink, never clarifying the Way. They are no wiser than the six livestock, their lives and deaths without term. Their mouths crave fine flavors, their bodies fine garments—does Heaven intend to let them live long? Your conduct cannot be followed; even in death, can your ways be adopted? If you provoke Heaven’s wrath, when will it be pleased? Does it cherish your life, sparing you from death?

All your deeds offend and transgress—yet you persist in them. This is self-seeking, as if you wished to hide from Heaven and Earth, sun and moon, stars and people, all living beings. Heaven’s admonitory writings fully expound good and evil; if you disbelieve its words, where else can you turn? Do you wish to live long and breathe freely? Are you not inferior to the six livestock, birds, and beasts in understanding? Such extreme folly—how can it rely on the profound? You act frivolously, squandering all wealth, your reckless conduct inviting punishment. Devoid of reason, year after year, you neglect your household, roaming and playing without restraint. Your thoughts never turn inward—how can you endure? Though born through your parents, your conduct lacks righteousness, showing no loyalty or filial piety, no obedience, only rebellion. Does Heaven intend to preserve you, letting your eyes blink and breath continue? In death, your excess transgressions shall extend even to your unborn children.

Consider those who bring calamity: though they commit evil in life and forfeit their years, they prevent the unborn from having a fate. Their hope of living as ghosts is vain; even death cannot expiate their guilt. Is this not the consequence of evil? How can they expect to live freely? If those yet to be born resent their wrongs, why do you speak recklessly and persist in folly? Why do the people of the world not reflect on themselves, reducing their transgressions? What benefit do accumulated faults bring to a person? Only the forfeiture of life! Should this not be pondered? Why invite further disaster? This is plain to see.

In this world, those who practice filial piety and goodness attain longevity, their descendants continuing in succession, and they witness the honor of high office and abundant emolument—is this not the result of doing good and being filial? Those who commit no good and disregard future consequences are the most rebellious and wicked of men, without equal and unceasing in their ways. When your parents gave you life, did they wish to hear of your goodness, or would they rather hear ill reports and the complaints of aged kin? Brothers who hate one another never know joy; each blames the other for their faults, yet they persist in their ways and do no good—such conduct cannot long endure.

It brings no benefit to Heaven, no benefit to Earth, no benefit to man, no benefit to the brightness of the four seasons, the five phases, the sun, moon, and stars. Such a person is utterly wicked—what hope can they have? Should they not look up in shame? Do they believe Heaven does not dispatch malevolent spirits to oversee their wrongdoing? Should they not reflect on themselves? In all they seek and do, there is nothing to rely upon; only daily decline, illness, and unending death. Why would Heaven delight in killing them? The multitudes say: "You have not a moment’s respite, so they slay you." Or they may encounter the magistrate, their wealth and property exhausted, and their grievances and misfortunes continue—is this not the result of their own conduct? Why blame Heaven and cry out in resentment?

Yet worldly people persist in this way, daring to offend Heaven again—what benefit is there in self-justification? Those who long evade the rites of sacrifice owe debts to the spirit-officials, refusing to make amends midway. What is owed must be resolved. Regularly, in the third month of spring, on an auspicious day, one should perform the rites of absolution. Three such absolutions may reduce the burden of official records, and the spirit-officials will not delight in heavily punishing men.

When official documents press upon them, passing blame up and down, how can the words of common folk prevail? Poverty and hardship bring all to a halt, leaving their deeds unfinished. In life, all consume tangible things; in death, they should consume qi, yet they do not. The ancients said: "One bears children only for the time after one’s death." Having obtained the means to consume qi alongside their peers, they yet refuse to do so. If one raises children in this manner, how can one expect descendants to long regard one another? They too shall perish, meeting the same fate as those who went before, and what shall they gain from hunger? In the celestial offices, those who are greatly filial and perform the rites with clarity need not doubt.

For three years after death, before burial, one must offer prayers and sacrifices. One cannot say, "There are unburied dead above the earth, yet no rites are performed for them." To refrain from offering is to increase transgressions and faults, bringing harm to descendants. This is plainly known—one must perform the rites. Often, in times of wealth, one indulges in extravagance, slaughtering cattle, sheep, pigs, and the six livestock for sacrifice, but the sacrificial officials grow distant. Later, one shall be held accountable, heedless of poverty. Wealth and property cannot be swiftly regained; if one’s conduct remains unworthy, wealth will not return. If one neglects the rites for long, how can the debt be swiftly resolved?

One should frequently atone for the debts of past neglect, and afterward, goodness may return, and descendants shall surely live long lives. Heaven delights in those who confess their faults. Even in impoverished households, if they partake of grain and know its savor, gathering together to bow their heads, strike their breasts, and look up in gratitude to Heaven, Heaven will take pity on their hardship. The sacrificial officials may grant them respite, allowing them to perform modest rites. The debt thus incurred is lent by Heaven; if one later acquires sufficient means, one must offer without hesitation. If one fails to do so, one shall again face the assembly of ancestors, and the sacrificial officials, resenting the neglect, shall send ghosts to escort one home, bringing unceasing illness to the living.

The ancestors shall again restrain and close the rites, and divination shall yield no answer. One must choose an auspicious day to perform them. Heaven’s grace has a term; to act within it is not amiss. One must give thanks to Heaven and Earth, summoning the bodily form into the earth, while the hun and po spirits are examined in the celestial prison, their offenses weighed and compared, death following in succession. These transgressions are too grave, so the text is set forth that all may know to accept Heaven’s punishment without complaint. They may warn one another and prevent further offenses.

Ancient writings have long existed, yet offenders never cease. For those whose coffins remain unburied, the rites must not be neglected. Now, this text is extended for those of sincere heart, that they may understand its meaning. Do not doubt its words, for one may yet be recorded in the register of the living. To doubt and fail to act is to set one’s day of death. Reflect on this yourself; do not blame Heaven or fault the Earth.

Proceed, and let the text rest briefly in your thoughts. Thereafter, ponder its words, understand what must be done, and return to the Way.

**Heaven’s Retribution is Certain: Divine Secrets, One Hundred Ninety-Seven**

Only those who advance in goodness and seek life, delighting in repayment and aligning with Heaven’s will, shall have their years extended before them. They witness the deeds that may be performed in Heaven and say: "I too shall follow Heaven’s transformative work." They see the texts on long life, altering their form and countenance, perfecting their spirit, their radiance increasing daily without cease. This is the mark of one whose heart is set on goodness, who does not forget Heaven’s grace.

For those who repay kindness, when would they ever complain? Even in the briefest moment of rest, their hearts reproach themselves, fortunate to be human and to receive guidance. Heaven’s work is fulfilled, and they come to know Heaven’s prohibitions, shunning harm and pursuing goodness, never opposing the divine. Seeing goodness, they follow it, never failing to reproach themselves and repent their errors, turning toward what is right. They reflect on their intentions, never daring to be complacent or doubtful. In their resolve to do good, they understand Heaven’s will, and all is clear—there is no room for doubt.

In self-reproach and repentance, days accumulate, and they receive blessings and protection, following Heaven’s transformative work, spared from peril. Knowing they have received Heaven’s recompense, how could they forget even for a moment, fearing the divine might reproach their words? Thus, they remain disquieted, never at ease. Eager to advance in what they say, they strive to align with Heaven’s will, fearing any lapse. Therefore, they purify their hearts and amend their conduct, moving the powers above, desiring to ascend and advance, yearning for life.

Truly, they dread the term of a short life, fearing they may long be unseen by Heaven and Earth. They exhaust their strength and devote their loyalty, pondering their sincerity. Though they often hear the words of the divine, they do not see the speakers, and their hearts are uneasy. Constantly fasting, they tremble with fear, day and night filled with dread, never daring to be at ease.

For this reason, they dare not abandon goodness to embrace evil deeds. All people receive sustenance, drawing in Heaven’s primordial *qi*, allowing them to breathe. They further understand human nature: knowing they have received Heaven’s grace and favor, they must repay and give thanks—how could there be any moment of doubt?

Heaven endows humans with essence, Earth nurtures their form, enabling them to grow and achieve maturity. Upon seeing Heaven’s scriptural admonitions and reading their words, they tremble uncontrollably—how could they speak falsely? Their hearts are constantly filled with dread and palpitation—when could they ever find peace?

Only the great spirits of Heaven, in their mercy, repeatedly examine and pardon, granting extensions of grace. Yet they know their great debt remains unpaid in due time. If only the great spirits would show compassion and allow them to remain long within the *qi* of life, extending the years of their allotted span, they would never dare forget the measure of this great bestowal. Once the grace and loan are fully repaid, they would not dare, even for a moment, to slacken or turn their backs on this favor.

Only if the great spirits fulfill this, allowing them to behold the celestial deities and converse with them, would they long to hear further admonitions. They hold Heaven’s words in the highest regard, and only when they receive recompense do they dare trust in themselves. The great spirits respond to the words of those with good hearts; the Heavenly Lord constantly cherishes such virtuous-hearted people, advancing them whenever they prove useful to Heaven.

From now on, when those with good hearts present themselves, their words shall be conveyed to the Heavenly Lord. Heed their recommendations without doubt, for they shall surely be as previously stated—this is what the Heavenly Lord himself dares to affirm. As the years and months draw near, strive to trust in Heaven’s words. Heaven, too, trusts those with good hearts, for they do not belong to the mundane world. The records in the celestial registers note their ascent into the daylight heavens—this principle is not deceptive.

The Heavenly Lord desires to advance the good, and those whose hearts do not betray their words are such people. The great spirits, even from afar, witness their conduct. Though their families may lack for a time, if they have already given their word, they need not worry. They should constantly reflect on standing before the deities of Heaven—this is the result of goodness, and they must not grow weary.

Those with good hearts say: “In life, I am no one destined for ascent. My only hope is to repay the great spirits, seeking advancement and clinging to life, exhausting all I know. How could I dare aspire to ascend in broad daylight? If selected, I am unworthy of such an honor. I fear being reproached by the great spirits, yet by their grace, I have been fortunate enough to receive favor. Though the measure of grace is fulfilled, I regret not yet having repaid this great debt in full—only the great mercy grants me respite and rest.”

Upon hearing the great spirits’ words, they compare their own intentions to those previously conveyed to the Heavenly Lord, who declares: “This is a person of good heart.” The Heavenly Lord himself wishes to draw near to them, allowing no doubt. The grace bestowed does not rest with the great spirits—why speak of repayment? They should instead clarify what they know, for there will surely be a trustworthy response. Their hearts are filled with gratitude and sincerity.

The deities will surely protect them, preventing evil spirits from interfering. They must be exceedingly cautious in their words, making goodness the foremost topic of discussion. Their written intentions must be trustworthy and mutually binding, ensuring they do not betray the words of those with good hearts who seek advancement. Heaven itself, day and night, commands its spirits to guard them—there is no cause for doubt. As for the writings that obstruct or oppose, these arise from the inherited burdens of past transgressions—do not let them be a source of worry.

Those with good hearts and aspirations say: “By nature, I am humble and lowly, long mired in the mundane world. I fear I cannot extricate myself from its midst, yet I long for the grace and favor of the great spirits, which have warmed my sincerity and self-awareness. If only the great spirits would inform the Heavenly Lord, allowing me to join the ranks of the undying—how could I dare hope for ascent in broad daylight?”

The great spirits say: “The Heavenly Lord trusts those with good hearts who seek advancement. His teachings hold no double promises, and there is no cause for doubt—this is the Heavenly Lord’s own intent. Though you may worry about your family’s insufficiency, with hunger and cold pressing in, there is the Heavenly Kitchen. Simply rely on the completion of the task, for the spirits themselves will instruct and transform your kin—do not let this weigh on your mind.”

They reply: “After receiving my allotted portion, how could I ever forget the words of the great spirits? My only concern is that I may fail to fulfill them. I dare not lose the great spirits’ pillow and mat, which remain ever in my heart and diaphragm, never slackening.”

The great spirits’ words are thus: “The Heavenly Lord knows that goodness naturally attains goodness, and those with good hearts naturally align with the Heavenly Lord’s intent.” When they previously presented their case to the Heavenly Lord, he commanded the great spirits: “I have already approved this person’s ascent. When the appointed day arrives, do not let them miss the deadline. There is a talisman clearly inscribed in their heart—let the spirits speak as a pledge, transforming it to set the date. They must only reflect on it day and night without slackening.”

They say: “After receiving this command, how could I dare grow lax? Will I truly be fulfilled?” The great spirits reply: “Once the talisman is inscribed, you will see it for yourself. Do not worry about failing to attain Heaven’s lifespan—not only the great spirits, but all deities affirm that this is a person of good heart. The deities are concerned for them; simply rely on the completion of the matter.”

They say: “This is a great weight. If my wishes are granted, I will surely devote myself wholeheartedly.” The great spirits say: “This is also what such a person should naturally embrace in their heart and express. The Heavenly Lord values their family, preventing them from falling into great transgressions, and resolving their inherited burdens. Do not trust the words of spirit-mediums or diviners—their divinations cannot alter anything. Those who wish to deliver and preserve life must rely on the true deities. Though minor spirits may be negligent, the higher powers will resolve it—do not act recklessly or inappropriately. This is known to those with hearts of goodness and the Dao.

Each must plan for themselves, trusting in Heaven’s words. Heaven does not deceive those with good hearts who seek advancement. Though they know kindness and constantly reflect, there is never a moment of forgetfulness. They hear that evil spirits descend from below, targeting those without resolve who fail to guard themselves, indulging in the extraordinary—thus, evil befalls them. They become unsettled or wicked, and their endeavors meet with no success.

This scripture does not trust evil people, nor do evil people trust this scripture. Only when its efficacy is proven and recompense received can it be truly known.”

"Now, those who have faith must recognize that the scripture for those who advance in goodness is such that the spirits themselves desire to manifest their trustworthiness. If one does not believe and put it into practice, those without the heart to advance in goodness will gain nothing. In action, the words of the scripture are already known; when trust is seen and verified, it will not be long in coming."

"How is this made clear?"
"Those who delight in life are made joyful by Heaven—this is Heaven’s trustworthy recompense. Such a person will surely transform into a spirit, ascending in broad daylight. They will no longer doubt, their days will grow lighter, and their meals will diminish. Through trust, their radiance becomes pure. Day by day, they draw closer to such a person. This trust is the clearest of clarities."

"Moreover, do not let doubt arise in your words. When you see the admonition and receive the decree, follow as it is spoken, reflect upon it, and do not dare to grow lax or forgetful. Though you may have been ignorant in the past, after witnessing it, you will grow ever closer without difference."

The great spirit said: "Good! Goodness should also be bestowed with a name. It is fitting to swiftly complete one’s work—this is the constant admonition of the spirits."

"Though the scripture’s words are weighty, the Way of life is inherently abundant."
"Do not fear it. The words will come to an end, and each will have their say."

Those with the heart and resolve to reflect replied in assent, not daring to forget.

**Decree of the Heavenly Lord of Merit, Scroll 198:**
Only those of great sincerity and faith, ancient and modern, each with proven efficacy, who accumulate merit before Heaven, dare to step forward. In movement and stillness, advance and retreat, they have never committed even the slightest transgression. They constantly harbor compassionate kindness, bestowing grace and favor, benefiting the multitude. They do not lose even the smallest trust, nor do they fail to revere Heaven and Earth, following the guidance of the four seasons and the five phases, aiding in creation and growth. They dare not harbor intentions of failure, thereby endangering themselves and causing unrest. Thus, they examine their own faults and debts, fearing they may not be resolved, and that the multitude of spirits will record them in ledgers to be reported to the Most High. For this reason, they dare to live in peace.

From ancient times to the present, goodness and evil flow in succession—when has there ever been an end? Therefore, they remain composed and tranquil, never growing lax or forgetting Heaven’s works. They merely reflect, seeking those of virtue, using their own hearts as a measure. When they see someone with a good heart, they rejoice; when they see someone with an evil heart, they tremble in fear. They imagine the heavenly spirits knowing all, each advancing accordingly.

They further reflect: originally born in the mundane world, their hearts constantly long for great transformation, coveting the Way of life and departing from the realm of death. They cherish the steadfast radiance of essence, desiring its presence within, causing self-love and peace of mind. Otherwise, they fear they will not remain among the commonly seen. Only the heavenly spirits, in their timely mercy, instruct them in advance and retreat, aligning with Heaven’s will—there must be no failure."

When even minor misdeeds reach the ears of the Supreme Sovereign, the spirits are thus entreated to inquire and examine, and by their gracious non-rejection, they are spared suspicion. Having received but a fraction of their allotted influence, they dare not forget it for even a moment. They only reflect upon their words, pondering the heavenly admonitions, to perfect their own persons and avoid falling into peril. This is the day of the spirits’ favor and grace, and they dare not rest, nor cease to contemplate repaying this profound kindness.

Before the spirits have reported to the Heavenly Lord, they learn of the dispatch and meet the attending spirit who bears the decree. They ask how the person’s conduct has wavered, thoroughly inquiring into their intentions, and the spirits question them in turn, returning to report at once. They say: this person of harmonious nature has long followed the good Way, accumulating merit over time, coveting long life. Though they modestly speak of themselves, they constantly reflect, fearing faults and transgressions, never slackening in their resolve. The spirits thus recount their merits.

The spirits then confer among themselves, saying: this person has accumulated virtue and merit, dwelling in harmony, ever mindful of repaying Heaven’s great kindness. Their good deeds have amassed over time, and though they wish to declare their merits through the spirits, they harbor doubts and dare not advance to report to the Heavenly Lord. They have long entrusted the spirits with their trust, having rendered service to Heaven, and those with merit should be advanced. Yet the spirits observe their conduct over time and wonder why they have not been reported.

The spirits, filled with apprehension, say: originally, they did not know this person’s origins, fearing their sincerity was not entirely pure. They deliberate on their intentions, uncertain whether the Heavenly Lord has heard of them. The spirits, lacking resolve, see this meritorious person yet fail to report them in due time. The messenger spirit is thus dispatched to investigate their accumulated deeds, which prove to be of great merit.

The spirits, having acted without propriety, lacking merit themselves, and harboring external intentions, assume the Heavenly Lord is unaware. They consider the spirits’ explanations—what use are they if they bring no benefit, each seeking only their own ease? The spirits apologize, recognizing their duty, removing their caps in remorse. They say: these minor spirits have served with wholehearted loyalty, yet upon inquiry, they are found guilty of impropriety, awaiting death at the gate.

The Heavenly Lord issues a decree, ordering them to wait outside while the attending spirits prostrate themselves, standing in perilous vigil. The decree commands the spirits, saying: the Heavenly Lord does not wish to punish them severely and cannot yet bear to harm them. They are to be exiled to the land of harmony, residing in the capital for ten years, selling medicine to heal the sick without accepting excessive payment. After their exile, those of higher rank shall be recorded in the Bureau of Reports; after one year of merit, they may be restored to their former positions.

The spirits, having received a pardon for their otherwise capital offense and granted only a light exile, truly recognize their faults. They are humbled, having despaired of life, yet the Heavenly Lord, unwilling to inflict harm, allows them to make amends through service. The Heavenly Lord says: "Inform the clerks of the Bureau to proceed without delay, dispatching a spirit to oversee their conduct." The clerks reply: "The dispatch shall proceed as the Heavenly Lord commands."

The Heavenly Lord instructs the clerks to inform the great spirits, showing them the documents so they may witness the decree. The clerks transmit the documents to the great spirits, who then instruct their subordinates to fulfill their duties, advancing those with merit and virtue who seek advancement. Previous matters are to be fully reported for clarity.

The Heavenly Lord commands the great spirit: "Observe this person at once and see whether their words align with the messenger spirit’s report." The great spirit replies: "Having been dispatched to observe the person, I have tallied the days and reviewed their merits, returning to report. As instructed, I have examined the meritorious person of harmony, and the report matches the messenger spirit’s words."

The Heavenly Lord, recognizing this as a person of merit whom the spirits’ subordinates failed to report in time, perceives their intent and asks: "Is this not a lack of diligence?" Having been lightly exiled to the land of harmony, from this day forward, let this serve as a warning. Those who fail to report merit shall themselves bear the punishment of exile. Each must attend to their duties, dispatching spirits to guide and transform such persons, helping them attain divinity and augment their essence and radiance. Review the registers, and for those not yet recorded above, inscribe their names.

The great spirit receives the decree and returns to the bureau, reviewing the registers to find the person’s name. They report to the clerks: "The documents contain this record; I request to examine the Heavenly Lord’s internal register to verify its correspondence." The Heavenly Lord produces the document and reviews it, finding it identical to the external record. He orders the name to be recorded above.

The great spirit asks: "I am uncertain whether their term has been fulfilled; I request to return and verify." The Heavenly Lord says: "Have you not placed your eyes and ears to observe fully, yet you ask to return and verify?" The great spirit apologizes for their duty.

The Heavenly Lord says: "Proceed swiftly with the verification." The great spirit then examines the person and finds their term already fulfilled. Their failure to report, lacking propriety, warrants punishment and awaits execution. The Heavenly Lord says: "For now, let them resume their duties and not slacken. Summon the person to ascend, ensuring they do not neglect their minor duties, knowing how to offer their merits."

"Understood. We shall follow the Heavenly Lord’s decree."

"Very well. Let the great spirit advance the person, appointing them to a minor post to observe their conduct."

"The time has been brief; I request to further assess their sincerity. If their merits are substantial and trustworthy, and a vacancy exists, they shall be appointed to fill it."

The Heavenly Lord says: "You must heed the great spirit’s report and not grow lax." The great spirit replies: "Understood. I request to dispatch a spirit to oversee their conduct." The Heavenly Lord says: "Very well."

**Scroll 199: On the Incompleteness of Life Without Written Decrees**

Only in the heavens do those of sagely wisdom hold their offices, each fulfilling their loyal conduct, never failing their superiors. Each exerts their utmost strength in their duties, never neglecting their intent. All foreknow their Heavenly Lord’s designs, ever straining to hear His will, ever examining the archives of the treasury and documents to discern His intent. When the Lord summons, there is no fixed hour—they dare not depart privately. Only on official business do they proceed, first reporting their purpose before venturing forth. Wherever they are sent, wherever they traverse, upon receiving the edict, they carry out their inspection without the slightest delay. Only after fulfilling their duties may they speak of private matters, for their sincerity is devoted to their service—they dare not act selfishly.

Those whose lives are not destined to be whole spare no day or night in self-reproach, ever fearing their usefulness may be insecure. Each governs their own conduct, striving to align with the Supreme’s intent. How could they dare grow lax, fearing they might fail in propriety? Their merits advance daily without need for spirits to urge them on. Thus they seek self-perfection, desiring long life and to serve among the heavenly spirits, great and small alike, all mutually aware. In carrying out affairs, they do not act unjustly nor presume authority, fearing suspicion. Every action is reported—when would they ever rest?

This is so because each person has their own aspirations, their own thoughts, their own accomplishments, their own calculations. Each has their own perceptions, their own origins, their own desires, their own knowledge. Their hearts are thus made clear. In these matters, life must be cherished above all—life is foremost. The rest is left to individual judgment.

The qi of life infuses the human body, and none are exempt. They guard and complete one another, and the spirits too value the attainment of their names. Transforming and emerging, entering through no aperture, they move freely, great or small. Common folk do not perceive the forms of spirits, yet spirits know one another intimately. Their forms are all composed of qi—how could they not achieve their ends?

Great spirits and lesser spirits differ in the brilliance of their essence, each according to their rank. When their lifespan increases ninefold, so too do their years. Those who enact great transformations through goodness enjoy boundless longevity—above, there is no higher; below, no lower. They enter and exit without obstruction, without outer or inner, their form like a ceaseless cycle. To halt is to halt; to move is to move. Breath becomes spirit, radiance and splendor flourish. There are appointed times for ascent and descent; when the moment arrives, they return in due course. Yet they are not entirely free, for hierarchy constrains them. Each serves the other, each has their records, their duties, their proper mindset. They uphold their resolve without deviation, illuminating their actions. Each sees their merits, each advances their knowledge, harboring no selfishness. Every move follows the teachings, never straying from the Lord’s words. They advance with unceasing diligence until the edict commands them to stop. This is the aspiration of the living spirits, and they possess talismanic transmissions as proof of their conduct.

In all their inspections, they receive provisions according to their assigned duties, never exceeding the written decrees, taking only what is allotted. The heavenly waystations have their own records—those unentitled to stay must not linger. The Heavenly Lord’s constant teaching forbids recklessness, lest the guardians of the transmissions abuse their authority. Offices have their hierarchy—none may falsely claim a higher rank to prolong their stay in the waystations. The officials receive the Heavenly Lord’s edicts and, if one overstays, report their name, rank, and affiliation without concealment or deceit. The Heavenly Lord already knows—how could they presume to act in private favor? All must adhere to impartiality. If one presumes to act without the Lord’s command, their records are frequently submitted. This results in the loss of their essence’s brilliance, their lifespan diminished—a matter well understood. They must be vigilant in their time, never daring to act on their own without heeding the Lord’s teachings.

The heavenly spirits constantly inspect and recommend one another without rest. Those who later ascend must know these prohibitions; the sagely wise do not transgress them. Fearing that later ascended ones may not see these warnings, the Heavenly Lord disseminates these texts to make the prohibitions known. This is the Heavenly Lord’s great mercy, lest any violate them. It is His desire to cultivate goodness, so He shows these texts even to common folk. Though few among them understand the harmony between Heaven and humanity, each has their own taboos.

Those who are repeatedly admonished in these texts yet refuse to reform merely wish to live out their years. If they do not desire goodness, they bring incompleteness upon themselves—how can such people persist in evil? The warnings may seem slight, yet they should be pondered for what follows. If any remain unprepared, let them reflect again.

**Great Longevity Admonition 200**

Only those of resolute will remain free from confusion. Following Heaven’s transformations, they take proper guidance as their teacher. Each is thus enabled to pursue their aspirations, fulfilling their heart’s desires.

All the myriad beings—twelve thousand in number—are born within the earth of harmony, where they grow and flourish, each returning to shelter its roots below. Their flowers and fruits sustain body and mouth, aiding the grains, offering flavors of sour, salty, tart, and bland as they please. Water is transformed into salt to season all tastes. Beans become fermented paste to enhance salt’s savor. Whether thick or thin, all vegetables and edibles that enter the mouth are provided for the people’s sustenance. Through warmth and fullness, their forms grow, their appearances flourish, and their descendants carry on. Even the six livestock unfit for labor are given to be eaten—rich, tender, sweet, and crisp—all made available for consumption.

Are these not the spirits Heaven appoints to their duties, harmonizing and balancing all things so each may follow their wishes without disturbance to their peace? Is this not Heaven’s bestowal of grace and favor upon the people? Yet how can Heaven’s gifts go unrequited? When does Heaven ever demand repayment? It is only that the common folk, having received such great kindness, fail to return thanks—thus the demand arises. Heaven feeds on the essence of qi, requiring no recompense from the people; it values only their intent. Yet they, in turn, forget the qi of Heaven that brings forth all things, allowing them to eat. Among the people, those who know yet do not repay act as if they were Heaven’s appointed agents.

The appointed agents traverse the land, commanding even the winged insects to issue decrees, urging the tillers to hasten their planting. The cuckoo calls daily, and the people heed its words. From the greatest to the least in every household, all who eat grain exhort one another day and night, scattering seeds upon the fields. Heaven makes them grow, timely rains and winds stir their branches and leaves, and their bodies swell with ripeness, ready to be harvested for human sustenance. Is not this grace profound? Year after year, when does it ever cease?

Yet they, in turn, show no filial piety, harboring rebellious hearts. What benefit do they bring to Heaven? Why does Heaven long endure such wicked and unfilial people, allowing them to see and consume its bounty? Does Heaven truly know nothing? Why should it continue to nourish the unfilial and rebellious? Thus, it assigns malevolent spirits to follow them, ensuring that the unfilial and rebellious face severe prohibitions. Their crimes bring grave misfortune, leaving no time for pardon.

Why do the people persist in such transgressions, shortening their own lives and forfeiting their allotted years? Do they not see that only the filial and good live long, bearing descendants? Good and evil must be compared: longevity and its absence stand in contrast, just as life and death are irreconcilable. Those who act with goodness and filial piety live out their years, some even gaining extended lifespans, their children and grandchildren succeeding them without premature death. Is this not the result of Heaven’s favor toward good and filial conduct? Why then do they act wickedly, inflicting harm upon others? Heaven deeply abhors such deeds, swiftly cutting short their lives and bringing misfortune to their descendants—what hope remains for such evil?

Heaven delights in the good and rejects the wicked. Let them ponder these words, for the text is complete and sufficient for self-protection, ensuring Heaven’s blessings. Why endure prolonged suffering and self-inflicted sorrow, filling the heart with grief? When grievances accumulate and remain unresolved, day and night are consumed by bitterness and sighs. Their thoughts fixate on the dispersal of wealth, fearing they cannot long preserve it. Illnesses persist year after year, confining them to bed, beyond the reach of physicians. Qi stagnates, unrelieved. As they brood, their strength wanes day and night, their appetite dwindles, and they cannot digest their food. The five viscera grow unsettled, the spleen fails to grind. This is the domain of incompleteness—shortness of breath, food unable to descend.

Their families watch, deeming them beyond recovery. Those with wealth may have some provisions left, but the penniless exhaust their property, impoverished within and without, unable to aid one another. Death arrives, yet no coffin is prepared; they are buried in the earth. Only when their heirs accumulate wealth might they be exhumed. For the impoverished, wealth departs and kin scatter—when will they reunite? Families fracture, unable to save one another. Thus, they lie without a coffin, becoming wandering ghosts without a home, with no one to offer them food. Dead and starving, they beg endlessly for sustenance.

This is the consequence of their evil deeds, yet they remain unaware, losing their clans forever. Alas, how grievous! Death leaves them with no refuge. Such are those who accumulate misfortune, bringing ruin upon their households and leaving no posterity. Heaven, too, grieves for them. Thus, a posthumous child may remain, its sex unknown. The child grows, but before reaching maturity, the mother departs to remarry. When the child is older, they ask their distant kin, “Where are my parents?” The kin reply, “Your father was young and restless, unable to settle. He followed reckless companions, neglecting his family, turning to robbery and banditry. He never ceased, and the authorities executed him in a foreign land. His wealth was exhausted, and he never returned to his hometown. For years, he wandered in distant regions; whether he lives or died, none can say.

All the households suffered his poison, and even distant kin fled. Your mother, pregnant with you, rejoiced at your birth, seeing you as a continuation. But the elders of the family had no support, impoverished and unable to sustain themselves, so they sent her to work. She followed a traveling merchant, with no set date for return.” The posthumous child laments, “All people are born dependent on their parents—why was I born without seeing mine?” As they grow older, they ask again, “Where is my father?”

People say, "Your father committed evil, abandoning his parents and wandering far away. Whether he lives or died, none can tell, and his whereabouts are unknown. Travelers passing through heard he had died, but no one knew where." His parents grieved for him, falling ill and never rising again, thus failing to live out their years. Their wealth was exhausted, their household both within and without declined, and the fault lay in our kin growing distant, having long shared no bond of kindness. I could only look to the heavens and weep bitterly, my tears soaking my robes.

Your father’s wicked deeds brought this upon himself, preventing his return. I reproached myself endlessly, finding no relief. At times, I worked as a traveling laborer, hired by wealthy households as their servant. Earning several thousand coins a year, my clothing came from this, and what little remained I saved. After more than ten years, I might have enough to return to my hometown. I longed to seek out my father, weeping day and night, with no one to rely on—how grievous the pain! Your father’s evil deeds left his child with no support, my tears flowing like a stream, never ceasing.

How great the sorrow from heaven! Yet it granted me strength, allowing me to manage my livelihood profitably, take a wife, and have descendants—only then did my heart find slight peace. I tell you again: your father committed evil, wandering far away and never returning. When travelers came and went, I hired diviners to inquire, but none could say whether he lived or died, or where he might be sought. Over the years, I worked to sustain myself. Heaven pitied the destitute, granting me profitable ventures. With some savings, I sought a wife to help manage our livelihood, and thus you were born.

I lament that your father committed evil in his youth, and so I warn you. From now on, you must only do good and not follow your father’s path, wandering far away. Reflect on my faults—heaven has pitied me. Strive to do good, avoid idleness, and manage your livelihood with order. Do not take others’ wealth; only then can you live sufficiently. Each must attend to their duties, avoid reckless drinking, and refrain from gossiping or stirring disputes, lest you suffer losses.

Ponder deeply your parents’ words, and you will avoid blame. If the heavens hear of this and deem you a good son, you may live a long and full life. I have grown old and offer this as a warning. The gods will hear and report to heaven. Heaven will send benevolent spirits to accompany you, your livelihood will prosper, your wealth will grow, your children will thrive, and you will have enough—this is heaven’s grace.

At the spring and autumn festivals and the year-end sacrifices, always offer thanks to heaven. Never cease in your efforts to do good, and you will secure your own blessings. Be cautious in speech and reflect on your actions. The heavenly spirits are always by your side—do not speak recklessly.

Beware the slightest deviation, for carelessness may cost you your life. When you see a warning, reproach yourself—do not blame others. This admonition is clear. Those who wish for great longevity must not neglect these words.

**Illness Returns to Heaven, Costly Remedies: Scroll 201**

All people dwell in the world, each with their proper path and each with their accomplishments. Let none obstruct another’s aspirations; let each find ease in what suits them. Whether in trade, farming, official service, medicine, divination, or craftsmanship, allow all to fulfill their calling. The Dao brings all to fruition, providing for the people’s needs. This is the teaching of heaven—how could any fail to succeed, ensuring their own sustenance?

Remember always to follow heaven’s way, to bestow kindness and share bounty, and to offer pure and unceasing sacrifices in return for the four seasons. This is how one repays heaven’s grace. If you persist in good deeds, the spirits will cherish you, for such conduct brings its own reward—how could it not be favored? Thus, heaven ever watches from above, judging human deeds, sending spirits to observe all actions. Good and evil are promptly reported—nothing is missed.

Those who doubt this should know that heaven reveals its signs through echoes and omens, making its will heard. The timing of wind and rain is made known—what room is there for doubt? Actions yield distinct outcomes, and written records preserve the law without fail. How can one remain ignorant and act wantonly, defying heaven?

Heaven, born of the primordial qi, naturally follows its own decrees. None dare even slightly disobey, fearing loss and the people’s undoing. Those who violate heavenly law, heedless of its snares, invite heaven’s reproof. To live long, you must be counted among the good. How can one presume to act as they please?

Thus, spirits follow the wicked, recording their misdeeds and reporting every transgression, great or small, to heaven. These are human failings—why blame the heavenly records? The texts contain warnings, yet if one ignores them, falls ill, and panics, how can they escape? Truly, people are foolish—what benefit do they bring to heaven? They weary the spirits with their troubles, and physicians and shamans labor to heal them.

If you seek life, do not forget your past transgressions. When you acted wrongly, why did you not immediately repent? Only when illness strikes do you beg for survival—by then, death often follows. Some pray and sacrifice to spirits: minor offenses may be absolved, but grave ones are not forgiven. Instead, they summon more spirits, calling them deceitful illness-demons, prostrating and striking themselves, pleading for life with countless petitions. Yet their names are already inscribed in death’s ledger—how can they escape?

Physicians, shamans, and spirit-mediums, eager for payment, claim the illness can be cured. They demand rich offerings, fine meats, and wine, invoking mighty spirits to intercede and spare your life. But if your name is not destined to be removed, your wealth will be exhausted, and you will still lose your life. If the spirits’ entreaties fail thrice, the illness will not improve—why persist? Disaster will only bring further disaster, and retribution will follow.

False spirits masquerade as true ones, slaughtering recklessly, killing the undeserving. Their crimes and grievances ascend to heaven, where the Heavenly Lord judges them. Those who serve such spirits—even their descendants suffer, seeking blessings for the sick. Hoping to secure life, they invoke spirits improperly and instead invite calamity.

Those who serve false spirits claim, *"Our spirits are true!"*—but what false spirit or demon would dare stand before the Heavenly Lord to intercede for others? They merely consume the people’s offerings—wine, millet, dates—and when illness strikes, they blame the false spirits’ households. If recovery occurs, it is because the person was not yet marked for death. If the transgression has not been recorded above, they may be spared—this is heaven’s doing, not the false spirits’ merit. Yet they boast of healing many, demanding rich rewards.

When false spirits are exposed, they are summoned for judgment, their hidden crimes examined. If their sins are many and grave, they will not survive. Those who serve spirits but fail to attract them, whose conduct is unworthy, will see their vitality wane—this is the retribution of false spirits. Spirit-mediums take the remnants of false spirits’ offerings to feed their families, wearing fine clothes, believing their prosperity will last. But spirits will punish them—how can they hope for long life?

Those who accept many spirit-offerings cannot be absolved; their descendants will perish. They blame others, saying, *"You killed my descendants!"*—yet they themselves may face extinction. People should correct themselves—why blame heaven?

Today’s people are foolish and shallow. When illness strikes and death looms, they do not turn to heaven, confess their faults, and prostrate themselves. Instead, their entire household, young and old, joins in desperate pleas. After days of this, heaven may pardon them, granting time to recover. But if they repeat their offenses, prostration is futile. This is plain to see.

Strive to do good, avoid forbidden acts, and you may live out your full span. If you refuse goodness, you invite a short life, choosing to become a ghost, scorning life itself—what can be done? Be cautious in speech, delight in understanding the rest.

Reflect on your actions; do not act unjustly. When ill, turn to heaven. This will save resources and spare you great trouble. Do not flee your home in panic, seeking distant refuge. What good is fleeing for one fated to die? Malevolent spirits will follow—can you truly escape? Fools act thus, yet how can they secure a place among the living? Avoidance does not kill—it only brings ruin to the household.

Heavenly spirits watch from above—what fate do you seek? Do you not know your place? Be mindful of your words. Heaven loves humanity and desires life—when has it ever wished to harm or kill? It sets prohibitions only to prevent transgressions.

Yet when one violates them oneself, how can life be prolonged? Ponder this deeply, again and again, and recall the words of the scriptures—let no doubt remain. When the scriptures briefly pause, pause and reflect; then, when the spoken Way resumes, follow its discourse once more.

**Second Hundred and Twenty Admonitions on Resolving Illness and Removing Heaven’s Reproof**

Consider the people of the world—how utterly foolish they are. They neglect filial piety and loyalty, turning instead to rebellion. They disregard the great scriptures, recklessly belittling themselves. Toward others, they show no kindness, while their misdeeds spread far and wide. Those who dwell in such ways invite disaster; those in their midst decline; those beneath them fall ill, never to recover. This is the evil they inflict upon others, ensuring their own guilt cannot be absolved, for they harbor no intent to bestow mercy. Day and night, they assail and undermine the good, provoking resentment and offering no benevolence in return. Instead, they incite themselves, entrapping others in accusations, subjecting them to punishment—even death—while severing their own masters’ protection.

Wealthy households may extricate themselves from trouble through drink. The penniless, however, violate the law, summoning officials to be summoned in turn, exhausting their resources to secure release. All their possessions are tallied and valued, then used to buy their freedom. Half remains for their family’s sustenance, while fine wine and choice delicacies are indulged at will. They deem this acceptable, unaware that others observe and resent their wickedness. They assume their ways endure, equal to all others.

When a county magistrate is stern, he dispatches officers to surveil. Those who seek merit report in kind. Day and night, they monitor, eager to uncover wrongdoing. They note who among the idle and dissolute frequents which doors, slipping in secret missives bearing names. The officials, corrupted, act as intermediaries, relaying faults and merits. With rich food and fine wine ever before their eyes, they remain vigilant. The magistrate, receiving the missives, summons the accused in silence, presenting evidence to silence their denials. Once guilt is determined, they are sent to prison, tortured to confess their crimes. If others speak against them, their punishment is compounded. Such is the fate they hear—and such is their own.

Wealth in trifling matters—failing to strive for self-improvement and secure one’s livelihood, yet turning to sell one’s tongue against others, entrapping them in accusations—this is true malice. How can one hope for long life? When high officials despise you, ensuring you cannot survive, whose fault is it? All stems from the depravity of wicked men. Parents grieve in bitterness, clans suffer poisonous harm. Behaving thus, what can one expect but to forfeit the hope of prolonged breath?

To invite calamity and punishment, yet still seek life—what manner of person is this? Heaven gazes down from above, declaring such deeds intolerable for long. Below, it dispatches officials to the bureau of malevolence, sending clerks to ally with evil spirits, aiding the county magistrate in punishing the lawless, driving them into the statutes of death, leaving no hope of survival. All this for greed—not the wealth of one household, but to augment their own gain at others’ expense. Only when guilt is fixed and death assured do they cease. No heirs remain to offer sacrifices, leaving the departed unhonored at ancestral rites. This is your fault alone.

From now on, let later generations take warning and desist, if only to eke out brief survival. Otherwise, they shall surely join the ranks of the dead, without doubt. Take heed in even slight matters, and you may avoid mutual resentment. Life cannot be regained once lost. All men are the same—why defy the prohibitions?

The lawless band together, forming gangs to rob others of their wealth. Their masters remain unscathed, and the magistrate has yet to execute them. Yet Heaven enacts its own punishment, annihilating households from above and cursing descendants below. For the sake of such wealth, they forfeit life—how is this calculation not wholly corrupt? Thus, these writings are issued repeatedly, valuing only that men refrain from transgression. Yet those who persist in the worst offenses cause many deaths, incurring Heaven’s deep displeasure.

Those with discernment, seeing such men, naturally avoid their crimes. But the people of this age are utterly benighted. They read these longevity texts yet disregard their words, dismissing them as untrustworthy. They do not see that those who attain immortality do so through filial piety and goodness—how boundless is their longevity! Carefully consider these words, for they share a common purpose: let good deeds flourish, and evil befall its authors. The warnings inscribed before and after aim but to guide men toward goodness and away from lawbreaking. When have they ever wronged you?

You ought to ponder deeply and engrave these admonitions within, making them your guide, lest you offend Heaven. To offend brings no benefit—only compounding your transgressions. Take care not to harbor resentment; your actions yield their own consequences. What cause for blame is there? Strive for goodness, and you may yet be called human. Act with self-regard, lest you incur the reproach of spirits. Do you not understand?

Each must weigh their own reckoning, avoiding the pursuit of wrongdoing, for death is insufficient to absolve guilt. Those to whom misfortune accrues are many; when will the cycle of hatred and resentment end? A guarded heart is essential—empty words are of no use. The affairs of this world bring only sorrow and bitterness. Why persist in provocation, when harmony might prevail?

To deem oneself virtuous and seek to reform others, only to prove oneself base—this is no standard to uphold. Born alike as humans, yet lacking insight, when questioned, they offer no clarity of purpose. Such men are no better than livestock. Their mouths know only foulness, yet they don fine robes and feign propriety. Their bowing and rising follow no proper model, their hearts ever harboring irreverence. Seeing elderly neighbors, they stand in arrogance; encountering women, they gossip, ranking their beauty or ugliness. These are evil men, fit for no honest labor.

They scheme and contrive, their mouths spewing curses, denying the gods of the earth. They incriminate one another, acting as they please, heedless of the coming retribution. Too late to save themselves, their aid arrives only when disaster has struck—what use is it then? Their pettiness and harshness will ultimately be laid bare. How can they justify themselves, absolve their debts? Condemned by the many, their misdeeds unceasing, they bring ruin upon their households, leaving no descendants, their lifespans cut short. Pitiable are such deeds—how can they endure?

The *Scripture of Great Peace* commands that inferiors obey their superiors, ensuring longevity. Disobedience forfeits life and invites ungovernable chaos. Yet the people of this age are ungrateful, lacking in principle. They indulge their immediate desires, heedless of their own lives. Unrestrained and self-willed, they deny the existence of spirits. Those who slight them are many, their affairs ever entangled. When the Hall of Light is consulted, past and present deeds are collated, names recorded, and the responsible officials take note. If debts or transgressions are found, they report to the supervising authority, who in turn informs the Bureau of Grand Darkness. The clerks of Grand Darkness summon the ancestors of the household, interrogating and torturing them. They compel the accused to return home and confess their curses, evasions, and misdeeds, which know no end, thus afflicting them with illness.

The afflicted household must perform rites to absolve the yin transgressions and misfortunes, halting their recurrence. If the absolution succeeds, the illness ceases; if not, the punishment persists, and the affliction continues. Having failed to absolve themselves, they dismiss the matter as false. Yet observe their conduct—such men exist in abundance, differing only in degree. This is plain to see. Beware henceforth, lest you compound your guilt. With awareness, you may avoid fault. Without it, you remain trapped between misfortune and blessing, never at rest.

Heed these words carefully. Do not betray one another, for the gods never cease their reckoning. To feign ignorance of others’ deeds is itself an evil. Good begets good; evil forfeits longevity. Why harbor resentment when you reap what you sow? Obey your superiors, and you shall have no wicked sons. Do you not understand? Take warning, take warning—let there be some respite.

The text is difficult to compose, its statutes and ordinances expansive. It is meant only to ensure you refrain from transgression. Some passages are brief, others less definitive. Ponder their implications, and let their meaning be clear. Take heed, take heed—small matters lead to great consequences.

The text is repetitive, so let a brief respite follow. After this pause, more words shall be set forth.

**On the Unyielding Duty of Parents (Section 203)**
Only those who walk in virtue transgress neither the prohibitions of Heaven and Earth, nor the taboos of the four seasons, five phases, sun, moon, stars, and all spirits. Fearing the consequences of violation, they inscribe their names above, thereby resolving to cultivate goodness and filial piety.

The celestial prohibitions are not meant to constrain the people but to ensure their flourishing. When all living things are nurtured and fed, why would Heaven wish them harm? It is man who brings ruin upon himself.

Thus, the virtuous speak no ill, for each precept and its fulfillment is plainly recorded. Goodness begets life; evil hastens death—what quarrel is there with fate? Therefore, the writings of the good are set forth to instruct the people, that they may know the origins of fortune and misfortune, follow the Way of admonition, and avoid transgression.

Those who do good encounter no harsh words. Heaven sees their virtue and commands spirits to attend them, altering their fate in the registers of destiny, transferring them to the ranks of the long-lived. Their merit is thus secured. Future generations, born under the auspices of virtuous days, shall face no omens or taboos below. The surplus years of their ancestors are added to their own, granting them a lifespan of one hundred and twenty.

Their descendants, inheriting this goodness, shall know no minor faults and likewise enjoy long life, their white hairs succeeding one another. Generation upon generation, their households shall be abundant, their members complete, and none shall encroach upon them. Whether tilling the land or trading in markets, all shall prosper. Entering officialdom, they shall rise through the ranks, untouched by punishment, for goodness is their guardian.

Yet some, unable to emulate such conduct, mock it instead. The heart of the virtuous remains steadfast in goodness, ever benefiting others. When they see others in distress, they lend aid without demanding repayment or interest. Those who receive their kindness shall never betray them. Even a small repayment—wine and meat in gratitude—shall bind both parties in mutual favor.

Heaven observes their deeds and blesses them further, ensuring their comings and goings are free from harm. The virtuous are aided by Heaven itself, spared from encountering evil—such is the fruit of their conduct.

As for those who do evil yet hope to live long and leave descendants, they fail to discern the natural order. Heaven distinguishes their lifespans, for only those who align their hearts with the Way of Heaven and perform celestial deeds may attain immortal records, their spirits ascending to the ranks of the sagely. What limit could there be to their longevity?

Thus, goodness must not be neglected, for it is beyond the reach of most. Heaven cherishes the virtuous and desires no evil for them. The good and the wicked occupy separate realms—how could they share the same fate? The celestial writings make this clear: the good are rewarded, the wicked admonished, lest they fall into peril and forfeit their years.

Heaven repays goodness by lengthening life and dooms the wicked to fail in their humanity—this is plain to see. Why harbor doubt? From birth to old age, each person begets descendants, raising them to maturity. Let them follow their inclinations and live in peace, never opposing their wills, that each may find their proper place and fulfill their desires.

To be a parent is no easy task. Children, in turn, must be filial, heeding their parents’ teachings. The virtuous preserve the integrity of their limbs and bones, keeping them whole. What parents give, they must not mar with injury or punishment. They dare not answer back but offer only what is fine. If the household lacks wealth, let them be reverent, gentle, and tender, frequently inquiring after their parents’ well-being to know their safety—this is the highest goodness.

Neighbors and close kin should be treated with love and respect, completing the work of virtue. When encountering the wicked, one must not engage in speech, lest conflict arise. Once discord erupts, the virtuous are blamed for the wicked’s faults, and Heaven grows resentful. Thus, all must cherish themselves and their descendants, avoiding transgressions that unsettle the household. Such unrest does not stop there but extends to kin near and far, disrupting all within.

If they then face official scrutiny, their wealth and property shall dwindle. Therefore, let them be cautious and never violate the written precepts. Let them foster harmony and unity, free from duplicity. Each shall have their calling and fulfill their duties—this is the conduct of the truly virtuous. Heaven shall grant them long life, and spirits and ghosts shall protect them, never failing in their duty.

The offerings to the four seasons shall be presented in proper order. In markets, let them choose the finest goods without haggling over prices. Why? Because all offerings possess spirit, ascending or descending in accord with their quality. Even slight impurities shall be recorded, incurring no loss. Thus, let them conduct their trade and travel with reverence, and the spirits shall rejoice. They shall report to the Controller of Destinies, and the officials of the altars and bureaus shall proceed in peace.

If they personally present offerings of purity and fragrance, partaking in the feast afterward, they shall make grand offerings to the Five Ancestors at the proper place, and all shall eat with joy. Their households shall grow prosperous, their descendants virtuous, free from wicked children. The commanderies and counties shall hear of them and summon them to office. They shall ascend to the prefecture, where prominent posts await.

When the province learns of them, it shall recruit them as trusted aides, recommending them for excellence and talent—such is the reward of goodness. Their positions shall rise of their own accord, for this is the natural course of their allotted fate. The signs of their virtue are clear, and evil shall not cross their threshold.

All the spirits of Heaven shall declare their conduct most excellent—only the will of Heaven remains unknown. Thus, the virtuous writings of the good are inscribed on bamboo and silk, that future generations may be inspired to emulate virtuous households, securing honor for their descendants, who shall never depart from the halls of power. Emperors shall cherish them, keeping them in positions of goodness.

This merit arises naturally, born of their own blessings. Therefore, those who would do good must take this text as their model, for its words are proven true, not empty speech.

The Right [Section] states: "Filial piety halts rebellion, repels the barbarians, and makes those below obedient and easy to govern."

*Collated Text of the Scripture of Great Peace*, Scrolls 115–116, Geng Section 13–14
*Scripture of Great Peace*, Scroll 116

The Two Hundred and Fourth Formula (preceding text originally missing):

When hearts and intentions align, all becomes great joy. When hearts diverge and intentions clash, all becomes discord and error, giving rise to bitter qi. What need is there for song and dance to call it joy? All voices in harmony suffice. What need is there for strife and conflict to call it suffering? All manner of misfortune arising together suffices.

Mutual joy serves to suppress and sever punishment. Mutual sorrow and suffering serve to invite rebellion. What then is meant by harmonious alignment of hearts? Whenever people, great or small, share the same intention, there must be joy—how could it be otherwise? One ought to refine and examine this intention further. The Supreme Master of the Celestial August Cavern of Utmost Peace, speaking for Heaven, adds these words to further resolve its meaning.

Yet if one does not yet fully grasp the heart and intention of Heaven and Earth—something beneficial to the governance of the Emperor—then one ought to follow and employ the heart and intention of Heaven and Earth. One must not go against the Great Year or the various spirits, but rather unite and harmonize their qi with the affairs of the Emperor. Share the same joy, the same heart, the same direction, the same path, the same movement, the same pivot, the same root, and the same intention.

Thus, the sages of old established laws for the Emperor: in spring, the east; in summer, the south; in autumn, the west; in winter, the north. This is to act in concert with the qi of Heaven, for when qi is aligned, it naturally responds. This is what is meant by "carefully following the Dao of Heaven and sharing its qi." Thus, succession and compliance bring mutual joy. What is meant by "harmony and unity" is mutual joy. When there is mutual joy, Heaven and Earth remain perpetually pleased, without strife or anger. Without strife or anger, disasters, calamities, treachery, and all manner of evil vanish entirely. When evil people are eradicated, balanced qi arises. The balanced qi of Heaven descends to govern below, while the balanced qi of Earth ascends to assist above.

If, however, one does not follow and employ the qi that the August Emperor of Heaven and the Earth Goddess follow and employ, but instead neglects and abandons it, all will fall into error and rebellion—rebelling against the Dao of Heaven and Earth, rebelling against the qi of the Emperor, and diverging from the intentions of Heaven and Earth. Heaven and Earth will grow wrathful, myriad transformations will arise together, treachery and evil will flourish daily, leading to instability and imbalance. Ominous years and baleful qi will come—one must deeply understand this.

"Excellent! Excellent! This foolish student has heard your command."

"Is this clear? When Heaven rejoices, the Perfected One must be cautious."
"Yes, yes. I shall carefully record this and dare not forget. Excellent! Excellent! Since the Heavenly Illuminated Master has gone to such lengths, I wish to hear how this applies to spring, summer, autumn, and winter."
"All must follow their qi according to their proper measures. Only the sixth month, beginning on the day of the Summer Solstice, activates the *gong* tone, encompassing the entire fifth month. The sixth month is purely the *gong* tone. Moreover, when music arises, it manifests in song and dance. The kingly qi should be stirred—stirring reveals the joy of mutual accord and the assistance of offerings. The qi of rest, imprisonment, and death all desire stillness; they do not wish to be stirred. If stirred, they grow displeased and wrathful, and wrath gives rise to treachery, evil, and calamity. This is the natural pattern of Heaven and Earth—never deviating even once."
"Which qi should be stirred? I wish to hear this as a principle, that I may not oppose even a single qi."
"One must first stir the Emperor’s qi, then the kingly qi, then the ministerial qi, then the seasonal qi, and finally the subtle qi. These qi all advance before the Celestial Dipper each day, desiring to be roused and invigorated—thus they are stirred. The remaining qi lie behind the Celestial Dipper. What Heaven turns away from, its qi daily wanes, and thus should not be stirred. To act contrary to Heaven and oppose Earth is to defy the will of Heaven and Earth—hence, misfortune arises. Therefore, what Heaven favors must be invigorated, and what Heaven rejects must be abandoned. This is how one knows the seasonal qi, and from this, good and ill fortune, safety and peril, may be discerned."
"I ask: if only the five tones are stirred, and they are insufficient to form a complete song or dance, what then?"
"Excellent question! Simply begin by stirring. For in the interplay of yin and yang, movement produces sound. Thus, when music stirs, it always arises with sound. Yang has sound: the first is *gong*, the third *zhi*, the fifth *yu*, the seventh *shang*, and the ninth *jiao*. But the second, fourth, sixth, and eighth are not named tones. The punitive and the Greater Yin lack sound when activated—hence, they harm others with their lesser aspect. This is what it means to act without sound."
"Why then does the military advisor have sound?"
"Another excellent question! Indeed, the noble one’s military advisor has sound, but it is merely the prelude to music—there is no intent to harm. Only when wrath erupts and harm is imminent does sound arise from within, and no further words are exchanged. Do you understand?"
"Yes, yes."

"Truly so—now even the foolish and ignorant have awakened to this."

"Thus, the sages of antiquity, when preparing to employ music, would carry it on the left; when preparing to employ punishment, they would carry it on the right. Auspicious affairs honor the left, inauspicious affairs honor the right. The left pertains to yang, the right to yin. This is to say, each follows its own kind."

"Excellent! Excellent indeed!"

"Therefore, in my affairs of culture, I follow Heaven in intent and Earth in principle. Those who comply with this will find fortune and prosperity; those who defy it will meet misfortune. If one’s intent differs from Heaven, what else can be hoped for? Thus, Heaven possesses three qi: the upper qi is called *music*, the middle qi is called *harmony*, and the lower qi is called *punishment*. Music belongs to yang, punishment to yin, and harmony to the center. Therefore, the southeast—yang and music—favors life, while the northwest—yin and wrath—favors killing. The qi of harmony follows and circulates between them. It conceals and reveals itself, governing the avoidance of harm.
