Thus, music should only be used for auspicious affairs and matters of life; it must not be used for inauspicious affairs or matters of death. Heaven’s pattern and law are thus—it cannot be reversed. O true one, heed my words with care."

"Yes, yes."

"Now, in speaking of tones, you have only discussed one *jia*—this is far from exhaustive. How then should the rest be expressed so that all their correspondences may be fully known?"

"Indeed. One ought to collate the writings of sages and worthies, arranging them by school and category, so that their entries and exits, ascents and descents, great and small, all align without fail. From one, infer ten; from ten, infer a hundred; from a hundred, a thousand; from a thousand, ten thousand; from ten thousand, the boundless. When the many worthies deliberate together, nothing will be left ungrasped. Thus, I merely present the beginning for you and do not exhaust every detail. The superior person, upon seeing my text, will naturally grasp its meaning in full; the middling person, upon seeing it, may yet aspire to rise to that level; the petty person, upon seeing it, may take it as a model and act accordingly. Without transgressing the prohibitions of Heaven and Earth, each may cultivate good intentions of their own. To expound everything at once would only dazzle and confuse with excess, losing the guiding principles and rendering the text chaotic and hard to govern. Therefore, one should only reveal the beginning and allow them to ponder it themselves."

"Excellent! Excellent!"

"Go now. My discourse on this minor matter is concluded; if you have further doubts, return again."

"Yes, yes. May I ask: regarding the harmony of tones, can one know whether its intent is attained or not?"

"Indeed, it can be known. The *qi* of emperors and kings depends on their celestial numbers. When the *qi* of an emperor or king prevails, the sound of their teachings and commands issues forth first—this is like an emperor or king first issuing proclamations to the world, whereupon all people and things follow in obedience, and the world attains peace. If any dare disobey, it is rebellion, and they will die. Thus, when the *qi* of the emperor or king is first emitted, all else follows."

"Excellent! Excellent!"

"If, however, the *qi* of the emperor or king is not emitted first, and instead the *qi* of *xiu* or *qiu* is activated prematurely, forcing the *qi* of the emperor or king to follow, this is a grave act of rebellion. Such is the pattern and law of Heaven and Earth—it cannot be forced. Do you understand?"

"Yes, yes."

"Moreover, the five tones each have their own correspondences: some draw upon Heaven, some upon Earth, some upon the sun, moon, and stars, some upon the four seasons and five phases, some upon mountains and rivers, and some upon the people and the myriad things. When a tone is activated, all that it moves will be stirred, each yielding its own effects. Thus, when harmony is achieved and its intent is grasped, good is brought forth; when its intent is not grasped, evil arises. When tones are activated, the spirits of all things first come to pay homage before any movement occurs, revealing their forms. Therefore, when activating musical tones, one must always understand the matter at hand, carefully grasp its intent, and thereby bring about great peace, dispelling inauspicious *qi*. True one, consider this well."

"Yes, yes. May I ask: how do musical tones activate and draw forth their correspondences?"

"Excellent! Your question strikes at the essential meaning. Consider this: in spring, the first movement begins with the great horn string activating *jia*. When the *jia* day ascends, it draws forth Jupiter; when the Heart Star descends, it draws forth the Eastern Marchmount. The *qi* stirs the lesser yang, the tone stirs the phase of Wood, the spirit stirs Gou Mang, the creature stirs the Azure Dragon, the position draws forth the Green Emperor, and the spirits summon the green-robed jade maidens. From the highest to the lowest, all come to pay homage in kind, delighting in the musical tone. By explaining one to seek its kind, the possibilities are endless. Examine the essential meaning with care, and you will grasp it all. Align it with ordinary texts and writings to form a model. Thus, in music, those who grasp its highest intent may transcend the world; those who grasp its middling intent may bring about peace and eliminate misfortune; those who grasp its lowest intent may bring joy to people. Those who attain its highest intent may bring joy to the spirits; those who attain its middling intent may bring joy to the essences; those who attain its lowest intent may bring joy to the body. When all grasp its intent, emperors and kings may wander without cares, music arises and punishments cease, and spirits and essences are satiated."

"I wish to hear the secret of how music arises and punishments cease."

"Excellent, your words are apt. Now, music is the essence of the great yang; punishment is the essence of the great yin. When yang flourishes, yin submits; when yin flourishes, yang submits. Thus, when music flourishes, punishments vanish. Why is music yang and punishment yin? When tones are harmonious, their direction is harmonious and good; when tones are disharmonious, their direction is inauspicious and evil. At the proper time, listen carefully to the tones. Those who know tones know all matters of good and ill fortune; those who do not know tones cannot know these things either. Yang moves and has sound; yin is silent. Thus, punishments often harm through yin. The sages of old, when following music, aligned with the intent of Heaven and Earth. Those who comply meet good fortune; those who defy meet misfortune. Thus, Heaven possesses three *qi*: the upper *qi* is called *music*, the middle *qi* is called *harmony*, and the lower *qi* is called *punishment*. Music belongs to yang, punishment to yin, and harmony to the center. Therefore, the southeast—yang—favors life, while the northwest—yin—favors killing. The *qi* of harmony follows and circulates between them, concealing and revealing itself to govern the avoidance of harm. Tones are the speech of music. Whether divining near or far, all must be aligned. The day, hour, surname, and given name, the divisions of boundaries, the waxing and waning of influences—all are taken together to form the discourse. Those with keen perception will hear without error."

"Excellent! Excellent!"

"May I ask how music is used to dispel disasters, treachery, and malevolence, modeling the numbers after the patterns of Heaven and Earth? Should the Emperor, adjusting to dawn or dusk, shake the musical instruments and begin the chant to dissolve the *qi* of sorrow and suffering, thereby bringing about great peace?"

"Excellent is your inquiry into the method—how truly refined! Does the August Heaven, long afflicted by disasters, pity the Emperor’s sorrows and send a Perfected One to resolve all doubts? Very well, very well. Be seated, for I dare not conceal anything. To hide the truth would risk Heaven’s censure, subjecting me to prolonged and heavy punishment, shortening my celestial years. Sit calmly and listen closely, as I shall distinguish and explain its profound meaning for you.

The Dao of Heaven is like a cycle, ever revolving and returning to its beginning. When music arises, it must be applied in accordance with the *qi* of the ruling phase, aligning with the position of the Dipper’s handle. The sound resonates in the direction it points, and the tones are activated. People may chant along, each using their own pitch. The numbers follow the six *jia* stems and the five phases. The five and six of *jia* and the five phases—these are the numbers of Heaven and Earth. The *qi* of the seasons is what Heaven and Earth respond to and act upon.

For example, on the day of *Lichun* (Beginning of Spring), when the Dipper points to *yin*, it is called the time of the Supreme Thearch. First, the great horn is sounded. At the midpoint of the month, when it aligns with *jia*, in the second month when the Dipper points to *mao*, and at the midpoint with *yi*, in the third month when it points to *chen*—proceed likewise for the rest. Each follows the *qi* of its season, adjusting for dawn or dusk in its measures.

First, sound the Emperor’s tone and the Emperor’s string; next, the King’s tone and the King’s string; then the Minister’s tone and the Minister’s string; then the Candidate’s tone and the Candidate’s string; and finally, the *zhi* tone and the *zhi* string, each in their proper sequence. This is called ‘receiving Heaven’s teaching and aligning with Earth’s *qi*.’ If Heaven and Earth themselves delight in and employ it, how much more so for humans? Humans are the most honored of all beings, the children of Heaven. When people reverently and respectfully apply these numbers, Heaven delights in them; when they act with caution and compliance, Earth delights in them. This is like a filial child following the teachings of their parents—how could the parents not love and favor them?

Now, Heaven has sent you to ask these questions. As I serve as Heaven’s spokesperson, charged with establishing the numbers for great peace above, I dare not omit anything. I fear the censure of Heaven and Earth and dare not deceive the Perfected Ones or conceal anything. Only when not asked do I remain silent; when questioned, I speak. Seeing the Perfected One inquire so earnestly, I know Heaven wishes to communicate, so I explain it fully for you. If you grasp this Dao, ponder its meaning deeply and transmit it to later generations, so they may model it and thereby dispel all manner of disasters. Above, this will pacify the *qi* of Heaven and Earth; below, it will assist the Emperor in governance. It will settle the hearts of all people, preventing them from straying into wrongdoing, and allow the twelve thousand beings to each find their proper place. Is this not joyous indeed?"

"Great indeed! Great indeed!"

"The Perfected Ones may truly be said to understand."

"May I ask about the affairs of the six caves and eight directions—what is most auspicious and good, and what is most inauspicious and evil?"

"Excellent is your inquiry. Listen closely, and I shall explain its meaning. What is most harmonious and joyful is good and auspicious; what is most contrary and sorrowful is inauspicious and evil.

Harmony and joy produce good sounds; opposition and sorrow produce inauspicious sounds. Thus, music is joy alone. Harmonious joy is good joy, and only in auspicious matters may music be made. In inauspicious matters, there must be no music; if there is, it is called ‘joy,’ but misfortune will multiply.

Therefore, when the *qi* of the Emperor, the King, or the subtle *qi* aligns with the Dipper’s position, it is auspicious. What Heaven and Earth delight in, they wish to bring forth; what they share, they employ together. Thus, one should rejoice in, comply with, and prosper such times. The *qi* of decline and desolation is what Heaven and Earth jointly abandon and weaken, so it should be set aside and not celebrated with music. To make music against the will of Heaven and Earth is called ‘great rebellion,’ failing to align with the *qi* of the seasons. The *qi* of the seasons is the proper *qi* of Heaven.

Heaven and Earth take this as their model: the *qi* of prosperity and ascendancy governs great peace, while the *qi* of imprisonment, desolation, and severance governs inauspicious years. The *qi* of prosperity and ascendancy generates much life and many good things. Thus, in years of great peace, all things flourish, and good things abound—this is clear evidence, the great effect of Heaven and Earth. The signs of Heaven and Earth’s delight in goodness extend to the people and the myriad beings; this is the great proof and verification.

Thus, the sages and worthies of old deeply examined and compared themselves, knowing the success or failure of their conduct. They clearly understood how to compare like kinds, like affairs, and like *qi*. When they obtained the image of a like *qi* or kind, they would reform their nature and change their conduct, daring not to do wrong. The language of Heaven and Earth is revealed through these effects, not through direct speech. By observing the images and kinds obtained, one may know for themselves.

The *qi* of imprisonment, desolation, death, and severance generates little and accomplishes no good. Thus, in inauspicious years, little is born, no good responses occur, and no good things appear—this is their shared affair and shared *qi*. Therefore, those who would bring about great peace may fully employ music, for music aligns with and delights in the *qi* of prosperity, bringing balance. But in years of misfortune, one must not make music or initiate it without cause. The *qi* of imprisonment and desolation opposes Heaven and Earth, so in inauspicious years and matters, music must not be made.

Thus, the *qi* of prosperity and ascendancy is where virtue resides; the *qi* of imprisonment and desolation is where punishment resides.

In inauspicious years, there are few good responses. Therefore, those who would bring about great peace must align their music with the *qi* of prosperity. In inauspicious years, music must not be made without cause, for the *qi* of imprisonment and desolation opposes Heaven and Earth—hence, misfortune. The *qi* of prosperity is where virtue resides; imprisonment and desolation are where punishment resides."

Thus, a ruler of virtue who cherishes life is enabled by Heaven to make music; a ruler without virtue is not permitted to make music. This is the clear evidence of Heaven. Does the Perfected One understand this?

"Indeed, indeed. How profound! Today, having fully inquired of the Heavenly Illuminated Master, I now fully grasp the intent of Heaven’s music. Before this inquiry, I thought making music was but a trivial matter—something any ordinary person could do at any time. Now, having asked, I shall never again dare to act recklessly."

"Excellent, discerning student! You may be said to comprehend the principles of the texts and have grasped the intent of Heaven. When Great Peace arrives, all baleful *qi* will depart."

"I humbly request to further clarify what still perplexes me."

"Go ahead, speak plainly without reservation."

"Indeed, indeed. Now, the *qi* of Heaven and Earth is half in ascendancy and half in repose—like day and night, without ceasing. Can music truly be made all day long? Or should it only be made in the direction of ascendancy, when the *qi* of prosperity prevails?"

"When first making music, it is because the Emperor-King begins—never does one begin with the *qi* of repose. The year is thus, the month is thus, the day is thus, the hour is thus."

"Though this student has yet to fully grasp the meaning, if one wishes to make music in a year, when the year resides in the east at *mao*, one makes music in the second month of spring. If one wishes to make music in a month, one aligns it with that month; for a day, with the day of ascendancy; for an hour, with the hour of ascendancy. In this way, one may be said to have attained the Dao of Heaven, and baleful *qi* will depart. If one does not act thus, it disrupts the heavenly order, and misfortune arises. Therefore, the sage-kings of antiquity, deeply understanding the intent of Heaven and Earth, dared not make music during inauspicious affairs. When inauspicious affairs encounter music, those inauspicious affairs daily increase and multiply, growing beyond remedy—thus, one must not make music then.

Heaven bestows nature, each with its own spirit. When one delights in goodness, the spirit of goodness arrives; when one delights in evil, the spirit of evil arrives. This is the natural disposition—nothing strange about it. Only the foolish fail to ponder this deeply."

"Excellent! Excellent!"

The Perfected One, wishing to know its great efficacy, may compare it to the Dao of Heaven. All that is pure and clear delights in returning to Heaven; all that is heavy and turbid delights in returning to Earth—each follows its own home, and none can be faulted for this. Thus, delighting in goodness brings goodness; delighting in misfortune brings misfortune, just as water flows downward and fire rises upward, not erring by even a fraction. The Perfected One entrusts this text to a ruler of virtue to show to ordinary people. Now that the *qi* of Great Peace has arrived, Heaven promotes goodness, causing all to delight in it, so there must no longer be those who, without reason, delight in misfortune. Those who delight in misfortune make enemies of Heaven and bring blame upon Earth—their transgressions cannot be erased. Today, those in Heaven call such people great rebels. Heaven’s baleful *qi* and all the faults within Earth will descend and converge upon them."

"May I ask: in urgent matters, when music must be made, and one performs auspicious music, but there is no time to wait for the hour of ascendancy—such as when battle is joined before the royal domain—what is to be done?"

"Excellent, your question grasps the essential point! In such cases, have the musicians remain in the royal domain, and if they cannot, have the musicians among the common people face the royal domain and petition it, using the same tones and the same measures. If only the person’s name and given name are known, and one holds to the pitch-pipes and calendrical reckoning so that the tones and *qi* correspond, one may also follow the *qi* of the hour of ascendancy and have that person perform the music—this too is permissible. In this way, all accords with the teachings of Heaven and Earth, preventing calamity. If one does not act thus, and the *qi* aligns with that of baleful prisoners, all manner of misfortune will arise. Moreover, when raising voices in song or leading music, one must also do so with the auspicious—auspicious tones and good deeds. The *qi* of the hour of ascendancy is like a ruler among men; it does not wish to hear of misfortune, baleful words, or inauspicious sounds. The reason is that the *qi* of the hour of ascendancy serves as the agent of August Heaven, presiding over life and bringing good deeds to fruition, thereby aiding Heaven in generating and completing all things. Evil sounds and baleful deeds do not aid Heaven in generating and completing all things. Thus, the *qi* of ascendancy does not wish to delight in hearing them, nor does the *qi* before battle. Therefore, the sage-kings of antiquity accumulated only good words and good deeds, never admitting baleful or evil matters. Such words were called ‘ominous speech,’ and the penalty was immediate execution. Even if the offense did not warrant death, they were killed simply for uttering ominous and inauspicious words. Perfected One, do you understand the severity of this prohibition?"

"Indeed, indeed. How excellent!"

"Excellent indeed!"

"You who understand early will long endure; those who do not understand become the root of death."

1. First, align with and delight in the *qi* of Heaven and Earth and the four seasons’ imperial *qi*. For every act, triple the joy to please Heaven, so that Heaven is greatly pleased. The emperor and kings enjoy long life, evil omens vanish, and celestial disasters are all dispelled. The *qi* of the sun does not rage in battle, and the realm remains at peace. Those who know to first move in accord with and delight in this *qi*—the Dao of Heaven prospers for them, true spirits emerge for them, and even those dwelling in hidden caves all gladly come to aid the right. How wondrous!

2. Second, first align with and delight in the *qi* of Heaven and Earth and the four seasons’ kingly *qi*. Double the joy to please Earth, so that Earth’s *qi* is greatly pleased and does not rage in battle. The ruler enjoys long life, treacherous thieves and weapons of war dissolve, and the realm flourishes in goodness. Below, all gladly submit to their superiors; the worthy emerge from the midst to aid in governing the state. Earth spirits comply in nurturing—how wondrous!

3. Third, first align with and delight in the *qi* of ascendancy and the subtle *qi*, so that the *qi* of harmony is greatly pleased. Ruler and ministers, the people—all act with reverence, each preserving their place. Thus, flattery, deceit, and theft do not arise, and the borders are secure. As harmonious *qi* daily grows, kingly *qi* is born, and all things incline toward goodness.

4. Take care never to move or delight in the *qi* of death and destruction, lest it invite violent thieves and many sudden deaths. The realm will be constantly imperiled, hard to pacify, and plagued by malevolent *qi* and spirits, causing grave harm. When this grows severe, it is called chaos and disturbance. The *qi* of extreme yin brings rebellion—beware, beware!

5. Do not move or delight in the *qi* of imprisonment and decline, lest it multiply thieves, prisoners, and legal cases, with punishments proliferating and peace difficult to achieve. The people will harm one another, resulting in many chronic illnesses.

6. Do not move or delight in the *qi* of decline and cessation, lest it produce many ailing and infirm people. It also breeds cunning and deceit, with people cheating one another, much slanderous speech, the realm lacking wealth, and the people mired in poverty.

Delight in the three upper divisions—the imperial, kingly, and subtle *qi*—and Heaven, Earth, and humanity will be pleased, bringing timely rains and dispelling disasters. This is called aligning with the good *qi* of Heaven, Earth, and humanity to bring forth good deeds. Delighting in the three lower divisions—the *qi* of death, destruction, imprisonment, decline, and cessation—invites calamities and rebellions. Heaven sends rain out of season, and malevolent harms abound, impossible to prevent. If these abandoned *qi* are stirred and delighted in, evil *qi* will burst forth in great measure. The wise and learned will hide, officials will fail in governance, the people and ministers will be hard to rule, and affairs will multiply in chaos. One cannot but guard against this—beware, beware!

All matters under Heaven and Earth have their fixed and constant laws. Where *qi* resides, one should face the honored and wish to see joy in places devoid of *qi*. Those in decline or near death should not be exposed to joy.

Thus, delighting in goodness is called "compliant governance" in Heaven; delighting in evil is called "rebellious decree." Compliant governance gains Heaven’s power; rebellious decrees incur Heaven’s enmity. Those who gain Heaven’s power attain longevity; those who incur Heaven’s enmity meet with misfortune. Why is this so? Heaven’s governance is like an echo—it does not wrest away what one cherishes. Delight in goodness and gain goodness; delight in evil and gain evil—what more need be said? Good and evil, safety and peril each follow their kind, never failing. Only fools do not consider this.

Thus, those who delight in the Dao gather the Dao; those who delight in virtue gather virtue; those who delight in martial arts gather martial prowess; those who delight in uprightness gather uprightness; those who delight in evil gather evil. Has it ever been otherwise?

Therefore, I have deeply pondered Heaven’s laws to warn you, Perfected One. How wondrous—Heaven’s laws must not be violated! Thus, I earnestly admonish you."

"Indeed, indeed."

The reason for tripling the joy in the imperial *qi* when delighting in the worthy is that imperial *qi* is most honored and supreme, symbolizing Heaven’s reverence—hence, it is tripled in joy. Heaven governs and controls Earth and humanity, so it is tripled to symbolize Heaven, Earth, and humanity. When Heaven, Earth, and humanity are seen to delight in and promote order, all things find their place, and auspicious signs and good omens—twelve thousand in number—all emerge in full. Thus, one first delights in them.

When delighting in them, one should listen attentively with single-minded focus, sit upright in prolonged contemplation, and feel joy in the heart, utterly content. Be loyal, sincere, and utterly without ill intent—like sitting before the emperor, not daring to act perversely. Heaven responds to such conduct: evil omens, disasters, and harms all depart without exception. Rely on Heaven as the honored, on imperial *qi* as the authority, and naturally follow Heaven’s laws—thus, achieving great peace is not difficult."

"Excellent! Excellent!"

"As for doubling the *qi* of kingship in joyous music, the *qi* of kingship resembles Earth. Earth dwells alongside humanity, thus its joy is doubled—this is the joy of Earth. When Earth and humanity are seen to delight and rejoice, all things are properly ordered.

[Moreover,] tripling the *qi* of emperorship in joyous music is because the *qi* of emperorship is most honored and supreme, resembling Heaven’s supremacy, thus its joy is multiplied. The twelve thousand things all arise, and auspicious *qi* fully responds.

As for doubling the *qi* of ministers in joyous music, the *qi* of ministers resembles Earth, and Earth dwells alongside humanity, thus its joy is doubled—Earth and humanity dwell together. When all people are seen to delight and rejoice, all things are properly ordered. Yet Earth is lowly, so its joy is less than Heaven’s."

"Excellent! Excellent!"

"Furthermore, the *qi* of kingship is weaker than the *qi* of emperorship, lower by one rank, thus its joy is diminished. The principle of hierarchy follows naturally."

"Excellent! Excellent!"

"As for the single performance of music for the *qi* of ministers and the subtle *qi*, the *qi* of ministers and subtle *qi* resemble the harmonious person. The harmonious person is lower than Heaven and Earth, thus their joy is less. Humanity governs the ordering of all things under Heaven and Earth; when people delight, they rejoice and do good, and when they do good, all things are ordered. If people do not delight, they do evil, and when they do evil, all things turn inauspicious."

"Excellent! Excellent!"

"Moreover, humanity is the chief of the harmonious ordering of all things. When the chief delights and orders rightly, all things are well-ordered; when the chief is disordered, all things fall into chaos. Thus, one first delights in the chief to follow the Dao of joyfully aligning Heaven, Earth, and humanity."

"Excellent! Excellent!"

"Therefore, the most honored and virtuous *qi* of supreme goodness is celebrated with tripled joy to delight in virtue. Thus, when the ancient emperors and kings governed well and aligned with Heaven’s will, they attained multiplied joy—this is clear proof. Now, as the *qi* of Great Peace arrives, we are taught to cultivate joy. When the *qi* of decline and chaos corresponds to inauspicious years, joy must not be cultivated; if one cultivates joy, it is called ‘joy in inauspicious decline,’ and Heaven names it ‘great rebellion’—the root of disasters and the source of calamities. How can one not be cautious?"

"Excellent! Excellent!"

Thus, the next level of joy is doubled, for the *qi* of kings does not match that of emperors, and so their joy is lesser. Therefore, when governance is only slightly virtuous, joy correspondingly diminishes. The reason for this diminution is that the *qi* is weak and not supremely good, so one dare not indulge in excessive joy. With inauspicious *qi* present, one dare not fully express joy—this is like a household with seven virtues and three vices, where the heart cannot rejoice wholeheartedly.

"Excellent! Excellent!"

"In a case of seven virtues and three vices, where good outweighs evil, can one rest content in joy? Though the human heart may rejoice, it constantly recalls the three vices, preventing pure joy—this is the nature of Heaven. Only when virtue is complete, with not a single worry, can there be great joy. Thus, joy is for delighting in virtue, not for delighting in misfortune."

"Excellent! Excellent!"

"My words are the Heavenly luminous contract, not a single character is amiss. Therefore, the next level of joy is but a single expression, for the *qi* of ministers is faint and offers little stability. Human virtue is at its weakest, not matching the *qi* of Heaven and Earth. Thus, being faint and not equaling Heaven and Earth, their joy is diminished. The *qi* of ministers is subtle and sparse in its transformations. Within the central kingdom, evil often outweighs good, so one dare not fully express joy. To do so would be called ‘rejoicing in misfortune and evil.’ Since virtue is scarce, joy is scarce. The reason for this scarcity is that one only delights in the good within, not daring to rejoice in the misfortune and evil within. Rejoicing in misfortune and evil is like a petty person with seven vices and three virtues—only the three virtues allow for three moments of joy. With seven vices, there are sevenfold sorrows and afflictions. How can one find contentment in joy? The principle here is that ten is divided into three parts. The *qi* of emperors is entirely good in all ten parts; the *qi* of kings has two parts good and one part evil; the *qi* of ministers has two parts evil and one part good."

Thus, the *qi* of emperors mirrors Heaven, which constantly delights in life, harbors no harmful intent, and desires to bestow blessings. The Three Sovereigns emulated this, ever purely good and kind, without evil or harmful intent. Heaven is like the Three Sovereigns, and the Three Sovereigns are like Heaven. Therefore, the supremely good person has not a single vice, only ever desiring to do good. Does this not mirror Heaven? Does it not mirror the true spirit?

"Excellent! Excellent!"

The *qi* of kings mirrors Earth, which constantly nurtures and favors virtue. The Five Emperors emulated this. Though Earth’s nurturing is called ‘killing,’ the Five Emperors still employed punishments.

"Excellent! Excellent!"

The faint *qi* of ministers mirrors humanity, which has no constant principle and frequently changes. The Three Kings emulated this, having no fixed laws. Harmonious *qi* shifts and alters, sometimes advancing, sometimes retreating, so there is no constancy in high or low. When harmony encounters firmness, it follows; when it encounters softness, it also follows—thus, it has no constancy. The *qi* of decline, death, imprisonment, and ruin mirrors the myriad things, endlessly changing and disordered, with no regular pattern of emergence or withdrawal. The Five Hegemons emulated this, their *qi* chaotic and inauspicious, so they could not possess joy. The nature of Heaven and Earth is to delight in virtue, not to delight in evil. The martial power of Heaven and Earth is for punishing evil, not for punishing good. The laws of Heaven and Earth cannot be reversed.

[Appendix]
The joy of imperial *qi* is emulated by the Three Sovereigns, who are like Heaven. The joy of kingly *qi* is modeled by the Five Emperors, who mirror Earth, favoring virtue and nurturing all things, yet occasionally resorting to punishment. The faint *qi* is emulated by the Three Kings, who have no constant laws. The *qi* of decline, imprisonment, and ruin is emulated by the Five Hegemons, whose *qi* is chaotic. The martial power of Heaven and Earth is for punishing evil and upholding good—this must be deeply examined.

"Excellent! Excellent! I ask to inquire about the meaning of ‘joy for delighting in virtue.’ I wish to hear the great secret, so that even the dull-witted may fully understand and dare not ask further. May I hear it?"

"Do you yourself not yet understand?"

"I have gained some small understanding. Yet I fear that people of later ages, long sunk in ignorance and confusion, even if given these texts, may still not comprehend and may again violate Heaven’s prohibitions. Thus, I dare not refrain from asking for the great secret that is easy to know."

"Excellent are your words, for you have grasped their meaning. Very well."

"When seated in peace, one may then begin to understand.

Now, in years of supreme goodness and great joy, all the myriad things give rise to goodness, and every person rejoices, their hearts constantly filled with joy and longing to sing and dance. People silently love one another, without contention or strife, and joy arises of itself. Above and below, none harm or oppress each other, and all delight together. Thus, joy arises from goodness and delights in goodness—Heaven causes this to be so naturally."

"Excellent! Excellent!"

"In years of great misfortune, not a single thing is good. Every person suffers from hunger and cold, wailing and weeping, harming and oppressing one another. Silently, sorrow, suffering, resentment, and anger arise, and their hearts know no joy. How could they sing, dance, or find delight? Silently, they wither and perish. Thus, in years of misfortune and calamity, there is no joy—Heaven causes this to be so naturally. This is clear evidence that Heaven does not delight in misfortune and evil.

Therefore, joy is born of delighting in goodness, while martial power arises from misfortune and calamity. Thus, when the ancient emperors and kings were about to rise, they received the response of joy and goodness; when they were about to decline, they received the response of evil. This is the natural law.

Thus, joy gives rise to goodness, and goodness gives rise to joy; misfortune and calamity give rise to martial power, and martial power gives rise to misfortune; non-action gives rise to joy, and joy gives rise to non-action; martial power gives rise to chaos, and chaos gives rise to martial power; joy gives rise to song and dance, and song and dance give rise to joy; misfortune and evil give rise to sorrow and suffering, and sorrow and suffering give rise to misfortune and evil.

Through this text, may people of later ages reflect upon and delight in it. Here, the explanation of the secret comes to a close."

"Excellent! Excellent!"

To the right: *"Arising"*—the five musical tones, when properly activated in sequence, align with the intentions of Heaven, Earth, and humanity to bring about Great Peace, eliminate disasters, suppress villainy, and usher in harmonious qi. Here ends the great secret. Untitled [Preserved]

*"Arising"*: The virtuous in my writings all possess azure heads and cinnabar eyes—why is this? My Dao is the true manifestation of cinnabar and azure. Azure embodies life and benevolence, possessing a heart; red is the great yang, the correct color of Heaven.

Here ends my Dao—the Dao of great yang and benevolent governance, which seeks no harm.

Untitled [Preserved]
**Question:** Now that the qi of the Supreme August Peace has fully arrived, what should be the order of governance between Heaven and Earth? May we hear of it?
**Answer:** Today, Heaven above establishes the model: for the joyful, follow with joy; for the suffering, follow with suffering. Such is Heaven’s model when the qi of Great Peace arrives. Thus, Heaven above follows joy to comply and serve it, urgently abolishing weapons and halting punishments. The same applies to Earth below. Joy is yang, the constant of Heaven; weapons, punishments, and warfare are yin, the wrath of Earth. When yin rises, it must harm yang’s transformation.

Now that the qi of Great Peace has arrived, Heaven and the divine soldiers govern together, thus severing punishments, weapons, and litigations, making all things clear and bright, never again to be recklessly disturbed. All shall be as the sun and moon, which cannot long remain hidden. When primordial qi naturally delights, it unites to generate Heaven and Earth; when pleased, yin and yang harmonize, and wind and rain are regulated. When wind and rain are regulated, they jointly generate the twelve thousand things. When all things delight, auspicious omens emerge together, and the responses of the myriad beings ascend as essence to Heaven, making the Three Luminaries ever more radiant. When the Three Luminaries delight and unite, the four seasons proceed in order: spring delights in birth, summer in growth, autumn in harvest, and winter in storage. When the four seasons rejoice, the Five Phases do not rebel, and the people flourish. When the people flourish, the emperor’s longevity is secured; when the emperor is long-lived, the common people rejoice; when the common people rejoice, spectral beings and malevolent spirits submit. When spectral malevolence submits, there are no premature deaths or illnesses; without harm to people, the qi of Great Peace arrives. The myriad states cease warfare, and thieves, bandits, and deceit vanish. The sixty thousand spirits of Heaven and Earth all rejoice, and the true immortals of Heaven and Earth emerge. When the true immortals of Heaven and Earth emerge, upright qi fully manifests while perverse qi wholly conceals itself. Evil people all sit in self-reflection, while the virtuous act; divine scriptures and strategies are revealed in full, and false, deceptive texts perish. None fail to rejoice and delight, as yin and yang harmonize and unite as one family, begetting one another. In all matters, joy brings no evil.

When yin and yang delight, it is the beginning of life, the origin from which the myriad things receive their mandate and arise—all resembling humanity. When men and women delight, they unite in heart and generate together, with nothing left unaccomplished. Without joy, they refuse to unite in harmony; if forced to unite in anger and displeasure, misfortune follows. My writings here merely outline the great principles, revealing the beginning of transforming the unvirtuous through joy—how could their full extent be recorded?

Having understood the goodness of joy, but not yet the prohibitions of its absence, I shall further expound its guiding principles: when dispirited and unwilling to join forces and unite in heart to co-generate primordial qi, they violate nature. When primordial qi is naturally displeased with contention, it cannot harmonize the body and unite in virtue to co-generate Heaven and Earth. When Heaven and Earth are displeased, yin and yang contend, unable to harmonize qi, regulate the four seasons and Five Phases, adjust wind and rain, or abundantly generate the twelve thousand things. When the twelve thousand things contend in displeasure, many are injured or die, and the year is greatly inauspicious. In all matters, contention without joy causes the Three Luminaries to lose their brightness, the emperor to grieve, and the people to flee. Virtuous qi is concealed, while malevolent qi prevails; upright spirits depart, and demonic beings arise. The myriad beings and people die prematurely, without longevity. When the twelve thousand states contend in displeasure, punishments surge, and warfare spreads; joy is severed and abandoned, and punishments escalate. When the six directions are disharmonious, each day brings misfortune. Heaven’s qi becomes disordered, beginning from this. Yet people, unaware of its cause, instead blame their superiors and hold the emperor accountable. Failing to recognize the great fault, they reverse the order, blaming above for what lies below, wholly inverting qi—how can Great Peace be achieved? Instead, misfortune ensues, punishments daily increase, and joy perishes. The blame lies with the teachings of the Middle Antiquity, where instructors repeatedly opened the gates of warfare and closed the doors of joy, allowing villainy to arise, impossible to swiftly suppress. The great fault lies here.

Thus, today the penetrating qi of Great Peace descends from above, greatly indulging joy and abolishing punishments. The same applies to Earth below—I cannot record it all. The goodness of indulging joy, the evil of indulging joy.

Therefore, the Dao of yin and yang extends from Heaven above to Earth below, spreading boundlessly. The male and female kinds frolic and delight in one another, then unite in heart to co-generate, co-accomplish, co-govern, transmit the legacy of Heaven and Earth, and wield the art of the infinite. If they do not frolic, refuse to unite in heart, and decline to co-generate, co-accomplish, co-govern, transmit the legacy of Heaven and Earth, or wield the art of the infinite, even if forced together through punishments and threats, they will eventually fail. Turning against one another in contention, yin and yang mutually harm and destroy, impossible to restrain. Even if father and son, mother and child, husband and wife—those most intimately bound—meet in harm, they jointly disrupt the Dao of Heaven, and no generation will endure. Such are the consequences of this great fault.

The music of joy is the warp of Heaven, the essence of the Great Yang. Filial piety is the warp of Earth, the essence of the Great Yin. Thus, joy initiates, gives life, and unites to accomplish success. Heaven ever delights in good and joyful generation, therefore it ever harmonizes with Heaven and shares its qi. Only when joy unites can mutual generation arise, and then there is above and below. Thus, joy belongs to Heaven and is above; filial piety, as Earth’s likeness, is below. Earth, being below, bears and obeys what is above; yin serves yang, children serve their fathers, ministers serve their lords. The lord above serves Heaven, and Earth likewise serves Heaven. Heaven serves what is above it, thus sharing qi with Earth. Therefore, joy and filial piety most accord with Heaven and Earth.

The *Yi* (Changes) governs the qi of yin and yang, with the eight winds as its measures, sharing position with the six jia, yin and yang as one body, joined in form with Heaven and Earth—thus it is the numinous Dao. Punishment, however, severs and hollows yin’s struggle, the qi of disharmony, and thus ever arises following yin’s measures. Punishment, when it meets yin, intensifies; when it meets spring and summer, it submits; when it meets autumn and winter, it flourishes. Thieves and bandits rise at night; wickedness and perversity act in dark and hidden places; ghosts, spirits, and all maladies erupt in darkness; resentments and grievances gather in perilous straits to slay one another. This is the great proof that joy does not follow punishment—can one not be cautious?

The foolish student fears this.
You who know fear—this is the sign of longevity. Those who do not know fear—this is the gate of misfortune. I warn you: be cautious.

Thus, in governing above, Heaven ever lets joy flow as the root of transformation. It causes all people to delight together in transformation, to sit and reflect on their faults and gains—how could doing good be difficult? Such is Heaven’s governance above, and so it is below on Earth. Therefore, those who wish to swiftly pacify governance must first cut off contention and punishment, and initiate joy—then the qi of imperial peace will immediately arrive.

May I ask: when the qi of Great Peace from above arrives in its time, all people will naturally transform into goodness, and the myriad things will naturally be at peace and free from illness. Now, Heaven above sets the model—why then does it rely on people to initiate it, creating joy to transform one another?

All matters lie in their beginning—one must guide and teach them. Good and evil are the forerunners of transformation, the opening of the gate for the ignorant and foolish. Thus, when Heaven is about to act, it always first initiates the beginning, and its sign appears in the heavens, divine patterns emerge. The sages of antiquity modeled their intentions upon these. Therefore, the Three Sovereigns above taught transformation through the Dao, and their people were all possessed of the Dao—so too were the myriad things. The Five Emperors taught transformation largely through virtue, and their people largely followed the warp of virtue—so too were the myriad things. The Three Kings taught transformation largely through culture, and their people were largely cultured—so too were the myriad things. The Five Hegemons taught transformation largely through martial power, and their people were largely martial, prone to anger, prizing strength and valor—this is not the beginning of complete transformation.

Thus, in the villages of good people, there are many good people; in the villages of evil people, there are many evil people—this is not interchangeable. All matters above in Heaven and below on Earth each have their own models and methods, each modeling their teachers’ methods, and what they transform all resembles one another. Heaven loves to give life and bring forth things, but if things are not joyful, they will not willingly live. Now, the qi of the Supreme Peace of the Great Cavern’s extremity has all emerged to govern, the essence of yang flourishes and rises, and the myriad things are all joyful and delighted. Therefore, one must model this qi and greatly let joy flow, to accord with and assist the Dao of Heaven—if one delights in this, then the Dao of Heaven is greatly pleased. Now, when emperors and kings govern with peace, the people are long-lived, so they let joy flow to serve the Dao of Heaven, and cause each to sit and reflect on self-transformation—what faults could there be?

Moreover, joy is Heaven, the essence of yang. When yang is present, the essence of yin submits—just as spring and summer arise, and autumn and winter submit, this is the natural pattern. The Perfected One must follow the words of my book, and punishment will naturally cease. To transform in this way is no different from the divine. Thus, if governance is difficult to pacify, it is because transformation has been lost.

Now, the Dao of Heaven naturally has decline and prosperity, good and ill fortune—why then do you speak of the beginning of transformation by teachers?

Heaven and Earth do not speak with people, so from time to time they give birth to sages, to sagely teachers, to transmit their affairs. When the times of Heaven are auspicious and joyful, good teachers are born to speak good words and enact good transformation. When the Dao of Heaven is about to fall into chaos, ill fortune, and decline, evil teachers are born to teach evil transformation. This is the sign that transformation governs the Dao of Heaven, and that it naturally brings forth good or evil.

Moreover, in years of joy, good things are born in abundance, the five grains mature to feed people, and those people delight in goodness. When the times of Heaven are evil, evil things are born in abundance, good things are few, and evil things feed people—those people’s countenances are evil. This is the clear sign of the teachers who transform people. Thus, when good teachers emerge, evil teachers submit—this is the sign of Heaven’s prosperity and decline, and that it governs Heaven.

Now, the Dao of Heaven has completed its great cycle, so it has sent me down to speak well of the Perfected One’s good affairs, to make joyful transformation the highest good, and thus to teach the first matter. When Heaven’s cycle is complete, its affairs are fully prepared, and all must be joyful. You who understand this principle—if all people and things are complete and present, there is joy in their homes. Now, Heaven’s cycle is complete—what is there not to delight in? How could one speak of ill fortune? This book will not change for ten thousand generations—such is the transformation of Heaven above!

*Comprehensive Collated Edition of the Scripture of Great Peace*, Scroll 117, Geng Section 15
*Scripture of Great Peace*, Scroll 117
"Heaven’s Joy Obtains Good People: Text Entrusted to the Fire Lord," Section 207

Now, the Perfected One has accumulated goodness and is worthy, understanding all matters. The qi of the Supreme Peace of the Great Cavern above has fully arrived—does the Perfected One also know what Heaven above urgently desires?

This humble student is foolish and dull, unable to comprehend—only the Heavenly Master knows.

Go, all Perfected Ones, sit at ease, and I will fully explain it to you. Now, Heaven above delights in obtaining good people, who can regulate wind and rain and bring forth all common things.

Since the initial opening of Heaven and Earth, those among humankind who practice goodness have been few—fewer still are those who align with Heaven’s intent. This has long been Heaven’s constant sorrow, for now there are none on earth who meet Heaven’s requirements.

Why does Heaven above not generate its own people, instead taking them from those on earth?
All things born of Heaven and Earth arise from the union of two as one. Now, the Heaven above and the Earth below form such a union. Every yang birth must occur within yin, and thus it is that Heaven takes people from this earth. Moreover, humans contain the intermingling of yin and yang qi, and must be born from the earth’s springs—hence they all take after the soil from which they arise. Therefore, the customs of the five directions differ, and the world’s minor variations never cease.

Thus, within each of the twelve thousand states, the people of one region do not resemble those of another. Do you understand this?
Indeed, indeed.

Those who are inherently good from birth are entrusted to their fathers, and good people are ultimately entrusted to Heaven. The finest essences of the myriad things ascend to form Heaven and become the Three Luminaries. Those of middling quality are entrusted to humans, enabling them to serve, follow the rhythms of yin and yang, and govern the myriad things. The lowest are entrusted to the earth, to walk upon it and perform their labors.

Do the Perfected Ones understand this?
Indeed, indeed. Excellent! Excellent!

Thus, when the heavens above now desire to harmonize wind and rain, nurture the myriad things, and delight in obtaining good people, I have been sent down to select and seek them. With this text I entrust the Perfected Ones, to be given to the conscientious people, that they may deliver it to the sovereign of the fire essence and the power of the Dao, and cause it to be shown to all under heaven, that they may together ponder my written words. Therefore, I entrust it to the Perfected Ones—take care not to sever its transmission. Should you fail in this, you will bring illness upon yourself; be ever vigilant in this matter.

Indeed, indeed.

Now, the foolish among the living suppose that the heavens above are boundless and upright, uniquely paired with this earth below?

Excellent is your question! Though the heavens move upward without bound, they too possess yin and yang, pairing as two. Is there also pairing below the earth?

Yes, the earth likewise moves downward without bound, and it too possesses yin and yang, pairing as two. Thus, one yin and one yang, above and below without end, extending laterally without limit. The Great Dao takes this as its nature; the heavenly law takes this as its constant. All use one yin and one yang as their throat and collar—this is the art of the Supreme Numinosity in its spontaneity. The governance of the boundless turns and returns to its beginning, without cessation or end.

I wish to distinguish one or two points for the Perfected Ones and expound the Dao. Will the Perfected Ones not understand?

Thus, I briefly raise its beginning for you, reveal its origin, and set forth its great principles. From these, you may reflect and bring forth its guiding threads, that the worthy and sagely of the world above and earth below may themselves find beauty in it. Do you understand?

Indeed, indeed. I wish to hear your instruction.

Very well. Carefully record my words in my teachings, and you may ascend and rest.

Indeed, indeed.

**Heaven’s Censure of Four Who Shame the Dao’s Admonitions, Scroll 208**

"What great abhorrence exists in the heavens above, called *Heaven’s Censure*? Perfected One, you have studied and practiced for so long—do you not deeply understand this as well?"

"Now, this foolish one falls short in so many ways. I wish to hear of it."

"Very well. From ancient times to the present, all who *arise* in the Dao take the August Heaven as their model. The most excellent appellation—crowning the unsurpassed, embracing the unbounded, inwardly without interior, emerging without gap, entering without aperture—serves as the teacher of all matters under heaven. It is the origin of life, the elder of all affairs, the enduring attainment of sages and worthies past and present. It is how emperors and kings win the heart of Heaven, becoming the parents who bring peace to the people, the source from which all transformations arise. Do you understand, Perfected One?"

"Indeed, indeed."

"The Dao is Heaven—pure and luminous, unwilling to be defiled or shamed. Yet now, those who study the Dao all engage in four ruinous deeds, jointly defiling the numinous Dao of August Heaven, throwing into chaos the principles of Earth, and thus can no longer serve as the head of transformation, as a model for teachers, or as parents. Together, they destroy Heaven’s precious vessel. Heaven names them all *great rebellious offspring*. *Cease!* You dwell upon the earth, yet do not conform to the model of teachers—how could Heaven, above, reverse itself and conform to your model? If you wish to know the truth of this: it is like a petty man living among the people, who does not conform to the model of teachers. When standing before the emperor, would he then conform to the model? If one remains below and does not conform to the model, yet Heaven above were to nurture him as a model—would this not be like Heaven and the emperor above treasuring and accumulating evil men? *Arise!* Thus, Heaven above deeply understands their deviation from the Dao’s intent and does not censure them out of mere hatred. Now, with the arrival of the Great Peace Qi of the Cavernous August Sovereign, it will no longer tolerate these four kinds of people. *Cease!* These four kinds of people cause both Heaven above and Earth below to despise those who practice the Dao, reversing their name to *evil offspring*. Therefore, the Dao of humanity daily declines and dissipates, decaying and never again rising. Now, the people of the world all engage in evil—this is precisely the ruin wrought by these four. Heaven above greatly abhors and censures them, and thus seeks to select anew. Do you understand, Perfected One?"

"This foolish one’s nature is dull and slow—I still do not comprehend. What does this mean? I wish to hear of it."

"If even you do not immediately understand, what can be hoped for from the common people? Very well. Open your ears and listen closely. I will explain in detail the great flaws and illnesses from which the Dao’s deviations arise, so that later learners under heaven may clearly know their loss of the Dao. *Arise!* The first is called *lack of filial piety*; the second, *not preserving one’s true nature*, leaving no posterity of their kind; the third, *eating feces and drinking urine*; the fourth, *acting as beggars*. Thus, these four kinds of people all jointly defile the true Dao of Heaven, utterly unfit to inspire transformation—*cease!*—and yet they have long served as models for teachers under Heaven above and Earth below. Even if they were to attain the Dao and ascend to Heaven, when Heaven examined them, they would be found entirely evil. Now, they cannot regulate wind and rain, bring forth the myriad creatures, or serve as teachers and elders."

"How lamentable! How lamentable!"

"Petty and ignorant, they remain utterly unaware of their offenses against Heaven. Now, only August Heaven and the enlightened masters—would that they might once more scrutinize with clarity, distinguish and resolve these matters, that I may humbly receive and further open my understanding."

"Proceed. Listen carefully, and I shall fully expound the meaning to the Perfected One, that it may serve as an eternal model for all generations. Let later learners, earnest and good, who practice the Dao, no longer violate Heaven’s prohibitions, so that when they attain the Dao and ascend to Heaven, Heaven above will rejoice in them. It is like an earthly king who, upon obtaining a virtuous person, governs together with them and likewise rejoices. Thus, what Heaven above promotes, the earth below mirrors—how excellent is this!"

"Indeed, indeed, your command is heard. The Daoist is Heaven’s teacher, the most precious treasure of Heaven. Those who practice it must conduct themselves as if Heaven itself had perfected them. The Daoist should ascend in conduct, for Heaven cherishes and employs such a one. Yet now, some who err and attain the Dao ascend to Heaven, only for Heaven to examine them and find instead conduct lacking in filial reverence. The Dao is the head of transformation, Heaven the model for humanity—how could it reverse its role to shelter and nurture the unfilial children of the world? If a child harbors such evil conduct, how could Heaven deem it fitting to grant this person long life and share governance with them? Would Heaven instead take such a rebellious one as its charge? Even on earth, such a person would not be employed—how then could Heaven employ them? Thus, not a single unfilial Daoist has ever ascended to Heaven. Though they depart, they are all deceived by wayward spirits and flattering demons, destined to dwell in death upon barren lands, in uninhabited wilds, where their forms are punished. Heaven’s response to humanity is like an echo to a sound—how could evil conduct yield good reward? Such a thing has been rare from ancient times to the present. Though many earthly kings have practiced the Dao, those who have transcended are few. Now, Heaven above has few virtuous people, none with whom to share governance, for their conduct is entirely wicked. Why then does Heaven not immediately slay them, but instead consigns them to barren lands, unpeopled wilds where the breath of life is cut off? The reason it does not immediately destroy them is that between Heaven and Earth, qi gathers in many places and is contained—thus it is called the harmonious mean. It is like human harmony, which encompasses all without exception. Thus, they are granted a brief respite. Heaven, which presides over clarity and brightness, is like one who stands before the sovereign—it cannot tolerate treacherous and evil people. Therefore, Heaven above does not govern together with such unworthy ones, and the earth below is the same. Heaven does not govern with the unfilial, just as a sage-king does not govern with the irreverent. Even a sage-king would not consent to govern with them—how then could Heaven alone do so? The sages of old, who refused to govern with them, deeply observed Heaven’s laws and modeled their conduct upon Heaven.

*Arise!* To govern with the foolish incurs Heaven’s great resentment. How is this known? When a ruler governs with them, Heaven manifests many disasters, strange omens, and frequent incursions by barbarians—this is clear proof of Heaven’s hatred. Is this not as precise as a compass and square, as binding as a contract? Now, if even humans, upon seeing others govern with them, detest and despise them, how could Heaven itself share governance with them? What humans hate, Heaven also hates. What humans cherish, Heaven also deeply cherishes. Thus, the sages of old, perceiving Heaven’s intent profoundly, always modeled their conduct upon Heaven, not daring to err even by a hair’s breadth. Therefore, they alone enjoyed Heaven’s favor and won its heart. Those who do not align with Heaven’s heart do not win its favor and meet with great misfortune. If human conduct is thus, how much more so for those who are to be Heaven’s chosen officers? Heaven’s chosen officers are to govern together with Heaven, administering the boundless arts, ever joining forces and harmonizing qi with a single heart. *Cease!* Perfected One, do you not understand? You must be vigilant—my words are the pure intent of Heaven’s heart and must not be violated. Those who violate them shall die. □□ indeed!"

"Excellent! Excellent!"

"Foolish beings grasp but a single good understanding in their hearts." "Even if you, sir, have attained this single good understanding, the common people do not comprehend—lost in darkness, they remain confused. Heaven detests this, and thus has sent me down to proclaim the great teaching and fully expound Heaven’s laws. From this point onward, learners must take heed and be vigilant!

Now, Heaven values the transmission of life through succession, so the four seasons receive Heaven’s Daoist instruction, passing life onward in an unending cycle to nurture all things. Thus, Heaven is called the Father of Generation, and Earth the Mother of Nurturance. Using the qi of the Six Jia, Twelve Branches, and Eight Trigrams as markers, they alternate in mutual generation and transformation, ensuring the Dao of Heaven endures without decay—this is the constant work of transformation and cultivation.

Those who study the Dao must model themselves purely upon Heaven’s laws. Yet many now act contrary to this, leaving no descendants and collectively severing Heaven’s lineage. Those who remain steadfast uphold Heaven’s nature, though their qi may be insufficient. The unfaithful, however, forcibly obstruct and block it, disrupting the Dao of yin and yang. When they sow their seed in the wilds, some abandon or kill their offspring, leaving their wives and children destitute—these are all people who greatly destroy and lose the Dao. They are utterly unworthy of emulation, being of the most inauspicious kind. How could they serve as teachers for humanity or stand as models for Heaven’s ordained masters?

Heaven, the Sovereign of All, is the elder of all affairs and the parent of humankind. All sages and worthies take it as their model—why then do some recklessly lose the Dao, becoming unfilial children without posterity, unfit to govern alongside it? If Heaven were to collaborate with such individuals, it would be called a master who shelters evil, promotes wicked arts, and abandons its sagely role as the teacher of humanity. Thus, it cannot but reject them.

The ancient sages and great worthies knew well to avoid such people, refusing to govern alongside those without descendants. To do so would be to lose Heaven’s favor. Therefore, Heaven causes the worthy and those with posterity to be honored, while despising those without heirs. The sages deeply understood Heaven’s intent and thus constantly modeled themselves upon it, never erring even by a hair’s breadth—how much more so for Heaven itself?

Now, for a long time, Heaven above has been devoid of good people, so it has sent me down to speak boldly and instruct those to come, that the foolish may all come to know. If Heaven were to employ such people, would it not become a gathering place for those without posterity? Acting in such a contrary manner, could one ascend to Heaven? Would Heaven then favor those without descendants and despise life?

Thus, they die in barren lands, lifeless soil, and uninhabited wilds, each returning to their own kind. You who do not cherish life oppose Heaven, so you are cast into lifeless places. You who favor desolation are sent to uninhabited wilds. The common people, blind and unseeing, claim they have transcended the world—yet in truth, they have not. I dare not deceive you, Perfected One. I have personally descended from Heaven’s realm, and whether you see or not is like showing the sun to the blind. If one tells them they are being deceived, they cover their mouths and laugh—such is the folly of the ignorant. Perfected One, be vigilant! What Heaven detests, those above detest as well."

"Excellent! Excellent indeed! This foolish student has never before witnessed such matters of Heaven—now truly, truly awakened at last."

"Strive diligently in virtuous conduct. My writings heal the ailments of Heaven and Earth, and relieve the sorrows and sufferings of emperors and kings. When your merits are complete, you will ascend to Heaven and witness these truths for yourself—then the great efficacy of my words shall be proven."

"Indeed, indeed. I dare not delay, nor dare I grow lax or negligent."

"Be vigilant and never grow lax or negligent. Should you truly falter in laxity or negligence, your great destiny shall be severed."

"This foolish student deeply reveres Heaven’s majesty and sincerely accepts and practices these teachings."

"Excellent! Excellent indeed! You have grasped Heaven’s intent.

Now, Heaven is pure and luminous; the Dao is clear and untainted. Heaven and the Dao dwell supreme above, serving as the model for humankind. Those who are pure and luminous favor purity and luminosity, thus the Three Luminaries ascend and adhere to Heaven, each following its kind, uniting as form and shadow. Heaven’s form is like a bright mirror, or like a person with two eyes that illuminate all—unwilling to behold defilement. Just as before a sage-king, one must always desire purity and luminosity—cease from beholding defilement, for to be defiled is to incur the transgression of annihilation and death. Perfected One, do you understand?"

"Indeed, indeed."

"Excellent indeed! Excellent indeed!"

"Thus, the human head and mouth resemble Heaven, unwilling to delight in beholding defilement, ever desiring freshness and clarity, desiring good things. Therefore, when the people of the world indulge in filth and defilement, offering such to others as food, Heaven sends down thunder and lightning to seize and take them away. Perfected One, do you understand that this is perverse and evil?"

"Indeed, indeed. I deeply fear it."

"From the Great Central High Antiquity to the present, people claim to be good, utterly distinct from common folk. Yet those who study the Dao often instruct one another to eat excrement and drink urine, calling themselves plain and good people—Heaven and the Dao deeply detest this. In Heaven, they are named the great rebellious offspring, and Heaven does not wish to see their human form. This is the work of great evil, the descent of dog and swine spirits.

Now, the Dao gives birth to Heaven, and Heaven possesses the Dao, which serves as the teacher and elder for all affairs. The upright Dao is that by which goodness is promoted and evil is eliminated. Thus, when ancient sage-kings and emperors were about to rise, they all received the Dao as their teacher, entering to receive its strategies and wisdom, transforming their people. The teacher was honored, and it was said that they could know the intent of Heaven’s heart, modeling their conduct after Heaven.

Heaven above also venerates and honors those of the good Dao, saying they can harmonize with the winds and qi, follow the four seasons, uphold the five phases, regulate wind and rain, assist the sun, moon, and stars in their luminosity, and cause the myriad things to flourish. How can those who eat excrement and drink urine serve as teachers? Even on earth, such teachers are unworthy of being called rebellious offspring—how could they ever become teachers in Heaven above? Such petty people are profoundly foolish, deeply mired in defilement that insults the Dao of Heaven. Perfected One, having received this ultimate text, ponder its meaning. What the earth below detests, Heaven above also detests; what Heaven above detests, the earth below likewise abhors."

Such earthly people who revile those who eat excrement and drink urine—Heaven above likewise reviles them, and thus dispatches thunder, lightning, and thunderbolts to descend and slay them. These words are merely meant to enlighten the people of the earth below. If Heaven’s revulsion is so severe that even those on earth abhor them, what use would Heaven have for them? Heaven is pure, luminous, and resplendent—how could it instead take them in as guests, gathering those who eat excrement and drink urine? Even if their transgressions were but momentary errors, and they attained the Dao in an instant, they would still be barred from ascending to Heaven. All shall perish in the five ruined lands of severed qi and ominous decay, thereby aligning with their conduct, manifesting their transgressions, and returning each to their rightful place—this is to ensure no deception remains.

Perfected One, when your years of virtuous completion draw near, take heed and be cautious, that you may instruct those who come after. When the Great Peace of the Supreme Sovereign descends with its harmonious qi, such vile conduct shall find no refuge—those who transgress shall surely die. How evident this is!

How solemn! How solemn!

Perfected One, do you understand? This is the awakening of the disciple. If you do not understand, you shall share in their guilt; if you know yet persist in such acts, your sins shall never be absolved.

“Yes, yes. I dare not, I dare not.”

Now, the nature of the Supreme Sovereign of Heaven is ever inclined to bestow and grant. Thus, it presides over giving, not receiving; over life, not death; over growth, not decay; over emergence, not containment; over triumph, not submission. To submit is to rebel, for the Dao of Heaven cannot be coerced or threatened—those who force or compel it shall perish.

Heaven presides over goodness, over clarity and brightness, and takes no delight in witnessing stagnation, defilement, or disgrace. Today, to be granted the Dao is to be granted the highest of honors. Thus, emperors and kings model their conduct upon Heaven, styling themselves as sovereigns without peer, daring not to deviate from Heaven’s Way. To act in accordance with it, even by the slightest measure, brings fortune; to stray from it invites great misfortune.

Now, those who study the Dao to attain longevity must wholly emulate Heaven. Heaven delights in life, so those who seek longevity must steadfastly guard the primal life-generating qi of Heaven, and their conduct must align with the intent of Heaven’s Dao. Earth, by contrast, presides over disgrace and destruction, over concealment—one must not follow Earth’s intent.

The Dao is the root of all transformation, the teacher and elder of all transformation. Thus, there is nothing under Heaven that does not arise by emulating it. Yet today, petty and foolish men who pursue the Dao bring no benefit to the people; instead, they collectively defile and disgrace the Dao of Heaven. Their rebellion is boundless, their formlessness extreme. In Heaven’s records, they are branded as rebellious sons, men of great misfortune—Heaven has no desire to behold them.

“What does this mean? My foolish mind is knotted and closed; I have not yet grasped it.”

"Excellent indeed is your question! Heaven has prompted your words—open wide your ears and eyes to listen.

Now, Heaven and the Dao do not favor deception, nor do they delight in killing or vainglory. Why then do you not divine with milfoil, prescribe remedies, and bring benefit to the people, allowing spirits to govern men so that illness may surely cease? These three kinds of men may all be called masters, yet they do not profit the Dao of Heaven, nor dare they defile and disgrace it.

The Dao of Heaven does not deceive; it ever demands utmost sincerity. If one deceives by means of the Dao of Heaven, in time, day by day, misfortune and decline will follow. The Dao of Heaven does not delight in defilement or disgrace, nor does it seek to benefit others. Heaven is supreme, and the Dao is yet more exalted. The Dao is the teacher and model of the Heavenly Thearch, loftier even than Heaven itself.

Thus, Heaven and the Dao preside over cultivation and rectitude, leading all affairs. They harmonize yin and yang, regulate wind and rain, order day and night, and array the ranks of all things. Between Heaven and Earth, none fail to receive grace and destiny, each attaining its proper place.

Yet today, the foolish who pursue the Dao instead engage in deceit, arrogance, folly, and madness. Together they confuse and disrupt the Dao of Heaven, ruining the foremost transformations of Heaven. They reverse course, begging and seeking alms from others, bringing no benefit to the people, defiling and disgracing the Dao of Heaven while inwardly profiting from the common folk. They cannot serve as models or teachers. Instead, they instruct later generations, each teaching the ‘Dao’ in ways that make people foolish, arrogant, deceitful, and mad, further engaging in defilement, disgrace, and begging. By such conduct, they are named the Dao of the foolish, mad beggars.

They cause all people to revile Heaven together, to despise the true Dao, and to sever the great transformations. Heaven deeply abhors them, and the Dao detests them; Heaven above does not wish to behold their forms.

Now, the Supreme Thearch of Heaven has sent forth the great rectifying qi in full measure. The sun, moon, and stars are arrayed in doubled radiance. The Dao and Heaven regulate wind and rain, harmonize yin and yang, and cause the myriad things to each attain their proper place. Those who formerly encountered the Dao and ascended to Heaven—none among them were fit for office. Heaven above questioned them and found all to be at fault; they could not be employed together. Yet you, dwelling upon the earth, are still called foolish, mad beggars.

How can those unfit to be teachers of emperors and kings be fit to be teachers of Heaven above? Heaven abhors them, and the great Dao declines and decays. The fault lies with the people of later ages who, in learning from one another, have lost the proper standards.

Heaven is afflicted by this, deeply grieved. The Dao of Heaven is obstructed, and so it has sent me down to speak with the Perfected Ones, to distinguish the gains and losses of the Dao. May the people of the world awaken as one, all understanding the intent of Heaven above. Let them reform their conduct, transform their hearts, and no longer violate Heaven’s prohibitions—then those who study will succeed.

If they persist in their former ways, Heaven will not raise them up. They will surely return to die in the land of the five disgraceful punishments, their lives consigned to the five defiled soils, cut off in the wilds of folly and madness where no one dwells—above, the three luminaries are absent; below, there is no good earth."

"Why is this so? I wish to hear it—how grave is their transgression?"

"“It does not condemn them outright. The Dao of Heaven is the law, and each follows its kind—this is the lower realm seizing them.”

“If so, why does it not kill them immediately, but instead brings them to this point?”

“If it wished to annihilate them at once, yet those people themselves claim they desire long life and hold fast to belief; if it were to kill them halfway, they would again wail to Heaven and weep upon the earth, calling themselves deeply wronged, unaware of how their transgressions arose. Thus, Heaven examines them and sends them forth, later casting them into the land of the five disgraceful punishments and mad folly, so they may come to know themselves.

If you wish to know the truth of this, it is like a wise king investigating a person’s faults and holding them accountable—not immediately putting them to death. Rather, according to the severity of their crime, they are sent to prison: great crimes to great prisons, lesser crimes to lesser prisons, where they are dealt with until the person submits, comes to know their guilt, and dies without resentment or complaint. If their words are not thoroughly examined, they will surely protest their innocence, die harboring grievance, and depart with hatred. Thus, the lords of the Five Hegemons—many of their subjects and ministers died with resentment in their hearts.

Do you now understand that the administration of punishment in Heaven is like this? Perfected One, do you comprehend?”

“How profound! How profound!”"

“Ah! Do you understand that alarm is the gateway to life, while unawareness of alarm is the root of death? Guard well my words—my words are the true weapons of Heaven, not to be defied or slighted. To defy them brings harm: slight defiance, slight harm; great defiance, annihilation. I caution you, Perfected One, with a single word: people of later ages accumulate folly, trusting their ignorant hearts, and say, ‘This cannot be,’ only to bring ruin upon themselves. I have personally traversed the ways of Heaven above and know their [unfailing] workings below—ten thousand times without a single error. I dare not deceive you; to deceive you would be to disrespect not the Perfected One, but the majesty of Heaven. Thus, my words are trustworthy and doubly so. The reason I speak repeatedly is to guard against those who might stubbornly err. Therefore, I reiterate, that my words may be rich in pattern and [clarity].

The affairs of Heaven are truly distant and difficult to know, so their patterns are frequently revealed below, aligning with earthly matters. When goodness arises on earth, goodness arises in Heaven. When evil arises on earth, evil arises in Heaven. Thus, when people do good on earth, Heaven responds in kind; when people do evil on earth, Heaven responds with evil—such is the ascent of qi. The five qi are interconnected, above and below as one; the six jia are linked, above and below as one; the twelve branches unite above and below, with no distance too far for their resonance. When below is good, above is bright; when below is evil, above is ominous. Thus, the five phases flourish below, and the five stars shine above. This is how Heaven enlightens the people of the world.

All three luminaries follow this principle. Heaven above and earth below share the same three luminaries: when the three luminaries shine below, so too in Heaven; when Heaven shines above, so too on earth. The two correspond in harmony, forming the warp of the Way. What is greatly good in Heaven is also greatly good on earth. Just as Heaven has the six jia and twelve branches, so too does earth; just as earth has the six jia and twelve branches, so too does Heaven. Thus, above and below constantly correspond, not deviating by even a fraction. Perfected One, be vigilant.

Though my words are profound, do not conceal them; share them with learners, but only after fasting and purification. Guard them well. Follow the text as law, and do not recite it carelessly.”

“Understood, understood.”

“Permit me to inquire: since the Highest Antiquity of the Middle Era, among those who have taught the Way under various guises, many have abandoned home and forsaken kin, cast off wives and children; many have feigned beggary, feigned madness and deception, eaten filth and drunk urine. Later learners, following their example, have all had masters and methods—yet none have acted without purpose.”

“Excellent! Your question cuts to the heart of their perverse intent. Does Heaven despise them, that you ask this? How cunningly phrased—why do you raise this?”

“I have long been troubled by it, yet lacked the opportunity to ask directly; my heart has ever been heavy with doubt.”

“Excellent! Has Heaven indeed appointed you to raise this matter? Very well. Open both ears, and I shall distinguish the truth for you.

When the Supreme Heaven first revealed the true Dao, it was not like this. All practiced filial devotion to parents, maintained posterity with wives and children, preserved proper form and bearing, neither feigned madness nor ate filth nor drank urine. All conducted themselves in accord with the Dao, their actions conforming to its laws. The highest adepts became teachers and counselors to emperors and kings, transmitting their kind and nurturing one another, without harm.
