The Dao is the head, virtue the belly, and benevolence the feet by which one walks. Heaven establishes official lodgings and post stations, and those who attain them may dwell therein. Those who seek the power of Heaven must practice the Dao; those who seek the power of Earth must practice virtue; those who seek the power of humanity must practice benevolence. These three are the inexhaustible Way. To lose them is the root of chaos; to disregard them is to rebel against Heaven. Thus, the sage embraces the Dao, practices virtue, and acts with benevolence. To go beyond this is to enter the realm of the myriad things.

May I ask: which spirits of the four seasons’ qi assist in governance, bringing forth goodness and eliminating evil? Which summon the great spirits? Which summon the middling spirits? Which summon the lesser spirits? Contemplating the imperial qi of the sun’s essence and the moon’s establishment summons the great spirits; contemplating the ministerial qi summons the middling spirits; contemplating the destructive qi summons the lesser spirits; contemplating the aged qi following the moon’s establishment summons old beings; contemplating the ailing and declining qi following the moon’s establishment summons malevolent ghosts; contemplating the dead qi following the moon’s establishment summons pure ghosts; contemplating the broken qi following the moon’s establishment summons ruin, slaughter, misfortune, and harm.

The generative qi belongs to Heaven, to yang, to what lies ahead. The Dao of Heaven generates through the qi of spirits, thus the six spirits before the Dipper are all generative. The six spirits behind belong to Earth, to yin. The Dao of Heaven takes dead qi as ghosts, as the misfortune and harm of beings. If you wish for later generations to remain ever cautious and ever faithful, to cherish and love themselves, so that the numinous spirits and essence-qi never depart from their bodies, they will neither know old age nor death.

The numinous spirits and essence-qi move with one’s intentions and never leave the body. If the numinous spirits remain constant, one does not fall ill or age, and one’s journeys do not encounter evil. If the numinous spirits depart, the sick die at once, and travelers meet with misfortune—this is the great proof. Those who wish to avoid illness should guard their essence with care.

In all things, do not exceed the natural. Within the natural, there is no essence-spirit. In all things, if one does not become spirit, one does not transcend the great Dao and the nature of Heaven and Earth. Without great essence-spirit at the center, nothing can be accomplished, nor can one preserve oneself. Thus, the Dao of Heaven and Earth relies on essence-spirit to act naturally. Therefore, in all things, great or small, there is essence-spirit: the great have great essence-spirit, the small have small essence-spirit. Each preserves and nurtures its own essence-spirit, and thus endures long.

When essence-spirit wanes, one ages; when essence-spirit perishes, one dies—this is the natural division. How can one forcibly contend against it? The safety or peril of all things lies in essence-spirit. Thus, the body is the home, qi the carriage and horse, and essence-spirit the magistrate. Prosperity and decline, coming and going, are governed by it. A body without essence-spirit is like a field, estate, or walled city without a magistrate. The magistrate is the arbiter of life for the people—this is the path for loyal ministers, filial children, and those who embody great compliance.

If one’s body is disloyal to superiors and unfilial to parents, it betrays itself, invites punishment, and loses its foundation. Constantly contemplating goodness, essence-spirit gathers and follows; contemplating evil, essence-spirit also gathers and follows. It enters the belly, moving with one’s thoughts, causing restlessness and obsession.

[Question:] The child in the womb does not eat but draws qi. Within the womb, it is the qi of the natural. After birth, it inhales and exhales the qi of yin and yang. By guarding the Dao and cultivating learning, one returns to the qi of the natural. Returning to the qi of the natural, the heart becomes like an infant’s—then one is born. Following the inhalation and exhalation of yin and yang qi, one dies.

[Note:] The *Scripture of Great Peace* states: May I ask why the child in the womb does not eat but draws qi? The Dao of Heaven possesses the qi of the natural and the qi of ebb and flow. While in the womb, the child receives qi—this is the qi of the natural Dao of Heaven. After birth, it breathes in and out the qi of yin and yang—this is the qi of ebb and flow. Those who guard the Dao and cultivate learning return to the qi of the natural and live; those who cling to the qi of ebb and flow die.

Thus, those who attain the true Dao can internalize qi and no longer rely on external qi. By using this internal qi to nurture their nature, they can return to infancy and restore their life. Therefore, one should practice internal qi to nourish the body within.

[Citation:] The *Three Caverns Pearl Satchel*, in the chapter "On Abstaining from Grain" from *Scroll Four*, quotes the *Scripture of Great Peace*, *Scroll 120*: "Thus, those who eat have a limited lifespan; those who do not eat consult with the spirits. Those who eat qi achieve clarity of spirit; those who neither drink nor eat complete their years with Heaven and Earth."

*Combined Collation of the Scripture of Great Peace*, *Scrolls 137–153*, *Ren Section* (undivided); *Excerpts from the Scripture of Great Peace*, *Ren Section*.

All people are incapable of restraining one another, and thus each shapes their own fate. Those who do evil will be punished by Heaven. Therefore, petty persons are punished by mediocre ones, mediocre ones by superior ones, and superior ones by the great. Even minor transgressions against the law lead to peril and ruin. The punishments of spirits and deities, great and small, follow the same principle. If one cannot restrain oneself, Heaven will surely punish them.

Heaven reveres the Dao, and the Dao reveres spontaneity. Heaven reveres the Dao because it embodies the utmost conduct. If the Dao is abandoned and not practiced, the Way of Heaven falls into chaos and ruin. When the Way of Heaven is in chaos and ruin, peril and destruction follow, and no laws or standards remain. Thus, spontaneity ensures that the Dao of Heaven and Earth is preserved. When the Dao is practiced without cease, yin and yang transmit and beget one another in succession. The Dao governs life; if the Dao is severed, the myriad things will not be born. If the myriad things are not born, there will be no generations, nothing to transmit. If the myriad things do not transmit and beget one another, all will perish. How then could Heaven and Earth endure? Heaven and Earth, yin and yang, must transmit and beget one another. If this ceases, they will perish. Thus, Heaven fears the severing of the Dao and the ensuing peril and ruin.

The Dao reveres spontaneity because without spontaneity, the Way of Heaven cannot be accomplished. Therefore, all things are accomplished only through spontaneity; without it, nothing can be truly achieved. Even if something is accomplished, it will be false and deceptive, and such accomplishments cannot endure. Though Heaven and Earth are vast and distant from one another, their governance of fate leaves no escape.

Someone asks: "When the qi of Great Peace arrives in full, and one wishes to constantly eliminate wickedness with good intentions, what should be prioritized?"

The answer: "The nature of Heaven and Earth is half yang and half yin. Yang is good and governs rewards and bestowals. Yin is evil; evil leads to punishments and penalties, governing deceit and falsehood. When rewards are many and punishments few, deceitful and cunning individuals proliferate, and the gates of wickedness open wide. The reason for this is that excessive punishments, which govern killing and harm, turn lawbreakers into wicked criminals, thus opening the gates of wickedness and increasing deceit.

Yang governs rewards and bestowals. When bestowals are abundant, virtue and power prevail. Yang and virtue govern nurturing and life—this is the law of spontaneity. Thus, day is yang, the sun, the ruler, and virtue; night is yin, the moon, the minister, and deceit. The nature of Heaven and Earth is half good and half evil. Therefore, the noble person, being supremely good, suppresses wickedness. Those who promote good receive good; those who promote evil receive evil. This is like using a *dou* to measure against another *dou*—what is not a *dou* naturally falls away; using a *chi* to measure against another *chi*—what is not a *chi* naturally drops off. It is like the square and the round, which do not align; the compass and the carpenter’s square, which do not meet; the vertical and the horizontal, which do not coincide. Thus, when yang arises, it moves in accord with its kind.

When fire blazes, thunder roars, and the Vermilion Bird appears within. This is why thunder occurs in summer and hides in winter. All things follow their roots—only thus can the Way of Heaven be understood. Without following their kind, how could the sage and the worthy deeply comprehend it? Therefore, since the opening of Heaven and Earth, the goodness, evil, truth, and falsehood of people can be observed through their actions. By seeking their kind, one can foretell their success or failure, their gains and losses, and discern the worthy from the unworthy. Why engage in futile disputes?"

Someone asks: "From ancient times to the present, the worthy, the enlightened, the wise, the eloquent, the strong, and the brave—these six types of people all possess talents a myriad times greater than others. How could they be anything but good?"

The answer: "These six types of people indeed possess talents a myriad times greater than others. If their talents harmonize with Heaven and Earth, preventing the rise of all evil and harmful influences, enabling the emperor to live long without worry, and allowing themselves to dispel illness and live out their natural years, their benevolence flowing to all people—then the worthy, enlightened, wise, eloquent, strong, and brave are truly good and beneficial.

Yet if they cannot harmonize with Heaven and Earth, if the emperor remains burdened with worries and does not live long, if they themselves suffer from illness, cannot dispel disasters, or die prematurely, no different from ordinary people—then these six types of people are of no benefit. One need only examine their accomplishments. Those who succeed are right; those who do not are wrong. If their actions align with this principle, they deeply accord with the will of August Heaven. The emperor’s years and fate are extended, and the myriad things are all well-governed."

Someone asks: "Among all things, some fail to be born at the proper time, while others are not nurtured. If they are not raised to maturity, where do their great faults originate?"

The answer: "When things that should be born are not born, it is the fault of Heaven. When things that should be nurtured are not nurtured, it is the fault of Earth. Heaven and Earth are the dwelling place of the myriad things, and the worthy are the artisans of the myriad things. The emperor, who embodies Heaven, constantly desires to give life. The empress, who embodies Earth, constantly desires to nurture. The great ministers, who embody humanity, constantly desire to bring things to completion. When these three work in unison, all things, from birth to their end, remain unharmed. To emulate the Way of equilibrium, those who establish laws must act accordingly."

"May I ask: Does the Way of Heaven assist the weak? The strong? The few? Or the many?" The divine being replied: "The Way of Heaven assists the weak."

"Why is this so?"
"The weak is the function of the Dao; the few is the essence of the Dao. Thus, the North Star stands alone, yet all stars align with it—through the few it governs the many. The essence of the Dao is singular, and the Dao follows it. For this reason, the king is exceedingly few, yet all under Heaven aid him in governance—this is the efficacy of assisting the few. Parents are exceedingly strong, yet they aid the infant—this is the efficacy of the strong assisting the weak. The supremely good are few and weak, while the unvirtuous are strong and numerous; yet the many are but few, and the strong are but weak. Therefore, the noble person seeks weakness, not strength; seeks the few, not the many. Thus, the Way of Heaven protects them. They do not contend with others, yet others contend of their own accord; they do not contend for strength, yet others aid them in becoming strong. Thus, without contending, they excel in victory."

Distinguish between the Way of Heaven’s refinement of the body and the unsevered bond of virtue.

"May I ask: 'When the Dao is properly aligned with joy and desire in action, what is its clear efficacy?'"

The divine being replied: "I received this text from the celestial deities, who declared: 'We have heard that it corresponds with yin and yang, wind and rain, cold and heat—this is its great efficacy. Heaven delights in the Dao’s enactment, yet people do not clearly believe in it, so we manifest efficacy by granting or withholding rain. When the Dao of Great Peace is practiced, all prayers are answered; when the Dao of Great Peace is not practiced, prayers go unanswered. This makes clear that the supreme Dao resides in Great Peace.

Thus, when the myriad things fail to be born, the fault lies in the Great Yang; when they are born but not nurtured, the fault lies in the Great Yin; when they are nurtured but not brought to completion, the fault lies in the harmony of the center. Therefore, that which gives birth is the father; that which nurtures is the mother; that which brings to completion is the child. That which gives birth is the Dao; that which nurtures is virtue; that which brings to completion is benevolence.

If a single thing fails to be born, one Dao is obstructed and impassable; if a single thing is not nurtured, one virtue is left uncultivated; if one virtue is not brought to completion, one act of benevolence is not enacted. To know for oneself whether one possesses the Dao, virtue, and benevolence, observe the things of the world—this will make it self-evident.

These five principles are what emperors, kings, lords, fathers, and teachers must deeply understand to assess the excellence or inferiority of the Dao, virtue, and benevolence. Simply observe this: the foremost good is to delight in giving life; the next good is to delight in nurturing; the next is to delight in bestowing. Thus, that which gives life resembles Heaven; that which nurtures resembles Earth; that which bestows resembles benevolence. These three are the great guiding principles of Heaven, Earth, and humanity. Anything beyond this is merely a last resort for times of exhaustion.

When this is so, the qi of Heaven naturally attains peace, perverse qi naturally vanishes, good people naturally arrive, and evil people naturally depart—all respond without fail. The one who clarifies this is the teacher, for the teacher is the title of the one who knows first and should take evidence as their guide to make it clear.

From ancient times to the present, all texts have issued from Heaven and Earth; thus, Heaven and Earth produce them first. The one who clarifies them is the teacher; thus, all texts emerge with a teacher, and the one who enacts them is the ruler. In antiquity, emperors and kings received the Mandate of Heaven, followed the teachings of their teachers, and diligently practiced them to eliminate disasters and calamities, thereby aligning with the will of Heaven and attaining longevity and extended life—this is what it means.

The creator is Heaven; the clarifier is the teacher; the enactor is the emperor or king. These three matters depend on one another to be fulfilled. If Heaven did not produce texts, teachers would have no way to know; if teachers did not clarify texts, emperors and kings would have no way to know how to govern. Thus, when Heaven intends to raise up an emperor or king, it must first produce extraordinary texts. Enlightened teachers then instruct the emperor, king, and officials, enabling them to attain longevity and extended life—this is the clear proof of Heaven’s protection of the emperor or king."

"When the people and the myriad things fail to be born, are born but not nurtured, are nurtured but do not grow, grow but do not reach completion, or do not fulfill their natural lifespan—where does the fault lie?"

"When the people and the myriad things fail to be born, the fault lies with Heaven; when they are born but not nurtured, the fault lies with Earth; when they grow but do not reach completion, the fault lies with humanity."

"Does the fault lie with humanity?"

"When the myriad things fail to be born in due season, the fault lies with the ruler; when they are born but not nurtured, the fault lies with the ministers; when they grow but do not reach completion, the fault lies with the people. Heaven and the ruler-father preside over birth—this is the dominion of the Great Yang, the origin of life. If Heaven does not desire life, things cannot be born; if the father does not desire to bestow, things also cannot be born; if the ruler does not desire life, things also cannot be born. Thus, Heaven and the ruler-father preside over birth.

The ruler-father who constantly contemplates life and does not delight in killing ensures that all things flourish. A single thought of killing results in the death of one thing; ten thoughts of killing result in the death of ten things; a hundred thoughts of killing result in the death of a hundred things—extending to ten thousand thoughts, it is always thus."

"Does the Earth-mother and her ministers, who receive the bestowal of Yang, preside over the nurturing of the myriad things—do they constantly contemplate nurturing?"

"A single thought of failing to nurture harms one thing; ten thoughts harm ten things; a hundred thoughts harm a hundred things—extending to ten thousand, it is always thus. Therefore, the emperors and kings of high antiquity appointed ministers who sought compassion and benevolence, delighting in nurturing the myriad things and governing accordingly. In middle antiquity, they were half compassionate and benevolent, so half of the things were harmed. In later antiquity, they did not carefully select and appoint ministers, so all things were harmed.

The virtue of the August Thearch and the king shines brilliantly. The Thearch acts as wisdom between Heaven and Earth, preventing them from falling into misfortune and calamity—hence the title 'Thearch.' The king is one to whom the people and the myriad things turn without harm—hence the title 'king' (wang), meaning 'to go toward.' The lord ensures that each remains within their proper bounds, and people turn to them without harm—hence the title 'lord' (jun), meaning 'to summon.' The official (li) governs, assisting their superiors in managing things so that all people and things, great and small, do not lose their proper governance—only then is the title 'official' fitting. The teacher (shi) fully comprehends the words of the world and is thus worthy of the title 'great teacher,' for they can interpret all the texts of Heaven and Earth. Thus, they are called 'August Thearch, King, Lord, and Teacher.'

Therefore, the Way of the August One is the head; the Way of the Thearch is the torso; the Way of the king is the thighs; the officials are the hands and feet. The Way of the teacher is the carpenter’s line and ink, the standard and rule, upon which high and low depend to stand. Thus, the good governor constantly contemplates the Way of the August One, secondarily contemplates the Way of the Thearch, and lastly contemplates the Ways of the lord and officials. By constantly reciting the laws of the great teacher, they uphold the carpenter’s line, and only then can the will of Heaven be at peace, the intent of Earth be attained, the four seasons proceed in order, the five phases not contend, the three luminaries remain bright, ghosts, spirits, and refined qi cause no harm, the five officials and five soils each attain their proper place, bandits and thieves do not arise, and the emperor or king governs with ease, all proclaiming 'ten thousand years.'

The Dao of Heaven is the law—without my texts, it is truly difficult! Carefully ponder their meaning and practice these two matters—there are also warnings here!"

The nature of Heaven and Earth is such that refined qi, ghosts, and spirits govern the learning and teaching of humanity. Spirits reside in the yin of the human heart; refined essence resides in the yin of the kidneys; ghosts reside in the yin of the liver.

When a person’s thoughts are upright and good, they teach others to do good; dwelling constantly in the hidden yin of humanity, they incline others toward evil and instruct them in evil, thus also inclining them toward evil. In ancient times, the worthy and the sages harbored hidden thoughts of goodness within, and so received good responses. Ordinary people harbor hidden thoughts of evil within, and so receive evil responses, unable to restrain themselves. The fault lies in the constant hidden thoughts of good and evil—ghosts and spirits accordingly incline toward good or evil, and the presence of ghosts here may be verified.

When the qi of Great Peace prevails, wind and rain come in their seasons, the myriad things grow abundantly, and the earth is well-fertilized, becoming daily more robust and rich, thus enabling long life. In inauspicious years, rain does not come in due time, the myriad things on earth grow sparse and few, short and stunted, unable to fertilize themselves, so the earth becomes daily poorer and barren, incapable of nurturing the myriad things. The movements of Heaven and Earth still require the harmonious union of yin and yang to achieve Great Peace and bring about the officials of the four seasons and five phases.

The monthly establishment of the emperor or king corresponds to the qi of the emperor or king, which expels the officials of evil and wickedness. The qi of establishment and the qi of kingship are the imperial qi of Heaven’s four seasons and five phases. The qi of ministerial influence and removal come before—one is to rectify what lies ahead, the officials who point directly like the tips of hair. What they face are crouching villains, who can no longer act to cause harm. The qi of removal, fulfillment, and pacification are all good and upright officials. The five who hold positions ahead reside in the forefront, preparing the qi of the emperor or king to grasp and expel great evil. The five generals of establishment and the forefront all receive the upright qi of Heaven, all being divine officials of Heaven, who serve as Heaven’s envoys. Without exception, the myriad things of the twelve thousand categories all don the virtue of these officials and follow their transformations.

When the qi of kingship should die, when the monthly establishment should be broken, this is the most revered and majestic qi, and thus it cannot be withstood. When it should die, it is called the great consuming qi of killing. What follows the monthly establishment is closure, which seals off evil and villainy, fearing that the subsequent qi of rest and submission might encroach upon the establishment qi of the emperor or king. Thus Heaven closes what follows, and when it opens again, it drives away the qi of rest and evil. What follows becomes the completion of villainy, and thus it should be reined in. The five that follow are perilous, for their position is near the great executioner of Heaven’s grasp, and with one turn of breaking, they strike—hence the peril. These five generals of the rear are those whom Heaven wishes to rest, aligning with Earth’s qi to preside over the closure and concealment of villainy and evil, where ghosts and spirits dwell together, and thus they must not be employed.

Someone asked: “The north is the beginning of the August One, the east is the beginning of the emperor, the south is the beginning of the king, and the west is the beginning of the hegemon. Now Heaven has the six jia and twelve branches—where should the August Way begin?”

“Indeed, Heaven has three systems, each with great boundlessness. The first is the Heavenly August One, the second is the emperor, the third is the king, and the fourth is the hegemon. The Heavenly August One begins with the first jiazi, the Earthly August One with yichou, the Human August One with bingyin, and the Hegemonic Way with dingmao—these are the reckonings of Heaven’s qi and destiny. As for the Earthly reckoning, the August Way begins with zi, the imperial way with chou, the kingly way with yin, and the hegemonic way with mao. These four all initially receive the subtle qi of Heaven and Earth to bring forth life and must not incur punishment. Those that incur punishment harm the August Way, for the Dao and its laws must not be harmed. Thus, zi punishes mao, chou punishes xu, and yin punishes si—all emanate punitive qi and cannot coexist.”

Someone asked: “Heaven bestows ranks upon people according to degree, Earth bestows ranks upon people according to degree, and people bestow ranks upon people according to degree—may I hear of this?”

“Heaven bestows upon people through the Dao, Earth bestows upon people through nurturing virtue, and people bestow upon people through emoluments and sustenance.”

“Why is this?”

“Heaven, by means of the Dao, is distinct and enduring, thus it bestows the Dao to grant longevity, enabling one to be sated by the qi of wind. Earth presides over nurturing good land. Earth makes people prosperous, thus it bestows upon people virtue and wealth. The ruler bestows upon people emoluments and sustenance, granting them clothing. These three matters are all good. Those who love the Dao without ceasing are thus bestowed by Heaven. Those who love virtue and cherish the earth, knowing how to select and dwell in land, avoiding misfortune and obtaining good fortune, are bestowed by Earth. Those who study diligently and benefit the governance of their superiors cannot be distanced by the ruler or father, for they must be employed in governance—thus they are bestowed by people. In ancient times, the sages and worthies exerted themselves in study and dared not lose these three matters. Thus, some obtained the Dao and departed, some avoided the world and returned to the earth, and some obtained the emoluments and sustenance of the ruler.”

Someone asked: “As for the five tones of music, what is it like to attain their proper sound? What is it like not to attain their proper sound? May I hear of both?”

“The tones are not empty—they are a method to summon true matters, to bring forth the real through the void, to call forth the embodied from the formless. Music, through its sounds, summons events. It is like a person opening their mouth to utter a sound—some are good, some are evil. The good bring forth good fortune, the evil bring forth misfortune. These words all emerge from the mouth, thus summoning responses of good and evil. The proper sounds of music are the language of Heaven and Earth’s yin and yang and five phases. By listening to their tones, one knows the sentiments of Heaven and Earth, the harmony of the qi of the four seasons and five phases—there is no end to what may be known. Thus, the superior person attains their meaning to govern and measure with balance; the middling person employs them to assist the ruler in governance and attain longevity; the worthy person employs them to attain freedom from care. Tones, through one, ride upon the myriad things, and the myriad things ride upon the boundless—all under Heaven is complete.”

Someone asked: “What is the significance of the *Scripture of Great Peace* having one hundred seventy scrolls?”

“The number one is the beginning of all reckoning. Thus, when Heaven and Earth were not yet divided, accumulated qi formed a single unity. Divided into two, they became husband and wife. Heaven descended upon Earth, conceiving in the profound darkness, and was named jiazi.”

“Roots spread to the northeast, where *chou* marks the beginning of *yin*; appearing in the east, the sun rises at *mao*. Life flourishes in the southeast, where *chen* extends to *si* with branches drooping toward the south, nurtured at *wu*. Turning old in the southwest, it is *wei* leading to *shen*; maturing in the west, the sun sets at *you*. All is stored in the northwest, between *xu* and *hai*. Thus, reckoning begins with one and ends at twelve. The root of the *Ganzhi* stems from the five phases. Therefore, one completes ten, and a hundred makes it complete. Thus, Heaven generates things: in spring, the resonance of a hundred days nears its end. Therefore, the celestial Dipper establishes *chen* and breaks at *xu*. *Jian* means to stand—all things fully arise at *chen*. *Po* means to decay—all things fully perish at *xu*. Thus, reckoning follows Heaven and descends to Earth, encompassing the eight directions, and is complete at ten. Yin and yang establish and break, cycling with seven, returning to their origin. Following the Dipper’s pointer clarifies affairs, for the Dipper has seven stars to illuminate the beginning and end of yin and yang. Thus, the *Scripture of Great Peace* in one hundred seventy scrolls models the numbers of Heaven and Earth, aligns with yin and yang as its method, and follows the four seasons and five phases in its practice, not daring to lose even a fraction. To lose it is to abandon Heaven’s affairs, to have no ground, to fail Heaven and Earth’s intent, to disregard celestial reckoning in making scripture—useless for governing the world, unable to model Heaven and Earth’s laws, and powerless to remove harm. To know its efficacy: gather the world’s scattered texts, amass them for thirty *li*, and even if they reach Heaven, they cannot dispel disasters. Beneath the great Heaven, within eighty-one regions and eleven thousand states, each has its own texts, all seeking to eliminate evil and bring goodness, to dispel disasters. Now, if all were collected and assembled in a hundred-*li* square, piled to Heaven’s height, they still could not dispel disasters. Though this text is few, if the emperor and kings practice it, they will surely await its clear efficacy.

In high antiquity, the first were the divine persons, the second the perfected persons, the third the immortals, and the fourth the Daoists—all modeled Heaven to grasp the true meaning of the Dao. Dazzling the eyes with inward vision, they ordered within with the heart, turning yin’s brightness to penetrate the great yang, inwardly attaining the Dao’s essentials alone. Like fire making light shine within but not without, they preserved constancy without confusion. Those who now study transcendence model the ancients in turning inward—this is what it means. Over time, transmission begets decline, and daily they grow weary of their practice, losing the Dao’s meaning, unable to illuminate within, and daily governance worsens. Thus, Heaven sends forth sages, modeling celestial patterns to order the world, for celestial patterns are self-evident. When celestial patterns are correct, Heaven is correct; when earthly patterns are correct, Earth is correct; when human patterns are correct, humans are correct. When Heaven, Earth, and humans are all correct, the myriad things are all correct. Humans are the foremost of the myriad things. If humans lose their proper role and suffer harm, dying before their time, the myriad things follow, and Heaven and Earth do likewise. Pernicious qi surges, and people fall ill, not living out their Heaven-appointed years. Only the practices of past and present each have their proper sequence, not transgressing one another.”

The Most Revered Divine Beings of the Supreme August One, who name themselves the Lords of Entrusted Qi, also called the Great Spirits, ever abide at the left side of the Celestial Sovereign. They preside over the compilation of the texts of the Hall of Luminous Patterns, ensuring distinctions are made and great duties are meticulously discharged. Their role is to enable rulers to commune with the immortals, recording the names of those yet unborn, each with their designated years, months, days, and hours. When the time for ascension arrives, spirits are dispatched to transform their bodies under the guidance of masters, allowing them to ascend. Each bears a name, with years, months, days, and hours assigned; when the appointed time for ascension comes, spirits are sent to transform their bodies under the masters’ guidance, enabling their ascent.

According to their wisdom and capacity, each is assigned roles without forgetfulness, with clear distinctions so all may know their own abilities. Only then are they entrusted with duties. Upon submission, it is declared: “The Great Spirits, as overseers of the celestial host, each govern their own domains. They must serve with clarity, leaving no room for doubt. Let their lifespans be long and their records precise; this must be carefully observed. Those of sagely illumination and intent should be granted all that lives beneath the sun.”

Again, through ledgers, tallies, and calculations, their accounts are made clear, to be kept in the Bureau of Accounts, which oversees the quantities of treasure and valuables. All those who must submit accounts must first notify the Bureau of Accounts, and together with its officials, they shall present them to the Minister of Agriculture. On the thirtieth day of long months and the twenty-ninth of short months, they shall assemble before the Great Spirits of the Hall of Luminous Patterns, never missing the appointed time, as commanded by the Celestial Sovereign. None may fail to arrive within the first three *ke* of dawn. The Great Spirits of the Hall of Luminous Patterns shall submit their reports at the fifth *ke*, following the Celestial Sovereign’s established decrees.

The Great Spirits, receiving the Sovereign’s mandate, instruct the Minister of Agriculture, who in turn commands the subordinate prefectures and kingdoms. They report on the domains they oversee, submitting ledgers of all goods delivered to the Minister of Agriculture. Should any be remiss in timely submission, the Minister shall report to the Great Spirits of the Hall of Luminous Patterns, who will inform the Celestial Sovereign. A decree shall then be issued to the Minister, ordering the prefectures and kingdoms to hasten compliance, ensuring no delay beyond the prescribed deadline. Time, days, and *ke* are assigned with distinctions, allowing no disorder; all must follow a unified system, with duplicate records kept. In Heaven, there are no disasters of flood or drought, and no alterations may be made to the records. When the Wheel of Fate turns, no delays or pretexts are permitted, lest one be suspected of embezzlement. Those who become aware must report it; Heaven is ever watchful, and offenses are never pardoned. Let each be vigilant in their duties and clear in their affairs.

The Celestial Sovereign foreknows all yet does not speak aloud; one must carefully consider what is asked, for such words are not to be used. Floods and droughts are without constancy, disasters and calamities arise together, people fall ill and die in countless numbers—all due to the failure to follow the Celestial Sovereign’s decrees. When the Celestial Sovereign issues commands to the Great Spirits, the high ministers, officials of the two-thousand-bushel rank, and all divine functionaries must devote themselves to loyalty and action, striving to fulfill the Celestial Sovereign’s will.

The Celestial Sovereign, together with the masters of transformation, shall verify those worthy of ascension and rectification. Each shall attain the radiance of spirit, their brilliance corresponding to their rank and the spirits they have transformed, all arranged in proper order with their respective offices and subordinates. The Celestial Sovereign commands the Great Spirits to perpetually refine and perfect them. Let each measure their own capacity, their aspirations growing daily, yearning for ascension. As they transform, their luminous essence becomes visible at midday, their true spirits penetrating and clear, drifting and roaming beyond the eight bounds. They observe Heaven’s works, discerning its movements, each following what is fitting.

Audiences with Heaven occur on fixed days. At the establishment of the new moon, the Great and Lesser Spirits arrange themselves in order, their ranks determined by precedence. Court assemblies with high ministers do not extend beyond the morning audience. Each spirit clarifies their domain, conducting inspections without fixed schedule, ensuring the clarity of documents and holding accountable those with duties. They must first address their tasks in accordance with the Celestial Sovereign’s decrees. Should they have matters to report, they must open the Hall of Luminous Patterns to speak. Each must demonstrate their clarity and bear their responsibilities, never lacking in merit.

The Celestial Sovereign commands the Great Spirits to assemble the host of officials, each rectifying their demeanor, ensuring no transgressions. They are to be assessed by law and examine their domains. Heaven is ever aware, and their faults will not be absolved. Let each be vigilant in their duties, lest they be found wanting by the spirits.

The Celestial Sovereign further commands the Great Spirits: “Within the prefectures and kingdoms, those of sagely wisdom and aspiration, who constantly yearn for the arts of longevity and wish to walk the path of the divine with Heaven, desiring to bestow kindness upon others, contemplating generation and transformation, aiding Heaven in governing life and Earth in nurturing form—let them aspire to benevolent transformation. Their names shall be submitted to the Great Spirits, with records kept in the bureaus, their merits frequently reported, and their trustworthiness verified. The bureaus shall present their intentions; the Celestial Sovereign shall determine their number, and the spirits who recommend them shall vouch for them. In selecting from the prefectures and kingdoms, only the most excellent shall be chosen.”

The Celestial Sovereign commands the Hall of Luminous Patterns: “All who serve the Celestial Sovereign in governing the myriad duties must cultivate impartiality. Each shall act in accordance with their celestial domains, ensuring proper division of labor. Let all be utterly loyal and sincere, communicating what they know, striving to accomplish their tasks and govern their affairs. Let their reputations be steadfast and far-reaching; they should advance their thoughts, and where their voices reach, though their intentions may be unspoken, the Celestial Sovereign already hears their words. How can any concealment or lack of loyalty exist?”

Someone asked: “Now, wishing to further clarify the laws of sagely and benevolent worthies and utterly eradicate heterodox texts, how can this be made even clearer?”

The reply: “Heaven is afflicted by these false and deceptive texts and commands their removal, to adopt the luminous Dao of Heaven. The texts of the sages of past and present are what govern Heaven and Earth. When the texts of the sages are clear, the Dao of Heaven is greatly ordered. What the August Heaven detests and finds displeasing gives rise to warfare, unending floods and droughts, and ceaseless disasters. Kings are distressed, all saying that the texts of the sages have gradually fallen into disorder and obscurity, hence the Dao of Heaven is clouded and difficult to govern. When the texts of the sages are disordered, the Dao of Heaven is likewise disordered; when the texts of the sages are abandoned and unused, the Dao of Heaven is likewise abandoned and unused.”

The question: “In ancient times, there were no texts, yet the Dao of Heaven was not disordered. At that time, the celestial decrees had not yet emerged. The Supreme Sovereign and divine beings governed the ancestral spirits, originally sharing the same body as August Heaven. Over time, they drifted far from the Dao of Heaven, descending into chaos and turmoil, no longer understanding the will of Heaven. Thus, Heaven issued the decrees, commanding the sages to record and transmit them. Yet the sages did not remain long in the world, so they inscribed and deposited them to bequeath to later generations. When the qi of Great Peace arrives, the Dao of Heaven will be properly ordered.”

The question: “Now, if one wishes to govern the affairs of qi and attain longevity, may I hear of this?”

The reply: “Indeed. Attend carefully to my words. August Heaven has its constant laws. For those who rule as lords above, they must emulate Heaven in their conduct, employing the Dao, virtue, and benevolence as the three guiding principles. If the lord above delights in desirelessness and tranquility, he should contemplate the Dao in the morning, virtue at midday, and benevolence in the evening—thus, no affairs will trouble him.”

The question: “I wish to hear why one contemplates the Dao in the morning, virtue at midday, and benevolence in the evening.”

The reply: “Indeed. The Dao of Heaven may be followed but not opposed. Those who follow Heaven prosper; those who oppose it perish.”

The question: “Now, I wish to hear the essential meaning of this.”

The reply: “Indeed. Heaven has four seasons and three divisions. Morning governs generation, midday governs nurturance, and evening governs bestowal. Thus, the southeast generates, the southwest nurtures, and the northwest bestows. Therefore, humans emulate Heaven in their conduct: in the southeast, they plant and generate; in the southwest, they nurture and cultivate; from mid-autumn onward, within the summer domain, they dwell, marry, and propagate their kind—this is the natural teaching of August Heaven. Thus, the people silently follow it. Those who can constantly emulate this align with the will of Heaven; those who cannot are said to oppose Heaven’s teachings and thus suffer many harms. Minor harm injures the spring’s beings, harm to the robust injures the summer’s beings, harm to the elderly injures the autumn’s beings, and harm to the pregnant injures the winter’s beings—this is the natural law. The sage-kings of old constantly reflected on the Dao of Heaven in their actions, never daring to deviate even slightly.”

"Someone asked, 'Is it possible to hear how one may attain enduring abundance from the earth?'

The answer: 'Those who constantly follow what Heaven does will long share in Heaven’s abundance; those who lightly oppose it will long incur Heaven’s resentment. Thus, the governance of the ancient sage-kings consisted of three principles: first, constant generation; second, constant nurturance; third, constant bestowal. Acting in this manner, they carefully upheld the Dao of Heaven, avoiding the reputation of disorder. Fourth is punishment without order, and fifth is killing—these are the extremes. By this distinction, the first-rank ruler purely generates, the second-rank purely nurtures, the third-rank purely bestows, the fourth-rank purely punishes, and the fifth-rank purely kills. The generating ruler extends years and prospers the state; the nurturing ruler increases longevity; the bestowing ruler commits no transgressions; the punishing ruler invites illness; the killing ruler meets with violent ruin.

The ancient sage-kings observed Heaven’s clear prohibitions and dared not act recklessly. On days when the six *jia* cyclical signs governed the kingly *qi* and subtle influences, they neither raged nor spoke of ill matters. On such days, they spoke only of good things, feasted, and made music to avert disasters and dispel inauspicious *qi*. Thus, the kingly *qi* was always shown reverence. Therefore, the people of the ancient era who measured their lives by this, and the governance of the sage-kings who followed it, could lie down in peace and reflection, completing their days without a single disturbance. In spring, they slept with heads to the east; in summer, to the south; in autumn, to the west; in winter, to the north; and during the four seasons, toward their respective corners.

When rulers, ministers, and people all knew this method, the world’s perverse *qi* was entirely dispelled. According to the celestial model, on kingly days, weapons were taken from the armories and buried in the earth. On days of rest and cessation, they were returned, so banditry did not arise, and warfare ceased.'

Someone asked, 'Does Heaven alone grow angry and fail to respond in harmony with humans—can this be known?'

The answer: 'Indeed, Heaven’s principle uses *qi* as its language, manifesting in the four seasons. If the *qi* of the *jue* (wood) angle is unrecognized, the liver’s pulse does not move, the *jue* and *cu* (cluster) notes are disharmonious, and the clear tones do not resonate, this is Heaven’s displeasure and silence. The ancient sage-kings, upon seeing this, would reflect on the principles of gain and loss to correct it. Where the kingly *qi* resides, benevolence aids its governance. These two *qi* together generate and complete things there. When the *qi* of rest, cessation, and misfortune reverses and arrives to assist governance, this becomes the third *qi*. The *qi* of petty people appears in this way, lacking alignment with Heaven’s position, thus resembling petty people.

When Heaven observes and sees its kind, it commands the worthy and sagely to devise strategies and reflect, seeking reclusive Daoists, virtuous people, and benevolent people to reverse and restore its *qi*, establishing correspondence. Thus, the king who governs the Dao of Heaven uses the people and ministers as his limbs; if his governance is poor, he disorders the Dao. The ancient sages, when governing the Dao of Heaven, sought those of Dao, virtue, benevolence, and wisdom to govern together, thereby dwelling in peace. Thus, the Daoist belongs to Heaven, the virtuous person to Earth, and the benevolent person to the center of harmony. If the three norms are disharmonious, the three worthies govern them. When the *qi* of Great Peace arrives, all things are ordered.'"

"Someone asked, 'How can all the people become fully benevolent?'

The reply: 'The Dao of Heaven gives birth to virtue, and virtue gives birth to benevolence. Now, if the ruler takes a Daoist as his teacher and models himself on the Dao, then his ministers will embody virtue. The people, in turn, model themselves on the ministers; if the ministers are virtuous, the people become benevolent. Commands flow downward, imitating those above, and those above model themselves on Heaven. Thus, in mutual generation, how could the people fail to become fully benevolent? The ancient sage-kings took great Daoists as their teachers precisely to transform those below. The highest ruler governs like Heaven, the middling ruler like Earth, and the lowest ruler like man. To govern like Heaven is to never lose Heaven’s intent, serving the Great Dao as a father. To govern like Earth is to never lose Earth’s intent, serving Earth’s Dao as a mother. To govern like man is to never lose human intent, seeking joy in attaining the Dao of central harmony.

The sage, seeing all things born, knows their principle reveres the Dao; seeing all things nurtured, knows their true virtue; seeing all things completed, knows their true benevolence. Those who order the true Dao have only the mind of generation; those who order true virtue have only the mind of nurturance; those who order benevolence have only the mind of bestowal. Without these three norms—Dao, virtue, and benevolence—one cannot be called a ruler of Great Peace.

The celestial scholar is born of Heaven, receiving its entrusted *qi* in formless generation. How could one who knows the celestial scholar fail to know, fail to understand, fail to see? They are the primordial *qi*, sharing office and acting in unison. The celestial scholar dwells always in the Palace of the Boundless, managing documents in harmony with Heaven. Above and below, none lose their duty, thus knowing what may be born; descending into earthly forms, they enable completion, and all things receive glory. The celestial scholar is revered by Heaven, looked up to by all spirits—like the crown prince of the Emperor, who would dare show disrespect?

The Heavenly Lord is entrusted with *qi*, hence named the Heavenly Lord, supreme without peer. What command or teaching of his would not be obeyed?'

Someone asked, 'When the ruler of Great Peace’s Dao flourishes, his virtue is next to Heaven’s. If he obtains the scripture and practices it alone, his transformative influence will flow throughout the world, and there will be nothing not at peace. The greatest spirits are none other than Heaven and Earth; the greatest luminaries are none other than the sun and moon—yet even they, each contributing half their power, together complete the whole. Heaven and Earth each exert half their strength, uniting in heart and desire to harmonize, and thus bring forth the myriad things. Day and night each contribute half their power to complete a single day. Spring, summer, autumn, and winter each exert half their strength to complete a year. The moon begins to wax in the west, grows toward the east, and by the fifteenth day is called yang; after the fifteenth, it wanes and is called yin. Each contributes half its power to complete a month. Man and woman each contribute half their strength, uniting in shared purpose to complete a household. The Dao of Heaven and Earth is one yin and one yang, each contributing half their power to become one, and only then do they together complete the whole. Thus, when ruler and minister unite in heart and strength, each contributing half their power, thinking alike in their modest efforts, they achieve the governance of Great Peace.'

Someone asked, 'Though the writings of people today are many, and they claim all things are complete, disasters, harms, bandits, and thieves are ever in excess. They are constantly beset by sorrow and suffering, and on inauspicious days, officials and people join to rescue them, yet cannot. What has been cut off revives again. Now, I can long supplement their deficiencies and ensure no further calamities. Since the emergence of the Heavenly Contract, among all the writings of sages and worthies, are there any that are the same? All differ. Thus, when Heaven commands a master to emerge, to eliminate inauspicious virtue, shelter the people and ministers, and extend radiance to the four directions, distant and near respond in echo, and grace reaches even the grasses and trees. This is the opening of their intent, and their writings all differ.'

Someone asked, 'The essential Dao of past and present all speaks of guarding the One, which can ensure long life without aging. To know how to guard the One is called the Dao of the Boundless. A person has one body, which should always unite with essence and spirit. The form is the master of death; essence and spirit are the masters of life. Constant union brings good fortune; separation brings misfortune. Without essence and spirit, there is death; with them, there is life. Constant union is called the One, which can ensure long life. The constant fear is that essence and spirit will scatter, not gathering within the body but instead following human thoughts to wander. Thus, the sage teaches guarding the One, meaning one should guard one’s body. If thoughts do not cease, essence and spirit will naturally come, and nothing will fail to respond; the hundred illnesses will be eliminated, and this is the tally of long life and enduring vision.

The yang guards the One; the yin guards the Two, hence called "killing." Thus, in daylight, which is yang, the human soul constantly dwells united; in darkness, which is yin, soul and spirit contend in action as dreams, thoughts lose their form, and they divide into two, leading to death. Essence and spirit are entirely lost, and only the form remains. Guarding the One is truly uniting the real as one. The essence and spirit of human life are all fully possessed; if one guards them without scattering, one can transcend the world, become a good parent to the people, meet the ruler of Great Peace, and be beloved by spirits and numina.'

The *Three Caverns Pearl Satchel*, Scroll Four, *On Abstaining from Grain*, citing the *Classic of Great Peace* 145, asks, 'How do those of the upper, middle, and lower ranks who attain the Dao and transcend the world sustain themselves?'

The reply: 'The highest first rank eats wind and *qi*; the second rank eats medicinal flavors; the third rank eats sparingly, just enough to keep the intestines and stomach clear. It also says: "Heaven is distant and boundless; without eating wind and *qi*, how could one move swiftly and circulate through Heaven’s Dao? One must also communicate merit with the spirit officials, forming a fellowship, hence eating wind and *qi*. The next rank should join forces with Earth’s essence, harmonizing the five soils, traversing high and low mountains and rivers, entering water along the mountains, communicating with Earth in turn, sharing merit in eating—thus, they cannot eat grain and instead drink water as they travel."'"

The next stage of Dao attainment is through regulated fasting, though the form remains unconsolidated—this merely distinguishes the practitioner from ordinary people. Thus, eating sparingly to clear the intestines also characterizes those who achieve the Dao.

*Tai ping jing* Collated Edition, Scrolls 154–170, *Gui* Section (unbound)
*Tai ping jing chao*, *Gui* Section

〈Beginning〉
1. *Shen dao shu* (Book of the Divine Dao)
2. *He shi wen* (Text of Verified Matters)
3. *Qu fu hua ji* (Record of Discarding Ornamentation)
〈End〉
Collectively termed *Da shun zhi dao* (The Dao of Great Compliance).

*Tai* means great; great means Heaven. Heaven covers and nurtures the myriad things—its merit is supreme. *Ping* means Earth; Earth is level, yet it nourishes the myriad things. *Jing* means constancy. Heaven takes the sun, moon, and five planets as its warp; Earth takes its mountains, rivers, peaks, and streams as its warp. When Heaven and Earth lose their constant Dao, the myriad things all suffer calamity. The emperor and king model themselves above on August Heaven, below on Empress Earth, and in the center on the warp and weft of stars, mountains, and rivers, nurturing the myriad things. Thus, it is called *Da shun zhi dao* (The Dao of Great Compliance).

Divine persons, perfected persons, sages, and worthies each determine for themselves whether a method is right or wrong. In ancient times, divine persons discerned right and wrong, success and failure—their affairs were immediately observable. Not only were they not obscure, but they were luminously clear. The divine Dao is most abundant; when one cultivates and habituates the spirits of the body, rectifies the heart-mind, nothing remains hidden. Good emerges, evil is suppressed, and one knows the methods of fortune and misfortune as if gazing into a mirror. At such times, the worthy and enlightened find peace; opportunities do not return, and things do not respond twice. Thus, one attains singular flourishing, harmonizing distant regions, and affairs manifest as they should. When responses appear, take care not to resist or oppose; gather them as treasured vessels—this may be called attaining the heart-mind of Heaven and Earth. The time is ripe, affairs are in order, the divine Dao arrives, the worthy deliberate, the auspicious come, the perverse do not approach, clarity and brightness appear, the four directions rejoice, recluses and hidden scholars emerge, the heart of Heaven is attained, the arts of governance are obtained, perversity does not arise, natural penetration is achieved, perfected persons come to assist, the world responds with goodness, each comes with their proper affairs, and confusion and disorder depart.

This response arises from the abdomen, issues from the heart-mind, and is as swift in verification as thunder and lightning.

〈Beginning〉
Now, auspicious responses arise from within the breast, following thoughts as they come and go. In an instant, they circulate throughout the world. The heart’s desires move August Heaven; yin and yang shift in response. Sincere speech moves Heaven—this is the principle.
〈End〉

[Appendix]
*Dao dian lun*, Scroll 4, *Miao rui pian* (Chapter on Wondrous Auspices), citing the *Tai ping jing*:
When the ruler acts with goodness within, wind and rain arrive on time without—thus, auspicious responses arise from within the human breast. Therefore, whatever one desires to do is met with auspicious responses; how could they not come? Sincerity alone moves August Heaven; yin and yang shift in response—who goes forth to move them?

The body and form cannot go forth to move them. That which moves lies hidden within the heart-mind; sincerity moves Heaven.

Thoughts can bring forth rectitude or perversity—all arise from the will. They can move Heaven and Earth, harmonize yin and yang, unite the myriad things, enter to refine the body, and emerge to establish a name. Worthiness and unworthiness all arise from this. Thus, the worthy govern with skill, losing nothing in ten thousand cases.

When there is fault within the abdomen, why does the face flush red?
The heart is the ruler of the five viscera; the ruler is the sovereign. The sovereign upholds rectitude and reports faults to Heaven.

When startled, why does the face turn green?
The liver governs the person; the person is care. Reversing the liver and gallbladder induces anger, hence the color rises as green.

All spirits have their governing principles, responding to the myriad things. Thus, one must always be cautious and good, complying with Heaven and Earth, so that calamities cannot arise again.

External learning is abundant, internal learning scarce; external affairs flourish daily, while internal affairs decline. Thus, people are often ill, and ornamentation proliferates. *Fu* means surface; *hua* means branch. The Dao of Heaven is distant, entering the midst of perversity—one cannot return on their own.

〈Beginning〉
*Shen dao shu* (Book of the Divine Dao): Concentrating essence without deviation, firmly guarding the root, uniting with yin and yang, and aligning with the divine luminaries.
*He shi wen* (Text of Verified Matters): Examining and verifying differences, doubts, and errors without fail.
*Qu fu hua ji* (Record of Discarding Ornamentation): Having strayed far from the root, dwelling in the wild, its texts are disordered and cannot be used regularly—only occasionally recorded.
〈End〉

Those who guard the root govern as if divine; those who guard the center are slightly disordered and troubled; those who guard the branch are benighted. Thus, the worthy guard the root and caution against the center, never daring to follow the branch. If one can guard this without ceasing, goodness will come from all directions. Without resistance or opposition, gather it as a treasured vessel—it will not change for ten thousand generations.

Can human effort in self-cultivation be obstructed? Can perverse and deviant barbarians be repelled? Can weapons and warfare cease? Can staffs and ropes fall silent? Can the four directions be at peace? Can roads be open? Can the ruler be enlightened?

Divine Strategy:
When great persons guard it, the four directions move; when middling scholars practice it, their ministers and subjects become good; when petty persons practice it, they do not harm one another. Its words are concise, its methods clear—how can one not act upon this divine text? If one cannot uphold it, take care not to harm or restrain with cunning.

Methods to Defend Against and Repel Inauspiciousness:
Follow the four seasons and five phases, rectify thoughts within and without, disperse perversity from the body, and repel inauspiciousness. Contemplate and guard the celestial patterns, act in accord with the qi of the four seasons, harmonize yin and yang, and govern ghosts and spirits with a net of administration, preventing them from wantonly harming people.

After the Beginning of Winter until the Beginning of Spring, vigorously employ the qi of Great Yin, and subtly employ the qi of Lesser Yang. Constantly observe one’s intentions: which illnesses are caused by spirits and officials? Their divine officials wear black garments. Contemplate this in seclusion for forty-five days, up to ninety days, and it will make one’s ears and eyes keen.

At the Beginning of Spring, the supreme virtue resides in benevolence, and the qi governs Lesser Yang. The royal qi shifts to the east, activating the Wood phase. Its qi is weak yet benevolent, and its divine officials wear blue-green garments. Contemplate this in seclusion for forty-five days, up to ninety days, and it will dissolve illness. By continuously practicing this without cease, one will daily embody benevolence and love.

Before the Spring Equinox, vigorously employ the qi of Lesser Yang and subtly employ the qi of Greater Yang to assist Lesser Yang. Observe one’s intentions without doubt, deeply contemplate them, and the hundred perversities will submit.

On the day of the Beginning of Summer, the supreme virtue is Fire, and the royal qi shifts to the south. The qi of Greater Yang governs with centered harmony. When its divine officials are employed with proper intent, sweetness arises in the mouth, and the red-clad divine officials guard it, driving the hundred ghosts a thousand miles away.

On the Summer Solstice, the supreme virtue is the qi of Greater Yang, the qi of centered harmony. Contemplating its divine officials can cure the hundred illnesses.

In the sixth month of late summer, the supreme virtue governs in harmony, and the royal qi shifts to the southwest, returning to the central palace. Its divine officials wear yellow garments; contemplating them makes sweetness arise in the mouth. Each season’s end should be contemplated for eighteen days.

On the day of the Beginning of Autumn, the supreme virtue resides in Metal. The royal qi shifts to the west, severing and completing the myriad things. Its divine officials wear white garments. Contemplate them for forty-five to ninety days to dispel illness. When one grasps their intent, the bones strengthen and old age brings longevity.

On the Autumn Equinox, the qi of Lesser Yin prevails, subtly employing the qi of Greater Yin. Reverse illnesses by aligning with it.

On the day of the Beginning of Winter, the supreme virtue resides in Water, and the royal qi shifts to the north. Its divine officials wear black garments. It sharpens the will and sharpens the ears. Guarding it for forty-five to ninety days dispels the hundred illnesses.

These are the qi of the five phases and four seasons. Internally, they govern the body; externally, they govern perversity. Thus, Heaven employs them for clarity, Earth for tranquility; Heaven employs them for generation, Earth for storage. Humans employ them for flourishing. Those who align with the seasonal qi are called loyal ministers and filial children. This is the great Dao of harmonizing Heaven and Earth, yin and yang, the four seasons, and the five phases. Thus, the Dao emerges for the benevolent and worthy, not for the foolish.

**Method for Preserving Life and Repelling Disasters**
At ten years, the spirit endures for twenty years.
At twenty years, the spirit endures for forty years.
At thirty years, the spirit endures for sixty years.
At forty years, the spirit endures for eighty years.
At fifty years, the spirit endures for a hundred years.
At sixty years, the spirit endures for a hundred and twenty years.
At seventy years, the spirit endures for a hundred years.
From eighty to a hundred and twenty, the spirit is exhausted.

In youth, the spirit flourishes; in old age, the spirit wanes. This refers to the essence-spirit of the five viscera, the internal signs. One thousand two hundred and twenty good spirits serve as its envoys, advancing and retreating to observe and await, while ten thousand spirits act as its people, all following the rise and fall of the person. This is the constant principle of Heaven and Earth. If one treats the spirit as a city and skillfully governs it, calming the body and preserving the spirit, illness will not afflict them, and their years will be long. The numinous will protect them.

Thus, Heaven and Earth establish the body with stillness, guard it with the spirit, and enliven it with the Dao. Therefore, if one can remain pure and still, embrace the essence-spirit, and not lose their thoughts and considerations, then inauspicious perversities cannot enter. The true spirit resides within, making one perpetually joyful, content, and disinclined toward greed for wealth and treasure, litigation, or competition for fame and merit. Over time, one will naturally perceive the spirit. The spirit is two feet and five inches tall, and its attire follows the five phases and five viscera.

When the ruler is benevolent, the Dao flourishes; when the ruler is gentle, virtue arises. If the heart harbors even a slight perverse intent, distant regions will fall into chaos. The spirit-qi circulates swifter than thunder and lightning. Swiftly return to the numinous brightness to illuminate the self within, and illness will naturally heal while the person governs themselves.

Thus, the upper limit of human longevity is a hundred and twenty years, the middle is eighty, and the lower is sixty. Beyond this is premature death, for the spirit wanders outside while illness attacks within. Contemplating the root and rectifying conduct makes people cherish one another. The ancients who sought longevity did not lose the Dao.

Heaven and Earth have constant movements; one cannot depart from the root. Therefore, those who seek peace and long life must not forget this foundational Dao. Thus, illustrations are drawn to instruct later generations. They depict the time when people receive life and destiny, from ancient times to the present, without losing the transmission of yin and yang or the succession of types. They generate one another and endure for myriad generations without end.

In decline and flourishing, high and low are balanced. When flourishing, one becomes a ruler; when declining, one becomes a commoner. When flourishing, one attains the Dao; when declining, one suffers punishment.

Of filial piety, nothing is greater than preserving one’s form, for it is the continuation of one’s ancestors. To propagate one’s name to later generations is called a good person who carefully guides the people. Heaven and Earth cherish them, the five phases aid them, the four seasons benefit them, the hundred kings employ them, the myriad people love them, ghosts and spirits protect them, and the spirits of the five viscera abide with them. To encounter this once is to gain life, yet now it is being lost. To depart from this numinous vessel is to return to ashes and dust, to transform without constancy, and to become the myriad things again.

**Method for Distinguishing Forms and Dissolving Perversity to Purify the Body**
The Dao’s generation of humans is fundamentally essence-qi, and all possess spirit. The temporary form is called a person, but fools do not know how to return and preserve their spirit-qi, thus losing the Dao. Those who can return and restore their spirit-qi will complete their natural lifespan, or even double it, for they are of superior talent.

For those seeking to transcend calamity, the method is as follows: Construct a fasting chamber, secure its doors and windows so that no one may enter recklessly. Go there daily to practice; if not refined or at ease, leave again and do not force it. Repeat this until gradually refined and at ease. Once at ease, one will no longer wish to leave, nor speak, nor see food and drink, nor hear human voices.

Accumulate goodness through focused refinement. Close the eyes and inwardly observe the form and appearance, as if residing in a mirror or gazing at the reflection in clear water—this is a minor accomplishment. Without whips or rods, there is strictness; without weapons or staffs, there is authority. All affairs govern themselves.

Is this not wondrous? It is called the path of entering the numinous.

To guard three is not as good as guarding two; to guard two is not as good as guarding one. Ponder this deeply, and the profound mysteries of the Dao are attained.

**Methods for Communing with the Numinous and Transcending Worldly Calamities**
Heaven endows humans with all things complete. Thus, after ten months of gestation, they are born and share the same beginning and end as all things. Therefore, one may transcend calamities and attain great peace.

The superior scholar studies the Dao to assist the emperor and king, ever accumulating merit to ensure enduring longevity. The middling scholar studies the Dao to deliver their household. The inferior scholar studies the Dao merely to free their own body.

The Dao emerges for the wise and enlightened, not for the foolish. Those who can employ it attain fortune; those who cannot—would it not bring harm or ruin?

**The Self-Knowing Methods of the Worthy and the Unworthy**
The superior scholar, of lofty worthiness, is revered in all matters, great and small. The middling scholar is half-revered, while the inferior scholar is not revered at all.

The reason the superior scholar is revered lies in turning inward to the self, not seeking from others. With an open heart and unobstructed intent, they know the root of primordial qi and the natural order. They honor Heaven and Earth, the sun and moon, the arrayed stars, the Five Phases and Four Seasons, the Six Jia and yin-yang, and all creatures that creep and move—none of these exist in vain. Within the six directions, spirits, demons, and spectral beings, as well as the inner and outer workings of wind, clouds, thunder, and lightning, do not act without purpose. All possess their own numinous powers and rulers, much like humans have their own signs. Thus, they are revered, and none dare act recklessly.

The middling scholar, half-reverent, does not fully grasp the arts of primordial qi and the natural order but only perceives the wind, rain, clouds, and living things. They sometimes claim Heaven has no spirits and do not revere the arrayed stars, sun, or moon, knowing only the Great Fire and the Northern Dipper. The inferior scholar, however, does not comprehend the vastness of mountains and rivers, knowing only how to till the fields, cultivate what they possess, and manage their household and kin. They do not understand how to align with the Four Seasons and Five Phases but merely follow the seasons to plant and harvest for profit. They do not recognize the Six Jia and yin-yang as spiritual forces, dismissing them as nonexistent.

Through diligent study, the foolish become worthy; the worthy, if they do not cease, become sages; the sages, if they persist, become perfected in the Dao; those perfected in the Dao, if they continue, become immortals; the immortals, if they advance further, become true beings; and the true beings, if they do not stop, become divine. All this is achieved through unceasing accumulation of study.

**Methods for Prolonging Life and Honoring the Superior**
First, prolonging life. The barbarians submit to myriad methods, their kinds differing, yet all attain long life. Heaven and Earth cherish them, and their bodies remain free of fault. The reason lies in what is called the path of great compliance. When the Dao is perfected throughout one’s life, one shares the same realm as Heaven and Earth. Those who practiced this in ancient times attained the favor of the myriad spirits. To witness its efficacy, auspicious signs naturally arrive, and misfortunes naturally recede. When emperors and kings govern by it, they need not exert force, and the barbarians submit of their own accord. Practicing it without cease, one becomes a perfected person.

Thus, the teachings of the sages do not require coercion or force to succeed but are established according to natural disposition. The reason emperors and kings can pacify the world is by aligning with the hearts of the people, thereby winning their allegiance.

This Dao was cultivated in ancient texts. When humans are born, they are called *shen* (spirit). They share with Heaven and Earth the division of authority, form, spirit, essence, qi, affairs, karma, and dwelling—thus forming three realms. One qi becomes Heaven, one qi becomes Earth, and one qi becomes humanity; the remaining qi disperses to complete the myriad things. Therefore, Heaven is honored, Earth is revered, and humanity is valued.

Thus, the Three Sovereigns and Five Emperors all established teachers, and those with doubts knelt to inquire. Therefore, the state remained ordered, and even calamities could be healed.

**The King’s Path to Freedom from Worry**
The path of great compliance ensures that the king has no worries or troubles and attains great peace. If Heaven and Earth do not greatly convulse, if wind and rain do not rage, if the hundred spirits remain in their abodes, then the world is free of disaster. When all things dwell in their proper places, joy and freedom from worry follow.

How is this achieved? Benevolence ensures the emperor and king are ever joyful, and the Dao ensures they are free from sorrow. If the emperor and king are sorrowful, the world is not at peace.

The emperor and king are the heart of the world; the ministers are the limbs; the common people are the hands and feet. When the heart is sorrowful, the limbs act recklessly, the hands and feet move without rest, and the people drift and scatter. This is their natural mutual influence, and Heaven operates likewise. When Heaven loses the Dao, the clouds and qi become chaotic; when Earth loses the Dao, it cannot contain. The king is in communion with Heaven.

The son delights in his father, the minister delights in his ruler, Earth delights in Heaven, and Heaven delights in the Dao. Thus, the qi of great peace may be attained. When Heaven’s qi is once again ordered, the Supreme August One brings peace below. When Heaven and Earth harmonize, the emperor and king practice our Dao—what fault could there be?

The Dao is the heart of Heaven, the head of Heaven. Once the heart and head act, how could the limbs and body not follow?

**Methods for Returning the Spirit and Dispelling Malevolence**
Distinguish the strengths of the three qi and return the spirit to guard the body.

The qi of Great Yang is Heaven, hence called *shen* (spirit). Form is governed by Great Yin, which nurtures the myriad things, hence the spirit and essence are stored in the abdomen, and Earth’s spirit is called *qi* (earth spirit). Essence is the harmonious essence of the myriad things, thus it advances and retreats without constancy. The essence of Heaven and Earth, yin and yang, together generate the myriad things—this is the sequence of the Three Powers.

Spirit governs life, essence governs nurturance, and form governs completion. These three together constitute the vessel of the spirit. They correspond to ruler, minister, and people, and thus cannot be without one another.

When the heart’s spirit stirs, causing the form to become unsettled, preserve it without ceasing. If it is beneficial to remain at peace, it stays; if not, it departs. Initially, employ what is beneficial, teach it to abide in peace, and over time, it will naturally remain without leaving.

Yin qi and yang qi alternately grind and polish one another, thereby generating. Human qi likewise circulates throughout the body, and spirit and essence ride it in their comings and goings.

The spirit and essence depend on qi as fish depend on water—when qi is cut off, spirit and essence scatter; when water is cut off, fish perish. Thus, the Dao of nurturing life begins with calming the body and cultivating qi, avoiding frequent anger or joy. In ancient times, enlightened masters taught emperors and kings to calm their bodies, freeing them from worry, so that they might govern with undivided focus.

When Heaven delights, the qi of great peace emerges, and nothing fails to be born and completed. When Heaven resents, the qi of punishment and harm arises, and none escape injury—all things suffer its poison, thus sharing the same sorrow.

If Heaven does not guard its spirit, the Three Luminaries dim; if Earth does not guard its spirit, mountains and rivers collapse; if humans do not guard their spirit, the body perishes; if the myriad things do not guard their spirit, they wither and decay. Therefore, returning to it is called strength; failing to return and merely preserving oneself is called dissolution and demise.

**The Method of Harmonizing Yin and Yang**
From Heaven comes Earth,
from the sun comes the moon,
from yin comes yang,
from spring comes autumn,
from summer comes winter,
from day comes night,
from left comes right,
from exterior comes interior,
from white comes black,
from brightness comes darkness,
from hardness comes softness,
from male comes female,
from front comes back,
from above comes below,
from ruler comes minister,
from *jia* comes *yi*,
from *zi* comes *chou*,
from five comes six,
from trees come grasses,
from female comes male,
from rooster comes hen,
from mountains come hills.
This is the root and handle of the Dao,
the pivot of yin and yang,
the supreme intent of the numinous spirit.

**The Method for Longevity, Governance, and Great Peace**

The arising of the three qi as one is the root of spirit. One is essence, one is spirit, and one is qi. These three share a single position, fundamentally the qi of Heaven, Earth, and humanity. Spirit is received from Heaven, essence from Earth, and qi from harmony. Together, they form a single Dao. Thus, spirit rides qi to move, while essence resides within. The three assist one another in governance. Therefore, those who desire longevity must cherish qi, revere spirit, and value essence.

To rectify great matters, one must do so through non-action. For non-action begets non-action—this is the constant law of Heaven and Earth, the art of spontaneity, swift as an echo or shadow. The superior person employs it to pacify the state, the middling person to prolong life, and the inferior person to govern the household. This may be called "achieving without acting" and "ordering without governing." The great Dao is smooth and broad, not far from the self. By cherishing one’s own body, governance naturally returns.

**The Seven Methods for Resolving Delusion**

How does governing the self through virtue fare, and how does it govern the myriad people to bring about the qi of great harmony? Though good, if not understood, how can there be peace?

How does governing the self through benevolence and righteousness fare, and how does it govern the myriad people? Though good, if not understood, how can there be peace?

How does governing the self through ritual fare, and how does it govern the myriad people? Though good, if not understood, how can there be peace?
